G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: As the letter A is the first of all letters, so the eternal God is first in the world.
Transliteration:
Akara Mudhala Ezhuththellaam Aadhi
Pakavan Mudhatre Ulaku
T.Kannan: A is the first of the alphabet; God is the primary force of the world.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A' leads letters; the Ancient Lord 
Leads and lords the entire world.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A, as its first of letters, every speech maintains;
The 'Primal Deity' is First through all the world's domains
Ramachandra Dikshitar: All the letters have the letter ‘A’ as their Origin; this world has God as its origin.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: “A” is the first and source of all the letters. Even so is God Primordial the first and source of all the world.
Various Translators:
With alpha begins all alphabets;
And the world with the first Bagavan.
Dinamalar:
With alpha begins all alphabets; And the
world with the first Bagavan.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: What Profit have those derived from learning, who worship not the good feet of Him who is possessed of pure knowledge ?
Transliteration:
Of what avail is learning if one worships
not The holy feet of Pure Intelligence?
T.Kannan:
Katradhanaal Aaya Payanenkol Vaalarivan
Natraal Thozhaaar Enin
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: What is the use of all your learning, if you can’t surrender yourself at the feet of God.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
That lore is vain which does not fall 
At His good feet who knoweth all.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Of what avail is learning, if the learned do not adore the good feet of Him who is Immaculate Wisdom?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
No Fruit have men of all their studied lore,
Save they the 'Purely Wise One's' feet adore.
Various Translators: What has learning profited a man, if it has not led him to worship the Good Feet of Him who is pure knowledge itself?
Dinamalar:
Of what avail is learning if one worships not
The holy feet of Pure Intelligence?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Long life on earth is theirs who reach The
glorious feet of Him who walked on flowers.
Transliteration: Those who find refuge in the great feet (of Him) who lives in the lotus of the heart (of the devotee) live eternally in heaven.
T.Kannan:
Malarmisai Ekinaan Maanati Serndhaar
Nilamisai Neetuvaazh Vaar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who surrender themselves at feet of the one, who resides in the flower-like hearts of all, will live long and well.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Long they live on earth who gain 
The feet of God in florid brain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
His Feet, 'who o'er the full blown flower hath past,' who gain
In bliss long time shall dwell above this earthly plain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The Supreme dwells within the lotus of the heart. Those who reach His Splendid Feet dwell enduringly within unearthly realms.
Various Translators:
Long life on earth is theirs who reach
The glorious feet of Him who walked on flowers.
Dinamalar: They who are united to the glorious feet of Him who passes swiftly over the flower of the mind, shall flourish long above all worlds.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who have attained the feet of Him who has no likes or dislikes will be rid of all troubles.
Transliteration:
No evil will befall those who reach the
feet Of the One beyond likes and dislikes.
T.Kannan:
Ventudhal Ventaamai Ilaanati
Serndhaarkku Yaantum Itumpai Ila
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who surrender at the feet of the one, who doesn’t have wants or hates, will never have any hassles anywhere.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who hold His feet who likes nor loathes
Are free from woes of human births.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
His foot, 'Whom want affects not, irks not grief', who gain
Shall not, through every time, of any woes complain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Draw near the Feet of Him who is free of desire and aversion, and live forever free of suffering.
Various Translators:
No evil will befall those who reach the feet
Of the One beyond likes and dislikes.
Dinamalar: To those who meditate the feet of Him who is void of desire or aversion, evil shall never come.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Actions, both good and bad that spring from darkness of the mind will never touch those who ever chant the glories of the Lord.
Transliteration:
The twin deeds of dark illusion do not
affect those Who delight meaningfully in Lord's
praise.
T.Kannan:
Irulser Iruvinaiyum Seraa Iraivan
Porulser Pukazhpurindhaar Maattu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Fate, which impacts those in the darkness of ignorance, will not impede those who hail the true glory of God.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
God's praise who tell, are free from right 
And wrong, the twins of dreaming night.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The men, 'who on the ''King's' true praised delight to dwell,
Affects not them the fruit of deeds done ill or well.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Good and bad, delusion’s dual deeds, do not cling to those who delight in praising the Immutable, Worshipful One.
Various Translators: The two-fold deeds that spring from darkness shall not adhere to those who delight in the true praise of God.
Dinamalar:
The twin deeds of dark illusion do not affect those
Who delight meaningfully in Lord's praise.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who still the five senses and walk in truth and right will ever live.
Transliteration:
Long life is theirs who tread the path of
Him Who conquered the five senses.
T.Kannan:
Porivaayil Aindhaviththaan Poidheer
Ozhukka Nerinindraar Neetuvaazh Vaar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who follow the true moral path of the one, who has doused the desires of the five senses, will last long.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
They prosper long who walk His way 
Who has the senses signed away.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Long live they blest, who've stood in path from falsehood freed;
His, ‘Who quenched lusts that from the sense gates five proceed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A long and joyous life rewards those who remain firmly on the faultless path of Him who controls the five senses.
Various Translators: Those shall long proposer who abide in the faultless way of Him who has destroyed the five desires of the senses.
Dinamalar:
Long life is theirs who tread the path of Him
Who conquered the five senses.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
They alone escape from sorrows who take refuge
In the feet of Him beyond compare.
Transliteration:
They alone escape from sorrows who take
refuge In the feet of Him beyond compare.
T.Kannan:
Thanakkuvamai Illaadhaan Thaalserndhaark
Kallaal
Manakkavalai Maatral Aridhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Except for those who surrender at the feet of the one, for whom, there is no simile, it is tough to cure the mental rues.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
His feet, whose likeness none can find, 
Alone can ease the anxious mind.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Unless His foot, ‘to Whom none can compare,‘ men gain,
‘Tis hard for mind to find relief from anxious pain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Anxiety of mind cannot be removed, except from those who are united to the feet of Him who is incomparable.
Various Translators: They alone dispel the mind’s distress who take refuge at the Feet of the Incomparable One.
Dinamalar: Only those who have sought refuge in the feet of the peerless can shake off anxiety. Others cannot.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
None can swim the sea of births, but those united
To the feet of that Being, a sea of virtue.
Transliteration:
None can swim the sea of births, but those
united To the feet of that Being, a sea of virtue.
T.Kannan:
Aravaazhi Andhanan Thaalserndhaark
Kallaal
Piravaazhi Neendhal Aridhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Except those who surrender at the feet of God, the ocean of morality, others will struggle to cross the ocean of desire.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who swims the sea of vice is he 
Who clasps the feet of Virtue's sea.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: None can swim the sea of vice, but those who are united to the feet of that gracious Being who is a sea of virtue.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Unless His feet, the Sea of Good, the Fair and Bountilful,’men gain,
‘Tis hard the further bank of being’s changeful sea to attain.
Various Translators: They alone can cross life’s other oceans who take refuge at the Feet of the Gracious One, Himself an Ocean of Virtue.
Dinamalar: Only those who have clung to the feet of the Lord who is the sea of righteousness, will be able to sail the other seas. Others cannot.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Depraved, senseless and worthless is the head
Unbowed at the feet of Him with eight qualities.
Transliteration:
Depraved, senseless and worthless is the
head Unbowed at the feet of Him with eight qualities.
T.Kannan: The head that worships not the feet of Him who is possessed of eight attributes, is as useless as a sense without the power of sensation.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kolil Poriyin Kunamilave
Enkunaththaan
Thaalai Vanangaath Thalai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The head that doesn’t bow to God, is similar to the organs that don’t have the right senses.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Like senses stale that head is vain 
Which bows not to Eight-Virtued Divine.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Before His Foot, ‘the Eight fold Excellence,‘ with unbent head,
Who stands, like palsied sense, is to all living functions dead.
Various Translators: The head that does not bow down before and worship the feet of the Lord of the eight attributes, will be as like the palsied senses.
Dinamalar: The head which cannot bow before the Feet of the Possessor of eight infinite powers is like the senses lacking the power to perceive.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The ocean of births can be crossed by none other than
Those who reach the feet of the Lord.
Transliteration: None can swim the great sea of births but those who are united to the feet of God.
T.Kannan:
The ocean of births can be crossed by none
other than Those who reach the feet of the Lord.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Piravip Perungatal Neendhuvar
Neendhaar
Iraivan Atiseraa Thaar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who surrender at the feet of God, will cross the great ocean of life; others won’t.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The sea of births they alone swim 
Who clench His feet and cleave to Him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who gain the feet of the Lord cross the great ocean of births; others cannot.
Various Translators:
They swim the sea of births, the 'Monarch’s’ foot who gain;
None other’s reach the shore of being’s mighty main.
Dinamalar: The boundless ocean of births can be crossed, indeed, but not without intimate union with Infinity’s Holy Feet.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is the unfailing fall of rain that sustains the world. Therefore, look upon rain as the nectar of life.
Transliteration:
Rain is deemed a nectar of life
As its unfailing fall sustains the world.
T.Kannan: By the continuance of rain the world is preserved in existence; it is therefore worthy to be called ambrosia.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Rain is deemed a nectar of life As its
unfailing fall sustains the world.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The world for its existence depends on unfailing rainfall; the rain may well be regarded as the nectar of life.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Vaannindru Ulakam Vazhangi
Varudhalaal
Thaanamizhdham Endrunarar Paatru
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The world survives because of the rains and therefore rain is known to be the nectar of immortality.
Various Translators:
The genial rain ambrosia call: 
The world but lasts while rain shall fall.
Dinamalar:
The World its course maintains through life that rain unfailing gives;
Thus rain is known the true ambrosial food of all that lives.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Rain produces man’s wholesome food; and rain itself forms part of his food besides.
Transliteration:
Rain is not only a consumable for the consumer
But also begets other consumables.
T.Kannan: Rain produces good food, and is itself food.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The rain is the source of all articles of food that man needs. It becomes his drink too.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Rain is not only a consumable for the
consumer But also begets other consumables.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Thuppaarkkuth Thuppaaya Thuppaakkith
Thuppaarkkuth
Thuppaaya Thooum Mazhai
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Oh rain! You not only create everything we eat, you are the indispensable food yourself.
Various Translators:
The rain begets the food we eat 
And forms a food and drink concrete.
Dinamalar:
The rain makes pleasant food for eaters rise;
As food itself, thirst quenching draught supplies.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If clouds. The promised rain, deceive, and in the sky remain,
Famine, sore torment, stalks o’er earth's vast ocean girdled plain.
Transliteration: Though oceanic waters surround it, the world will be deluged by hunger’s hardships if the billowing clouds betray us.
T.Kannan: If the cloud, withholding rain, deceive (our hopes) hunger will long distress the sea-girt spacious world.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
This vast world, with expanse of seas,
Will still suffer with famine if clouds deceive rain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Hunger would stalk abroad and torment this wide sea-girt world were the rims to fail in time.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
This vast world, with expanse of seas,
Will still suffer with famine if clouds deceive rain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Vinindru Poippin Virineer
Viyanulakaththu
Ulnindru Utatrum Pasi
Various Translators: If the skies fail to rain, the world, though surrounded by sea, will yet suffer of hunger.
Dinamalar:
Let clouds their visits stay, and dearth 
Distresses all the sea girt earth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If clouds their wealth on waters fail on earth to pour,
The ploughers plough with oxen’s sturdy team no more.
Transliteration: When clouds withhold their watery wealth, farmers cease to ply their plows.
T.Kannan: If the abundance of wealth imparting rain diminish, the labour of the plough must cease.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
If that bounty called rain decrease,
Ploughing by ploughmen would also cease.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The cultivators would cease to plough were the clouds’ free supply of water to fail.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If that bounty called rain decrease,
Ploughing by ploughmen would also cease.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Erin Uzhaaar Uzhavar Puyalennum
Vaari Valangundrik Kaal
Various Translators: If the monsoons fail, farmers won’t till their lands to produce food.
Dinamalar:
Unless the fruitful shower descend, 
The ploughman's sacred toil must end.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is the tormentor; it is the saviour of the tormented: the rain is everything for us.
Transliteration:
Destruction it may sometimes pour, 
But only rain can life restore.
T.Kannan:
‘Tis rain works all: it ruin spreads, then timely aid supplies;
As, in the happy days before, it bids the ruined rise.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Rain by its absence ruins men; and by its existence restores them to fortune.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It is rain that ruins, and it is rain again that raises up those it has ruined.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: It is the rain that afflicts man and it is its fall that relieves him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Rain holds the power of ruin.
Rain also lifts up those it has ruined.
Various Translators:
Rain holds the power of ruin.Rain also
lifts up those it has ruined.
Dinamalar:
Ketuppadhooum Kettaarkkuch Chaarvaaimar
Raange
Etuppadhooum Ellaam Mazhai

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Visumpin Thuliveezhin Allaalmar
Raange
Pasumpul Thalaikaanpu Aridhu
Transliteration: Unless drops of precious rain fall down, not even grass will sprout its head.
T.Kannan:
No grassy blade its head will rear, 
If from the cloud no drop appear.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If no drop falls from the clouds, not even the green blade of grass will be seen.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If from the clouds no drops of rain are shed,
‘Tis rare to see green herb lift up its head.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Unless raindrops fall from the sky, not a blade of green grass will rise from the earth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If the clouds were to withhold rain not even a blade of grass would rustle on earth.
Various Translators:
If clouds stop dropping raindrops,
Even blades of grass will stop rising.
Dinamalar:
If clouds stop dropping raindrops, Even
blades of grass will stop rising.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even the wealth of the wide sea will be diminished, if the cloud that has drawn (its waters) up gives them not back again (in rain).
Transliteration:
Netungatalum Thanneermai Kundrum
Thatindhezhili
Thaannalkaa Thaaki Vitin
T.Kannan: Even the vast ocean will start shrinking, if the clouds that took the water away from it, don’t pour it back.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The ocean's wealth will waste away,
Except the cloud its stores repay.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If clouds restrain their gifts and grant no rain,
The treasures fail in ocean’s wide domain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even the illimitable deep shrinks if the clouds do not pour and replenish it.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The very nature of oceans, though vast, would diminish if clouds ceased to take up water and replenish rain’s gifts.
Various Translators:
Even the vast sea will lose its richness,
If clouds cease and fail to bestow.
Dinamalar:
Even the vast sea will lose its richness,
If clouds cease and fail to bestow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If the heaven dry up, neither yearly festivals, nor daily worship will be offered in this world, to the celestials.
Transliteration:
If the heavens dry up, the very gods Will
lack festival and worship.
T.Kannan:
Sirappotu Poosanai Sellaadhu Vaanam
Varakkumel Vaanorkkum Eentu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Special offerings and daily rituals to gods will stop, if the skies dry up.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The earth, beneath a barren sky, 
Would offerings for the gods deny.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: If the rains were to fail there would be no more o£ferings and festivals to the gods.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If heaven grow dry, with feast and offering never more,
Will men on earth the heavenly ones adore.
Various Translators: Should the heavens dry up, worship here of the heavenly ones in festivals and daily rites would wither.
Dinamalar:
If the heavens dry up, the very gods
Will lack festival and worship.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Both charity and penance would cease in
this vast world, Should heavens fail to deliver.
Transliteration: If the rains were to fail, there would neither be alms nor penance on this wide earth.
T.Kannan:
Thaanam Thavamirantum Thangaa
Viyanulakam
Vaanam Vazhangaa Thenin
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Charity and penance will both cease to exist in this world, if the clouds are not charitable.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Were heaven above to fail below 
Nor alms nor penance earth would show.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If heaven its watery treasures ceases to dispense,
Through the wide world ceases gifts, and deeds of ’penitence’.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Unless the heavens grant their gifts, neither the giver’s generosity nor the ascetic’s detachment will grace this wide world.
Various Translators:
Both charity and penance would cease in this vast world,
Should heavens fail to deliver.
Dinamalar: If rain fall not, penance and alms-deeds will not dwell within this spacious world.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The world cannot exist without water; there will be no ceaseless supply without rainfall.
Transliteration:
If the world cannot exist without water,
Neither can water exist without rain.
T.Kannan:
Neerindru Amaiyaadhu Ulakenin
Yaaryaarkkum
Vaanindru Amaiyaadhu Ozhukku
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: World can’t survive without water and morality can’t exist without rains.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Water is life that comes from rain 
Sans rain our duties go in vain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When water fails, functions of nature cease, you say;
Thus when rain fails, no men can walk in ‘duty’s ordered way’.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: No life on Earth can exist without water, and water’s ceaseless flow cannot exist without rain.
Various Translators:
If the world cannot exist without water,
Neither can water exist without rain.
Dinamalar: If it be said that the duties of life cannot be discharged by any person without water, so without rain there cannot be the flowing of water.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The one supreme thing all scriptures affirm is the great renunciation of those who walk in right conduct.
Transliteration:
Scriptures ought to exalt with firmness
The greatness of disciplined ascetics.
T.Kannan:
Ozhukkaththu Neeththaar Perumai
Vizhuppaththu
Ventum Panuval Thunivu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: All books willingly conclude as the most excellent, the greatness of those with the right conduct who have given up attachment.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
No merit can be held so high
As theirs who sense and self deny.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The settled rule of every code requires, as highest good,
Their greatness who, renouncing all, true to their rule have stood.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The Scriptures exalt above every other good the greatness of virtuous renunciates.
Various Translators: The end and aim of all treatise is to extol beyond all other excellence, the greatness of those who, while abiding in the rule of conduct peculiar to their state, have abandoned all desire.
Dinamalar:
Scriptures ought to exalt with firmness
The greatness of disciplined ascetics.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To measure the greatness of one who has renounced is like reckoning the number of the dead in this world.
Transliteration:
To recount an ascetic's greatness Is to
count the world's dead.
T.Kannan:
Thurandhaar Perumai Thunaikkoorin
Vaiyaththu
Irandhaarai Ennikkon Tatru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Trying to quantify the greatness of those who have overcome desire is like counting those who have died till now.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To con ascetic glory here
Is to count the dead upon the sphere.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As counting those that from the earth have passed away,
‘Tis vain attempt the might of holy men to say.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Attempting to speak of the renunciate’s magnitude is like numbering all the human multitudes who have ever died.
Various Translators: To describe the measure of the greatness of those who have forsaken the two-fold desires, is like counting the dead.
Dinamalar:
To recount an ascetic's greatness
Is to count the world's dead.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The world shines on the greatness of those who,
Knowing both, choose renunciation.
Transliteration:
The world shines on the greatness of those
who, Knowing both, choose renunciation.
T.Kannan:
Irumai Vakaidherindhu Eentuaram
Poontaar
Perumai Pirangitru Ulaku
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The greatness of those who have known the nature of both worlds, And have eschewed desire to live a righteous life, is most admirable in this world.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
No lustre can with theirs compare
Who know the right and virtue wear.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Their greatness earth transcends, who, way of both worlds weighed,
In this world take their stand, in virtue’s robe arrayed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The greatness of those who have discovered the properties of both states of being, and renounced the world, shines forth on earth (beyond all others).
Various Translators: Behold those who have weighed the dual nature of things and followed the renunciate’s way. Their greatness illumines the world.
Dinamalar: The greatest thing on earth is the renunciation of those who understand birth and liberation.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The restraint of senses five by the ankush of firmness
Is the seed for the bliss of heaven.
Transliteration:
The restraint of senses five by the ankush
of firmness Is the seed for the bliss of heaven.
T.Kannan:
Uranennum Thottiyaan Oraindhum
Kaappaan
Varanennum Vaippirkor Viththu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Using the ankus called resoluteness, one who controls the elephant named five senses, is sowing for future glory.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
With hook of firmness to restrain
The senses five, is heaven to gain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He who guides his five senses by the hook of wisdom will be a seed in the world of heaven.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
He, who with firmness’ curb the five restrains,
Is seed for soil of yonder happy plains.
Various Translators: He whose firm will, wisdom’s goading hook, controls his five senses is a seed that will flourish in the fields of Heaven.
Dinamalar: He who with firmness bridles the five senses is (himself) the seed of the eternal bliss.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even the celestial king Indra will vouch the strength
Of one who rules his senses five.
Transliteration:
Even the celestial king Indra will vouch
the strength Of one who rules his senses five.
T.Kannan: Indra, the king of the inhabitants of the spacious heaven, is himself, a sufficient proof of the strength of him who has subdued his five senses.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aindhaviththaan Aatral Akalvisumpu
Laarkomaan
Indhirane Saalung Kari
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: God, the king of heavens, is an example of what the ability to conquer one’s five senses can result in.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Indra himself has cause to say 
How great the power ascetics' sway.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Their might who have destroyed ‘the five,' shall soothly tell
Indra, the lord of those in heaven’s wide realms that dwell.
Various Translators: Indra, the Lord of the skies is himself a witness, to the might of those who have conquered their five senses.
Dinamalar: Such is the power of those who subdue the five senses, that even Indra, sovereign of spacious Heaven’s celestials, suffered their curse.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Great people take on difficult tasks;
Small people avoid them.
Transliteration: The great will do those things which is difficult to be done; but the mean cannot do them.
T.Kannan:
Great people take on difficult tasks;
Small people avoid them.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seyarkariya Seyvaar Periyar Siriyar
Seyarkariya Seykalaa Thaar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What separates the great from the ordinary is their ability to do the seemingly impossible.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The small the paths of ease pursue 
The great achieve things rare to do.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The great achieve the impossible; the little cannot.
Various Translators:
Things hard in the doing will great men do;
Things hard in the doing the mean eschew.
Dinamalar: The magnificent ones are they who can dispatch the most difficult tasks; the insignificant ones are they who cannot.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Touch, taste, sight, smell and hearing are the senses— he who controls these five magically controls the world.
Transliteration:
This world is his who knows for what these five are:
Taste, sight, touch, sound and smell.
T.Kannan: The world is within the knowledge of him who knows the properties of taste, sight, touch, hearing and smell.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
This world is his who knows for what these
five are: Taste, sight, touch, sound and smell.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The world falls at the feet of one who has realised the true nature of the taste, sight, touch, sound and smell.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Suvaioli Ooruosai Naatramendru
Aindhin
Vakaidherivaan Katte Ulaku
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: One who has analysed and conquered the urges of taste, sight, touch, sound and smell, will control this world.
Various Translators:
They gain the world, who grasp and tell 
Of taste, sight, hearing, touch and smell.
Dinamalar:
Taste, light, touch, sound , and smell: who knows the way
Of all the five, the world submissive owns his sway.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Their own subtle sayings reveal to the world the greatness of men whose words prove prophetic.
Transliteration:
The scriptures of the world proclaim
The potent utterance of the great.
T.Kannan: The hidden words of the men whose words are full of effect, will shew their greatness to the world.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The greatness of the sages in this world is borne out by their prophetic utterances.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The scriptures of the world proclaim The
potent utterance of the great.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Niraimozhi Maandhar Perumai
Nilaththu
Maraimozhi Kaatti Vitum
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The words of those glorious people, who control their minds completely, become the gospel.
Various Translators:
Full worded men by what they say, 
Their greatness to the world display.
Dinamalar:
The might of men whose word is never vain,
The ‘Secret word’ shall to the earth proclaim.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The wrath ‘tis hard e’en for an instant to endure,
Of those who virtue’s hill have scaled, and stand secure.
Transliteration: The anger of those who have ascended the mountain of goodness, though it continue but for a moment, cannot be resisted.
T.Kannan: It is impossible to endure, even for a second, the wrath of those who have scaled and stand upon the mountain called virtue.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The wrath of those who have scaled the heights of character
Can't be endured even for a moment.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It is impossible to resist even for a minute the wrath of those who stand on the hill of virtue’s actions.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wrath of those who have scaled the
heights of character Can't be endured even for a
moment.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kunamennum Kundreri Nindraar Vekuli
Kanameyum Kaaththal Aridhu
Various Translators: Those who have scaled the mountain of morality will not allow their anger to last for a moment.
Dinamalar:
Their wrath, who've climb'd the mount of good,
Though transient, cannot be withstood.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The virtuous are truly called Anthanar; because in their conduct towards all creatures they are clothed in kindness.
Transliteration:
Towards all that breathe, with seemly graciousness adorned they live;
And thus to virtue’s son’s the name of ‘Anthanar’ men give.
T.Kannan: Pious men are called the priestly ones, for they are clothed in robes of compassion for all life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ascetics are called men of virtue
For they assume the role of mercy for all that live.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: They are the Brahmans who are righteous and love all creation.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Ascetics are called men of virtue For they
assume the role of mercy for all that live.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Andhanar Enpor Aravormar Revvuyir
KkumSendhanmai Poontozhuka Laan
Various Translators: All (and only) those righteous people, who shower love on all living beings, can be classified as Anthanar*.
Dinamalar:
With gentle mercy towards all,
The sage fulfils the vitue's call.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Righteousness yields good reputation and wealth; is there anything more precious?
Transliteration:
From virtue weal and wealth outflow;
What greater good can mankind know?
T.Kannan:
It yields distinction, yields prosperity: what gain
Greater than virtue can a living man obtain?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Virtue yields Heaven’s honor and Earth’s wealth. What is there then that is more fruitful for a man?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Is there anything higher in life than Dharma? It secures glory and wealth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What gain greater than virtue can a living man obtain,
Which yields fame and fortune?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What gain greater than virtue can a living
man obtain, Which yields fame and fortune?
Various Translators: Virtue will confer heaven and wealth; what greater source of happiness can man possess ?
Dinamalar:
Sirappu Eenum Selvamum Eenum
AraththinoounguAakkam Evano Uyirkku

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Araththinooungu Aakkamum Illai
Adhanai
Maraththalin Oongillai Ketu
Transliteration: Rectitude is the most precious possession; there is nothing more pernicious than straying from it.
T.Kannan:
Virtue enhances joy and gain;
Forsaking it is fall and pain.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
No greater gain than virtue aught can cause;
No greater loss than life oblivious of her laws.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: There is nothing more rewarding than virtue, nor anything more ruinous than its neglect.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Nothing is higher than Dharma; to forget it is wrought with greatest evil.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
There is no greater gain than virtue.
No surer path to ruin than its neglect.
Various Translators: There can be no greater source of good than (the practice of) virtue; there can be no greater source of evil than the forgetfulness of it.
Dinamalar:
There is no greater gain than virtue.No
surer path to ruin than its neglect.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ollum Vakaiyaan Aravinai Ovaadhe
Sellumvaai Ellaanj Cheyal
Transliteration: Keep doing the morally right things, in every possible manner, wherever you go.
T.Kannan:
Perform good deeds as much you can
Always and everywhere, o man!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To finish virtue’s work with ceaseless effort strive,
What way thou may’st where’er thou see’st the work may thrive.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Avail yourself of all opportunities. Do not cease from practising Dharma on all possible occasions to the best of your ability.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Be unremitting in the doing of good deeds; do them with all your might and by every possible means.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The right thing to do is to be righteous
At all places and all times.
Various Translators: As much as possible, in every way, incessantly practise virtue.
Dinamalar:
The right thing to do is to be righteous
At all places and all times.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A blemishless mind is the basis of all
virtue.Everything else is empty show.
Transliteration:
Manaththukkan Maasilan Aadhal
Anaiththu
AranAakula Neera Pira
T.Kannan: True moral integrity lies in being flawless in your thoughts; everything else is loud and blatant posturing.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
In spotless mind virtue is found
And not in show and swelling sound.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Be pure in mind. That is Dharma. All else is but pompous show.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Spotless be thou in mind! This only merits virtue’s name;
All else, mere pomp of idle sound, no real worth can claim.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Keep the mind free of impurity. That alone is the practice of virtue. All else is nothing but empty display.
Various Translators:
A blemishless mind is the basis of all virtue.
Everything else is empty show.
Dinamalar: Let him who does virtuous deeds be of spotless mind; to that extent is virtue; all else is vain show.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Envy, greed, wrath and harsh words: These
four avoided is virtue.
Transliteration: That course of conduct that steers clear of every desire, wrath, and offensive speech — is alone Dharma.
T.Kannan:
Azhukkaaru Avaavekuli Innaachchol
Naankum
Izhukkaa Iyandradhu Aram
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Righteousness is all about removing the four flaws. envy, desire, anger and harmful words.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Four ills eschew and virtue reach, 
Lust, anger, envy, evil speech.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
‘Tis virtue when, his footsteps sliding not through envy, wrath,
Lust, evil speech these four, man onwards moves in ordered path.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Virtue is living in such a way that one does not fall into these four: envy, anger, greed and unsavory speech.
Various Translators: That conduct is virtue which is free from these four things, viz, malice, desire, anger and bitter speech.
Dinamalar:
Envy, greed, wrath and harsh words:
These four avoided is virtue.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Do not postpone doing Dharma. Do it now. For it will be a never failing friend at your death.
Transliteration:
Defer not virtue but practice now.At the
dying hour she will be your undying friend.
T.Kannan:
Andrarivaam Ennaadhu Aranjeyka
Matradhu
Pondrungaal Pondraath Thunai
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Do the righteous deeds now without waiting for senility to set in; they will remain your permanent companions then.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Do good enow; defer it not
A deathless aid in death if sought.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Do deeds of virtue now, Say not, 'To morrow we’ll be wise';
Thus, when thou diest, shalt thou find a help that never dies.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Don’t tell yourself you’ll be wise enough to practice virtue tomorrow. Do it now, for it will be your deathless companion when you die.
Various Translators: Defer not virtue to another day; receive her now; and at the dying hour she will be your undying friend.
Dinamalar:
Defer not virtue but practice now.
At the dying hour she will be your undying friend.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Why search for the fruits of Dharma? Behold the one in the palanquin and the palanquin-bearer.
Transliteration:
Inquiring about virtues' benefits?See that
between The rider and bearer of a palanquin.
T.Kannan:
Araththaaru Ithuvena Ventaa Sivikai
Poruththaanotu Oorndhaan Itai
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One man lifting another on a palanquin, can’t be justified as the fruit of any prior moral deeds.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Litter bearer and rider say
Without a word, the fortune's way.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Needs not in words to dwell on virtue’s fruits; compare
The man in litter borne with them that toiling bear!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The fruit of virtue need not be described in books; it may be inferred from seeing the bearer of a palanquin and the rider therein.
Various Translators: It is utterly superfluous to inquire about virtue’s benefits, so evident in the difference between the palanquin’s rider and bearer.
Dinamalar:
Inquiring about virtues' benefits? See that between
The rider and bearer of a palanquin.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If one were to practise righteousness every day it would be the stone that blocks the way to re-birth.
Transliteration:
The good you do without wasting a day Is
the stone that blocks the way to rebirth.
T.Kannan:
Veezhnaal Pataaamai Nandraatrin
Aqdhoruvan
Vaazhnaal Vazhiyataikkum Kal
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Never let a day pass without a good deed; it makes this life fulfilling and the next unnecessary.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Like stones that block rebirth and pain
Are doing good and good again.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: If one allows no day to pass without some good being done, his conduct will be a stone to block up the passage to other births.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If no day passing idly, good to do each day toil,
A Stone ’t will be to block the way of future days of moil.
Various Translators: Not allowing a day to pass without doing some good is a boulder that will block your passage on the path to rebirth.
Dinamalar:
The good you do without wasting a day
Is the stone that blocks the way to rebirth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Virtue alone brings happiness;
All else is naught, and without praise.
Transliteration:
Virtue alone brings happiness; All else is
naught, and without praise.
T.Kannan: Only that pleasure which flows from domestic virtue is pleasure; all else is not pleasure, and it is without praise.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Araththaan Varuvadhe Inpam
MarRellaam
Puraththa Pukazhum Ila
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: True joy blossoms only due to righteous deeds; all else cause unhappiness and disrepute.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Weal flows only from virtue done
The rest is rue and renown gone.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What from virtue floweth, yieldeth dear delight;
All else extern, is void of glory’s light.
Various Translators: Only virtuous deeds abound in true joy. All other deeds are empty and devoid of distinction.
Dinamalar: Happiness springs only from Dharma. All else is sorrow and merits no praise.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Virtue is that which should be done.
And vice is that which should be shun.
Transliteration: That is virtue which each ought to do, and that is vice which each should shun.
T.Kannan:
Virtue is that which should be done.And
vice is that which should be shun.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seyarpaala Thorum Arane Oruvarku
Uyarpaala Thorum Pazhi
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A righteous deed deserves to be done; an evil deed ought to be avoided to protect oneself from infamy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Worthy act is virtue done
Vice is what we ought to shun.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
‘Virtue’ sums the things that should be done;
‘Vice’ sums the things that man should shun.
Various Translators: Virtue is merely that which should be done in life, and vice is merely that which should be avoided.
Dinamalar: To do good and to avoid evil must be the law of our being.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A householder is a steadfast friend
To the other three orders in their virtuous paths.
Transliteration: He will be called a (true) householder, who is a firm support to the virtuous of the three orders in their good path.
T.Kannan:
A householder is a steadfast friend To the
other three orders in their virtuous paths.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ilvaazhvaan Enpaan Iyalputaiya
Moovarkkum
Nallaatrin Nindra Thunai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A good family person is one who supports all three relationships (parents, wife, children) in a balanced and righteous manner.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The ideal householder is he
Who aids the natural orders there.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The men of household virtue, firm in way of good, sustain
The other orders three that rule professed maintain.
Various Translators: The householder is the prop of the three orders of life in the conduct of their virtue.
Dinamalar: He alone may be called a householder who supports students, elders and renunciates pursuing well their good paths.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The householder supports the needs of
Renunciates, ancestors and the poor.
Transliteration: He will be said to flourish in domestic virtue who aids the forsaken, the poor, and the dead.
T.Kannan:
The householder supports the needs of
Renunciates, ancestors and the poor.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A good family person also extends support to saints, poor and needy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Thurandhaarkkum Thuvvaa Dhavarkkum
Irandhaarkkum
Ilvaazhvaan Enpaan Thunai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
His help the monk and retired share, 
And celebrate students are his care.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The householder is the mainstay of the ascetics, the needy and the dead.
Various Translators:
To anchorites, to indigent, to those who’ve passed away,
The man for household virtue famed is needful help and stay.
Dinamalar: The virtuous householder supports the needs of renunciates, ancestors and the poor.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The foremost duty of family life is to serve duly these five: God, guests, kindred, ancestors and oneself.
Transliteration: The chief (duty of the householder) is to preserve the five-fold rule (of conduct) towards the manes, the Gods, his guests, his relations and himself.
T.Kannan:
A householder's main duty is to serve these five:
God, guests, kindred, ancestors and himself.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A householder's main duty is to serve
these five: God, guests, kindred, ancestors and
himself.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It is the supreme virtue (of the householder) to fulfil his obligations to forefathers, gods, guests, relatives and himself.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Teachers, God, guests, relatives and oneself. it is important to nurture all these five in addition to the family.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thenpulaththaar Theyvam Virundhokkal
Thaanendraangu
Aimpulaththaaru Ompal Thalai
Various Translators:
By dutiful householder's aid
God, manes, kin, self and guests are served.
Dinamalar:
The manes, God. Guest, Kindred, self, in due degree
These Five to cherish well is chiefest charity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The posterity of householders who gather wealth without misdeeds and share meals without miserliness will never perish.
Transliteration: His descendants shall never fail who, living in the domestic state, fears vice (in the acquisition of property) and shares his food (with others).
T.Kannan:
His life and lineage will never end
who shuns blame and shares his food.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If one were to live in fear of infamy and partake of the remains of food (offered) one’s line would never perish.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
His life and lineage will never end who
shuns blame and shares his food.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: One who earns well but avoids the blame of hoarding wealth, by philanthropy, will lead a complete life with no complaints.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Pazhiyanjip Paaththoon Utaiththaayin
Vaazhkkai
Vazhiyenjal Egngnaandrum Il
Various Translators:
Sin he shuns and food he shares
His home is bright and brighter fares.
Dinamalar:
Who shares his meal with other, while all guilt he shuns,
His virtuous line unbroken though the ages runs.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If love and virtue in the household reign,
This is of life the perfect grace and gain.
Transliteration: If the married life possess love and virtue, these will be both its duty and reward.
T.Kannan: When family life possesses love and virtue, it has found both its essence and fruition.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Family life actuated by love and virtue,
Endows it with character and happiness
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The life of householder marked by love and rectitude is itself virtue and its fruit.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Family life actuated by love and virtue,
Endows it with character and happiness
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If love and virtue pervade the family life, they become the characteristic and fruit of the family life.
Various Translators:
Anpum Aranum Utaiththaayin
Ilvaazhkkai
Panpum Payanum Adhu
Dinamalar:
In grace and gain the home excels, 
Where love with virtue sweetly dwells.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: What will he who lives virtuously in the domestic state gain by going into the other, (ascetic) state ?
Transliteration:
If man in active household life a virtuous soul retain,
What fruit from other modes a virtue can he gain?
T.Kannan: If a man masters the duties of married life, what further merits could monkhood offer him?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What gains are there in other paths
When one leads the virtuous path of householder?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Is there any gain greater in resorting to other orders of life than by pursuing the right path of the householder?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What gains are there in other paths When
one leads the virtuous path of householder?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The only way to live is to live righteously; if you set aside virtues, what more is there to gain?
Various Translators:
Araththaatrin Ilvaazhkkai Aatrin
Puraththaatril
Pooip Peruva Thevan?
Dinamalar:
Who turns from righteous family
To be a monk, what profits he?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Of all who strive for bliss, the great
Is he who leads the married state.
Transliteration:
In nature's way who spends his calm domestic days,
'Mid all that strive for virtue's crown hath foremost place.
T.Kannan: Among those who strive for liberation, the foremost are they who live the blessed state of family life as it should be lived.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The life of the householder is far greater than that of one in the path of renunciation.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Foremost among those who strive for release,
Are the householders leading a righteous life.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Foremost among those who strive for
release, Are the householders leading a righteous
life.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Among all those who labour (for future happiness) he is greatest who lives well in the household state.
Various Translators: One who leads a normal and intimate family life, is far ahead of those who seek other priorities.
Dinamalar:
Iyalpinaan Ilvaazhkkai Vaazhpavan
Enpaan
Muyalvaarul Ellaam Thalai

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If one lives by the right virtues and assists others to do the same, such a family life is better than the penance of saints
Transliteration:
Aatrin Ozhukki Aranizhukkaa
Ilvaazhkkai
Norpaarin Nonmai Utaiththu
T.Kannan:
Straight in virtue, right in living
Make men brighter than monks praying.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Others it sets upon their way, itself from virtue ne'er declines;
Than stern ascetics' pains such life domestic brighter shines.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The householder dedicated to duty and to aiding ascetics on their path of penance endures more than they do.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The householder who keeps others in the right path and himself does not deviate from his, does greater penance than the anchorite.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A virtuous householder endures
More than the penance of the penance doer.
Various Translators: The householder who, not swerving from virtue, helps the ascetic in his way, endures more than those who endure penance.
Dinamalar:
A virtuous householder endures More than
the penance of the penance doer.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: True virtue is to lead a harmonious family life; it is even better if it is beyond others’ blame.
Transliteration:
Aran Enap Pattadhe Ilvaazhkkai
AqdhumPiranpazhippa Thillaayin Nandru
T.Kannan:
Home life and virtue, are the same; 
Which spotless monkhood too can claim.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The life domestic rightly bears true virtue's name;
That other too, if blameless found, due praise may claim.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What is Dharma but the life of the householder? There is no greater life if it is free from reproach.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Domestic life is rightly called virtue. The monastic path, rightly lived beyond blame, is likewise good.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Domestic life is proclaimed virtuous
And it is praiseworthy if free from blame.
Various Translators: The marriage state is truly called virtue. The other state is also good, if others do not reproach it.
Dinamalar:
Domestic life is proclaimed virtuous And
it is praiseworthy if free from blame.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
He who lives his life in this world as he
should, Ranks with the gods in the heaven.
Transliteration: One who lives worldly life the way it ought to be lived will be treated on par with the Gods inhabiting the heavens.
T.Kannan:
Vaiyaththul Vaazhvaangu Vaazhpavan
Vaanuaryum
Theyvaththul Vaikkap Patum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
He is a man of divine worth 
Who lives in ideal home on earth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who lives the true life of the householder on earth becomes one among the gods in Heaven.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who shares domestic life, by household virtues graced,
Shall, mid the Gods, in heaven who dwell, be placed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He who rightly pursues the householder’s life here on Earth will be rightfully placed among the Gods there in Heaven.
Various Translators:
He who lives his life in this world as he should,
Ranks with the gods in the heaven.
Dinamalar: He who on earth has lived in the conjugal state as he should live, will be placed among the Gods who dwell in heaven.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
An ideal wife is a virtuous life partner
Living within her husband's means.
Transliteration: She is the true partner in life who possesses all the wifely virtues and spends according to the income of her husband.
T.Kannan: A spouse who possesses virtues required for the family and spends within the means is the ideal life partner.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Manaikdhakka Maanputaiyal Aakiththar
Kontaan
Valaththakkaal Vaazhkkaith Thunai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A good housewife befits the house, 
Spending with thrift the mate's resource.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As doth the house beseem, she shows her wifely dignity;
As doth her husband's wealth befit, she spends: helpmeet is she.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: She is the helpful wife who possesses the fullness of domestic virtues and spends within her husband’s means.
Various Translators: She who has the excellence of home virtues, and can expend within the means of her husband, is a help in the domestic state.
Dinamalar:
An ideal wife is a virtuous life partner
Living within her husband's means.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Home life shorn of its grace will be barren however pompous it may be.
Transliteration:
If the wife lacks household excellence,
All other excellence in life comes to nil.
T.Kannan: If your spouse doesnt possess the virtues needed for married life, whatever else you possess in life is irrelevant.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Manaimaatchi Illaalkan Illaayin
Vaazhkkai
Enaimaatchith Thaayinum Il
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Bright is home when wife is chaste.
If not all greatness is but waste.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If household excellence be wanting in the wife,
Howe'er with splendour lived, all worthless is the life.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Family life, however full, remains empty if the wife lacks the lofty culture of the home.
Various Translators: If the wife be devoid of domestic excellence, whatever (other) greatness be possessed, the conjugal state, is nothing.
Dinamalar:
If the wife lacks household excellence,
All other excellence in life comes to nil.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If the wife abounds in virtues is there anything lacking in home? Lacking which, it lacks everything.
Transliteration:
With a good wife, what is lacking?And when
she is lacking, what is good?
T.Kannan: If your spouse has the qualities suited for family life, what is it that you dont have? If not, what is it that you have?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Illadhen Illaval Maanpaanaal
Ulladhen
Illaval Maanaak Katai?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What is rare when wife is good. 
What can be there when she is bad?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
There is no lack within the house, where wife in worth excels,
There is no luck with the house, where wife dishonoured dwells.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If his wife be eminent (in virtue), what does (that man) not possess ? If she be without excellence, what does (he) possess ?
Various Translators: What does a man lack if his wife is worthy? And what does he possess if she is lacking worth?
Dinamalar:
With a good wife, what is lacking?
And when she is lacking, what is good?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Is there anything greater than a woman if only she is the citadel of chastity?
Transliteration:
What more grandeur does a woman need Than
possessing the strength of chastity?
T.Kannan: If your spouse is strongly virtuous, can there be anything worthier that your spouse?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pennin Perundhakka Yaavula Karpennum
Thinmaiun Taakap Perin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What greater fortune is for men
Than a constant chaste woman?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: What is more excellent than a wife, if she possess the stability of chastity ?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If women might of chastity retain,
What choicer treasure doth the world contain?
Various Translators: What is more majestic than a woman who preserves the prodigious strength of chastity?
Dinamalar:
What more grandeur does a woman need
Than possessing the strength of chastity?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even rains fall at the command of the wife
Who upon rising worships not God, but her husband.
Transliteration:
Even rains fall at the command of the wife
Who upon rising worships not God, but her husband.
T.Kannan: If she, who does not worship God, but who rising worships her husband, say, "let it rain," it will rain.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Rain will pour instantly at the order of a wife who prays not to God but to her husband.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Theyvam Thozhaaal Kozhunan
Thozhudhezhuvaal
Peyyenap Peyyum Mazhai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Her spouse before God who adores, 
Is like rain that at request pours.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
No God adoring , low she bends before her lord;
Then rising, serves: the rain falls instant at her word!
Various Translators: Even the rains will fall at her command who upon rising worships not God, but her husband.
Dinamalar: Waking up she worships no other god than her husband. Verily at her very bidding it rains.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A tireless woman guards herself,
Cares for her spouse and upholds family name.
Transliteration: She is a wife who unweariedly guards herself, takes care of her husband, and preserves an unsullied fame.
T.Kannan:
A tireless woman guards herself, Cares for
her spouse and upholds family name.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A woman not only protects herself, but tirelessly takes care of her husband and preserves the family reputation.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Tharkaaththuth Tharkontaar Penith
Thakaisaandra
Sorkaaththuch Chorvilaal Pen
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The good wife guards herself from blame, 
She tends her spouse and brings him fame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who gaurds herself, for husband's comfort cares, her household's fame,
In perfect wise with sleepless soul preserves, give her a woman's name.
Various Translators: A married woman is one who vigilantly guards herself, cares for her husband and protects their unblemished reputation.
Dinamalar: She is the woman who shields herself, serves her wedded lord, maintains her glory and never ceases from her toil.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What use is physical restraint to a woman
When her moral restraint is the best?
Transliteration: What avails the guard of a prison ? The chief guard of a woman is her chastity.
T.Kannan:
What use is physical restraint to a woman
When her moral restraint is the best?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Is it of any use to possess women by imposing physical barriers? A woman will remain virtuous only on her own volition.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Siraikaakkum Kaappevan Seyyum
Makalir
Niraikaakkum Kaappe Thalai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Of what avail are watch and ward? 
Their purity is women's guard.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Of what avail is watch and ward?
Honour's a woman's safest guard.
Various Translators: Of what use is one’s watch and ward? Her chastity is her only shield.
Dinamalar: Why do guardians protect women by confinement when her own resolute chastity is a woman’s best protection?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The woman who gains her husband's love
Gains great glory in the heaven.
Transliteration: If women shew reverence to their husbands, they will obtain great excellence in the world where the gods flourish.
T.Kannan:
The woman who gains her husband's love
Gains great glory in the heaven.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If a woman gets a spouse with great character, she will enjoy the glory of heaven on earth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Petraar Perinperuvar Pentir
Perunjirappup
Puththelir Vaazhum Ulaku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Women who win their husbands' heart 
Shall flourish where the gods resort.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A dutiful wife inherits heaven with all its glory.
Various Translators:
If wife be wholly true to him who gained her as his bride,
Great glory gains she in the world where gods bliss abide.
Dinamalar: A woman deeply devoted to the man who wed her will be worthy of great rewards in the world where Gods delight.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Unless the wife pursues praiseworthy purity, the husband cannot stride before critics like a proud lion.
Transliteration: The man whose wife seeks not the praise (of chastity) cannot walk with lion-like stately step, before those who revile them.
T.Kannan:
He whose wife is not praiseworthy
Cannot walk with leonine gait before his critics.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
He whose wife is not praiseworthy Cannot
walk with leonine gait before his critics.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A cuckold knows not the lovely gait of a lion before his detractors.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those who dont have respectable family lives, will not be able to stride with a lion-like pride before their opponents.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Pukazhpurindha Illilorkku Illai
Ikazhvaarmun
Erupol Peetu Natai
Various Translators:
A cuckold has not the lion like gait
Before his detractors aright.
Dinamalar:
Who have not spouses that in virtue's praise delight,
They lion like can never walk in scorner's sight.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is said a worthy wife is the blessing of a home, and good children are its precious ornaments.
Transliteration: The excellence of a wife is the good of her husband; and good children are the jewels of that goodness.
T.Kannan:
A good wife is called boon to a house;
Besides that, good children its jewels.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The grace of a home is her virtue. Her blessed children are its adornment.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A good wife is called boon to a house;
Besides that, good children its jewels.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A great harmonious married life is a boon; having good offsprings adds luster to it.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Mangalam Enpa Manaimaatchi Matru
AdhanNankalam Nanmakkat Peru
Various Translators:
An honest wife is home's delight 
And children good are jewels abright.
Dinamalar:
The house's 'blessing', men pronounce the house wife excellent;
The gain of blessed childern is its goodly ornament.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Of all that men acquire, we know not any greater gain,
Than that which by the birth of learned children men obtain.
Transliteration: Among all the benefits that may be acquired, we know no greater benefit than the acquisition of intelligent children.
T.Kannan: Of all blessings we know of none greater than the begetting of children endowed with intelligence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Of all blessings we know,
Nothing worth than begetting intelligent children.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: We do not know of any other asset than that of intelligent off-spring.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Of all blessings we know, Nothing worth
than begetting intelligent children.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Other than having children who are wise enough to know what needs to be known, there is no other treasure that I value more.
Various Translators:
Perumavatrul Yaamarivadhu Illai
Arivarindha
Makkatperu Alla Pira
Dinamalar:
The world no higher bliss bestows 
Than children virtuous and wise.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The evils of the seven births shall not touch those who abtain children of a good disposition, free from vice.
Transliteration:
Who children gain, that none reproach, of virtuous worth,
No evils touch them, through the sev'n fold maze of birth.
T.Kannan: Those who bear children of blameless character will be untouched by evil for seven births.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
No harm will befall in all seven births
If one begets blameless children.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: All the seven births no evil befalls one who is blest with good and unstained children.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No harm will befall in all seven births If
one begets blameless children.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: No harm will befell one for even seven births, if one gives birth to children who have irreproachable character.
Various Translators:
Ezhupirappum Theeyavai Theentaa
Pazhipirangaap
Panputai Makkat Perin
Dinamalar:
No evil comes and no blemish;
Noble sons bring all we wish.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Children are one's wealth indeed 
Their wealth is measured by their deed.
Transliteration:
Man's children are his fortune, ' say the wise;
From each one's deeds his varied fortunes rise.
T.Kannan: It is said that children are a man’s real wealth, and that this wealth is determined by his deeds.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A man’s riches are his children; their riches are the fruit of their actions.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Children are called one's fortune;
And their fortune the result of their own deeds.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Children are called one's fortune; And
their fortune the result of their own deeds.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Men will call their sons their wealth, because it flows to them through the deeds which they (sons) perform on their behalf.
Various Translators: One’s children are defined as one’s wealth; the wealth that the children make will be through their own deeds.
Dinamalar:
Thamporul Enpadham Makkal Avarporul
Thamdham Vinaiyaan Varum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The porridge stirred playfully with the tiny hands of one’s children is sweeter than nectar.
Transliteration:
Amizhdhinum Aatra Inidhedham Makkal
Sirukai Alaaviya Koozh
T.Kannan:
The food is more than nectar sweet 
In which one's children hands insert.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Than God's ambrosia sweeter far the food before men laid,
In which the little hands of children of their own have play'd.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Far sweeter than divine nectar is simple boiled rice stirred by the small hands of one’s own child.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Sweeter than ambrosia is the food handled by the tender hand of one’s children.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Sweeter than nectar is the porridge messed up
By the tiny hands of one’s children.
Various Translators: The rice in which the little hand of their children has dabbled will be far sweeter (to the parent) than ambrosia.
Dinamalar:
Sweeter than nectar is the porridge messed
up By the tiny hands of one’s children.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The tender skin of one’s children is joyous to touch; their sweet voices rapturous to hear.
Transliteration:
Makkalmey Theental Utarkinpam Matru
AvarSorkettal Inpam Sevikku
T.Kannan:
Children's touch delights the body 
Sweet to ears are their words lovely.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To parent sweet the touch of children dear;
Their voice is sweetest music to his ear.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The delight of the body is the touch of one’s children. The delight of the ear is their lisp.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The touch of one’s children is a delight to the body, and listening to them chatter is a joy to the ear.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To be touched by children is a delight to the body,
And to hear their speech a joy to the ear.
Various Translators: The touch of children gives pleasure to the body, and the hearing of their words, pleasure to the ear.
Dinamalar:
To be touched by children is a delight to
the body, And to hear their speech a joy to the ear.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The flute is sweet', 'The lute is sweet',
Say those who never heard their children lisp.
Transliteration: Only those who don’t listen to their baby’s sweet babble will claim that a flute or yaazh sounds melodious.
T.Kannan:
Kuzhal Inidhu Yaazhinidhu Enpadham
MakkalMazhalaichchol Kelaa Thavar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The flute and lute are sweet they say
Deaf to baby's babble's lay!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The ‘lute is sweet’, ‘the Veena is sweet’, they say who have not heard the lisp of their little ones.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The pipe is sweet', 'the lute is sweet,' by them 't will be averred,
Who music of their infants' lisping lips have never heard.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: “Sweet are the sounds of the flute and the lute,” say those who have not heard the prattle of their own children.
Various Translators:
The flute is sweet, The lute is sweet,
Say those who never heard their children lisp.
Dinamalar: The pipe is sweet, the lute is sweet, say those who have not heard the prattle of their own children.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The good a father can do to his child Is
to make him excel in the midst of the learned.
Transliteration: The good a father can do his son is to make him occupy the first rank in an assembly.
T.Kannan: The duty of a father towards his children is to give them a headstart in knowledge over the best of scholars.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thandhai Makarkaatrum Nandri
Avaiyaththu
Mundhi Iruppach Cheyal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A father's duty to his son is
To seat him in front of the wise.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Sire greatest boon on son confers, who makes him meet,
In councils of the wise to fill the highest seat.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A father benefits his son best by preparing him to sit at the forefront of learned councils.
Various Translators: The benefit which a father should confer on his son is to give him precedence in the assembly of the learned.
Dinamalar:
The good a father can do to his child
Is to make him excel in the midst of the learned.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Wisdom of the child is not merely the father’s delight but the delight of the world.
Transliteration:
The wisdom of one's own children Brings
joy to all life on the earth.
T.Kannan: All living creatures on this earth feel prouder when their children are smarter than themselves.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thammindham Makkal Arivutaimai
Maanilaththu
Mannuyirk Kellaam Inidhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
With joy the hearts of parents swell 
To see their children themselves excel.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Their children's wisdom greater than their own confessed,
Through the wide world is sweet to every human breast.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What pleasure it is to human beings everywhere when their children possess knowledge surpassing their own!
Various Translators: That their children should possess knowledge is more pleasing to all men of this great earth than to themselves.
Dinamalar:
The wisdom of one's own children
Brings joy to all life on the earth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A mother’s joy to hear of her son’s greatness transcends that at his birth.
Transliteration:
A woman rejoices at the birth of a son,
But even more when he is praised.
T.Kannan: A mother feels more ecstatic to hear her son being praised as a noble scholar than when the son was born.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Eendra Pozhudhin Peridhuvakkum
Thanmakanaich
Chaandron Enakketta Thaai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The mother, hearing her son's merit
Delights more than when she begot.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When mother hears him named 'fulfill'd of wisdom's lore,'
Far greater joy she feels, than when her son she bore.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The mother who hears her son called "a wise man" will rejoice more than she did at his birth.
Various Translators: When a mother hears her son heralded as a good and learned man, her joy exceeds that of his joyous birth.
Dinamalar:
A woman rejoices at the birth of a son,
But even more when he is praised.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The service a son can do his father is to make the public exclaim ‘see, the fruit of his father’s good deeds.’
Transliteration:
The son's duty to his father is to make
world ask, 'By what austerities did he merit such a
son!
T.Kannan: The duty of a son towards his father is to make others wonder what great deeds did the father do to deserve such a son.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Makandhandhaikku Aatrum Udhavi
IvandhandhaiEnnotraan
Kol Enum Sol
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The son to sire this word is debt 
"What penance such a son begot!"
Ramachandra Dikshitar: (So to act) that it may be said "by what great penance did his father beget him," is the benefit which a son should render to his father.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To sire, what best requital can by grateful child be done?
To make men say, 'what merit gained the father such a son?'
Various Translators: The son’s duty to his father is to make the world ask, “By what great austerities did he merit such a son?”
Dinamalar:
The son's duty to his father is to make world ask,
By what austerities did he merit such a son!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Can love be latched and hidden?
A trickling tear will proclaim it loud.
Transliteration:
Can love be latched and hidden?A trickling
tear will proclaim it loud.
T.Kannan: Is there any fastening that can shut in love ? Tears of the affectionate will publish the love that is within.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Can there be a latch to lock in and hide love? It will reveal itself through tears when a loved one is in trouble.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Anpirkum Unto Ataikkundhaazh
Aarvalar
Punkaneer Poosal Tharum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What bolt can bar true love in fact 
The trickling tears reveal the heart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
And is there bar that can even love restrain?
The tiny tear shall make the lover's secret plain.
Various Translators: Can any lock keep love confined within, when the loving heart’s tiny tears escape and confess it?
Dinamalar: Is there a bolt to fasten one’s love? The trickling tears at the distress of one’s friends will proclaim the love within.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The unloving belong only to themselves,
But the loving belong to others to their very bones.
Transliteration: Those who are destitute of love appropriate all they have to themselves; but those who possess love cons ider even their bones to belong to others.
T.Kannan:
The unloving belong only to themselves,
But the loving belong to others to their very bones.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Loveless people hold everything to themselves. Those who are filled with love bear even their bones for others.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Anpilaar Ellaam Thamakkuriyar
Anputaiyaar
Enpum Uriyar Pirarkku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To selves belong the loveless ones;
To oth'rs the loving e'en to bones.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The loveless to themselves belong alone;
The loving men are other's to the very bone.
Various Translators: The unloving belong only to themselves, but the loving belong to others to their very bones.
Dinamalar: The loveless are full of themselves but the loving lay down their lives for others.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
They say it is to know the union with love
That the soul takes union with the body.
Transliteration: They say that the union of soul and body in man is the fruit of the union of love and virtue (in a former birth).
T.Kannan:
They say it is to know the union with love
That the soul takes union with the body.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Precious life is associated with the body Since love is associated with the way of life, they say.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Anpotu Iyaindha Vazhakkenpa
Aaruyirkku
Enpotu Iyaindha Thotarpu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Soul is encased in frame of bone 
To taste the life of love alone.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Of precious soul with body's flesh and bone,
The union yields one fruit, the life of love alone.
Various Translators: They say the endless incarnation of one’s spirit is for the fulfilment of love.
Dinamalar: They say it is to know union with love that the soul takes union with the body.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Love begets desire: and that begets
The priceless excellence called friendship.
Transliteration: Love begets desire: and that (desire) begets the immeasureable excellence of friendship.
T.Kannan:
Love begets desire: and that begets The
priceless excellence called friendship.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Love yields affection for all, which leads to invaluable friendships.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
AnpuEenum Aarvam Utaimai Adhueenum
NanpuEnnum Naataach Chirappu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Love yields aspiration and thence 
Friendship springs up in excellence.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Out of love springs kindness. It in turn grows into inestimable prize of friendship.
Various Translators:
From love fond yearning springs for union sweet of minds;
And that the bond of rare excelling friendship binds.
Dinamalar: Love makes one affectionate toward all, and affection affords the priceless treasure of friendship.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: They say love’s greatness is this: it yields to good families worldly happiness here and heavenly bliss hereafter.
Transliteration: They say that the felicity which those who, after enjoying the pleasure (of the conjugal state) in this world, obtain in heaven is the result of their domestic state imbued with love.
T.Kannan:
The excellence of worldly happiness, they say,
Is attained by those leading a loving life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The excellence of worldly happiness, they
say, Is attained by those leading a loving life.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The joy of heaven is but the fruit of righteous life rooted in love.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The honour for those who found joy in this world Is the result of leading a life of love, it’s said.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Anputru Amarndha Vazhakkenpa
Vaiyakaththu
Inputraar Eydhum Sirappu
Various Translators:
The crowning joy of home life flows 
From peaceful psychic love always.
Dinamalar:
Sweetness on earth and rarest bliss above,
These are the fruits of tranquil life of love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The uninformed say love abides with virtuous souls, unaware that love is also friend to those immersed in vice.
Transliteration: The ignorant say that love is an ally to virtue only, but it is also a help to get out of vice.
T.Kannan:
Love supports virtue alone, say the fools.
It supports vice as well.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The ignorant say that kindness is an ally of virtue. No, it is a defence against evil too.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Love supports virtue alone', say the
fools.It supports vice as well.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The ignorant think that love is needed only for righteous deeds; they know not that love is an ally for bravery too.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Araththirke Anpusaar Penpa Ariyaar
Maraththirkum Aqdhe Thunai
Various Translators:
"Love is virtue's friend" say know nots
It helps us against evil plots.
Dinamalar:
The unwise deem love virtue only can sustain,
It also helps the man who evil would restrain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
As sun's fierce ray dries up the boneless things,
So loveless beings virtue's power to nothing brings.
Transliteration: Virtue will burn up the soul which is without love, even as the sun burns up the creature which is without bone, i.e. worms.
T.Kannan: As the blazing sun dries up a boneless worm, so does virtue scorch a loveless being.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
As the blazing sun dries up a boneless worm,
So does virtue scorch a loveless being.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The sun dries up a boneless body. Likewise the god of righteousness destroys the loveless one.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As the blazing sun dries up a boneless
worm, So does virtue scorch a loveless being.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A life without love will be stung by the righteous conscience like a body without bones that is burnt by the sun.
Various Translators:
Enpi Ladhanai Veyilpolak Kaayume
Anpi Ladhanai Aram
Dinamalar:
Justice burns the loveless form
Like solar blaze the boneless worm.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The domestic state of that man whose mind is without love is like the flourishing of a withered tree upon the parched desert.
Transliteration:
The loveless soul, the very joys of life may know,
When flowers, in barren soil, on sapless trees, shall blow.
T.Kannan: Life without love in the heart is like a sapless tree in a barren desert.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The life of a loveless soul is a sapless tree
In a barren desert failing to shoot.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: To live a life void of love is like a withered tree bursting into leaf in a barren land.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The life of a loveless soul is a sapless
tree In a barren desert failing to shoot.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A life without love in the heart is as futile as a dried-up tree blossoming in a desert.
Various Translators:
Anpakath Thillaa Uyirvaazhkkai
Vanpaarkan
Vatral Marandhalirth Thatru
Dinamalar:
Life bereft of love is gloom
Can sapless tree in desert bloom?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Love is the heart which limbs must move, 
Or vain the outer parts will prove.
Transliteration:
