Though every outward part complete, the body's fitly framed;
What good, when soul within, of love devoid, lies halt and maimed?
T.Kannan: What good is a body perfect in outer ways, if inwardly it is impaired by lack of love?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: What profits one’s outward feature if one's heart is devoid of love?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Of what avail is body frame - the external,
To those who lack love - the internal?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Of what avail is body frame - the
external, To those who lack love - the internal?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Of what avail are all the external members (of the body) to those who are destitute of love, the internal member.
Various Translators: What useful things can external body parts do, if the heart is devoid of love.
Dinamalar:
Puraththurup Pellaam Evanseyyum
Yaakkai
Akaththuruppu Anpi Lavarkku

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Only a person who follows the path of love, is in a state of living; else it is just a skeleton dressed with skin.
Transliteration:
Anpin Vazhiyadhu Uyirnilai
Aqdhilaarkku
Enpudhol Porththa Utampu
T.Kannan:
The seat of life is love alone; 
Or beings are but skin and bone!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Bodies of loveless men are bony framework clad with skin;
Then is the body seat of life, when love resides within.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: With love enshrined in the heart, one truly lives. Without it, the body is but bones encased in skin.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: That body where love dwells is the seat of life; all others are but skin-clad bones.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The throb of life is love. Without it,
Humans are bodies of bones clad with skin.
Various Translators: That body alone which is inspired with love contains a living soul: if void of it, (the body) is bone overlaid with skin.
Dinamalar:
The throb of life is love.Without it,
Humans are bodies of bones clad with skin.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The purpose of nurturing wealth and leading a family life, is to be able to be hospitable to guests.
Transliteration:
Irundhompi Ilvaazhva Thellaam
Virundhompi
Velaanmai Seydhar Poruttu
T.Kannan:
Men set up home, toil and earn 
To tend the guests and do good turn.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
All household cares and course of daily life have this in view.
Guests to receive with courtesy, and kindly acts to do.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: To keep house and to acquire wealth is only to minister to guests.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The whole purpose of earning wealth and maintaining a home is to provide hospitality to guests.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
It is to exercise the benevolence of hospitality
That people earn a living and establish homes.
Various Translators: The whole design of living in the domestic state and laying up (property) is (to be able) to exercise the benevolence of hospitality.
Dinamalar:
It is to exercise the benevolence of
hospitality That people earn a living and establish
homes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
With a guest outside, it is wrong to eat
alone, Even the nectar of immortality.
Transliteration: Even if you have nectar that will assure immortality, it is not appreciable to dine alone, leaving the guests out.
T.Kannan:
Virundhu Puraththadhaath Thaanuntal
Saavaa
Marundheninum Ventarpaar Randru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To keep out guests cannot be good
Albeit you eat nectar like food.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: With a guest waiting it would not be proper to eat even though it were nectar.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though food of immortality should crown the board,
Feasting alone, the guests without unfed, is thing abhorred.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When a guest is in the home, it is improper to hoard one’s meal, even if it happens to be the nectar of immortality.
Various Translators:
With a guest outside, it is wrong to eat alone,
Even the nectar of immortality.
Dinamalar: It is not fit that one should wish his guests to be outside (his house) even though he were eating the food of immortality.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
His life won’t suffer from want, Who
always cherishes his flowing guests.
Transliteration: A life of one who daily looks after the incoming guests will never suffer from poverty.
T.Kannan: One who is hospitable to guests everyday never suffers because of that.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Varuvirundhu Vaikalum Ompuvaan
Vaazhkkai
Paruvandhu Paazhpatudhal Indru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who tends his guests day in and out 
His life in want never wears out.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Each day he tends the coming guest with kindly care;
Painless, unfailing plenty shall his household share.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If a man cares daily for those who come to him, his life will never suffer the grievous ruin of poverty.
Various Translators: The domestic life of the man that daily entertains the guests who come to him shall not be laid waste by poverty.
Dinamalar:
His life won’t suffer from want,
Who always cherishes his flowing guests.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Fortune smiles on the house of one who entertains with cheerful face worthy guests.
Transliteration:
The goddess of fortune will dwell in the
house of one Who plays host with a smile.
T.Kannan: The Goddess of wealth will reside happily with someone who attends to his guests with a smile on the face.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Akanamarndhu Seyyaal Uraiyum
Mukanamarndhu
Nalvirundhu Ompuvaan Il
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The goddess of wealth will gladly rest
Where smiles welcome the worthy guest.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
With smiling face he entertains each virtuous guest;
'Fortune'with gladsome mind shall in his dwelling rest.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Wealth’s Goddess dwells in the hospitable home of those who host guests with a smiling face.
Various Translators: Lakshmi with joyous mind shall dwell in the house of that man who, with cheerful countenance, entertains the good as guests.
Dinamalar:
The goddess of fortune will dwell in the house of one
Who plays host with a smile.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Does the field of one who partakes of what remains after entertaining the guest, need to be sown with seeds?
Transliteration:
Should his field be sown, Who first feeds
the guests and eats the rest?
T.Kannan: Does one even need to sow his field, if he always eats only what remains after feeding his guests?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Viththum Italventum Kollo
Virundhompi
Michchil Misaivaan Pulam
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Should his field be sown who first
Feeds the guests and eats the rest?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who first regales his guest, and then himself supplies,
O'er all his fields, unsown, shall plenteous harvests rise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Is it necessary to sow the field of the man who, having feasted his guests, eats what may remain ?
Various Translators: If a man eats only after attending to guests’ needs, what further sowing will his fertile fields require?
Dinamalar:
Should his field be sown,
Who first feeds the guests and eats the rest?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He who cherishes the guests who come to him, and looks forward to new guests, will himself be the honoured guest of the gods.
Transliteration:
Who hosts the passing guests and waits for
hosting more Will be hosted by the gods.
T.Kannan: One who is hospitable to his guests, and when they leave, awaits his next guests, will be a welcome-guest in the heavens.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Selvirundhu Ompi Varuvirundhu
Paarththiruppaan
Nalvarundhu Vaanath Thavarkku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who tends a guest and looks for next
Is a welcome guest in heaven's feast.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He who, having entertained the guests that have come, looks out for others who may yet come, will be a welcome guest to the inhabitants of heaven.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The guest arrived he tends, the coming guest expects to see;
To those in heavenly homes that dwell a welcome guest is he.
Various Translators: The host who, caring for guests, watches hopefully for more, will himself be a welcomed guest of those whose home is Heaven.
Dinamalar:
Who hosts the passing guests and waits for hosting more
Will be hosted by the gods.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The gains of hospitality cannot be reckoned.
Their worth depends on the guest.
Transliteration:
The gains of hospitality cannot be
reckoned.Their worth depends on the guest.
T.Kannan: The advantages of benevolence cannot be measured; the measure (of the virtue) of the guests (entertained) is the only measure.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: We can’t quantify the benefits of hospitality; it is limited only by the quality of the guests.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Inaiththunaith Thenpadhon Rillai
Virundhin
Thunaiththunai Velvip Payan
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Worth of the guest of quality
Is worth of hospitality.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To reckon up the fruit of kindly deeds were all in vain;
Their worth is as the worth of guests you entertain.
Various Translators: Charity’s merit cannot be measured by gifts given. It is measured by measuring the receiver’s merits.
Dinamalar: The effects of hospitality cannot be exactly measured. They are proportionate to the worth of the guest.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
We toiled, stored and lost, lament those
Who never sacrificed for hospitality.
Transliteration: Those who have taken no part in the benevolence of hospitality shall (at length lament) saying, "we have laboured and laid up wealth and are now without support."
T.Kannan:
We toiled, stored and lost', lament those
Who never sacrificed for hospitality.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who dont take up hospitality as a spiritual ritual, will later repent that they have lost the wealth they loved.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Parindhompip Patratrem Enpar
Virundhompi
Velvi Thalaippataa Thaar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who loathe guest service one day cry: 
"We toil and store; but life is dry".
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
With pain they guard thei stores, yet 'All forlorn are we' they'll cry,
Who cherish is not their guests, nor kindly help supply.
Various Translators: Those who never sacrifice to care for guests will later lament: “We hoarded wealth, estranged ourselves, now none will care for us.”
Dinamalar: Those who have failed in their duties to guests will regret the folly of mere hoarding.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To have no guests is to want amidst plenty:
Such poverty belongs to fools.
Transliteration: That stupidity which excercises no hospitality is poverty in the midst of wealth. It is the property of the stupid.
T.Kannan:
To have no guests is to want amidst
plenty: Such poverty belongs to fools.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: There are fools who choose to be poor despite possessing wealth, by not being hospitable to guests.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Utaimaiyul Inmai Virundhompal Ompaa
Matamai Matavaarkan Untu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The man of wealth is poor indeed 
Whose folly fails the guest to feed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To turn from guests is penury, though wordly goods abound;
'Tis senseless folly, only with senseless found.
Various Translators: To be poor amidst plenty is to despise hospitality. Such folly is only of the ignorant.
Dinamalar: The poverty of poverties is having plenty yet shunning guests. Such senselessness is only found in senseless fools.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Flower aniccham withers when merely smelt.
An unwelcome look is enough to wither a guest.
Transliteration: As the Anicham flower fades in smelling, so fades the guest when the face is turned away.
T.Kannan:
Flower aniccham withers when merely
smelt.An unwelcome look is enough to wither a guest.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The flower, anicham, shrivels when it is smelt. A guest will wilt if the host’s face betrays the slightest twitch.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Moppak Kuzhaiyum Anichcham
Mukandhirindhu
Nokkak Kuzhaiyum Virundhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Anicham smelt withers: like that 
A wry faced look withers the guest.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The aniccam flower withers when smelt, and the guest under a displeased look.
Various Translators:
The flower of 'Anicha' withers away, 
  if you but its fragrance inhale; If the face of the host cold welcome convey,   the guest's heart within him will fail.
Dinamalar: The delicate anicham flower withers when merely smelled, but an unwelcome look is enough to wither a guest’s heart.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Pleasant words, full of tenderness and devoid of deceit, fall from the lips of virtuous men.
Transliteration: Sweet words are those which imbued with love and free from deceit flow from the mouth of the virtuous.
T.Kannan:
The speech of the enlightened is sweet words
Soaked in love, free from pretence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The speech of the enlightened is sweet
words Soaked in love, free from pretence.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Sweet are the words that fall from the lips of those who are full of guileless love and truth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The words uttered by enlightened scholars will only be kind words carrying love and no malice.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Insolaal Eeram Alaiip Patiruilavaam
Semporul Kantaarvaaich Chol
Various Translators:
The words of Seers are lovely sweet 
Merciful and free from deceit.
Dinamalar:
Pleasant words are words with all prevading love that burn;
Words from his guileless mouth who can the very truth discern.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Better than a gift given with a joyous heart are sweet words spoken with a cheerful smile.
Transliteration: Sweet speech, with a cheerful countenance is better than a gift made with a joyous mind.
T.Kannan:
More pleasing than a gracious gift
Are sweet words with a smiling face.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: To speak with a pleasant look is better than to give with a cheerful heart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
More pleasing than a gracious gift Are
sweet words with a smiling face.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To be someone who speaks sweet words with a smile is even better than being philanthropic with a happy heart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Akanamarndhu Eedhalin Nandre
Mukanamarndhu
Insolan Aakap Perin
Various Translators:
Sweet words from smiling lips dispense 
More joys than heart's beneficence.
Dinamalar:
A pleasant word with beaming smile's preferred,
Even to gifts with liberal heart conferred.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
With brightly beaming smile, and kindly light of loving eye,
And heart sincere, to utter pleasant words is charity.
Transliteration: Sweet speech, flowing from the heart (uttered) with a cheerful countenance and a sweet look, is true virtue.
T.Kannan: A kindly countenance and sweet words spoken from the heart are virtue’s way.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
This is virtue: A welcome face, smiling look,
And sweet words from the heart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: To welcome one with a pleasant look and loving words is righteousness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
This is virtue: A welcome face, smiling
look, And sweet words from the heart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To look at someone with kindness, to smile at them and to say pleasant words, is a nice virtue.
Various Translators:
Mukaththaan Amarndhuinidhu Nokki
Akaththaanaam
Inso Linadhe Aram
Dinamalar:
Calm face, sweet look, kind words from heart 
Such is the gracious virtue's part.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Sorrow-increasing poverty shall not come upon those who use towards all, pleasure-increasing sweetness of speech.
Transliteration:
The men of pleasant speech that gladness breathe around,
Through indigence shall never sorrow's prey be found.
T.Kannan: Poverty provoking sorrow will not pursue those who speak joy producing words to all they meet.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Want and sorrow shall never be theirs
Who have a pleasant word for all.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The torment of poverty does not befall those who have a good word to say to all.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Want and sorrow shall never be theirs Who
have a pleasant word for all.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Painful poverty will not afflict someone who speaks only pleasant words to everyone.
Various Translators:
Thunpurooum Thuvvaamai Illaakum
Yaarmaattum
Inpurooum Inso Lavarkku
Dinamalar:
Whose loving words delight each one 
The woe of want from them is gone.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To be humble and sweet words speak 
No other jewel do wise men seek.
Transliteration:
Humility with pleasant speech to man on earth,
Is choice adornment; all besides is nothing worth.
T.Kannan: Humility and pleasant words are the jewels that adorn a man; there are none other.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Humility and loving words are only true ornaments. Others are not.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Humility and pleasant speech constitute one's ornaments.
Other things do not count.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Humility and pleasant speech constitute
one's ornaments.Other things do not count.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Humility and sweetness of speech are the ornaments of man; all others are not (ornaments).
Various Translators: Humility and pleasant words are the true jewels for anyone and not anything else.
Dinamalar:
Panivutaiyan Insolan Aadhal Oruvarku
Aniyalla Matrup Pira

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If one seeks and speaks pleasant words that cause good all around, righteousness resides and harm recedes.
Transliteration:
Allavai Theya Aramperukum Nallavai
Naati Iniya Solin
T.Kannan:
His sins vanish, his virtues grow
Whose fruitful words with sweetness flow.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who seeks out good, words from his lips of sweetness flow;
In him the power of vice declines, and virtues grow.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If a man seeks to do good while speaking sweet words, his virtues will wax and his vices will wane.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Vice wears out and virtue grows in one who speaks kind and wholesome words.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Virtues will wax and vices wane
If one seeks the good and speaks sweet.
Various Translators: If a man, while seeking to speak usefully, speaks also sweetly, his sins will diminish and his virtue increase.
Dinamalar:
Virtues will wax and vices wane If one
seeks the good and speaks sweet.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Speech that is inseparable from sweetness will yield just-consequences and will reflect right virtues.
Transliteration:
Nayan Eendru Nandri Payakkum
PayaneendruPanpin Thalaippiriyaach Chol
T.Kannan:
The fruitful courteous kindly words
Lead to goodness and graceful deeds.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The words of sterling sense, to rule of right that strict adhere,
To virtuous action prompting, blessings yeild in every sphere.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Sweetly uttered words that do good to others will light up the path of virtue.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Words yield spiritual rewards and moral excellence when they do not wander far from usefulness and agreeableness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Helpful words yoked with courtesy
Breed justice and strengthen virtue.
Various Translators: That speech which, while imparting benefits ceases not to please, will yield righteousness (for this world) and merit (for the next world).
Dinamalar:
Helpful words yoked with courtesy Breed
justice and strengthen virtue.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Sweet words free of meanness yield joy,
Both here and hereafter.
Transliteration: A sweet word, said without the slightest spite, will provide delight in this life and the next.
T.Kannan:
Sirumaiyul Neengiya Insol Marumaiyum
Immaiyum Inpam Tharum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kind words free from meanness delight
This life on earth and life the next.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Sweet and inoffensive words yield one happiness both here and hereafter.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Sweet kindly words, from meanness free, delight of heart,
In world to come and in this world impart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Sweet speech that is a stranger to pettiness imparts pleasure not only in this life, but in the next.
Various Translators:
Sweet words free of meanness yield joy,
Both here and hereafter.
Dinamalar: Sweet speech, free from harm to others, will give pleasure both in this world and in the next.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
How can anyone speak harsh words, Having
seen what kind words do?
Transliteration: Why should a man use harsh words, knowing the pleasure that sweet speech kindles?
T.Kannan: Having seen the sweet benefits of pleasant words, why should one utter harsh words?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Insol Inidheendral Kaanpaan Evankolo
Vansol Vazhangu Vadhu?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who sees the sweets of sweetness here 
To use harsh words how can he dare?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who sees the pleasure kindly speech affords,
Why makes he use of harsh, repellant words?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Why would anyone speak cruel words, having observed the happiness that kind words confer?
Various Translators: Why does he use harsh words, who sees the pleasure which sweet speech yields ?
Dinamalar:
How can anyone speak harsh words,
Having seen what kind words do?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Indulging in offensive words and avoiding sweet ones is like prefering the raw to a ripe fruit.
Transliteration:
To use harsh words, when sweet ones are at
hand, Is to prefer raw fruit to ripe.
T.Kannan: To say harsh words when you have nice words, is like plucking an unripe fruit when there are ripe ones.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Iniya Ulavaaka Innaadha Kooral
Kaniiruppak Kaaikavarn Thatru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Leaving ripe fruits the raw he eats
Who speaks harsh words when sweet word suits.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When pleasant word are easy, bitter words to use,
Is, leaving sweet ripe fruit, the sour unripe to choose.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To utter harsh words when sweet ones would serve is like eating unripe fruits when ripe ones are at hand.
Various Translators: To say disagreeable things when agreeable are at hand is like eating unripe fruit when there is ripe.
Dinamalar:
To use harsh words, when sweet ones are at hand,
Is to prefer raw fruit to ripe.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: For the help rendered expecting no return even earth and heaven will prove no recompense.
Transliteration:
Neither earth nor heaven can truly repay
Spontaneous aid.
T.Kannan: A favour done, not as return for another, is more valuable than heaven and earth put together.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seyyaamal Seydha Udhavikku
Vaiyakamum
Vaanakamum Aatral Aridhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Unhelped in turn good help given 
Exceeds in worth earth and heaven.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Assistance given by those who ne'er received our aid,
Is debt gift of heaven and earth but poorly paid.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: (The gift of) heaven and earth is not an equivalent for a benefit which is conferred where none had been received.
Various Translators: The bounty of Heaven and Earth are scant repayment for help rendered though no help was received.
Dinamalar:
Neither earth nor heaven can truly repay
Spontaneous aid.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A help timely, though small, transcends the world.
Transliteration:
A timely help, though small, Is of greater
value than all the earth.
T.Kannan: A timely favour, however trivial its material value is, is invaluable.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaalaththi Naarseydha Nandri
Siridheninum
Gnaalaththin Maanap Peridhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A help rendered in hour of need 
Though small is greater than the world.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A favour conferred in the time of need, though it be small (in itself), is (in value) much larger than the world.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A timely benefit, though thing of little worth,
The gift itself, in excellence transcends the earth.
Various Translators: A kindness done in the hour of need may itself be small, but in worth it exceeds the whole world.
Dinamalar:
A timely help, though small,
Is of greater value than all the earth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The help given without weighing the return,
When weighed, outweighs the sea.
Transliteration:
The help given without weighing the
return, When weighed, outweighs the sea.
T.Kannan: If we weigh the excellence of a benefit which is conferred without weighing the return, it is larger than the sea.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If we delve into the real impact of a favour, done without calculating the returns, it is vaster than the ocean.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Payandhookkaar Seydha Udhavi
Nayandhookkin
Nanmai Katalin Peridhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Help rendered without weighing fruits 
Outweighs the sea in grand effects.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kindness, shown by those who weigh not what the returns may be;
When you ponder right its merit, 'Tis Vaster than the sea.
Various Translators: When help is given by weighing the recipient’s need and not the donor’s reward, its goodness is greater than the sea.
Dinamalar: Help done expecting no return, if weighed will be vaster than the sea.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To the discerning even millet of aid
Is as big as a palm tree.
Transliteration: Though the benefit conferred be as small as a millet seed, those who know its advantage will consider it as large as a palmyra fruit.
T.Kannan:
To the discerning even millet of aid Is as
big as a palm tree.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who know the value of a favour, will not evaluate its worth, even if a favour done is a minor one.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Thinaiththunai Nandri Seyinum
Panaiththunaiyaak
Kolvar Payandheri Vaar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Help given though millet small
Knowers count its good palm tree tall.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Each benefit to those of actions' fruit who rightly deem,
Though small as millet seed, as palm tree vast will seem.
Various Translators: While aid may outwardly seem as puny as a mustard seed, those who know will deem it as imposing as a towering palm.
Dinamalar: Small as millet is the help given, the wise hold it as big as a palmyra fruit.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Not according to the aid but its receiver
Is its recompense determined.
Transliteration: The benefit itself is not the measure of the benefit; the worth of those who have received it is its measure.
T.Kannan:
Not according to the aid but its receiver
Is its recompense determined.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A favour returned, is not to be based on quantum of favour done, but on the magnanimity of the person who did the favour.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Udhavi Varaiththandru Udhavi Udhavi
Seyappattaar Saalpin Varaiththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A help is not the help's measure 
It is gainer's worth and pleasure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The kindly aid's extent is of its worth no measure true;
It's worth is as the worth of him to whom the act you do.
Various Translators: Help rendered is not in terms of the return but its value depends on the receiver.
Dinamalar: Help rendered another cannot be measured by the extent of assistance given. Its real measure is the recipient’s worthiness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Forget not the friendship of the pure,
Nor forsake friends who supported in trouble.
Transliteration: Forsake not the friendship of those who have been your staff in adversity. Forget not be benevolence of the blameless.
T.Kannan:
Forget not the friendship of the pure, Nor
forsake friends who supported in trouble.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Never forget your ties with a flawless person; never forego the friendship of those who stood by you during a distress.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Maravarka Maasatraar Kenmai
Thuravarka
Thunpaththul Thuppaayaar Natpu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Forget not friendship of the pure 
Forsake not timely helpers sure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Forget not the companionship of the pure of heart. Give up not the friendship of those who have stood by you in hour of sorrow.
Various Translators:
Kindness of men of stainless soul remember evermore!
Forsake thou never friends who were thy stay in sorrow sore!
Dinamalar: Never forget fellowship with pure souls, nor forsake friendship with those who aided you in adversity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: For seven lives in seven bodies the grateful will remember friends who relieved their anguish and affliction.
Transliteration: (The wise) will remember throughout their seven-fold births the love of those who have wiped away their affliction.
T.Kannan:
The good remember through all seven births
The friends who wiped their tears.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The good remember through all seven births
The friends who wiped their tears.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The good remember with gratitude, all through seven births, the friendship of those who have wiped out their suffering.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: One would remember the friendship of those who helped overcome a distress, forever, even if there are seven births.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ezhumai Ezhupirappum Ulluvar Thangan
Vizhuman Thutaiththavar Natpu
Various Translators:
Through sevenfold births, in memory fares 
The willing friend who wiped one's tears.
Dinamalar:
Through all seven worlds, in seven fold birth, 
  Remains in mem'ry of the wise,Friendship of those who wiped on earth,   The tears of sorrow from their eyes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is improper to ever forget a kindness, but good to forget at once an injury received.
Transliteration: It is not good to forget a benefit; it is good to forget an injury even in the very moment (in which it is inflicted).
T.Kannan:
To forget a good turn is not good, and good it is
To forget at once what isn't good.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It is not good to forget the benefit received; but it is good to forget then and there the injury done by another.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To forget a good turn is not good, and
good it is To forget at once what isn't good.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: It is not right to forget the help rendered by someone; it is virtuous to forget any harm, the moment it is done.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Nandri Marappadhu Nandrandru
Nandralladhu
Andre Marappadhu Nandru
Various Translators:
To forget good turns is not good 
Good it is over wrong not to brood.
Dinamalar:
Tis never good to let the thought of good things done thee pass away;
Of things not good, 'tis good to rid thy memory that very day.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Effaced straightway is deadliest injury,
By thought of one kind act in days gone by.
Transliteration: Though one inflict an injury great as murder, it will perish before the thought of one benefit (formerly) conferred.
T.Kannan: The deadliest injury is effaced the moment the mind recalls a single kindness received from the injurer.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Even a deadly hurt is soon effaced,
If one recollects a past good turn.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The remembrance of one good act done removes from our mind the sting of a deadly injury.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Even a deadly hurt is soon effaced, If one
recollects a past good turn.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even if a person commits murderous injury, it will be overlooked if he has done one good deed earlier.
Various Translators:
Kondranna Innaa Seyinum Avarseydha
Ondrunandru Ullak Ketum
Dinamalar:
Let deadly harms be forgotten 
While remembering one good turn.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He who has killed every virtue may yet escape; there is no escape for him who has killed a benefit.
Transliteration:
Who every good have killed, may yet destruction flee;
Who 'benefit' has killed, that man shall ne'er 'scape free!
T.Kannan: Having killed every kind of goodness, one may yet be saved, but there is no redemption for those who let gratitude die.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
One may slain every goodness and yet escape,
But no escape for one who slain gratitude.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: There is salvation to those guilty of any other sin; but there is no redemption for the sin of ingratitude.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
One may slain every goodness and yet
escape, But no escape for one who slain gratitude.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: There is salvation for faltering on any virtue but not for ingratitude.
Various Translators:
Ennandri Kondraarkkum Uyvuntaam
Uyvillai
Seynnandri Kondra Makarku
Dinamalar:
The virtue killer may be saved 
Not benefit killer who is damned.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Equity is supreme virtue 
It is to give each man his due.
Transliteration:
If justice, failing not, its quality maintain,
Giving to each his due, 'tis man's one highest gain.
T.Kannan: Justice may be called good when it acts impartially toward enemies, strangers and friends.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: An equity which knows no partiality is in itself a unique virtue.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Justice may be called good only when it acts impartially
Regardless of the class of men.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Justice may be called good only when it
acts impartially Regardless of the class of men.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: That equity which consists in acting with equal regard to each of (the three) divisions of men [enemies, strangers and friends] is a pre-eminent virtue.
Various Translators: Neutrality is a great virtue when one practices impartiality, unfailingly, towards all sections. (Foes, friends, strangers)
Dinamalar:
Thakudhi Enavondru Nandre
Pakudhiyaal
Paarpattu Ozhukap Perin

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The wealth of one who has a balanced view, will remain intact and will last for the next generations.
Transliteration:
Seppam Utaiyavan Aakkanj
Chidhaivindri
Echchaththir Kemaappu Utaiththu
T.Kannan:
Wealth of the man of equity 
Grows and lasts to posterity.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The just man's wealth unwasting shall endure,
And to his race a lasting joy ensure.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The wealth of those who possess justice will not perish; rather it will be their posterity’s soothing security.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The wealth of the upright dwindles not and passes on to their posterity.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The wealth of a just man, without decline,
Passes intact to his posterity.
Various Translators: The wealth of the man of rectitude will not perish, but will bring happiness also to his posterity.
Dinamalar:
The wealth of a just man, without decline,
Passes intact to his posterity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even if some good comes out of the gains generated by being unfair, desist from making that gain.
Transliteration:
Nandre Tharinum Natuvikandhaam
Aakkaththai
Andre Yozhiya Vital
T.Kannan:
Though profitable, turn away 
From unjust gains without delay.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though only good it seem to give, yet gain
By wrong acquired, not e'en one day retain!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Give up ill-gotten wealth though it brings in its train prosperity.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: However prosperous it may seem, all wealth gained by loss of rightness must be relinquished that very day.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though profitable, turn away
From unjust gains without delay.
Various Translators: Forsake in the very moment (of acquisition) that gain which, though it should bring advantage, is without equity.
Dinamalar:
Though profitable, turn away From unjust
gains without delay.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The just and unjust shall be known By what
they leave behind.
Transliteration: Whether a person has been just or unjust in life, will be ascertained by the nature of offsprings left behind.
T.Kannan:
Thakkaar Thakavilar Enpadhu Avaravar
Echchaththaar Kaanap Patum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The worthy and the unworthy 
Are seen in their posterity.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The just and the unjust are known by the progeny.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who just or unjust, lived shall soon appear;
By each one's offspring shall the truth be clear.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: In their offspring one may doubtlessly discern who are the just and who are the unjust.
Various Translators:
The just and unjust shall be known
By what they leave behind.
Dinamalar: The worthy and unworthy may be known by the existence or otherwise of good offsprings.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Adversity and prosperity come and go, But
an unbiased heart adorns the noble.
Transliteration: To hold the scales even unmindful of prosperity or adversity is the ornament of the wise.
T.Kannan: Ups and downs in life are inevitable; noble scholars are embellished by not letting their hearts vacillate in either case.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ketum Perukkamum Illalla Nenjaththuk
Kotaamai Saandrork Kani
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Loss and gain by cause arise; 
Equal mind adorns the wise.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The gain and loss in life are not mere accident;
Just mind inflexible in sage's ornament.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Adversity and prosperity never cease to exist. The adornment of great men’s minds is to remain unswervingly just under both.
Various Translators: Loss and gain come not without cause; it is the ornament of the wise to preserve evenness of mind (under both).
Dinamalar:
Adversity and prosperity come and go,
But an unbiased heart adorns the noble.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even an iniquitous thought spells one's ruin.
Transliteration:
If your thoughts show signs of doing
injustice, Know that misfortune awaits you.
T.Kannan: When the heart falters to think unfairly, be alerted that you are on course for ruination.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ketuvalyaan Enpadhu Arikadhan Nenjam
Natuvoreei Alla Seyin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Of perdition let him be sure
Who leaves justice to sinful lure.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If, right deserting, heart to evil turn,
Let man impending ruin's sign discern!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When his heart forsakes fairness and his deeds turn depraved, a man realizes deep within himself, “I am ruined.”
Various Translators: Let him whose mind departing from equity commits sin well consider thus within himself, "I shall perish."
Dinamalar:
If your thoughts show signs of doing injustice,
Know that misfortune awaits you.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The world despises not the poverty of the just.
Transliteration:
The world will not deem as poverty The low
estate of virtuous men who dwell in equity.
T.Kannan: The world will not think ill of one who has stumbled into poverty because of being fair and righteous.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ketuvaaka Vaiyaadhu Ulakam Natuvaaka
Nandrikkan Thangiyaan Thaazhvu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The just reduced to poverty 
Is not held down by equity.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The man who justly lives, tenacious of the right,
In low estate is never low to wise man's sight.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The great will not regard as poverty the low estate of that man who dwells in the virtue of equity.
Various Translators: Though a man is profoundly impoverished, if he remains just, the world will not regard him as poor.
Dinamalar:
The world will not deem as poverty
The low estate of virtuous men who dwell in equity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Not to tilt like the well poised balance is the grace of the wise.
Transliteration:
To be unbiased like an unswerving weighing
scale Is an ornament for the great.
T.Kannan: Like a weighing scale that is balanced and sways correctly, the grace of noble scholars lies in dispassionate assessment.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Samanseydhu Seerdhookkung Kolpol
Amaindhorupaal
Kotaamai Saandrork Kani
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Like balance holding equal scales 
A well poised mind is jewel of the wise.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To incline to neither side, but to rest impartial as the even-fixed scale is the ornament of the wise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To stand, like balance rod that level hangs and rightly weighs,
With calm unbiassed equity of soul, is sages' praise.
Various Translators: To incline to neither side, like a balance scale’s level beam, and thus weigh impartially is the wise one’s ornament.
Dinamalar:
To be unbiased like an unswerving weighing scale
Is an ornament for the great.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Equity is words without bias
And it comes from a firm, unbiased mind.
Transliteration:
Equity is words without bias And it comes
from a firm, unbiased mind.
T.Kannan: F reedom from obliquity of speech is rectitude, if there be (corresponding) freedom from bias of mind.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It is righteous to speak words that are not deviant; such words are a result of unbiased thoughts that are not deviant.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Sorkottam Illadhu Seppam
Orudhalaiyaa
Utkottam Inmai Perin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Justice is upright, unbending
And free from crooked word twisting.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Inflexibility in word is righteousness,
If men inflexibility of soul possess.
Various Translators: Speech uttered without bias is integrity, if no unspoken bias lurks in the heart.
Dinamalar: Equity is the impartial expression of an unbiased mind.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A merchant's best merchandise
Is tending other's goods as his own.
Transliteration: The true merchandize of merchants is to guard and do by the things of others as they do by their own.
T.Kannan:
A merchant's best merchandise Is tending
other's goods as his own.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Responsible business is when a business-person, caringly, deploys other people’s money as one’s own.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vaanikam Seyvaarkku Vaanikam Penip
Piravum Thamapol Seyin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A trader's trade prospers fairly 
When his dealings are neighbourly.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As thriving trader is the trader known,
Who guards another's interests as his own.
Various Translators: Those businessmen will prosper whose business protects as their own the interests of others.
Dinamalar: To deal with others’ goods as their own is the only true trade among traders.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Self-control takes one to the gods;
Want of it will push one into utter darkness.
Transliteration: Self-control will place (a man) among the Gods; the want of it will drive (him) into the thickest darkness (of hell).
T.Kannan:
Self-control takes one to the gods; Want
of it will push one into utter darkness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Restraint will result in a place among the divine; lack of it will lead to utter darkness.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Atakkam Amararul Uykkum Atangaamai
Aarirul Uyththu Vitum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Self rule leads to realms of gods
Indulgence leads to gloomy hades.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Control of self does man conduct to bliss th' immortals share;
Indulgence leads to deepest night, and leves him there.
Various Translators: Self-control places one among the gods; lack of it leads one to the darkness of hell.
Dinamalar: Self control will place one among the Gods, while lack of it will lead to deepest darkness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Guard self-control as a treasure;
There is nothing more precious in life.
Transliteration: Let self-control be guarded as a treasure; there is no greater source of good for man than that.
T.Kannan:
Guard self-control as a treasure; There is
nothing more precious in life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Preserve your restraint as you would preserve your wealth; for humans, there is no treasure more precious.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kaakka Porulaa Atakkaththai Aakkam
Adhaninooung Killai Uyirkku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No gains with self control measure 
Guard with care this great treasure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: There is no greater wealth than self-control; treasure it as your wealth.
Various Translators:
Guard thou as wealth the power of self control;
Than this no greater gain to living soul!
Dinamalar: Guard your self control as a precious treasure, for there is no greater wealth in life than this.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Comprehending and acquiring self control confers upon one the esteem of wise men.
Transliteration: Knowing that self-control is knowledge, if a man should control himself, in the prescribed course, such self-control will bring him distinction among the wise.
T.Kannan:
Those who follow the wise path of self-restraint
Are conferred with virtuous fame.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those who follow the wise path of
self-restraint Are conferred with virtuous fame.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If one knows the value of self-control and restrains oneself it will bring one fame.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The greatness of one, who is wise and follows the right path by being restrained, will be recognized and appreciated.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Serivarindhu Seermai Payakkum
Arivarindhu
Aatrin Atangap Perin
Various Translators:
Knowing wisdom who lives controlled 
Name and fame seek him untold.
Dinamalar:
If versed in wisdom's lore by virtue's law you self restrain,
Your self repression known will yeild you glory's gain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: More imposing than a mountain is the greatness of a man who, steadfast in domestic life, has mastered self control.
Transliteration: More lofty than a mountain will be the greatness of that man who without swerving from his domestic state, controls himself.
T.Kannan:
More imposing than a mountain
Is the stature of the steadfast and self-controlled.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Loftier than a mountain is the greatness of one who practises self-control.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
More imposing than a mountain Is the
stature of the steadfast and self-controlled.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The stature of one, who doesn’t diverge from the right path and remains restrained, will belittle a mountain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Nilaiyin Thiriyaadhu Atangiyaan
Thotram
Malaiyinum Maanap Peridhu
Various Translators:
Firmly fixed in self serene
The sage looks grander than mountain.
Dinamalar:
In his station, all unswerving, if man self subdue,
Greater he than mountain proudly rising to the view.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To all humility is goodly grace; but chief to them
With fortune blessed,, 'tis fortune's diadem.
Transliteration: Humility is good in all; but especially in the rich it is (the excellence of) higher riches.
T.Kannan: Humility is a precious quality in all people, but it has a rare richness in the rich.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Humility is good for all
But is an added richness to the rich.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Humility becomes all; but it crowns anew the wealthy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Humility is good for all But is an added
richness to the rich.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Humility is a good quality in everyone; in particular, for the wealthy, it is like their wealth.
Various Translators:
Ellaarkkum Nandraam Panidhal
Avarullum
Selvarkke Selvam Thakaiththu
Dinamalar:
Humility is good for all 
To the rich it adds a wealth special.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Should one throughout a single birth, like a tortoise keep in his five senses, the fruit of it will prove a safe-guard to him throughout the seven-fold births.
Transliteration:
Like tortoise, who the five restrains
In one, through seven world bliss obtains.
T.Kannan: Like a tortoise withdrawing five limbs into its shell, those who restrain the five senses in one life will find safe shelter for seven.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Like a tortoise, withdraw your five senses in one birth,
To protect you in the next seven.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If one were to withdraw within oneself the five senses like a tortoise, it would afford him protection all the seven births.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Like a tortoise, withdraw your five senses
in one birth, To protect you in the next seven.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If one can restrain his five senses, like a tortoise that retreats into its single shell, it will be a protection through seven births.
Various Translators:
Orumaiyul Aamaipol Aindhatakkal
Aatrin
Ezhumaiyum Emaap Putaiththu
Dinamalar:
Who senses five like tortoise hold 
Their joy prolongs to births sevenfold.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Rein the tongue if nothing else 
Or slips of tongue bring all the woes.
Transliteration:
What'er they fail to guard, o'er lips men guard should keep;
If not, through fault of tongue, they bittter tears shall weep.
T.Kannan: Whatever you may fail to guard, guard well your tongue, for flawed speech unfailingly invokes anguish and affliction.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Whatever else you may not control, control your tongue, lest you should repent your indiscreet words.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Guard your tongue if nothing else;
For words unguarded cause distress.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Guard your tongue if nothing else; For
words unguarded cause distress.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Whatever besides you leave unguarded, guard your tongue; otherwise errors of speech and the consequent misery will ensue.
Various Translators: Even if nothing else can be restrained, one must control his tongue; if not, he will suffer because of the harm inflicted by his words.
Dinamalar:
Yaakaavaa Raayinum Naakaakka
Kaavaakkaal
Sokaappar Sollizhukkup Pattu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even if there is one harm caused by harsh words, all the good caused by other virtuous deeds will also be seen as evil.
Transliteration:
Ondraanun Theechchol Porutpayan
Untaayin
Nandraakaa Thaaki Vitum
T.Kannan:
Even a single evil word 
Will turn all good results to bad.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though some small gain of good it seem to bring,
The evil word is parent still of evil thing.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The goodness of all one’s virtues can be lost by speaking even a single word of injury.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: One would lose the fruits of one’s good actions, if one word of evil were to land another in trouble.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A bitter word, even if said once,
Can undo all the good intended.
Various Translators: If a man's speech be productive of a single evil, all the good by him will be turned into evil.
Dinamalar:
A bitter word, even if said once, Can undo
all the good intended.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A wound caused by fire will heal inside; a scar caused by the tongue never heals.
Transliteration:
Theeyinaar Suttapun Ullaarum
Aaraadhe
Naavinaar Sutta Vatu
T.Kannan:
The fire burnt wounds do find a cure 
Tongue burnt wound rests a running sore.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
In flesh by fire inflamed, nature may throughly heal the sore;
In soul by tongue inflamed, the ulcer healeth nevermore.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The blister caused by fire will heal. But the brand of a bitter tongue will never heal.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The wound caused by fire heals in its time; the burn inflicted by an inflamed tongue never heals.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The wound caused by fire will heal within,
But not the scar left by the tongue.
Various Translators: The wound which has been burnt in by fire may heal, but a wound burnt in by the tongue will never heal.
Dinamalar:
The wound caused by fire will heal within,
But not the scar left by the tongue.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Virtue waits for a timely entry on the
path of one Who curbs wrath and learns self restraint.
Transliteration: Virtue will wait for the moment to adorn one, who controls anger, learns all there is to learn and exercises restraint.
T.Kannan:
Kadhangaaththuk Katratangal Aatruvaan
Sevvi
Arampaarkkum Aatrin Nuzhaindhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Virtue seeks and peeps to see
Self controlled savant anger free.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The God of righteousness seeks one who is on guard against anger and attains self-control through knowledge.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who learns restraint, and guards his soul from wrath,
Virtue, a timely aid, attends his path.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Virtue will wait in the streets to meet a man possessed of learning and self discipline, his anger subdued.
Various Translators:
Virtue waits for a timely entry on the path of one
Who curbs wrath and learns self restraint.
Dinamalar: Virtue, seeking for an opportunity, will come into the path of that man who, possessed of learning and self-control, guards himself against anger.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Discipline is more precious than life
itself, For it is discipline that confers eminence.
Transliteration: Right conduct exalts one. So it should be prized above one’s life.
T.Kannan: Propriety confers prominence; hence, propriety is cherished more than existence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ozhukkam Vizhuppan Tharalaan
Ozhukkam
Uyirinum Ompap Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Decorum does one dignity 
More than life guard its purity.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Decorum' gives especial excellence; with greater care
'Decorum' should men guard than life, which all men share.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Virtuous conduct leads a man to eminent greatness. Therefore, it should be guarded as more precious than life itself.
Various Translators: Propriety of conduct leads to eminence, it should therefore be preserved more carefully than life.
Dinamalar:
Discipline is more precious than life itself,
For it is discipline that confers eminence.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Strive hard to walk in the right path. One finds in it one’s surest ally.
Transliteration:
Strive and preserve good conduct; By any
reckoning, you will find it your sole companion.
T.Kannan: Take painstaking effort to preserve propriety; after researching all there is to, one can conclude, it is the best ally.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Parindhompik Kaakka Ozhukkam
Therindhompith
Therinum Aqdhe Thunai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Virtues of conduct all excel; 
The soul aid should be guarded well.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Searching, duly watching, learning, 'decorum' still we find
Man's only aid; toiling, guard thou this with watchful mind.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: In your striving, be mindful to preserve good conduct. In your deliberations, discover it is your staunchest ally.
Various Translators: Let propriety of conduct be laboriously preserved and guarded; though one know and practise and excel in many virtues, that will be an eminent aid.
Dinamalar:
Strive and preserve good conduct;
By any reckoning, you will find it your sole companion.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Right conduct ennobles one’s family. Bad conduct makes one sink in the scale.
Transliteration:
Propriety of conduct is great birth, And
impropriety will sink into a mean birth.
T.Kannan: Class is determined by propriety of conduct; impropriety will lead to being considered part of an ignoble class.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ozhukkam Utaimai Kutimai Izhukkam
Izhindha Pirappaai Vitum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Good conduct shows good family 
Low manners mark anomaly.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Decorum's true nobility on earth;
Indecorum's issue is ignoble birth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Propriety of conduct is true greatness of birth, and impropriety will sink into a mean birth.
Various Translators: Morality is the birthright of high families, while immoral conduct’s legacy is lowly birth.
Dinamalar:
Propriety of conduct is great birth,
And impropriety will sink into a mean birth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The Brahman may learn anew the Vedas which he forgot. If he were to fall from his estate he would be lost.
Transliteration:
Scriptures forgot can be recapitulated;
Bad conduct debases a Brahmin and his birth.
T.Kannan: One can relearn if he forgets the scriptures; but, a brahmin ceases to be one, when he strays from his decorum.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Marappinum Oththuk Kolalaakum
Paarppaan
Pirappozhukkang Kundrak Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Readers recall forgotten lore, 
But conduct lost returns no more.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A Brahman though he should forget the Vedas may recover it by reading; but, if he fail in propriety of conduct even his high bi rth will be destroyed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though he forget, the Brahman may regain his Vedic lore;
Failing in 'Decorum due,' birthright's gone for evermore.
Various Translators: If a priest forgets the Vedas, he can relearn them. But if he falls from virtue, his high birth is forever lost.
Dinamalar:
Scriptures forgot can be recapitulated;
Bad conduct debases a Brahmin and his birth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Just as jealousy can’t lead to prosperity,
So also impropriety to greatness.
Transliteration:
Just as jealousy can’t lead to prosperity,
So also impropriety to greatness.
T.Kannan: Just as the envious man will be without wealth, so will the man of destitute of propriety of conduct be without greatness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A person who has envy has no wealth; a person who has no decorum has no growth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Azhukkaa Rutaiyaankan Aakkampondru
Illai
Ozhukka Milaankan Uyarvu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The envious prosper but ill 
The ill behaved sinks lower still.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The envious soul in life no rich increase of blessings gains,
So man of 'due decorum' void no dignity obtains.
Various Translators: Prosperity is not for the envious, nor is greatness for men of impure conduct.
Dinamalar: The envious do not prosper; likewise one straying from the right path does not advance.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The strong-willed do not shrink from right conduct;
They know its breach will spell ruin.
Transliteration: Those firm in mind will not slacken in their observance of the proprieties of life, knowing, as they do, the misery that flows from the transgression from them.
T.Kannan:
The strong-willed do not shrink from right
conduct; They know its breach will spell ruin.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The strong-willed don’t shrivel their propriety, knowing the suffering inflicted by impropriety.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ozhukkaththin Olkaar Uravor
Izhukkaththin
Edham Patupaak Karindhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The firm from virtue falter not 
They know the ills of evil thought.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The strong of soul no jot abate of strict decorum's laws,
Knowing that due decorum's breach foulest disgrace will cause.
Various Translators: The firm minded never slacken in upholding virtuous conduct, for they know the miseries brought on by such neglect.
Dinamalar: The strong of mind will not shrink from virtue; for they know that any deviation is wrought with dire consequences.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Right conduct exalts one, while a bad name
Exposes one to undeserved disgrace.
Transliteration: From propriety of conduct men obtain greatness; from impropriety comes insufferable disgrace.
T.Kannan:
Right conduct exalts one, while a bad name
Exposes one to undeserved disgrace.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One attains eminence through decorum; one attains unprecedented infamy due to indecorum.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ozhukkaththin Eydhuvar Menmai
Izhukkaththin
Eydhuvar Eydhaap Pazhi
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Conduct good ennobles man, 
Bad conduct entails disgrace mean.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Tis source of dignity when 'true decorum' is preserved;
Who break decorum's rules endure e'en censures undeserved.
Various Translators: Men of right conduct are crowned with glory. Men of evil ways are covered with disgrace.
Dinamalar: By honest conduct one achieves honorable eminence, while corrupt conduct brings one nothing but blame.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Good conduct sows good,
And from bad springs eternal trouble.
Transliteration: Propriety of conduct is the seed of virtue; impropriety will ever cause sorrow.
T.Kannan:
Good conduct sows good, And from bad
springs eternal trouble.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Good conduct becomes the seed for goodwill and impropriety always yields agony.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nandrikku Viththaakum Nallozhukkam
Theeyozhukkam
Endrum Itumpai Tharum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Good conduct sows seeds of blessings 
Bad conduct endless evil brings.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Good conduct is the spring of happiness. Bad conduct leads one ever to misery.
Various Translators:
Decorum true' observed a seed of good will be;
'Decorum's breach' will sorrow yeild eternally.
Dinamalar: Good conduct is the seed in virtue’s field; wicked conduct’s harvest is never ending sorrow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Men who conduct themselves virtuously are incapable of voicing harmful words, even forgetfully.
Transliteration: Those who study propriety of conduct will not speak evil, even forgetfully.
T.Kannan:
Men of good conduct cannot speak ill
Even by a slip of tongue.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Men of good conduct cannot speak ill Even
by a slip of tongue.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It is difficult for a man of right conduct to utter evil words even in a forgetful mood.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those who practice propriety find it impossible to utter harmful words even forgetfully.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ozhukka Mutaiyavarkku Ollaave Theeya
Vazhukkiyum Vaayaar Solal
Various Translators:
Foul words will never fall from lips 
Of righteous men even by slips.
Dinamalar:
It cannot be that they who 'strict decorum's' law fulfil,
E'en in forgetful mood, should utter words of ill.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who cannot live in harmony with the world, though they have learned many things, are still ignorant.
Transliteration: Those who know not how to act agreeably to the world, though they have learnt many things, are still ignorant.
T.Kannan:
Those are fools, however learned,
Who have not learnt to walk with the world.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who cannot move in harmony with the world are learned fools.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Those are fools, however learned, Who have
not learnt to walk with the world.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those who don’t learn to abide by the decorous norms of the society, even if well-read, are unwise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ulakaththotu Otta Ozhukal Palakatrum
Kallaar Arivilaa Thaar
Various Translators:
Though read much they are ignorant 
Whose life is not world accordant.
Dinamalar:
Who know not with the world in harmony to dwell,
May many things have learned, but nothing well.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who laws of virtue and possession's rights have known,
Indulge no foolish love of her by right another's own.
Transliteration: The folly of desiring her who is the property of another will not be found in those who know (the attributes of) virtue and (the rights of) property.
T.Kannan: Those who know virtue’s laws and marital rights never indulge in the folly of desiring another man’s wife.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those who realize the benefit of virtue
Don't commit the folly of desiring another's wife.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The folly of intriguing with another’s wife is not found in one versed in the laws of truth and wealth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those who realize the benefit of virtue
Don't commit the folly of desiring another's wife.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The indiscretion of desiring another’s wife will not be found in those who are enlightened about virtue and possession.
Various Translators:
Piranporulaal Pettozhukum Pedhaimai
Gnaalaththu
Aramporul Kantaarkan Il
Dinamalar:
Who know the wealth and virtue's way 
After other's wife do not stray.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Among all those who stand on the outside of virtue, there are no greater fools than those who stand outside their neighbour's door.
Transliteration:
No fools, of all that stand from virtue's pale shut out,
Like those who longing lurk their neighbour's gate without.
T.Kannan: Among those who stand outside virtue, there is no greater fool than he who stands with a lustful heart outside another’s gate.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
No sinner so foolish as he who lurks
At the door of another's wife.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Among those who walk in the ways of sin, the most foolish are those who stand at the entrance of another’s (house).
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No sinner so foolish as he who lurks At
the door of another's wife.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Of all those who have been beyond the boundaries of morality, there are no greater imbeciles than those who go after another’s wife.
Various Translators:
Arankatai Nindraarul Ellaam
Pirankatai
Nindraarin Pedhaiyaar Il
Dinamalar:
He is the worst law breaking boor
Who haunts around his neighbour's door.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The vile are dead who evil aim 
And put faithful friends' wives to shame.
Transliteration:
They 're numbered with the dead, e'en while they live how otherwise?
With wife of sure confiding friend who evil things devise.
T.Kannan: No different from the dead are those who wickedly desire the wife of a friend.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: They are as good as dead who misbehave towards the wives of their confiding friends.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
No different from the dead are those
Who wickedly desire the wife of a friend.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No different from the dead are those Who
wickedly desire the wife of a friend.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Certainly they are no better than dead men who desire evil towards the wife of those who undoubtingly confide in them.
Various Translators: A person is not any better than the dead, when he indulges in adultery with the wife of another who trusts him.
Dinamalar:
Vilindhaarin Verallar Mandra
ThelindhaarilTheemai
Purindhu Ozhuku Vaar

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: What worth is one’s reputation, however big it is, when, without considering the least bit, he has an affair with another’s wife.
Transliteration:
Enaiththunaiyar Aayinum Ennaam
Thinaiththunaiyum
Theraan Piranil Pukal
T.Kannan:
Their boasted greatness means nothing
When to another's wife they cling.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
How great soe'er they be, what gain have they of life,
Who, not a whit reflecting, seek a neighbour's wife.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Though a man’s measure be mountainous, what good is it if, without the minutest concern, he takes another’s wife?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: What avails one’s greatness if one desecrates the sanctity of the house of another reckless of the consequences.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What does greatness avail if one without even least guilt
Goes into another's home?
Various Translators: However great one may be, what does it avail if, without at all considering his guilt, he goes unto the wife of another ?
Dinamalar:
What does greatness avail if one without
even least guilt Goes into another's home?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One who indulges in adultery with another’s wife, considering it to be simple (without anticipating the consequences), will beget a blame that will stay forever.
Transliteration:
Elidhena Illirappaan Eydhumenj
Gnaandrum
Viliyaadhu Nirkum Pazhi
T.Kannan:
Who trifles with another's wife 
His guilty stain will last for life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Mere triflel' saying thus, invades the home; so he ensures.
A gain of guilt that deathless aye endures.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who invades (easily) the house of another thinking it a mere trifie will incur eternal infamy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A man who seduces another man’s wife, knowing she is easy, suffers a shame that neither dies nor diminishes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Erring with another's wife may seem easy,
But disgrace will be irredeemable for all time.
Various Translators: He who thinks lightly of going into the wife of another acquires guilt that will abide with him imperishably and for ever.
Dinamalar:
Erring with another's wife may seem easy,
But disgrace will be irredeemable for all time.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The adulterer has no respite from these
four: Hatred, sin, fear and disgrace.
Transliteration: Animosity, sin, fear and vengeance. these four will never leave one with a liaison with another’s wife.
T.Kannan:
Pakaipaavam Achcham Pazhiyena
Naankum
Ikavaavaam Illirappaan Kan
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Hatred, sin, fear, and shame these four 
Stain adulterers ever more.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Four evils, enmity, sin, fear and disgrace dog one who covets another’s wife.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who home invades, from him pass nevermore,
Hatred and sin, fear, foul disgrace; these four.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Hatred, sin, fear and disgrace—these four never forsake the man who commits adultery.
Various Translators:
The adulterer has no respite from these four:
Hatred, sin, fear and disgrace.
Dinamalar: Hatred, sin, fear, disgrace; these four will never leave him who goes in to his neighbour's wife.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
He is a virtuous householder Who does not
covet another's wife.
Transliteration: He is a true householder who does not love another man’s wife.
T.Kannan: One, who leads a righteous family life, will not crave the feminine grace of another’s wife.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Araniyalaan Ilvaazhvaan Enpaan
Piraniyalaal
Penmai Nayavaa Thavan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
He is the righteous householder 
His neighbour's wife who covets never.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who sees the wife, another's own with no desiring eye
In sure domestic bliss he dwelleth ever virtuously.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He is decreed a worthy householder who holds no desire for the womanly charms of another’s wife.
Various Translators: He who desires not the womanhood of her who should walk according to the will of another will be praised as a virtuous house-holder.
Dinamalar:
He is a virtuous householder
Who does not covet another's wife.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The heroic manhood that does not lust after another’s wife is to the wise not mere virtue but the very law of their being.
Transliteration:
The manliness that scorns adultery Is both
virtue and propriety for the great.
T.Kannan: The magnanimous machismo of not coveting another’s wife is, for noble scholars, an exalted virtue and decent decorum.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Piranmanai Nokkaadha Peraanmai
Saandrorkku
Aranondro Aandra Vozhukku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
They lead a high souled manly life 
The pure who eye not another's wife.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Manly excellence, that looks not on another's wife,
Is not virtue merely, 'tis full 'propriety' of life.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The chivalry that does not look upon another’s wife is not mere virtue—it is saintly conduct.
Various Translators: That noble manliness which looks not at the wife of another is the virtue and dignity of the great.
Dinamalar:
The manliness that scorns adultery
Is both virtue and propriety for the great.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Verily he is a gentleman on this sea-girt earth who is free from the sin of adultery.
Transliteration:
Who deserves all the good in this world?
He who clasps not the arms of another's wife!
T.Kannan: Whosoever deserves all the good in this world, surrounded by the fearsome ocean, will never surrender on the shoulders of a woman who belongs to another.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nalakkuriyaar Yaarenin Naamaneer
Vaippin
Pirarkkuriyaal Tholdhoyaa Thaar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Good in storm bound earth is with those
Who clasp not arms of another's spouse.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who 're good indeed, on earth begirt by ocean's gruesome tide?
The men who touch not her that is another's bride.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Is it asked, "who are those who shall obtain good in this world surrounded by the terror-producing sea ?" Those who touch not the shoulder of her who belongs to another.
Various Translators: In a world encircled by the awesome sea, to whom do good things belong? To men never impassioned to caress a married woman.
Dinamalar:
Who deserves all the good in this world?
He who clasps not the arms of another's wife!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One may be guilty of any other sins; let one be free from adultery.
Transliteration:
You may trespass the bounds of other
virtues, But not the bounds of another's wife.
T.Kannan: Even if one is unrighteous and does many a misdeed, he should, atleast, not fall for the feminine charm of another’s wife.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aranvaraiyaan Alla Seyinum
Piranvaraiyaal
Penmai Nayavaamai Nandru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Sinners breaking virtue's behest 
Lust not for another's wife at least.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Though a man perform no virtuous deeds and commit (every) vice, it will be well if he desire not the womanhood of her who is within the limit (of the house) of another.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though virtue's bounds he pass, and evil deeds hath wrought;
At least, 'tis good if neighbour's wife he covet not.
Various Translators: Though a man deserts virtue and indulges in vice, he keeps some decency by not wanting another’s wife’s womanliness.
Dinamalar:
You may trespass the bounds of other virtues,
But not the bounds of another's wife.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To bear insults is best, like the earth
Which bears and maintains its diggers.
Transliteration:
To bear insults is best, like the earth
Which bears and maintains its diggers.
T.Kannan: To bear with those who revile us, just as the earth bears up those who dig it, is the first of virtues.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Like the earth that bears even those who till it, supreme virtue is to be patient with one’s deriders.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Akazhvaaraith Thaangum Nilampolath
Thammai
Ikazhvaarp Poruththal Thalai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As earth bears up with diggers too 
To bear revilers is prime virtue.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As earth bears up the men who delve into her breast,
To bear with scornful men of virtues is the best.
Various Translators: Just as the Earth bears those who dig into her, it is best to bear with those who despise us.
Dinamalar: The earth sustains even those who dig into her. To bear with those who slander us is the crown of virtue.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Forgive transgressions always,
Better still forget them.
Transliteration: Bear with reproach even when you can retaliate; but to forget it will be still better than that.
T.Kannan:
Forgive transgressions always, Better
still forget them.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One should always tolerate a transgression; it is even better to forget it.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Poruththal Irappinai Endrum Adhanai
Maraththal Adhaninum Nandru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Forgive insults is a good habit 
Better it is to forget it.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Forgiving trespasses is good always;
Forgetting them hath even higher praise.
Various Translators: It is always good to endure injuries done to you, but to forget them is even better.
Dinamalar: Put up always with one’s transgressions. Far greater than one’s forbearance is one’s oblivion of them.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The want of wants is to be inhospitable,
The might of might to suffer fools.
Transliteration: To neglect hospitality is poverty of poverty. To bear with the ignorant is might of might.
T.Kannan:
The want of wants is to be inhospitable,
The might of might to suffer fools.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Turning away a guest is the most abject poverty; enduring the excesses of a moron is the mightiest might.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Inmaiyul Inmai Virundhoraal
Vanmaiyul
Vanmai Matavaarp Porai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Neglect the guest is dearth of dearth 
To bear with fools is strength of strength.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The sorest poverty is bidding guest unfed depart;
The mightiest might to bear with men of foolish heart.
Various Translators: Poverty within poverty is denying hospitality to guests; grace within grace is bearing with the foolish.
Dinamalar: It is impoverished poverty to be inhospitable to guests. It is stalwart strength to be patient with fools.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If you desire that greatness should never leave,
Foster the conduct of forbearance.
Transliteration: If you desire that greatness should never leave, you preserve in your conduct the exercise of patience.
T.Kannan:
If you desire that greatness should never
leave, Foster the conduct of forbearance.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If you want to lead an unabated fulfilling life, you have to preserve and practice forbearance.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Niraiyutaimai Neengaamai Ventin
Poraiyutaimai
Potri Yozhukap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Practice of patient quality
Retains intact integrity.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If one wishes to maintain character one’s conduct must be marked by patience.
Various Translators:
Seek'st thou honour never tarnished to retain;
So must thou patience, guarding evermore, maintain.
Dinamalar: Desiring that greatness should never cease, let one’s conduct foster forbearance.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Worthless are those who injure others vengefully, while those who stoically endure are like stored gold.
Transliteration: (The wise) will not at all esteem the resentful. They will esteem the patient just as the gold which they lay up with care.
T.Kannan:
Avengers are despised as worthless,
Forbearers are prized as gold.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Avengers are despised as worthless,
Forbearers are prized as gold.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The world takes no note of the avenger but it esteems the patient like gold.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: One who retaliates is not held in high regard; one who is patient is precious as gold.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Oruththaarai Ondraaka Vaiyaare
Vaippar
Poruththaaraip Ponpor Podhindhu
Various Translators:
Vengeance is not in esteem held 
Patience is praised as hidden gold.
Dinamalar:
Who wreak their wrath as worthless are despised;
Who patiently forbear as gold are prized.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The joy of the vengeful lasts only for a day, but the glory of the forbearing lasts until the end of time.
Transliteration: The pleasure of the resentful continues for a day. The praise of the patient will continue until (the final destruction of) the world.
T.Kannan:
Retaliation gives but a day's joy;
Forbearance brings glory for all time.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The delight of the avenger is for a day. The joy of the forbearing lasts till the end of the earth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Retaliation gives but a day's joy;
Forbearance brings glory for all time.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those who retaliate rarely rejoice for a day; the repute of the patient remains till the end of the world.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Oruththaarkku Orunaalai Inpam
Poruththaarkkup
Pondrun Thunaiyum Pukazh
Various Translators:
Revenge accords but one day's joy
Patience carries its praise for aye.
Dinamalar:
Who wreak their wrath have pleasure for a day;
Who bear have praise till earth shall pass away.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Though others work thee ill, thus shalt thou blessing reap;
Grieve for their sin, thyself from vicious action keep!
Transliteration: Though others inflict injuries on you, yet compassionating the evil (that will come upon them) it will be well not to do them anything contrary to virtue.
T.Kannan: Though unjustly aggrieved, it is best to suffer the suffering and refrain from unrighteous retaliation.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though unjustly afflicted by others, pity them
And refrain from unrighteous response.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Resist not a wrong however grievous but forgive out of pity other’s transgressions.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though unjustly afflicted by others, pity
them And refrain from unrighteous response.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even if an untoward evil is done unto you, it is better not to resent and do an unrighteous deed.
Various Translators:
Thiranalla Tharpirar Seyyinum
Nonondhu
Aranalla Seyyaamai Nandru
Dinamalar:
Though others cause you wanton pain
Grieve not; from unjust harm refrain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Let a man by patience overcome those who through pride commit excesses.
Transliteration:
With overweening pride when men with injuries assail,
