By thine own righteous dealing shalt thou mightily prevail.
T.Kannan: Let a man conquer by forbearance those who in their arrogance have wronged him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Let a man conquer by his forbearance
Those who wrong him with arrogance.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Conquer with forbearance one who has done you harm in one’s insolent pride.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let a man conquer by his forbearance Those
who wrong him with arrogance.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Defeat a person who has, out of arrogance, done you harm, by your forbearance.
Various Translators:
Mikudhiyaan Mikkavai Seydhaaraith
Thaandham
Thakudhiyaan Vendru Vital
Dinamalar:
By noble forbearance vanquish
The proud that have caused you anguish.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
More than ascetics they are pure
Who bitter tongues meekly endure.
Transliteration:
They who transgressors' evil words endure
With patience, are as stern ascetics pure.
T.Kannan: Those who patiently endure rude remarks possess the rare purity of an ascetic.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Greater than an ascetic is one who endures the insolent words of the transgressor.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
More pure than ascetics are they
Who bear the insult of transgressors.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
More pure than ascetics are they Who bear
the insult of transgressors.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who bear with the uncourteous speech of the insolent are as pure as the ascetics.
Various Translators: One who, patiently, bears the harsh words of a transgressor, is purer than a puritan.
Dinamalar:
Thurandhaarin Thooimai Utaiyar
Irandhaarvaai
Innaachchol Norkir Pavar

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Great ascetics who conquer hunger, by fasting, are inferior to those who patiently endure the harsh words of others.
Transliteration:
Unnaadhu Norpaar Periyar Pirarsollum
Innaachchol Norpaarin Pin
T.Kannan:
Who fast are great to do penance 
Greater are they who bear offence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though 'great' we deem the men that fast and suffer pain,
Who others' bitter words endure, the foremost place obtain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Great are those who suffer fasting’s hardships; yet they are surpassed by those who suffer hard words.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Great are those who fast and do penance but greater than they are those who put up with insults.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Fasting and penance of the great
Come next only to bearing insults of others.
Various Translators: Those who endure abstinence from food are great, next to those who endure the uncourteous speech of others.
Dinamalar:
Fasting and penance of the great Come next
only to bearing insults of others.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One should make it a righteous way of life, to hold no envy in his heart.
Transliteration:
Ozhukkaaraak Kolka Oruvandhan
Nenjaththu
Azhukkaaru Ilaadha Iyalpu
T.Kannan:
Deem your heart as virtuous
When your nature is not jealous.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
As 'strict decorum's laws,that all men bind,
Let each regard unenvying grace of mind.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let no one have envy; for freedom from envy must be one’s virtue.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The unenvious heart is to be valued no less than virtuous conduct itself.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Deem virtuous that heart of men
Who by nature are not jealous.
Various Translators: Let a man esteem that disposition which is free from envy in the same manner as propriety of conduct.
Dinamalar:
Deem virtuous that heart of men Who by
nature are not jealous.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No blessing is so great as a nature That
is free from all envy.
Transliteration: Not being envious of anybody is a rich reward; there is nothing that can match it.
T.Kannan:
Vizhuppetrin Aqdhoppadhu Illaiyaar
Maattum
Azhukkaatrin Anmai Perin
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
No excellence excels the one
That by nature envies none.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Envy none; there is no other possession greater than one’s freedom from it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If man can learn to envy none on earth,
'Tis richest gift, beyond compare its worth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Among the many precious things a man may acquire, none surpasses a nature free from envy toward all.
Various Translators:
No blessing is so great as a nature
That is free from all envy.
Dinamalar: Amongst all attainable excellences there is none equal to that of being free from envy towords others.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
One who eyes the growth of others with
envy Forfeits the wealth of virtue.
Transliteration: He who envies other’s riches neither loves virtue nor wealth.
T.Kannan: One who, in his envy, doesn’t appreciate the wealth of others, is known not to value virtue and his own wealth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aranaakkam Ventaadhaan Enpaan
Piranaakkam
Penaadhu Azhukkarup Paan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who envies others' good fortune 
Can't prosper in virtue of his own.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nor wealth nor virtue does that man desire, 'tis plain
Whom others' wealth delights not, feeling envious pain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: They say he who is jealous instead of joyous of another’s wealth clearly desires no wealth or virtue of his own.
Various Translators: Of him who instead of rejoicing in the wealth of others, envies it, it will be said "he neither desires virtue not wealth."
Dinamalar:
One who eyes the growth of others with envy
Forfeits the wealth of virtue.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The wise do not commit any wrong out of envy; for, they know the evils that spring from it.
Transliteration:
Those who know the woes of evil deeds,
Dare not do wrong out of envy.
T.Kannan: Those who know of the ills inflicted by envy, will not do anything evil out of envy.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Azhukkaatrin Allavai Seyyaar
Izhukkaatrin
Edham Patupaakku Arindhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The wise through envy don't others wrong 
Knowing that woes from evils throng.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wise through envy break not virtue's laws,
Knowing ill deeds of foul disgrace the cause.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Envy will never cause one to commit wrongful deeds who rightly fathoms the disgrace that follows.
Various Translators: (The wise) knowing the misery that comes from transgression will not through envy commit unrighteous deeds.
Dinamalar:
Those who know the woes of evil deeds,
Dare not do wrong out of envy.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The envious need no enemies to work their own ruin; for they find in their envy their sufficient foe.
Transliteration:
The envious need no other foes; Their envy
is more than enough.
T.Kannan: For destruction to be caused, there is no need for enemies; if one has envy, it will suffice.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Azhukkaaru Utaiyaarkku Adhusaalum
Onnaar
Vazhukkayum Keteen Padhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Man shall be wrecked by envy's whim 
Even if enemies spare him.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Envy they have within! enough to seal their fate!
Though foemen fail, envy can ruin consummate
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To those who cherish envy that is enough. Though free from enemies that (envy) will bring destruction.
Various Translators: A man’s own envy is foe enough to forge his ruin, even if he has no other enemies.
Dinamalar:
The envious need no other foes;
Their envy is more than enough.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The envious that stand in the way of charity perish with their kith and kin.
Transliteration:
A man who envies charitable deeds Will see
his folk perish - naked and starving.
T.Kannan: One who feels envious of the wealth given away as charity, will have even his kin suffer without anything to wear and eat.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kotuppadhu Azhukkaruppaan Sutram
Utuppadhooum
Unpadhooum Indrik Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who envies gifts shall suffer ruin 
Without food and clothes with his kin.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He who is envious at a gift (made to another) will with his relations utterly perish destitute of food and rainment.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who scans good gifts to others given with envious eye,
His kin, with none to clothe or feed them, surely die.
Various Translators: Whoever begrudges another’s bounty will watch his kindred die in poverty, naked and starving.
Dinamalar:
A man who envies charitable deeds
Will see his folk perish - naked and starving.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The goddess of fortune departs the envious,
Introducing him to her elder sister.
Transliteration:
The goddess of fortune departs the
envious, Introducing him to her elder sister.
T.Kannan: Lakshmi envying (the prosperity) of the envious man will depart and introduce him to her sister.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Sridevi, goddess of wealth, will despise a jealous person and direct him to her sister, Moodevi, goddess of poverty.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Avviththu Azhukkaaru Utaiyaanaich
Cheyyaval
Thavvaiyaik Kaatti Vitum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Fortune deserts the envious 
Leaving misfortune omnious.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
From envious man good fortune's goddess turns away,
Grudging him good, and points him out misfortune's prey.
Various Translators: Goddess Fortune, intolerant of those who cannot tolerate others’ success, introduces them to her sister, Misfortune, and goes away.
Dinamalar: Fortune forsakes the envious to her elder sister.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
That sin called envy slays fortune
And leads one to the swirl pool of evil.
Transliteration: Envy will destroy (a man's) wealth (in his world) and drive him into the pit of fire (in the world to come.)
T.Kannan:
That sin called envy slays fortune And
leads one to the swirl pool of evil.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Envy is a damned ill that will destroy one’s wealth and consign him to a fiery inferno.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Azhukkaaru Enaoru Paavi
Thiruchchetruth
Theeyuzhi Uyththu Vitum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Caitiff envy despoils wealth 
And drags one into evil path.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Envy, embodied ill, incomparable bane,
Good fortune slays, and soul consigns to fiery pain.
Various Translators: The wicked one called Envy consumes this world’s wealth, then consigns sinners to those worlds of hellish fire.
Dinamalar: Envy is a deadly sin. It blights one’s fortune and casts one into hell.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The prosperity of the envious
And the poverty of the righteous will be pondered.
Transliteration: The wealth of a man of envious mind and the poverty of the righteous will be pondered.
T.Kannan:
The prosperity of the envious And the
poverty of the righteous will be pondered.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The wealth in the hands of a person with envy at heart, and the destitution of a person, devoid of it, are aberrations that need to be analysed.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Avviya Nenjaththaan Aakkamum
Sevviyaan
Ketum Ninaikkap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Why is envy rich, goodmen poor
People with surprise think over.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To men of envious heart, when comes increase of joy,
Or loss to blameless men, the 'why' will thoughtful hearts employ.
Various Translators: The prosperity of the envious and the adversity of the virtuous afford food for reflection.
Dinamalar: It is worth pondering why good men may be poor while the envious in heart can prosper.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
None has gained through envy,
Nor have the un-envious ever lost.
Transliteration: Never have the envious become great; never have those who are free from envy been without greatness.
T.Kannan:
None has gained through envy, Nor have the
un-envious ever lost.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: An envious person doesn’t ever attain glory; of those who have no envy, there is none who has fallen from glory.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Azhukkatru Akandraarum Illai
Aqdhuillaar
Perukkaththil Theerndhaarum Il
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The envious prosper never 
The envyless prosper ever.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Envy never thrives; fortune never forsakes one who is free from it.
Various Translators:
No envious men to large and full felicity attain;
No men from envy free have failed a sure increase to gain.
Dinamalar: There are no envious men who have risen to prosperity. There are no men free from envy who have fallen from it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: In the very attempt to wrongly gain another’s wealth, a man forfeits his family’s future and his own faultlessness.
Transliteration: If a man departing from equity covet the property (of others), at that very time will his family be destroyed and guilt be incurred.
T.Kannan:
Unjust desire to covet others’ honest wealth
At once ruins home and begets evil.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Unjust desire to covet others’ honest
wealth At once ruins home and begets evil.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Iniquitous coveting of wealth results in the ruin of one's home and brings in its train many sins.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: If, without fairness, you desire to usurp the well-earned wealth of others, it will destroy your family, trigger more crimes and result in guilt.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Natuvindri Nanporul Veqkin
Kutipondrik
Kutramum Aange Tharum
Various Translators:
Who covets others' honest wealth 
That greed ruins his house forthwith.
Dinamalar:
With soul unjust to covet others' well earned store,
Brings ruin to the home, to evil opes the door.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who deem injustice shameful never commit guilt yielding deeds driven by money yielding desires.
Transliteration: Those who blush at the want of equity will not commit disgraceful acts through desire of the profit that may be gained.
T.Kannan:
Those who deem injustice a shame,
Refrain from covetousness that brings blame.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who stand for equity do not commit sinful acts through covetousness.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Those who deem injustice a shame, Refrain
from covetousness that brings blame.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those, who desist being unfair, will not sin, coveting the material benefits of other’s possessions.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Patupayan Veqkip Pazhippatuva
Seyyaar
Natuvanmai Naanu Pavar
Various Translators:
Who shrink with shame from sin, refrain 
From coveting which brings ruin.
Dinamalar:
Through lust of gain, no deeds that retribution bring
Do they, who shrink with shame from evey unjust thing.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No deeds of ill, misled by base desire,
Do they, whose souls to other joys aspire.
Transliteration: Those who desire the higher pleasures (of heaven) will not act unjustly through desire of the trifling joy. (in this life.)
T.Kannan: Those who seek immortal bliss will not succumb to immoral deeds that follow desire for fleeting delights.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
They will not sin for fleeting pleasures
Who seek eternal joy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who seek eternal happiness will never commit unrighteous acts through love of low pleasures.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They will not sin for fleeting pleasures
Who seek eternal joy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Craving for the cheap thrills that other’s money can give, one, who seeks TRUE happiness, will not do an unrighteous act.
Various Translators:
Sitrinpam Veqki Aranalla Seyyaare
Matrinpam Ventu Pavar
Dinamalar:
For spiritual bliss who long 
For fleeting joy commit no wrong.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The wise who have conquered their senses and are free from crime, will not covet (the things of others), with the thought "we are destitute."
Transliteration:
Men who have conquered sense, with sight from sordid vision freed,
Desire not other's goods, e'en in the hour of sorest need.
T.Kannan: With senses conquered and sight unclouded by depravity, one will not wish for others’ wealth, even in destitution.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Their senses conquered,
The clear-eyed cite not their poverty to covet.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The spotless wise who have conquered their senses though destitute, will not covet other’s wealth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Their senses conquered, The clear-eyed
cite not their poverty to covet.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: One who is flawless and wise and has mastered all senses, will never feel ‘I’m poor’ and yearn for other’s wealth.
Various Translators:
Ilamendru Veqkudhal Seyyaar
Pulamvendra
Punmaiyil Kaatchi Yavar
Dinamalar:
The truth knowers of sense control 
Though in want covet not at all.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What is one's subtle wisdom worth
If it deals ill with all on earth.
Transliteration:
What gain, though lore refined of amplest reach he learn,
His acts towards all mankind if covetous desire to folly turn?
T.Kannan: What avails a man’s subtle and comprehensive learning, if, crazed by covetousness, he treats others insensibly?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Of what avail is one’s keen and penetrating intellect if one through covetousness acts foolishly?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Of what avail is a keen and sharp intellect,
If greed seizes one to covet?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Of what avail is a keen and sharp
intellect, If greed seizes one to covet?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What is the advantage of extensive and accurate knowledge if a man through covetousness act senselessly towards all ?
Various Translators: What is the use of deep wisdom and broad knowledge, if one acts indiscreetly with anyone, coveting his wealth.
Dinamalar:
Aqki Akandra Arivennaam Yaarmaattum
Veqki Veriya Seyin

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One who seeks to be compassionate and manifests it in virtuous ways, will succumb to destructive thoughts and acts, if he falters and covets others’ possession.
Transliteration:
Arulveqki Aatrinkan Nindraan
Porulveqkip
Pollaadha Soozhak Ketum
T.Kannan:
Who seeks for grace on righteous path
Suffers by evil covetous wealth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though, grace desiring, he in virtue's way stand strong,
He's lost who wealth desires, and ponders deeds of wrong.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Desiring grace and doing his duty, a man who desires wealth but acquires it wrongly is destroyed nevertheless.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even he who treads the path of grace comes to ruin through covetous intentions.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Even he whom grace beckons, if beckoned by greed,
Will perish beckoned with evil.
Various Translators: If he, who through desire of the virtue of kindness abides in the domestic state i.e., the path in which it may be obtained, covet (the property of others) and think of evil methods (to obtain it), he will perish.
Dinamalar:
Even he whom grace beckons, if beckoned by
greed, Will perish beckoned with evil.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Do not covet others’ wealth; on fruition, the consequences are always contemptible.
Transliteration:
Ventarka Veqkiyaam Aakkam Vilaivayin
Maantar Karidhaam Payan
T.Kannan:
Shun the fruit of covetousness 
All its yield is inglorious.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seek not increase by greed of gain acquired;
That fruit matured yeilds never good desired.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Covet not other’s wealth for out of covetousness spring evils.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Do not seek the fortune that greed gathers, for its fruit is bitter on the day of enjoyment.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Avoid wealth though greed.
Out of it comes no good.
Various Translators: Desire not the gain of covetousness. In the enjoyment of its fruits there is no glory.
Dinamalar:
Avoid wealth though greed. Out of it comes
no good.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Do not covet another's wealth If you would
keep your own un-shrunk.
Transliteration: How will one’s wealth never shrink? By, not desiring to usurp the wealth of others.
T.Kannan:
Aqkaamai Selvaththirku Yaadhenin
Veqkaamai
Ventum Pirankaip Porul
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The mark of lasting wealth is shown 
By not coveting others' own.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Preservation of one’s property lies through one’s freedom from covetousness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What saves prosperity from swift decline?
Absence of lust to make another's cherished riches thine!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To protect one’s own prosperity from decline, one must not crave the property held by others.
Various Translators:
Do not covet another's wealth
If you would keep your own un-shrunk.
Dinamalar: If it is weighed, "what is the indestructibility of wealth," it is freedom from covetousness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Fortune finds the worth and draws near to
those Who know the worth of non-coveting.
Transliteration: The wise who know what is righteous covet not; the Goddess of Fortune would seek them unbidden.
T.Kannan: Wealth will find means to bestow itself on those who, knowing the virtue of not coveting others’ property, wisely desist from it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aranarindhu Veqkaa Arivutaiyaarch
Cherum
Thiranarin Thaange Thiru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Fortune seeks the just and wise 
Who are free from coveting vice.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Good fortune draws anigh in helpful time of need,
To him who, schooled in virtue, guards his soul from greed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Just as wise men know the goodness of noncoveting, so Fortune Herself knows their goodness and draws near.
Various Translators: Lakshmi, knowing the manner (in which she may approach) will immediately come to those wise men who, knowing that it is virtue, covet not the property of others.
Dinamalar:
Fortune finds the worth and draws near to those
Who know the worth of non-coveting.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A blind covetousness brings about one’s ruin. Freedom from it begets one’s triumph.
Transliteration:
Mindless coveting brings ruin. The pride
of freedom from desire yields success.
T.Kannan: Coveting others’ wealth injudiciously will result in dire consequences; one who takes pride in not so desiring will meet success.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Iraleenum Ennaadhu Veqkin Viraleenum
Ventaamai Ennunj Cherukku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Desireless, greatness conquers all; 
Coveting misers ruined fall.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From thoughtless lust of other's goods springs fatal ill,
Greatness of soul that covets not shall triumph still.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: There is a thoughtless desire for others’ things that is destructive. There is a mindful pride that, in refusing to covet, is triumphant.
Various Translators: To covet (the wealth of another) regardless of consequences will bring destruction. That greatness (of mind) which covets not will give victory.
Dinamalar:
Mindless coveting brings ruin.
The pride of freedom from desire yields success.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One may be guilty of wrongful deeds, but let not one be guilty of slander.
Transliteration:
One may not preach or practice virtue, But
not being called a slanderer is pleasing.
T.Kannan: Even someone, who is a sinner and does not speak of virtue, will benefit from never slandering anyone in his absence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Arangooraan Alla Seyinum Oruvan
Purangooraan Endral Inidhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Though a man from virtue strays, 
To keep from slander brings him praise.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though virtuous words his lips speak not, and all his deeds are ill,
If neighbour he defame not, there's good within him still.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though one do not even speak of virtue and live in sin, it will be well if it be said of him "he does not backbite."
Various Translators: Silent about virtue and swift to act wrongly, one who does not slander others may still be called good.
Dinamalar:
One may not preach or practice virtue,
But not being called a slanderer is pleasing.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: More heinous than sin is the deceitful smile of a slanderer.
Transliteration:
Viler than violating virtue for committing
vile, Is to smile before and vilify behind.
T.Kannan: To wear a deceitful smile in one’s presence but to slander him in his absence slaughtering his reputation, is more harmful than refuting all that is virtuous and doing unrighteous deeds.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aranazheei Allavai Seydhalin Theedhe
Puranazheeip Poiththu Nakai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who bite behind, and before smile
Are worse than open traitors vile.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To smile deceitfully (in another's presence) after having reviled him to his destruction (behind his back) is a greater evil than the commission of (every other) sin and the destruction of (every) virtue.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Than he who virtue scorns, and evil deeds perfoms , more vile,
Is he that slanders friend, then meets him with false smile.
Various Translators: More vile than violating virtue and committing crime is slandering a man, then smiling to his face.
Dinamalar:
Viler than violating virtue for committing vile,
Is to smile before and vilify behind.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Better die in virtue than live a life of slanderer
Under false pretences.
Transliteration:
Better die in virtue than live a life of
slanderer Under false pretences.
T.Kannan: Death rather than life will confer upon the deceitful backbiter the profit which (the treatises on) virtue point out.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It is better to die than to live by backbiting and then being hypocritical; so dying, may yield the benefits spoken of by moral scriptures.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Purangoorip Poiththuyir Vaazhdhalin
Saadhal
Arangootrum Aakkath Tharum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Virtue thinks it better to die,
Than live to backbite and to lie.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Tis greater gain of virtuous good for man to die,
Than live to slander absent friend, and falsely praise when nigh.
Various Translators: Virtue declares that dying, not living, will bring better rewards to deceiving backbiters.
Dinamalar: Prefer death to a life of slander; for one finds in it the fruit of one’s virtue.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Better heartless words to man's face
Than thoughtless ones at his back.
Transliteration: Though you speak without kindness before another's face speak not in his absence words which regard not the evil subsequently resulting from it.
T.Kannan:
Better heartless words to man's face Than
thoughtless ones at his back.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It is passable to speak impolitely to someone face to face, but never utter an imprudent word behind the back.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kannindru Kannarach Chollinum
Sollarka
Munnindru Pinnokkaach Chol
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though harsh you speak in one's presence 
Abuse is worse in his absence.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
In presence though unkindly words you speak, say not,
In absence words whose ill result exceeds your thought.
Various Translators: Though you speak unkind words to a man’s face, do not talk behind his back heedless of consequent harm.
Dinamalar: Talk your bitterest to one’s face but abstain from wanton slander.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The meanness in the heart of one posing virtuous,
Shall be known by his slanderous tongue.
Transliteration: The emptiness of that man's mind who (merely) praises virtue will be seen from the meanness of reviling another behind his back.
T.Kannan:
The meanness in the heart of one posing
virtuous, Shall be known by his slanderous tongue.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One, who extols righteousness but is insincere at heart, is exposed when he is devious enough to backbite.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Aranjollum Nenjaththaan Anmai
Puranjollum
Punmaiyaar Kaanap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who turns to slander makes it plain 
His praise of virtue is in vain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The slanderous meanness that an absent friend defames,
'This man is words owns virtue, not in heart,' proclaims.
Various Translators: The tongue of the base slanderer that talks of virtue belies his heart.
Dinamalar: Though his every word is full of kindly virtue, a man’s mean backbiting will betray an empty heart.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
His failings will be found and shown,
If one makes another's failings known.
Transliteration: The character of the faults of that man who publishes abroad the faults of others will be sought out and published.
T.Kannan:
His failings will be found and shown, If
one makes another's failings known.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One who smears another behind his back, opens himself up to similar smear when he falters.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Piranpazhi Kooruvaan Thanpazhi
Yullum
Thirandherindhu Koorap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
His failings will be found and shown, 
Who makes another's failings known.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Ye scandal-mongers, beware of your being scandalized.
Various Translators:
Who on his neighbours' sins delights to dwell,
The story of his sins, culled out with care,the world will tell.
Dinamalar: If a man spreads tales of others’ faults, his own worst faults will be exposed and spread.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Not knowing the companionable art of cheerful conversation, men estrange even friends by divisive discourse.
Transliteration: Those who know not to live in friendship with amusing conversation will by back-biting estrange even their relatives.
T.Kannan:
Those who cannot laugh and make friends
Can only slander and make foes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those who cannot laugh and make friends
Can only slander and make foes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who alienate friends by back-biting may have forgotten the art of making friends through suavity of speech.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Through slander behind the back, one who gets estranged from friends, is incapable of indulging in pleasant talk and gaining friends.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Pakachchollik Kelirp Pirippar
Nakachcholli
Natpaatal Thetraa Thavar
Various Translators:
By pleasing words who make not friends 
Sever their hearts by hostile trends.
Dinamalar:
With friendly art who know not pleasant words to say,
Speak words that sever hearts, and drive choice friends away.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If men are disposed to spread the faults of friends, what deadly harm might they do to strangers?
Transliteration: What will those not do to strangers whose nature leads them to publish abroad the faults of their intimate friends ?
T.Kannan:
What won't they do to strangers
Who broadcast their friends' faults?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who trumpet the faults of their closest friends, what would they not do in the case of strangers?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What won't they do to strangers Who
broadcast their friends' faults?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: If one is known to habitually sully his friends for their faults, what damage would he do unto others?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thunniyaar Kutramum Thootrum
Marapinaar
Ennaikol Edhilaar Maattu
Various Translators:
What will they not to strangers do
Who bring their friends' defects to view?
Dinamalar:
Whose nature bids them faults of closest friends proclaim,
What mercy will they show to other men's good name?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Tis charity, I ween, that makes the earth sustain their load,
Who, neighbours' absence watching, tales or slander tell abroad.
Transliteration: The world through charity supports the weight of those who reproach others observing their absence.
T.Kannan: Only because she weighs duty well does Earth bear the weight of those who wait for a man’s departure to defame him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The earth bears the weights of scandalmongers
Only for the sake of duty.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: How the earth bears the heavy burden of one who scandalises others! Perhaps patience is her virtue.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The earth bears the weights of
scandalmongers Only for the sake of duty.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Out of its commitment to its virtue of patience, the earth tolerates the presence of a slanderer on it.
Various Translators:
Arannokki Aatrungol Vaiyam
Purannokkip
Punsol Uraippaan Porai
Dinamalar:
The world in mercy bears his load 
Who rants behind words untoward

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If they observed their own faults as they observe the faults of others, would any evil happen to men ?
Transliteration:
If each his own, as neighbours' faults would scan,
Could any evil hap to living man?
T.Kannan: If men perceived their own faults as they do the faults of others, could misfortune ever come to them?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Will any evil befall mankind if we can see,
Like others' faults, ours as well?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Will ever harm befall one who looks upon the faults of others as one’s own?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Will any evil befall mankind if we can
see, Like others' faults, ours as well?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If one looks at his faults in the same light as others’ faults, will any harm befell the lingering human lives?
Various Translators:
Edhilaar Kutrampol Thangutrang
Kaankirpin
Theedhunto Mannum Uyirkku
Dinamalar:
No harm would fall to any man 
If each his own defect could scan.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
With silly words who insults all 
Is held in contempt as banal.
Transliteration:
Words without sense, while chafe the wise,
Who babbles, him will all despise.
T.Kannan: Everyone is disgusted by a man who offends one and all with meaningless chatter.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: He who revels in frivolous talk will be despised by all.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To disgust people with empty words
Is to be despised by all.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To disgust people with empty words Is to
be despised by all.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He who to the disgust of many speaks useless things will be despised by all.
Various Translators: Those who make vain discourses, detested by many wise, will be disparaged by all.
Dinamalar:
Pallaar Muniyap Payanila Solluvaan
Ellaarum Ellap Patum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is more harmful to speak vain words in front of many, than to do contemptible deeds to your friends.
Transliteration:
Payanila Pallaarmun Sollal Nayanila
Nattaarkan Seydhalir Reedhu
T.Kannan:
Vain talk before many is worse 
Than doing to friends deeds adverse.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Words without sense, where many wise men hear, to pour
Than deeds to friends ungracious done offendeth more.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Uttering useless words to crowds is worse than committing unkindnesses toward companions.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To talk frivolously in the presence of many is worse than an unjust act towards friends.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Vain speech in public is worse
Than a wrong done to a friend.
Various Translators: To speak useless things in the presence of many is a greater evil than to do unkind things towards friends.
Dinamalar:
Vain speech in public is worse Than a
wrong done to a friend.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One’s gracelessness is exposed by his elaborate hollow speeches.
Transliteration:
Nayanilan Enpadhu Sollum Payanila
Paarith Thuraikkum Urai
T.Kannan:
The babbler's hasty lips proclaim 
That "good for nothing" is his name.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Diffusive speech of useless words proclaims
A man who never righteous wisdom gains.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Indulgence in useless words at once betrays one’s lack of probity.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A long and pointless discourse itself declares to all the speaker’s lack of worth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
He that multiplies empty words
Declares loud his want of worth.
Various Translators: That conversation in which a man utters forth useless things will say of him "he is without virtue."
Dinamalar:
He that multiplies empty words Declares
loud his want of worth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Vain words of inconsequence in an assembly
Rob one of any gain or goodness.
Transliteration: Vain words spoken without dignity to a group, are ungainly, unrighteous and yield no gains.
T.Kannan:
Nayansaaraa Nanmaiyin Neekkum
Payansaaraap
Panpilsol Pallaa Rakaththu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Vain words before an assembly
Will make all gains and goodness flee.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Uttering empty words before all deprives one of one’s sense of justice and mars one’s noble qualities.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Un meaning , worthless words, said to the multitude,
To none delight afford, and sever men from good.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Worthless words are doubly unprofitable: the listeners’ enjoyment is lost, and the speaker’s own virtues vanish.
Various Translators:
Vain words of inconsequence in an assembly
Rob one of any gain or goodness.
Dinamalar: The words devoid of profit or pleasure which a man speaks will, being inconsistent with virtue, remove him from goodness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Men of worth, speaking nonsense, Will lose
greatness and esteem.
Transliteration: If good-natured men speak profitless words, their greatness and glory will disappear.
T.Kannan: Reputation and respect will be lost, when an affable person speaks worthless words.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seermai Sirappotu Neengum Payanila
Neermai Yutaiyaar Solin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Glory and grace will go away 
When savants silly nonsense say.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Gone are both fame and boasted excellence,
When men of worth speak of words devoid of sense.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Prestige and popularity flee the best of men the moment they speak inane and useless words.
Various Translators: If the good speak vain words their eminence and excellence will leave them.
Dinamalar:
Men of worth, speaking nonsense,
Will lose greatness and esteem.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He is not a man but the chaff among men, who indulges in vain words.
Transliteration:
Call him not a man who loves idle words.
Call him rather chaff among men.
T.Kannan: Call him not a man, one who speaks vain words; he is a scum.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Payanil Sol Paaraattu Vaanai
MakanenalMakkat Padhati Yenal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Call him a human chaff who prides
Himself in weightless idle words.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who makes display of idle words' inanity,
Call him not man, chaff of humanity!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Do not call him a man who enjoys displaying his own empty words. Rather, call him the chaff of men.
Various Translators: Call not him a man who parades forth his empty words. Call him the chaff of men.
Dinamalar:
Call him not a man who loves idle words.
Call him rather chaff among men.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Let great men speak untruth; it is better they refrain from uttering useless words.
Transliteration:
Even unpleasant words may be spoken, But
the wise should avoid idle speech.
T.Kannan: A noble scholar may speak ungraciously, if he has to; but he must refrain from speaking vain words.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nayanila Sollinunj Cholluka Saandror
Payanila Sollaamai Nandru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Let not men of worth vainly quack
Even if they would roughly speak.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let those who list speak things that no delight afford,
'Tis good for men of worth to speak no idle word.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Let the wise if they will, speak things without excellence; it will be well for them not to speak useless things.
Various Translators: Let the wise, if they deem it necessary, speak even unpleasant words, but it is good if they always refrain from pointless speech.
Dinamalar:
Even unpleasant words may be spoken,
But the wise should avoid idle speech.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Men of great discernment will never speak words devoid of great import.
Transliteration:
The wise who weigh their worth Refrain
from words that have no grain of worth.
T.Kannan: The wise, who seek to understand deeper significance of things, will not utter words with no substantial worth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Arumpayan Aayum Arivinaar Sollaar
Perumpayan Illaadha Sol
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The wise who weigh the worth refrain 
From words that have no grain and brain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The wise who seek after rare pleasures will not speak words that have not much weight in them.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The wise, who weigh the worth of every utterance,
Speak none but words of deep significance.
Various Translators: Even in search of extraordinary gains, the wise will never speak trivial or ungainful words.
Dinamalar:
The wise who weigh their worth
Refrain from words that have no grain of worth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The clear-eyed and spotless never even forgetfully
Say things that are meaningless.
Transliteration:
The clear-eyed and spotless never even
forgetfully Say things that are meaningless.
T.Kannan: Those wise men who are without faults and are freed from ignorance will not even forgetfully speak things that profit not.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who are flawlessly wise, and have overcome all delusion, will desist from speaking worthless words, even unconsciously.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Poruldheerndha Pochchaandhunj Chollaar
Maruldheerndha
Maasaru Kaatchi Yavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wise of spotless self vision
Slip not to silly words mention.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The men of vision pure, from wildering folly free,
Not e'en in thoughtless hour, speak words of vanity.
Various Translators: The wise, faultless and free from ignorance, never utter pointless words, even forgetfully.
Dinamalar: Men of unclouded wisdom never utter nonsense even in a forgetful mood.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Should you speak, speak useful words.
Never indulge in vain speech.
Transliteration: Speak what is useful, and speak not useless words.
T.Kannan:
Should you speak, speak useful words.
Never indulge in vain speech.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Speak, such that what you speak is worthy; speak not if what you speak is not worthy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Solluka Sollir Payanutaiya Sollarka
Sollir Payanilaach Chol
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To purpose speak the fruitful word 
And never indulge in useless load.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If speak you will, speak words that fruit afford;
If speak you will, speak never fruitless word.
Various Translators: In your speaking, say only that which is purposeful. Never utter words that lack purpose.
Dinamalar: Speak profitable words; avoid nonsense.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The sinful will not dread; the great will dread
The wanton pride of sinful action.
Transliteration: Those who have experience of evil deeds will not fear, but the excellent will fear the pride of sin.
T.Kannan:
The sinful will not dread; the great will
dread The wanton pride of sinful action.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Sinners do not dread, while great men dread the delusion of evil deeds.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Theevinaiyaar Anjaar Vizhumiyaar
Anjuvar
Theevinai Ennum Serukku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Sinners fear not the pride of sin.
The worthy dread the ill within.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
With sinful act men cease to feel the dread of ill within,
The excellent will dread the wanton pride of cherished sin.
Various Translators: Men hardened in sins do not fear evil; but the good dread it.
Dinamalar: Wicked men do not fear, but worthy men dread, the arrogance of sinful deeds.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Evil begets evil and hence
Fear evil more than fire.
Transliteration: Because evil produces evil, therefore should evil be feared more than fire.
T.Kannan:
Evil begets evil and hence Fear evil more
than fire.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Vile deeds yield vile results; and hence, vile deeds are more fearsome than fire.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Theeyavai Theeya Payaththalaal
Theeyavai
Theeyinum Anjap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Since evil begets evil dire 
Fear ye evil more than fire.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Evil is to be dreaded more than fire; for it lands one in disaster.
Various Translators:
Since evils new from evils ever grow,
Evil than fire works out more dreaded woe.
Dinamalar: From evil springs forth more evil. Hence evil is to be feared even more than fire.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To commit no wrong, even against one’s enemies, is said to be supreme wisdom.
Transliteration: To do no evil to enemies will be called the chief of all virtues.
T.Kannan:
The height of wisdom, it is said,
Is not to return ill even to foes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The height of wisdom, it is said, Is not
to return ill even to foes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Not to return evil to those who do evil unto you, is, they say, the crown of wisdom.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The foremost among all wise deeds, is to refrain from doing harmful deeds even to those who detest you.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Arivinul Ellaan Thalaiyenpa Theeya
Seruvaarkkum Seyyaa Vital
Various Translators:
The wisest of the wise are those
Who injure not even their foes.
Dinamalar:
Even to those that hate make no return of ill;
So shalt thou wisdom's highest law. 'Tis said, fulfil.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Only the forgetful plot another’s ruin; others remember that virtue itself devises every plotter’s downfall.
Transliteration: Even though forgetfulness meditate not the ruin of another. Virtue will meditate the ruin of him who thus meditates.
T.Kannan:
Plot not thy neighbour's fall, even forgetfully;
Else, justice will plot the plotter's fall.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Let none plot evil to others even in forgetfulness. If he does so, the God of Righteousness will compass his ruin.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Plot not thy neighbour's fall, even
forgetfully; Else, justice will plot the plotter's
fall.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Desire not the destruction of another, even sub-consciously; else, virtue will determine the destruction of the one who desires so.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Marandhum Piranketu Soozharka
Soozhin
Aranjoozham Soozhndhavan Ketu
Various Translators:
His ruin virtue plots who plans 
The ruin of another man's.
Dinamalar:
Though good thy soul forget, plot not thy neighbour's fall,
Thy plans shall 'virtue's Power' by ruin to thyself forestall.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Make not thy poverty a plea for ill;
Thy evil deeds will make thee poorer still.
Transliteration: Commit not evil, saying, "I am poor": if you do, you will become poorer still.
T.Kannan: Do not commit wrongful deeds, claiming to be poor. Such deeds only cause one to be poorer still.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Plead not poverty for doing ill,
Whereby you will become poorer still.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let none do wrong on account of poverty; if he does so he becomes poorer still.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Plead not poverty for doing ill, Whereby
you will become poorer still.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Don’t commit anything evil in the name of poverty; the poorer, it will render you.
Various Translators:
Ilan Endru Theeyavai Seyyarka
SeyyinIlanaakum Matrum Peyarththu
Dinamalar:
Who makes poverty plea for ill 
Shall reduce himself poorer still.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Let him not do evil to others who desires not that sorrows should pursue him.
Transliteration:
What ranks as evil spare to do, if thou would'st shun
Affliction sore through ill to thee by others done.
T.Kannan: Let one who hopes for freedom from afflictions’ pain avoid inflicting harm on others.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Let him, who seeks to be free from suffering,
Not be a cause of suffering to others.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let not one do evil unto others, if one wants to be free from affliction.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let him, who seeks to be free from
suffering, Not be a cause of suffering to others.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If one wishes not to be tormented by painful reactions, do not harm others.
Various Translators:
Theeppaala Thaanpirarkan Seyyarka
Noippaala
Thannai Atalventaa Thaan
Dinamalar:
From wounding others let him refrain 
Who would from harm himself remain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Men may escape other foes and live
But sin its deadly blow will give.
Transliteration:
From every enmity incurred there is to 'scape, a way;
The wrath of evil deeds will dog men's steps, and slay.
T.Kannan: One can escape from hate filled enemies, but his own hateful acts will pursue and destroy him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: You may escape your enemies but your evil follows you and hunts you down relentlessly.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Escape from other enemies is likely,
But not from the relentless pursuit of evil deeds.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Escape from other enemies is likely, But
not from the relentless pursuit of evil deeds.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: However great be the enmity men have incurred they may still live. The enmity of sin will incessantly pursue and kill.
Various Translators: There is scope for surviving any sort of enmity; but there can be no respite from the repercussions of an evil deed.
Dinamalar:
Enaippakai Yutraarum Uyvar
Vinaippakai
Veeyaadhu Pinsendru Atum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The shadow stays rooted to the foot; the evil that men do will remain to torment them.
Transliteration:
Theeyavai Seydhaar Ketudhal
Nizhaldhannai
Veeyaadhu Atiurain Thatru
T.Kannan:
Ruin follows who evil do 
As shadow follows as they go.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Man's shadow dogs his steps wher'er he wends;
Destruction thus on sinful deeds attends.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: As a man’s shadow follows his footsteps wherever he goes, even so will destruction pursue those who commit sinful deeds.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Evil dogs you close on your heels like a shadow.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The consequences of evil deeds leave not
Like the persistent shadow under the feet.
Various Translators: Destruction will dwell at the heels of those who commit evil even as their shadow that leaves them not.
Dinamalar:
The consequences of evil deeds leave not
Like the persistent shadow under the feet.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If one loves himself, he shouldn’t do an evil act, howsoever small it is.
Transliteration:
Thannaiththaan Kaadhala Naayin
Enaiththondrum
Thunnarka Theevinaip Paal
T.Kannan:
Let none who loves himself at all 
Think of evil however small.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Beware, if to thyself thyself is dear,
Lest thou to aught that ranks as ill draw near!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If one really loves oneself let one not do any harm to others.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: If a man feels any fond affection for himself, let him not indulge in immoral deeds, however trifling.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If you love yourself,
Refrain from causing ill of any degree.
Various Translators: If a man love himself, let him not commit any sin however small.
Dinamalar:
If you love yourself, Refrain from causing
ill of any degree.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Know that no harm shall ever befall the
one Who never strays into evil.
Transliteration: Know a man to be free of torment, if he doesn’t take a shortcut to do an evil deed.
T.Kannan:
Arungetan Enpadhu Arika Marungotith
Theevinai Seyyaan Enin
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
He is secure, know ye, from ills 
Who slips not right path to do evils.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Hardly doth sorrow befall one who does not deviate from right.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The man, to devious way of sin that never turned aside,
From ruin rests secure, whatever ills betide.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If men neither deviate from right nor act wrongly, they will be defended against destruction.
Various Translators:
Know that no harm shall ever befall the one
Who never strays into evil.
Dinamalar: Know ye that he is freed from destruction who commits no evil, going to neither side of the right path.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Duty is not for reward. Does the world
recompense the rain-cloud?
Transliteration: Do not expect any return for the services (duty) done. What does the world give in exchange for the clouds that pour rain?
T.Kannan: Doing one’s duty without desiring any favours, is like rain; what can the world do in return for the rains.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaimmaaru Ventaa Katappaatu
Maarimaattu
EnAatrung Kollo Ulaku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Duty demands nothing in turn;
How can the world recompense rain?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Duty demands no recompense; to clouds of heaven,
By men on earth, what answering gift is given?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The benevolent expect no return for their dutiful giving. How can the world ever repay the rain cloud?
Various Translators: Benevolence seeks not a return. What does the world give back to the clouds ?
Dinamalar:
Duty is not for reward.
Does the world recompense the rain-cloud?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: All the wealth one earns is for rendering help to the deserving.
Transliteration:
All the wealth earned by toils Is meant to
serve those who deserve.
T.Kannan: The purpose of one’s hard-earned money is to be deployed to help the deserving.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thaalaatrith Thandha Porulellaam
Thakkaarkku
Velaanmai Seydhar Poruttu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
All the wealth that toils give
Is meant to serve those who deserve.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The worthy say, when wealth rewards their toil spent hours,
For uses of beneficence alone 'tis ours.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is to meet the needs of the deserving that the worthy work so hard to acquire wealth.
Various Translators: All the wealth acquired with perseverance by the worthy is for the exercise of benevolence.
Dinamalar:
All the wealth earned by toils
Is meant to serve those who deserve.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Is there anything greater than decorum either here or in the world to come?
Transliteration:
Rare it is to find another good equal to
benevolence, Either here or in the heaven.
T.Kannan: In this world and the other, it is tough to attain anything better than beneficence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Puththe Lulakaththum Eentum
Peralaridhe
Oppuravin Nalla Pira
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
In heav'n and earth 'tis hard to find 
A greater good than being kind.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To 'due beneficence' no equal good we know,
Amid the happy gods, or in this world below.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is difficult to obtain another good equal to benevolence either in this world or in that of the gods.
Various Translators: Of all duties, none is better than benevolence, whether in this world or that of the Gods.
Dinamalar:
Rare it is to find another good equal to benevolence,
Either here or in the heaven.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Verily he is alive who is in harmony with the world; others should be ranked with the dead.
Transliteration:
He who realizes what is oneness, lives;
The rest will be placed among the dead.
T.Kannan: One who is aligned to the right ways of the world, lives amongst the alive; the others are placed amongst the dead.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Oththa Tharavon Uyirvaazhvaan
Matraiyaan
Seththaarul Vaikkap Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
He lives who knows befitting act 
Others are deemed as dead in fact.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He truly lives who knows (and discharges) the proper duties (of benevolence). He who knows the m not will be reckoned among the dead.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who knows what's human life's befitting grace,
He lives; the rest 'mongst dead men have their place.
Various Translators: He who understands the duty of giving truly lives. All others shall be counted among the dead.
Dinamalar:
He who realizes what is oneness, lives;
The rest will be placed among the dead.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The wealth of a wise philanthropist
Is a village pool ever full.
Transliteration:
The wealth of a wise philanthropist Is a
village pool ever full.
T.Kannan: The wealth of that man of eminent knowledge who desires to exercise the benevolence approved of by the world, is like the full waters of a city-tank.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The wealth of the wise one who loves, and is loved by, the world, is like a public pond brimming with water.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ooruni Neernirain Thatre Ulakavaam
Perari Vaalan Thiru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wealth that wise and kind do make 
Is like water that fills a lake.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The wealth of men who love the 'fitting way,' the truly wise,
Is as when water fills the lake that village needs supplies.
Various Translators: The wealth of a community loving wise man may be likened to a well filled village water tank.
Dinamalar: The wealth of the wise is a never-failing spring.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When wealth comes to the generous,
It is like the village tree coming to fruit.
Transliteration: The wealth of a man (possessed of the virtue) of benevolence is like the ripening of a fruitful tree in the midst of a town.
T.Kannan:
When wealth comes to the generous, It is
like the village tree coming to fruit.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Riches falling upon the benevolent, resemble a ripe tree laden with fruits, in the middle of a village.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Payanmaram Ulloorp Pazhuththatraal
Selvam
Nayanutai Yaankan Patin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who plenty gets and plenty gives 
Is like town tree teeming with fruits.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A tree that fruits in th' hamlet's central mart,
Is wealth that falls to men of liberal heart.
Various Translators: Riches retained by the big hearted resemble fruits ripening on a tree in the heart of a village.
Dinamalar: The wealth of the truly liberal is like a tree ripening in the heart of a village.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When wealth comes to the large-hearted,
It is like an unfailing medicine tree.
Transliteration: If wealth be in the possession of a man who has the great excellence (of benevolence), it is like a tree which as a medicine is an infallible cure for disease.
T.Kannan:
When wealth comes to the large-hearted, It
is like an unfailing medicine tree.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Riches falling upon a person of great qualities, resemble an unfailing herbal tree that is a source of medicines.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Marundhaakith Thappaa Maraththatraal
Selvam
Perundhakai Yaankan Patin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wealth of a wide hearted soul 
Is a herbal tree that healeth all.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Unfailing tree that healing balm distils from every part,
Is ample wealth that falls to him to large and noble heart.
Various Translators: The wealth of the generous is like a healing medicinal tree.
Dinamalar: In the hands of a generous man, wealth is like a medicinal tree whose healing gifts help all.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those known for their duty will not slacken to help
Even during times of poverty.
Transliteration: The wise who know what is duty will not scant their benevolence even when they are without wealth.
T.Kannan:
Those known for their duty will not
slacken to help Even during times of poverty.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even in times of distress, those who dont shy away from beneficence, have clear vision of their moral responsibilities.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Itanil Paruvaththum Oppuravirku
Olkaar
Katanari Kaatchi Yavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though seers may fall on evil days 
Their sense of duty never strays.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even in poverty the truly discerning never ceases to be liberal.
Various Translators:
E'en when resources fail, they weary not of 'kindness due,'
They to whom duty's self appears in vision true.
Dinamalar: Those who know duty deeply never neglect giving, even in their own unprosperous season.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The benevolent man considers himself poor only when he is unable to render his accustomed duty to humanity.
Transliteration: The poverty of a benevolent man, is nothing but his inability to exercise the same.
T.Kannan:
The poverty of a generous man is nothing but
His inability to exercise his generosity.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The poverty of a generous man is nothing
but His inability to exercise his generosity.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The poverty of the liberal of heart is his failure in the offices of tenderness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A benevolent person turns poor when he laments his inability to do the good deeds he is used to doing.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Nayanutaiyaan Nalkoorndhaa Naadhal
Seyumneera
Seyyaadhu Amaikalaa Vaaru
Various Translators:
The good man's poverty and grief
Is want of means to give relief.
Dinamalar:
The kindly hearted man is poor in this alone,
When power of doing deeds of goodness he finds none.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Were it said that loss of wealth is the price of generosity, such loss would be worth selling one’s self to acquire.
Transliteration: If it be said that loss will result from benevolence, such loss is worth being procured even by the sale of one's self.
T.Kannan:
If poverty comes of doing good,
One's self may be sold to do it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The poverty that results from a just course of action is worth purchasing by going into the very bond of slavery.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If poverty comes of doing good, One's self
may be sold to do it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: What harm can come out of beneficence? Such harm deserves to be bought even by selling oneself.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Oppuravi Naalvarum Ketenin
Aqdhoruvan
Vitrukkol Thakka Thutaiththu
Various Translators:
By good if ruin comes across
Sell yourself to save that loss.
Dinamalar:
Though by 'beneficence' the loss of all should come,
'Twere meet man sold himself, and bought it with the sum.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
call that a gift to needy men thou dost dispense,
All else is void of good, seeking for recompense.
Transliteration: To give to the destitute is true charity. All other gifts have the nature of (what is done for) a measured return.
T.Kannan: Giving to the poor is true charity. All other giving expects some return.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To give to the needy alone is charity;
All the rest is investment for a return.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Gift to the poor alone is true charity. Everything else is of the nature of a barter.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To give to the needy alone is charity; All
the rest is investment for a return.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Giving to the poor is charity; all else have the quality of anticipating a return.
Various Translators:
Variyaarkkondru Eevadhe Eekaimar
Rellaam
Kuriyedhirppai Neera Thutaiththu
Dinamalar:
To give the poor is charity 
The rest is loan and vanity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To beg is evil, even though it were said that it is a good path (to heaven). To give is good, even though it were said that those who do so cannot obtain heaven.
Transliteration:
Though men declare it heavenward path, yet to receive is ill;
Though upper heaven were not, to give is virtue still.
T.Kannan: Though some may declare it a good path, garnering gifts is bad. Even if they say it denies one Heaven, giving gifts is good.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To receive is bad, even for good cause;
And to give is good even if there is no heaven.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Receiving gifts is bad though one is assured of heaven. Bestowing gifts is good, though thereby one should be bereft of it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To receive is bad, even for good cause;
And to give is good even if there is no heaven.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To receive is a vice, even if it is accepted as a good virtue; to give, is good, even if the heaven is denied.
Various Translators:
Nallaaru Eninum Kolaldheedhu
Melulakam
Illeninum Eedhale Nandru
Dinamalar:
To beg is bad e'en from the good 
To give is good, were heaven forbid.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No pleading, "I am nothing worth," 
But giving marks a noble birth.
Transliteration:
I' ve nought' is ne'er the high born man's reply;
He gives to those who raise themselves that cry.
T.Kannan: Men of good birth graciously give, never uttering the wretched excuse, “I have nothing.”
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The innately noble never beg but give ere charity begins.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The mark of the well-born is to give
Without uttering the wretched excuse, I have nothing.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The mark of the well-born is to give
Without uttering the wretched excuse, 'I have
nothing.'
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: (Even in a low state) not to adopt the mean expedient of saying "I have nothing," but to give, is the characteristic of the mad of noble birth.
Various Translators: Charity, without mention of the distress of poverty, is present only in those from a good family.
Dinamalar:
Ilanennum Evvam Uraiyaamai Eedhal
Kulanutaiyaan Kanne Yula

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To be asked to give is bitter too, until seeing the smiling face of the recipient.
Transliteration:
Innaadhu Irakkap Patudhal Irandhavar
Inmukang Kaanum Alavu
T.Kannan:
The cry for alms is painful sight
Until the giver sees him bright.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The suppliants'cry for aid yeilds scant delight,
Until you see his face with grateful gladness bright.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: How unpleasant a beggar’s pleading can become, until one sees his face so sweetly pleased.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even to be begged is miserable for we feel wretched till the beggar’s face is lit with joy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To be begged is agonizing, till you give
And see the smiling face of the beggar.
Various Translators: To see men begging from us in disagreeable, until we see their pleasant countenance.
Dinamalar:
To be begged is agonizing, till you give
And see the smiling face of the beggar.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The strength of the strongest is to endure hunger; it trails the ability to eradicate that hunger.
Transliteration:
Aatruvaar Aatral Pasiaatral
Appasiyai
Maatruvaar Aatralin Pin
T.Kannan:
Higher's power which hunger cures
Than that of penance which endures.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Mid devotees they're great who hunger's pangs sustain,
Who hunger's pangs relieve a higher merit gain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Endurance of one’s hunger is the test of one’s penance. Far greater than that endurance is the spirit of appeasing the hunger of others.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Great, indeed, is the power to endure hunger. Greater still is the power to relieve others’ hunger.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Strong is the strength of enduring hunger,
But stronger still is the strength of relieving it.
Various Translators: The power of those who perform penance is the power of enduring hunger. It is inferior to the power of those who remove the hunger (of others).
Dinamalar:
Strong is the strength of enduring hunger,
But stronger still is the strength of relieving it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Wiping out the hunger of the have-nots, Is
the treasury the haves have deposited their wealth.
Transliteration: To douse the destructive hunger of the destitute, is the safe to store the riches of the rich.
T.Kannan:
Atraar Azhipasi Theerththal
Aqdhoruvan
Petraan Porulvaip Puzhi
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Drive from the poor their gnawing pains
If room you seek to store your gains.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let the rich appease the devouring hunger of the indigent poor. It is a charity rendered unto themselves.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let men relieve the wasting hunger man endure;
For treasure gained thus finds he treasure house secure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Relieving the ravaging hunger of the poor is a right use for wealth men have obtained.
Various Translators:
Wiping out the hunger of the have-nots,
Is the treasury the haves have deposited their wealth.
Dinamalar: The removal of the killing hunger of the poor is the place for one to lay up his wealth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
That dreaded disease called hunger touches
not the one Who shares his food by habit.
Transliteration: The pest of hunger never touches one who shares one’s food with the poor.
T.Kannan: Hunger, the deadly disease, never touches one who is accustomed to share his food with others.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Paaththoon Mareei Yavanaip
Pasiyennum
Theeppini Theental Aridhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who shares his food with those who need
Hunger shall not harm his creed.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Whose soul delights with hungry men to share his meal,
The hand of hunger's sickness sore shall never feel.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The fiery scourge called hunger never touches the man who shares his daily meal with others.
Various Translators: The fiery disease of hunger shall never touch him who habitually distributes his food to others.
Dinamalar:
That dreaded disease called hunger touches not the one
Who shares his food by habit.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The callous rich hide their barren metal; perhaps they know not the joy of giving.
Transliteration:
Unaware of the joys of giving, The
hard-hearted waste their wealth hoarding it.
T.Kannan: Do they not know to enjoy the joy of giving, those loveless people, who keep their wealth only to lose it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Eeththuvakkum Inpam Ariyaarkol
Thaamutaimai
Vaiththizhakkum Vanka Navar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The joy of give and take they lose 
Hard hearted rich whose hoarding fails.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Delight of glad'ning human hearts with gifts do they not know,
Men of unpitying eye, who hoard their wealth, and lose it so?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Is it because they are unaware of the joys of giving that hard hearted men waste their wealth by hoarding it?
Various Translators: Do the hard-eyed who lay up and lose their possessions not know the happiness which springs from the pleasure of giving ?
Dinamalar:
Unaware of the joys of giving,
The hard-hearted waste their wealth hoarding it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: More squalid than begging is a life of self-indulgence.
Transliteration:
To eat alone what one has hoarded Is worse
than begging.
T.Kannan: Eating alone to increase one’s accumulated wealth, is more distressing than begging.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Iraththalin Innaadhu Mandra
Nirappiya
Thaame Thamiyar Unal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Worse than begging is that boarding
Alone what one's greed is hoarding.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They keep their garners full, for self alone the board they spread; 
'Tis greater pain, be sure, than begging daily bread!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Solitary and unshared eating for the sake of filling up one's own riches is certainly much more unpleasant than begging.
Various Translators: More bitter than even a beggar’s bread is the meal of the miser who hoards wealth and eats alone.
Dinamalar:
To eat alone what one has hoarded
Is worse than begging.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Death indeed is the greatest calamity; worse than death is one’s failure in charity.
Transliteration:
Nothing is worse than death; but even
death is sweet If one can't help the poor.
T.Kannan: There is nothing more harrowing than death; that too seems sweet, if one is unable to give a thing to the needy.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Saadhalin Innaadha Thillai
Inidhadhooum
Eedhal Iyaiyaak Katai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nothing is more painful than death
Yet more is pain of giftless dearth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Nothing is more unpleasant than death: yet even that is pleasant where charity cannot be exercised.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Tis bitter pain to die. 'Tis worse to live,
For him who nothing find to give!
Various Translators: There is nothing more bitter than death; yet even death seems sweet when giving is impossible.
Dinamalar:
Nothing is worse than death; but even death is sweet
If one can't help the poor.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No greater income in life than to live with fame
That comes out of charity.
Transliteration:
No greater income in life than to live
with fame That comes out of charity.
T.Kannan: Give to the poor and live with praise. There is no greater profit to man than that.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Give, and live with fame; there is no other gain for lives.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Eedhal Isaipata Vaazhdhal
Adhuvalladhu
Oodhiyam Illai Uyirkku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They gather fame who freely give 
The greatest gain for all that live.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
See that thy life the praise of generous gifts obtain;
Save this for living man exists no real gain.
Various Translators: Give to the poor and become praiseworthy. Life offers no greater reward than this.
Dinamalar: Give and make a name. There is no greater gain to man than such a renown.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The fame of men who give to those in need
Will live for ever in the words of all.
Transliteration: Whatsoever is spoken in the world will abide as praise upon that man who gives alms to the poor.
T.Kannan:
The fame of men who give to those in need
Will live for ever in the words of all.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: All that chroniclers chronicle, is the renown that rests on those who give to the needy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Uraippaar Uraippavai Ellaam
Irappaarkkondru
Eevaarmel Nirkum Pukazh
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The glory of the alms giver 
Is praised aloud as popular.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The speech of all that speak agrees to crown
The men that give to those that ask, with fair renown.
Various Translators: Those who expound will always praise people who bestow alms on the imploring poor.
Dinamalar: The one undying theme of praise is the praise of charity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nothing imperishable lasts long in this world
Than glorious fame beyond compare.
Transliteration: There is nothing that stands forth in the world imperishable, except fame, exalted in solitary greatness.
T.Kannan:
Nothing imperishable lasts long in this
world Than glorious fame beyond compare.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Nothing other than incomparable fame, lasts forever in this world.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ondraa Ulakaththu Uyarndha
Pukazhallaal
Pondraadhu Nirpadhon Ril
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nothing else lasts on earth for e'er
Saving high fame of the giver!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Save praise alone that soars on high,
Nought lives on earth that shall not die.
Various Translators: Nothing lasts save one’s fearless renown.
Dinamalar: Nothing on Earth is imperishable, except exalted glory, which endures forever.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even celestials will cease praising saints
When you gain world-wide lasting fame.
Transliteration: If one has acquired extensive fame within the limits of this earth, the world of the Gods will no longer praise those sages who have attained that world.
T.Kannan:
Even celestials will cease praising saints
When you gain world-wide lasting fame.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The world of devas, will cease to praise pure scholars, if one, through his deeds across this world, earns everlasting fame.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nilavarai Neelpukazh Aatrin
Pulavaraip
Potraadhu Puththel Ulaku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From hailing gods heavens will cease
To hail the men of lasting praise
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The wise are not favoured of the gods; but the' renowned on earth are adored by them.
Various Translators:
If men do virtuous deeds by world wide ample glory crowned,
The heavens will cease to laud the sage for other gifts renowned.
Dinamalar: So great is glory gained by men in this world that celestials cease praising ascended sages.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Loss that is gain and death that is life of immortal glory are attained only by the wise.
Transliteration: Prosperity to the body of fame, resulting in poverty to the body of flesh and the stability to the former arising from the death of the latter, are achievable only by the wise.
T.Kannan:
None other than the wise can have
Some gain in loss and fame in death.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
None other than the wise can have Some
gain in loss and fame in death.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Out of death and ruin the wise fashion things enduring.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Growth (of fame) amidst adverstiy and survival (of name) after death, are possible only for the smartest.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Naththampol Ketum Uladhaakum
Saakkaatum
Viththakark Kallaal Aridhu
Various Translators:
Fame in fall and life in death 
Are rare but for the soulful worth.
Dinamalar:
Loss that is gain, and death of life's true bliss fulfilled,
Are fruits which only wisdom rare can yeild.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If you must be born, be born for glory. Those born without it would be better off without birth.
Transliteration: If you are born (in this world), be born with qualities conductive to fame. From those who are destitute of them it will be better not to be born.
T.Kannan:
Be born, if you must, for fame;
Or else better not to be born at all.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Let man be born to achieve renown. Let not the unrenowned see the light of day.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Be born, if you must, for fame; Or else
better not to be born at all.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Appear with fame, if you must appear; if not, it is better not to appear than appear.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thondrin Pukazhotu Thondruka
Aqdhilaar
Thondralin Thondraamai Nandru
Various Translators:
Be born with fame if birth you want 
If not of birth you must not vaunt.
Dinamalar:
If man you walk the stage, appear adorned with glory's grace;
Save glorious you can shine, 'twere better hide your face.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If you your days will spend devoid of goodly fame,
When men despise, why blame them? You ' ve yourself to blame.
Transliteration: Why do those who cannot live with praise, grieve those who despise them, instead of grieving themselves for their own inability.
T.Kannan: Why do those whose life is devoid of renown blame enemies who hate them, when they have themselves to blame?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Why blame those who blame the shame of those
Who cannot live in fame?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let the inglorious blame themselves. Let them not reproach others.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Why blame those who blame the shame of
those Who cannot live in fame?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Why do those, who live with no fame, instead of blaming themselves, blame those who revile them.
Various Translators:
Pukazhpata Vaazhaadhaar Thannovaar
Thammai
Ikazhvaarai Novadhu Evan?
Dinamalar:
Why grieve at those who blame the shame 
Of those who cannot live in fame?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Not to beget fame will be esteemed a disgrace by the wise in this world.
Transliteration:
Fame is virtue's child, they say; if, then,
You childless live, you live the scorn of men.
T.Kannan: Barren are they and deemed a disgrace by all men on Earth who fail to beget the offspring called fame.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The whole world will blame, they say,
If you fail to earn that renown called fame.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: World’s reproach befalls one who does not achieve lasting fame.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The whole world will blame, they say, If
you fail to earn that renown called fame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Reproach will remain for those who, with no fame, have no legacy to leave behind.
Various Translators:
Vasaiyenpa Vaiyaththaark Kellaam
Isaiyennum
Echcham Peraaa Vitin
Dinamalar:
To men on earth it is a shame
Not to beget the child of fame.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The land will shrink in yield if men 
O'erburden it without renown.
Transliteration:
The blameless fruits of fields 'increase will dwindle down,
If earth the burthen bear of men without renown.
T.Kannan: Even flawlessly fruitful lands will lessen their yields when forced to support the body of one who lacks illustriousness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: In a land which bears the burden of the unrenowned even nature’s bounty is on the wane.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The land that bears inglorious bodies
Will shrink in its glory of yield.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
