The land that bears inglorious bodies Will
shrink in its glory of yield.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The ground which supports a body without fame will diminish in its rich produce.
Various Translators: The unblemished, fertile yield will diminish for the land that bears a body with no repute.
Dinamalar:
Vasaiyilaa Vanpayan Kundrum
Isaiyilaa
Yaakkai Poruththa Nilam

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who lead a life free of blame, are alive; those who live devoid of fame, are not alive.
Transliteration:
Vasaiyozhiya Vaazhvaare Vaazhvaar
Isaiyozhiya
Vaazhvaare Vaazhaa Thavar
T.Kannan:
They live who live without blemish 
The blameful ones do not flourish.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who live without reproach, them living men we deem;
Who live without renown, live not, though living men they seem.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who live without reproach truly live. Those who live without renown don’t live at all.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The unblemished truly live; the unrenowned merely exist.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Life without blame alone blooms.
The one without fame fades.
Various Translators: Those live who live without disgrace. Those who live without fame live not.
Dinamalar:
Life without blame alone blooms. The one
without fame fades.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The gains of compassion are most precious; material wealth is possessed even by the despicable.
Transliteration:
Arutchelvam Selvaththul Selvam
Porutchelvam
Pooriyaar Kannum Ula
T.Kannan:
The wealth of wealth is wealth of grace
Earthly wealth e'en the basest has.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Wealth 'mid wealth is wealth 'kindliness;
Wealth of goods the vilest too posses.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The crown of wealth is one’s compassion; all other wealth is found even among meanest of men.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Among the wealthy, compassionate men claim the richest wealth, for material wealth is possessed even by contemptible men.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The wealth of wealth is the wealth of grace.
Material wealth, even the mean possess.
Various Translators: The wealth of kindness is wealth of wealth, in as much as the wealth of property is possessed by the basest of men.
Dinamalar:
The wealth of wealth is the wealth of
grace. Material wealth, even the mean possess.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Obtain grace by seeking the path of
goodness. That is the aid cited in all paths.
Transliteration: Pursue the virtuous path and have compassion; all spiritual quests lead to this companion.
T.Kannan:
Nallaatraal Naati Arulaalka
Pallaatraal
Therinum Aqdhe Thunai
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seek by sound ways good compassion; 
All faiths mark that for salvation.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Be compassionate; for compassion is the pivot of all tenets.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The law of 'grace' fufil, by methods good due trial made,
Though many systems you explore, this is your only aid.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Find and follow the good path, ruled by compassion. Of the many ways, that one leads to liberation.
Various Translators:
Obtain grace by seeking the path of goodness.
That is the aid cited in all paths.
Dinamalar: (Stand) in the good path, consider, and be kind. Even considering according to the conflicting tenets of the different sects, kindness will be your best aid, (in the acquisition of heavenly bliss.)

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those who are kind-hearted enter not Into
the terrible world of darkness.
Transliteration: The compassionate know not hell.
T.Kannan: Those with their hearts filled with compassion will never enter a woeful world of darkness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Arulserndha Nenjinaark Killai
Irulserndha
Innaa Ulakam Pukal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The hearts of mercy shall not go
Into dark worlds of gruesome woe.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They in whose breast a ' gracious kindliness ' resides,
See not the gruesome world, where darkness drear abides.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those whose hearts are drawn toward mercy will never be drawn into the dark and woeful world.
Various Translators: They will never enter the world of darkness and wretchedness whose minds are the abode of kindness.
Dinamalar:
Those who are kind-hearted enter not
Into the terrible world of darkness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Freedom from dread of sin is only for the compassionate that love all creation.
Transliteration:
Those who protect other life with kindness
Need not fear for their own lives.
T.Kannan: The compassionate, who care for all other lives, do not fear for their own lives.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Mannuyir Ompi Arulaalvaarkku Illenpa
Thannuyir Anjum Vinai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
His soul is free from dread of sins 
Whose mercy serveth all beings.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who for undying souls of men provides with gracious zeal.
In his own soul the dreaded guilt of sin shall never feel.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Kindly ones who lovingly protect all life need never dread hurt from the actions of their own life.
Various Translators: (The wise) say that the evils, which his soul would dread, will never come upon the man who exercises kindness and protects the life (of other creatures)
Dinamalar:
Those who protect other life with kindness
Need not fear for their own lives.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The compassionate know not life’s agonies; verily the wind-blown earth is witness to it.
Transliteration:
This great earth and its biosphere declare
That sorrows are not for the merciful.
T.Kannan: The fertile world which endows us with breathing air illustrates that there is no sorrow for the compassionate.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Allal Arulaalvaarkku Illai
Valivazhangum
Mallanmaa Gnaalang Kari
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The wide wind fed world witness bears: 
Men of mercy meet not sorrows.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The teeming earth's vast realm, round which the wild winds blow,
In witness, men of 'grace' no woeful want shall know.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: This great rich earth over which the wind blows, is a witness that sorrow never comes upon the kind-hearted.
Various Translators: This wide and wind swept fertile Earth is witness to the truth that misery is not for kind hearted men.
Dinamalar:
This great earth and its biosphere declare
That sorrows are not for the merciful.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The cruel that delight in sin perhaps know not what awaits them.
Transliteration:
Those who do ill forsaking kindness, they
say, Must be oblivious of forsaking morality.
T.Kannan: Those who do evil, abandoning compassion, must have forsaken and forgotten the meaning of life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Porulneengip Pochchaandhaar Enpar
Arulneengi
Allavai Seydhozhuku Vaar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who grace forsake and graceless act
The former loss and woes forget.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: (The wise) say that those who neglect kindness and practise cruelties, neglected virtue (in their former birth), and forgot (the sorrows which they must suffer.)
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Gain of true wealth oblivious they eschew,
Who 'grace' forsake, and graceless actions do.
Various Translators: They say those who act cruelly by forsaking kindness must have forgotten what it means to forsake virtue.
Dinamalar:
Those who do ill forsaking kindness, they say,
Must be oblivious of forsaking morality.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
This world is not for the poor,
Nor the next for the unkind.
Transliteration:
This world is not for the poor, Nor the
next for the unkind.
T.Kannan: As this world is not for those who are without wealth, so that world is not for those who are without kindness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The poor do not possess this world; likewise, the uncompassionate do not inhabit the other world.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Arulillaarkku Avvulakam Illai
Porulillaarkku
Ivvulakam Illaaki Yaangu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
This world is not for weathless ones 
That world is not for graceless swines.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As to impoverished men this present world is not;
The 'graceless' in you world have neither part nor lot.
Various Translators: As this world is not for the penniless, so is that world not for the pitiless!
Dinamalar: Heaven is not for the unfeeling; earth is not for the indigent.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The poor may be rich one day,
But the graceless will always lack grace.
Transliteration: Those who are without wealth may, at some future time, become prosperous; those who are destitute of kindness are utterly destitute; for them there is no change.
T.Kannan:
The poor may be rich one day, But the
graceless will always lack grace.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who lack wealth may, one day, bloom; those who lack compassion are incorrigible, and are forever, doomed.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Porulatraar Pooppar Orukaal
Arulatraar
Atraarmar Raadhal Aridhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wealthless may prosper one day;
The graceless never bloom agay.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who lose the flower of wealth, when seasons change, again may bloom;
Who lose, 'benevolence,' lose all ; nothing can change their doom.
Various Translators: Those without wealth may one day prosper, but those without kindness are utterly and incurably poor.
Dinamalar: Fortune may smile on the ruined; the un feeling are the unredeemed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The good acts of the graceless, if examined,
Resemble the muddled head seeing Truth.
Transliteration: If you consider, the virtue of him who is without kindness is like the perception of the true being by him who is without wisdom.
T.Kannan:
The good acts of the graceless, if
examined, Resemble the muddled head seeing Truth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The uncompassionate doing a righteous deed is like the unwise finding true enlightenment.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Therulaadhaan Meypporul Kantatraal
Therin
Arulaadhaan Seyyum Aram
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Like Truth twisted by confused mind
Wisdom is vain in hearts unkind.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When souls un wise true wisdom's mystic vision see,
The 'graceless' man may work true work of charity.
Various Translators: Behold the unfeeling seeking virtue; it is like ignorance seeing light.
Dinamalar: Practicing charity without compassion is as inconceivable as realizing God without clarity of mind.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When you threaten one weaker than yourself,
Think of yourself before a bully.
Transliteration: When a man is about to rush upon those who are weaker than himself, let him remember how he has stood (trembling) before those who are stronger than himself.
T.Kannan:
When you threaten one weaker than
yourself, Think of yourself before a bully.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When you confront those meeker than you, think of yourself in front of a stronger person.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Valiyaarmun Thannai Ninaikka Thaan
ThanninMeliyaarmel Sellu Mitaththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Think how you feel before the strong
When to the feeble you do wrong.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Oppress not the weak; remember your fate in stronger hands.
Various Translators:
When weaker men you front with threat'ning brow,
Think how you felt in presence of some stronger foe.
Dinamalar: Before proceeding against men weaker than yourself, ponder when you stood before those more powerful.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: How can he practice true compassion who eats the flesh of an animal to fatten his own flesh?
Transliteration: How can he be possessed of kindness, who to increase his own flesh, eats the flesh of other creatures.
T.Kannan:
How can one command grace
Who eats the flesh of others to swell his own flesh?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
How can one command grace Who eats the
flesh of others to swell his own flesh?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who fattens on the flesh of animals, can he ever understand the rule of love?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: How can someone possess kindness, if one eats meat from another body to grow one’s own body?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thannoon Perukkarkuth Thaanpiridhu
Oonunpaan
Engnganam Aalum Arul?
Various Translators:
What graciousness can one command
who feeds his flesh by flesh gourmand.
Dinamalar:
How can the wont of 'kindly grace' to him be known,
Who other creatures' flesh consumes to feed his own?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Riches cannot be found in the hands of the thriftless, nor can compassion be found in the hearts of those who eat meat.
Transliteration: As those possess no property who do not take care of it, so those possess no kindness who feed on flesh.
T.Kannan:
No scope for wealth with a spendthrift.
So too compassion with a meat eater.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Wealth is not for the unwary. Compassion is not for the flesh-eater.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
No scope for wealth with a spendthrift. So
too compassion with a meat eater.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: One, who doesn’t value money can’t be wealthy; one, who eats meat, can’t be compassionate.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Porulaatchi Potraadhaarkku Illai
Arulaatchi
Aangillai Oondhin Pavarkku
Various Translators:
The thriftless have no property 
And flesh eaters have no pity.
Dinamalar:
No use of wealth have they who guard not their estate;
No use of grace have they with flesh who hunger state.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Like heart of them that murderous weapons bear, his mind,
Who eats of savoury meat, no joy in good can find.
Transliteration: Like the (murderous) mind of him who carries a weapon (in his hand), the mind of him who feasts with pleasure on the body of another (creature), has no regard for goodness.
T.Kannan: He who feasts on a creature’s flesh is like he who wields a weapon. Goodness is never one with the minds of these two.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
No mercy in the hearts of those armed to kill
And those who feast on flesh.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The heart of a flesh-eater is devoid of love like that of the wielder of a deadly weapon.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No mercy in the hearts of those armed to
kill And those who feast on flesh.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The heart of one who has eaten and relished flesh, is like the heart of one leading an army: it cannot be compassionate.
Various Translators:
Pataikontaar Nenjampol Nannookkaadhu
Ondran
Utalsuvai Untaar Manam
Dinamalar:
Who wields a steel is steel hearted
Who tastes body is hard hearted.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If it be asked what is kindness and what its opposite, the answer would be preservation and destruction of life; and therefore it is not right to feed on the flesh (obtained by taking away life).
Transliteration:
What's grace, or lack of grace?'To kill' is this , that 'not to kill';
To eat dead flesh can never worthy end fulfil.
T.Kannan: If you ask, “What is kindness and what is unkindness?” It is not killing and killing. Thus, eating flesh is never virtuous.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What is grace? It is not killing; To kill, disgrace.
And senseless to eat that meat.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What is compassion but refraining from killing; what is sin but eating flesh?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What is grace? It is not killing; To kill,
disgrace. And senseless to eat that meat.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What is compassion, and the lack of it : not killing and killing; it is not virtuous to eat meat got by killing.
Various Translators:
Arulalladhu Yaadhenin Kollaamai
Koral
Porulalladhu Avvoon Thinal
Dinamalar:
If merciless it is to kill, 
To kill and eat is disgraceful.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Off with flesh; a life you save
The eater hell's mouth shall not waive!
Transliteration:
If flesh you eat not, life's abodes unharmed remain;
Who eats, hell swallows him,and renders not again.
T.Kannan: Life is perpetuated by not eating meat. The jaws of Hell close on those who do.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Will there be throb of life when there is flesh-eating? Will there be any escape from hell for the flesh-eater?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Abstain from meat to save life.
The clenched jaws of hell hold those who don't.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Abstain from meat to save life. The
clenched jaws of hell hold those who don't.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Not to eat flesh contributes to the continuance of life; therefore if a man eat flesh, hell will not open its mouth (to let him escape out, after he has once fallen in).
Various Translators: Survival of species, depends on not being eaten; those who eat them…hell will not split its mouth to spit them out.
Dinamalar:
Unnaamai Ulladhu Uyirnilai Oonunna
Annaaththal Seyyaadhu Alaru

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There wont be anyone selling meat for the sake of earning, if the world stops killing for the sake of eating.
Transliteration:
Thinarporuttaal Kollaadhu Ulakenin
Yaarum
Vilaipporuttaal Oondraruvaa Ril
T.Kannan:
None would kill and sell the flesh
For eating it if they don't wish.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
We eat the slain,' you say, 'by us no living creatures die;
Who'd kill and sell, I pray, if none came there the flesh to buy?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If the world did not purchase and consume meat, no one would slaughter and offer meat for sale.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Would there be meat for sale, if men were not to kill animals for eating flesh?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The world may say: Meat we eat, but don't kill'.
But no one will sell if there is none to buy.
Various Translators: If the world does not destroy life for the purpose of eating, then no one would sell flesh for the sake of money.
Dinamalar:
The world may say: 'Meat we eat, but don't
kill'. But no one will sell if there is none to buy.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Meat is the wound of some body; if one gets this realization, stop eating it.
Transliteration:
Unnaamai Ventum Pulaaal Piridhondran
Punnadhu Unarvaarp Perin
T.Kannan:
From eating flesh men must abstain
If they but feel the being's pain.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
With other beings' ulcerous wounds their hunger they appease;
If this they felt, desire to eat must surely cease.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If one realises that meat is nothing but the wound of another creature, one refrains from eating it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: When a man realizes that meat is the butchered flesh of another creature, he will abstain from eating it.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Abstain from eating flesh realizing it
As the wound of another
Various Translators: If men should come to know that flesh is nothing but the unclean ulcer of a body, let them abstain from eating it.
Dinamalar:
Abstain from eating flesh realizing it As
the wound of another

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those visionaries freed of ignorance Will
not feed on a flesh freed of its life.
Transliteration: Those who have wisdom, free of flaws, would not eat a body, freed of its life.
T.Kannan:
Seyirin Thalaippirindha Kaatchiyaar
Unnaar
Uyirin Thalaippirindha Oon
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Whose mind from illusion is freed
Refuse on lifeless flesh to feed.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Men of clear vision abstain from the flesh of a slaughtered animal.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Whose souls the vision pure and passionless perceive,
Eat not the bodies men of life bereave.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Insightful souls who have abandoned the passion to hurt others will not feed on flesh that life has abandoned.
Various Translators:
Those visionaries freed of ignorance
Will not feed on a flesh freed of its life.
Dinamalar: The wise, who have freed themselves from mental delusion, will not eat the flesh which has been severed from an animal.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Better than a thousand burnt offerings Is
one life un-killed, un-eaten.
Transliteration: Far nobler than a thousand oblations on fire is an act of abstinence from flesh.
T.Kannan: To desist from killing a life and eating it, is better than doing a thousand rituals, offering oblation.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Avisorin Thaayiram Vettalin Ondran
Uyirsekuth Thunnaamai Nandru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Not to kill and eat, truly 
Excels thousand pourings of ghee!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Than thousand rich oblations, with libations rare,
Better the flesh of slaughtered beings not to share.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Greater than a thousand ghee offerings consumed in sacrificial fires is to not sacrifice and consume any living creature.
Various Translators: Not to kill and eat (the flesh of) an animal, is better than the pouring forth of ghee etc., in a thousand sacrifices.
Dinamalar:
Better than a thousand burnt offerings
Is one life un-killed, un-eaten.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The whole world folds its hands in prayer to one who kills not and abjures flesh.
Transliteration:
All living things will fold their hands
And bow to one who refuses to kill or eat meat.
T.Kannan: To one who doesnt kill and refuses meat, all lives will fold their arms and pay obeisance.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kollaan Pulaalai Maruththaanaik
Kaikooppi
Ellaa Uyirun Thozhum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
All lives shall lift their palms to him
Who eats not flesh nor kills with whim.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who slays nought flesh rejects his feet before,
All living things with clasped hands adore.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: All life will press palms together in prayerful adoration of those who refuse to slaughter or savor meat.
Various Translators: All creatures will join their hands together, and worship him who has never taken away life, nor eaten flesh.
Dinamalar:
All living things will fold their hands
And bow to one who refuses to kill or eat meat.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The true form of penance is to put up with all pain and to abstain from injury.
Transliteration:
The characteristic of penance lies in
Enduring hardships and harming no life.
T.Kannan: To endure any ordeal and to cause none to other lives, embodies penance.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Utranoi Nondral Uyirkkurukan
Seyyaamai
Atre Thavaththir Kuru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pains endure; pain not beings 
This is the type of true penance.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To bear due penitential pains, while no offence,
He causes others, is the type of 'penitence'.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The nature of religious discipline consists, in the endurance (by the ascetic) of the sufferings which it brings on himself, and in abstaining from giving pain to others.
Various Translators: It is the nature of asceticism to patiently endure hardship and to not harm living creatures.
Dinamalar:
The characteristic of penance lies in
Enduring hardships and harming no life.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Penance is possible only for the disciplined. Disgrace attends the undisciplined.
Transliteration:
Penance is for the capable. It is futile
for others to attempt it.
T.Kannan: Penance makes sense only for those who have been virtuous; for others, it is useless.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thavamum Thavamutaiyaarkku Aakum
Adhanai
Aqdhilaar Merkol Vadhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Penance is fit for penitents 
Not for him who in vain pretends.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Austerities can only be borne, and their benefits enjoyed, by those who have practised them (in a former birth); it will be useless for those who have not done so, to attempt to practise them (now).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To 'penitents' sincere avails their 'Penitence';
Where that is not, 'tis but a vain pretence.
Various Translators: Austerity belongs to the naturally austere. Others may attempt it, but to no avail.
Dinamalar:
Penance is for the capable.
It is futile for others to attempt it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Is it to support those who do penance
That others have forgotten it?
Transliteration:
Is it to support those who do penance That
others have forgotten it?
T.Kannan: It is to provide food etc, for the ascetics who have abandoned (the desire of earthly possessions) that other persons have forgotten (to practise) austerity ?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Is it to assist the ascetics that the others have forgotten penance?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Thurandhaarkkuth Thuppuravu Venti
Marandhaarkol
Matrai Yavarkal Thavam
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Is it to true penitent's aid, 
That others austere path avoid?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Have other men forgotten 'penitence, 'who strive
To earn for penitents the things by which they live?
Various Translators: Is it because they must provide for renunciates that others forget to perform penance?
Dinamalar: In their ministering to the needs of the ascetic, verily the householders have become oblivious of their penance.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
In penance lies the power
To save friends and foil foes.
Transliteration: If (the ascetic) desire the destruction of his enemies, or the aggrandizement of his friends, it will be effected by (the power of) his austerities.
T.Kannan:
In penance lies the power To save friends
and foil foes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who do penance, if they so choose, can crush those who harm them and elevate those who delight them.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Onnaarth Theralum Uvandhaarai
Aakkalum
Ennin Thavaththaan Varum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In penance lies the power to save 
The friends and foil the foe and knave.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Destruction to his foes, to friends increase of joy,
The 'Penitent' can cause if this his thoughts employ.
Various Translators: Should he but wish it, an ascetic’s austerities will ruin his foes and reward his friends.
Dinamalar: Penance, if it wills can mar its foe, or bless its friend.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Men do penance in this world
For the fulfillment of their desired desires.
Transliteration: Religious dislipline is practised in this world, because it secures the attainment of whatever one may wish to enjoy (in the world to come).
T.Kannan:
Men do penance in this world For the
fulfillment of their desired desires.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Since it gives the power to attain whatever one wishes to, penance needs to be attempted at the earliest.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ventiya Ventiyaang Keydhalaal
Seydhavam
Eentu Muyalap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What they wish as they wish is won 
Here hence by men penance is done.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
That what they wish may, as they wish, be won,
By men on earth are works of painful 'penance' done.
Various Translators: They persevere in penance; for through penance they achieve their desired goal.
Dinamalar: In this world men do austerities diligently, assured of acquiring desires they desire.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
While the austere are engaged in their duties,
Others toil in vain ensnared by desire.
Transliteration: Those discharge their duty who perform austerities; all others accomplish their own destruction, through the entanglement of the desire (of riches and sensual pleasure).
T.Kannan:
While the austere are engaged in their
duties, Others toil in vain ensnared by desire.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who do penance do their duty; others, engage in futile tasks, ensnared in desire.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Thavanj Cheyvaar Thangarumanj
Cheyvaarmar
RallaarAvanjeyvaar Aasaiyut Pattu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who do penance achieve their aim 
Others desire rid themselves harm.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To do penance is to be alive to one’s duty; those enmeshed in desire come to ruin.
Various Translators:
Who works of 'penence' do , their end attain,
Others in passion's net ensnared, toil but in vain.
Dinamalar: Men who follow some austerity fulfill their karma. All others, ensnared in desires, act in vain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: As the intense fire of the furnace refines gold to brilliance, so does the burning suffering of austerity purify the soul to resplendence.
Transliteration: Just as gold is purified as heated in the fire, will those shine, who have endured the burning of pain (in frequent austerities).
T.Kannan:
As the intense fire makes gold shine,
So does the burning austerities relieve pain.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
As the intense fire makes gold shine, So
does the burning austerities relieve pain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Gold shines all the more in fire; those who do penance become mellowed through suffering.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Like flame that makes gold glitter more, pangs of pain can only enlighten those who do penance.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Sutachchutarum Ponpol Olivitum
Thunpanjjch
Utachchuta Norkir Pavarkku
Various Translators:
Pure and bright gets the gold in fire; 
and so the life by pain austere.
Dinamalar:
The hotter glows the fining fire, the gold the brighter shines;
The pain of penitence, like fire, the soul of man refines.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One who has realized by himself his soul’s Self will be worshiped by all other souls.
Transliteration: All other creatures will worship him who has attained the control of his own soul.
T.Kannan:
All souls will worship him who, losing his ego,
Gets control of his own soul.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The world worships one who has regained one’s soul.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
All souls will worship him who, losing his
ego, Gets control of his own soul.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: One, who has given up the thought of ‘I, myself’, will be hailed by all.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thannuyir Thaanarap Petraanai Enaiya
Mannuyi Rellaan Thozhum
Various Translators:
He worship wins from every soul 
Who Master is by soul control.
Dinamalar:
Who gains himself in utter self control,
Him worships every other living soul.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even over death the victory he may gain,
If power by penance won his soul obtain.
Transliteration: Those who have attained the power which religious discipline confers, will be able also to pass the limit of Yama, (the God of death).
T.Kannan: So potent is the power acquired through disciplined self denial that those who attain it may even delay the moment of death.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those who have achieved the strength of penance
Could defeat even the Lord of Death.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Men at the height of their penance can triumph over even death.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those who have achieved the strength of
penance Could defeat even the Lord of Death.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those, who have mastered penance, will find it possible to even defer death.
Various Translators:
Kootram Kudhiththalum Kaikootum
Notralin
Aatral Thalaippat Tavarkkul
Dinamalar:
They can even defy death 
Who get by penance godly strength.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Because there are few who practise austerity and many who do not, there are many destitute and few rich in this world.
Transliteration:
The many all things lack! The cause is plain,
The 'penitents' are few. The many shun such pain.
T.Kannan: A few people fast and abstain, while most do not. Due to this, many suffer deprivation.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The have-nots outnumber the haves
Because penance is not for the many.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Many are the indigent; for only a few practise penance.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The have-nots outnumber the haves Because
penance is not for the many.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The poor are abundant, since those who observe abstinence are few, and those who dont are more.
Various Translators:
Ilarpala Raakiya Kaaranam Norpaar
Silarpalar Nolaa Thavar
Dinamalar:
Many are poor and few are rich 
For they care not for penance much.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Elements five of feigned life 
Of a sly hypocrite within laugh.
Transliteration:
Who with deceitful mind in false way walks of covert sin,
The five fold elements his frame compose, deride within.
T.Kannan: A deceiver’s own five elements remain undeceived by his double dealing mind and silently mock him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A man’s five senses will laugh within at the false conduct of a deceitful mind.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The five elements will laugh within
At a hypocrite's lying conduct.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The five elements will laugh within At a
hypocrite's lying conduct.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The five elements (of his body) will laugh within him at the feigned conduct of the deceitful minded man.
Various Translators: The deceitful conduct of a treacherous mind, will be sneered at by the five elements within.
Dinamalar:
Vanja Manaththaan Patitrozhukkam
Poodhangal
Aindhum Akaththe Nakum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Is a sky-high prominence of any use, when one’s heart knowingly harbors a vice.
Transliteration:
Vaanuyar Thotram Evanseyyum
Thannenjam
Thaanari Kutrap Patin
T.Kannan:
Of what avail are sky high shows
When guild the conscience gnaws and knows.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What gain, thought virtues' semblance high as heaven his fame exalt,
If heart dies down through sense of self detected fault?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Of what avail is an outer appearance of saintliness if the mind suffers inwardly from knowledge of its iniquity?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Of what avail is a man’s saintly mien, if his mind is bent on evil?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What use is a sky-high pose to one
Who knowingly does wrong?
Various Translators: What avails an appearance (of sanctity) high as heaven, if his mind suffers (the indulgence) of conscious sin.
Dinamalar:
What use is a sky-high pose to one Who
knowingly does wrong?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A person with a frail heart assuming an imposing appearance is like a cow grazing wearing a tiger’s skin.
Transliteration:
Valiyil Nilaimaiyaan Valluruvam
Petram
Puliyindhol Porththumeyn Thatru
T.Kannan:
Vaunting sainthood while weak within 
Seems a grazer with tiger skin.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
As if a steer should graze wrapped round with tiger's skin,
Is show of virtuous might when weakness lurks within.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The ascetic appearance of one who has no strength of will, is like that of an ox grazing in the guise of a tiger.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He who has not attained the power yet wears the garb of saints is like a cow that grazes about wearing a tiger’s skin.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A weakling posing a giant form
Is an ox grazing in a tiger's skin.
Various Translators: The assumed appearance of power, by a man who has no power (to restrain his senses and perform austerity), is like a cow feeding on grass covered with a tiger's skin.
Dinamalar:
A weakling posing a giant form Is an ox
grazing in a tiger's skin.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A posing ascetic who sins secretly Is like
a fowler hiding in bush to trap birds.
Transliteration: Doing misdeeds in the guise of an ascetic is like a hunter capturing birds from behind the bushes.
T.Kannan:
Thavamaraindhu Allavai Seydhal
Pudhalmaraindhu
Vettuvan Pulsimizhth Thatru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sinning in saintly show is like
Fowlers in ambush birds to strike.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Committing evil under the mask of holiness is like the hunter lying in wait for birds.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Tis as a fowler, silly birds to snare, in thicket lurks,
When, clad in stern ascetic garb, one secret evil works.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He who conceals himself beneath holy robes and commits sins is like a hunter hiding in the bushes to snare unwary birds.
Various Translators:
A posing ascetic who sins secretly
Is like a fowler hiding in bush to trap birds.
Dinamalar: He who hides himself under the mask of an ascetic and commits sins, like a sportsman who conceals himself in the thicket to catch birds.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The deceitful acts of those claiming
dispassion Will make them exclaim in pain, 'Alas!
Alas!'
Transliteration: The hypocrisy of one who professes asceticism lands one in endless troubles.
T.Kannan: If those who claim to have given up material desires, indulge in deceitful conduct, it will cause suffering aplenty leading to self-pity.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Patratrem Enpaar Patitrozhukkam
Etretrendru
Edham Palavun Tharum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who false within but freedom feign
Shall moan "What have we done" with pain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Our souls are free,' who say, yet practise evil secretly,
'What folly have we wrought!' by many shames o'erwhelmed, shall cry.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The day will come when those who claim dispassion yet act deceitfully exclaim,”Alas! Alas! What have I done?”
Various Translators: The false conduct of those who say they have renounced all desire will one day bring them sorrows that will make them cry out, "Oh! what have we done, what have we done."
Dinamalar:
The deceitful acts of those claiming dispassion
Will make them exclaim in pain, Alas! Alas!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There is none so hardened in vice as one who though hollow at heart, wears the mask of saintliness.
Transliteration:
None so cruel as the posing ascetic Who
lives by deceit without renouncing by heart.
T.Kannan: There is nobody more evil than those who pretend to be ascetics when their hearts haven’t renounced desire.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nenjin Thuravaar Thurandhaarpol
Vanjiththu
Vaazhvaarin Vankanaar Il
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vilest is he who seems a saint
Cheating the world without restraint.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In mind renouncing nought, in speech renouncing every tie,
Who guileful live, no men are found than these of 'harder eye.'
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: None is so heartless as he who, without renunciation in his heart, poses as a renunciate and lives in pretense.
Various Translators: Amongst living men there are none so hard-hearted as those who without to saking (desire) in their heart, falsely take the appearance of those who have forsaken (it).
Dinamalar:
None so cruel as the posing ascetic
Who lives by deceit without renouncing by heart.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: This world contains (many) men who like the Kunri seed are fair of face but foul of heart.
Transliteration:
Like the kunri - red to view but black on
top Are many, ochre-robed but black within.
T.Kannan: There are people, even if they, externally, resemble the lustrous exterior of a ‘kunri’ pea, have hearts like the dark nose of the pea.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Purangundri Kantanaiya Renum
Akangundri
Mukkir Kariyaar Utaiththu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Berry red is his outward view, 
Black like its nose his inward hue.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Outward, they shine as 'kunri' berry's scarlet bright;
Inward, like tip of 'kunri' bead, as black as night.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: (The world) contains persons whose outside appears (as fair) as the (red) berry of the Abrus, but whose inside is as black as the nose of that berry.
Various Translators: Like the poisonous jequirity bean, with its red and black sides, there are outwardly dazzling men whose insides are dark.
Dinamalar:
Like the kunri - red to view but black on top
Are many, ochre-robed but black within.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There are many insincere men who frequent sacred waters to pass for holy men.
Transliteration:
Many spotted minds bathe in holy streams
And lead a double life.
T.Kannan: There are many, who, like holy men, take a dip in the river, but hide the impurities of their heart.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Manaththadhu Maasaaka Maantaar
Neeraati
Maraindhozhuku Maandhar Palar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Filthy in mind some bathe in streams 
Hiding sins in showy extremes.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: There are many men of masked conduct, who perform their ablutions, and (make a show) of greatness, while their mind is defiled (with guilt).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Many wash in hallowed waters, living lives of hidden shame;
Foul in heart, yet high upraised of men in virtuous fame.
Various Translators: Many are the men who piously bathe in purifying waters, while in their black hearts impure conduct lies concealed.
Dinamalar:
Many spotted minds bathe in holy streams
And lead a double life.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The lute is bent, the arrow straight:
Judge men not by their looks but acts.
Transliteration:
The lute is bent, the arrow straight:
Judge men not by their looks but acts.
T.Kannan: As, in its use, the arrow is crooked, and the curved lute is straight, so by their deeds, (and not by their appearance) let (the uprightness or crookedness of) men be estimated.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Judge a person by his deeds: the straight arrow is destructive and yazh, the bent musical bow, is sweet.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kanaikotidhu Yaazhkotu Sevvidhuaang
Kanna
Vinaipatu Paalaal Kolal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Know men by acts and not by forms 
Strait arrow kills, bent lute but charms.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Cruel is the arrow straight, the crooked lute is sweet,
Judge by their deeds the many forms of men you meet.
Various Translators: The arrow is straight but cruel; the lute is crooked but sweet. Therefore, judge men by their acts, not their appearance.
Dinamalar: The arrow, though straight is deadly; the yāl though crooked is sweet. Let people be judged by their actions.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No need of tonsure or long hair,
If one avoids what the world condemns.
Transliteration: There is no need of a shaven crown, nor of tangled hair, if a man abstain from those deeds which the wise have condemned.
T.Kannan:
No need of tonsure or long hair, If one
avoids what the world condemns.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Tonsuring or growing long tresses is unnecessary, if one refrains from doing what the world disdains.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Mazhiththalum Neettalum Ventaa
Ulakam
Pazhiththadhu Ozhiththu Vitin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No balding nor tangling the hair! 
Abstain from condemned acts with care.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What's the worth of shaven head or tresses long,
If you shun what all the world condemns as wrong?
Various Translators: Neither shaven head nor long matted locks are needed, provided one casts off conduct condemned by the world.
Dinamalar: If persons abstain from deeds condemned by the world there is no need either for tonsure or for matted locks.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Let him guard against every thought of fraud
If he wishes not to be scorned.
Transliteration: Let him, who desires not to be despised, keep his mind from (the desire of) defrauding another of the smallest thing.
T.Kannan:
Let him guard against every thought of
fraud If he wishes not to be scorned.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If one wishes not to be ridiculed, let him protect his heart from thoughts of swindling.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ellaamai Ventuvaan Enpaan
Enaiththondrum
Kallaamai Kaakkadhan Nenju
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let him who would reproachless be 
From all frauds guard his conscience free.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who seeks heaven's joys, from impious levity secure,
Let him from every fraud preserve his spirit pure.
Various Translators: He who wants to command respect must guard his mind against robbing others.
Dinamalar: He who wishes not to be scorned by others guards his own mind against the slightest thought of fraud.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even to harbour in mind
The idea of defrauding another's wealth is sin.
Transliteration: Even the thought (of sin) is sin; think not then of crafiily stealing the property of another.
T.Kannan:
Even to harbour in mind The idea of
defrauding another's wealth is sin.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even to think such thoughts is evil : thoughts of swindling others’ property.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ullaththaal Ullalum Theedhe
Piranporulaik
Kallaththaal Kalvem Enal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
"We will by fraud win other's wealth" 
Even this thought is sin and stealth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is a sin to lust for another’s belongings.
Various Translators:
Tis sin if in the mind man but thought conceive;
'By fraud I will my neighbour of his wealth bereave.'
Dinamalar: The mere thought of sin is sin. Therefore, avoid even the thought of stealing from another.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A fortune amassed by fraud may appear to prosper but will all too soon perish altogether.
Transliteration: The property, which is acquired by fraud, will entirely perish, even while it seems to increase.
T.Kannan:
Stolen wealth may seem to swell
But in the end will burst.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Stolen wealth may seem to swell But in the
end will burst.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Ill-gotten wealth however vast comes to nought.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Swindled wealth, will seem to swell, but will breach its limits and bust.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kalavinaal Aakiya Aakkam Alavirandhu
Aavadhu Polak Ketum
Various Translators:
The gain by fraud may overflow
But swift to ruin it shall go.
Dinamalar:
The gain that comes by fraud, although it seems to grow
With limitless increase, to ruin swift shall go.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Taking delight in defrauding others yields the fruit of undying suffering when those delights ripen.
Transliteration: The eager desire of defrauding others will, when it brings forth its fruit, produce undying sorrow.
T.Kannan:
The excessive love for fraudulent gain
Leads to everlasting pain.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Inordinate desire to steal brings in its train endless suffering.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The excessive love for fraudulent gain
Leads to everlasting pain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The love for swindling, when it yields, yields indestructible distress.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kalavinkan Kandriya Kaadhal
Vilaivinkan
Veeyaa Vizhumam Tharum
Various Translators:
The fruit that fraud and greed obtain
Shall end in endless grief and pain.
Dinamalar:
The lust inveterate of fraudful gain,
Yields as its fruit undying pain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Grace' is not in their thoughts, nor know they kind affection's power,
Who neighbour's goods desire, and watch for his unguarded hour.
Transliteration: The study of kindness and the exercise of benevolence is not with those who watch for another's forgetfulness, though desire of his property.
T.Kannan: Benevolent thoughts and kindly feelings flee from those who watch for another’s unwatchfulness to swindle his property.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Love and grace are alien virtues to one
Who plots for innocent's wealth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Can ever grace and love be found in one who exploits the unwary?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Love and grace are alien virtues to one
Who plots for innocent's wealth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Love, inspired by compassion, doesnt occur to those who await others’ lapses to grab their wealth.
Various Translators:
Arulkarudhi Anputaiya Raadhal
Porulkarudhip
Pochchaappup Paarppaarkan Il
Dinamalar:
Love and Grace are not their worth 
Who watch to waylay dozer's wealth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: They cannot walk steadfastly, according to rule, who eagerly desire to defraud others.
Transliteration:
They cannot walk restrained in wisdom's measured bound,
In whom inveterate lust of fraudful gain is found.
T.Kannan: Those who walk deceit’s desirous path cannot hope to work wisdom’s measured way.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those who love stealing
Can never be content with what they have.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who have a burning desire to steal cannot walk in the path of virtue.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those who love stealing Can never be
content with what they have.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The excessive love for swindling renders a person unable to abide by the limits of reason.
Various Translators:
Alavinkan Nindrozhukal Aatraar
Kalavinkan
Kandriya Kaadha Lavar
Dinamalar:
They cannot walk in measured bounds 
who crave and have covetous ends.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Men of measured wisdom shun 
Black art of fraud and what it won.
Transliteration:
Practice of fraud's dark cunning arts they shun,
Who long for power by ' measured wisdom' won.
T.Kannan: The dark deceits of fraud cannot be found in those who desire the greatness called virtue.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The dark thought of stealing is absent in those who are alive to the value of life.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Those gifted with the faculty of contentment
Never have that shady skill called fraud.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those gifted with the faculty of
contentment Never have that shady skill called fraud.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: That black-knowledge which is called fraud, is not in those who desire that greatness which is called rectitude.
Various Translators: The clouded intelligence for defrauding is not for those who understand the limits of reason and morality.
Dinamalar:
Kalavennum Kaarari Vaanmai Alavennum
Aatral Purindhaarkanta Il

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Guile lies in the heart of the fraudulent like righteousness residing in the hearts of those who operate within boundaries.
Transliteration:
Alavarindhaar Nenjath Tharampola
Nirkum
Kalavarindhaar Nenjil Karavu
T.Kannan:
Virtue abides in righteous hearts 
Into minds of frauds deceit darts.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
As virtue dwells in heart that 'measured wisdom' gains;
Deceit in hearts of fraudful men established reigns.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: As righteousness resides in the hearts of the virtuous, so does deceit dwell in the hearts of thieves.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Virtue dwells in the person of known probity; deceit dwells in persons addicted to stealing.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As virtue in the hearts of the righteous,
Deceit dwells in the hearts of thieves.
Various Translators: Deceit dwells in the mind of those who are conversant with fraud, even as virtue in the mind s of those who are conversant with rectitude.
Dinamalar:
As virtue in the hearts of the righteous,
Deceit dwells in the hearts of thieves.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those, who have mastered nothing but swindling, will exceed all limits and fall instantly.
Transliteration:
Alavalla Seydhaange Veevar Kalavalla
Matraiya Thetraa Thavar
T.Kannan:
They perish in their perfidy 
Who know nothing but pilfery.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who have no lore save that which fraudful arts supply,
Acts of unmeasured vice committing straightway die.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who know nothing else than stealing will indulge in unrighteous acts and forthwith perish.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Men who know nothing but deception die a little each time they contrive their crooked deeds.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Discontented men who know nothing but fraud
Perish as and when they corrupt.
Various Translators: Those, who are acquainted with nothing but fraud, will perish in the very commission of transgression.
Dinamalar:
Discontented men who know nothing but
fraud Perish as and when they corrupt.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even life abandons him who defrauds
others, But heaven never forsakes the honest.
Transliteration: The fraudulent will lose their living state; those who desist from defrauding will not be denied the world of Devas.
T.Kannan:
Kalvaarkkuth Thallum Uyirnilai
Kalvaarkkuth
Thallaadhu Puththe Lulaku
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Even the body rejects thieves; 
The honest men, heaven receives.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Their very bodies fail the defrauding. The world of the gods fail not the upright.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The fraudful forfeit life and being here below;
Who fraud eschew the bliss of heavenly beings know.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even the life in his body will abandon him who cheats others, while Heaven itself never forsakes those who are honest.
Various Translators:
Even life abandons him who defrauds others,
But heaven never forsakes the honest.
Dinamalar: Even their body will fail the fraudulent; but even the world of the gods will not fail those who are free from fraud.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What is truthfulness? It is nothing but
utterance Wholly devoid of ill.
Transliteration: What is truth but unsullied utterance?
T.Kannan: Truth is defined as speaking words that cause no harm.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Vaaimai Enappatuvadhu Yaadhenin
Yaadhondrum
Theemai Ilaadha Solal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If "What is truth"? the question be,
It is to speak out evil free.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
You ask , in lips of men what 'truth' may be;
'Tis speech from every taint of evil free.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What is truthfulness? It is speaking words which are totally free from harmful effects.
Various Translators: Truth is the speaking of such words as are free from the least degree of evil (to others).
Dinamalar:
What is truthfulness? It is nothing but utterance
Wholly devoid of ill.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even untruth has the stamp of truth, if it is free from harm.
Transliteration:
Even a lie would take the place of truth,
If it brings blameless benefit.
T.Kannan: Even a lie will be placed on par with the truth, if it yields unblemished benefits.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Poimaiyum Vaaimai Yitaththa
Puraidheerndha
Nanmai Payakkum Enin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
E'en falsehood may for truth suffice,
When good it brings removing vice.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Falsehood may take the place of truthful word,
If blessing, free from fault, it can afford.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even falsehood is of the nature of truth if it renders good results, free from fault.
Various Translators: Even falsehood has the nature of truth, if it confer a benefit that is free from fault.
Dinamalar:
Even a lie would take the place of truth,
If it brings blameless benefit.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Let none utter a falsehood against his conscience lest it should torment him.
Transliteration:
Lie not against your conscience, Lest your
own conscience burn you.
T.Kannan: Do not lie consciously; once you lie so, your own conscience will sear you.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thannenj Charivadhu Poiyarka
Poiththapin
Thannenje Thannaich Chutum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Let not a man knowingly lie; 
Conscience will scorch and make him sigh.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Speak not a word which false thy own heart knows,
Self kindled fire within the false one's spirit glows.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Let not a man knowingly tell a lie; for after he has told the lie, his mind will burn him (with the memory of his guilt).
Various Translators: Let one not speak as true what he knows to be false, for his conscience will burn him when he has lied.
Dinamalar:
Lie not against your conscience,
Lest your own conscience burn you.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One sits high in the hearts of all who is true to oneself.
Transliteration:
He who lives truly in his own heart, Truly
lives in the hearts of all people.
T.Kannan: One who, guided by his heart, lives without lies, will forever live in the hearts of all.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ullaththaar Poiyaa Thozhukin
Ulakaththaar
Ullaththu Lellaam Ulan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
He lives in loving hearts of all 
Who serves the Truth serene in soul.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He who, in his conduct, preserves a mind free from deceit, will dwell in the minds of all men.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
True to his inmost soul who lives, enshrined
He lives in souls of all mankind.
Various Translators: One who lives by truth in his own heart truly lives in the hearts of all people.
Dinamalar:
He who lives truly in his own heart,
Truly lives in the hearts of all people.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Truthfulness in thought and word
Outweighs penance and charity.
Transliteration:
Truthfulness in thought and word Outweighs
penance and charity.
T.Kannan: He, who speaks truth with all his heart, is superior to those who make gifts and practise austerities.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One who tells the truth, with all his heart, is ahead of those who do penance and charity.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Manaththotu Vaaimai Mozhiyin
Thavaththotu
Thaananjey Vaarin Thalai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To speak the truth from heart sincere 
Is more than giving and living austere.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Greater is he who speaks the truth with full consenting mind.
Than men whose lives have penitence and charity combined.
Various Translators: Those who speak only truth from the heart surpass even penitents and philanthropists.
Dinamalar: Far greater than a benefactor or an ascetic is one whose words come from the depths of truth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nothing but the fame of truthfulness
Can give all other virtues effortlessly.
Transliteration: There is no praise like the praise of never uttering a falsehood: without causing any suffering, it will lead to every virtue.
T.Kannan:
Nothing but the fame of truthfulness Can
give all other virtues effortlessly.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: No other fame equals not lying; without any physical strain it yields all virtues.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Poiyaamai Anna Pukazhillai Eyyaamai
Ellaa Aramun Tharum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Not to lie brings all the praise
All virtues from Truth arise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
No praise like that of words from falsehood free;
This every virtue yields spontaneously.
Various Translators: No prestige surpasses the absence of falsehood; all other virtues flow from it effortlessly.
Dinamalar: One’s renown is rooted only in truth; it leads one easily to every other virtue.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If one speaks the truth and only truth,
He need not seek other virtues.
Transliteration: If a man has the power to abstain from falsehood, it will be well with him, even though he practise no other virtue.
T.Kannan:
If one speaks the truth and only truth, He
need not seek other virtues.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Not lying, not lying, if practiced, makes it acceptable not to do, not to do other righteous deeds.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Poiyaamai Poiyaamai Aatrin Arampira
Seyyaamai Seyyaamai Nandru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Lie not lie not. Naught else you need 
All virtues are in Truth indeed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If all your life be utter truth, the truth alone,
'Tis well , though other virtuous acts be left undone.
Various Translators: Practise truth, you need not practise any other virtue.
Dinamalar: Not lying, and merely not lying, is beneficial for those who cannot or will not practice other virtues.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Water ensures external purity
And truthfulness shows the internal.
Transliteration: Purity of body is produced by water and purity of mind by truthfulness.
T.Kannan:
Water ensures external purity And
truthfulness shows the internal.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Water ensures cleanliness externally; truthfulness makes inner purity evident.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Puraldhooimai Neeraan Amaiyum
Akandhooimai
Vaaimaiyaal Kaanap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Water makes you pure outward
Truth renders you pure inward.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Water cleanses the body; truth cleanses the soul.
Various Translators:
Outward purity the water will bestow;
Inward purity from truth alone will flow.
Dinamalar: Water is sufficient to cleanse the body, but truthfulness alone can purify the mind.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Not all lamps give light. The lamp of not lying is the learned man’s light.
Transliteration: All lamps of nature are not lamps; the lamp of truth is the lamp of the wise.
T.Kannan:
Not all lights cause illumination; For the wise,
Only the light of truth is illuminant.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Not all lights cause illumination; For the
wise, Only the light of truth is illuminant.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: All lamps are not lamps. To the great the lamp of truth is the lamp.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: All light is not light; for noble scholars, truthfulness is the true light of enlightenment.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ellaa Vilakkum Vilakkalla
Saandrorkkup
Poiyaa Vilakke Vilakku
Various Translators:
All lights are not lights for the wise;
Truth light is light bright like sun light
Dinamalar:
Every lamp is not a lamp in wise men's sight;
That's the lamp with truth's pure radiance bright.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Among all great truths we have ever beheld, not a single one rivals the goodness of telling the truth.
Transliteration: Amidst all that we have seen (described) as real (excellence), there is nothing so good as truthfulness.
T.Kannan:
Amidst all that we have seen as real,
There is nothing as good as truthfulness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: In all the scriptures we have read, there is no virtue greater than truth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Amidst all that we have seen as real,
There is nothing as good as truthfulness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Of all the known truths, there is nothing more significant than truthfulness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Yaameyyaak Kantavatrul Illai
Enaiththondrum
Vaaimaiyin Nalla Pira
Various Translators:
Of all the things we here have seen 
Nothing surpasses Truth serene !
Dinamalar:
Of all good things we've scanned with studious care,
There's nought that can with truthfulness compare.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Where thou hast power thy angry will to work, thy wrath restrain;
Where power is none, what matter if thou check or give it rein?
Transliteration: He restrains his anger who restrains it when it can injure; when it cannot injure, what does it matter whether he restrain it, or not ?
T.Kannan: It is restraint that restrains rage when it can injure. If it cannot harm, what does restraint really matter?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Curb wrath in places where it matters. In other places,
What matters if curbed or uncurbed?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who restrains his wrath where it can be vented shows real restraint. What does it matter whether one restrains it or not in an unavailing hour?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Curb wrath in places where it matters. In
other places, What matters if curbed or uncurbed?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Restrain anger where anger will be effective; where it won’t be, does it matter whether one restrains it or not?
Various Translators:
Sellitaththuk Kaappaan Sinangaappaan
Allitaththuk
Kaakkinen Kaavaakkaal En?
Dinamalar:
Anger against the weak is wrong
It is futile against the strong.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Anger is bad, even when it cannot injure; when it can injure; there is no greater evil.
Transliteration:
Where power is none to wreak thy wrath importent is ill;
Where thou hast power thy will to work, 'tis greater, evil still.
T.Kannan: Wrath is wrong even when it cannot cause injury, but when it can, there is nothing more evil.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Even where it cannot hurt others, anger is bad;
But where it does, there is nothing worse.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Anger is bad even where it is unavailing; but where it can be effectively exercised there is no worse evil.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Even where it cannot hurt others, anger is
bad; But where it does, there is nothing worse.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Where it can’t have an impact, anger is harmful; where it can, there is still nothing more harmful.
Various Translators:
Sellaa Itaththuch Chinandheedhu
Sellitaththum
Iladhanin Theeya Pira
Dinamalar:
Vain is wrath against men of force 
Against the meek it is still worse.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Off with wrath with any one. 
It is the source of sin and pain.
Transliteration:
If any rouse thy wrath, the trespass straight forget;
For wrath an endless train of evils will beget.
T.Kannan: Forget anger toward all who have offended you, for it gives rise to teeming troubles.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Do not get angry with any one; for out of anger springs forth a host of evils.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
From anger is born all evil.
Forget provocation given by anyone.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From anger is born all evil. Forget
provocation given by anyone.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Forget anger towards every one, as fountains of evil spring from it.
Various Translators: Erase your anger against anyone; only harm springs forth from it.
Dinamalar:
Maraththal Vekuliyai Yaarmaattum
Theeya
Piraththal Adhanaan Varum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Is there a foe other than anger, which anhilates smile and joy.
Transliteration:
Nakaiyum Uvakaiyum Kollum Sinaththin
Pakaiyum Ulavo Pira
T.Kannan:
Is there a foe like harmful ire 
Which kills the smile and joyful cheer?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Wrath robs the face of smiles, the heart of joy,
What other foe to man works such annoy?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Anger kills the face’s smile and the heart’s joy. Does there exist a greater enemy than one’s own anger?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Is there any enemy other than anger that kills both joy and pleasure?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Can there be a greater foe than anger
Which kills laughter and joy?
Various Translators: Is there a greater enemy than anger, which kills both laughter and joy ?
Dinamalar:
Can there be a greater foe than anger
Which kills laughter and joy?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If you seek to protect yourself, curb your anger, lest anger destroys you.
Transliteration:
Thannaiththaan Kaakkin Sinangaakka
Kaavaakkaal
Thannaiye Kollunj Chinam
T.Kannan:
Thyself to save, from wrath away!
If not thyself the wrath will slay.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
If thou would'st guard thyself, guard against wrath alway;
'Gainst wrath who guards not, him warth shall slay.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If a man were to guard himself let him restrain anger. Otherwise anger gets the better of him.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: If a man be his own guard, let him guard himself against rage. Left unguarded, his own wrath will annihilate him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If you want to guard yourself, guard against anger;
If unguarded, anger will kill you.
Various Translators: If a man would guard himself, let him guard against anger; if he do not guard it, anger will kill him.
Dinamalar:
If you want to guard yourself, guard
against anger; If unguarded, anger will kill you.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The fire of anger which kills kinsmen
Burns the life-saving boat of kith and kin.
Transliteration: Anger, the fire known to destroy those who harbor it, will also burn down the lifeboat, namely, one’s clan.
T.Kannan:
Sinamennum Serndhaaraik Kolli
Inamennum
Emap Punaiyaich Chutum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Friend killer is the fatal rage 
It burns the helpful kinship barge.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Anger destroys even one’s kindred who is the canoe of his life.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Wrath, the fire that slayeth whose draweth near,
Will burn the helpful 'raft' of kindred dear.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Anger’s fire engulfs all who draw near it, burning even friends and family who risk rescue.
Various Translators:
The fire of anger which kills kinsmen
Burns the life-saving boat of kith and kin.
Dinamalar: The fire of anger will burn up even the pleasant raft of friendship.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
He who holds anger worthy will be hurt
Like the hands that smash the earth.
Transliteration: The ruin of one who nourishes wrath is as certain as the injury to one’s hands when beat on the ground.
T.Kannan: One, who possesses anger as a trait, will perish with the unfailing precision of a hand that slams the ground.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sinaththaip Porulendru Kontavan Ketu
Nilaththaraindhaan Kaipizhaiyaa Thatru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The wrath lover to doom is bound 
Like failless hand that strikes the ground.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The hand that smites the earth unfailing feels the sting;
So perish they who nurse their warth as noble thing.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: As a man trying to strike the ground with his hand can hardly fail, just as surely will one who treasures his temper be destroyed.
Various Translators: Destruction will come upon him who ragards anger as a good thing, as surely as the hand of him who strikes the ground will not fail.
Dinamalar:
He who holds anger worthy will be hurt
Like the hands that smash the earth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is better you show no wrath even against one who inflicts on you harm scorching you like a thousand-tongued flame.
Transliteration:
Better curb one's wrath even if tortured
Like being forced into blazing fire.
T.Kannan: Even if taunted with a harmful deed, tantamount to toasting in a multi-tongued fire, better try not to be angered.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Inareri Thoivanna Innaa Seyinum
Punarin Vekulaamai Nandru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Save thy soul from burning ire 
Though tortured like the touch of fire.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though men should work thee woe, like touch of tongues of fire.
'Tis well if thou canst save thy soul from burning ire.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though others inflict wrongs as painful as flaming torches, it is good if a man can refrain from inflammatory tantrums.
Various Translators: Though one commit things against you as painful (to bear) as if a bundle of fire had been thrust upon you, it will be well, to refrain, if possible, from anger.
Dinamalar:
Better curb one's wrath even if tortured
Like being forced into blazing fire.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Banish anger from your mind; you get all that you long for.
Transliteration:
All wishes are realized at once If they
keep away wrath from their mind.
T.Kannan: If the heart doesn’t harbour anger, one would attain instantly all that it aspires to.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ulliya Thellaam Utaneydhum
Ullaththaal
Ullaan Vekuli Enin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Wishes he gains as he wishes 
If man refrains from rage vicious!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If man his soul preserve from wrathful fires,
He gains with that whate'er his soul desires.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If a man never indulges anger in his heart, he will at once obtain whatever he has thought of.
Various Translators: If hostile thoughts do not invade his mind, all his other thoughts may swiftly manifest.
Dinamalar:
All wishes are realized at once
If they keep away wrath from their mind.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Men given to wrath are one with the devil; Men free from it are one with the immortals.
Transliteration:
Deem those given to anger dead And those
renounced it on par with saints.
T.Kannan: Those who yield to anger are as good as dead; those who’ve shed anger are in effect saints.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Irandhaar Irandhaar Anaiyar
Sinaththaith
Thurandhaar Thurandhaar Thunai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Dead are they who are anger fed 
Saints are they from whom wrath has fled.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those, who give way to excessive anger, are no better than dead men; but those, who are freed from it, are equal to those who are freed (from death).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Men of surpassing wrath are like the men who've passed away;
Who wrath renounce , equals of all renouncing sages they.
Various Translators: As men who have died resemble the dead, so men who have renounced rage resemble renunciates.
Dinamalar:
Deem those given to anger dead
And those renounced it on par with saints.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The pure in heart will never hurt others
Even for wealth that confers renown.
Transliteration:
The pure in heart will never hurt others
Even for wealth that confers renown.
T.Kannan: It is the determination of the spotless not to cause sorrow to others, although they could (by so causing) obtain the wealth which confers greatness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even if it yields glory and riches galore, refraining from harming others is the principled path of the impeccable.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Sirappeenum Selvam Perinum Pirarkku
InnaaSeyyaamai Maasatraar Kol
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The pure by faith mean pain to none
Though princely wealth by that is won.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though ill to neighbour wrought should glorious pride of wealth secure,
No ill to do is fixed decree of men in spirit pure.
Various Translators: Even if injuring others would bring princely riches, the pure in heart would still avoid it.
Dinamalar: It is the nature of the spotless not to inflict suffering on others, though by it they may get wealth and renown.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The code of the pure in heart
Is not to hurt in return any hurt caused in hate.
Transliteration: It is the determination of the spotless not to do evil, even in return, to those who have cherished enmity and done them evil.
T.Kannan:
The code of the pure in heart Is not to
hurt in return any hurt caused in hate.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Not to hurt those who have caused harm before, out of wrath, is the principled path of the impeccable.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Karuththuinnaa Seydhavak Kannum
Maruththinnaa
Seyyaamai Maasatraar Kol
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The spotless hearts seek not revenge 
Though Malice does the worst in rage.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though malice work its worst, planning no ill return, to endure,
And work no ill, is fixed decree of men in spirit pure.
Various Translators: It is the principle of the pure in heart never to injure others, even when they themselves have been hatefully injured.
Dinamalar: It is the nature of the stainless not to resist evil.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Vengeance even against a wanton insult
Brings unbearable woes.
Transliteration: In an ascetic inflict suffering even on those who hate him, when he has not done them any evil, it will afterwards give him irretrievable sorrow.
T.Kannan:
Vengeance even against a wanton insult
Brings unbearable woes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: To harm even those who antagonize us unprovoked, will bring boundless suffering.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Seyyaamal Setraarkkum Innaadha
Seydhapin
Uyyaa Vizhuman Tharum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Revenging even causeless hate 
Bad blood breeds and baneful heat.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though unprovoked thy soul malicious foes should sting,
Retaliation wrought inevitable woes will bring.
Various Translators: Even our vengeance for a wanton injury results in our own unbearable sorrow.
Dinamalar: Harming others, even enemies who harmed you unprovoked, surely brings incessant sorrow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Punish an evil-doer
By shaming him with a good deed.
Transliteration: The (proper) punishment to those who have done evil (to you), is to put them to shame by showing them kindness, in return and to forget both the evil and the good done on both sides.
T.Kannan:
Punish an evil-doer By shaming him with a
good deed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The way to punish those who harmed us is to shame them by doing them good.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Innaasey Thaarai Oruththal Avarnaana
Nannayanj Cheydhu Vital
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Doing good turns, put them to shame
Thus chide the evil who do harm.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The noblest revenge is to put the foe to the blush by our acts of kindness.
Various Translators:
To punish wrong, with kindly benefits the doers ply;
Thus shame their souls; but pass the ill unheeded by.
Dinamalar: If you return kindness for injuries received and forget both, Those who harmed you will be punished by their own shame.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: What good is a man’s knowledge unless it prompts him to prevent the pain of others as if it were his own pain?
Transliteration: What benefit has he derived from his knowledge, who does not endeavour to keep off pain from another as much as from himself ?
T.Kannan:
What does a man gain from his wisdom
If he pines not at others' pain as his own?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What does a man gain from his wisdom If he
pines not at others' pain as his own?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What profiteth one’s reason, if one does not feel others’ sufferings as his own and guard against them?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: What use is it to be wise, if one cant treat others’ woes as one’s own.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Arivinaan Aakuva Thunto Piridhinnoi
Thannoipol Potraak Katai
Various Translators:
What does a man from wisdom gain
If he pines not at other's pain?
Dinamalar:
From wisdom's vaunted lore what doth the learner gain,
If as his own he guard not others' souls from pain?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Actions that are known to harm oneself should never be inflicted upon others.
Transliteration: Let not a man consent to do those things to another which, he knows, will cause sorrow.
T.Kannan:
Do not do to others what you know
Has hurt yourself.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Avoid all that causes pain to others.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Do not do to others what you know Has hurt
yourself.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Shy away from doing to others what you perceive would have harmed you.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Innaa Enaththaan Unarndhavai
Thunnaamai
Ventum Pirankan Seyal
Various Translators:
What you feel as 'pain' to yourself
 Do it not to the other self
Dinamalar:
What his own soul has felt as bitter pain,
From making others feel should man abstain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To work no wilful woe, in any wise, through all the days,
To any living soul, is virtue's highest praise.
Transliteration: It is the chief of all virtues not knowingly to do any person evil, even in the lowest degree, and at any time.
T.Kannan: The highest principle is this: never knowingly harm anyone at any time in any way.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
It is best to refrain from willfully hurting
Anyone, anytime, anyway.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It is the supremest virtue not to commit at any time even slight injury to others.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
It is best to refrain from willfully
hurting Anyone, anytime, anyway.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Never do a harmful deed, however small, to anyone, in any circumstance, consciously or otherwise.
Various Translators:
Enaiththaanum Egngnaandrum Yaarkkum
Manaththaanaam
Maanaasey Yaamai Thalai
Dinamalar:
Any, anywhere injure not 
At any time even in thought.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Why does a man inflict upon other creatures those sufferings, which he has found by experience are sufferings to himself ?
Transliteration:
Whose soul has felt as bitter smart of wrong, how can,
He wrongs inflict on ever living soul of man?
T.Kannan: Why does he who knows what injury to his own life is like inflict injury upon other living human beings?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Why does one hurt others
Knowing what it is to be hurt?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: How is it a man inflicts injury upon others knowing how painful it would be to himself?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Why does one hurt others Knowing what it
is to be hurt?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Why does one hurt other lives, doing what he knows can hurt oneself?
Various Translators:
Thannuyirkaku Ennaamai Thaanarivaan
Enkolo
Mannuyirkku Innaa Seyal
Dinamalar:
How can he injure other souls
Who in his life injury feels.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Harm others in the forenoon 
Harm seeks thee in afternoon.
Transliteration:
If, ere the noontide , you to others evil do,
Before the eventide will evil visit you.
T.Kannan: If a man visits sorrow on another in the morning, sorrow will visit him unbidden in the afternoon.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: As the night follows day, evil that we do recoils on us.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The pain you inflict on others in the morn,
Will come back at you on its own by eve.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The pain you inflict on others in the
morn, Will come back at you on its own by eve.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If a man inflict sorrow upon others in the morning, it will come upon him unsought in the very evening.
Various Translators: If you harm others in the forenoon, harm will visit you, by itself, in the afternoon.
Dinamalar:
Pirarkkinnaa Murpakal Seyyin
Thamakku
InnaaPirpakal Thaame Varum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Harm descends on those who harm others; hence, those who wish not to be harmed, do no harm.
