Transliteration:
Noyellaam Noiseydhaar Melavaam
Noiseyyaar
Noyinmai Ventu Pavar
T.Kannan:
No harm is done by peace lovers 
For pains rebound on pain givers.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
O'er every evil doer evil broodeth still;
He evil shuns who freedom seeks from ill.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: All suffering recoils on the wrongdoer himself. Thus, those desiring not to suffer refrain from causing others pain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: All sufferings befall those who inflict harm on others. Those who desire immunity from suffering never commit injury.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Hurt comes to the hurtful; hence it is those
Who don't want to be hurt cause no hurt.
Various Translators: Sorrow will come upon those who cause pain to others; therfore those, who desire to be free from sorrow, give no pain to others.
Dinamalar:
Hurt comes to the hurtful; hence it is
those Who don't want to be hurt cause no hurt.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: What is a righteous deed? Not killing. Killing leads to everything evil.
Transliteration:
Aravinai Yaadhenin Kollaamai Koral
Piravinai Ellaan Tharum
T.Kannan:
What is Virtue? 'Tis not to kill
For killing causes every ill.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What is the work of virtue? 'Not to kill';
For 'killing' leads to every work of ill.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If you ask what is the sum total of virtues, it is non-killing; killing begets sin.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: What is virtuous conduct? It is never destroying life, for killing leads to every other sin.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What is virtue? It is not to kill,
For killing causes every ill.
Various Translators: Never to destroy life is the sum of all virtuous conduct. The destruction of life leads to every evil.
Dinamalar:
What is virtue? It is not to kill, For
killing causes every ill.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The chief of all codes ever written Is to
share your food and protect all life.
Transliteration: Sharing food and taking care of all lives, is the foremost amongst all virtues compiled in all scriptures.
T.Kannan:
Pakuththuntu Palluyir Ompudhal
Noolor
Thokuththavatrul Ellaan Thalai
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Share the food and serve all lives 
This is the law of all the laws.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: All the scriptures emphasise the virtue of hospitality and the creed of non-violence.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let those that need partake your meal; guard everything that lives;
This the chief and sum of lore that hoarded wisdom gives.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Of all virtues summed by ancient sages, the foremost are to share one’s food and to protect all living creatures.
Various Translators:
The chief of all codes ever written
Is to share your food and protect all life.
Dinamalar: The chief of all (the virtues) which authors have summed up, is the partaking of food that has been shared with others, and the preservation of the mainfold life of other creatures.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The first and foremost good is 'Non
killing'. Next to it in rank comes 'Not lying'.
Transliteration: The crown of all virtues is non-violence. Next comes non-lying.
T.Kannan: Not killing is the foremost virtue; it is good to follow that up with not lying.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ondraaka Nalladhu Kollaamai
Matradhan
Pinsaarap Poiyaamai Nandru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Not to kill is unique good
The next, not to utter falsehood.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Alone, first of good things, is 'not to slay';
The second is, no unture word to say.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Not killing is the first and foremost good. The virtue of not lying comes next.
Various Translators: Not to destroy life is an incomparably (great) good next to it in goodness ranks freedom from falsehood.
Dinamalar:
The first and foremost good is 'Non killing'.
Next to it in rank comes 'Not lying'.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The path of rectitude is the path of non-violence.
Transliteration:
What is the perfect path? It is the path
of avoiding killing anything.
T.Kannan: What is a perfect path? It is the pursuit of the principle of not slaying any being.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nallaaru Enappatuvadhu Yaadhenin
Yaadhondrum
Kollaamai Soozhum Neri
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What way is good? That we can say
The way away from heat to slay.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
You ask, what is the good and perfect way?
'Tis path of him who studies nought to slay.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What is the good way? It is the path that reflects on how it may avoid killing any living creature.
Various Translators: Good path is that which considers how it may avoid killing any creature.
Dinamalar:
What is the perfect path?
It is the path of avoiding killing anything.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Far greater than an ascetic who renounces the fleeting world is the follower of non-violence.
Transliteration:
Of all who renounce fearing instability,
the foremost is he Who avoids killing fearing murder.
T.Kannan: Of all those who, despising material existence, have embraced renunciation, the foremost are those who fear and shun killing.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nilaianji Neeththaarul Ellaam
Kolaianjik
Kollaamai Soozhvaan Thalai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Of saints who renounce birth fearing 
The head is he who dreads killing.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Of those who 'being' dread, and all renounce, the chief are they,
Who, dreading crime of slaughter, study nought to slay.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Of all those who, fearing the permanence of earthly births, have abandoned desire, he is the chief who, fearing (the guilt of) murder, considers how he may avoid the destruction of life.
Various Translators: Among all who disown the world out of dismay, the foremost, dismayed with killing, embrace nonkilling.
Dinamalar:
Of all who renounce fearing instability, the foremost is he
Who avoids killing fearing murder.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Yama, the Destroyer of life, never invades the realm where non-violence prevails.
Transliteration:
Death that eats up life spares the breath
of him Who puts no life to death.
T.Kannan: Death dares not trample on the life of one who abides by the principle of not killing any life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kollaamai Merkon Tozhukuvaan
Vaazhnaalmel
Sellaadhu Uyirunnung Kootru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Life eating Death shall spare the breath 
Of him who no life puts to death.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Yama, the destroyer of life, will not attack the life of him, who acts under the determination of never destroying life.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ev'n death, that life devours, their happy days shall spare,
Who law, 'Thou shall not kill,' uphold with reverent care.
Various Translators: Life devouring death will not lay waste the living days of one whose code of conduct is to never kill.
Dinamalar:
Death that eats up life spares the breath of him
Who puts no life to death.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Avoid removing the dear life of another
Even when your own life is under threat.
Transliteration:
Avoid removing the dear life of another
Even when your own life is under threat.
T.Kannan: Let no one do that which would destroy the life of another, although he should by so doing, lose his own life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even if one were to sacrifice one’s own life, do not commit the act of taking another life.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Thannuyir Neeppinum Seyyarka
Thaanpiridhu
Innuyir Neekkum Vinai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Kill not life that others cherish 
Even when your life must perish.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though thine own life for that spared life the price must pay,
Take not from aught that lives gift of sweet life away.
Various Translators: Refrain from taking precious life from any living being, even to save your own life.
Dinamalar: Do not commit any act of violence though your life is in peril.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
However great its gains,
The wise despise the profits of slaughter.
Transliteration: The advantage which might flow from destroying life in sacrifice, is dishonourable to the wise (who renounced the world), even although it should be said to be productive of great good.
T.Kannan:
However great its gains, The wise despise
the profits of slaughter.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even if great wealth leads to great benefits, great men loathe wealth obtained by sacrifice of lives.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nandraakum Aakkam Peridheninum
Saandrorkkuk
Kondraakum Aakkang Katai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The gain of slaughter is a vice
Though deemed good in sacrifice.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though great the gain of good should seem, the wise,
Will any gain by slaughter won despise.
Various Translators: By sacrifice of life, some gain great wealth and welfare, but great men scorn such odious gains.
Dinamalar: The truly great scorn the riches acquired through slaughter.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Men who practice slaughter as a profession
Are placed amongst men of disgrace.
Transliteration: Men who destroy life are base men, in the estimation of those who know the nature of meanness.
T.Kannan:
Men who practice slaughter as a profession
Are placed amongst men of disgrace.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: For those who can see the folly of it, the savage imbeciles in any profession involving killing are doing a despicable job.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kolaivinaiya Raakiya Maakkal
Pulaivinaiyar
Punmai Therivaa Rakaththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those who live by slaying are 
Eaters of carrion bizarre!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Whose trade is 'killing'; always vile they show,
To minds of them who what is vileness know.
Various Translators: In the eyes of the discerning, men given to slaughter are but churls.
Dinamalar: Those whose trade is killing creatures are deemed defiled by men who know the defiling nature of being mean.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A deprived life of diseased bodies, they say,
Comes from depriving the life of another.
Transliteration: (The wise) will say that men of diseased bodies, who live in degradation and in poverty, are those who separated the life from the body of animals (in a former birth).
T.Kannan:
A deprived life of diseased bodies, they
say, Comes from depriving the life of another.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those with a rotting sickly body and a rotten life mired in poverty, must have killed other beings before.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
UyirUtampin Neekkiyaar Enpa
SeyirUtampin
Sellaaththee Vaazhkkai Yavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The loathsome poor sickly and sore 
Are killers stained by blood before
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Behold the Lazarus, he is guilty of acts of violence in his former birth.
Various Translators:
Who lead a loathed life in bodies sorely pained,
Are men, the wise declare, by guilt of slaughter stained.
Dinamalar: They say that beggars who suffer a depraved life in a diseased body once deprived another’s body of its life.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There is no baser folly than the infatuation that looks upon the ephemeral as if it were everlasting.
Transliteration: That ignorance which considers those things to be stable which are not so, is dishonourable (to the wise).
T.Kannan:
No baser folly than the infatuation
That takes the fleeting for the permanent.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
No baser folly than the infatuation That
takes the fleeting for the permanent.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It is contemptible folly to mistake the unstable for the stable.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To believe that transient things will last forever is deplorable stupidity.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Nillaadha Vatrai Nilaiyina
Endrunarum
Pullari Vaanmai Katai
Various Translators:
The worst of follies it is told 
The fleeting as lasting to hold.
Dinamalar:
Lowest and meanest lore, that bids men trust secure,
In things that pass away, as things that shall endure!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Amassing great wealth is gradual, like the gathering of a theater crowd. Its dispersal is sudden, like that same crowd departing.
Transliteration: The acquisition of wealth is like the gathering together of an assembly for a theatre; its expenditure is like the breaking up of that assembly.
T.Kannan:
Great wealth, like a crowd at a concert,
Gathers and melts.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The flow of fortune is like the gathering of a crowd at a concert; its ebb is like the melting of the crowd at its close.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Great wealth, like a crowd at a concert,
Gathers and melts.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Great wealth accumulates like a crowd assembled at a theatre; when it goes, it vanishes like the crowd at the end of the play.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kooththaattu Avaik Kuzhaath Thatre
PerunjelvamPokkum Adhuvilin Thatru
Various Translators:
Like a drama crowd wealth gathers 
Like passing show its pride too goes.
Dinamalar:
As crowds round dancers fill the hall, is wealth's increase;
It's loss, as throngs dispersing, when the dances cease.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Unenduring is all wealth; if you wealth enjoy,
Enduring works in working wealth straightway employ.
Transliteration: Wealth is perishable; let those who obtain it immediately practise those (virtues) which are imperishable.
T.Kannan: Wealth’s nature is to be unenduring. Upon acquiring it, quickly do that which is enduring.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Perishable is the nature of wealth; if you obtain it,
Forthwith do something not perishable.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Fortune is fickle; if you come by it delay not; put it to proper use.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Perishable is the nature of wealth; if you
obtain it, Forthwith do something not perishable.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Wealth is transient; when it comes about, use it to do a lasting righteous deed.
Various Translators:
Arkaa Iyalpitruch Chelvam
Adhupetraal
Arkupa Aange Seyal
Dinamalar:
Wealth wanes away; but when it comes 
Take care to do enduring things.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Time, which shows itself (to the ignorant) as if it were something (real) is in the estimation of the wise (only) a saw which cuts down life.
Transliteration:
As 'day' it vaunts itself; well understood, 'tis knife',
That daily cuts away a portion from thy life.
T.Kannan: Though it seems a harmless gauge of time, to those who fathom it, a day is a saw steadily cutting down the tree of life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A day in reality is nothing but
A relentless slicing of a saw through one's life.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Time seems all laughter; but to the discerning it is a saw sawing away the life of men.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A day in reality is nothing but A
relentless slicing of a saw through one's life.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The wise get this : Time, that manifests itself as days, is a sword that slices off life.
Various Translators:
Naalena Ondrupor Kaatti Uyir
EerumVaaladhu Unarvaarp Perin
Dinamalar:
The showy day is but a saw 
Your life, know that, to file and gnaw.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ere tongue benumbs and hiccough comes 
Rise up to do good deeds betimes.
Transliteration:
Before the tongue lie powerless, 'mid the gasp of gurgling breath,
Arouse thyself, and do good deeds beyond the power of death.
T.Kannan: Do good deeds with a sense of urgency, before death’s approaching rattle strangles the tongue.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Before hiccough arises and before the tongue is paralysed, do good that leads to salvation.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Better commit some good acts before the tongue
Benumbs and deadly hiccup descends.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Better commit some good acts before the
tongue Benumbs and deadly hiccup descends.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Let virtuous deeds be done quickly, before the biccup comes making the tongue silent.
Various Translators: Before your tongue goes numb and you let out your last breath, make haste to do a good deed.
Dinamalar:
Naachchetru Vikkulmel Vaaraamun
Nalvinai
Mersendru Seyyap Patum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Who was there yesterday, is gone today: the world is thus.
Transliteration:
Nerunal Ulanoruvan Indrillai Ennum
Perumai Utaiththuiv Vulaku
T.Kannan:
One was yesterday; not today! 
The wonder of the world's way!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Existing yesterday, to day to nothing hurled! 
Such greatness owns this transitory world.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What wondrous greatness this world possesses— that yesterday a man was, and today he is not.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Yesterday he was but to-day he is not; this is the glory of the earth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The one who existed yesterday is no more today.
That is the glory of earthly life.
Various Translators: This world possesses the greatness that one who yesterday was is not today.
Dinamalar:
The one who existed yesterday is no more
today. That is the glory of earthly life.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: They, who, hold over a billion thoughts in their minds, know not how to live their lives for a moment.
Transliteration:
Orupozhudhum Vaazhvadhu Ariyaar
Karudhupa
Kotiyum Alla Pala
T.Kannan:
Man knows not his next moment 
On crores of things he is intent.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who know not if their happy lives shall last the day,
In fancies infinite beguile the hours away!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: One is not sure what awaits him the next moment; but he becomes a prey to a thousand and one thoughts.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Men do not know if they will live another moment, yet their thoughts are ten million and more.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Men unsure of living the next moment,
Make more than a million plans.
Various Translators: Innumerable are the thoughts which occupy the mind of (the unwise), who know not that they shall live another moment.
Dinamalar:
Men unsure of living the next moment, Make
more than a million plans.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The soul's link to the body Is like the
bird that flies away from the nest.
Transliteration: A bird breaks away from the egg, leaving the shells alone; so is life related to body.
T.Kannan:
Kutampai Thaniththu Ozhiyap Pulparan
ThatreUtampotu Uyiritai Natpu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The soul from body any day 
Like bird from egg shell flies away.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The attachment of life to the body is like that of a full-fledged bird flying from its broken shell.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Birds fly away, and leave the nest deserted bare;
Such is the short lived friendship soul and body share.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The soul’s attachment to the body is like that of a fledgling, which forsakes its empty shell and flies away.
Various Translators:
The soul's link to the body
Is like the bird that flies away from the nest.
Dinamalar: The love of the soul to the body is like (the love of) a bird to its egg which it flies away from and leaves empty.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Death is like sleep, And birth an
awakening from it.
Transliteration: Death is like sleep, birth is that awakening from sleep.
T.Kannan: Death is like going off to sleep; birth is like waking up from it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Urangu Vadhupolunj Chaakkaatu Urangi
Vizhippadhu Polum Pirappu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Death is like a slumber deep 
And birth like waking from that sleep.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Death is sinking into slumbers deep;
Birth again is walking out of sleep.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Death is like falling asleep, and birth is like waking from that sleep.
Various Translators: Death is like sleep; birth is like awaking from it.
Dinamalar:
Death is like sleep,
And birth an awakening from it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Why should the soul seek a temporary shelter in the perishable body? Is there not a durable habitation for it?
Transliteration:
Is there no permanent refuge for the soul,
Which takes a temporary shelter in the body?
T.Kannan: Doesn’t life have a permanent dwelling? It has taken shelter in this body.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pukkil Amaindhindru Kollo Utampinul
Thuchchil Irundha Uyirkku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The life berthed in this body shows 
A fixed home it never knows.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The soul in fragile shed as lodger courts repose: 
Is it because no home's conclusive rest it knows?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Not yet settled in a permanent home, the soul takes temporary shelter in a body.
Various Translators: It seems as if the soul, which takes a temporary shelter in a body, had not attained a home.
Dinamalar:
Is there no permanent refuge for the soul,
Which takes a temporary shelter in the body?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A man does not suffer pain from whatever things he has renounced.
Transliteration:
'Whatever thing of whatever kind' a man
relinquishes, Suffering 'there from, there from' he has
none.
T.Kannan: Pain, there is none, from all those one renounces.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Yaadhanin Yaadhanin Neengiyaan
Nodhal
Adhanin Adhanin Ilan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
From what from what a man is free 
From that, from that his torments flee.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From whatever, aye, whatever, man gets free,
From what? aye, from that, no more of pain hath he!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Whatever thing, a man has renounced, by that thing; he cannot suffer pain.
Various Translators: Whatsoever a man has renounced, from the sorrow born of that he has freed himself.
Dinamalar:
'Whatever thing of whatever kind' a man relinquishes,
Suffering 'there from, there from' he has none.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There is endless joy in early renunciation.
Transliteration:
Renounce early if you seek joy; For many
are the delights in store after renouncing.
T.Kannan: The pleasures of this world after renouncing are immense; if you wish those, renounce when you can .
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ventin Un Taakath Thurakka
ThurandhapinEentuiyar Paala Pala
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Give up all to gain the True
And endless joys shall hence seek you.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: After a man has renounced (all things), there will still be many things in this world (which he may enjoy); if he should desire them, let him, while it is time abandon. (the world).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Renounciation' made ev'n here true pleasures men acquire;
'Renounce' while time is yet, if to those pleasures you aspire,
Various Translators: The greatest gladness in the world comes after renunciation. Let men desiring that rapture renounce early in life.
Dinamalar:
Renounce early if you seek joy;
For many are the delights in store after renouncing.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To be controlled are the senses five
And to be given up at once are all cravings.
Transliteration:
To be controlled are the senses five And
to be given up at once are all cravings.
T.Kannan: Let the five senses be destroyed; and at the same time, let everything be abandoned that (the ascetic) has (formerly) desired.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: To renounce all that one desires, the five senses should be overcome.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Atalventum Aindhan Pulaththai
Vitalventum
Ventiya Vellaam Orungu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Curb the senses five and renounce
The craving desires all at once.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Perceptions of the five' must all expire: 
'Relinquished in its order each desire.
Various Translators: The five senses must be subdued, and every desire simultaneously surrendered.
Dinamalar: Subdue your senses and give up all your longings.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nature of penance is giving up everything.
Else, it is a return to snares once given up.
Transliteration: To be altogether destitute is the proper condition of those who perform austerities; if they possess anything, it will change (their resolution) and bring them back to their confused state.
T.Kannan:
Nature of penance is giving up everything.
Else, it is a return to snares once given up.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Not to have a thing is the essense of penance; any possession lures one away from it.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Iyalpaakum Nonpirkondru Inmai
Utaimai
Mayalaakum Matrum Peyarththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To have nothing is law of vows 
Having the least deludes and snares.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Privation absolute' is penance true;
'Possession' brings bewilderment anew.
Various Translators: The ascetic’s austerity permits not a single possession, for possessions draw him back into delusion.
Dinamalar: Renunciation is the mark of asceticism. Any clinging leads to one’s delusion.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When the body itself is a burden on the way to liberation,
Why carry other attachments?
Transliteration: What means the addition of other things those who are attempting to cut off (future) births, when even their body is too much (for them).
T.Kannan:
When the body itself is a burden on the
way to liberation, Why carry other attachments?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: For those ascetics seeking relief from rebirth, own flesh is an excess. what purpose do other affinities serve?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Matrum Thotarppaatu Evankol
Pirapparukkal
Utraarkku Utampum Mikai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Why add to bonds while this body
Is too much for saints to be birth free.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To those who sev'rance seek from being's varied strife,
Flesh is burthen sore; what then other bonds of life?
Various Translators: Why talk of other attachments; even our body is a hindrance.
Dinamalar: What are life’s petty attachments to the man who seeks severance from future births, when even his body is a burden?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
His is the world beyond heaven
Who is free of the delusion of I and Mine.
Transliteration: He who destroys the pride which says "I", "mine" will enter a world which is difficult even to the Gods to attain.
T.Kannan:
His is the world beyond heaven Who is free
of the delusion of 'I' and 'Mine'.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One who severs the vanity of ‘I’ and ‘Mine’, shall reach some place better than paradise.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
YaanEnadhu Ennum SerukkuAruppaan
Vaanorkku
Uyarndha Ulakam Pukum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who curbs the pride of I and mine 
Gets a world rare for gods to gain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He enters the abode of the gods who lays the axe at ‘I’ and ‘mine.’
Various Translators:
Who kills conceit that utters 'I' and 'mine',
Shall enter realms above the powers divine.
Dinamalar: One who slays the conceit that clamors “I” and “mine” will reach a realm above the celestials’ world.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If one clings to his attachments, refusing to let go, sorrows will not let go their grip on him.
Transliteration: Sorrows will never let go their hold of those who give not up their hold of desire.
T.Kannan:
Sorrows will never give up its hold on those
Who never give up their hold of desire.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sorrows will never give up its hold on
those Who never give up their hold of desire.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Sufferings seize men of desire.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Miseries will not near those who desist from desire.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Patri Vitaaa Itumpaikal Patrinaip
Patri Vitaaa Thavarkku
Various Translators:
Grief clings on and on to those 
Who cling to bonds without release.
Dinamalar:
Who cling to things that cling and eager clasp,
Griefs cling to them with unrelaxing grasp.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who perfectly renounce attain the highest peak; the rest remain ensnared in delusion’s net.
Transliteration: Those who have entirely renounced (all things and all desire) have obtained (absorption into God); all others wander in confusion, entangled in the net of (many) births.
T.Kannan:
Those who give up all are saved.
The rest are caught in the snare of delusion.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Salvation is for one of renunciation; others get entangled in endless births and deaths.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Those who give up all are saved. The rest
are caught in the snare of delusion.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those who renounce completely, surge ahead; others get enticed and end up entangled in a web.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thalaippattaar Theerath Thurandhaar
Mayangi
Valaippattaar Matrai Yavar
Various Translators:
Who renounce all are free from care 
Others suffer delusive snare.
Dinamalar:
Who thoroughly 'renounce' on highest highest height are set;
The rest, bewildered, lie entangled in the net.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When that which clings falls off, severed is being's tie;
All else will then be seen as instability.
Transliteration: At the moment in which desire has been abandoned, (other) births will be cut off; when that has not been done, instability will be seen.
T.Kannan: Birth ceases when all attachments are severed; until then, one only sees life’s impermanence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Detachment alone severs rebirth.
All else will be found transient.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Cut off all attachments; you cut off the tangle of life; otherwise you are caught.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Detachment alone severs rebirth. All else
will be found transient.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Only when all attachments are severed, the cycle of life and death is broken; anything short of it is transient.
Various Translators:
Patratra Kanne Pirapparukkum Matru
Nilaiyaamai Kaanap Patum
Dinamalar:
Bondage cut off, rebirth is off 
The world then seems instable stuff.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Desire the desire of Him who is without desire; in order to renounce desire, desire that desire.
Transliteration:
Cling thou to that which He, to Whom nought clings, hath bid thee cling,
Cling to that bond, to get thee free from every clinging thing.
T.Kannan: Attach yourself to Him who is free from all attachments. Bind yourself to that bond so all other bonds may be broken.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Cling to the one who clings to nothing;
And so clinging, cease to cling.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Cling fast to Him who is free from all desire. Seek Him for your freedom, from attachment.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Cling to the one who clings to nothing;
And so clinging, cease to cling.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Be attached to God, who is attached to none, only so that you leverage that attachment to let go of all other attachments.
Various Translators:
Patruka Patratraan Patrinai
Appatraip
Patruka Patru Vitarku
Dinamalar:
Bind Thyself to the unbound one 
That binding breaks all bonds anon.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
That error entails ignoble birth 
Which deems vain things as things of worth.
Transliteration:
Of things devoid of truth as real things men deem;
Cause of degraded birth the fond delusive dream!
T.Kannan: The muddled mentality that mistakes the unreal for the Real is the genesis of woeful births.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Out of ignorance which mistakes things unreal for things real springs the wretched cycle of births.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The misery of birth arises out of the delusion
Which takes the unreal for the Real.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The misery of birth arises out of the
delusion Which takes the unreal for the Real.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Inglorious births are produced by the confusion (of mind) which considers those things to be real which are not real.
Various Translators: To be deluded into accepting anything untrue as gospel truth leads to a wasted life.
Dinamalar:
Porulalla Vatraip Porulendru Unarum
Marulaanaam Maanaap Pirappu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Darkness will give way to joy, when delusion is replaced with a flawless vision.
Transliteration:
Irulneengi Inpam Payakkum
Marulneengi
Maasaru Kaatchi Yavarkku
T.Kannan:
Men of spotless pure insight 
Enjoy delight devoid of night.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Darkness departs, and rapture springs to men who see,
The mystic vision pure, from all delusion free.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: For those of undimmed perception, free from delusion, darkness departs and rapture rushes in.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Men of pure vision are led from darkness to light.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Darkness disappears and bliss descends
Upon men of clear vision and free of delusion.
Various Translators: A clear, undimmed vision of things will deliver its possessors from the darkness of future births, and confer the felicity (of heaven).
Dinamalar:
Darkness disappears and bliss descends
Upon men of clear vision and free of delusion.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: For those with conviction, who have dispelled all doubts, the skies are nearer than the earth.
Transliteration:
Aiyaththin Neengith Thelindhaarkku
Vaiyaththin
Vaanam Naniya Thutaiththu
T.Kannan:
To doubtless minds whose heart is clear 
More than earth heaven is near.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
When doubts disperse, and mists of error roll
Away, nearner is heav'n than earth to sage's soul.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: To men of unclouded wisdom heaven is nearer than earth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Heaven is nearer than Earth for those who dispel all doubt and know the Truth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To those enlightened souls freed of doubt,
More than earth is heaven near.
Various Translators: Heaven is nearer than earth to those men of purified minds who are freed from from doubt.
Dinamalar:
To those enlightened souls freed of doubt,
More than earth is heaven near.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Where a sense of the Real is lacking, The
other five senses are useless.
Transliteration: Conquering the five senses makes no sense, when there is no comprehension of truth.
T.Kannan:
Aiyunarvu Eydhiyak Kannum Payamindre
Meyyunarvu Illaa Thavarkku
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Knowledge of five senses is vain 
Without knowing the Truth within.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What profits one’s perfect senses if one is not endowed with true knowledge.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Five fold perception gained, what benefits accure
To them whose spirits lack perception of the true?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: All knowledge acquired through the five senses is worthless to those without knowledge of Truth.
Various Translators:
Where a sense of the Real is lacking,
The other five senses are useless.
Dinamalar: Even those who have all the knowledge which can be attained by the five senses, will derive no benefit from it, if they are without a knowledge of the true nature of things.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Wisdom is to ascertain the reality In
whatever way things are presented.
Transliteration: To track all things to their subtlest retreats is true knowledge.
T.Kannan: Whatever seems to be the nature of anything, wisdom lies in seeking to grasp its true nature.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Epporul Eththanmaith Thaayinum
Apporul
Meypporul Kaanpadhu Arivu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Knowledge is Truth of things to find
In every case of every kind.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Whatever thing, of whatsoever kind it be,
'Tis wisdom's part in each the very thing to see.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: In everything of every kind whatsoever, wisdom perceives Truth in that thing.
Various Translators: (True) knowledge is the perception concerning every thing of whatever kind, that that thing is the true thing.
Dinamalar:
Wisdom is to ascertain the reality
In whatever way things are presented.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who have learnt the truth never enter back to this world.
Transliteration:
Those who have learnt to see the reality
here Will have learnt not to come back here.
T.Kannan: Those who have learnt and grasped the true essence here, will find a path that will not bring them back here.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Katreentu Meypporul Kantaar
Thalaippatuvar
Matreentu Vaaraa Neri
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who learn and here the Truth discern
Enter the path of non return.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who learn, and here the knowledge of the true obtain,
Shall find the path that hither cometh not again.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who find the highest Reality here and now follow a path which never comes back to this world.
Various Translators: They, who in this birth have learned to know the True Being, enter the road which returns not into this world.
Dinamalar:
Those who have learnt to see the reality here
Will have learnt not to come back here.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There is no fear of one’s re-birth if one seeks and finds the truth.
Transliteration:
Reality once searched and seized, No need
to think of rebirth.
T.Kannan: The mind that, after careful consideration, ascertains the truth conclusively, would not contemplate rebirth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Orththullam Ulladhu Unarin
Orudhalaiyaap
Perththulla Ventaa Pirappu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
One minded sage sees inner truth
He is free from thoughts of rebirth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The mind that knows with certitude what is, and ponders well,
Its thoughts on birth again to other life need not to dwell.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Let it not be thought that there is another birth for him whose mind having thoroughly considered (all it has been taught) has known the True Being.
Various Translators: Having thought profoundly and realized fully That which is, one need never think of being born again.
Dinamalar:
Reality once searched and seized,
No need to think of rebirth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Seek the truth to remove delusion; that is wisdom.
Transliteration:
Wisdom lies in realizing that unique
Reality To remove the folly of rebirth.
T.Kannan: For the vanity of birth to vanish, fathom those ultimate truths of true significance.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pirappennum Pedhaimai Neengach
Chirappennum
Semporul Kaanpadhu Arivu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
It is knowledge to know Self Truth 
And remove the folly of birth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: True knowledge consists in the removal of ignorance; which is (the cause of) births, and the perception of the True Being who is (the bestower of) heaven.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When folly, cause of births, departs; and soul can view
The truth of things, man's dignity; 'tis wisdom true.
Various Translators: Wisdom is that rare realization of Perfection’s True Being, which banishes forever the folly of rebirth.
Dinamalar:
Wisdom lies in realizing that unique Reality
To remove the folly of rebirth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To one who does not cling, realizing what to cling,
Clinging ills will not cling.
Transliteration:
To one who does not cling, realizing what
to cling, Clinging ills will not cling.
T.Kannan: He who so lives as to know Him who is the support of all things and abandon all desire, will be freed from the evils which would otherwise cleave to him and destroy (his efforts after absorption).
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: To understand our desires, and to give up those desires, decimates the distress caused by those desires.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Saarpunarndhu Saarpu Ketaozhukin
Matrazhiththuch
Chaardharaa Saardharu Noi
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Know the Refuge; off with bondage 
Be free from ills of thraldom, O sage.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The true'support' who knows rejects'supports' he sought before 
Sorrow that clings and all destroys, shall cling to him no more.
Various Translators: He who clings to life’s true support clings not to lesser things. Sorrows, which destroy by clinging, no longer cling to him.
Dinamalar: Seek the truth on which everything rests; you will be free from all the ills that assail life.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Lust, wrath and delusion: Where these three are unknown,
Sorrows shall not be.
Transliteration: If the very names of these three things, desire, anger, and confusion of mind, be destroyed, then will also perish evils (which flow from them).
T.Kannan:
Lust, wrath and delusion: Where these
three are unknown, Sorrows shall not be.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Live such that even the labels for Desire, anger and ignorance do not exist; then, the ills caused by them will cease.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kaamam Vekuli Mayakkam Ivaimundran
Naamam Ketakketum Noi
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Woes expire when lust, wrath, folly 
Expire even to name, fully.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When lust and wrath and error's triple tyranny is o'er,
Their very names for aye extinct, then pain shall be no more.
Various Translators: Desire, delusion and indignation—annihilation of these three terms is the termination of torment.
Dinamalar: Wipe out the very names of lust, anger and delusion; you will be wiping out the pause of re-birth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Desire, they say, is the seed of ceaseless birth
For all things living at all times.
Transliteration: (The wise) say that the seed, which produces unceasing births, at all times, to all creatures, is desire.
T.Kannan:
Desire, they say, is the seed of ceaseless
birth For all things living at all times.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Desire is the seed which, for all lives, unfailingly, leads to an endless cycle of birth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Avaaenpa Ellaa Uyirkkum Enj
GnaandrumThavaaap Pirappeenum Viththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Desire to all, always is seed 
From which ceaseless births proceed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The wise declare, through all the days, to every living thing,
That ceaseless round of birth from seed of strong desire doth spring.
Various Translators: The learned say desire is the eternal seed of life.
Dinamalar: At all times and to all creatures, the seed of ceaseless births is desire.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Must you desire, desire freedom from birth.
That comes only by desiring desirelessness.
Transliteration: If anything be desired, freedom from births should be desired; that (freedom from births) will be attained by desiring to be without desire.
T.Kannan:
Must you desire, desire freedom from
birth. That comes only by desiring desirelessness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If you desire, desire for freedom from birth; desiring not to desire, too, leads to that freedom.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ventungaal Ventum Piravaamai
Matradhu
Ventaamai Venta Varum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If long thou must, long for non birth
It comes by longing no more for earth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Do you long for anything? Long for not being born again; this you can achieve if you cease your desires.
Various Translators:
If desire you feel, freedom from changing birth require!
'Twill come, if you desire to 'scape, set free from all desire.
Dinamalar: If you must desire, desire freedom from birth. That will only come by desiring desirelessness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Here no fortune is as dear as desirelessness; and even there, nothing like it can be found.
Transliteration: There is in this world no excellence equal to freedom from desire; and even in that world, there is nothing like it.
T.Kannan:
No greater fortune here than not to yearn,
And none to excel it hereafter too!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
No greater fortune here than not to yearn,
And none to excel it hereafter too!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: There is no greater possession than freedom from desire either here or in the world beyond.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: There is no wealth here better than lack of desire; nowhere else is there anything that equals it.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ventaamai Anna Vizhuchchelvam
Eentillai
Aantum Aqdhoppadhu Il
Various Translators:
No such wealth is here and there
As peerless wealth of non desire.
Dinamalar:
No glorious wealth is here like freedom from desire;
To bliss like this not even there can soul aspire.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Purity is but freedom from desire, and that comes from thirsting after Truth.
Transliteration: Purity (of mind) consists in freedom from desire; and that (freedom from desire) is the fruit of the love of truth.
T.Kannan:
Purity is freedom from yearning
And that comes of seeking Truth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: What is purity of mind but absence of desire? It will follow if one burns for truth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Purity is freedom from yearning And that
comes of seeking Truth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Purity is absence of desire; which, is obtained through the quest for truth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thoouymai Enpadhu Avaavinmai
Matradhu
Vaaaimai Venta Varum
Various Translators:
To nothing crave is purity 
That is the fruit of verity.
Dinamalar:
Desire's decease as purity men know;
That, too, from yearning search for truth will grow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Men freed from bonds of strong desire are free;
None other share such perfect liberty.
Transliteration: They are said to be free (from future birth) who are freed from desire; all others (who, whatever else they may be free from, are not freed from desire) are not thus free.
T.Kannan: They say only those who have renounced desire are renunciates. Others, though they have renounced all else, are not.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those are free who are free of yearning.
Others, of all else free, remain un-free.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Only those who have renounced are free; others are not.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those are free who are free of yearning.
Others, of all else free, remain un-free.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Only those who’ve renounced desire have renounced; the rest, who’ve renounced all else, have not truly renounced.
Various Translators:
Atravar Enpaar Avaaatraar Matraiyaar
Atraaka Atradhu Ilar
Dinamalar:
The free are those who desire not
The rest not free in bonds are caught.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is the chief duty of (an ascetic) to watch against desire with (jealous) fear; for it has power to deceive (and destroy) him.
Transliteration:
Desire each soul beguiles;
True virtue dreads its wiles.
T.Kannan: As it is desire, above all else, which deceives a man, ascetics rightfully dread it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
If you love virtue, flee from desire;
For desire is a great betrayer.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It is desire that seduces men into sin; Asceticism dreads desires.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If you love virtue, flee from desire; For
desire is a great betrayer.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Desire is a deceptive trap; fearing it, is a virtue.
Various Translators:
Anjuva Thorum Arane Oruvanai
Vanjippa Thorum Avaa
Dinamalar:
Dread desire; Virtue is there
To every soul desire is snare!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Destroy desire; deliverance 
Comes as much as you aspire hence.
Transliteration:
Who thoroughly rids his life of passion prompted deed,
Deeds of unfailing worth shall do, which , as he plans, succeed.
T.Kannan: Desisting from all desire driven deeds, a renouncer finds liberation approaching, just as he desired.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The desired path of virtue is open to one who kills desire.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
When all deeds of desire are uprooted,
Liberation comes as and when desired.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When all deeds of desire are uprooted,
Liberation comes as and when desired.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If a man thoroughly cut off all desire, the deeds, which confer immortality, will come to him, in the path in which he seeks them.
Various Translators: One can do flawless deeds the way one wants to do, when desire is destroyed completely.
Dinamalar:
Avaavinai Aatra Aruppin Thavaavinai
Thaanventu Maatraan Varum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who are devoid of desire are free from misery; for others, it keeps piling up.
Transliteration:
Avaaillaark Killaakun Thunpam
Aqdhuntel
Thavaaadhu Menmel Varum
T.Kannan:
Desire extinct no sorrow taints
Grief comes on grief where it pretends.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Affliction is not known where no desires abide;
Where these are, endless rises sorrow's tide.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who has no desires has no sorrow. But where desire exists, endless sorrows ensue.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: There is no sorrow for those who are free from desire. Endless sorrows befall men with desire.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Where there is no desire, there is no sorrow.
Where there is, it comes over and above.
Various Translators: There is no sorrow to those who are without desire; but where that is, (sorrow) will incessantly come, more and more.
Dinamalar:
Where there is no desire, there is no
sorrow. Where there is, it comes over and above.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When desire, the misery of miseries, is decimated, unending joy abounds.
Transliteration:
Inpam Itaiyaraa Theentum Avaavennum
Thunpaththul Thunpang Ketin
T.Kannan:
Desire, the woe of woes destroy 
Joy of joys here you enjoy.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
When dies away desire, that woe of woes
Ev'n here the soul unceasing rapture knows.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: There is an eternal flow of life’s happiness when desire, the evil of ail evils, dies out.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: When desire, sorrow’s sorrow, dies away, undying bliss prevails here on Earth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When the misery of miseries called desire ends,
The result is never-ending joy.
Various Translators: Even while in this body, joy will never depart (from the mind, in which) desire, that sorrow of sorrows, has been destroyed.
Dinamalar:
When the misery of miseries called desire
ends, The result is never-ending joy.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The state of eternal bliss will result
When desire that is insatiable is conquered.
Transliteration: Eternal bliss ensues, when insatiable desire ends.
T.Kannan:
Aaraa Iyarkai Avaaneeppin Annilaiye
Peraa Iyarkai Tharum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Off with desire insatiate 
You gain the native blissful state.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Give up your insatiable longings; you will be conferring on yourself an eternal life.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Drive from thy soul desire insatiate;
Straight way is gained the moveless blissful state.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is the nature of desire never to be fulfilled, but he who utterly gives it up is eternally fulfilled at that very moment.
Various Translators:
The state of eternal bliss will result
When desire that is insatiable is conquered.
Dinamalar: The removal of desire, whose nature it is never to be satisfied, will immediately confer a nature that can never be changed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The gains of labour, and loss due to
languor, Are both outcomes of fate.
Transliteration: Out of fate springs perseverance which leads to one’s fortune. Out of fate springs one’s indolence which leads to one’s ruin.
T.Kannan: Constructive ool causes tireless endeavor leading to prosperity; destructive ool causes indolence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aakoozhaal Thondrum Asaivinmai
Kaipporul
Pokoozhaal Thondrum Mati
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Efforts succeed by waxing star 
Wealth losing brings waning star.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Wealth giving fate power of unflinching effort brings;
From fate that takes away idle remissness springs.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: On Wealth
Various Translators: Perseverance comes from a prosperous fate, and idleness from an adverse fate.
Dinamalar:
The gains of labour, and loss due to languor,
Are both outcomes of fate.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Fate makes fools of the wise. Fate makes folly pass for wisdom.
Transliteration:
Adverse fate befools, and when time serves
A harmless fate expands knowledge.
T.Kannan: Malign ool blunts one’s intelligence; in its turn, benign ool sharpens it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pedhaip Patukkum Izhavoozh
Arivakatrum
Aakaloozh Utrak Katai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Loss fate makes a dull fool of us
Gain fate makes us prosperous, wise!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The fate that loss ordains makes wise men's wisdom foolishness;
The fate that gain bestows with ampler power will wisdom bless.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: That destiny which decreases prosperity increases ignorance. That destiny which diminishes loss expands knowledge.
Various Translators: An adverse fate produces folly, and a prosperous fate produces enlarged knowledge.
Dinamalar:
Adverse fate befools, and when time serves
A harmless fate expands knowledge.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: What if one is a man of subtle learning; one’s mind is swayed by fate.
Transliteration:
A man may have studied many subtle works,
But what survives is his innate wisdom.
T.Kannan: Even if knowledge comes through profound books, one’s innate wisdom remains dominant.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nunniya Noolpala Karpinum Matrundhan
Unmai Yarive Mikum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What matters subtle study deep? 
Levels of innate wisdom keep.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In subtle learning manifold though versed man be,
The wisdom, truly his, will gain supremacy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Although (a man) may study the most polished treatises, the knowledge which fate has decreed to him will still prevail.
Various Translators: However subtle the sundry texts he studies, a man is left with his native intelligence.
Dinamalar:
A man may have studied many subtle works,
But what survives is his innate wisdom.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Fate has a double sway. It makes the foolish rich and the wise poor.
Transliteration:
The world ordains two different ways:
Acquiring wealth is one, attaining wisdom another.
T.Kannan: The world is stratified based on two factors: wealth and wisdom; and, they are not correlated.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Iruveru Ulakaththu Iyarkai Thiruveru
Thelliya Raadhalum Veru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Two natures in the world obtain 
Some wealth and others wisdom gain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: There are (through fate) two different natures in the world, hence the difference (observable in men) in (their acquisition of) wealth, and in their attainment of knowledge.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Two fold the fashion of the world; some live in fortune's light;
While other some have souls in wisdom's radiance bright.
Various Translators: Two natural ways are ordained in this world. Securing wealth is one. Seeking wisdom’s light is another.
Dinamalar:
The world ordains two different ways:
Acquiring wealth is one, attaining wisdom another.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
In business dealings, fate can turn
All good things bad and even bad good.
Transliteration:
In business dealings, fate can turn All
good things bad and even bad good.
T.Kannan: In the acquisition of property, every thing favourable becomes unfavourable, and (on the other hand) everything unfavourable becomes favourable, (through the power of fate).
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: While seeking wealth, positive aspects can turn harmful; and negative aspects beneficial.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nallavai Ellaaan Theeyavaam
Theeyavum
Nallavaam Selvam Seyarku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In making wealth fate changes mood; 
The good as bad and bad as good.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
All things that good appear will oft have ill success;
All evil things prove good for gain of happiness.
Various Translators: In karma’s presence, sure success with wealth can fail, and certain failure can succeed.
Dinamalar: Things favourable become adverse, and the unfavourable favourable.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What is not naturally ours cannot be got,
Nor what is natural, ejected.
Transliteration: Whatever is not conferred by fate cannot be preserved although it be guarded with most painful care; and that, which fate has made his, cannot be lost, although one should even take it and throw it away.
T.Kannan:
What is not naturally ours cannot be got,
Nor what is natural, ejected.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Strive hard, we may; but what we don’t deserve doesn’t stay, and what we deserve, we can’t dispose.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pariyinum Aakaavaam Paalalla
Uyththuch
Choriyinum Pokaa Thama
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Things not thine never remain 
Things destined are surely thine.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Things not your own will yeild no good, howe'er you guard with pain;
You own, however you scatter them abroad, will yours remain.
Various Translators: Though you guard it well, what destiny does not decree disappears. Though you cast it aside, what destiny calls yours will not depart.
Dinamalar: One may lose one’s wealth however carefully one may guard it. One may not lose it though he flings it away. It is all ordained by fate.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Except as disposed by the Disposer,
Even millions amassed may not be enjoyed.
Transliteration: Even those who gather together millions will only enjoy them, as it has been determined by the disposer (of all things).
T.Kannan:
Except as disposed by the Disposer, Even
millions amassed may not be enjoyed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One may amass wealth worth crores, but can consume only as ordained by the Ordainer (based on ool).
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vakuththaan Vakuththa Vakaiyallaal
Koti
Thokuththaarkku Thuyththal Aridhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who crores amass enjoy but what 
The Dispenser's decrees allot.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Save as the 'sharer' shares to each in due degree,
To those who millions store enjoyment scarce can be.
Various Translators: Unless pre-ordained by the divine Disposer, even if a man did pile up a crore it would not be possible for him to enjoy it.
Dinamalar: A man may amass millions, but its enjoyment will never exceed the portion allotted to him.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
That the destitute have not renounced
Is because fate has not relieved them of their share.
Transliteration: The destitute will renounce desire (and become ascetics), if (fate) do not make them suffer the hindrances to which they are liable, and they pass away.
T.Kannan:
That the destitute have not renounced Is
because fate has not relieved them of their share.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even those who possess nothing to enjoy will ‘renounce’, if only one can escape the misery that is to be suffered.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Thurappaarman Thuppura Villaar
Urarpaala
Oottaa Kazhiyu Menin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The destitute desire will quit
If fate with ills visit them not.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The poor could easily renounce the world if fate were to refrain from visiting them with the curse of their past deeds.
Various Translators:
The destitute with ascetics merit share,
If fate to visit with predestined ills would spare.
Dinamalar: The poor are practically ascetics and would renounce if only karma, approaching with experiences yet to be, would pass them by.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Why should those who rejoice when destiny brings them good moan when that same destiny decrees misfortune?
Transliteration: How is it that those, who are pleased with good fortune, trouble themselves when evil comes, (since both are equally the decree of fa te) ?
T.Kannan:
Why do those who take good luck in their stride,
Struggle when encountered with bad?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Why do those who take good luck in their
stride, Struggle when encountered with bad?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Why worry about pain and pleasure? They are all the workings of fate.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Why bemoan the misery caused by ool, when one enjoys the good without complaint.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Nandraangaal Nallavaak Kaanpavar
Andraangaal
Allar Patuva Thevan?
Various Translators:
Who good in time of good perceive 
In evil time why should they grieve?
Dinamalar:
When good things come, men view them all as gain;
When evils come, why then should they complain?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: What is there that is mightier than destiny? For it is present even in the plans we devise to overcome it.
Transliteration: What is stronger than fate ? If we think of an expedient (to avert it), it will itself be with us before (the thought).
T.Kannan:
What is there mightier than fate? For it overtakes us
In spite of our plans to overcome it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: What is there so potent as Fate? Even if we devise some way of counteracting it, it takes us by surprise.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What is there mightier than fate? For it
overtakes us In spite of our plans to overcome it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Is there anything mightier than ool? It remains dominant despite all plans devised to counter it.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Oozhir Peruvali Yaavula Matrondru
Soozhinun Thaanmun Thurum
Various Translators:
What power surpasses fate? Its will 
Persists against the human skill.
Dinamalar:
What powers so great as those of Destiny? Man's skill
Some other thing contrives; but fate's beforehand still.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
An army, people, wealth, a minister, friends, fort; six things 
Who owns them all , a lion lives amid the kings.
Transliteration: He who possesses these six things, an army, a people, wealth, ministers, friends and a fortress, is a lion among kings.
T.Kannan: He is lion among kings who is well endowed with these six: army, citizens, wealth, ministers, allies and fortresses.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who has these six is a lion among kings:
An army, subjects, food, ministers, allies and forts.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He is a lion among kings, who possesses with an army, a territory, wealth, ministers, allies and a fortress.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who has these six is a lion among kings:
An army, subjects, wealth, ministers, allies and
forts.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The military, citizenry, resources, advisers, friends and fortresses : who owns these six is a lion amongst kings.
Various Translators:
Pataikuti Koozhamaichchu Natparan
Aarum
Utaiyaan Arasarul Eru
Dinamalar:
People, troops, wealth, forts, council, friends 
Who owns these six is lion of kings.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Never to fail in these four things, fearlessness, liberality, wisdom, and energy, is the kingly character.
Transliteration:
Courage, a liberal hand, wisdom, and energy; these four
Are qualities a king adorn for evermore.
T.Kannan: There are four attributes that cannot be absent in a king: fearlessness, generosity, wisdom and industriousness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
These four unfailing mark a king:
Courage, liberality, wisdom and energy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Fearlessness, liberality, wisdom and energy are the unfailing marks of a King.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
These four unfailing mark a king: Courage,
liberality, wisdom and energy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Fearlessness, generosity, wisdom and vitality: these four are persistent characteristics expected of a king.
Various Translators:
Anjaamai Eekai Arivookkam Innaankum
Enjaamai Vendhark Kiyalpu
Dinamalar:
Courage, giving, knowledge and zeal
Are four failless features royal.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Alertness, learning, bravery 
Are adjuncts three of monarchy.
Transliteration:
A sleepless promptitude, knowledge, decision strong:
These three for aye to rulers of the land belong.
T.Kannan: In those who rule the land, three traits must never lapse: vigilance, valor and virtuous learning.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The ruler of the earth must never be bereft of his sleepless watchfulness, learning and courage.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A ruler should never lack these three:
Diligence, learning and boldness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A ruler should never lack these three:
Diligence, learning and boldness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: These three things, viz., vigilance, learning, and bravery, should never be wanting in the ruler of a country.
Various Translators: Vigilance, erudition and boldness: these three never abandon a competent ruler.
Dinamalar:
383 Thoongaamai Kalvi Thunivutaimai
ImmoondrumNeengaa Nilanaan Pavarkku

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Not swerving from righteousness and justice (aram); and deterring any violations; assuming greatness and pride through benevolent courage : a ruler should do.
Transliteration:
Aranizhukkaa Thallavai Neekki
Maranizhukkaa
Maanam Utaiya Tharasu
T.Kannan:
A brave noble king refrains from vice 
Full of virtue and enterprise.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kingship, in virtue failing not , all vice restrains,
In courage failing not, it honour's grace maintains.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The noble king is unswerving in virtue, restrains wrongdoing and courageously maintains his honor.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He is an honourable King who swerves not from virtue and abstains from vice.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
He is a honourable king who sticks to virtue,
Removes evil, and is spotless in valour.
Various Translators: He is a king who, with manly modesty, swerves not from virtue, and refrains from vice.
Dinamalar:
He is a honourable king who sticks to
virtue, Removes evil, and is spotless in valour.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Strategizing, earning revenues, preserving and allocating resources : a government should be capable of.
Transliteration:
Iyatralum Eettalung Kaaththalum
Kaaththa
Vakuththalum Valla Tharasu
T.Kannan:
The able king gets, stores and guards 
And spends them for people's safeguards.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A king is he who treasure gains, stores up, defends,
And duly for his Kingdom's weal expends.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He is the King who is capable of acquiring, preserving and wisely distributing wealth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He who can produce a treasury of wealth, deposit it, preserve it and apportion it wisely—now, that is a king!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
He is a king who can do these:
Produce, acquire, conserve and dispense.
Various Translators: He is a king who is able to acquire (wealth), to lay it up, to guard, and to distribute it.
Dinamalar:
He is a king who can do these: Produce,
acquire, conserve and dispense.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
That king, who is easy of access and
soft-spoken, Is extolled in his kingdom.
Transliteration: The world will eulogize a ruler, who is easily accessible and refrains from rude rebukes.
T.Kannan:
Kaatchik Keliyan Katunjollan Allanel
Meekkoorum Mannan Nilam
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
That land prospers where the king is
Easy to see, not harsh of words.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The world will extol the kingdom of one who is easy of access and who does not indulge in harsh words.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Where king is easy of access, where no harsh word repels,
That land's high praises every subject swells.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: All peoples praise that nation whose sovereign is always accessible and never speaks harshly.
Various Translators:
That king, who is easy of access and soft-spoken,
Is extolled in his kingdom.
Dinamalar: The whole world will exalt the country of the king who is easy of access, and who is free from harsh language.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The world listens to all the commands of
the king Who is sweet-spoken and liberal.
Transliteration: He who is not harsh of tongue but full of grace and liberality commands the homage of the world.
T.Kannan: For those who, with sweet words, are capable of giving generously and protecting their people, the world is how they wish it to be.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Insolaal Eeththalikka Vallaarkkuth
Thansolaal
Thaankan Tanaiththiv Vulaku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The world commends and acts his phrase
Who sweetly speaks and gives with grace.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
With pleasant speech, who gives and guards with poweful liberal hand,
He sees the world obedient all to his command.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Behold the king who speaks graciously, gives generously and protects powerfully—the world considers his word its command.
Various Translators: The world will praise and submit itself to the mind of the king who is able to give with affability, and to protect all who come to him.
Dinamalar:
The world listens to all the commands of the king
Who is sweet-spoken and liberal.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He is a God among men who shields his subjects.
Transliteration:
A just king, who guards over his subjects,
Will be deemed god by them.
T.Kannan: A righteous king who renders justice, and nurtures his people, will be hailed as an almighty leader.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Muraiseydhu Kaappaatrum Mannavan
Makkatku
Iraiyendru Vaikkap Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
He is the Lord of men who does
Sound justice and saves his race.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who guards the realm and justice strict maintains,
That king as god o'er subject people regins.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Ruling righteously himself and safeguarding his subjects, a monarch may be deemed divine by his people.
Various Translators: That king, will be esteemed a God among men, who performs his own duties, and protects (his subjects).
Dinamalar:
A just king, who guards over his subjects,
Will be deemed god by them.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The world is under the sway of the monarch who puts up with bitter counsel.
Transliteration:
The world is secure under the parasol of
the worthy king Who brooks bitter counsel.
T.Kannan: The leader who heeds to counsel that stings the ear, will have the world rest under his sceptre.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sevikaippach Chorporukkum Panputai
Vendhan
Kavikaikkeezhth Thangum Ulaku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Under his shelter thrives the world 
Who bears remarks bitter and bold.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The king of worth, who can words bitter to his ear endure,
Beneath the shadow of his power the world abides secure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The whole world will dwell under the umbrella of the king, who can bear words that embitter the ear.
Various Translators: The world lives protected beneath the umbrella of an ethical leader who can endure words bitter to the ear.
Dinamalar:
The world is secure under the parasol of the worthy king
Who brooks bitter counsel.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He is a light among Kings who is endowed with liberality, grace, love for his subjects, and a desire for just rule.
Transliteration:
A light among kings is he who has these
four: Grace, bounty, justice and concern.
T.Kannan: Charity, love, justice and safeguarding the people: who has these four is the guiding light for all leaders.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kotaiyali Sengol Kutiyompal Naankum
Utaiyaanaam Vendhark Koli
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
He is the Light of Kings who has
Bounty, justice, care and grace.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He is the light of kings who has there four things, beneficence, benevolence, rectitude, and care for his people.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Gifts, grace, right sceptre, care of people's weal;
These four a light of dreaded kings reveal.
Various Translators: He is a light among rulers who is endowed with the four merits of generosity, graciousness, justice and care for the people.
Dinamalar:
A light among kings is he who has these four:
Grace, bounty, justice and concern.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Learn thoroughly what should be learnt.
And having learnt, stand according to that.
Transliteration:
Learn thoroughly what should be learnt.
And having learnt, stand according to that.
T.Kannan: Let a man learn thoroughly whatever he may learn, and let his conduct be worthy of his learning.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Learn, what is to be learnt, with no flaws; once learnt, stand by what you learned.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Karka Kasatarak Karpavai Katrapin
Nirka Adharkuth Thaka
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Lore worth learning, learn flawlessly
Live by that learning thoroughly.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
So lear that you may full and faultless learning gain,
Then in obedience meet to lessons learnt remain.
Various Translators: All that you learn, learn perfectly, and thereafter keep your conduct worthy of that learning.
Dinamalar: Faultlessly pursue knowledge and abide by it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
They say: Numbers and other one called Letters
Are the two eyes to live with.
Transliteration: Letters and numbers are the two eyes of man.
T.Kannan:
They say: Numbers and other one called
Letters Are the two eyes to live with.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Numbers and letters, they are known as; eyes to humans, they are.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ennenpa Enai Ezhuththenpa Ivvirantum
Kannenpa Vaazhum Uyirkku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Letter, number, art and science
Of living kind both are the eyes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The twain that lore of numbers and of letters give
Are eyes, the wise declare, to all on earth that live.
Various Translators: Two are the eyes of those who truly live— one is called numbers, and the other letters.
Dinamalar: Verily the numbers and letters are the eyes of the living one.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Only the learned have eyes.
The unlearned have two sores on their face!
Transliteration: The learned are said to have eyes, but the unlearned have (merely) two sores in their face.
T.Kannan:
Only the learned have eyes. The unlearned
have two sores on their face!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The erudite have eyes; the ignorant have on their faces, two gashes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kannutaiyar Enpavar Katror
Mukaththirantu
Punnutaiyar Kallaa Thavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The learned alone have eyes on face
The ignorant two sores of disgrace.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Men who learning gain have eyes, men say;
Blockheads' faces pairs of sores display.
Various Translators: The learned alone are said to possess eyes; but they are only sores in the face of the unlettered.
Dinamalar: The learned have eyes that see, they say. The unlearned have two open sores on their face.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
It is the prowess of scholars that meetings bring delight
And departures leave memories.
Transliteration: It is the part of the learned to give joy to those whom they meet, and on leaving, to make them think (Oh! when shall we meet them again.)
T.Kannan:
It is the prowess of scholars that
meetings bring delight And departures leave memories.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Elation when they meet, and nostalgia when they part, are effects of the erudite’s deeds.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Uvappath Thalaikkooti Ullap Piridhal
Anaiththe Pulavar Thozhil
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To meet with joy and part with thought
Of learned men this is the art.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The duty of the learned is to delight man by their company. Hunger ever more for it even while parting.
Various Translators:
You meet with joy, with pleasant thought you part;
Such is the learned scholar's wonderous art.
Dinamalar: It is the learned man’s prowess that meetings with him bring delight, and departures leave pleasant thoughts.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The learned remain ever humble, as the poor are before the prosperous. Lowly men lack such learning.
Transliteration: The unlearned are inferior to the learned, before whom they stand begging, as the destitute before the wealthy.
T.Kannan:
The learned learn to humble, like destitute before the rich;
Only the low never learn.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The learned learn to humble, like
destitute before the rich; Only the low never learn.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Eager like the beggars at the door of the wealthy is the sufferer of knowledge; the illiterate are held in scorn.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Learned are those, who, like the poor before rich, stay humble before others, lovingly, to learn; those who thus don’t learn are lowly.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Utaiyaarmun Illaarpol Ekkatrung
Katraar
Kataiyare Kallaa Thavar
Various Translators:
Like poor before rich they yearn:
For knowledge: the low never learn.
Dinamalar:
With soul submiss they stand, as paupers front a rich man's face;
Yet learned men are first; th' unlearned stand in lowest place.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The deeper a sand well is dug, the more freely its water flows. Even so, the deeper a man’s learning, the greater is his wisdom.
Transliteration: Water will flow from a well in the sand in proportion to the depth to which it is dug, and knowledge will flow from a man in proportion to his learning.
T.Kannan:
The more you dig a sand-spring, more the flow.
The more you learn more the wisdom.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The deeper you delve into the earth, the greater will be the flow of water. Likewise knowledge is in proportion to your learning.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The more you dig a sand-spring, more the
flow. The more you learn more the wisdom.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The deeper a well is dug, the more the water that springs; the more one learns, the more the wisdom it brings.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thottanaith Thoorum Manarkeni
Maandharkkuk
Katranaith Thoorum Arivu
Various Translators:
As deep you dig the sand spring flows 
As deep you learn the knowledge grows.
Dinamalar:
In sandy soil, when deep you delve , you reach the springs below;
The more you learn, the freer streams of wisdom flow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The learned make each land their own, in every city find a home;
Who, till they die; learn nought, along what weary ways they roam!
Transliteration: How is it that any one can remain without learning, even to his death, when (to the learned man) every country is his own (country), and every town his own (town) ?
T.Kannan: Knowing that knowledge makes all nations and neighborhoods one’s own, how can a man stay untutored until his death?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Why does one stop learning till he dies
When it makes all lands and place his?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: No country and no place is alien to the learned. How is it that persons remain in ignorance to the end of their lives?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Why does one stop learning till he dies
When it makes all lands and place his?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: For the learned, every nation is their nation; and every place their place; why then, does one shun learning till death.
Various Translators:
Yaadhaanum Naataamaal Ooraamaal
Ennoruvan
Saandhunaiyung Kallaadha Vaaru
Dinamalar:
All lands and towns are learner's own 
Why not till death learning go on!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The learning, which a man has acquired in one birth, will yield him pleasure during seven births.
Transliteration:
The man who store of learning gains,
In one, through seven worlds, bliss, attains.
T.Kannan: The learning a man secures in one birth will secure his well being in seven.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The learning acquired in one birth
Protects a man in the next seven.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The knowledge that a person gains in one birth stands him in good stead for seven births.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The learning acquired in one birth
Protects a man in the next seven.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Learning acquired once will stand in good stead for seven births.
Various Translators:
Orumaikkan Thaan Katra Kalvi
OruvarkuEzhumaiyum Emaap Putaiththu
Dinamalar:
The joy of learning in one birth
Exalts man upto his seventh.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The learned foster learning more 
On seeing the world enjoy their lore.
Transliteration:
Their joy is joy of all the world, they see; thus more
The learners to love their cherished lore.
T.Kannan: When the learned discern that the learning which delights them also delights the world, they love learning all the more.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The learned thirst for knowledge more and more, because what gives them pleasure delights the world.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Seeing that what delights him delights the world,
Gets a scholar also delighted.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Seeing that what delights him delights the
world, Gets a scholar also delighted.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The learned will long (for more learning), when they see that while it gives pleasure to themselves, the world also derives pleasure from it.
Various Translators: Seeing that what they enjoy, the world enjoys too, the erudite fall more in love with learning.
Dinamalar:
Thaamin Puruvadhu Ulakin PurakKantu
Kaamuruvar Katrarin Thaar
