G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Learning is the indestructubile, and significant, wealth; other riches are not true wealth.
Transliteration:
Ketil Vizhuchchelvam Kalvi Yoruvarku
Maatalla Matrai Yavai
T.Kannan:
Learning is wealth none could destroy 
Nothing else gives genuine joy.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Learning is excellence of wealth that none destroy;
To man nought else affords reality of joy
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A man’s learning is an imperishable and precious wealth. No other possession is as golden.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The precious undecaying wealth of a man is his learning. All other riches are no wealth at all.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The wealth that never declines is learning.
All others are not riches.
Various Translators: Learning is the true imperishable riches; all other things are not riches.
Dinamalar:
The wealth that never declines is
learning. All others are not riches.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Speaking before an audience, without reading relevant books, is like rolling the dice without drawing the squares.
Transliteration:
Arangindri Vattaati Yatre Nirampiya
Noolindrik Kotti Kolal
T.Kannan:
Like play of chess on squareless board
Vain is imperfect loreless word.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Like those at draughts would play without the chequered square,
Men void of ample lore counsels of the learned share.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Entering an assembly without sufficient knowledge is like playing at a dice board without its knowledge.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Speaking to a learned gathering without ample knowledge is like playing a dice game without the board.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Addressing a gathering with poor scholarship
Is like playing dice without a board.
Various Translators: To speak in an assembly (of the learned) without fullness of knowledge, is like playing at chess (on a board) without squares.
Dinamalar:
Addressing a gathering with poor
scholarship Is like playing dice without a board.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
An illiterate's lust for words is like the
lust of a woman Who has neither of her breasts.
Transliteration: An illiterate wishing to make a speech is like a breastless androgyne wishing to become a woman.
T.Kannan:
Kallaadhaan Sorkaa Murudhal
Mulaiyirantum
Illaadhaal Penkaamur Ratru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Unlearned man aspiring speech 
Is breastless lady's love approach.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The desire of the ignorant to speak is like the desire of a woman without breasts claiming womanhood.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Like those who doat on hoyden's undeveloped charms are they,
Of learning void, who eagerly their power of words display.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: An uneducated man desiring to be eloquent is like a breastless woman longing to be feminine.
Various Translators:
An illiterate's lust for words is like the lust of a woman
Who has neither of her breasts.
Dinamalar: The desire of the unlearned to speak (in an assembly), is like a woman without breasts desiring (the enjoyment of ) woman-hood.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even a fool is fine If he can hold his
tongue before the wise!
Transliteration: Blessed are the ignorant if they venture not to address the assembly of the learned.
T.Kannan: Even the ignorant will be considered good if they shut themselves up before the learned.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kallaa Thavarum Naninallar
Katraarmun
Sollaa Thirukkap Perin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ev'n unread men are good and wise
If before the wise, they hold their peace.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The blockheads too, may men of worth appear,
If they can keep from speaking where the learned hear!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even the ignorant will be considered wise if they refrain from speaking in the presence of the learned.
Various Translators: The unlearned also are very excellent men, if they know how to keep silence before the learned.
Dinamalar:
Even a fool is fine
If he can hold his tongue before the wise!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The learned value not the intelligence of the illiterate.
Transliteration:
The learned will not acknowledge An
ignoramus' occasional knowledge.
T.Kannan: Though the illiterate may display streaks of intelligence, they would still not be acknowledged by the learned.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kallaadhaan Otpam Kazhiyanan
Raayinum
Kollaar Arivutai Yaar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The unread's wit though excellent 
Is not valued by the savant.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From blockheads' lips, when words of wisdom glibly flow,
The wise receive them not , though good they seem to show.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: However excellent an untaught man’s knowledge may be, erudite men will never accept it.
Various Translators: Although the natural knowledge of an unlearned man may be very good, the wise will not accept for true knowledge.
Dinamalar:
The learned will not acknowledge
An ignoramus' occasional knowledge.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The pretensions of the illiterate disappear the moment they launch upon a discussion with the learned.
Transliteration:
An unlettered man's conceit will find its
end When the occasion for speech arrives.
T.Kannan: The vanity of the ignorant vanishes, when they start speaking in a gathering.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kallaa Oruvan Thakaimai
Thalaippeydhu
Sollaatach Chorvu Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A man untaught when speech he vaunts 
Sadly fails before savants.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As worthless shows the worth of man unlearned,
When council meets, by words he speakes discerned.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The self-conceit of an unlearned man will fade away, as soon as he speaks in an assembly (of thelearned).
Various Translators: An unschooled man’s self conceit will shrivel the moment he speaks to an assembly.
Dinamalar:
An unlettered man's conceit will find its end
When the occasion for speech arrives.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The ignorant just exist; they are like a piece of barren land.
Transliteration:
The ignorant are like barren land: They
are there, but useless.
T.Kannan: The illiterate are seen as existing to fill space; they are like barren waste lands.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ularennum Maaththiraiyar Allaal
Payavaak
Kalaranaiyar Kallaa Thavar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
People speak of untaught minds 
"They just exist like barren lands".
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The unlearned are like worthless barren land: all that can be said of them is, that they exist.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
They are'; so much is true of men untaught;
But, like a barren field, they yield us nought.
Various Translators: Like unproductive barren land is the man who has neglected learning. All that can be said about him is that he exists.
Dinamalar:
The ignorant are like barren land:
They are there, but useless.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A handsome man without subtle and sharp intellect
Has the beauty of a mud-doll.
Transliteration:
A handsome man without subtle and sharp
intellect Has the beauty of a mud-doll.
T.Kannan: The beauty and goodness of one who is destitute of knowledge by the study of great and exquisite works, is like (the beauty and goodness) of a painted earthen doll.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A person who has no in-depth learning and intellectual acumen, is as impressive as a doll made of mud.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nunmaan Nuzhaipulam Illaan
Ezhilnalam
Manmaan Punaipaavai Yatru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Like painted clay doll is his show
Grand subtle lore who fails to know.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who lack the power of subtle, large and penetrating sense,
Like puppet, decked with ornaments of clay, their beauty's vain pretence.
Various Translators: The handsome charm of him whose knowledge is neither subtle nor penetrating is like that of a painted clay doll.
Dinamalar: The imposing position of one who lacks penetrating intellect reminds us of the external glitter of clay.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The wealth of the ignorant does more harm
Than the want of the learned.
Transliteration: Wealth, gained by the unlearned, will give more sorrow than the poverty which may come upon the learned.
T.Kannan:
The wealth of the ignorant does more harm
Than the want of the learned.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Not even the penury of the good is as pernicious as the wealth that has fallen on the ignorant.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nallaarkan Patta Varumaiyin Innaadhe
Kallaarkan Patta Thiru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Wealth in the hand of fools is worse 
Than a learned man's empty purse.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To men unlearned, from fortune's favour greater evil springs,
Than proverty to men of goodly wisdom brings.
Various Translators: Even more wretched than a learned man’s poverty is the unlearned man’s wealth.
Dinamalar: Far sweeter is the poverty of the learned than the riches of the ignorant.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The ignorant, however high-born,
Is lower than the low-born learned.
Transliteration: The unlearned, though born in a high caste, are not equal in dignity to the learned; though they may have been born in a low caste.
T.Kannan:
The ignorant, however high-born, Is lower
than the low-born learned.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The uneducated maybe of higher birth; but they are not respected as much as the learned men born in low classes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Merpirandhaa Raayinum Kallaadhaar
Keezhppirandhum
Katraar Anaiththilar Paatu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Lower are fools of higher birth
Than low born men of learning's worth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Lower are men unlearned, though noble be their race,
Than low born men adorned with learning's grace.
Various Translators: The highborn ignorant sink low in the scale while the learned even of humble birth are exalted.
Dinamalar: Though he is humbly born, a lettered man’s nobility transcends that of the illiterate nobleman.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Amid scholars of celebrated works,
Are others like beasts among men.
Transliteration: As beasts by the side of men, so are other men by the side of those who are learned in celebrated works.
T.Kannan:
Amid scholars of celebrated works, Are
others like beasts among men.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Animal amongst men are those uneducated amongst the erudite.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vilangotu Makkal Anaiyar Ilangunool
Katraarotu Enai Yavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Like beasts before men, dunces are
Before scholars of shining lore.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The ignorant are but beasts by the side of men of wide learning.
Various Translators:
Learning's irradiating grace who gain,
Others excel, as men the bestial train.
Dinamalar: As men are to wild beasts, so are the masters of brilliant texts to other men.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The most precious wealth is the wealth acquired by the ear. Indeed, of all wealth, that wealth is paramount.
Transliteration: Wealth (gained) by the ear is wealth of wealth; that wealth is the chief of all wealth.
T.Kannan:
The wealth of wealths is the wealth of hearing;
That wealth out-tops all else.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The wealth of wealths is the wealth of
hearing; That wealth out-tops all else.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The wealth of all wealth is the wealth of hearing. It out-tops all other wealth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The richness of the ear is the wealth amongst all wealth, the foremost wealth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Selvaththut Selvanj Chevichchelvam
Achchelvam
Selvaththu Lellaan Thalai
Various Translators:
Wealth of wealths is listening's wealth 
It is the best of wealths on earth.
Dinamalar:
Wealth of wealth is acquired be ear attent;
Wealth mid all wealth supremely excellent.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Only when no fare can be found for the ear is it time to offer the stomach a morsel.
Transliteration: When there is no food for the ear, give a little also to the stomach.
T.Kannan:
When there is no food for the ear,
A little can be given to the stomach as well.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Men think a little of the stomach only when the ear is not fed.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
When there is no food for the ear, A
little can be given to the stomach as well.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: When food there is none for the ear, spare a little for the belly.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Sevikkuna Villaadha Pozhdhu Siridhu
Vayitrukkum Eeyap Patum
Various Translators:
Some food for the stomach is brought 
When the ear gets no food for thought.
Dinamalar:
When 'tis no longer time the listening ear to feed
With trifling dole of food supply the body's need.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who feed their ear with learned teachings rare,
Are like the happy gods oblations rich who share.
Transliteration: Those who in this world enjoy instruction which is the food of the ear, are equal to the Gods, who enjoy the food of the sacrifices.
T.Kannan: In Heaven, Deities feed from sacrificial fires. On Earth, men who feast on listening are their equal.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
As gods in heaven are fed through fire,
So men on earth are fed through their ears.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those mortals who feast their ears with learning are one with the immortals with their sacrificial offerings.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As gods in heaven are fed through fire, So
men on earth are fed through their ears.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who can feed aurally through listening, are equal, in this world, to the noble beings devouring divine food.
Various Translators:
Seviyunavir Kelvi Yutaiyaar
Aviyunavin
Aandraaro Toppar Nilaththu
Dinamalar:
Whose ears get lots of wisdom food 
Equal gods on oblations fed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Although a man be without learning, let him listen (to the teaching of the learned); that will be to him a staff in adversity.
Transliteration:
Though learning none hath he,yet let him hear alway:
In weakness this shall prove a staff and stay.
T.Kannan: Though he has no learning, if a man listens to the learned, that will serve as his staff of strength in adversity.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though unlettered, listen;
You will find this a great help in distress.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Though devoid of learning let one fill one’s ear with knowledge. It is his prop in his hour of gloom.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though unlettered, listen; You will find
this a great help in distress.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even if you can’t learn by reading, listen; it is the crutch in times of crisis.
Various Translators:
Katrila Naayinung Ketka Aqdhoruvarku
Orkaththin Ootraan Thunai
Dinamalar:
Though not learned, hear and heed 
That serves a staff and stay in need.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Virtuous men's wisdom is found 
A strong staff on slippery ground.
Transliteration:
Like staff in hand of him in slippery ground who strays,
Are words from mouth of those who walk in righteous ways.
T.Kannan: Words from the lips of upright men are like a steadying staff in a slippery place.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The counsel of the upright is like a staff over a slippery ground.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Words from the lips of upright men
Are like a steadying staff in a slippery place.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Words from the lips of upright men Are
like a steadying staff in a slippery place.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The words of the good are like a staff in a slippery place.
Various Translators: A steadying staff on a skiddy surface, are the words of those who possess utmost propriety.
Dinamalar:
Izhukkal Utaiyuzhi Ootrukkol Atre
Ozhukka Mutaiyaarvaaich Chol

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Listen to the good; doesn’t matter, how much; whatever be the quantum, immense greatness, it will bring.
Transliteration:
Enaiththaanum Nallavai Ketka
Anaiththaanum
Aandra Perumai Tharum
T.Kannan:
Lend ear to good words however few 
That much will highly exalt you.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Let each man good things learn, for e'en as he
Shall learn, he gains increase of perfect dignity.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let a man listen to good things, however little. Even that little will enlarge his greatness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Listen to wholesome counsel however meagre; for out of it springs great good.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Listen to the good however little
And even that much will bring great dignity.
Various Translators: Let a man listen, never so little, to good (instruction), even that will bring him great dignity.
Dinamalar:
Listen to the good however little And even
that much will bring great dignity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Misconstrue they may, but, ludicrous words, they will not utter: those who’ve always listened, analysed, and learnt.
Transliteration:
Pizhaith Thunarndhum Pedhaimai
Sollaa
RizhaiththunarnTheentiya Kelvi Yavar
T.Kannan:
Who listen well and learn sharply 
Not ev'n by slip speak foolishly.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Not e'en through inadvertence speak they foolish word,
With clear discerning mind who 've learning's ample lessons heard.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Men of searching understanding do not speak foolishly even in a thoughtless mood.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those who have studied deeply and listened diligently never speak foolish words, even when they have misunderstood a matter.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Those who have sought and heard much
Will not talk nonsense even by mistake.
Various Translators: Not even when they have imperfectly understood (a matter), will those men speak foolishly, who have profoundly studied and diligently listened (to instruction).
Dinamalar:
Those who have sought and heard much Will
not talk nonsense even by mistake.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ears may hear and yet remain deaf, If not
drilled by words of instruction.
Transliteration: Hear, they can; but deaf they are: the ears that are not pierced by aural learning.
T.Kannan:
Ketpinung Kelaath Thakaiyave
Kelviyaal
Thotkap Pataadha Sevi
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
That ear though hearing is dulled
Which is not by wisdom drilled.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The ear that is not filled with understanding is really deaf.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Where teaching hath not oped the learner's ear,
The man may listen, but he scarce can hear.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If not pierced by acute listening, ears may hear and yet remain deaf.
Various Translators:
Ears may hear and yet remain deaf,
If not drilled by words of instruction.
Dinamalar: The ear which has not been bored by instruction, although it hears, is deaf.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A modest mouth is hard for those Whose
ears lend not to wise counsels.
Transliteration: Men that lack subtle understanding lack modesty in speech.
T.Kannan: Unless one is an intense, attentive aural learner, it is unlikely that one will be have a humble tongue.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nunangiya Kelviya Rallaar Vanangiya
Vaayina Raadhal Aridhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A modest mouth is hard for those
Who care little to counsels wise.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Tis hard for mouth to utter gentle, modest word.
When ears discourse of lore refined have never heard.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Unless he has listened to learning’s subtlety, it is rare indeed for a man to speak with humility.
Various Translators: It is a rare thing to find modesty, a reverend mouth- with those who have not received choice instruction.
Dinamalar:
A modest mouth is hard for those
Whose ears lend not to wise counsels.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: What avails it whether men live or die, if they merely satisfy the palate and not feed the ear with wisdom.
Transliteration:
What matters if they live or die Whose
taste is in their tongues, not ears?
T.Kannan: Those beings who know the taste, only of the tongue, and not of the ear : does it matter whether die or live?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seviyir Suvaiyunaraa Vaayunarvin
Maakkal
Aviyinum Vaazhinum En?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who taste by mouth and not by ear 
What if they fare ill or well here?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
His mouth can taste, but ear no taste of joy can give!
what matter if he die, or prosperous live?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: There are those whose tongues taste but whose ears savor nothing. What does it matter whether they live or die?
Various Translators: What does it matter whether those men live or die, who can judge of tastes by the mouth, and not by the ear ?
Dinamalar:
What matters if they live or die
Whose taste is in their tongues, not ears?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The weapon of wisdom saves one from evil. It is a citadel which cannot be destroyed by the foe.
Transliteration:
Wisdom is a weapon of defence, An inner
fortress no foe can raze.
T.Kannan: Wisdom is the shield against suffering; and the fortress, impregnable and indestructible for the foes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
421 Arivatrang Kaakkung Karuvi
SeruvaarkkumUllazhikka Laakaa Aran
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Wisdom's weapon wards off all woes
It is a fort defying foes.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
True wisdom wards off woes, 
  A circling fortress high;Its inner strength man's eager foes,   Un'shaken will defy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Wisdom is a weapon to ward off destruction; it is an inner fortress which enemies cannot destroy.
Various Translators: Wisdom is a weapon that can ward off destruction. It is an inner fortress that no enemy can assail.
Dinamalar:
Wisdom is a weapon of defence,
An inner fortress no foe can raze.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Wisdom bridles the wandering mind, keeps it away from evil and bids it tread the right path.
Transliteration:
Wisdom checks the wandering mind And pulls
it from ill to good.
T.Kannan: Without letting the mind to wander on its own will, wisdom steers it away from harm, and towards good.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sendra Itaththaal Selavitaa
Theedhoreei
Nandrinpaal Uyppa Tharivu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Wisdom checks the straying senses
Expels evils, impels goodness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Not to permit the mind to go where it lists, to keep it from evil, and to employ it in good, this is wisdom.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Wisdom restrains, nor suffers mind to wander where it would;
From every evil calls it back, and guides in way of good.
Various Translators: Wisdom will harness the mind, diverting it from wrong and directing it toward right.
Dinamalar:
Wisdom checks the wandering mind
And pulls it from ill to good.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The mark of wisdom is to discern the truth
From whatever source it is heard.
Transliteration:
The mark of wisdom is to discern the truth
From whatever source it is heard.
T.Kannan: To discern the truth in every thing, by whomsoever spoken, is wisdom.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Whatever whoever may say, listen to it, and wisdom is to comprehend the true meaning of it.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Epporul Yaaryaarvaaik Ketpinum
Apporul
Meypporul Kaanpa Tharivu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To grasp the Truth from everywhere 
From everyone is wisdom fair.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though things diverse from divers sages' lips we learn,
'Tis wisdom's part in each the true thing to discern.
Various Translators: Whatever is heard from whomever’s lips, wisdom will rightly discern its true meaning.
Dinamalar: Wisdom seeks the truth of all things which are heard or uttered.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Wisdom lies in simplifying intricate facts
And grasping that of others, however intricate.
Transliteration: To speak so as that the meaning may easily enter the mind of the hearer, and to discern the subtlest thought which may lie hidden in the words of others, this is wisdom.
T.Kannan:
Wisdom lies in simplifying intricate facts
And grasping that of others, however intricate.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Wisdom is to keep it simple for your audience, and to comprehend complexities in others’ speech.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Enporula Vaakach Chelachchollith
Thaanpirarvaai
Nunporul Kaanpa Tharivu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Speaking out thoughts in clear trends 
Wisdom subtle sense comprehends.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Wisdom hath use of lucid speech, words that acceptance win,
And subtle sense of other men's discourse takes in.
Various Translators: Wisdom speaks well, conveying each meaning clearly, and listens for the subtlest sense in others’ speech.
Dinamalar: Wisdom unravels things subtle and seeks them in others.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Prudence goes with the world,
But wisdom is not a lotus to open and shut at will.
Transliteration: To secure the friendship of the great is true wisdom; it is (also) wisdom to keep (that friendship unchanged, and) not opening and closing (like the lotus flower).
T.Kannan:
Prudence goes with the world, But wisdom
is not a lotus to open and shut at will.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Wisdom, it is to embrace the world, and not to be overtly delighted or dismayed.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ulakam Thazheeiya Thotpam
Malardhalum
Koompalum Illa Tharivu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wise world the wise befriend 
They bloom nor gloom, equal in mind.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Wisdom embraces frank the world, to no caprice exposed;
Unlike the lotus flower, now opened wide, now petals strictly closed.
Various Translators: To befriend the world is wisdom; and wisdom is not inconstant like the flower that blossoms and fades.
Dinamalar: The wise befriend the wise and keep that friendship constant, not opening and closing it like the petaled lotus.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
It is a part of wisdom to conform
To the ways of the world.
Transliteration: T o live as the world lives, is wisdom.
T.Kannan:
It is a part of wisdom to conform To the
ways of the world.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: What the world conforms to, wisdom lies in conforming to those.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Evva Thuraivadhu Ulakam Ulakaththotu
Avva Thuraiva Tharivu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As moves the world so move the wise
In tune with changing times and ways.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To be one with the world is wisdom.
Various Translators:
As dwells the world, so with the world to dwell
In harmony this is to wisely live and well.
Dinamalar: It is wisdom to live in the world in the way that the world lives.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who know, know what will happen next. Such things are unknown to the unknowing.
Transliteration: The wise are those who know beforehand what will happen; those who do not know this are the unwise.
T.Kannan:
The wise know what comes next.
The unwise lack that wisdom.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The wise know what comes next. The unwise
lack that wisdom.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Wisdom knows the future but not ignorance.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The wise anticipate the outcomes; unwise are those who can’t.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Arivutaiyaar Aava Tharivaar
Arivilaar
Aqdhari Kallaa Thavar
Various Translators:
The wise foresee what is to come 
The unwise lack in that wisdom.
Dinamalar:
The wise discern, the foolish fail to see,
And minds prepare for things about to be.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is folly not to fear what ought to be feared. So the wise dread what should be dreaded.
Transliteration: Not to fear what ought to be feared, is folly; it is the work of the wise to fear what should be feared.
T.Kannan:
It is folly not to fear what ought to be feared.
The wise dread what ought to be dreaded.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It is folly not to fear what must be feared. It is wisdom to fear what must be feared.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
It is folly not to fear what ought to be
feared. The wise dread what ought to be dreaded.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: It is foolish, not to fear, what ought to be feared; the wise fear those that must be feared.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Anjuva Thanjaamai Pedhaimai
Anjuvadhu
Anjal Arivaar Thozhil
Various Translators:
Fear the frightful and act wisely 
Not to fear the frightful's folly.
Dinamalar:
Folly meets fearful ills with fearless heart;
To fear where cause of fear exists is wisdom's part.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
This wise with watchful soul who coming ills foresee;
From coming evil's dreaded shock are free.
Transliteration: No terrifying calamity will happen to the wise, who (foresee) and guard against coming evils.
T.Kannan: Fearsome sufferings shall never happen to knowing ones who guard against future happenings.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
No frightful evil shocks the wise
Who guard against surprises.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Men of foresight who guard themselves against coming events know no distress.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No frightful evil shocks the wise Who
guard against surprises.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The wise who are perceptive and take preventive measures, will not be staggered by any harm.
Various Translators:
Edhiradhaak Kaakkum Arivinaark
Killai
Adhira Varuvadhor Noi
Dinamalar:
No frightful evil shocks the wise
Who guard themselves against surprise.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who possess wisdom, possess every thing; those who have not wisdom, whatever they may possess, have nothing.
Transliteration:
The wise is rich, with ev'ry blessing blest;
The fool is poor, of everything possessed.
T.Kannan: Those who possess wisdom possess everything. Whatever others possess, without wisdom they have nothing.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those who have wisdom have all:
Fools with all have nothing.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The wise possess everything; but the poor are the unwise rich.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those who have wisdom have all: Fools with
all have nothing.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The wise have everything; the unwise have nothing, irrespective of whatever they may possess.
Various Translators:
Arivutaiyaar Ellaa Mutaiyaar
Arivilaar
Ennutaiya Renum Ilar
Dinamalar:
Who have wisdom they are all full 
Whatev'r they own, misfits are nil.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Plenty is their prosperity
Who're free from wrath pride lust petty.
Transliteration:
Who arrogance, and wrath and littleness of low desire restrain.
To sure increase of lofty dignity attain.
T.Kannan: Those who are free from vanity, vulgarity and venomousness will prosper in deserving dignity.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Exalted is the wealth that is free from pride, wrath and lust.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Freedom from arrogance, anger and meanness
Spells dignity in greatness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Freedom from arrogance, anger and meanness
Spells dignity in greatness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Truly great is the excellence of those (kings) who are free from pride, anger, and lust.
Various Translators: Those who lack arrogance, wrath and pettiness: wealth, in their hands, assumes dignity.
Dinamalar:
Serukkunj Chinamum Sirumaiyum Illaar
Perukkam Perumidha Neerththu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Avarice, ignominious pride, and repulsive gloating, are fatal flaws in a leader.
Transliteration:
Ivaralum Maanpirandha Maanamum
Maanaa
Uvakaiyum Edham Iraikku
T.Kannan:
Mean pride, low pleasure, avarice 
These add blemishes to a prince.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A niggard hand, o'erweening self regard and mirth
Unseemly, bring disgrace to men of kingly birth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Avarice, arrogance and crude amusements are flaws in the character of an unfit king.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Niggardliness, empty honour, blind favouritism, are all the faults of a King.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Miserliness, undignified pride and fraudulent indulgence
Are flaws in a king.
Various Translators: Avarice, undignified pride, and low pleasures are faults in a king.
Dinamalar:
Miserliness, undignified pride and
fraudulent indulgence Are flaws in a king.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: For those who fear disgrace, their faults, though grain-sized, woud seem gigantic.
Transliteration:
Thinaiththunaiyaang Kutram Varinum
Panaiththunaiyaak
Kolvar Pazhinaanu Vaar
T.Kannan:
Though millet small their faults might seem
Men fearing disgrace, Palm tall deem.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though small as millet'seed the fault men deem;
As palm tree vast to those who fear disgrace 'twill seem.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Even the slightest fault looms large in the eyes of those who dread dishonour.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Though their fault be as small as a millet seed, to those who dread disgrace it will appear as large as a palm tree.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To those ashamed of wrong doings,
Even millet of fault is as big as a palm-tree.
Various Translators: Those who fear guilt, if they commit a fault small as a millet seed, will consider it to be as large as a palmyra tree.
Dinamalar:
To those ashamed of wrong doings, Even
millet of fault is as big as a palm-tree.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Guard against error as you would guard
wealth, For error is a foe that kills.
Transliteration: Fend off your own flaws; those flaws are your fatal foes.
T.Kannan:
Kutrame Kaakka Porulaakak Kutrame
Atran Tharooum Pakai
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Watch like treasure freedom from fault
Our fatal foe is that default.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Guard against your error as you would your wealth. For error spells your ruin.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Freedom from faults is wealth; watch heedfully
'Gainst these, for fault is fatal enmity.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: One’s own faults are one’s mortal enemies. It follows that to guard against them is life’s gravest concern.
Various Translators:
Guard against error as you would guard wealth,
For error is a foe that kills.
Dinamalar: Guard against faults as a matter (of great consequence; for) faults are a deadly enemy.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A life that does not guard against faults
Would vanish like a heap of straw before fire.
Transliteration: Like a piece of straw in a consuming flame, will be destroyed the life of one who does not guard against faults.
T.Kannan: Having no safeguards before the onset of trouble, will make our lives, dry straws before a raging fire.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Varumunnark Kaavaadhaan Vaazhkkai
Erimunnar
Vaiththooru Polak Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who fails to guard himself from flaw 
Loses his life like flame lit straw.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
His joy who guards not 'gainst the coming evil day,
Like straw before the fire shall swift consume away.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The good fortune of a man who does not guard against failings before they manifest will perish like a stack of straw before a fire.
Various Translators: The prosperity of him who does not timely guard against faults, will perish like straw before fire.
Dinamalar:
A life that does not guard against faults
Would vanish like a heap of straw before fire.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: What fault will befall a King who is free from guilt and detects guilt in others?
Transliteration:
How can a king be faulted who removes his
own fault Before seeing that of others?
T.Kannan: What flaw could fall upon a leader who rectifies his faults before observing and assailing others’ faults.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thankutram Neekkip Pirarkutrang
Kaankirpin
Enkutra Maakum Iraikku?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What fault can be the king's who cures 
First his faults, then scans others.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Faultless the king who first his own faults cures, and then
Permits himself to scan the faults of other men.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What fault remains in a king who expunges his own faults before examining the faults in others?
Various Translators: What fault will remain in the king who has put away his own evils, and looks after the evils of others.
Dinamalar:
How can a king be faulted who removes his own fault
Before seeing that of others?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The hoarded wealth of the miser who fails in his offices perishes.
Transliteration:
The miser's wealth, unspent on what should
be spent, Does not increase but cease.
T.Kannan: The wealth of one who, out of pettiness, doesn’t do what ought to done, will vanish without growth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seyarpaala Seyyaa Thivariyaan Selvam
Uyarpaala Thandrik Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
That miser's wealth shall waste and end
Who would not for a good cause spend.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who leaves undone what should be done, with niggard mind.
His wealth shall perish, leaving not a wrack behind.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The wealth of the avaricious man, who does not expend it for the purposes for which he ought to expend it will waste away and not continue.
Various Translators: The wealth of him who, out of avarice, fails to do what should be done will vanish without the slightest vestige.
Dinamalar:
The miser's wealth, unspent on what should be spent,
Does not increase but cease.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A clutching greedy heart that knows no charity commits the greatest folly.
Transliteration:
That miserliness which clings to men Is
one thing that stands out among all sins.
T.Kannan: Clinging to wealth, out of avarice, is worse than the any other flaw.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Patrullam Ennum Ivaranmai Etrullum
Ennap Patuvadhon Randru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The gripping greed of miser's heart 
Is more than fault the worst apart.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Griping avarice is not to be reckoned as one among other faults; (it stands alone - greater than all).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The greed of soul that avarice men call;
When faults are summed, is worst of all.
Various Translators: When all faults are reckoned, one remains unrivaled: the greedy grasping known as avarice.
Dinamalar:
That miserliness which clings to men
Is one thing that stands out among all sins.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Never flatter yourself,
Nor delight in deeds that bring no good.
Transliteration:
Never flatter yourself, Nor delight in
deeds that bring no good.
T.Kannan: Let no (one) praise himself, at any time; let him not desire to do useless things.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Never give in to egotism; never indulge in vain acts that benefit none.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Viyavarka Egngnaandrum Thannai
Nayavarka
Nandri Payavaa Vinai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Never boast yourself in any mood 
Nor do a deed that does no good.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Never indulge in self complaisant mood,
Nor deed desire that yeilds no gain of good.
Various Translators: Never indulge in admiring yourself. Never be drawn toward deeds that do not benefit others.
Dinamalar: Let not conceit enter your heart at any time of your life; do not run after trifles.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Keep your delights in pleasures unknown
To keep the designs of your foes at bay.
Transliteration: If (a king) enjoys, privately the things which he desires, the designs of his enemies will be useless.
T.Kannan:
Keep your delights in pleasures unknown To
keep the designs of your foes at bay.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who enjoys what they enjoy, unknown to foes, are difficult to defeat.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kaadhala Kaadhal Ariyaamai Uykkirpin
Edhila Edhilaar Nool
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
All designs of the foes shall fail 
If one his wishes guards in veil.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If, to your foes unknown, you cherish what you love,
Counsels of men who wish you harm will harmless prove.
Various Translators: Delighting in life’s pleasures in guarded privacy nullifies the conspiring schemes of enemies.
Dinamalar: Of what avail are the designs of the foe, if one does not betray one’s secrets?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Value and secure the friendship
Of the virtuous, mature and wise.
Transliteration: Let (a king) ponder well its value, and secure the friendship of men of virtue and of mature knowledge.
T.Kannan:
Value and secure the friendship Of the
virtuous, mature and wise.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Assess, know the potential, and secure the company of virtuous, veteran, wise men.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Aranarindhu Mooththa Arivutaiyaar
Kenmai
Thiranarindhu Therndhu Kolal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Weigh their worth and friendship gain 
Of men of virtue and mature brain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As friends the men who virtue know, and riper wisdom share,
Their worth weighed well, the king should choose with care.
Various Translators: The friendship of virtuous men of mature wisdom is to be appreciated and secured.
Dinamalar: If men fathom what it means to have virtuous and wise friends, they will find the means to procure such friendships.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ally with them who can allay your present ills
And avert those to come.
Transliteration: Let (a king) procure and kindly care for men who can overcome difficulties when they occur, and guard against them before they happen.
T.Kannan:
Ally with them who can allay your present
ills And avert those to come.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Nurture the relationship of those who relieve, and ward off your miseries.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Utranoi Neekki Uraaamai Murkaakkum
Petriyaarp Penik Kolal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Cherish the help of men of skill 
Who ward and safe guard you from ill.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Seek the friendship of those who can remove existing distress and guard against future.
Various Translators:
Cherish the all accomplished men as friends,
Whose skill the present ill removes, from coming ill defends.
Dinamalar: There are men who allay today’s trials and avert tomorrow’s troubles. Befriend and look after them.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To cherish and befriend men of greatness is the rarest of all rare things.
Transliteration: To cherish great men and make them his own, is the most difficult of all difficult things.
T.Kannan:
The rarest of rare things is to seek and secure
The friendship of the great.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The rarest of rare things is to seek and
secure The friendship of the great.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: To seek and win the alliance of the great is the rarest of all blessings.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: It is most precious to nurture, and possess the company of great men.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ariyavatru Lellaam Aridhe
Periyaaraip
Penith Thamaraak Kolal
Various Translators:
Honour and have the great your own 
Is rarest of the rare things known.
Dinamalar:
To cherish men of mighty soul, and make them all their own,
Of kingly treaures rare, as rarest gift is known.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A man’s greatest strength is meriting friendship with those greater than himself.
Transliteration: So to act as to make those men, his own, who are greater than himself is of all powers the highest.
T.Kannan:
The greatest of all strengths come from
Associating with one greater than oneself.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: To follow in the footsteps of those that are greater than oneself is the crown of one’s strength.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The greatest of all strengths come from
Associating with one greater than oneself.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The mightiest of all strengths is to patronize, and pay heed to those who are better than us.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thammir Periyaar Thamaraa Ozhukudhal
Vanmaiyu Lellaan Thalai
Various Translators:
To have betters as intimates 
Power of all powers promotes.
Dinamalar:
To live with men of greatness that their own excels,
As cherished friends, is greatest power that with a monarch dwells.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The king, since counsellors are monarch's eyes,
Should counsellors select with counsel wise.
Transliteration: As a king must use his ministers as eyes (in managing his kingdom), let him well examine their character and qualifications before he engages them.
T.Kannan: Knowing that they function as a monarch’s eyes, a king looks at ministers meticulously before engaging them.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A king's counselors are his eyes
To be chosen with careful counseling.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Verily the ministers are the eyes of the monarch; let the monarch have tried ones.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A king's counselors are his eyes To be
chosen with careful counseling.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A ruler rules best with wise counsellors as eyes; select them after watchful scrutiny.
Various Translators:
Soozhvaarkan Naaka Ozhukalaan
Mannavan
Soozhvaaraik Soozhndhu Kolal
Dinamalar:
Ministers are the monarch's eyes 
Round him should be the right and wise.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There will be nothing left for enemies to do, against him who has the power of acting (so as to secure) the fellowship of worthy men.
Transliteration:
The king, who knows to live with worthy men allied,
Has nought to fear from any foeman's pride.
T.Kannan: A man’s foes are rendered ineffective if he can live in fellowship with the worthy.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Foes are rendered ineffective by one
Who lives in fellowship with the worthy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: No adversary can ruin the King who relies on his efficient counselors.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Foes are rendered ineffective by one Who
lives in fellowship with the worthy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When a capable leader feels at ease with capable associates, there is nothing his foes can do to harm him.
Various Translators:
Thakkaa Rinaththanaaith Thaanozhuka
Vallaanaich
Chetraar Seyakkitandha Thil
Dinamalar:
To move with worthy friends who knows
Has none to fear from frightful foes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No foe can foil his powers 
whose friends reprove him when he errs.
Transliteration:
What power can work his fall, who faithful ministers
Employs, that thunder out reproaches when he errs.
T.Kannan: Who can destroy the man who enjoys the friendship of aides who will not hesitate to admonish him?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: None can harm the ruler who seeks the wholesome counsel of his ministers though bitter.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who can ruin the man who commands
The friendship of those who can reprove him?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who can ruin the man who commands The
friendship of those who can reprove him?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Who are great enough to destroy him who has servants that have power to rebuke him ?
Various Translators: One who leads companions who can admonish him : who is capable of harming him?
Dinamalar:
Itikkun Thunaiyaarai Yaalvarai Yaare
Ketukkun Thakaimai Yavar

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A ruler unprotected by companions who can admonish him, will face ruin without any foes ruining him.
Transliteration:
Itippaarai Illaadha Emaraa Mannan
Ketuppaa Rilaanung Ketum
T.Kannan:
The careless king whom none reproves 
Ruins himself sans harmful foes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The king with none to censure him, bereft of safeguards all,
Though none his ruin work, shall surely ruined fall.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: With no one to reprove and thus protect him, a king will be destroyed, though no one seeks his destruction.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The King who is not guarded by men of firm counsel will perish even though he has no enemies.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A king unguarded with reproving counsel
Needs no foes to come to grief.
Various Translators: The king, who is without the guard of men who can rebuke him, will perish, even though there be no one to destroy him.
Dinamalar:
A king unguarded with reproving counsel
Needs no foes to come to grief.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There is no return without investment; for leaders, there is no stability without the prop of their supporters.
Transliteration:
Mudhalilaarkku Oodhiya Millai
Madhalaiyaanjjch
Aarpilaark Killai Nilai
T.Kannan:
No capital, no gain in trade 
No prop secure sans good comrade.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who owns no principal, can have no gain of usury;
Who lacks support of friends, knows no stability.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Is there profit without capital? Is there security for the monarch devoid of wise counselors?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Profit is not for those who have no capital; nor is stability for those who lack the support of faithful friends.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
There can be no gain without capital,
And no stability unpropped by wise counsel.
Various Translators: There can be no gain to those who have no capital; and in like manner there can be no permanence to those who are without the support of adherents.
Dinamalar:
There can be no gain without capital, And
no stability unpropped by wise counsel.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To give up good friends is ten times worse
than Being hated by countless foes.
Transliteration: Tenfold worse it is, to lose the company of the good, than to earn the hostility of many foes.
T.Kannan:
Pallaar Pakai Kolalir Paththatuththa
TheemaiththeNallaar Thotarkai Vital
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To give up good friends is ten times worse 
Than being hated by countless foes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Greatly injurious is the forsaking of the friendship of the good; it is like encountering singlehanded many foes.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Than hate of many foes incurred, works greater woe
Ten fold, of worthy men the friendship to forego.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: While it is perilous to make a multitude of foes, it is ten times worse to give up the friendship of the worthy.
Various Translators:
To give up good friends is ten times worse than
Being hated by countless foes.
Dinamalar: It is tenfold more injurious to abandon the friendship of the good, than to incur the hatred of the many.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The great fear the company of the base.
Only the mean take them as kinsmen.
Transliteration: The great dread the company of the ignoble, for the ignoble delight in the company of the mean.
T.Kannan: The great, fear petty company; the petty, perceive, and accept, them as their own.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
451 Sitrinam Anjum Perumai
SirumaidhaanSutramaach Choozhndhu Vitum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The ignoble the noble fear 
The mean hold them as kinsmen dear.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The great of soul will mean association fear;
The mean of soul regard mean men as kinsmen dear.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Men of greatness dread base company, while the low minded consider them kinsmen.
Various Translators: (True) greatness fears the society of the base; it is only the low - minded who will regard them as friends.
Dinamalar:
The great fear the company of the base.
Only the mean take them as kinsmen.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Water smacks of the soil; The wisdom of man takes the colour of the company he keeps.
Transliteration:
Nature of soil governs the quality of
water. One's wisdom by the nature of company.
T.Kannan: Water assumes the quality of the land; wisdom depends on the company one keeps.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nilaththiyalpaal Neerdhirin Thatraakum
Maandharkku
Inaththiyalpa Thaakum Arivu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
With soil changes water's taste 
With mates changes the mental state.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The waters' virtues change with soil through which they flow;
As man's companionship so will his wisdom show.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: As water changes according to the soil through which it flows, so a man assimilates the character of his associates.
Various Translators: As water changes (its nature), from the nature of the soil (in which it flows), so will the character of men resemble that of their associates.
Dinamalar:
Nature of soil governs the quality of water.
One's wisdom by the nature of company.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is the mind that helps a man to gain knowledge; but it is one’s association that makes people say what sort of man he is.
Transliteration:
Perceptions spring from nature And
character from company.
T.Kannan: Senses are governed by the brain; reputation is determined by one’s company.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Manaththaanaam Maandhark Kunarchchi
Inaththaanaam
Innaan Enappatunj Chol
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Wisdom depends upon the mind 
The worth of man upon his friend.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Perceptions manifold in men are of the mind alone;
The value of the man by his companionship is known.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The power of knowing is from the mind; (but) his character is from that of his associates.
Various Translators: By knowing his thoughts, a man’s mind is discovered. By knowing his associates, his character is revealed.
Dinamalar:
Perceptions spring from nature
And character from company.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One’s wisdom partakes of the nature of one’s mind and one is known by the company he keeps.
Transliteration:
Wisdom which seems to come from the mind
Comes really from one's company.
T.Kannan: Wisdom seems to stem from the mind but is shaped by people around us.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Manaththu Ladhupolak Kaatti Oruvarku
Inaththula Thaakum Arivu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Wisdom seems to come from mind 
But it truly flows from the kind.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Wisdom appears to rest in the mind, but it really exists to a man in his companions.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Man's wisdom seems the offspring of his mind;
'Tis outcome of companionship we find.
Various Translators: Wisdom, appearing to originate in a man’s mind, has its source in his companions.
Dinamalar:
Wisdom which seems to come from the mind
Comes really from one's company.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The pure thought and the pure deed, these two,
Come from pure company.
Transliteration:
The pure thought and the pure deed, these
two, Come from pure company.
T.Kannan: Chaste company is the staff on which come, these two things, viz, purity of mind and purity of conduct.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Purity of mind, and deeds, depends on the quality of one’s associations.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Manandhooimai Seyvinai Thooimai
Irantum
Inandhooimai Thoovaa Varum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Purity of the thought and deed 
Comes from good company indeed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Both purity of mind, and purity of action clear,
 Leaning no staff of pure companionship, to man draw near.
Various Translators: Purity of mind and purity of conduct—these two depend upon the purity of a man’s companions.
Dinamalar: Purity of mind and purity of action are of a piece with the purity of one’s associates.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Good legacy is for the pure-minded.
No evil deeds befall men of pure company.
Transliteration: To the pure-minded there will be a good posterity. By those whose associates are pure, no deeds will be done that are not good.
T.Kannan:
Good legacy is for the pure-minded. No
evil deeds befall men of pure company.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who are pure at heart, will leave behind good children and legacy; those who have clean company will find no good task impossible.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Manandhooyaark Kechchamnan Raakum
InandhooyaarkkuI
llainan Raakaa Vinai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Pure hearted get good progeny 
Pure friendship acts with victory.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
From true pure minded men a virtuous race proceeds;
To men of pure companionship belong no evil deeds.
Various Translators: Praiseworthy progeny come to pure–minded men whose pure companions keep impure deeds away.
Dinamalar: A good progeny awaits the pure. There is no effort of one endowed with good company but bears fruit.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A good mind is an asset to everyone
While good company contributes to glory.
Transliteration: Goodness of mind will give wealth, and good society will bring with it all praise, to men.
T.Kannan:
A good mind is an asset to everyone While
good company contributes to glory.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The goodness of heart is a treasure for humans; goodness of company leads to glory.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Mananalam Mannuyirk Kaakkam Inanalam
Ellaap Pukazhum Tharum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Goodness of mind increases gain
Good friendship fosters fame again.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Goodness of mind to lives of men increaseth gain;
And good companionship doth all of praise obtain.
Various Translators: Company of the pure brings one all glory.
Dinamalar: Wealth will be bestowed on good–minded men, and all renown will be granted by good company.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even though the wise have a good mind,
They strengthen it by good company.
Transliteration: Although they may have great (natural) goodness of mind, yet good society will tend to strengthen it.
T.Kannan:
Even though the wise have a good mind,
They strengthen it by good company.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even for noble scholars, who are good at heart, good company offers strong protection.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Mananalam Nankutaiya Raayinum
Saandrorkku
Inanalam Emaap Putaiththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Men of wisdom, though good in mind 
In friends of worth a new strength find.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The wise may be pure in mind. Good company is the source of one’s strength.
Various Translators:
To perfect men, though minds right good belong,
Yet good companionship is confirmation strong.
Dinamalar: Even perfect men, possessing the mind’s full goodness, are fortified by pious fellowship.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Goodness of mind leads to bliss in the next world, and even that is secured by the company of good men.
Transliteration: Future bliss is (the result) of goodness of mind; and even this acquires strength from the society of the good.
T.Kannan:
Purity of mind leads to heaven,
But even that is secured by good company.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Purity of mind leads to heaven, But even
that is secured by good company.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Heaven awaits the pure of heart; verily it is the reward of good company.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Goodness of heart leads to joy even after death; good company protects it from straying.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Mananalaththin Aakum Marumaimar
Raqdhum
Inanalaththin Emaap Putaiththu
Various Translators:
Good mind decides the future bliss 
Good company gains strength to this.
Dinamalar:
Although to mental goodness joys of other life belong,
Yet good companionship is confirmation strong;

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There exists no greater aid than virtuous fellowship, and no greater affliction than evil fraternity.
Transliteration: There is no greater help than the company of the good; there is no greater source of sorrow than the company of the wicked.
T.Kannan:
There is no greater aid than good company,
Nor worse affliction than bad.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: There is no greater evil than the company of the wicked.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
There is no greater aid than good company,
Nor worse affliction than bad.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: There is no better ally than good company; no woe can be worse than bad company.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Nallinaththi Noongun Thunaiyillai
Theeyinaththin
Allar Patuppadhooum Il
Various Translators:
No help good company exeeds; 
The bad to untold anguish leads.
Dinamalar:
Than good companionship no surer help we know;
Than bad companionship nought causes direr woe.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Expenditure, return,and profit of the deed
In time to come; weigh these than to the act proceed.
Transliteration: Let a man reflect on what will be lost, what will be acquired and (from these) what will be his ultimate gain, and (then, let him) act.
T.Kannan: When action is needed, ponder what is to be gained, what lost, and what ultimately achieved, then proceed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Act after taking into account the cost,
The benefit and the resultant net.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: After much deliberation over profit and loss and the final gains, launch on a task.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Act after taking into account the cost,
The benefit and the resultant net.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What gets consumed, what gets created, and the returns the creation yields : consider all before starting a task.
Various Translators:
Azhivadhooum Aavadhooum Aaki
Vazhipayakkum
Oodhiyamum Soozhndhu Seyal
Dinamalar:
Weigh well output the loss and gain
And proper action ascertain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There is nothing too difficult to (be attained by) those who, before they act, reflect well themselves, and thoroughly consider (the matter) with chosen friends.
Transliteration:
With chosen friends deliberate; next use the private thought;
Then act.by those who thus proceed all works with ease are wrought.
T.Kannan: There is nothing too difficult for a man who, before he acts, deliberates with chosen friends and reflects privately.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nothing is hard for him who acts with
Worthy counsels weighing facts.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Nothing is impossible for those who act after listening to the counsel of persons of known probity.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nothing is hard for him who acts with
Worthy counsels weighing facts.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Nothing is impossible for those who start a task with aptly chosen associates, and after thorough assessment.
Various Translators:
Therindha Inaththotu Therndhennich
Cheyvaarkku
Arumporul Yaadhondrum Il
Dinamalar:
Nothing is hard for him who acts
With worthy counsels weighing facts.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The wise risk not their capital 
In doubtful gains and lose their all.
Transliteration:
To risk one's all and lose, aiming at added gain,
Is rash affair, from which the wise abstain.
T.Kannan: The wise never undertake an enterprise that rashly risks existing capital to reach for potential profits.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The wise do not approve of the action of those who lose their capital anticipating some distant gain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The wise will never, in the hope of profit,
Launch an undertaking to lose their capital.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wise will never, in the hope of
profit, Launch an undertaking to lose their capital.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Wise men will not, in the hopes of profit, undertake works that will consume their principal.
Various Translators: Losing the capital in pursuit of profit is not a task the wise will undertake.
Dinamalar:
Aakkam Karudhi Mudhalizhakkum
Seyvinai
Ookkaar Arivutai Yaar

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Without assessing and getting clarity, will they not start, they who fear the stain of ignominy.
Transliteration:
Thelivi Ladhanaith Thotangaar
Ilivennum
Edhappaatu Anju Pavar
T.Kannan:
They who scornful reproach fear
Commence no work not made clear.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A work of which the issue is not clear,
Begin not they reproachful scorn who fear.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who dread ridicule and disgrace will not commence any task that is unclear.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Men who dread ignominy never embark on a work without deliberation.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Those who fear the disgrace of failure
Will not launch thoughtless ventures.
Various Translators: Those who fear reproach will not commence anything which has not been (thoroughly considered) and made clear to them.
Dinamalar:
Those who fear the disgrace of failure
Will not launch thoughtless ventures.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Leaping before you look is like planting foes, and nurturing them.
Transliteration:
Vakaiyarach Choozhaa Thezhudhal
Pakaivaraip
Paaththip Patuppadho Raaru
T.Kannan:
Who marches without plans and ways 
His field is sure to foster foes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
With plans not well matured to rise against your foe,
Is way to plant him out where he is sure to grow!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A thoughtless expedition only fosters the might of one’s foes.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To sally forth without a well–conceived plan is one way to cultivate an enemy’s strength.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ill considered aggressive operations serve
Only to mobilize and strengthen the enemy.
Various Translators: One way to promote the prosperity of an enemy, is (for a king) to set out (to war) without having thoroughly weighed his ability (to cope with its chances).
Dinamalar:
Ill considered aggressive operations serve
Only to mobilize and strengthen the enemy.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
It is ruinous to do what should not be
done, And ruinous to leave undone what should be done.
Transliteration: To do what ought not to be done is disastrous; not to do what ought to be done is equally so.
T.Kannan:
Seydhakka Alla Seyak Ketum
SeydhakkaSeyyaamai Yaanung Ketum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Doing unfit action ruins 
Failing fit act also ruins.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: To do a thing which ought not to be done is to court trouble; to fail to do a thing which ought to be done is to land oneself in ruin.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Tis ruin if man do an unbefitting thing;
Fit things to leave undone will equal ruin bring.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Doing what should not be done will bring ruin, and not doing what should be done will also bring ruin.
Various Translators:
It is ruinous to do what should not be done,
And ruinous to leave undone what should be done.
Dinamalar: He will perish who does not what is not fit to do; and he also will perish who does not do what it is fit to do.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Think before you launch. To launch and
then think is disgrace.
Transliteration: Begin your task after much deliberation. To think after launching action is to court a grievous blunder.
T.Kannan: Think before you start; to think that you can think after starting spells doom.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ennith Thunika Karumam Thunindhapin
Ennuvam Enpadhu Izhukku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Think and dare a proper deed 
Dare and think is bad in need.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Think, and then dare the deed! Who cry,
'Deed dared, we’ll think.; disgraced shall be.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Embark upon an action after careful thought. It is folly to say, “Let us begin the task now and think about it later.”
Various Translators: Consider, and then undertake a matter; after having undertaken it, to say "We will consider," is folly.
Dinamalar:
Think before you launch.
To launch and then think is disgrace.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: An ill-organised scheme though supported by many goes to pieces.
Transliteration:
Undetermined efforts of any scheme Are
bound to fail even if backed by many.
T.Kannan: Hard work, the wrong way, will be futile even if the world applauds.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aatrin Varundhaa Varuththam
Palarnindru
Potrinum Poththup Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Toil without a plan ahead 
Is doomed to fall though supported.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
On no right system if man toil and strive,
Though many men assist, no work can thrive.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Any task not methodically performed may go awry, though men in multitudes support it.
Various Translators: The work, which is not done by suitable methods, will fail though many stand to uphold it.
Dinamalar:
Undetermined efforts of any scheme
Are bound to fail even if backed by many.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even a good scheme falls through if we do not divine aright the disposition of men.
Transliteration:
Even perfect schemes can fail when there
is Imperfection in the division of labour.
T.Kannan: Well-intended actions could go awry, if they are not customized to suit the nature of all those involved.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nandraatra Lullun Thavuruntu
Avaravar
Panparin Thaatraak Katai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Attune the deeds to habitude 
Or ev'n good leads to evil feud.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though well the work be done, yet one mistake is made,
To habitudes of various men when no regard is paid.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: There are failures even in acting well, when it is done without knowing the various dispositions of men.
Various Translators: Even in doing good deeds a man may err if he does not consider the recipient’s unique nature.
Dinamalar:
Even perfect schemes can fail when there is
Imperfection in the division of labour.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Let not the king do; any unwise act lest the world should hold him in scorn.
Transliteration:
Think and act without incurring scorn. The
world will not approve what is improper.
T.Kannan: The world doesn’t accept what it can’t approve; assess and act such that you are not ridiculed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ellaadha Ennich Cheyalventum
Thammotu
Kollaadha Kollaadhu Ulaku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Do deeds above reproachfulness
The world refutes uncomely mess.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Let a man reflect, and do things which bring no reproach; the world will not approve, with him, of things which do not become of his position to adopt.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Plan and perform no work that others may despise;
What misbeseems a king the world will not approve as wise.
Various Translators: Having made his plans, let a man keep his actions above blame. The world will never approve of acts that are beneath him.
Dinamalar:
Think and act without incurring scorn.
The world will not approve what is improper.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Weigh the strengths of the task, yourselves,
Opponents, and allies before acting.
Transliteration:
Weigh the strengths of the task,
yourselves, Opponents, and allies before acting.
T.Kannan: Let (one) weigh well the strength of the deed (he purposes to do), his own strength, the strength of his enemy, and the strength of the allies (of both), and then let him act.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Assess before an action, the strengths of the task, self, opponents and companions.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vinaivaliyum Thanvaliyum Maatraan
Valiyum
Thunaivaliyum Thookkich Cheyal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Judge act and might and foeman's strength 
The allies' strength and go at length.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The force the strife demands, the force he owns, the force of foes,
The force of friends; these should he weigh ere to the war he goes.
Various Translators: The prudent man acts after weighing the strength a deed demands, his own strength and the strengths of allies and opposition.
Dinamalar: A king must act after measuring the strength of his plan, his own resources, the strength of the enemy and that of the ally.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nothing is impossible for him
Who knows his task and strength, and is well set.
Transliteration: There is nothing which may not be accomplished by those who, before they attack (an enemy), make themselves acquainted with their own ability, and with whatever else is (needful) to be known, and apply themselves wholly to their object.
T.Kannan:
Nothing is impossible for him Who knows
his task and strength, and is well set.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Anticipate outcomes, learn what needs to be learnt, and stay focussed : nothing is impossible.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Olva Tharivadhu Arindhadhan
Kandhangich
Chelvaarkkuch Chellaadhadhu Il
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nothing hampers the firm who know 
What they can and how to go.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who know what can be wrought, with knowledge of the means, on this
Their mind firm set, go forth, nought goes with them amiss.
Various Translators: Nothing is impossible for those who perceive the nature and means of their task and proceed with determination.
Dinamalar: Nothing is impossible for them who know the nature of their task and throw themselves heart and soul into it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ignorant of their strengths,
Many in their zeal have perished midway.
Transliteration: There are many who, ignoran t of their (want of) power (to meet it), have haughtily set out to war, and broken down in the midst of it.
T.Kannan:
Ignorant of their strengths, Many in their
zeal have perished midway.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Many have boken down midway, having started with fervour without assessing their capabilities.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Utaiththam Valiyariyaar Ookkaththin
Ookki
Itaikkan Murindhaar Palar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Many know not their meagre might
Their pride breaks up in boastful fight.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
I'll deeming of their proper powers, have many monarchs striven,
And midmost of unequal conflict fallen asunder riven.
Various Translators: Many kings have failed in the middle of their enterprise, for they have launched on it in their blind ignorant zeal.
Dinamalar: Ignorant of their strengths, many plunge zealously into projects, only to miscarry midway.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The inadaptable have speedy end
Who boast unconcerned of their real strengths.
Transliteration: He will quickly perish who, ignorant of his own resources flatters himself of his greatness, and does not live in peace with his neighbours.
T.Kannan:
The inadaptable have speedy end Who boast
unconcerned of their real strengths.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: He is uncollaborative; he knows not his capabilities; he is narcissistic to boot; he is set for a swift fall.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Amaindhaang Kozhukaan Alavariyaan
Thannai
Viyandhaan Viraindhu Ketum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who adapts not, outsteps measure 
And brags himself his fall is sure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He who is ignorant of the might of his foe and who thinks too much of himself will come to grief.
Various Translators:
Who not agrees with those around, no moderation knows,
In self applause indulging, swift to ruin goes.
Dinamalar: How swiftly men who praise themselves perish, unappraised of their real measure, unable to live in peace with others.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Load too many of them, and even peacock feathers would break a sturdy cart’s axle.
Transliteration: The axle tree of a bandy, loaded only with peacocks' feathers will break, if it be greatly overloaded.
T.Kannan:
Too great a load of even peacock-feathers
Will break the axle-tree of the cart.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Too great a load of even peacock-feathers
Will break the axle-tree of the cart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A cart, though laden with only peacock feathers, may yet have its axle broken, when overloaded.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The axle of a cart breaks even under the overload of a peacock’s feathers.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Peelipey Saakaatum Achchirum
Appantanjjch
Aala Mikuththup Peyin
Various Translators:
Even the gentle peacock's plume 
Cart's axle breaks by gross volume.
Dinamalar:
With peacock feathers light you load the wain;
Yet, heaped too high, the axle snaps in twain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He who has climbed out to the tip of a tree branch and attempts to climb farther will forfeit his life.
Transliteration: There will be an end to the life of him who, having climbed out to the end of a branch, ventures to go further.
T.Kannan:
Persisting to climb beyond the terminal branches of a tree
Will forfeit one's life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Over-vaulting ambition perishes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Persisting to climb beyond the terminal
branches of a tree Will forfeit one's life.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Having climbed to the tip of a branch, striving to go further, will be fatal.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Nunikkompar Erinaar Aqdhiran
Thookkin
Uyirkkirudhi Aaki Vitum
Various Translators:
Beyond the branches' tip who skips 
Ends the life as his body rips.
Dinamalar:
Who daring climbs, and would himself upraise
Beyond the branch's tip, with life the forfeit pays.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
With knowledge of the measure due,as virtue bids you, give!
That is the way to guard your wealth, and seemly live.
Transliteration: Let a man know the measure of his ability (to give), and let him give accordingly; such giving is the way to preserve his property.
T.Kannan: Know the measure of your capacity to give, then give accordingly; such clarity is the way wealth is preserved.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Know the limit and grant with measure.
This is the way to guard your treasure.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let your charity be according to the measure of your wealth. That is the way to preserve it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Know the limit and grant with measure.
This is the way to guard your treasure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Do charity, but within your means; that is the way to utilize, and protect, wealth.
Various Translators:
Aatrin Aravarindhu Eeka Adhuporul
Potri Vazhangu Neri
Dinamalar:
Know the limit; grant with measure
This way give and guard your treasure.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even though the income (of a king) be small, it will not cause his (ruin), if his outgoings be not larger than his income.
Transliteration:
Incomings may be scant; but yet, no failure there,
If in expenditure you rightly learn to spare.
T.Kannan: A small income is no cause for failure, provided expenditures do not exceed it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
No harm if income is narrow
If outgoings are not broad.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: No harm comes of one’s small earnings. Let not one’s expense out-run one’s income.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No harm if income is narrow If outgoings
are not broad.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though revenues are limited, no harm. if you don’t let expenses exceed them.
Various Translators:
Aakaaru Alavitti Thaayinung Ketillai
Pokaaru Akalaak Katai
Dinamalar:
The outflow must not be excess
No matter how small income is.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who does not know to live in bounds
His life seems rich but thins and ends.
Transliteration:
Who prosperous lives and of enjoyment knows no bound,
His seeming wealth, departing, nowhere shall be found.
T.Kannan: Prosperous as his life may appear, unless a man measures well his wealth, it will disappear without a trace.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The seeming prosperity of the extravagant perishes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A life lived without adjustment to the means
May seem to prosper but will perish.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A life lived without adjustment to the
means May seem to prosper but will perish.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A life lived beyond one’s means, will look glitzy but will lose its sheen and give way to gloom.
Various Translators: The prosperity of him who lives without knowing the measure (of his property), will perish, even while it seems to continue.
Dinamalar:
Alavarindhu Vaazhaadhaan Vaazhkkai
Ulapola
Illaakith Thondraak Ketum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ulavarai Thookkaadha Oppura Vaanmai
Valavarai Vallaik Ketum
Transliteration:
Wealth amassed quickly vanishes 
Sans level if one lavishes.
T.Kannan:
Beneficence that measures not its bond of means,
Will swiftly bring to nought the wealth on which it leans.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: How swiftly a generous man’s riches dwindle and die, if he does not evaluate the limits of his means.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The fortune of one, lavish of charity beyond measure, goes to rack and rain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
He who is generous beyond his means
Will quickly lose the measure of his wealth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The measure of his wealth will quickly perish, whose liberality weighs not the measure of his property.
Various Translators:
He who is generous beyond his means Will
quickly lose the measure of his wealth.
Dinamalar: Generosity beyond the limits of one’s resources, is bound to cease soon, after exhausting the resources.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A crow will defeat an owl during the day; a king needs to pick the right time to defeat his foes.
Transliteration:
Pakalvellum Kookaiyaik Kaakkai
Ikalvellum
Vendharkku Ventum Pozhudhu
T.Kannan:
By day the crow defeats the owl 
Kings need right time their foes to quell.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A crow will conquer owl in broad daylight;
The king that foes would crush needs fitting time to fight.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: During the day the crow conquers the owl. So the monarch who wishes to defeat the enemy must choose the proper time.
