Ramachandra Dikshitar: During the day, a crow can overcome the more powerful owl. Desiring to defeat his enemy, a king must pick the proper time.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A crow can defeat an owl by day.
Kings need the right time to win.
Various Translators: A crow will overcome an owl in the day time; so the king who would conquer his enemy must have (a suitable) time.
Dinamalar:
A crow can defeat an owl by day. Kings
need the right time to win.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The rope that binds Fortune Is deeds done
at the right time.
Transliteration: Doing the right things at the right time, is the rope which binds the wealth, making it boundless.
T.Kannan:
Paruvaththotu Otta Ozhukal
Thiruvinaith
Theeraamai Aarkkung Kayiru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Well ordered seasoned act is cord 
That fortune binds in bon accord.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Action at the appropriate hour is the rope that holds for ever the Goddess of Fortune to the King.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The bond binds fortune fast is ordered effort made,
Strictly observant still of favouring season's aid.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A man may tightly bind himself to prosperity by the tether called timely action.
Various Translators:
The rope that binds Fortune
Is deeds done at the right time.
Dinamalar: Acting at the right season, is a cord that will immoveably bind success (to a king).

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What is impossible If right means are
adopted at the right time?
Transliteration: Does an impossible task exist, when the right resources and strategy are deployed at the right time?
T.Kannan: Is there anything impossible if one acts at the right time and with the proper equipment?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aruvinai Yenpa Ulavo Karuviyaan
Kaalam Arindhu Seyin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What is hard for him who acts
With proper means and time and tacts?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Can any work be hard in very fact,
If men use fitting means in timely act?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Is there any task too difficult for the man who acts at the right time and with the proper means?
Various Translators: Is there anything difficult for him to do, who acts, with (the right) instruments at the right time ?
Dinamalar:
What is impossible
If right means are adopted at the right time?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One can succeed in the attempt to conquer the world if the right time and the right place are chosen.
Transliteration:
Even the world will be yours, If you act
choosing the right time and place.
T.Kannan: Desire the world, you may, and it will be yours, if, for your actions, you choose the right time and place.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Gnaalam Karudhinung Kaikootung
Kaalam
Karudhi Itaththaar Seyin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Choose proper time and act and place 
Even the world you win with ease.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The pendant world's dominion may be won,
In fitting time and place by action done.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: One may aim to acquire the whole world and succeed, if actions target the right time and place.
Various Translators: Though (a man) should meditate (the conquest of) the world, he may accomplish it if he acts in the right time, and at the right place.
Dinamalar:
Even the world will be yours,
If you act choosing the right time and place.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He who without any fear aims at the conquest of the world will await the season for it.
Transliteration:
Those who hope for the world wait
unperturbed Hoping for the right moment.
T.Kannan: They will await the opportune moment. they, who determinedly desire the world.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaalam Karudhi Iruppar Kalangaadhu
Gnaalam Karudhu Pavar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who want to win the world sublime
Wait unruffled biding their time.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who think the pendant world itself to subjugate,
With mind unruffled for the fitting time must wait.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: They who thoughtfully consider and wait for the (right) time (for action), may successfully meditate (the conquest of) the world.
Various Translators: Those who aim to own the world must wait, unruffled, for the fitting hour.
Dinamalar:
Those who hope for the world wait unperturbed
Hoping for the right moment.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The self-restraint of the mighty is like the drawing back of the fighting ram just before its attack.
Transliteration:
The restraint of an active person Is akin
to the retreat of a butting ram.
T.Kannan: The ardent and the mighty too can stay subdued like a rampant ram that withdraws before it pounces.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ookka Mutaiyaan Otukkam Porudhakar
Thaakkarkup Perun Thakaiththu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
By self restraint stalwarts keep fit 
Like rams retreating but to butt.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The self-restraint of the energetic (while waiting for a suitable opportunity), is like the drawing back of a fighting-ram in order to butt.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The men of mighty power their hidden energies repress,
As fighting ram recoils to rush on foe with heavier stress.
Various Translators: The powerful man’s patient restraint is like the drawing back of the fighting ram before he strikes the stunning blow.
Dinamalar:
The restraint of an active person
Is akin to the retreat of a butting ram.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The wise do not burst with rage.
They hold it for the right time.
Transliteration:
The wise do not burst with rage. They hold
it for the right time.
T.Kannan: The wise will not break into an external rage instantly; they will keep their anger suppressed, biding their time.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The wise will not immediately and hastily shew out their anger; they will watch their time, and restrain it within.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pollena Aange Puramveraar
Kaalampaarththu
Ulverppar Olli Yavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wise jut not their vital fire 
They watch their time with hidden ire.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The glorious once of wrath enkindled make no outward show,
At once; they bide their time, while hidden fires within them glow.
Various Translators: When irate, clear minded men never show it then and there. Holding it within, they watch for an opportune moment.
Dinamalar: The wise will not fly into a passion when assailed; they allow their anger to smoulder within till the right time comes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The best is to bear with your enemy
Till the time comes to topple him.
Transliteration: If one meets his enemy, let him show him all respect, until the time for his destruction is come; when that is come, his head will be easily b rought low.
T.Kannan:
The best is to bear with your enemy Till
the time comes to topple him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Bear with your foes; when the time is ripe, turn things around.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Serunaraik Kaanin Sumakka Iruvarai
Kaanin Kizhakkaam Thalai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Bear with hostiles when you meet them 
Fell down their head in fateful time.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If foes' detested form they see, with patience let them bear;
When fateful hour at last they spy, the head lies there.
Various Translators: Bow ever so humbly when meeting an enemy. His own head will hang humiliated when, in time, he meets defeat.
Dinamalar: Bow before the enemy till the time of his destruction. When the hour comes, strike him down.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Hesitate not to seize opportunities rare,
And achieve tasks otherwise hard.
Transliteration: If a rare opportunity occurs, while it lasts, let a man do that which is rarely to be accomplished (but for such an opportunity).
T.Kannan:
Hesitate not to seize opportunities rare,
And achieve tasks otherwise hard.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When the rarest of moments comes about, grab it to accomplish the toughest of tasks.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Eydhar Kariyadhu Iyaindhakkaal
Annilaiye
Seydhar Kariya Seyal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When comes the season ripe and rare
Dare and do hard things then and there.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When hardest gain of opportunity at last is won,
With promptitude let hardest deed be done.
Various Translators: Do not let slip a golden opportunity; when the hour dawns, attempt the impossible.
Dinamalar: When a rare opportunity comes your way, do not hesitate to swiftly accomplish otherwise impossible tasks.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Bide your time like the stork, and like it
Strike at the opportune moment.
Transliteration: At the time when one should use self-control, let him restrain himself like a heron; and, let him like it, strike, when there is a favourable opportunity.
T.Kannan:
Bide your time like the stork, and like it
Strike at the opportune moment.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Like a heron, be still when the time is not ripe, and spear the prey when it is near.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kokkokka Koompum Paruvaththu
Matradhan
Kuththokka Seerththa Itaththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In waiting time feign peace like stork 
In fighting time strike like its peck.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When the time is not ripe, be still as a heron. But at the ripe hour, attack the enemy without missing your aim.
Various Translators:
As heron stands with folded wing, so wait in waiting hour;
As heron snaps its prey, when fortune smiles, put forth your power.
Dinamalar: There are times to stay still as a stalking heron. There are times to move swiftly as a heron strikes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Neither ridicule the opposition nor initiate an offensive until you possess a strategic place from which to strike.
Transliteration: Let not (a king) despise (an enemy), nor undertake any thing (against him), until he has obtained (a suitable) place for besieging him.
T.Kannan:
Don't despise your foe, nor start any action
Till you find a place to besiege him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Don't despise your foe, nor start any
action Till you find a place to besiege him.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Start not a task, thinking it is easy, until you choose the right place to accomplish it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Scorn not the foe; embark not on any action till you secure a coign of vantage to overwhelm him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thotangarka Evvinaiyum Ellarka
Mutrum
Itanganta Pinal Ladhu
Various Translators:
No action take, no foe despise 
Until you have surveyed the place.
Dinamalar:
Begin no work of war, despise no foe,
Till place where you can wholly circumvent you know.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: In battle, a fortified position yields plentiful advantages, even to those already possessing power and prowess.
Transliteration: Even to those who are men of power and expedients, an attack in connection with a fortification will yield many advantages.
T.Kannan:
A fortress gives numerous advantages
Even to men of strength and valour.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even to men of great valour and power, manifold are the advantages yielded by a fortress.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A fortress gives numerous advantages Even
to men of strength and valour.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even for the mighty, seeking to conquer, a fortress offers benefits galore.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Muranserndha Moimpi Navarkkum
Aranserndhaam
Aakkam Palavun Tharum
Various Translators:
Many are gains of fortresses 
Ev'n to kings of power and prowess.
Dinamalar:
Though skill in war combine with courage tried on battle field,
The added gain of fort doth great advantage yeild.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
E'en weak ones mightily prevail, if palce of strong defence,
They find, protect themselves, and work their foes offence.
Transliteration: Even the powerless will become powerful and conquer, if they select a proper field (of action), and guard themselves, while they make war on their enemies.
T.Kannan: Even the weak may prevail if they pick the right field of action, establish good defenses and then fight well.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Even the weak can fight enemies with determination
If they choose the right place.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Even the weak are able to win if they choose the right place to assail the foe.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Even the weak can fight enemies with
determination If they choose the right place.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even the meek will battle and win, when they tenaciously take on their foes at the right place.
Various Translators:
Aatraarum Aatri Atupa Itanarindhu
Potraarkan Potrich Cheyin
Dinamalar:
Weaklings too withstand foe's offence
In proper fields of strong defence.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If they who draw near (to fight) choose a suitable place to approach (their enemy), the latter, will have to relinquish the thought which they once entertained, of conquering them.
Transliteration:
The foes who thought to triumph, find their thoughts were vain,
If hosts advance, seize vantage ground, and thence the fight maintain.
T.Kannan: When an attacker lays siege from a strategic location, his enemy’s thoughts of conquest become unthinkable.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
When fighters fight from strategic locations,
Enemies lose their strategic plans.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If a king stations himself at a right place the conquering foe loses all hope.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When fighters fight from strategic
locations, Enemies lose their strategic plans.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Their dismissive opponents will lose the plot, when those who undertake a task, do it right at the right place.
Various Translators:
Enniyaar Ennam Izhappar Itanarindhu
Thunniyaar Thunnich Cheyin
Dinamalar:
If fighters fight in vantage field
The plans of foes shall be baffled.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
In water crocodile prevails 
In land before others it fails.
Transliteration:
The crocodile prevails in its own flow of water wide,
If this it leaves, 'tis slain by anything beside.
T.Kannan: In a river’s depths the crocodile is unconquerable, but others may defeat him if he leaves those waters.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The crocodile in waters deep overpowers all; once it leaves the waters, he falls an easy prey to its foes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A crocodile prevails in deep waters;
But when out of water, others prevail over it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A crocodile prevails in deep waters; But
when out of water, others prevail over it.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: In deep waters, the crocodile wins. When it gets out, it is vanquished.
Various Translators: In deep water, a crocodile will conquer (all other animals); but if it leave the water, other animals will conquer it.
Dinamalar:
Netumpunalul Vellum Mudhalai
Atumpunalin
Neengin Adhanaip Pira

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Katalotaa Kaalval Netundher
Katalotum
Naavaayum Otaa Nilaththu
Transliteration:
Sea going ship goes not on shore 
Nor on sea the strong wheeled car.
T.Kannan:
The lofty car, with mighty wheel, sails not o'er watery main,
The boast that skims the sea, runs not on earth's hard plain.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A massive chariot with mighty wheels cannot sail the sea; nor can an ocean going ship traverse the land.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The strong wheeled lofty chariot cannot cross the seas, nor can ocean sailing ships move on land.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A mighty chariot cannot run in the sea,
Nor a boat navigate land.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Wide chariots, with mighty wheels, will not run on the ocean; neither will ships that the traverse ocean, move on the earth.
Various Translators:
A mighty chariot cannot run in the sea,
Nor a boat navigate land.
Dinamalar: Neither will the strongest chariots sail the seas, nor will the seafaring ships ride the land.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If, after considering all angles, one chooses to do a task at an apt place, he needs no company other than fearlessness.
Transliteration:
Anjaamai Allaal Thunaiventaa
Enjaamai
Enni Itaththaal Seyin
T.Kannan:
No aid but daring dash they need 
When field is chosen right for deed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Save their own fearless might they need no other aid,
If in right place they fight, all due provision made.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If one selects a suitable place by one’s discretion, no other help is needed.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Fearlessness is the only friend one needs, if he relentlessly ponders from which place to pounce.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
No other aid than courage is needed
If one ponders from which place to pounce.
Various Translators: You will need no other aid than fearlessness, if you thoroughly reflect (on what you are to do), and select (a suitable) place for your operations.
Dinamalar:
No other aid than courage is needed If one
ponders from which place to pounce.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A large army will lose its morale If
driven to a place meant for a small one.
Transliteration: If a king with a measly army battles from a strategic location, the confidence of the mighty foe gets shattered.
T.Kannan:
Sirupataiyaan Sellitam Serin
Urupataiyaan
Ookkam Azhindhu Vitum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though force is small, if place is right
One quells a foe of well armed might.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Ruined will be the strength of one who takes a large army to a place where the enemy of small forces is entrenched.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If lord of army vast the safe retreat assail
Of him whose host is small, his mightiest efforts fail.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even a small army, if well–entrenched, can repel the power of a large army, forcing it to retreat.
Various Translators:
A large army will lose its morale
If driven to a place meant for a small one.
Dinamalar: The power of one who has a large army will perish, if he goes into ground where only a small army can act.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Men on their own ground are hard to tackle
Even when they lack fortress and strength.
Transliteration: Even if the foes are devoid of fortresses and exceptional valour, it is tough to beat them on their turf.
T.Kannan: A people may not have either strength or strongholds; still it is difficult to fight with them on their own soil.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sirainalanum Seerum Ilareninum
Maandhar
Urainilaththotu Ottal Aridhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To face a foe at home is vain 
Though fort and status are not fine.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though fort be none, and store of wealth they lack,
'Tis hard a people's homesteads to attack!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even if they are without firm forts and inferior in force, a people defending their own soil are difficult to defeat.
Various Translators: It is a hazardous thing to attack men in their own country, although they may neither have power nor a good fortress.
Dinamalar:
Men on their own ground are hard to tackle
Even when they lack fortress and strength.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A mad elephant that kills the bold spearman is killed even by a jackal when it gets stuck up in the mire.
Transliteration:
A fearless tusker that defies spearman, if
caught in a bog, Will be overcome by jackals.
T.Kannan: An uncontrollable tusker that has gored many a spearman, when stuck in a deep quagmire, is easy prey for a fox.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaalaazh Kalaril Nariyatum Kannanjaa
Velaal Mukaththa Kaliru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A fox can kill a war tusker 
Fearless with feet in deep quagmire.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The jackal slays, in miry paths of foot betraying fen,
The elephant of fearless eye and tusks transfixing armed men.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The fearless elephant may slaughter a multitude of warriors, yet be slain by a single jackal if his legs sink in muddy marsh.
Various Translators: A fox can kill a fearless, warrior-faced elephant, if it go into mud in which its legs sink down.
Dinamalar:
A fearless tusker that defies spearman, if caught in a bog,
Will be overcome by jackals.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One should be chosen after patting one to a fourfold test of righteousness, wealth, inclination and fear of life and death.
Transliteration:
Before you trust, test people's attitude
to these four: Virtue, wealth, love and survival.
T.Kannan: Assess the attitude of a person on these four aspects before choosing him: righteousness (aram), money, lust and fear for life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aramporul Inpam Uyirachcham Naankin
Thirandherindhu Therap Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pleasure, gold, fear of life Virtue 
Test by these four and trust the true.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
How treats he virtue, wealth and pleasure? How , when life's at stake,
Comports himself? This four fold test of man will full assurance make.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Let (a minister) be chosen, after he has been tried by means of these four things, viz,-his virtue, (love of) money, (love of) sexual pleasure, and tear of (losing) life.
Various Translators: Pick that man who passes a four fold test: how he handles virtue, wealth, pleasure and loss of life.
Dinamalar:
Before you trust, test people's attitude to these four:
Virtue, wealth, love and survival.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One of good family, free of faults, and possessed of a wholesome fear of sin, should be chosen.
Transliteration:
Noble heritage, freedom from faults and
shame of blame Are some norms to choose.
T.Kannan: Accept only a person who is of good birth, is clear of flaws, has fear for infamy and shame.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kutippirandhu Kutraththin Neengi
Vatuppariyum
Naanutaiyaan Sutte Thelivu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Spotless name of noble birth 
Shamed of stain that choice is worth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: (The king's) choice should (fall) on him, who is of good family, who is free from faults, and who has the modesty which fears the wounds (of sin).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Of noble race, of faultless worth, of generous pride
That shrinks from shame or stain; in him may king confide.
Various Translators: Place trust in a man of good family, free from faults, with a modest nature that dreads reproach.
Dinamalar:
Noble heritage, freedom from faults and shame of blame
Are some norms to choose.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even the widely-read and faultless, when scrutinized,
Are rarely found free of ignorance.
Transliteration:
Even the widely-read and faultless, when
scrutinized, Are rarely found free of ignorance.
T.Kannan: Even a person who is known to be erudite and faultless, if assessed well, will rarely be free of flaws and ignorance.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When even men, who have studied the most difficult works, and who are free from faults, are (carefully) examined, it is a rare thing to find them without ignorance.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ariyakatru Aasatraar Kannum
Theriyungaal
Inmai Aridhe Veliru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though deep scholars of stainless sense 
Rare is freedom from ignorance.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though deeply learned, unflecked by fault, 'tis rare to see,
When closely scanned, a man from all unwisdom free.
Various Translators: Even faultless, deeply learned men, when closely examined, are rarely found to be entirely free from ignorance.
Dinamalar: One may be an unblemished man and of vast learning; but it is rare to find one free from ignorance.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Weigh a man's merits and also his defects.
Whichever weighs more is his nature.
Transliteration: Let (a king) consider (a man's) good qualities, as well as his faults, and then judge (of his character) by that which prevails.
T.Kannan:
Weigh a man's merits and also his defects.
Whichever weighs more is his nature.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Weigh the virtues and vices, discern which is more, and thus decide.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kunamnaatik Kutramum Naati Avatrul
Mikainaati Mikka Kolal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Good and evil in man weigh well 
Judge him by virtues which prevail.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Weigh well the good of each, his failings closely scan,
As these or those prevail, so estimate the man.
Various Translators: Weigh a man’s merits and weigh his faults, then judge him according to the greater.
Dinamalar: Examine the good and bad in a person and judge his character according to what predominates in his composition.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A man's deeds are the touchstone of his
Greatness and littleness.
Transliteration: A man's deeds are the touchstone of his greatness and littleness.
T.Kannan:
A man's deeds are the touchstone of his
Greatness and littleness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The touchstone for greatness or unworthiness is one’s own deeds.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Perumaikkum Enaich Chirumaikkum
Thaththam
Karumame Kattalaik Kal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
By the touchstone of deeds is seen 
If any one is great or mean.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Of greatness and of meanness too,
The deeds of each are touchstone true.
Various Translators: One’s own deed is the touchstone of one’s greatness and littleness.
Dinamalar: The touchstone that discloses a man’s greatness or smallness is simply this: his deeds.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Choose not men who have no kindred.
With no bonds to restrain, they dread no shame.
Transliteration: Let (a king) avoid choosing men who have no relations; such men have no attachment, and thereforehave no fear of crime.
T.Kannan:
Choose not men who have no kindred. With
no bonds to restrain, they dread no shame.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Choose not those who have made no friends : devoid of any affinity, they won’t dread disgrace.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Atraaraith Therudhal Ompuka Matravar
Patrilar Naanaar Pazhi
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Choose not those men without kinsmen
Without affine or shame of sin.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Choose not persons who have no kith and kin, and who possesses no social instincts, they will be callous of heart and dread no crime.
Various Translators:
Beware of trusting men who have no kith or kin,
No bonds restrain such men, no shame deters from sin.
Dinamalar: Beware of trusting men who have no kin. Unattached to people, they are unashamed of misdeeds.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When a man employs a know–nothing out of affection, he engages all kinds of foolishness.
Transliteration: To choose ignorant men, through partiality, is the height of folly.
T.Kannan:
To favour and select the incompetent out of love,
Leads to folly in all forms.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To favour and select the incompetent out
of love, Leads to folly in all forms.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Out of affection, choosing those who know not what needs to be known, will result in folly.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: It is the height of folly to choose the ignorant blinded by affection.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kaadhanmai Kandhaa Arivariyaarth
Therudhal
Pedhaimai Ellaan Tharum
Various Translators:
On favour leaning fools you choose; 
Folly in all its forms ensues.
Dinamalar:
By fond affection led who trusts in men of unwise soul,
Yeilds all his being up to folly's blind control.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To trust a stranger without investigation invites troubles so endless that even descendants must endure them.
Transliteration: Sorrow that will not leave even his posterity will come upon him chooses a stranger whose character he has not known.
T.Kannan:
To choose a stranger untried
Will trouble one's line without end.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: To choose a stranger without knowing his traits results in one’s grief.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To choose a stranger untried Will trouble
one's line without end.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: One who accepts without assessing, will invite harm that will last for generations.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Theraan Piranaith Thelindhaan
Vazhimurai
Theeraa Itumpai Tharum
Various Translators:
To trust an untried stranger brings
Endless troubles on all our kins.
Dinamalar:
Who trusts an untried stranger, brings disgrace,
Remediless, on all his race.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Trust no man whom you have not fully tried,
When tested, in his prudence proved confide.
Transliteration: Let (a king) choose no one without previous consideration; after he has made his choice, let him unhesitatingly select for each such duties as are appropriate.
T.Kannan: Without investigation, trust no one. Having investigated, entrust a man with matters for which he is trustworthy.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Trust none untried, and after trial
Entrust him with the trusted job.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let men be chosen with deliberate care; when once the choice is made, let no suspicions crump into your soul.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Trust none untried, and after trial
Entrust him with the trusted job.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Choose not anyone without assessment; once chosen, trust the person to deliver on the assigned tasks.
Various Translators:
Therarka Yaaraiyum Theraadhu
Therndhapin
Theruka Therum Porul
Dinamalar:
Trust not without testing and then 
Find proper work for trusted men.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To make choice of one who has not been examined, and to entertain doubts respecting one who has been chosen, will produce irremediable sorrow.
Transliteration:
Trust where you have not tried, doubt of a friend to feel,
Once trusted, wounds inflict that nought can heal.
T.Kannan: To trust a man who has not been tested and to suspect a man who has proven trustworthy lead alike to endless ills.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Trusting those untested and suspecting those tested,
Both lead to endless trouble.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: To choose men with no forethought and to suspect them will land you in endless woes.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Trusting those untested and suspecting
those tested, Both lead to endless trouble.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Selecting without assessing, and doubting after selecting, will ensure enduring distress.
Various Translators:
Theraan Thelivum Thelindhaankan
Aiyuravum
Theeraa Itumpai Tharum
Dinamalar:
Trust without test; The trusted doubt;
Both entail troubles in and out.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Employ the wise who will discern
The good and bad and do good turn.
Transliteration:
Who good and evil scanning, ever makes the good his joy;
Such man of virtuous mood should king employ.
T.Kannan: Employ men who discern the good and the bad in every situation and naturally choose the good.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: After examining the good and the bad, cling to the good.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Employ those who prefer to do the good
After scanning both good and bad.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Employ those who prefer to do the good
After scanning both good and bad.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A person, because of his ability to execute well by assessing pros and cons, will assume charge of key assignments.
Various Translators: He should be employed (by a king), whose nature leads him to choose the good, after having weighed both the evil and the good in any undertaking.
Dinamalar:
Nanmaiyum Theemaiyum Naati
Nalampurindha
Thanmaiyaan Aalap Patum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Vaari Perukki Valampatuththu Utravai
Aaraaivaan Seyka Vinai
Transliteration:
Let him act who resource swells;
Fosters wealth and prevents ills.
T.Kannan:
Who swells the revenues, spreads plenty o'er the land,
Seeks out what hinders progress, his the workman's hand.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Let him do the work who can increase profits, spread prosperity and search out problems.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who taps all productive sources and guards against losses is the true servant.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Entrust the job to one who can augment revenue,
Foster wealth and find out hurdles.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Let him do (the king's) work who can enlarge the sources (of revenue), increase wealth and considerately prevent the accidents (which would destroy it).
Various Translators:
Entrust the job to one who can augment
revenue, Foster wealth and find out hurdles.
Dinamalar: Let him do that task. he, who has multiplied the sources of income, generated revenues, and analysed and overcome hurdles.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Love, wisdom, fearless analytical mind and lack of misdirected desire: go for a person who scores high on these.
Transliteration:
Anparivu Thetram Avaavinmai
Innaankum
Nankutaiyaan Katte Thelivu
T.Kannan:
Trust him in whom these four you see: 
Love, wit, non craving, clarity.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A loyal love with wisdom, clearness, mind from avarice free;
Who hath these four good gifts should ever trusted be.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Choose men, who are endowed with love, wisdom, clever vision and freedom from covetousness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He alone is trustworthy who fully possesses these four: kindness, intelligence, assurance and freedom from greed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The qualified possess these four:
Affection, wisdom, clarity and contentment.
Various Translators: Let the choice (of a king) fall upon him who largely possesses these four things, love, knowledge, a clear mind and freedom from covetousness.
Dinamalar:
The qualified possess these four:
Affection, wisdom, clarity and contentment.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Put into many tests, they pass. Yet when
subjected to different tasks, many fail.
Transliteration: In whatever way we may have assessed and chosen people, they stand out based on quality of execution.
T.Kannan:
Enaivakaiyaan Theriyak Kannum
Vinaivakaiyaan
Veraakum Maandhar Palar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though tried and found fit, yet we see 
Many differ before duty.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Position corrupts even the men of our own deliberate choice.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Even when tests of every kind are multiplied,
Full many a man proves otherwise, aby action tried!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though tested fully in simulated settings, many men function differently under working conditions.
Various Translators:
Put into many tests, they pass.
Yet when subjected to different tasks, many fail.
Dinamalar: Even when (a king) has tried them in every possible way, there are many men who change, from the nature of the works (in which they may be employed).

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Where knowledge and diligence are
required, Don't entrust tasks on personal loyalty.
Transliteration: Assign the task to those who know it, can plan, execute and get it done; and not to the most prominent, or likeable, person.
T.Kannan: Let worth prevail. Let not blind affection dictate the choice of men.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Arindhaatrich Cheykirpaarku Allaal
Vinaidhaan
Sirandhaanendru Evarpaar Randru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Wise able men with power invest 
Not by fondness but by hard test.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No specious fav'rite should the king's commision bear,
But he that knows, and work performs with patient care.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Work should be entrusted to men based on their knowledge and diligence and not merely on bonds of affection.
Various Translators: (A king's) work can only be accomplished by a man of wisdom and patient endurance; it is not of a nature to be given to one from mere personal attachment.
Dinamalar:
Where knowledge and diligence are required,
Don't entrust tasks on personal loyalty.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The thing to be done, the proper person for it and the appropriate time for doing it, must all be duly weighed.
Transliteration:
Weigh well the agent, the task And the
time before you act.
T.Kannan: Assign a task after assessing the person, the task and the most suited time.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seyvaanai Naati Vinainaatik
Kaalaththotu
Eydha Unarndhu Seyal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Discern the agent and the deed 
And just in proper time proceed.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let king first ask, 'Who shall the deed perform?' and 'What the deed?'
Of hour befitting both assured, let every work proceed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Consider the work, choose the workman, calculate the timing with care, then commence.
Various Translators: Let (a king) act, after having considered the agent (whom he is to employ), the deed (he desires to do), and the time which is suitable to it.
Dinamalar:
Weigh well the agent, the task
And the time before you act.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Let the king be first convinced of the competency of a person; then he shall allow him to move freely in the sphere of his appointed task.
Transliteration:
Assured this man will do this task this
way, Leave it to him.
T.Kannan: This task. he can do, using these resources : once you reason it out thus, leave the task to him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ithanai Ithanaal Ivanmutikkum
Endraaindhu
Adhanai Avankan Vital
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
This work, by this, this man can do 
Like this entrust the duty due.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
This man, this work shall thus work out,' let thoughtful king command;
Then leave the matter wholly in his servant's hand.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: After having considered, "this man can accomplish this, by these means", let (the king) leave with him the discharge of that duty.
Various Translators: Having decided, “This man is qualified to do this work in this way,” leave him alone to perform it.
Dinamalar:
Assured this man will do this task this way,
Leave it to him.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Choose men of approved merit and then make them worthy of the station.
Transliteration:
After ascertaining what work befits a man,
Assign him the responsibility.
T.Kannan: After figuring out who should own a task, equip and empower him to get the task done.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Vinaik Kurimai Naatiya Pindrai
AvanaiAdharkuriya Naakach Cheyal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
His fitness for the duty scan 
Leave him to do the best he can.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Having considered what work a man is fit for, let (the king) employ him in that work.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As each man's special aptitude is known,
Bid each man make that special work his own.
Various Translators: After ascertaining what work befits a man, assign him to a fitting function.
Dinamalar:
After ascertaining what work befits a man,
Assign him the responsibility.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Fortune deserts him who doubts
The liberties taken by a devout worker.
Transliteration:
Fortune deserts him who doubts The
liberties taken by a devout worker.
T.Kannan: Wealth will desert the leader who doubts the intimacy of the expert doing a task on account of the task.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Prosperity will leave (the king) who doubts the friendship of the man who steadily labours in the discharge of his duties.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vinaikkan Vinaiyutaiyaan Kenmaive
Raaka
Ninaippaanai Neengum Thiru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who do duty for duty's sake
Doubt them; and fortune departs quick.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Fortune deserts the king who ill can bear,
Informal friendly ways of men his toils who share.
Various Translators: Wealth withdraws from the man who refuses to acknowledge the informal friendliness his workers wish to share with him.
Dinamalar: Prosperity deserts one who suspects the motives of a servant ever loyal to his work.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nothing goes wrong in the state of a king
Who often checks his officials for any wrong.
Transliteration: Let a king daily examine the conduct of his servants; if they do not act crookedly, the world will not act crookedly.
T.Kannan:
Nothing goes wrong in the state of a king
Who often checks his officials for any wrong.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The ruler should review progress regularly. as long as his officials don’t falter, his state won’t falter.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
520 Naatorum Naatuka Mannan
VinaiseyvaanKotaamai Kotaa Thulaku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Worker straight the world is straight
The king must look to this aright.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Let king search out his servants'deeds each day;
When these do right, the world goes rightly on its way.
Various Translators: The king should scrutinize his staff’s conduct daily. If they do not go astray, the world will not go astray.
Dinamalar: Let them not swerve from the right path; for on them rests the just conduct of the world.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Only the kindred, because of their old contact,
Show attachment even in adversity.
Transliteration: Even when (a man's) property is all gone, relatives will act towards him with their accustomed (kindness).
T.Kannan:
Only the kindred, because of their old
contact, Show attachment even in adversity.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even when all wealth is lost, it is the kin who will maintain their ties.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Patratra Kannum Pazhaimaipaa
Raattudhal
Sutraththaar Kanne Ula
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let fortunes go; yet kinsmen know
The old accustomed love to show.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When wealth is fled, old kindness still to show,
Is kindly grace that only kinsmen know.
Various Translators: It is one’s own kith and kin that cherish their old attachments to men out of suit with fortune.
Dinamalar: Should a man’s wealth disappear, only his kinsmen will maintain their customary kindness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When kindred show unfailing love,
Wealth of all kinds never fail to flow.
Transliteration: If (a man's) relatives remain attached to him with unchanging love, it will be a source of ever-increasing wealth.
T.Kannan:
When kindred show unfailing love, Wealth
of all kinds never fail to flow.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If one gets kin who never lose their love, wealth never ceases sprouting in different ways.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Virupparaach Chutram Iyaiyin
Arupparaa
Aakkam Palavum Tharum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The gift of loving Kins bestows
Fadeless fortune's fresh flowers.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: One’s unceasing kinship is the source of all one’s fortune.
Various Translators:
The gift of kin's unfailing love bestows
Much gain of good , like flower that fadeless blows.
Dinamalar: If a man’s kindred cling to him with unfailing love, his fortunes will never fail to flourish.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Pursuing a happy life without mixing with one’s clan is like flooding a pond that has flimsy banks.
Transliteration: The wealth of one who does not mingle freely with his relatives, will be like the filling of water in a spacious tank that has no banks.
T.Kannan:
The life of an unattached man
Is like a boundless pond flowing unbound.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The life of an unattached man Is like a
boundless pond flowing unbound.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The life of one with no intimate relationship, is like water flowing into a pond with no bounds.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The life of one with no kin will be like overflowing waters of a tank with no bund.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Alavalaa Villaadhaan Vaazhkkai
Kulavalaak
Kotindri Neernirain Thatru
Various Translators:
A kinless wealth is like a tank 
Which overflows without a bank.
Dinamalar:
His joy of life who mingles not with kinsmen gathered round,
Is lake where streams pour in, with no encircling bound.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The real profit gained by gaining riches is that one may then live surrounded by relatives.
Transliteration: To live surrounded by relatives, is the advantage to be derived from the acquisition of wealth.
T.Kannan:
To be circled by circles of kin is the benefit
One gains by gaining wealth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The value of one’s wealth consists in a life surrounded by one’s kinsmen.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To be circled by circles of kin is the
benefit One gains by gaining wealth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To live surrounded by the kin, is the benefit gained by gaining wealth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Sutraththaal Sutrap Pataozhukal
Selvandhaan
Petraththaal Petra Payan
Various Translators:
The fruit of growing wealth is gained 
When kith and kin are happy found.
Dinamalar:
The profit gained by wealth's increase,
Is living compassed round by relatives in peace.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who knows the use of pleasant words, and liberal gifts can give,
Connections, heaps of them, surroundings him shall live.
Transliteration: He will be surrounded by numerous relatives who manifests generosity and affability.
T.Kannan: Scores of kin will crowd around the kindly man who gives generously and speaks sweetly.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Generosity and sweet words enable a man
To be circled by circles of kin.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: One delights in the company of one generous of heart and suave of speech.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Generosity and sweet words enable a man To
be circled by circles of kin.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: One who practices generosity and kind words, will be encircled by an extended family.
Various Translators:
Kotuththalum Insolum Aatrin Atukkiya
Sutraththaal Sutrap Patum
Dinamalar:
Loving words and liberal hand 
Encircle kith and kin around.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: No one, in all the world, will have so many relatives (about him), as he who makes large gift, and does not give way to anger.
Transliteration:
Than one who gifts bestows and wrath restrains,
Through the wide world none larger following gains.
T.Kannan: In this wide world none enjoys a more faithful family than he who hands out large gifts and holds back all anger.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
None in this world has a larger kinship than he
Who is liberal and curbs his wrath.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Nothing excels on earth the love of one large of heart and free of wrath, but shares it with the rest.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
None in this world has a larger kinship
than he Who is liberal and curbs his wrath.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He gives generously and is free of anger. none on this earth can have better kin than him.
Various Translators:
Perungotaiyaan Penaan Vekuli Avanin
Marungutaiyaar Maanilaththu Il
Dinamalar:
Large giver and wrathless man 
Commands on earth countless kinsmen.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The crows hide not; thy call and eat 
Welfare abides a man of heart.
Transliteration:
The crows conceal not, call their friends to come, then eat;
Increase of good such worthy ones shall meet.
T.Kannan: The crow does not conceal his food, but calls his kind to share it; prosperity will remain with men of such a nature.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Fortune smiles on one of like disposition.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Crows trumpet their finds and share them.
Prosperity also abides with such men.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Crows trumpet their finds and share them.
Prosperity also abides with such men.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The crow never conceals food but cries out for company; wealth and progress too stays only with those of such quality.
Various Translators: The crows do not conceal (their prey), but will call out for others (to share with them) while they eat it; wealth will be with those who show a similar disposition (towards their relatives).
Dinamalar:
Kaakkai Karavaa Karaindhunnum
Aakkamum
Annanee Raarkke Ula

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Podhunokkaan Vendhan Varisaiyaa
Nokkin
Adhunokki Vaazhvaar Palar
Transliteration:
From public gaze when kings perceive 
Each one's merits so many thrive.
T.Kannan:
Where 'king regards not all alike, but each in his degree,
'Neath such discerning rule many dwell happily.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The multitudes thrive when they observe their monarch observing each one’s merits, not seeing mere sameness in all.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The king must not be indifferent to one’s deserts but reward people according to their merit.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Many thrive seeing a king who sees case by case,
Not seeing mere sameness in all.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Many relatives will live near a king, when they observe that he does not look on all alike, but that he looks on each man according to his merit.
Various Translators:
Many thrive seeing a king who sees case by
case, Not seeing mere sameness in all.
Dinamalar: A king who avoids an undifferentiated approach but tailors it to suit differing capabilities, will retain many who will appreciate it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Well-wishers who had broken with you before, will return if the cause for resentment is rectified.
Transliteration:
Thamaraakik Thatrurandhaar Sutram
Amaraamaik
Kaaranam Indri Varum
T.Kannan:
Forsaken friends will come and stay 
When cause for discord goes away.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who once were his, and then forsook him, as before
Will come around, when cause of disagreement is no more.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Reject none on the score of disagreement. Men who have become estranged will flock to you.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Close kinsmen who have become estranged will come back when the cause of disagreement goes away.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Associates who left will return,
Once the cause of dissociation is removed.
Various Translators: Those who have been friends and have afterwards forsaken him, will return and join themselves (to him), when the cause of disagreement is not to be found in him.
Dinamalar:
Associates who left will return, Once the
cause of dissociation is removed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The king should ascertain the motive of
the deserters Who wish to come back.
Transliteration: When defectors return for any reason, the ruler should be open to accept them, after due assessment.
T.Kannan:
Uzhaippirindhu Kaaranaththin Vandhaanai
Vendhan
IzhaithThirundhu Ennik Kolal
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who leaves and returns with motive 
The king should test him and receive.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let the king embrace his estranged kith and kin by redressing their grievances.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who causeless went away , then to return, for any cause, ask, leave;
The king should sift their motives well, consider and receive!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When one who left him returns with justifying reason, the ruler may, after careful reflection, accept him back.
Various Translators:
The king should ascertain the motive of the deserters
Who wish to come back.
Dinamalar: When one may have left him, and for some cause has returned to him, let the king fulfil the object (for which he has come back) and thoughtfully receive him again.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Worse than too much wrath is the laxity
Due to too much exultation.
Transliteration: Getting slack and smug when relishing a joyous moment is more harmful than excessive anger.
T.Kannan: Forgetfulness which cometh of mad joy is more dangerous than wild wrath.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Irandha Vekuliyin Theedhe Sirandha
Uvakai Makizhchchiyir Sorvu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Worse than wrath in excess is 
Forgetfulness in joy excess.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Tis greater ill, if rapture of o'erweening gladness to the soul,
Bring self forgetfulness, than if transcendent wrath control.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Excessive anger’s harm is exceeded by excessive merriment’s mindless mishaps.
Various Translators: More evil than excessive anger, is forgetfulness which springs from the intoxication of great joy.
Dinamalar:
Worse than too much wrath is the laxity
Due to too much exultation.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Poverty freezes knowledge. Forgetfulness blights one’s reputation.
Transliteration:
Just as constant want crushes the
intellect, Negligence kills repute.
T.Kannan: Complacence, sloth and contempt slaughter one’s reputation just as begging and gorging will kill one’s wisdom.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pochchaappuk Kollum Pukazhai
Arivinai
Nichcha NirappukKon Raangu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Negligence kills renown just as 
Ceaseless want wisdom destroys.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Perpetual poverty is death to wisdom of the wise;
When man forgets himself his glory dies!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Just as perpetual poverty slowly nullifies one’s knowledge, so frequent forgetfulness destroys one’s prestige.
Various Translators: Forgetfulness will destroy fame, even as constant poverty destroys knowledge.
Dinamalar:
Just as constant want crushes the intellect,
Negligence kills repute.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Fame is not for the thoughtless, so say the scriptures of the world.
Transliteration:
All writings of the world conclude the
same That fame is not for the lax.
T.Kannan: There is no fame for those who are smug, lax or derisive : scholars of all walks and beliefs concur on this.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pochchaappaark Killai Pukazhmai
Adhuulakaththu
Eppaalnoo Lorkkum Thunivu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Forgetful nature fails of fame 
All schools of thinkers say the same.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To self oblivious men no praise'; this rule
Decisive wisdom sums of every school.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Thoughtlessness will never acquire fame; and this tenet is upheld by all treatises in the world.
Various Translators: Unmindful men will never know renown. This is the verdict of every virtuous text in the world.
Dinamalar:
All writings of the world conclude the same
That fame is not for the lax.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Of what avail is a citadel to a crown, what good availeth the thoughtless.
Transliteration:
There is no refuge for the coward, Nor is
there anything good for the lax.
T.Kannan: No fortress is good enough for those who’ve fear; no good can occur to those who are smug, slack or derisive.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Achcha Mutaiyaarkku Aranillai
Aangillai
Pochchaap Putaiyaarkku Nanku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The fearful find no fortress here 
The forgetful find good never.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Just as the coward has no defence (by whatever fortifications ha may be surrounded), so the thoughtless has no good (whatever advantages he may possess).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To cowards is no fort's defence'; e'en so
The self oblivious men no blessing know.
Various Translators: Nothing will provide defense for the cowardly, and nothing will secure good for the unmindful.
Dinamalar:
There is no refuge for the coward,
Nor is there anything good for the lax.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The negligent unmindful of threats beforehand
Will repent for the mistakes later on.
Transliteration:
The negligent unmindful of threats
beforehand Will repent for the mistakes later on.
T.Kannan: One who is complacent and derisive, and doesn’t anticipate the repercussions, will resent his lapses later.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The thoughtless man, who provides not against the calamities that may happen, will afterwards repent for his fault.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Munnurak Kaavaadhu Izhukkiyaan
Thanpizhai
Pinnooru Irangi Vitum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Failing foresight the guardless man
Shall rue his folly later on.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To him who nought foresees, recks not of anything,
The after woe shall sure repentance bring.
Various Translators: The forgetful man who fails to take precautions against impending perils will regret his negligence afterwards.
Dinamalar: Who is not on his guard against impending evil, rues his folly?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nothing can equal never being lax
With anyone at any time without fail.
Transliteration: There is nothing comparable with the possession of unfailing thoughtfulness at all times; and towards all persons.
T.Kannan:
Nothing can equal never being lax With
anyone at any time without fail.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Never be complacent about any task or deride anyone : nothing is better than following this unswervingly.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Izhukkaamai Yaarmaattum Endrum
Vazhukkaamai
Vaayin Adhuvoppadhu Il
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Forget none; watch with wakeful care 
Miss none; the gain is sans compare.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Towards all unswerving, ever watchfulness of soul retain,
Where this is found there is no greater gain.
Various Translators: Nothing can compare to watchfulness extended unfailingly to all people at all times.
Dinamalar: There is no greater good than to be ever on the vigil.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
There is nothing too difficult for a man
Armed with vigilance.
Transliteration: There is nothing too difficult to be accomplished, if a man set about it carefully, with unflinching endeavour.
T.Kannan:
There is nothing too difficult for a man
Armed with vigilance.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The impossible doesn’t exist when you do the task diligently, with an alert, incomplacent mind.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ariyaendru Aakaadha Illaipoch
Chaavaak
Karuviyaal Potrich Cheyin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
With cautious care pursue a thing 
Impossible there is nothing.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though things are arduous deemed, theer's nought may not be won,
When work with mind's unslumbering energy and thought is done.
Various Translators: Nothing is impossible for the thoughtful.
Dinamalar: There is nothing too difficult for the man who consciously conceives and carefully executes his work.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Cherish and perform praiseworthy acts.
To neglect and put off deprives one in seven births.
Transliteration: Let (a man) observe and do these things which have been praised (by the wise); if he neglects and fails to perform them, for him there will be no (happiness) throughout the seven births.
T.Kannan:
Cherish and perform praiseworthy acts. To
neglect and put off deprives one in seven births.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Do, diligently, deeds that have been extolled; not in seven births will they benefit. those who derisively avoid those deeds.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pukazhndhavai Potrich Cheyalventum
Seyyaadhu
Ikazhndhaarkku Ezhumaiyum Il
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Do what the wise commend as worth 
If not, for seven births no mirth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: No good awaits him in birth to come who fails of his noble deeds.
Various Translators:
Let things that merit praise thy watchful soul employ;
Who these despise attain through sevenfold births no joy.
Dinamalar: One should do that which men extol as praiseworthy. Forgetfully failing to do so brings deprivation lasting seven births.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Whenever the mind is engrossed in pleasant infatuations, one should remember men who were ruined by forgetfulness.
Transliteration: Let (a king) think of those who have been ruined by neglect, when his mind is elated with joy.
T.Kannan:
When the mind is elated with joy,
Think of those who were ruined by neglect.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
When the mind is elated with joy, Think of
those who were ruined by neglect.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Think of those who were doomed due to derision and negligence, when you bask smugly in the glory of your might.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: When drunk with delight, remember those who have perished through wilful neglect.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ikazhchchiyin Kettaarai Ulluka
Thaandham
Makizhchchiyin Maindhurum Pozhdhu
Various Translators:
When joy deludes, their fate recall 
Whom negligence has made to fall.
Dinamalar:
Think on the men whom scornful mind hath brought to nought,
When exultation overwhelms thy wildered thought.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is easy to get what you think of if you can get yourself to think of it.
Transliteration: It is easy for (one) to obtain whatever he may think of, if he can again think of it.
T.Kannan:
What is aimed is easy to achieve,
If only the mind is set on what is aimed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: No task is difficult to the thoughtful and diligent.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What is aimed is easy to achieve, If only
the mind is set on what is aimed.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Easy it is, to get what you seek, if you’re focused on that you seek.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ulliyadhu Eydhal Elidhuman
Matrundhaan
Ulliyadhu Ullap Perin
Various Translators:
Easy it is a thing to get 
When the mind on it is set.
Dinamalar:
Tis easy what thou hast in mind to gain,
If what thou hast in mind thy mind retain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Search out, to no one favour show, with heart that justice loves
Consult,then act; this is the rule that right approves.
Transliteration: To examine into (the crimes which may be committed), to show no favour (to any one), to desire to act with impartiality towards all, and to inflict (such punishments) as may be wisely resolved on, constitute rectitude.
T.Kannan: Investigate well, show favor to none, maintain impartiality, consult the law, then give judgment—that is the way of justice.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The way is to launch an enquiry, investigate with impartiality,
And dispense as per norms.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Strict enquiry and impartial justice mark the rule of a just monarch.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The way is to launch an enquiry,
investigate with impartiality, And dispense as per
norms.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Investigating intensely, leading fairly without unduly favoring anyone, analysing and acting, constitute justice.
Various Translators:
Orndhukan Notaadhu Iraipurindhu
Yaarmaattum
Therndhusey Vaqdhe Murai
Dinamalar:
Test and attest impartially
Consult and act the laws justly.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When there is rain, the living creation thrives; and so when the king rules justly, his subjects thrive.
Transliteration:
All earth looks up to heav'n whence raindrops fall;
All subjects looks to king that ruleth all.
T.Kannan: All the world looks to the rain cloud for sustenance. All the people look to the king’s scepter for protection.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
All the world looks up to heaven for rain
And the subjects to their king for justice.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The world looks to rain for its existence. The subjects look to the sceptre for their existence.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
All the world looks up to heaven for rain
And the subjects to their king for justice.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The world survives, looking up to the skies for rain; the people live, looking up to their ruler’s sceptre for justice.
Various Translators:
Vaanokki Vaazhum Ulakellaam Mannavan
KolNokki Vaazhung Kuti
Dinamalar:
The earth looks up to sky and thrives 
And mankind to king's rod of justice.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The Sage's scripture and virtue spring 
From the sceptre of a stately king.
Transliteration:
Learning and virtue of the sages spring,
From all controlling sceptre of the king.
T.Kannan: Even the Vedas of the brahmins and all dharma therein rely on the sovereign’s sturdy staff for sustenance.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The king’s sceptre is the standing proof of Brahminical books and their teachings.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The scepter of the king furnishes the basic support
To virtue and scriptures.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The scepter of the king furnishes the
basic support To virtue and scriptures.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The scriptures that scholars write and the virtues they extol, have their roots in the sceptre of the ruler.
Various Translators: The sceptre of the king is the firm support of the Vedas of the Brahmin, and of all virtues therein described.
Dinamalar:
Andhanar Noorkum Araththirkum
Aadhiyaai
Nindradhu Mannavan Kol

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Kutidhazheeik Kolochchum Maanila
Mannan
Atidhazheei Nirkum Ulaku
Transliteration:
The world clings to the ruler's feet
Whose sceptre clasps the people's heart.
T.Kannan:
Whose heart embraces subjects all, lord over mighty land
Who rules, the world his feet embracing stands.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The world embraces the feet of a great kingdom’s monarch who lovingly embraces subjects under his justice wielding scepter.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The world falls at the feet of a great King who wields the sceptre for his subjects’ welfare.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A great kingdom's monarch who rules embracing his subjects
Has the world embrace his feet.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The world will constantly embrace the feet of the great king who rules over his subjects with love.
Various Translators:
A great kingdom's monarch who rules
embracing his subjects Has the world embrace his feet.
Dinamalar: The world will embrace the feet of the ruler, who embraces his people and renders justice.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: In the state of the king who rules justly, as befits a king, even monsoons and harvests will happen unfailingly.
Transliteration:
Iyalpulik Kolochchum Mannavan Naatta
Peyalum Vilaiyulum Thokku
T.Kannan:
Full rains and yields enrich the land 
Which is ruled by a righteous hand.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Were king, who righteous laws regards, the sceptre wields,
There fall the showers ,there rich abundance crowns the fields.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Both seasonal rains and waving corn are seen in the land of a righteous monarch.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Rain and rich harvests arise together in a country whose sovereign ruler raises his rod lawfully.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The king who rules according to the law
Never lacks rain and corn.
Various Translators: Rain and plentiful crops will ever dwell together in the country of the king who sways his sceptre with justice.
Dinamalar:
The king who rules according to the law
Never lacks rain and corn.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Not his spear but a straight scepter Is
what gives a monarch his triumph.
Transliteration: It is not the spear that gives victory; it is the king’s sceptre, the one that never tilts unjustly.
T.Kannan:
Velandru Vendri Tharuvadhu Mannavan
Koladhooung Kotaa Thenin
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Not the spear but the sceptre straight 
That brings success to monarch's might.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Victory is won not by the spear but by the unswerving sceptre of a monarch.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Not lance gives kings the victory,
But sceptre swayed with equity.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Victory is not won by the lance, but by the king’s scepter, provided it is not crooked.
Various Translators:
Not his spear but a straight scepter
Is what gives a monarch his triumph.
Dinamalar: It is not the javelin that gives victory, but the king's sceptre, if it do no injustice.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The king guards all the land, and his own
rule Will guard him if he is straight.
Transliteration: A king protects all the world; he is protected by the justice that he dispenses resolutely.
T.Kannan: The king protects the whole world and justice protects him if unfailingly admonished.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Iraikaakkum Vaiyakam Ellaam Avanai
Muraikaakkum Muttaach Cheyin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The king protects the entire earth 
And justice protects his royal worth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The king all the whole realm of earth protects;
And justice guards the king who right respects.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The potentate protects the whole world, and Justice protects him if he does not stray from Her.
Various Translators: The king defends the whole world; and justice, when administered without defect, defends the king.
Dinamalar:
The king guards all the land, and his own rule
Will guard him if he is straight.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The king who does not administer impartial justice goes to ruin.
Transliteration:
An indifferent unjust king beyond the
reach of his subjects Will sink beyond and perish.
T.Kannan: A king who isn’t readily accessible and doesn’t rule justly, will be ruined by his own lowly deeds.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Enpadhaththaan Oraa Muraiseyyaa
Mannavan
Thanpadhaththaan Thaane Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Hard of access, the unjust king 
He shall himself his ruin bring.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Hard of access, nought searching out, with partial hand
The king who rules, shall sink and perish from the land.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: An inaccessible ruler who listens and adjudicates inattentively will inevitably plummet from power and perish.
Various Translators: The king who gives not facile audience (to those who approach him), and who does not examine and pass judgment (on their complaints), will perish in disgrace.
Dinamalar:
An indifferent unjust king beyond the reach of his subjects
Will sink beyond and perish.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To punish crime is the duty, not the fault of the king who attends to the welfare of his subjects.
Transliteration:
For a king who would guard and cherish his
people, To punish crimes is a duty, not defect.
T.Kannan: To punish a crime, in order to protect and nurture one’s subjects, is not a blot on the king but his duty.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kutipurang Kaaththompik Kutram
Katidhal
Vatuvandru Vendhan Thozhil
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Save his subjects and chide the wrong 
Is flawless duty of a king.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Abroad to guard, at home to punish, brings
No just reproach; 'tis work assigned to kings.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: In guarding his subjects (against injury from others), and in preserving them himself; to punish crime is not a fault in a king, but a duty.
Various Translators: No fault befalls a king who, in guarding and caring for his subjects, punishes wrongdoers—for that is his duty.
Dinamalar:
For a king who would guard and cherish his people,
To punish crimes is a duty, not defect.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Punishing murderers with death is like plucking out weeds among the crops.
Transliteration:
A king punishing criminals by execution Is
like a farmer removing weeds from his fields.
T.Kannan: The king punishing, severely, those brutal murderers, is akin to clearing weeds from the crop.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kolaiyir Kotiyaarai Vendhoruththal
Paingoozh
Kalaikat Tadhanotu Ner
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Killing killers, the king, behold 
Weeds removes from cropful field.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: For a king to punish criminals with death, is like pulling up the weeds in the green corn.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
By punishment of death the cruel to restrain,
Is as when farmer frees from weeds the tender grain.
Various Translators: A ruler’s punishing cruel criminals by execution is like a gardener’s removing weeds from his garden.
Dinamalar:
A king punishing criminals by execution
Is like a farmer removing weeds from his fields.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
More malicious than a murderer is the king
Who rules with injustice and oppression.
Transliteration:
More malicious than a murderer is the king
Who rules with injustice and oppression.
T.Kannan: He is worse than assassins, the ruler who harries his citizens, and indulges in unjust acts.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The king who gives himself up to oppression and acts unjustly (towards his subjects) is more cruel than the man who leads the life of a murderer.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kolaimerkon Taarir Kotidhe
Alaimerkontu
Allavai Seydhozhukum Vendhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The unjust tyrant oppressor 
Is worse than cruel murderer.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Than one who plies the murderer's trade, more cruel is the king
who all injustice works, his subjects harassing.
Various Translators: More malicious than a professional murderer is the monarch who rules his people with injustice and oppression.
Dinamalar: The unrighteous king who oppresses his subjects is more cruel than the one who leads the life of a murderer.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A tyrant taxing his subjects
Is like an armed dacoit extorting money.
Transliteration: The request (for money) of him who holds the sceptre is like the word of a highway robber who stands with a weapon in hand and says "give up your wealth".
T.Kannan:
A tyrant taxing his subjects Is like an
armed dacoit extorting money.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The extortion and graft done wielding the sceptre is no different from robbery done pointing a spear.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Velotu Nindraan Ituven Radhupolum
Kolotu Nindraan Iravu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Sceptered tyrant exacting gold 
Is "give" of lanced robber bold.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As 'Give' the robber cries with lance uplift,
So kings with sceptred hand implore a gift.
Various Translators: A scepter wielding king requesting a gift is like a lance bearing robber demanding, “Give me all you have.”
Dinamalar: The wielder of the sceptre asking for gifts, is like the spearman asking the way-farer ‘give.’

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A king who fails in his day today affairs
Loses his kingdom day by day.
Transliteration: The country of the king who does not daily examine into the wrongs done and distribute justice, will daily fall to ruin.
T.Kannan:
A king who fails in his day today affairs
Loses his kingdom day by day.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The ruler who doesn’t assess and administer justly, day after day, will let his state rot day by day.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Naatorum Naati Muraiseyyaa Mannavan
Naatorum Naatu Ketum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Spy wrongs daily and do justice 
Or day by day the realm decays.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who makes no daily search for wrongs, nor justly rules, that king
Doth day by day his realm to ruin bring.
Various Translators: That country will perish any day whose monarch does not administer justice day by day.
Dinamalar: Day to day the king must seek out and punish unlawfulness, or day by day his country will plummet toward ruin.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A thoughtless king who abuses his scepter
Will lose at once his wealth and subjects.
Transliteration: The king, who, without reflecting (on its evil consequences), perverts justice, will lose at once both his wealth and his subjects.
T.Kannan:
A thoughtless king who abuses his scepter
Will lose at once his wealth and subjects.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The king who lets his sceptre tilt towards tyranny will lose all his wealth, people and state.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Koozhung Kutiyum Orungizhakkum
Kolkotich
Choozhaadhu Seyyum Arasu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The king shall wealth and subjects lose 
If his sceptre he dares abuse.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: That king who allows his sceptre to bend indiscriminately will lose his wealth together with his subjects.
Various Translators:
Whose rod from right deflects, who counsel doth refuse,
At once his wealth and people utterly shall lose.
Dinamalar: Without thinking, a king rules crookedly, and thus forfeits his subjects’ loyalty, together with his own fortune.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Are not the tears of a people who cannot bear their monarch’s oppressive reign the force that erodes his prosperity?
Transliteration: Will not the tears, shed by a people who cannot endure the oppression which they suffer (from their king), become a saw to waste away his wealth ?
T.Kannan:
It is the tears of those groaning under oppression
That wear out the prosperity of the king.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
It is the tears of those groaning under
oppression That wear out the prosperity of the king.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The tears shed by citizens subjected to intolerable grief are the weapons that erode the rulers’ wealth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Are not the tears, shed as a result of oppression, the weapons which destroy the prosperity of the monarch?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Allarpattu Aatraadhu Azhudhakan
Neerandre
Selvaththaith Theykkum Patai
Various Translators:
Groaning tears caused by tyrant's sway
File the royal wealth away.
Dinamalar:
His people's tears of sorrow past endurance , are not they
Sharp instruments to wear the monarch's wealth away?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Ruling rightly, a monarch may long endure. Without that, his majesty is rightfully unenduring.
Transliteration: Righteous government gives permanence to (the fame of) kings; without that their fame will have no endurance.
T.Kannan:
Just rule stabilizes a king.
Lacking it his glory fades.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Good Government makes one’s rule enduring. Where it is not found, his lustre will not last long?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Just rule stabilizes a king. Lacking it
his glory fades.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Just rule yields lasting fame to a ruler; no justice, no fame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Mannarkku Mannudhal Sengonmai
Aqdhindrel
Mannaavaam Mannark Koli
Various Translators:
Glory endures by sceptre right
Without it wanes the royal light.
Dinamalar:
To rulers' rule stability is sceptre right;
When this is not, quenched is the rulers' light.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
As lack of rain to thirsty lands beneath,
Is lack of grace in kings to all that breathe.
Transliteration: As is the world without rain, so live a people whose king is without kindness.
T.Kannan: As the Earth fares under a rainless sky, so do a people languish under an unkind king.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
How fares the earth without rain?
So fares life under a ruthless king.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The people who live under a graceless king suffer like the earth unvisited by drops of rain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
How fares the earth without rain? So fares
life under a ruthless king.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Just as lack of rain is to the world, so is to mankind. rulers’ lack of benevolence.
Various Translators:
Thuliyinmai Gnaalaththirku Etratre
Vendhan
Aliyinmai Vaazhum Uyirkku
Dinamalar:
Dry like the earth without rainfall 
Is graceless king to creatures all.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Property gives more sorrow than poverty, to those who live under the sceptre of a king without justice.
Transliteration:
To poverty it adds a sharper sting,
To live beneath the sway of unjust king.
T.Kannan: Possessions hold less pleasure than poverty for oppressed subjects living under an unjust king.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Possessions are worse than poverty
Under the scepter of an unjust king.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Where people possess a king, who does not enforce justice, wealth does not confer more happiness than poverty.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Possessions are worse than poverty Under
the scepter of an unjust king.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Being wealthy is worse than being poor, under an unjust ruler.
Various Translators:
Inmaiyin Innaadhu Utaimai
Muraiseyyaa
Mannavan Korkeezhp Patin
Dinamalar:
To have is worse than having not 
If ruler is unjust despot.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The sky withdraws season's shower
If the king misuses his power.
Transliteration:
Where king from right deflecting, makes unrighteous gain,
The seasons change, the clouds pour down no rain.
T.Kannan: If the king acts contrary to justice, contrary seasons will befall the land and rain laden clouds will fail to come forth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Were the king to rule unjustly, the Heavens would withhold rains?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If a king acts contrary to justice,
Monsoons fail and clouds shed no rain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If a king acts contrary to justice,
Monsoons fail and clouds shed no rain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If the king lets his sceptre of justice waver, the skies won’t yield and monsoons will fail.
Various Translators: If the king acts contrary to justice, rain will become unseasonable, and the heavens will withhold their showers.
Dinamalar:
Muraikoti Mannavan Seyyin Uraikoti
Ollaadhu Vaanam Peyal

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Aapayan Kundrum Arudhozhilor
Noolmarappar
Kaavalan Kaavaan Enin
Transliteration:
The <sup>*</sup>six functioned forget their lore 
Cows give less if kings guard no more.
T.Kannan:
Where guardian guardeth not, udder of kine grows dry,
And Brahmans' Sacred lore will all forgoten lie.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If the people’s protector fails to protect brahmins will forget the Vedas and cows’ milk will dry up.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If the protecting monarch fails in his duties, the yield of cows will diminish and Brahmans with their six duties will forget their Vedas.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
