Cows yield less and priests forget their hymns
If the protector fails to protect.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If the guardian (of the country) neglects to guard it, the produce of the cows will fail, and the men of six duties viz., the Brahmins will forget the vedas.
Various Translators:
Cows yield less and priests forget their
hymns If the protector fails to protect.
Dinamalar: The cows’ milk will dry up; the brahmans will forget the scriptures; when the king stops being their saviour.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Investigating neutrally, and punishing appropriately, so as to deter the repeat of a crime, is the duty of the king.
Transliteration:
Thakkaangu Naatith Thalaichchellaa
Vannaththaal
Oththaangu Oruppadhu Vendhu
T.Kannan:
A king enquires and gives sentence
Just to prevent future offence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who punishes, investigation made in due degree,
So as to stay advance of crime, a king is he.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A righteous king investigates and fittingly punishes the wrongdoer so that he may not repeat it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He is a true king who impartially investigates and then duly punishes so that the offense will not recur.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Call him king who probes and whose punishment
Is deterrent and proportionate.
Various Translators: He is a king who having equitably examined (any injustice which has been brought to his notice), suitably punishes it, so that it may not be again committed.
Dinamalar:
Call him king who probes and whose
punishment Is deterrent and proportionate.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Raise your hand forcibly but bring it
lightly To have a lasting effect.
Transliteration: Raise the sceptre swift and stern, but land it softly, those who wish never to lose what they possess.
T.Kannan:
Katidhochchi Mella Erika
Netidhaakkam
Neengaamai Ventu Pavar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Wield fast the rod but gently lay
This strict mildness prolongs the sway.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If you wish enduring prosperity behave as if you punish excessively, but do it mildly.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
For length of days with still increasing joys on Heav'n who call,
Should raise the rod with brow severe, but let it gently fall.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He who wishes his prosperity to long remain will raise the rod severely, but let it fall softly.
Various Translators:
Raise your hand forcibly but bring it lightly
To have a lasting effect.
Dinamalar: Let the king, who desires that his prosperity may long remain, commence his preliminary enquires wi th strictness, and then punish with mildness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A dictator causing oppression Will have a
speedy and certain end.
Transliteration: A king will be isolated and will face rapid ruin, if he becomes a tyrant indulging in terrifying deeds.
T.Kannan: The tyrant who terrifies his subjects will soon perish.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Veruvandha Seydhozhukum Vengola
Naayin
Oruvandham Ollaik Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
His cruel rod of dreadful deed 
Brings king's ruin quick indeed.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Where subjects dread of cruel wrongs endure,
Ruin to unjust king is swift and sure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The tyrant who causes dread in his people will perish quickly and inevitably.
Various Translators: The cruel-sceptred king, who acts so as to put his subjects in fear, will certainly and quickly come to ruin.
Dinamalar:
A dictator causing oppression
Will have a speedy and certain end.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: That king whom people speak of as a tyrant will rapidly perish.
Transliteration:
When a king is decried a tyrant, His life
is shortened and end becomes imminent.
T.Kannan: My king. he is a tyrant : such a denouncement is certain to hasten a king’s downfall.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Iraikatiyan Endruraikkum Innaachchol
Vendhan
Uraikatuki Ollaik Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
As men the king a tyrant call 
His days dwindled, hasten his fall.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Ah! cruel is our king', where subjects sadly say,
His age shall dwindle, swift his joy of life decay.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: “Our king is cruel.” When these bitter words are spoken, the monarch’s life is shortened, and he soon succumbs.
Various Translators: The king who is spoken of as cruel will quickly perish; his life becoming shortened.
Dinamalar:
When a king is decried a tyrant,
His life is shortened and end becomes imminent.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The great wealth of a king who is inaccessible and assumes a fearful look, is no better than in the possession of a demon.
Transliteration:
The great wealth of one inaccessible and
sour-faced Is no better than a demon's.
T.Kannan: Inaccessible and has a harsh countenance. his huge wealth resembles a treasure protected by demons.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Arunjevvi Innaa Mukaththaan
Perunjelvam
Peeykan Tannadhu Utaiththu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Whose sight is scarce, whose face is foul 
His wealth seems watched by a ghoul.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Whom subjects scarce may see, of harsh forbidding countenance;
His ample wealth shall waste, blasted by demon's glance.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The great wealth of him who is difficult of access and possesses a sternness of countenance, is like that which has been obtained by a devil.
Various Translators: If a man’s countenance is harsh and access to him is hard, his wealth, however vast, might as well belong to a demon.
Dinamalar:
The great wealth of one inaccessible and sour-faced
Is no better than a demon's.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The abundant wealth of a king who utters harsh words and puts on unkind looks will not last long.
Transliteration:
If he is unkind and speaks harsh, His
lofty wealth ends there without lasting long.
T.Kannan: If he is of harsh words, and has no compassion, his extensive wealth will become extinct soon.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Katunjollan Kannilan Aayin
Netunjelvam
Neetindri Aange Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Whose word is harsh, whose sight is rude 
His wealth and power quickly fade.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The abundant wealth of the king whose words are harsh and whose looks are void of kindness, will instantly perish instead of abiding long, with him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The tyrant, harsh in speach and hard of eye.
His ample joy, swift fading, soon shall die.
Various Translators: If a man is unkind and speaks cruelly, his vast wealth will not last long before perishing.
Dinamalar:
If he is unkind and speaks harsh,
His lofty wealth ends there without lasting long.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Harsh words and excessive punishments
Are files that grind down a king's might.
Transliteration:
Harsh words and excessive punishments Are
files that grind down a king's might.
T.Kannan: Harsh words and excessive punishments form the saw that files away the king’s military might.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Severe words and excessive punishments will be a file to waste away a king's power for destroying (his enemies).
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Katumozhiyum Kaiyikandha Thantamum
Vendhan
Atumuran Theykkum Aram
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Reproofs rough and punishments rude 
Like files conquering power corrode.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Harsh words and punishments severe beyond the right,
Are file that wears away the monarch's conquering might.
Various Translators: Harsh language and overly severe punishment, like a keen file, grind down a king’s conquering powers.
Dinamalar: Severity in speech and excess in punishment are like the file which removes his capacity to destroy (his enemies).

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The king who rages but not reflect on his counsel,
Will soon see his wealth shrink.
Transliteration: The prosperity of that king will waste away, who without reflecting (on his affairs himself), commits them to his ministers, and (when a failure occurs) gives way to anger, and rages against them.
T.Kannan:
The king who rages but not reflect on his
counsel, Will soon see his wealth shrink.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When the king doesn’t take counsel of his advisers, and tends to explode with rage, his wealth starts imploding.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Inaththaatri Ennaadha Vendhan
Sinaththaatrich
Cheerir Sirukum Thiru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The king who would not take counsels 
Rages with wrath his fortune fails.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who leaves the work to those around, and thinks of it no more;
If he in wrathful mood reprove, his prosperous days are o'er!
Various Translators: A king’s wealth wanes when, without thoughtful involvement, he lets ministers work, then furiously faults their efforts.
Dinamalar: The prosperity of a king who does not consult his advisers but makes them the victims of his fury will shrink.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A king who neglects his defences,
Will die of fright at the time of war.
Transliteration: The king who has not provided himself with a place of defence, will in times of war be seized with fear and quickly perish.
T.Kannan:
A king who neglects his defences, Will die
of fright at the time of war.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When the foes strike, a king who has not built his defences, will fall swiftly, trembling with fear.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Seruvandha Pozhdhir Siraiseyyaa
Vendhan
Veruvandhu Veydhu Ketum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The king who builds not fort betimes 
Fears his foes in wars and dies.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who builds no fort whence he may foe defy,
In time of war shall fear and swiftly die.
Various Translators: If a king who has no fortress meets a foe, he will be ruined by fear.
Dinamalar: The sovereign who does not secure defenses will be seized by fear when wartime comes and promptly perish.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The earth bears no heavier burden
Than a tyrant surrounded by ignorant men.
Transliteration: The earth bears up no greater burden than ignorant men whom a cruel sceptre attaches to itself (as the ministers of its evil deeds).
T.Kannan:
The earth bears no heavier burden Than a
tyrant surrounded by ignorant men.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A tyrant will assemble an ensemble of the unlearned; but for them, there is no burden for the earth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kallaarp Pinikkum Katungol
Adhuvalladhu
Illai Nilakkup Porai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The crushing burden borne by earth 
Is tyrants bound to fools uncouth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: No burden is harder for the earth to bear than the cruel sceptre wielded by the unwise.
Various Translators:
Tyrants with fools their counsels share;
Earth can no heavier burthen bear!
Dinamalar: Earth bears no greater burden than crude counselors that a cruel sceptered king binds to his court.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The fairest graciousness, they say, is a kindly look. Wherever it thrives, the whole world flourishes.
Transliteration: The world exists through that greatest ornament (of princes), a gracious demeanour.
T.Kannan:
What truly moves this world
Is that ravishing beauty called compassion.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What truly moves this world Is that
ravishing beauty called compassion.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: There exists this stupendous beauty called compassion; and therefore, the world exists.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The world exists because of the existence of the most beautiful virtue called kindliness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kannottam Ennum Kazhiperung Kaarikai
Unmaiyaan Untiv Vulaku
Various Translators:
Living in the world implies 
The bounteous dame of benign eyes.
Dinamalar:
Since true benignity, that grace exceeding great, resides
In kingly souls, world in happy state abides.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is compassion that sustains the world’s existence. The existence of those bereft of it is a burden to the Earth.
Transliteration: The prosperity of the world springs from the kindliness, the existence of those who have no (kindliness) is a burden to the earth.
T.Kannan:
Compassion sustains the world.
Without it men are but a burden on earth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The world lives through kindliness; those who do not have it are a burden to the earth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Compassion sustains the world. Without it
men are but a burden on earth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: It is compassion that keeps the world functioning as it should; there are those who lack it, and they burden the earth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kannottath Thulladhu Ulakiyal
Aqdhilaar
Unmai Nilakkup Porai
Various Translators:
World lives by looks of lovely worth
Who lack them are burdens of earth.
Dinamalar:
The world goes on its wonted way, since grace benign is there;
All other men are burthen for the earth to bear.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Where not accordant with the song, what use of sounding chords?
What gain of eye that no benignant light affords?
Transliteration: Of what avail is a song if it be inconsistent with harmony ? what is the use of eyes which possess no kindliness.
T.Kannan: What use is melody in an unmusical song? What use are eyes that express no sympathy?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What use is a rāgā that cannot be sung?
Or eyes without sympathy?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What is the use of a song that could not be enjoyed? Likewise, what is the use of the eyes that have no kindliness?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What use is a rāgā that cannot be sung? Or
eyes without sympathy?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Of what use is a tune that can’t suit any song? of what use are eyes, which have no compassion?
Various Translators:
Panennaam Paatarku Iyaipindrel
Kanennaam
Kannottam Illaadha Kan
Dinamalar:
Of tuneless song what is the use? 
Without gracious looks what are eyes?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Beyond appearing to be in the face, what good do they do, those eyes in which is no well-regulated kindness ?
Transliteration:
The seeming eye to face gives no expressive light,
When not with duly meted kindness bright.
T.Kannan: Other than being facial ornaments, what do eyes with no quality of kindness really do?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What use are eyes that look like eyes
But lack boundless sympathy?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What is the use of one’s eyes if they do not beam with immeasurable love?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What use are eyes that look like eyes But
lack boundless sympathy?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: An eye that is not abound with compassion, what purpose is it serving on the face, feigning existence?
Various Translators:
Ulapol Mukaththevan Seyyum Alavinaal
Kannottam Illaadha Kan
Dinamalar:
Except that they are on the face 
What for are eyes sans measured grace.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Kind looks are jewels for eyes to wear 
Without them they are felt as sore.
Transliteration:
Benignity is eyes ' adorning grace;
Without it eyes' are wounds disfiguring face.
T.Kannan: A compassionate glance is the eyes’ true ornament. Without such kindness, eyes become unsightly sores.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Kindliness is the fitting ornament for the eyes. They are a sore, where it is absent.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Compassion is an ornament of the eyes.
Without it eyes are deemed sores.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Compassion is an ornament of the eyes.
Without it eyes are deemed sores.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Eyes are adorned by compassion; but for it, they would be considered wounds.
Various Translators: Kind looks are the ornaments of the eyes; without these they will be considered (by the wise) to be merely two sores.
Dinamalar:
Kannirku Anikalam Kannottam
Aqdhindrel
Punnendru Unarap Patum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Manno Tiyaindha Maraththanaiyar
Kanno
Tiyaindhukan Notaa Thavar
Transliteration:
Like trees on inert earth they grow 
Who don't eye to eye kindness show.
T.Kannan:
Whose eyes'neath brow infixed diffuse no ray
Of grace; like tree in earth infixed are they.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Eyes that remain unmoved by pity might as well be unmovable tree stumps bound in earth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those whose eyes do not reflect love resemble trees that stand on the earth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Like trees earth-bound which cannot move
Are eyes unmoved by pity.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: They resemble the trees of the earth, who although they have eyes, never look kindly (on others).
Various Translators:
Like trees earth-bound which cannot move
Are eyes unmoved by pity.
Dinamalar: Trees rooted to the land they resemble, those though born with eyes, don’t use them to be compassionate.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who lack compassion have no eyes; who truly have eyes can’t lack compassion.
Transliteration:
Kannottam Illavar Kannilar
Kannutaiyaar
Kannottam Inmaiyum Il
T.Kannan:
Ungracious men lack real eyes
Men of real eyes show benign grace.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Eyeless are they whose eyes with no benignant lustre, shine;
Who've eyes can never lack the light of grace benign.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Verily they are blind who have no kindly look.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those who lack a kindly look are indeed without eyes, and those who truly have eyes never lack a gracious look.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Men without sympathy have no eyes;
Nor those who have eyes lack sympathy.
Various Translators: Men without kind looks are men without eyes; those who (really) have eyes are also not devoid of kind looks.
Dinamalar:
Men without sympathy have no eyes; Nor
those who have eyes lack sympathy.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
This world is theirs who compassionately
perform Their duties without fail.
Transliteration: The world belongs to those who do their duty unfalteringly, while being compassionate.
T.Kannan:
Karumam Sidhaiyaamal Kannota
Vallaarkku
Urimai Utaiththiv Vulaku
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who gracious are but dutiful 
Have right for this earth beautiful.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The world belongs to a king who can do his duty and yet be courteous.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who can benignant smile, yet leave no work undone;
By them as very own may all the earth be won.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: This world belongs to those who, while neglecting no duty, never neglect to behold others benevolently.
Various Translators:
This world is theirs who compassionately perform
Their duties without fail.
Dinamalar: The world is theirs (kings) who are able to show kindness, without injury to their affairs, (administration of justice).

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
That quality of forbearance and sympathy
is the best, Even to those who hurt us.
Transliteration: Being compassionate and patient, even with those who hurt us, is a quality, most admirable.
T.Kannan: It behoves a king to put up with the doer of harm and even be kind to him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Oruththaatrum Panpinaar Kannumkan
Notip
Poruththaatrum Panpe Thalai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To be benign and bear with foes 
Who vex us is true virtue's phase.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To smile on those that vex, with kindly face,
Enduring long, is most excelling grace.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To grant forbearing kindness even to those who aggrieve us is the foremost of virtues.
Various Translators: Patiently to bear with, and show kindness to those who grieve us, is the most excellent of all dispositions.
Dinamalar:
That quality of forbearance and sympathy is the best,
Even to those who hurt us.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who wish to acquire loveable urbanity will knowingly swallow even the poison served.
Transliteration:
Those desirous of refinement will drink
with smile Even hemlock when offered.
T.Kannan: Even after seeing poison being poured, they will consume it and converse cordially, they who seek to be captivatingly civilized and compassionate.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Peyakkantum Nanjun Tamaivar
Nayaththakka
Naakarikam Ventu Pavar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Men of graceful courtesy 
Take hemlock and look cheerfully.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They drink with smiling grace, though poison interfused they see,
Who seek the praise of all esteemed courtesy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Desiring to be gracious above all else, guests may politely accept even poison they watched their host prepare and serve.
Various Translators: Those who desire (to cultivate that degree of) urbanity which all shall love, even after swallowing the poison served to them by their friends, will be friendly with them.
Dinamalar:
Those desirous of refinement will drink with smile
Even hemlock when offered.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Verily the two eyes of a king are espionage and the celebrated code of laws.
Transliteration:
Spies and classics on statecraft: These
two are a king's pair of eyes.
T.Kannan: Intelligence operations and highly regarded books. a king should consider them his eyes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Otrum Uraisaandra Noolum
Ivaiyirantum
Thetrenka Mannavan Kan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A king should treat these two as eyes 
The code of laws and careful spies.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
These two: the code renowned, and spies,
In these let king confide as eyes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Let a king consider as his eyes these two things, a spy and a book (of laws) universally esteemed.
Various Translators: Competent spies and the respected codes of law— consider these two the eyes of a king.
Dinamalar:
Spies and classics on statecraft:
These two are a king's pair of eyes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A king’s duty is to get day to day knowledge of everything that happens.
Transliteration:
A king's job is to know in time everything
That happens to everyone every day.
T.Kannan: Knowing everything that happens to everyone. to always gain such intelligence at great speed is the duty of a king.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ellaarkkum Ellaam Nikazhpavai
Egngnaandrum
Vallaridhal Vendhan Thozhil
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
All that happens, always, to all 
The king should know in full detail.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: It is the duty of a king to know quickly (by a spy) what all happens, daily, amongst all men.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Each day, of every subject every deed,
'Tis duty of the king to learn with speed.
Various Translators: Duty requires the monarch to swiftly acquire knowledge of all happenings among all men each day.
Dinamalar:
A king's job is to know in time everything
That happens to everyone every day.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No king has ever succeeded
Without considering the news of the spies.
Transliteration:
No king has ever succeeded Without
considering the news of the spies.
T.Kannan: There is no better way to victory for a king than deploying spies on surveillance and gathering credible intelligence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: There is no way for a king to obtain conquests, who knows not the advantage of discoveries made by a spy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Otrinaan Otrip Poruldheriyaa
Mannavan
Kotrang Kolakkitandhadhu Il
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Conquests are not for the monarch 
Who cares not for the Spy's remark.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
By spies who spies, not weighing things they bring,
Nothing can victory give to that unwary king.
Various Translators: Without assessing the intelligence reports of informants, a king can never achieve victory.
Dinamalar: The sure way of achieving success for a king is to get correct information from spies.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Employees, kinsmen and enemies
Are the people a spy should cover.
Transliteration: He is a spy who watches all men, to wit, those who are in the king's employment, his relatives, and his enemies.
T.Kannan:
Employees, kinsmen and enemies Are the
people a spy should cover.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Having everyone. officials, kin and foes, under surveillance is the job of a spy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vinaiseyvaar Thamsutram Ventaadhaar
Endraangu
Anaivaraiyum Aaraaivadhu Otru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
His officers, kinsmen and foes 
Who watch keenly are worthy spies.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
His officers, his friends, his enemies,
All these who watch are trusty spies.
Various Translators: The working staff, close kindred and known enemies— all such people are the legitimate study of spies.
Dinamalar: Espionage consists of watching all people, to wit, the king’s employees, his relations and his enemies.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Able spies are always elusive
With perfect guise and fearless eyes.
Transliteration: A spy is one who is able to assume an appearance which may create no suspicion (in the minds of others), who fears no man's face, and who never reveals (his purpose).
T.Kannan:
Able spies are always elusive With perfect
guise and fearless eyes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A spy should be capable of inconspicuous appearance, fearlessly looking into others’ eyes and never disclosing critical facts.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kataaa Uruvotu Kannanjaadhu Yaantum
Ukaaamai Valladhe Otru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Fearless gaze, suspectless guise 
Guarding secrets mark the spies.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Of unsuspected mien and all unfearing eyes,
Who let no secret out, are trusty spies.
Various Translators: An able spy puts on undoubted disguise, does not fear when detected, and never reveals his purpose.
Dinamalar: An able spy is one who can assume an unsuspicious disguise, is fearless when caught and never betrays his secrets.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Disguised as a monk a spy should probe all places
Unperturbed despite hardships.
Transliteration: He is a spy who, assuming the appearance of an ascetic, goes into (whatever place he wishes), examines into (all, that is needful), and never discovers himself, whatever may be done to him.
T.Kannan:
Disguised as a monk a spy should probe all
places Unperturbed despite hardships.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A spy should be able to go incognito, as an ascetic and others, infiltrate all places, and tirelessly gather intelligence by any means.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Thurandhaar Pativaththa Raaki
Irandhaaraaindhu
Enseyinum Sorviladhu Otru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Guised as monks they gather secrets
They betray them not under threats.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A spy in the guise of an ascetic should gather information however difficult and should never be tired whatever be the troubles.
Various Translators:
As monk or devotee, through every hindrance making way,
A spy , whate'er men do must watchful mind display.
Dinamalar: Disguised as a monk or a mendicant, the master spy moves about investigating all, never careless, come what may.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A spy must ferret out hidden facts, assuring himself that knowledge found is beyond doubt.
Transliteration: A spy is one who is able to discover what is hidden and who retains no doubt concerning what he has known.
T.Kannan:
A spy should ferret out hidden facts
And get them verified beyond doubt.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A spy should ferret out hidden facts And
get them verified beyond doubt.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A spy should be capable of extracting top secrets nonchalantly, and verifying their veracity beyond doubt.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A spy should secure knowledge of things secret and should have no doubt about his information.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Maraindhavai Ketkavar Raaki
Arindhavai
Aiyappaatu Illadhe Otru
Various Translators:
A spy draws out other's secrets 
Beyond a doubt he clears his facts.
Dinamalar:
A spy must search each hidden matter out,
And full report must render, free from doubt.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Before believing one spy’s espionage, have another spy espy the information.
Transliteration: Let not a king receive the information which a spy has discovered and made known to him, until he has examined it by another spy.
T.Kannan:
Even what one spy has spied
Must be spied through another.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One must get confirmed the information supplied by one spy, by that of another.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Even what one spy has spied Must be spied
through another.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Ascertain even the intelligence gathered by a spy by deploying another spy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Otrotrith Thandha Porulaiyum
Matrumor
Otrinaal Otrik Kolal
Various Translators:
The reports given by one spy 
By another spy verify.
Dinamalar:
Spying by spies, the things they tell
To test by other spies is well.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
One spy must not another see; contrive it so;
And things by three confirmed as truth you know.
Transliteration: Let a king employ spies so that one may have no knowledge of the other; and when the information of three agrees together, let him receive it.
T.Kannan: See that informants do not know one another, and accept their findings only when three reports agree.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Let not one spy know another.
And act when three spies agree.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let the engagement of one spy be not known to another. Accept the information supplied independently by three spies.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let not one spy know another. And act when
three spies agree.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Lead the sleuths such that they don’t know each other; when three of them concur on an input, you know it is reliable.
Various Translators:
Otrer Runaraamai Aalka Utanmoovar
Sotrokka Therap Patum
Dinamalar:
Engage the spies alone, apart 
When three agree confirm report.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Let not a king publicly confer on a spy any marks of his favour; if he does, he will divulge his own secret.
Transliteration:
Reward not trusty spy in others' sight,
Or all the mystery will com to light.
T.Kannan: One must not openly honor operatives. To do so is to divulge one’s deepest secrets.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Never honour a spy in public
Lest your secret should be out.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let not a king honour the spy publicly; for, by so doing he will be letting out his own secret.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Never honour a spy in public Lest your
secret should be out.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When you honour a spy, do it not in public; else, you would broadcast your own secret.
Various Translators:
Sirappariya Otrinkan Seyyarka Seyyin
Purappatuththaan Aakum Marai
Dinamalar:
Give not the spy open reward 
It would divulge the secret heard!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To own is to own energy 
All others own but lethargy.
Transliteration:
Tis energy gives men o'er that they own a true control;
They nothing own who own not energy of soul.
T.Kannan: Possessing belongs only to the industrious. Do those who lack such energy really possess their possessions?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One’s real possession is one’s exertion. If one does not have it, can one be said to really possess anything else?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What is one's own is one's vigour.
Without it what does one own?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What is one's own is one's vigour. Without
it what does one own?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The haves are haves if they have zeal; if they have it not, they are have-nots, whatever else they may have.
Various Translators: Energy makes out the man of property; as for those who are destitute of it, do they (really) possess what they possess ?
Dinamalar:
Utaiyar Enappatuvadhu Ookkam
Aqdhillaar
Utaiyadhu Utaiyaro Matru

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ullam Utaimai Utaimai Porulutaimai
Nillaadhu Neengi Vitum
Transliteration:
Psychic heart is wealth indeed 
Worldly wealth departs in speed.
T.Kannan:
The wealth of mind man owns a real worth imparts,
Material wealth man owns endures not, utterly departs.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who own a mental energy possess a thing of worth. Material wealth is an unenduring possession that goes away.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Exertion alone is one’s wealth; inconstant material wealth will pass away.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Real asset is the asset of a resolute mind.
Material assets stay not but flee.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The possession of (energy of) mind is true property; the possession of wealth passes away and abides not.
Various Translators:
Real asset is the asset of a resolute
mind. Material assets stay not but flee.
Dinamalar: Possessing passion is the true possession; all other wealth is transient and will vanish.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: They will not bemoan the loss of wealth, they who have enduring zeal.
Transliteration:
Aakkam Izhandhemendru Allaavaar
Ookkam
Oruvandham Kaiththutai Yaar
T.Kannan:
he strong in will do not complain 
The loss of worldly wealth and gain.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Lost is our wealth', they utter not this cry distressed,
The men of firm concentred energy of soul possessed.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who possess constant exertion will not grieve over the loss of their wealth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those who possess persevering industry will never say in despair, “We have lost our wealth.”
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Those who have vigour will not lament saying:
We have suffered loss.
Various Translators: They who are possessed of enduring energy will not trouble themselves, saying, "we have lost our property."
Dinamalar:
Those who have vigour will not lament
saying: 'We have suffered loss'.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To a man of unshaken vigour, Wealth will
ask and find its way.
Transliteration: Wealth, on its own, will find the way to reach those with unflagging fervor.
T.Kannan:
Aakkam Adharvinaaich Chellum
Asaivilaa
Ookka Mutaiyaa Nuzhai
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Fortune enquires, enters with boom 
Where tireless strivers have their home.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Prosperity will discover a route to a person of undaunted will.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The man of energy of soul inflexible,
Good fortune seeks him out and comes a friend to dwell.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Good fortune of its own accord ferrets out and finds the man of unflagging energy.
Various Translators:
To a man of unshaken vigour,
Wealth will ask and find its way.
Dinamalar: Wealth will find its own way to the man of unfailing energy.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Water level determines the lotus height. A
man's stature by the level of his mind.
Transliteration: The depth of water determines how tall an aquatic plant grows; zeal in the heart dictates how far man goes.
T.Kannan: The length of a watery plant is determined by the depth of the water. Likewise the greatness of a person is proportionate to the strength of his will power.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Vellath Thanaiya Malarneettam
Maandhardham
Ullath Thanaiyadhu Uyarvu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Water depth is lotus height 
Mental strength is men's merit.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
With rising flood the rising lotus flower its stem unwinds,
The dignity of men is measured by their mind,
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The length of the lotus stalk depends on the water’s depth. Even so, a man’s greatness is proportionate to his mind’s energy.
Various Translators: The stalks of water-flowers are proportionate to the depth of water; so is men's greatness proportionate to their minds.
Dinamalar:
Water level determines the lotus height.
A man's stature by the level of his mind.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: In all acts and deeds, let exertion be one’s ideal. Even if it were unattainable, its presence is enough.
Transliteration:
Let all thy aims be high. Failure then is
as good as success.
T.Kannan: Fervently aspire for the best; even if you fail, it is still as good as succeeding.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ulluva Thellaam Uyarvullal Matradhu
Thallinun Thallaamai Neerththu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Let thoughts be always great and grand 
Though they fail their virtues stand.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Whate'er you ponder, let your aim be lofty still,
Fate cannot hinder always, thwart you as it will.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Let all thoughts be thoughts of noble progress, for then even failing cannot be called a failure.
Various Translators: In all that a king thinks of, let him think of his greatness; and if it should be thrust from him (by fate), it will have the nature of not being thrust from him.
Dinamalar:
Let all thy aims be high.
Failure then is as good as success.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The elephant stands undaunted despite piercing arrows; so too, a person of strong will, will not get discouraged even in a losing concern.
Transliteration:
An elephant pierced by arrows stands
unperturbed. The courageous relent not in adversities.
T.Kannan: The zealous won’t flinch in the face of trouble; the elephant, even if buried under a barrage of arrows, never relents.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sidhaivitaththu Olkaar Uravor
Pudhaiyampir
Pattuppaa Toondrung Kaliru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Elephants are firm when arrows hit 
Great minds keep fit ev'n in defeat.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The men of lofty mind quail not in ruin's fateful hour,
The elephant retains his dignity mind arrow's deadly shower.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The strong minded will not faint, even when all is lost; the elephant stands firm, even when wounded by a shower of arrows.
Various Translators: Elephants stand firm even when wounded by a barrage of arrows. Strong willed men are not discouraged when they meet disaster.
Dinamalar:
An elephant pierced by arrows stands unperturbed.
The courageous relent not in adversities.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A man of no strong will, cannot win the esteem of the world for his action.
Transliteration:
The poor in spirit can never attain the
pride of being The generous patrons of the world.
T.Kannan: Those without zeal, will never attain the pride of being hailed as generous.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ullam Ilaadhavar Eydhaar Ulakaththu
Valliyam Ennunj Cherukku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Heartless persons cannot boast 
"We are liberal to our best".
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those who have no (greatness of) mind, will not acquire the joy of saying in the world, "we have excercised liaberality".
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The soulless man can never gain
Th' ennobling sense of power with men.
Various Translators: Without a zealous spirit, one will never enjoy the proud exhilaration of the world’s generosity.
Dinamalar:
The poor in spirit can never attain the pride of being
The generous patrons of the world.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Though huge and sharp-tusked,
An elephant fears a tiger when attacked.
Transliteration:
Though huge and sharp-tusked, An elephant
fears a tiger when attacked.
T.Kannan: It is huge; it has sharp tusks; yet, the tusker is frightened when the tiger attacks.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Although the elephant has a large body, and a sharp tusk, yet it fears the attack of the tiger.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pariyadhu Koorngottadhu Aayinum
Yaanai
Veruum Pulidhaak Kurin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Huge elephant sharp in tusk quails 
When tiger, less in form, assails.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Huge bulk of elephant with pointed tusk all armed,
When tiger threatens shrinks away alarmed!
Various Translators: The towering elephant, with his tapering tusks, still shrinks in fear when a fierce tiger attacks.
Dinamalar: Even the huge elephant with sharp tusks dreads the attacking tiger.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Energy is a man's strength: the immobile are
Trees in human form.
Transliteration: Energy is mental wealth; those men who are destitute of it are only trees in the form of men.
T.Kannan:
Energy is a man's strength: the immobile
are Trees in human form.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Abundant zeal is one’s strength and wisdom; those without it are trees, their human form being the only difference.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Uramoruvarku Ulla Verukkaiaq
Thillaar
Marammakka Laadhale Veru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Mental courage is true manhood 
Lacking that man is like a wood
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Firmness of soul in man is real excellence;
Others are trees, their human form a mere pretence.
Various Translators: An industrious mind is a man’s real wealth. Lacking it, he is immobile—more tree like than human.
Dinamalar: One’s strength is one’s exertion. Without it persons are only trees in the form of men.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The eternal flame of a family vanishes
When eclipsed by that dark cloud called laziness.
Transliteration: By the darkness, of idleness, the indestructible lamp of family (rank) will be extinguished.
T.Kannan:
The eternal flame of a family vanishes
When eclipsed by that dark cloud called laziness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The inextinguishable flame of distinguished ancestry will be put out, if the filth of sloth starts blocking it.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
601 Kutiyennum Kundraa Vilakkam
MatiyennumMaasoora Maaindhu Ketum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Quenchless lamp of ancestry goes 
When foul idleness encloses.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Of household dignity the lustre beaming bright,
Flickers and dies when sluggish foulness dims its light.
Various Translators: If sloth extends its darkness it will extinguish the lustrous lamp of one’s family.
Dinamalar: The eternal flame of a family vanishes when eclipsed by that dark cloud called idleness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Sloth is dismissed as sloth by those
Who wish to retain their family repute.
Transliteration: Let those, who desire that their family may be illustrious, put away all idleness from their conduct.
T.Kannan:
Sloth is dismissed as sloth by those Who
wish to retain their family repute.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Kill laziness, if you wish your clan to become a reputed clan.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Matiyai Matiyaa Ozhukal Kutiyaik
Kutiyaaka Ventu Pavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To make your home an ideal home 
Loath sloth as sloth; refuse it room.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who wish the esteem of their family should never encourage sloth.
Various Translators:
Let indolence, the death of effort, die,
If you'd uphold your household's dignity.
Dinamalar: Let those who wish their family to be a noble family call laziness “laziness” and live without it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The simpleton whose actions are stifled by ruinous indolence will see his family perish before he dies.
Transliteration: The (lustre of the) family of the ignorant man, who acts under the influence of destructive laziness will perish, even before he is dead.
T.Kannan:
A fool, who holds on to sloth,
Will ruin his household before he gets ruined.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A fool, who holds on to sloth, Will ruin
his household before he gets ruined.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The imbecile who lives clutching the fatal indolence, will see his family’s demise before his own.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The family of the fool who hugs sloth in his own lap fades away before him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Matimatik Kontozhukum Pedhai
Pirandha
Kutimatiyum Thanninum Mundhu
Various Translators:
The fool who fosters sluggishness 
Before he dies ruins his house.
Dinamalar:
Who fosters indolence within his breast, the silly elf!
The house from which he springs shall perish ere himself.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Their families decrease and their vices increase when men, ensnared in sloth, do not put forth earnest effort.
Transliteration: Family (greatness) will be destroyed, and faults will increase, in those men who give way to laziness, and put forth no dignified exertions.
T.Kannan:
The society that broods in sloth without striving,
Decays and steeps in crime.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Faults will be many among those who are devoid of exertion and will result in the ruin of their families.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The society that broods in sloth without
striving, Decays and steeps in crime.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A ruler who falls into the lap of laziness and doesn’t strive hard, will witness the destruction of his subjects and an upsurge in crime.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kutimatindhu Kutram Perukum
Matimatindhu
Maanta Ugnatri Lavarkku
Various Translators:
Who strive not high, sunk deep in sloth 
Ruin their house by evil growth.
Dinamalar:
His family decays, and faults unheeded thrive,
Who, sunk in sloth, for noble objects doth not strive.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Delay, oblivion, sloth and sleep; these four
Are pleasure boat to bear the doomed to ruin's shore.
Transliteration: Procrastination, forgetfulness, idleness, and sleep, these four things, form the vessel which is desired by those destined to destruction.
T.Kannan: Procrastination, forgetfulness, sloth and sleep— these four shape the ship bearing those destined for ruin.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The pleasure-junks of destruction are four:
Procrastination, forgetfulness, sloth and sleep.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Procrastination, carelessness, sluggardliness and sleep are the four boats fondly entered into by those who go to ruin.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The pleasure-junks of destruction are
four: Procrastination, forgetfulness, sloth and sleep.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Procrastination, neglect, sloth and slumber : these four are the ship that is boarded lovingly by habitual losers.
Various Translators:
Netuneer Maravi Matidhuyil Naankum
Ketuneeraar Kaamak Kalan
Dinamalar:
To lag, forget, idle and doze 
These four are pleasure boats of loss.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is a rare thing for the idle, even when possessed of the riches of kings who ruled over the whole earth, to derive any great benefit from it.
Transliteration:
Through lords of earth unearned possessions gain,
The slothful ones no yeild of good obtain.
T.Kannan: Seldom do languid men achieve anything special, even when supported by the world’s wealthy proprietors.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seldom do men possessed by sloth achieve anything great
Even if they possess worldly wealth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Even when the wealth of the rulers of all earth is within his reach, the slothful will hardly derive any great benefit from it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Seldom do men possessed by sloth achieve
anything great Even if they possess worldly wealth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is unlikely that the lazy will prosper, even if they inherit the riches of an emperor.
Various Translators:
Patiyutaiyaar Patramaindhak Kannum
Matiyutaiyaar
Maanpayan Eydhal Aridhu
Dinamalar:
With all the wealth of lords of earth 
The slothful gain nothing of worth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The slothful lacking noble deeds 
Subject themselves to scornful words.
Transliteration:
Who hug their sloth, not noble works attempt,
Shall bear reproofs and words of just contempt.
T.Kannan: Idle men, incapable of honorable exertion, invite scorn and suffer the shame of scolding words.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Lovers of idleness with no praiseworthy exertion will be the butt of disgrace and will receive words of rebuke.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The lazy ones, inept in noble exertion,
Must endure scolding and scorn.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The lazy ones, inept in noble exertion,
Must endure scolding and scorn.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Well-meaning rebukes will be followed by ridicule, if one is indolent and refrains from striving hard.
Various Translators: Those who through idleness, and do not engage themselves in dignified exertion, will subject themselves to rebukes and reproaches.
Dinamalar:
Itipurindhu Ellunj Chol Ketpar
MatipurindhuMaanta Ugnatri Lavar

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Matimai Kutimaikkan Thangindhan
Onnaarkku
Atimai Pukuththi Vitum
Transliteration:
If sloth invades a noble house 
It will become a slave of foes.
T.Kannan:
If sloth a dwelling find mid noble family,
Bondsmen to them that hate them shall they be.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If languor is allowed to linger in aristocrats, they will be forced into servitude under foes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If sloth comes to stay in one’s family, it will make one the slave of one’s enemies.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If sloth inhabits a family,
The family will soon be enslaved to its foes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If idleness take up its abode in a king of high birth, it will make him a slave of his enemies.
Various Translators:
If sloth inhabits a family, The family
will soon be enslaved to its foes.
Dinamalar: If laziness rests on a state and its rulers, it will be enslaved by its foes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The ills that befell his state and leadership, will vanish if one gives up his indolence.
Transliteration:
Kutiyaanmai Yulvandha Kutram Oruvan
Matiyaanmai Maatrak Ketum
T.Kannan:
The blots on race and rule shall cease 
When one from sloth gets his release.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who changes slothful habits saves
Himself from all that household rule depraves.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: By conquering sloth, one can wipe out the reproach that has come over one’s family.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Disgrace that has come upon a man and his family will disappear the moment he casts out laziness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Even inherent flaws in a family can be overcome
By getting rid of indolence.
Various Translators: When a man puts away idleness, the reproach which has come upon himself and his family will disappear.
Dinamalar:
Even inherent flaws in a family can be
overcome By getting rid of indolence.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A king freed of sloth can get at once All
that the Lord had measured by his feet.
Transliteration: The ruler who has no sloth will attain all that was attained by the one who measured the world with his feet.
T.Kannan:
Matiyilaa Mannavan Eydhum
Atiyalandhaan
Thaaaya Thellaam Orungu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The slothless king shall gain en masse 
<sup>*</sup>All regions trod by Lord apace.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: All the universe once measured by God will be with the king of no sloth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The king whose life from sluggishness is rid,
Shall rule o'er all by foot of mighty god bestrid.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A king devoid of indolence will thereby procure all that cosmic expanse measured by God’s immeasurable strides.
Various Translators:
A king freed of sloth can get at once
All that the Lord had measured by his feet.
Dinamalar: The king who never gives way to idleness will obtain entire possession of (the whole earth) passed over by him who measured (the worlds) with His foot.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Do not give up saying 'It is impossible'.
Effort will overcome.
Transliteration: Shun not a task because it is tough; perseverance brings respect.
T.Kannan: “Do not give up (your task) saying ‘O’ It is very difficult." The art of doing it comes of exertion.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Arumai Utaiththendru Asaavaamai
Ventum
Perumai Muyarsi Tharum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Feel not frustrate saying "Tis hard".
Who tries attains striving's reward.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Say not 'Tis hard', in weak , desponding hour,
For strenuous efforts gives prevailing power.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Never say in weakness, “This task is too difficult.” Perseverance will confer the ability to accomplish it.
Various Translators: Yield not to the feebleness which says, "this is too difficult to be done"; labour will give the greatness (of mind) which is necessary (to do it).
Dinamalar:
Do not give up saying It is impossible.
Effort will overcome.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Do not give up your task in the middle; for the world will abandon those who leave their task unfinished.
Transliteration:
Leave no task incomplete, For the world
gives up those who give up.
T.Kannan: The world deserts those who desert an essential task; while executing, don’t wilt and let the task fail.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Vinaikkan Vinaiketal Ompal
Vinaikkurai
Theerndhaarin Theerndhandru Ulaku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
In doing work don't break and shirk 
The world will quit who quits his work.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In action be thou' ware of act's defeat;
The world leaves those who work leave incomplete!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Beware of leaving any work undone, remembering that the world abandons those who abandon their work unfinished.
Various Translators: Take care not to give up exertion in the midst of a work; the world will abandon those who abandon their unfinished work.
Dinamalar:
Leave no task incomplete,
For the world gives up those who give up.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The greatness which consists in helping others dwells in the virtue of persevering effort.
Transliteration:
The pride of being a philanthropist
belongs to those Who have that quality called
perseverance.
T.Kannan: The greatness of benevolence rests on those who have the quality of perseverance.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thaalaanmai Ennum Thakaimaikkan
Thangitre
Velaanmai Ennunj Cherukku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
On excellence of industry 
Depends magnanimous bounty.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In strenuous effort doth reside
The power of helping others; noble pride!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The lustre of munificence will dwell only with the dignity of laboriousness or efforts.
Various Translators: The pride of profuse giving dwells only with the dignity of diligent effort.
Dinamalar:
The pride of being a philanthropist belongs to those
Who have that quality called perseverance.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The service of one with no persevering effort is vain like the sword wielded by a hermaphrodite.
Transliteration:
The liberality of the indolent man will
not endure, Like a sword in eunuch's hand.
T.Kannan: Benevolence of the person without persistence, will turn futile like a sword in the hands of a coward.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thaalaanmai Illaadhaan Velaanmai
Petikai
Vaalaanmai Polak Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Bounty of man who never strives 
Like sword in eunuch's hand it fails.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The liberality of him, who does not labour, will fail, like the manliness of a hermaphrodite, who has a sword in its hand.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Beneficent intent in men by whom no strenuous work is wrought,
Like battle axe in sexless being's hand availeth nought.
Various Translators: Like the swordsmanship of an effeminate man, the philanthropy of those who avoid hard work will end in failure.
Dinamalar:
The liberality of the indolent man will not endure,
Like a sword in eunuch's hand.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A pillar of comfort to his friends is he
Who scorns delight and loves labour.
Transliteration:
A pillar of comfort to his friends is he
Who scorns delight and loves labour.
T.Kannan: Forsaking gratification, he who perseveres, is a pillar for one’s kin. wiping and bearing their woes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: He who desires not pleasure, but desires labour, will be a pillar to sustain his relations, wiping away their sorrows.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Inpam Vizhaiyaan Vinaivizhaivaan
Thankelir
Thunpam Thutaiththoondrum Thoon
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Work who likes and not pleasure 
Wipes grief of friends, pillar secure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Whose heart delighteth not in pleasure, but in action finds delight,
He wipes away his kinsmen's grief and stands the pillar of their might.
Various Translators: Standing like a pillar, he who prefers work to pleasure supports his family and sweeps away their every sad sorrow.
Dinamalar: One who does not seek pleasure but delights in work will be a pillar of support to one’s relatives in their sorrow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Exertion leads to wealth;
Lack of it brings forth poverty.
Transliteration: Labour will produce wealth; idleness will bring poverty.
T.Kannan:
Exertion leads to wealth; Lack of it
brings forth poverty.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Effort creates wealth; lack of it induces poverty.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Muyarsi Thiruvinai Aakkum
Muyatrinmai
Inmai Pukuththi Vitum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Industry adds prosperity
Indolence brings but poverty.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Effort brings fortune's sure increase,
Its absence brings to nothingness.
Various Translators: Perseverance generates prosperity, and the lack of it engenders poverty.
Dinamalar: Exertion achieves wealth; absence of it brings on poverty.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The black ogress 'misfortune' lurks in laziness,
While goddess 'fortune' lingers in active men.
Transliteration: They say that the black Mudevi (the goddess of adversity) dwells with laziness, and the Latchmi (the goddess of prosperity) dwells with the labour of the industrious.
T.Kannan:
The black ogress 'misfortune' lurks in
laziness, While goddess 'fortune' lingers in active
men.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Thus they speak : the angel of poverty resides with the sluggard; the lotus-residing angel of wealth rests on the efforts of the unsluggish.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Matiyulaal Maamukati Enpa Matiyilaan
Thaalulaan Thaamaraiyi Naal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Illuck abides with sloth they say 
<sup>*</sup>Laxmi's gifts with labourers stay.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
In sluggishness is seen misfortune's lurid form, the wise declare;
Where man unslothful toils, she of the lotus flower is there!
Various Translators: Goddess of misfortune dwells in sloth; the Goddess of fortune lives in exertion.
Dinamalar: They say the black ogress called Misfortune lurks in laziness, while Goddess Fortune lingers in the laboring toils of active men.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ill-luck is never blamed. What is blamed
Is knowledge without exertion.
Transliteration: Adverse fate is no disgrace to any one; to be without exertion and without knowing what should be known, is disgrace.
T.Kannan:
Ill-luck is never blamed. What is blamed
Is knowledge without exertion.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Lack of good fortune brings not disgrace; not gaining requisite knowledge, and not persisting, is disgraceful.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Poriyinmai Yaarkkum Pazhiyandru
Arivarindhu
Aalvinai Inmai Pazhi
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Misfortune is disgrace to none 
The shame is nothing learnt or done.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Ill-luck is no disgrace; but it is a disgrace if one does not exert himself as to what should be done.
Various Translators:
Tis no reproach unpropitious fate should ban;
But not to do man's work is foul disgrace to man!
Dinamalar: To be destitute of good fortune is no one’s disgrace, but shame belongs to those devoid of wisdom and tenacity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Though destiny decrees that one’s deeds will fail, the wages for determined work are always paid.
Transliteration: Although it be said that, through fate, it cannot be attained, yet labour, with bodily exertion, will yield its reward.
T.Kannan:
Even though God be against,
Effort is bound to pay the wages of labour.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Even though God be against, Effort is
bound to pay the wages of labour.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Even if god has given up, perseverance will pay the wages for one’s efforts.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Though fate should ordain failure, bodily exertion will yield its own reward.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Theyvaththaan Aakaa Theninum
Muyarsidhan
Meyvaruththak Kooli Tharum
Various Translators:
Though fate is against fulfilment 
Hard labour has ready payment.
Dinamalar:
Though fate divine should make you labour vain;
Efforts its labour's sure reward will gain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who strive with tireless exertion and remain undaunted will live to behold the backside of retreating Fate.
Transliteration: They who labour on, without fear and without fainting will see even fate (put) behind their back.
T.Kannan:
Those who never get tired of striving undauntedly
Shall leave even Fate behind.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who labour hard, undaunted by obstacles will overcome destiny.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Those who never get tired of striving
undauntedly Shall leave even Fate behind.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: They will defeat and see the back of ool (fate). they who persevere resolutely without respite.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Oozhaiyum Uppakkam Kaanpar
Ulaivindrith
Thaazhaadhu Ugnatru Pavar
Various Translators:
Tireless Toiler's striving hand 
Shall leave even the fate behind.
Dinamalar:
Who strive with undismayed , unfaltering mind.
At length shall leave opposing fate behind.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Smile, with patient, hopeful heart, in troublous hour;
Meet and so vanquish grief; nothing hath equal power.
Transliteration: If troubles come, laugh; there is nothing like that, to press upon and drive away sorrow.
T.Kannan: துன்பம் வரும் போது சிரித்துக் கொள்க. அதனைப் பகைத்து வெற்றி கொள்ளவல்ல வேறெதுவுமே இல்லை.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Laugh at misfortune. There is nothing so able,
To triumph over it.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Laugh over your obstacles; nothing like it to push them further and further.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Laugh at misfortune. There is nothing so
able, To triumph over it.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Smile in times of trouble; it is without equal, in repeatedly trouncing trouble.
Various Translators:
Itukkan Varungaal Nakuka Adhanai
Atuththoorvadhu Aqdhoppa Thil
Dinamalar:
Laugh away troubles; there is 
No other way to conquer woes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A flood of troubles will be overcome by the (courageous) thought which the minds of the wise will entertain, even in sorrow.
Transliteration:
Through sorrow, like a flood, comes rolling on,
When wise men's mind regards it, it is gone.
T.Kannan: அலைகள் போல் வருந் துன்பங்களை உள்ளம் ஒன்றித் தளராது எதிர்த்து நிற்க அவை பின் வாங்கிச் சென்று விடும்.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Misfortune may rise like a flood,
But the wise counter it by firm thoughts.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Troubles like a flood will be overcome by a courageous thought rising in the minds of the wise.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Misfortune may rise like a flood, But the
wise counter it by firm thoughts.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Floods of tribulation will be wiped away, when the wise set their minds on overcoming it.
Various Translators:
Vellath Thanaiya Itumpai
Arivutaiyaan
Ullaththin Ullak Ketum
Dinamalar:
Deluging sorrows come to nought 
When wise men face them with firm thought.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Grief they face and put to grief 
Who grieve not grief by mind's relief.
Transliteration:
Who griefs confront with meek, ungrieving heart,
From them griefs, put to grief, depart.
T.Kannan: துன்பத்தைக் கண்டு வருந்தாத நெஞ்சுரம் உள்ளவர் துன்பத்துக்கே துன்பத்தை விளைவித்துக் விரட்டி விடுவர்
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The courageous will be causing sorrow to sorrow itself.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Those whom grief cannot grieve
Can grieve grief itself.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those whom grief cannot grieve Can grieve
grief itself.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: They will torment the torment, those who don’t get tormented by torment.
Various Translators: They give sorrow to sorrow, who in sorrow do not suffer sorrow.
Dinamalar:
Itumpaikku Itumpai Patuppar
Itumpaikku
Itumpai Pataaa Thavar

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Matuththavaa Yellaam Pakatannaan
Utra
Itukkan Itarppaatu Utaiththu
Transliteration:
Who pulls like bulls patiently on 
Causes grief to grieve anon.
T.Kannan:
Like bullock struggle on through each obstructed way;
From such an one will troubles , troubled , roll away.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: மேடு பள்ளத்தில் எல்லாம் வண்டியை உறுதியுடன் இழுக்கும் எருது போல துன்பங்களுக்கு முகங் கொடுத்து நிற்பவன் முன் அத்துன்பங்களே துன்பப்படும்.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Just as the buffalo drags a cart through miry depth, one who fights on will overcome his difficulties.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Trouble is troubled by him who like a bull
Drags his cart through every hurdle.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Troubles will vanish (i.e., will be troubled) before the man who (struggles against difficulties) as a buffalo (drawing a cart) through deep mire.
Various Translators:
Trouble is troubled by him who like a bull
Drags his cart through every hurdle.
Dinamalar: Whenever stuck in a mire, if one chugs along like a bull, trouble will be distressed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even under an onslaught of adversities, if one is unfazed, his torments will be tormented.
Transliteration:
Atukki Varinum Azhivilaan Utra
Itukkan Itukkat Patum
T.Kannan:
Before the brave grief grieves and goes
Who dare a host of pressing woes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
When griefs press on , but fail to crush the patient heart,
Then griefs defeated, put to grief, depart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The troubles of one who braves a series of adversity wear out and disappear.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: மலை போல் துன்பங்கள் வந்து குவியினும் ஒருவரின் கலங்காத மனத் திண்மையால் அவை அழிந்து விடும்.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The resolute can put their troubles to trouble
Even if it comes relentlessly.
Various Translators: The troubles of that man will be troubled (and disappear) who, however thickly they may come upon him , does not abandon (his purpose).
Dinamalar:
The resolute can put their troubles to
trouble Even if it comes relentlessly.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Will they whine 'We have nothing', Who
never crowed 'We have much?'
Transliteration: Will they be distressed by poverty. those who, in times of wealth, don’t stingily cling to their wealth?
T.Kannan:
Atremendru Allar Patupavo
Petremendru
Ompudhal Thetraa Thavar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The wise that never gloat in gain 
Do not fret in fateful ruin.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Will those who do not during prosperity exultingly say “we are rich”, cry out (during adversity) “Oh, we are destitute”?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who boasted not of wealth, nor gave it all their heart,
Will not bemoan the loss, when prosperous days depart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: என்னிடம் மிகு பொருள் உண்டு எனத் தம் செல்வத்தைப் பெருமையுடன் கூறாதவர் வறுமை வரும் போது என்னிடம் சிறிதே உண்டு எனக் கண்ணீர் சொட்டமாட்டார்கள்
Various Translators:
Will they whine We have nothing,
Who never crowed We have much?
Dinamalar: Will those men ever cry out in sorrow, "we are destitute" who, (in their prosperity), give not way to (undue desire) to keep their wealth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Knowing body a target of miseries, The
great are not troubled in calamities.
Transliteration: Knowing that the human body is ever a target for afflictions, the wise will not be distressed by distress.
T.Kannan: The great know that the body is ever the target of trouble and will not regard trouble as trouble at all.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ilakkam Utampitumpaik Kendru
Kalakkaththaik
Kaiyaaraak Kollaadhaam Mel
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The wise worry no more of woes 
Knowing body's butt of sorrows.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Mans' frame is sorrow's target, ' the noble mind reflects,
Nor meets with troubled mind and the sorrows it expects.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: இவ்வுடல் துன்பத்துக்கே இரையாகும் என உணர்ந்து உயர்ந்தோர் துன்பத்தைத் துன்பமாகக் கொள்ளமாட்டார்கள்.
Various Translators: The great will not regard trouble as trouble, knowing that the body is the butt of trouble.
Dinamalar:
Knowing body a target of miseries,
The great are not troubled in calamities.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He who never gives way to sorrow, will not long for pleasure; he will regard trouble as quite natural.
Transliteration:
He will never be sad who scorns delight
And takes sorrow in his stride.
T.Kannan: He who yearns not for pleasures, dismisses adversities as inevitable, will never be distressed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Inpam Vizhaiyaan Itumpai Iyalpenpaan
Thunpam Urudhal Ilan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who seek not joy, deem grief norm 
By sorrows do not come to harm.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
He seeks not joy, to sorrow man is boorn, he knows;
Such man will walk unharmed by touch of human woes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: துன்பங்கள் வந்து சேருதல் இயற்கையே எனவுணர்ந்து, வாழ்வின் இன்பத்தை நாடிச் செல்லாதவர் வருந் துன்பங்களால் வருந்த மாட்டார்கள்.
Various Translators: That man never experiences sorrow, who does not seek for pleasure, and who considers distress to be natural (to man).
Dinamalar:
He will never be sad who scorns delight
And takes sorrow in his stride.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He who does seek for pleasure in pleasure will not be vexed in sorrow.
Transliteration:
He who never exulted in joy Will not be
depressed by sorrow.
T.Kannan: He who yearns not for pleasure in joyous times, will not be distressed in times of sorrow.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Inpaththul Inpam Vizhaiyaadhaan
Thunpaththul
Thunpam Urudhal Ilan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
In joy to joy who is not bound 
In grief he grieves not dual round!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Mid joys he yields hot heart to joys' control,
Mid sorrows, sorrow cannot touch his soul.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He does not suffer sorrow, in sorrow who does not look for pleasure in pleasure.
Various Translators: இன்பம் வந்த காலத்தில் அதில் இன்பம் காண ஆசைப் படாதவன் துன்பம் வந்து அதை அனுபவிக்கும் போது வருத்தம் அடைய மாட்டான்.
Dinamalar:
He who never exulted in joy
Will not be depressed by sorrow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One who regards trouble as pleasure will gain the elevation which his enemies desire (for themselves).
Transliteration:
To take pain as pleasure Is to gain your
foe's esteem.
T.Kannan: If one accepts adversities as pleasures, his adversaries too will acclaim him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Innaamai Inpam Enakkolin Aakundhan
Onnaar Vizhaiyunj Chirappu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
His glory is esteemed by foes
Who sees weal in wanton woes!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The elevation, which even his enemies will esteem, will be gained by him, who regards pain as pleasure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who pain as pleasure takes,he shall acquire
The bliss to which his foes in vain aspire.
Various Translators: இன்பத்தையும் துன்பத்தையும் வேறு படுத்தி நோக்காதவர் பகைவருமே அஞ்சலி செய்யும் வகை சிறப்புற்று விளங்குவர்.
Dinamalar:
To take pain as pleasure
Is to gain your foe's esteem.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Call him minister who best contrives the means,
The time, the mode and the deed.
Transliteration:
Call him minister who best contrives the
means, The time, the mode and the deed.
T.Kannan: A minister is one who can envisage rare deeds, the resources and time entailed, and the means to execute.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The minister is one who can make an excellent choice of means, time, manner of execution, and the difficult undertaking (itself).
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Karuviyum Kaalamum Seykaiyum Seyyum
Aruvinaiyum Maantadhu Amaichchu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
He is minister who chooses 
Right means, time, mode and rare ventures.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A minister is he who grasps, with wisdom large.
Means,time, work's mode and functions rare he must discharge.
Various Translators: A minister is he who can conceive a great enterprise, rightly choose the ways, means and time, then carry it out.
Dinamalar: He is the minister who, finds out the means, the time, the deed and its full accomplishment.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A minister excels in firmness, protection,
Learning and perseverance, besides the five tactics.
Transliteration: The minister is one who in addition to the aforesaid five things excels in the possession of firmness, protection of subjects, clearness by learning, and perseverance.
T.Kannan:
A minister excels in firmness, protection,
Learning and perseverance, besides the five tactics.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Resolve, protecting the citizens, learning and perseverance. a minister is one who is capable in these too.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vankan Kutikaaththal Katraridhal
Aalvinaiyotu
Aindhutan Maantadhu Amaichchu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
With these he guards people, by his 
Knowledge, firmness and manliness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A minister must greatness own of guardian power, determined mind.
Learn'd wisdom, manly effort with the former five combined.
Various Translators: Added to the above five, a minister is well endowed with steadfastness, learning, perseverance and protection of the people.
Dinamalar: A minister should have five qualities; tenacity of purpose, birth in a respectable family, welfare of the people, profound learning and perseverance.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
An able minister can disunite allies,
Cherish friends and reunite enemies.
Transliteration: The minister is one who can effect discord (among foes), maintain the good-will of his friends and restore to friendship those who have seceded (from him).
T.Kannan:
An able minister can disunite allies,
Cherish friends and reunite enemies.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A minister is adept at these : splitting the foes, binding the allies, and uniting the estranged.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Piriththalum Penik Kolalum
Pirindhaarp
Poruththalum Valla Thamaichchu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A minister cherishes friends 
Divides foes and the parted blends.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A minister is he whose power can foes divide,
Attach more firmly friends, of severed ones can heal the breaches wide.
Various Translators: A minister must be able to separate a foe from his ally, befriend allies and reunite separated allies.
Dinamalar: He who can divide ememies, bind friends more firmly and reunite estranged allies is unequivocally a minister.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Call him a minister who comprehends things,
Executes them and directs others.
Transliteration: The minister is one who is able to comprehend (the whole nature of an undertaking), execute it in the best manner possible, and offer assuring advice (in time of necessity).
T.Kannan:
Call him a minister who comprehends
things, Executes them and directs others.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A minister should be proficient in assessing, executing and articulating unequivocally.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Theridhalum Therndhu Seyalum
Orudhalaiyaach
Chollalum Valladhu Amaichchu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A minister must sift reflect
Select and say surely one fact.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A minister should study the consequences of an act and carry it successfully by a decisive speech.
Various Translators:
A minister has power to see the methods help afford,
To ponder long, then utter calm conclusive word.
Dinamalar: Call him a minister who comprehends things, effectively executes them and competently directs others.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The helpful aide understands codes of conduct, discerns what is fitting in every situation and speaks with learned deliberation.
Transliteration: He is the best helper (of the king) who understanding the duties, of the latter, is by his special learning, able to tender the fullest advice, and at all times conversant with the best method (of performing actions).
T.Kannan:
A helpful counsellor knows the codes,
Is learned in discourse and ever resourceful.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A helpful counsellor knows the codes, Is
learned in discourse and ever resourceful.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He knows righteousness; he can enunciate eruditely; he is always adroit at execution : he is an apt counsellor.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He is a helpful counselor who is righteous and considerate in his speech, and always knows how to act.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Aranarindhu Aandramaindha Sollaanenj
Gnaandrun
Thiranarindhaan Therchchith Thunai
Various Translators:
Have him for help who virtue knows 
Right wisdom speaks, ever apt in acts.
Dinamalar:
The man who virtue knows, has use of wise and plesant words,
With plans for every season apt, in counsel aid affords.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When shrewd intelligence combines with scholastic study, who can stand before such peerless subtlety?
Transliteration: What (contrivances) are there so acute as to resist those who possess natural acuteness in addition to learning ?.
T.Kannan:
What is there too subtle to stand before men
Who add learning to their intelligence?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: To a keen intellect combined with learning no difficulty stands in the way.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What is there too subtle to stand before
men Who add learning to their intelligence?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: For one who has an impressive intellect, and is well-read, is there any task that can be extremely challenging?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Madhinutpam Noolotu Utaiyaarkku
Adhinutpam
Yaavula Munnir Pavai
Various Translators:
Which subtler brain can stand before 
The keen in brain with learned love?
Dinamalar:
When native subtilty combines with sound scholastic lore,
'Tis subtilty surpassing all , which nothing stands before.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Though knowing all that books can teach, ' tis truest tact
To follow common sense of men in act.
Transliteration: Though you are acquainted with the (theoretical) methods (of performing an act), understand the ways of the world and act accordingly.
T.Kannan: Though thoroughly learned in theoretical methods, one should act only after fathoming the world’s proven practices.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Even if well-versed in theory,
Act as per the ways of the world.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Even though you know the rules, act in conformity with the world opinion.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Even if well-versed in theory, Act as per
the ways of the world.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even if you know well how to do a task, do it knowing the nature of your world.
Various Translators:
Seyarkai Arindhak Kataiththum
Ulakaththu
Iyarkai Arindhu Seyal
Dinamalar:
Albeit you know to act from books
Act after knowing world's outlooks.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Although the king be utterly ignorant, it is the duty of the minister to give (him) sound advice.
Transliteration:
Tis duty of the man in place aloud to say
The very truth, though unwise king may cast his words away.
T.Kannan: The loyal minister’s duty is to communicate his counsel, even if his leader is a dullard who spurns advice.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
It is a minister's duty to advise aright
Though the ruler in ignorance may refute wisdom.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Though a king listens not to wise words it is the duty of the minister to speak firmly to him.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
It is a minister's duty to advise aright
Though the ruler in ignorance may refute wisdom.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The king ought to listen to good counsel; even if he doesn’t know or listen, it is the duty of the minister to advise firmly.
Various Translators:
Arikondru Ariyaan Eninum Urudhi
Uzhaiyirundhaan Kooral Katan
Dinamalar:
The man in place must tell the facts 
Though the ignorant king refutes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Seventy crores of foes are better 
Than a minister with mind bitter.
Transliteration:
A minister who by king's side plots evil things
Worse woes than countless foemen brings.
T.Kannan: Better for the king to face 700 million far off foes than to retain a single counselor who conspires at his side.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A treacherous minister by the king’s side is equal to seventy crores of enemies.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Better seventy million open foes
Than one treacherous minister inside.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Better seventy million open foes Than one
treacherous minister inside.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is better to face 700 million foes than have a scheming minister.
Various Translators: Far better are seventy crores of enemies (for a king) than a minister at his side who intends (his) ruin.
Dinamalar:
Pazhudhennum Mandhiriyin Pakkadhadhul
Thevvor
Ezhupadhu Koti Urum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Muraippatach Choozhndhum Mutivilave
Seyvar
Thirappaatu Ilaaa Thavar
Transliteration:
The unresolved, though well designed 
To fulfil an act they have no mind.
T.Kannan:
For gain of end desired just counsel nought avails
