To minister, when tact in execution fails.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Little matter that they can devise the perfect plan; those without executive skills never finish their work.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Ministers who have no requisite ability will leave a task unfinished though well begun.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The inefficient will leave undone
Even well-planned schemes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those ministers who are destitute of (executive) ability will fail to carry out their projects, although they may have contrived aright.
Various Translators:
The inefficient will leave undone Even
well-planned schemes.
Dinamalar: They plan meticulously but yet can’t take it to completion, those who are poor at execution.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The benefits of a gifted tongue, outclass the benefits of anything else.
Transliteration:
Naanalam Ennum Nalanutaimai Annalam
Yaanalaththu Ulladhooum Andru
T.Kannan:
The goodness called goodness of speech
Is goodness which nothing can reach.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A tounge that rightly speaks the right is greatest gain,
It stands alone midst goodly things that men obtain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The virtue of good speech is greater than all the other good qualities found in one.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Among a man’s many good possessions, none can equal having a good tongue.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Real asset is the gift of speech.
That gift is a class apart from all other gifts.
Various Translators: The possession of that goodness which is called the goodness of speech is (even to others) better than any other goodness.
Dinamalar:
Real asset is the gift of speech. That
gift is a class apart from all other gifts.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Speech can both make and mar, And hence
guard it from negligence.
Transliteration: It creates and destructs; hence ensure there is never a blemish in your speech.
T.Kannan:
Aakkamung Ketum Adhanaal Varudhalaal
Kaaththompal Sollinkat Sorvu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Since gain or ruin speeches bring 
Guard against the slips of tongue.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: As I both prosperity and ruin are caused by words, a minister must guard against imperfection in his speech.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Since gain and loss in life on speech depend,
From careless slip in speech thyself defend.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Prosperity and ruin issue from the power of the tongue. Therefore, guard yourself against thoughtless speech.
Various Translators:
Speech can both make and mar,
And hence guard it from negligence.
Dinamalar: Since (both) wealth and evil result from (their) speech, ministers should most carefully guard themselves against faultiness therein.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A speech should hold fast the convinced
And be pleasing even to the unconvinced.
Transliteration: Speak with such quality that it binds those who lend their ears, and casts a spell on even those who don’t.
T.Kannan: The minister must use such words as have the effect of strengthening the approval of those who agree and differ.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kettaarp Pinikkum Thakaiyavaaik
Kelaarum
Vetpa Mozhivadhaam Sol
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A speech is speech that holds ears 
And attracts ev'n those that are averse.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Tis speech that spell bound holds the listening ear,
While those who have hot heard desire to hear.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The substance of artful speech holds friends spell bound, and its eloquence enchants even enemies.
Various Translators: The (minister's) speech is that which seeks (to express) elements as bind his friends (to himself) and is so delivered as to make even his enemies desire (his friendship).
Dinamalar:
A speech should hold fast the convinced
And be pleasing even to the unconvinced.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Speak having regard to one’s capacity to listen; for there is no greater virtue nor wealth than that.
Transliteration:
Speak to the capacity of the audience.
Nothing more virtuous or valuable than this.
T.Kannan: Speak words that befit the capabilities; there is no greater virtue and wealth than that.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thiranarindhu Solluka Sollai Aranum
Porulum Adhaninooungu Il
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Weigh thy words and speak; because
No wealth or virtue words surpass.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Speak words adapted well to various hearers' state;
No higher virtue lives, no gain more surely great.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Judge the nature of your listeners and speak accordingly. There is nothing more virtuous or valuable than this.
Various Translators: Understand the qualities (of your hearers) and (then) make your speech; for superior to it, there is neither virtue nor wealth.
Dinamalar:
Speak to the capacity of the audience.
Nothing more virtuous or valuable than this.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Speak out what you have to say only after knowing that your own argument will not be turned against you.
Transliteration:
Utter not a word without making sure There
is no other word to beat it.
T.Kannan: Say a word such that no other word can surpass that word.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Solluka Sollaip Piridhorsol
Achchollai
Vellunjol Inmai Arindhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Speak out thy world so that no word 
Can win it and say untoward.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Speak out your speech, when once 'tis past dispute
That none can utter speech that shall your speech refute.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Deliver your speech, after assuring yourself that no counter speech can defeat your own.
Various Translators: Speak out your speech after ascertaining that no speech can be spoken to refute that speech.
Dinamalar:
Utter not a word without making sure
There is no other word to beat it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A good minister wins the approval of the listener by persuasive speech.
Transliteration:
To speak as desired and gain from what
others say Is the hallmark of spotless men.
T.Kannan: Speaking alluring words, and seeking to learn when others speak, is the way of those with impeccable qualities.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Vetpaththaanj Chollip Pirarsol
Payankotal
Maatchiyin Maasatraar Kol
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Spotless men speak what is sweet 
And grasp in others what is meet.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: It is the opinion of those who are free from defects in diplomacy that the minister should speak so as to make his hearers desire (to hear more) and grasp the meaning of what he hears himself.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Charming each hearer's ear, of others words to seize the sense,
Is method wise of men of spotless excellence.
Various Translators: To speak so that listeners long to hear more and to listen so that others’ meaning is grasped are ideals of the impeccably great.
Dinamalar:
To speak as desired and gain from what others say
Is the hallmark of spotless men.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
An eloquent, tireless and fearless speaker
Can rarely be prevailed upon by any one.
Transliteration:
An eloquent, tireless and fearless speaker
Can rarely be prevailed upon by any one.
T.Kannan: If he is capable with words, tireless, and fearless; it is impossible to confront and defeat him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It is impossible for any one to conquer him by intrique who possesses power of speech, and is neither faulty nor timid.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Solalvallan Sorvilan Anjaan Avanai
Ikalvellal Yaarkkum Aridhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No foe defies the speaker clear 
Flawless, puissant, and free from fear.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Mighty in word, of unforgetful mind, of fearless speech.
'Tis hard for hostile power such man to overreach.
Various Translators: In a war of words, none can defeat a persuasive man who never succumbs to fear or forgetfulness.
Dinamalar: A clever speaker is neither tired nor fearful; none can defeat him in a debate.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The world will rush and listen to those
Who can to speak orderly and pleasingly.
Transliteration: If there be those who can speak on various subjects in their proper order and in a pleasing manner, the world would readily accept them.
T.Kannan:
The world will rush and listen to those
Who can to speak orderly and pleasingly.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The world will instantly pay heed to those who can speak coherently and pleasingly.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Viraindhu Thozhilketkum Gnaalam
Nirandhinidhu
Solludhal Vallaarp Perin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The world will quickly carry out
The words of counsellors astute.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Swiftly the listening world will gather round,
When men of mighty speech the weighty theme propound.
Various Translators: Upon finding men whose forceful speech is couched in cogent and enchanting ways, the world swiftly gathers around.
Dinamalar: Cogent reasoning and soft speech can bring the people over to one’s side.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those fond of talking much
Cannot be brief and faultless.
Transliteration: They will desire to utter many words, who do not know how to speak a few faultless ones.
T.Kannan:
Those fond of talking much Cannot be brief
and faultless.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who know not how to converse clearly and flawlessly in a few words, love to speak profusely.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Palasollak Kaamuruvar Mandramaa
Satra
Silasollal Thetraa Thavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They overspeak who do not seek 
A few and flawless words to speak.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who have not skill ten faultness to utter plain,
Their tongues will itch with thousand words men's ears to pain.
Various Translators: Those who cannot say a few words correctly will evince a desire to speak much.
Dinamalar: Unaware of the artful use of a few flawless words, men become enamored with excessive verbiage.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those who can't express what they have learnt
Are a bunch of flowers without scent.
Transliteration: Those who are unable to set forth their acquirements (before others) are like flowers blossoming in a cluster and yet without fragrance.
T.Kannan:
Those who can't express what they have
learnt Are a bunch of flowers without scent.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who cannot convey, and make others comprehend, what they have learnt, are like a bunch of bloomed flowers that have no fragrance.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Inaruzhththum Naaraa Malaranaiyar
Katradhu
Unara Viriththuraiyaa Thaar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who can't express what they have learnt 
Are bunch of flowers not fragrant.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who cannot explain well what they have learnt resemble the odourless flowers with their petals open.
Various Translators:
Like scentless flower in blooming garland bound
Are men who can't their lore acquired to other's ears expound.
Dinamalar: Men who cannot communicate their knowledge to others resemble a bouquet of unfragrant flowers in full bloom.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Good friendships bring wealth to a man, but goodness of action fulfills his every wish.
Transliteration: The efficacy of support will yield (only) wealth; (but) the efficacy of action will yield all that is desired.
T.Kannan:
Good alliance brings success;
And good deeds all one needs.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Good alliance brings success; And good
deeds all one needs.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Good companions lead to valuable gains, and good deeds lead to everything needed.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A man’s friends bring prosperity to him; but his good acts fetch him his wish.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thunainalam Aakkam Tharuum
Vinainalam
Ventiya Ellaan Tharum
Various Translators:
Friendship brings gain; but action pure 
Does every good thing we desire.
Dinamalar:
The good external help confers is worldly gain;
By action good men every needed gift obtain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Fame garnering actions of no real benefit should always be strictly avoided.
Transliteration: Ministers should at all times avoid acts which, in addition to fame, yield no benefit (for the future).
T.Kannan:
Avoid always deeds that do not lead to
Lasting good and fame.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: That deed must always be discarded which does not promote virtue and produce fame.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Avoid always deeds that do not lead to
Lasting good and fame.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: They should be desisted from forever: deeds not leading to the good and yielding fame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Endrum Oruvudhal Ventum Pukazhotu
Nandri Payavaa Vinai
Various Translators:
Eschew always acts that do not 
Bring good nor glory on their part.
Dinamalar:
From action evermore thyself restrain
Of glory and of good that yields no gain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who tell themselves that nobler things shall yet be won,
All deeds that dim the light of glory must they shun.
Transliteration: Those who say, "we will become (better)" should avoid the performance of acts that would destroy (their fame).
T.Kannan: Declaring that their future will be brighter, men must desist from deeds that darken glory’s light.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those who seek greatness must avoid
What will stain their name.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who wish to become great must always avoid deeds which darken the lustre of their reputation.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those who seek greatness must avoid What
will stain their name.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: They who seek greater heights should shun deeds that dent their reputation.
Various Translators:
Oodhal Ventum Olimaazhkum Seyvinai
Aaadhum Ennu Mavar
Dinamalar:
Those in the world desire for fame
Should shun the deed that dims their name.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who have infallible judgement though threatened with peril will not do acts which have brought disgrace (on former ministers).
Transliteration:
Though troubles press, no shameful deed they do.
Whose eyes the ever during vision view.
T.Kannan: However troubled the times, men of imperturbable perception never commit shameful or sordid deeds.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Men of clear understanding
Will not do mean acts even in distress.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Even adversity does not prompt men of unswerving purity to do mean things.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Men of clear understanding Will not do
mean acts even in distress.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even in distress, they won’t do deplorable deeds, those with unfaltering clarity and vision.
Various Translators:
Itukkan Patinum Ilivandha Seyyaar
Natukkatra Kaatchi Yavar
Dinamalar:
Though perils press the faultless wise 
Shun deeds of mean, shameful device.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Do not wrong act and grieve, "Alas" 
If done, do not repeat it twice.
Transliteration:
Do nought that soul repenting must deplore.
If thou hast sinned, 'tis well if thou dost sin no more.
T.Kannan: Do nothing that would make you regret, “What have I done!” However, if regrettable deeds occur, do not remain regretful.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Desist from deeds which you may regret later; but if you once happen to do such a deed, repeat it not.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Do not do what you will regret; and if you do,
Better not repeat the same.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Do not do what you will regret; and if you
do, Better not repeat the same.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: ‘What have I done?’. do not do deeds leading to such regret; even if you do, do not ever repeat them.
Various Translators: Let a minister never do acts of which he would have to grieve saying, "what is this I have done"; (but) should he do (them), it were good that he grieved not.
Dinamalar:
Etrendru Iranguva Seyyarka Seyvaanel
Matranna Seyyaamai Nandru

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Eendraal Pasikaanpaan Aayinunj
Cheyyarka
Saandror Pazhikkum Vinai
Transliteration:
Though she who begot thee hungers
Shun acts denounced by ancient seers.
T.Kannan:
Though her that bore thee hung'ring thou behold, no deed
Do thou, that men of perfect soul have crime decreed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Though he must behold his own mother’s hunger, let a man desist from deeds condemned by wise men.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Though you find your mother starving, do not do anything which will be condemned by the great.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Do not do what the wise condemn
Even to save your starving mother.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though a minister may see his mother starve; let him do not act which the wise would (treat with contempt).
Various Translators:
Do not do what the wise condemn Even to
save your starving mother.
Dinamalar: Even when you see your mother starving, don’t do deeds deplored by those, noble and respected.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Far better than ill-gotten wealth is the extreme poverty fallen on the noble and exemplary.
Transliteration:
Pazhimalaindhu Eydhiya Aakkaththin
Saandror
Kazhinal Kurave Thalai
T.Kannan:
Pinching poverty of the wise
Is more than wealth hoarded by Vice.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Than store of wealth guilt laden souls obtain,
The sorest poverty of perfect soul is richer gain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Better the poverty adopted by the great than the wealth resulting from sin.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The worst poverty of worthy men is more worthwhile than the greatest wealth amassed by wrongful means.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Better the pinching poverty of the wise
Than the pile of wealth hoarded by vice.
Various Translators: Far more excellent is the extreme poverty of the wise than wealth obtained by heaping up of sinful deeds.
Dinamalar:
Better the pinching poverty of the wise
Than the pile of wealth hoarded by vice.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ends achieved without any regard to the
means Will bring grief..
Transliteration: Though successful, they yield nothing but pain, when deplorable deeds are done rather than being shunned.
T.Kannan:
Katindha Katindhoraar Seydhaarkku
Avaidhaam
Mutindhaalum Peezhai Tharum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those who dare a forbidden deed 
Suffer troubles though they succeed.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who do knowingly forbidden things will suffer in the end, although they may succeed in doing them.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To those who hate reproof and do forbidden thing,
What prospers now, in after days shall anguish bring.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Forbidden deeds, however well accomplished, inflict sorrow on those who seek after rather than shun them.
Various Translators:
Ends achieved without any regard to the means
Will bring grief..
Dinamalar: The actions of those, who have not desisted from doing deeds forbidden (by the great), will, even if they succeed, cause them sorrow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What's gained with other's tears will go
in tears; What's won fair, though lost, will surge
again.
Transliteration: What is acquired with others’ tears, goes away with your tears; good deeds, even if begun with losses, will yield fruits later on.
T.Kannan: What is secured by causing tears to others will be lost with tears. But good deeds will result in good later.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Azhak Konta Ellaam Azhappom
IzhappinumPirpayakkum Narpaa Lavai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Gains from weeping, weeping go
Though lost, from good deeds blessings flow.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What's gained through tears with tears shall go;
From loss good deeds entail harvests of blessings grow.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What is gained by tears will go by tears. Even if it begins with loss, in the end, goodness gives many good things.
Various Translators: All that has been obtained with tears (to the victim) will depart with tears (to himself); but what has been by fair means; though with loss at first, will afterwards yield fruit.
Dinamalar:
What's gained with other's tears will go in tears;
What's won fair, though lost, will surge again.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A minister who promotes his king’s resources by fraud is like one who tries to store up water in a pot of unburnt clay.
Transliteration:
Stocking ill-got wealth is like storing
Water in an unbaked pot.
T.Kannan: Being content with ill-gotten wealth, is like storing water in a fresh unbaked mud pot.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Salaththaal Porulseydhe Maarththal
Pasuman
Kalaththulneer Peydhireei Yatru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The wealth gathered in guilty ways 
Is water poured in wet clay vase.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In pot of clay unburnt he water pours and would retain.
Who seeks by wrong the realm in wealth and safety to maintain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Protecting the country with wrongly garnered wealth is like preserving water in an unbaked clay pot.
Various Translators: (For a minister) to protect (his king) with wealth obtained by foul means is like preserving a vessel of wet clay by filling it with water.
Dinamalar:
Stocking ill-got wealth is like storing
Water in an unbaked pot.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Determination in action is one’s resolution. All others are nothing.
Transliteration:
Efficiency consists in a resolute mind.
Other things come thereafter.
T.Kannan: Execution focus lies in the resolve of the mind; all else is secondary.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Vinaiththitpam Enpadhu Oruvan
Manaththitpam
Matraiya Ellaam Pira
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A powerful mind does powerful act
And all the rest are imperfect.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What men call ' power in action 'know for' power of mind';
Externe to man all other aids you find.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Firmness in action is (simply) one's firmness of mind; all other (abilities) are not of this nature.
Various Translators: What is called resoluteness of action is, in truth, resoluteness of mind. It is a quality unlike any other.
Dinamalar:
Efficiency consists in a resolute mind.
Other things come thereafter.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Ministers versed in lore will not do unprofitable deeds, and if they do, they will not regret it.
Transliteration:
To avoid failures and not to give up
despite failures Are the two traits scholars
emphasize.
T.Kannan: Doing flawlessly, and resolute in the event of a flaw, are the paths shown by the learned.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Oororaal Utrapin Olkaamai Ivvirantin
Aarenpar Aaindhavar Kol
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Shun failing fuss; fail not purpose 
These two are maxims of the wise.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Not to perform a ruinous act, and not to be discouraged by the ruinous termination of an act, are the two maxims which, the wise say, from the principles of those who have investigated the subject.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Each hindrance shun','unyielding onward press, if obstacle be there'
These two define you way, so those that search out truth declare.
Various Translators: Avoiding all failure prone action and remaining undiscouraged by failures are said to be the dual directives of wise men.
Dinamalar:
To avoid failures and not to give up despite failures
Are the two traits scholars emphasize.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Reveal thy means in the end. Premature disclosure
Can cause irrevocable damage.
Transliteration:
Reveal thy means in the end. Premature
disclosure Can cause irrevocable damage.
T.Kannan: Virility lies in taking a task to completion; giving up midway causes endless misery.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: So to perform an act as to publish it (only) at its termination is (true) manliness; for to announce it beforehand, will cause irremediable sorrow.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
663, Kataikkotkach Cheydhakka
Thaanmai
ItaikkotkinEtraa Vizhuman Tharum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The strong achieve and then display 
Woe unto work displayed midway.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Man's fitting work is known but by success achieved;
In midst the plan revealed brings ruin ne'er to be retrieved.
Various Translators: Revealing an action after its completion is resoluteness. Disclosing an action midway causes endless misery.
Dinamalar: A clever minister publishes a deed after its completion; if it becomes public in the intermediate stage, it will end in trouble.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
It is easy for anyone to speak,
But difficult to execute what has been spoken.
Transliteration: To say (how an act is to be performed) is (indeed) easy for any one; but far difficult it is to do according to what has been said.
T.Kannan:
It is easy for anyone to speak, But
difficult to execute what has been spoken.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Easy it is, to say; rare it is, the ability to do what one says.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Solludhal Yaarkkum Eliya Ariyavaam
Solliya Vannam Seyal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Easy it is to tell a fact 
But hard it is to know and act.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Easy to every man the speech that shows the way;
Hard thing to shape one's life by words they say!
Various Translators: It is easy for anyone to speak of a plan, but difficult indeed to execute what has been spoken.
Dinamalar: It is easy for one to say, but it is difficult to do it in the said manner.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Dynamic deeds of brave souls
Will reach the king to win his praise.
Transliteration: The firmness in action of those who have become great by the excellence (of their counsel) will, by attaining its fulfilment in the person of the king, be esteemed (by all).
T.Kannan:
Dynamic deeds of brave souls Will reach
the king to win his praise.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who have gained great acclaim for their execution resolve, bring good to their rulers, and are hence thought of highly.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Veereydhi Maantaar Vinaiththitpam
Vendhankan
Ooreydhi Ullap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Dynamic deeds of a doughty soul 
Shall win the praise of king and all.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The power in act of men renowned and great,
With king acceptance finds and fame through all the state.
Various Translators: The resolution of a thoughtful and good minister in strengthening his monarch will earn all praise.
Dinamalar: Strong willed exploits of virtuous men win the crown’s respect and the crowd’s acclaim.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What is sought will be got as desired
If only the seeker is determined.
Transliteration: If those who have planned (an undertaking) possess firmness (in executing it) they will obtain what they have desired even as they have desired it.
T.Kannan:
What is sought will be got as desired If
only the seeker is determined.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: What they seek, they will achieve as they seek, if those who seek are made of firm resolve.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Enniya Enniyaangu Eydhu Enniyaar
Thinniyar Aakap Perin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The will to do achieves the deed
When mind that wills is strong indeed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Firm of purpose, ministers carry out their resolution.
Various Translators:
Whate'er men think, ev'n as they think, may men obtain,
If those who think can steadfastness of will retain.
Dinamalar: Those who think will have their thoughts fulfilled, just as they thought, provided they possess strength of will.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Do not disparage men who appear small, for there are those, seemingly insignificant, who are like the linchpin of a mighty chariot.
Transliteration: Let none be despised for (their) size; (for) the world has those who resemble the linch-pin of the big rolling car.
T.Kannan:
Despise not by looks! Even linchpins hold in place
The wheels of mighty chariots!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Despise not by looks! Even linchpins hold
in place The wheels of mighty chariots!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Deride not a person seeing their appearance; there are those who are like a small lynchpin that make a large chariot roll.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Do not despise one for lack of personality. Does not the little nail of the chariot keep the wheel going?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Uruvukantu Ellaamai Ventum
Urulperundherkku
Achchaani Annaar Utaiththu
Various Translators:
Scorn not the form: for men there are 
Like linchpin of big rolling car.
Dinamalar:
Despise not men of modest bearing; 
Look not at form , but what men are;For some there live, high functions sharing, Like linch pin of the mighty car!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Visualize actions with unclouded clarity, then forcefully undertake them without delay or indecision.
Transliteration: An act that has been firmly resolved on must be as firmly carried out without delay.
T.Kannan:
Acts resolved without ambiguity
Should be unwaveringly carried out without delay.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: What you have clearly decided to do, do it without hesitation and delay.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Acts resolved without ambiguity Should be
unwaveringly carried out without delay.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Do the task that you conceived with clarity of thought, unwaveringly and without procrastination.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kalangaadhu Kanta Vinaikkan
Thulangaadhu
Thookkang Katindhu Seyal
Various Translators:
Waver not; do wakefully 
The deed resolved purposefully.
Dinamalar:
What clearly eye discerns as right, with steadfast will,
And mind unslumbering , that should man fulfil.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Though toil and trouble face thee, firm resolve hold fast,
And do the deeds that pleasure yeild at last.
Transliteration: Though it should cause increasing sorrow (at the outset), do with firmness the act that yield bliss (in the end).
T.Kannan: Despite dire hardships, hold to strength of mind and do those deeds which yield joy of heart.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
However great the hardship,
Pursue with firmness the act that yields bliss.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Be resolute in deed which ends in happiness, though troublesome at the beginning.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
However great the hardship, Pursue with
firmness the act that yields bliss.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even if it causes distress while doing, daringly do the task that brings joy.
Various Translators:
Thunpam Uravarinum Seyka Thunivaatri
Inpam Payakkum Vinai
Dinamalar:
Do with firm will though pains beset 
The deed that brings delight at last.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The great will not esteem those who esteem not firmness of action, whatever other abilities the latter may possess.
Transliteration:
The world desires not men of every power possessed,
Who power in act desire not, crown of all the rest.
T.Kannan: The world has no use for those who have no use for resolute action, whatever other strengths they may possess.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The world has no place for those who,
Despite other strengths, have no strength of firmness.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The world will not esteem him who has no determined will, notwithstanding his other strong virtues.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The world has no place for those who,
Despite other strengths, have no strength of firmness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Whatever ability they may have acquired, the world desires them not, when they desire not the resoluteness to execute.
Various Translators:
Enaiththitpam Ey Thiyak Kannum
VinaiththitpamVentaarai Ventaadhu Ulaku
Dinamalar:
The world merits no other strength
But strength of will to do at length.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When counsel takes a resolve strong 
Weak delay of action is wrong.
Transliteration:
Resolve is counsel's end. If resolutions halt
In weak delays, still unfulfilled, 'tis grievous fault.
T.Kannan: Deliberation ends when a decision is reached. To delay that decision’s execution is detrimental.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Decision is the result of deliberation. It is harmful to rest it low.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The end of deliberation is decision.
To decide and dawdle is bad.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The end of deliberation is decision. To
decide and dawdle is bad.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The end of strategizing is gaining the confidence to execute; it is wasteful to cede that confidence in delays.
Various Translators: When a decision is reached, deliberation ends. To delay that decision's execution is detrimental.
Dinamalar:
Soozhchchi Mutivu Thuniveydhal
Aththunivu
Thaazhchchiyul Thangudhal Theedhu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Thoonguka Thoongich Cheyarpaala
Thoongarka
Thoongaadhu Seyyum Vinai
Transliteration:
Delay such acts as need delay 
Delay not acts that need display.
T.Kannan:
Slumber when sleepy work's in hand:beware
Thou slumber not when action calls for sleepless care!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Slumber when sleepy work awaits, but never rest when actions demand sleepless vigilance.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Delay such things as call for delay. But never delay that which cannot be delayed.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Delay where delay is needed,
But do not delay when you must act.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Slumber when sleepy work awaits, But never rest when actions demand sleepless vigilence.
Various Translators:
Delay where delay is needed, But do not
delay when you must act.
Dinamalar: Delay those tasks that better be delayed; delay not, those tasks that cannot be delayed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Act whenever possible; when not possible, do whatever is needed to make action possible.
Transliteration:
Ollumvaa Yellaam Vinainandre
Ollaakkaal
Sellumvaai Nokkich Cheyal
T.Kannan:
It's best to act when feasible
If not see what is possible.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
When way is clear, prompt let your action be;
When not, watch till some open path you see.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Achieve a thing wherever possible; if it were not possible adopt a cautious policy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Direct action is good whenever possible, but when it is not, seek other means of success.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Better strike wherever possible;
Elsewhere, consider other feasible means.
Various Translators: Direct action is good whenever feasible, but when it is not, seek other means of success.
Dinamalar:
Better strike wherever possible;
Elsewhere, consider other feasible means.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Both tasks and foes, if left unfinished,
Will destroy like fire left un-extinguished.
Transliteration: The remnants of a task and an enmity, (left unfinished, ) when we think of it, can harm as much as the remains of a fire.
T.Kannan:
Vinaipakai Endrirantin Echcham
Ninaiyungaal
Theeyechcham Polath Therum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Work or foe left unfinished
Flare up like fire unextinguished.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: An unfinished deed and an unfinished fight will like a half extinguished fire, cause ultimate harm.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
With work or foe, when you neglect some little thing,
If you reflect, like smouldering fire, 'twill ruin bring.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Reflect on this: efforts and enemies, if left unfinished, can both ravage you like an unextinguished fire.
Various Translators:
Both tasks and foes, if left unfinished,
Will destroy like fire left un-extinguished.
Dinamalar: Reflect on this: Both efforts and enemies, if left unfinished, Can destroy like an unextinguished fire.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Five things should be pondered before you
act: Resources, weapons, time, place and deed.
Transliteration: Resources, tools, time, place and the task. analyze these beyond doubt, and then act.
T.Kannan: Do a thing after carefully deliberating on five things; resources, means, the time, the nature of the deed, and the place.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Porulkaruvi Kaalam Vinaiyitanotu
Aindhum
Iruldheera Ennich Cheyal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Money and means, time, place and deed 
Decide these five and then proceed.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Treasure and instument and time and deed and place of act;
These five, till every doubt remove, think o'er with care exact.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Before acting, resolve all doubts by pondering five points: cost, means, time, place and the action itself.
Various Translators: Before acting resolve all doubts through consideration of these five: Cost, means, time, place and the action itself.
Dinamalar:
Five things should be pondered before you act:
Resources, weapons, time, place and deed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: In doing a thing, weigh deeply your aim, the hindrances and the final gain thereof.
Transliteration:
Weigh well before you plunge: The inputs,
impediments and gain.
T.Kannan: The means to the end, the obstacles and the fruits of the deed. anticipate all these, and then act.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Mutivum Itaiyoorum Mutriyaangu
Eydhum
Patupayanum Paarththuch Cheyal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Weigh well the end, hindrance, profit 
And then pursue a fitting act.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Accomplishment, the hindrances, large profits won
By effort: these compare, then let the work be done.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Discern the outcome of an enterprise, the obstacles and the opulent earnings that successful effort assures—then act.
Various Translators: Discern a deed's outcome, obstacles and opulent earnings Successful effort affirms - then act.
Dinamalar:
Weigh well before you plunge:
The inputs, impediments and gain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The manner in which a thing should be done is to be determined after consulting an expert.
Transliteration:
Experts have the expertise. Get that
expertise by knowing him inside out.
T.Kannan: One who is excellent at execution, executes after grasping the subtleties of all tasks from the experts.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seyvinai Seyvaan Seyanmurai Avvinai
Ullarivaan Ullam Kolal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Know first the secret from experts
That is the way of fruitful acts.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who would succeed must thus begin: first let him ask
The thoughts of them who throughly know the task.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The way to accomplish any task is to ascertain The inmost thoughts of an expert in that task.
Various Translators: The way to accomplish any task is to ascertain the inmost thoughts of an expert in that task.
Dinamalar:
Experts have the expertise.
Get that expertise by knowing him inside out.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Use one act to achieve another just as one wild elephant is used to capture another.
Transliteration:
Let one target be achieved through one's
action, Like an elephant through another.
T.Kannan: Using one task to accomplish another task, is like tethering a musth elephant using another.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Vinaiyaan Vinaiyaakkik Kotal
Nanaikavul
Yaanaiyaal Yaanaiyaath Thatru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Lure a tusker by a tusker 
Achieve a deed by deed better.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Just as one elephant may be used to tether another, So one task may be the means of accomplishing another.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
By one thing done you reach a second work's accomplishment;
So furious elephant to snare its fellow brute is sent.
Various Translators: Just as one elephant may be used to tether another, so one task may be the means of accomplishing another.
Dinamalar:
Let one target be achieved through one's action,
Like an elephant through another.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
More urgent than rewarding friends,
Is to befriend enemies.
Transliteration:
More urgent than rewarding friends, Is to
befriend enemies.
T.Kannan: More pressing than doing favors to friends, is befriending foes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Rather than bestow kind favors on friends, Hasten to befriend your unkind enemies.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nattaarkku Nalla Seyalin
Viraindhadhe
Ottaarai Ottik Kolal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Than doing good to friends it is 
More urgent to befriend the foes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Than kindly acts to friends more urgent thing to do,
Is making foes to cling as friends attached to you.
Various Translators: Before bestowing kind favors on friends, hasten to befriend those still estranged.
Dinamalar: It is much more urgent to secure the alliance of one’s enemies, than to do good to one’s friends.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If you are weak and fear internal trouble,
Seize conciliation with the strong.
Transliteration: Fearing their people's inner apprehensions, Men of minor realms bow before mightier rulers, accepting terms.
T.Kannan:
If you are weak and fear internal trouble,
Seize conciliation with the strong.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The smaller state, fearing internal panic, will submit to a superior power, if their concerns are addressed.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Uraisiriyaar Ulnatungal Anjik
Kuraiperin
Kolvar Periyaarp Panindhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Small statesmen fearing people's fear 
Submit to foes superior.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The men of lesser realm, fearing the people's inward dread,
Accepting granted terms, to mightier ruler bow the head.
Various Translators: Sensing with trepidation their peoples’ fears, leaders of minor realms bow and accept the terms of mightier rulers.
Dinamalar: Fearing that their weak king may quake with fear, ministers will bow before superior kings and accept their terms.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Kindliness, high birth, and a nature pleasing to kings
Are the qualities of an envoy.
Transliteration: The qualification of an ambassador are affection (for his relations) a fitting birth, and the possession of attributes pleasing to royalty.
T.Kannan:
Kindliness, high birth, and a nature
pleasing to kings Are the qualities of an envoy.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Love, birth in a suitable family, affable nature attractive to any king are qualities of an emissary.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Anputaimai Aandra Kutippiraththal
Vendhavaam
Panputaimai Thoodhuraippaan Panpu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Love, noble birth, good courtesy
Pleasing kings mark true embassy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Benevolence, high birth the courtesy kings love; 
These qualities the envoy of a king approve.
Various Translators: The characteristics of an ambassador are lovability, noble birth and other qualities which evoke the monarch’s respect.
Dinamalar: Kindliness, high birth and a nature congenial to kings comprise the innate disposition of an ambassador.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
An envoy's three essentials
Are loyalty, intelligence and sagacious speech.
Transliteration: Love (to his sovereign), knowledge (of his affairs), and a discriminating power of speech (before other sovereigns) are the three sine qua non qualifications of an ambassador.
T.Kannan:
An envoy's three essentials Are loyalty,
intelligence and sagacious speech.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Love, wisdom and sagacious speech are three qualities essential for an envoy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Anparivu Aaraaindha Solvanmai
Thoodhuraippaarkku
Indri Yamaiyaadha Moondru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Envoys must bear love for their prince 
Knowledge and learned eloquence.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Love, wisdom, ability to talk with full knowledge, are the three indispensable qualities of an ambassador.
Various Translators:
Love, knowledge, power of chosen words, three things,
Should he possess who speaks the words of kings.
Dinamalar: Kindliness, knowingness and deliberateness of speech are three necessities a diplomat finds indispensable.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: An envoy sent to announce to lance bearing monarchs his own king’s imminent victory must be a pandit among pandits.
Transliteration: To be powerful in politics among those who are learned (in ethics) is the character of him who speaks to lance-bearing kings on matters of triumph (to his own sovereign).
T.Kannan:
An envoy should be a scholar among the learned
To succeed among the powerful.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
An envoy should be a scholar among the
learned To succeed among the powerful.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: An emissary on a mission, seeking a diplomatic win over other rulers, should be erudite enough to excel amongst the erudite.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A skilful ambassador who wishes to gain his mission among other monarchs wielding the spear must be more learned than the learned.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Noolaarul Noolvallan Aakudhal
Velaarul
Vendri Vinaiyuraippaan Panpu
Various Translators:
Savant among savants, he pleads 
Before lanced king, triumphant words.
Dinamalar:
Mighty in lore amongst the learned must he be,
Midst jav'lin bearing kings who speaks the words of victory.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Send him on mission who possesses three attractive traits: well winnowed wisdom, modest dignity and ample learning.
Transliteration: He may go on a mission (to foreign rulers) who has combined in him all these three. viz., (natural) sense, an attractive bearing and well-tried learning.
T.Kannan:
Let him go on a mission who has these three:
Wisdom, personality and scholarship.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Only those who have wisdom, personality and mature scholarship must be sent on a mission.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Let him go on a mission who has these
three: Wisdom, personality and scholarship.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Wisdom, physical presence and thorough learning. he who has these three in abundance, let him be the one to go on a diplomatic mission.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Arivuru Vaaraaindha Kalviim Moondran
Serivutaiyaan Selka Vinaikku
Various Translators:
Who has these three: good form, sense, lore 
Can act as bold ambassador.
Dinamalar:
Sense, goodly grace, and knowledge exquisite,
Who hath these three for envoy's task is fit.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
In terms concise, avoiding wrathful speech who utters pleasant word,
An envoy he who gains advantage for his lord.
Transliteration: He is an ambassador who (in the presence of foreign rulers) speaks briefly, avoids harshness, talks so as to make them smile, and thus brings good (to his own sovereign).
T.Kannan: Whatever good an ambassador procures derives from succinct speech, cheerful conversation and avoidance of argument.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
An envoy's words should be compact,
Unoffending, pleasant and useful.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A good ambassador is he who can talk cogently and sweetly and who is not offensive even in saying things that are disagreeable.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
An envoy's words should be compact,
Unoffending, pleasant and useful.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Being coherent, avoiding objectionable words, and evoking smiles are the ways of an envoy to get desired results.
Various Translators:
Thokach Chollith Thoovaadha Neekki
NakachcholliNandri Payappadhaan Thoodhu
Dinamalar:
Not harsh, the envoy's winsome ways 
Does good by pleasant words concise.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He is an ambassador who having studied (politics) talks impressively, is not afraid of angry looks, and knows (to employ) the art suited to the time.
Transliteration:
An envoy meet is he , well learned of fearless eye
Who speaks right home, preparerd for each emergency.
T.Kannan: An envoy is educated, eloquently persuasive, unafraid of the fiercest stare and knows what befits the moment.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
An envoy should be well-read, fearless, persuasive,
And know what fits the occasion.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The envoy must be learned, fearless, persuasive and expedient.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
An envoy should be well-read, fearless,
persuasive, And know what fits the occasion.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A good envoy is well learned, can look anyone in the eye, has compelling speech and comes up with timely strategies.
Various Translators:
Katrukkan Anjaan Selachchollik
Kaalaththaal
Thakkadhu Arivadhaam Thoodhu
Dinamalar:
Learned; fearless, the envoy tends
Convincing words which time demands.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Knowing duty time and place 
The envoy employs mature phrase.
Transliteration:
He is the best who knows what's due, the time considered well,
The place selects, then ponders long ere he his errand tell.
T.Kannan: He is unsurpassed who knows duty and place, judges the suitable time and thinks before he speaks.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The best envoy states his case convincingly knowing his duty at the proper time and place.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The best know their mission, bide their time,
Wait for the occasion and think before speaking.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The best know their mission, bide their
time, Wait for the occasion and think before speaking.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Foremost among envoys is one who knows the task, weighs the time and place, and speaks with sagacity.
Various Translators: He is chief (among ambassadors) who understands the proper decorum (before foreign princes), seeks the (proper) occasion, knows the (most suitable) place, and delivers his message after (due) consideration.
Dinamalar:
Katanarindhu Kaalang Karudhi
Itanarindhu
Enni Uraippaan Thalai

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Thooimai Thunaimai Thunivutaimai
Immoondrin
Vaaimai Vazhiyuraippaan Panpu
Transliteration:
The true envoy of three virtues 
Is pure helpful and bold in views.
T.Kannan:
Integrity, resources, soul determined, truthfulness;
Who rightly speaks his message must these marks possess.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Integrity, influence and intrepidity—these three and truthfulness are qualities of one who faithfully delivers his monarch’s message.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The qualifications of a true envoy are morality, loyalty to his monarch and courage.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A truthful messenger should have these three qualities:
Goodness, friendliness and boldness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The qualifications of him who faithfully delivers his (sovereign's) message are purity, the support (of foreign ministers), and boldness, with truthfulness in addition to the (aforesaid) three.
Various Translators:
A truthful messenger should have these
three qualities: Goodness, friendliness and boldness.
Dinamalar: Principled, endearing and courageous. these three are qualities of an envoy conveying a message truthfully.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: An emissary conveying his ruler’s message to another, should be firm enough never to denigrate him even by slip of tongue.
Transliteration:
Vitumaatram Vendharkku Uraippaan
Vatumaatram
Vaaiseraa Vanka Navan
T.Kannan:
The envoy who ports the king's message
Has flawless words and heart's courage.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
His faltering lips must utter no unworthy thing,
Who stands, with steady eye, to speak the mandates of his king.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who does not falter even when faced with personal danger is fit to deliver his king’s message.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Commission him to deliver the monarch’s mandates who has a steady gaze and never blurts out flawed words.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A king's herald will not even negligently
Utter words that leave a stain.
Various Translators: He alone is fit to communicate (his sovereign's) reply, who possesses the firmness not to utter even inadvertently what may reflect discredit (on the latter).
Dinamalar:
A king's herald will not even negligently
Utter words that leave a stain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A brave envoy braves his life to safeguard
The ruler's interests at any cost.
Transliteration: Even if it means meeting his own end, an emissary ought to further his leader’s ends.
T.Kannan:
Irudhi Payappinum Enjaadhu Iraivarku
Urudhi Payappadhaam Thoodhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Braving death the bold envoy
Assures his king's safety and joy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A true envoy delivers his message even at the risk of death.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Death to the faithful one his embassy may bring;
To envoy gains assured advantage for his king.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: An ambassador fearlessly extends his king’s glory, though he might thereby expend his own life.
Various Translators:
A brave envoy braves his life to safeguard
The ruler's interests at any cost.
Dinamalar: He is the ambassador who fearlessly seeks his sovereign's good though it should cost him his life (to deliver his message).

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Courtiers round a king, like men before a
fire, Should be neither too far nor too near.
Transliteration: Not too far, not too near. while being with an irritable ruler, resemble those warming before a fire.
T.Kannan: Those who personally serve the monarch do not go too near him or too far away from him, like those who warm themselves by the fire side.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Akalaadhu Anukaadhu Theekkaaivaar
Polka
Ikalvendharch Cherndhozhuku Vaar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Move with hostile kings as with fire 
Not coming close nor going far.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who warm them at the five draw not too near, nor keep too much aloof;
Thus let them act who dwell beneath of warlike kings the palace roof.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Associates of contentious kings should be like men warming themselves by a fire, moving neither too near nor too far away.
Various Translators: Ministers who serve under fickle-minded monarchs should, like those who warm themselves at the fire, be neither (too) far, nor (too) near.
Dinamalar:
Courtiers round a king, like men before a fire,
Should be neither too far nor too near.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Not to covet those things which are desired by the monarch produce lasting wealth.
Transliteration:
The way to gain gifts from a king Is not
to covet what he covets.
T.Kannan: Desiring not the objects of desire for the king, gives lasting riches through the king.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Mannar Vizhaipa Vizhaiyaamai
Mannaraal
Manniya Aakkan Tharum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Crave not for things which kings desire 
This brings thee their fruitful favour.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To those who prize not state that kings are wont to prize,
The king himself abundant wealth supplies.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Do not desire to get what the king desires to have, and the king himself will confer enduring wealth.
Various Translators: For ministers not to cover the things desired by their kings will through the kings themselves yield them everlasting wealth.
Dinamalar:
The way to gain gifts from a king
Is not to covet what he covets.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To save himself a minister must avoid gross faults, for it is difficult to please, once being found fault with.
Transliteration:
Beware and ward off faults. Suspicion once
aroused is hard to clear.
T.Kannan: If you deem it imperative, maintain impeccable decorum; it maybe tough to placate anyone, once they turn bitter.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Potrin Ariyavai Potral Katuththapin
Thetrudhal Yaarkkum Aridhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Guard thyself from petty excess 
Suspected least, there's no redress.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who would walk warily, let him of greater faults beware;
To clear suspicions once aroused is an achievement rare.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Ministers who would save themselves should avoid (the commission of) serious errors for if the king's suspicion is once roused, no one can remove it.
Various Translators: One wishing to be wary must beware of his own indiscretions. Once suspicions are aroused, they are rarely removed.
Dinamalar:
Beware and ward off faults.
Suspicion once aroused is hard to clear.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: In the presence of the great avoid whispering and smiling.
Transliteration:
Whisper not, nor exchange smiles, Amidst
illustrious august men.
T.Kannan: Whisper not in others’ ears nor giggle with them in the presence of dignified elders.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sevichchollum Serndha Nakaiyum
Aviththozhukal
Aandra Periyaa Rakaththu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Whisper not; nor smile exchange 
Amidst august men's assemblage.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: While in the presence of the sovereign, ministers should neither whisper to nor smile at others.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
All whispered words and interchange of smiles repress,
In presence of the men who kingly power possess.
Various Translators: In the presence of the great ones, never speak in whispers or exchange smiles with others.
Dinamalar:
Whisper not, nor exchange smiles,
Amidst illustrious august men.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Don't eavesdrop or pursue a king's secret.
Rather listen when secrets are revealed.
Transliteration:
Don't eavesdrop or pursue a king's secret.
Rather listen when secrets are revealed.
T.Kannan: Don’t eavesdrop on or badger about any confidential matter; hear it only when it is revealed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: (When the king is engaged) in secret counsel (with others), ministers should neither over-hear anything whatever nor pry into it with inquisitive questions, but (wait to) listen when it is divulged (by the king himself).
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Epporulum Oraar Thotaraarmar
Rapporulai
Vittakkaal Ketka Marai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Hear not, ask not the king's secret 
Hear only when he lets it out.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Seek not, ask not, the secret of the king to hear;
But if he lets the matter forth, give ear!
Various Translators: The emissary neither eavesdrops nor meddles into matters. Instead, he listens raptly when secrets are revealed.
Dinamalar: Let not the minister lend ear to the king’s secret or be inquisitive to know it. But let him listen to it when the king reveals it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Know his mood, consider the moment,
Avoid the unpleasant and speak the needful.
Transliteration: Knowing the (king's disposition and seeking the right time, (the minister) should in a pleasing manner suggest things such as are desirable and not disagreeable.
T.Kannan:
Know his mood, consider the moment, Avoid
the unpleasant and speak the needful.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Gauge the mood; await the ripe time; avoid what he abhors; and speak what is essential, such that it charms him.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kuripparindhu Kaalang Karudhi
Veruppila
Ventupa Vetpach Cholal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Discern his mood and time and tell 
No dislikes but what king likes well.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Knowing the signs, waiting for fitting time, with courteous care,
Things not displeasing, needful things, declare.
Various Translators: Sensing unspoken thoughts and ascertaining the ripe moment, speak of vital matters amiably, without offending others.
Dinamalar: Watch the mood of the monarch. Talk to him pleasantly and inoffensively.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Tell the useful and even when asked
Avoid always the useless.
Transliteration: Ministers should (always) give agreeable advice but on no occasion recommend useless actions, though requested (to do so).
T.Kannan:
Tell the useful and even when asked Avoid
always the useless.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Tell him what will enthrall him; but indulge not in useless small talk, even if he desires so.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vetpana Solli Vinaiyila Egngnaandrum
Ketpinum Sollaa Vital
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Tell pleasing things; and never tell 
Even if pressed what is futile.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Speak pleasant things, but never utter idle word;
Not though by monarch's ears with pleasure heard.
Various Translators: Speak desirable things though unasked, but abstain from profitless talk although solicited by him.
Dinamalar: Speak useful ideas that interest the sovereign. Always leave useless thoughts unspoken—even if he inquires.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Don't treat him lightly as young or kin
But act as befits his splendour.
Transliteration: Ministers should behave in accordance with the (Divine) light in the person of kings and not despise them saying, "He is our junior (in age) and connected with our family!".
T.Kannan:
Don't treat him lightly as young or kin
But act as befits his splendour.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Scorn him not because he is younger or is related; respect him for his position and reputation.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ilaiyar Inamuraiyar Endrikazhaar
Nindra
Oliyotu Ozhukap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As young and kinsman do not slight; 
Look with awe king's light and might.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Do not disrespect a king on the ground of age or kinship, but behave as befits his royalty.
Various Translators:
Say not, 'He's young, my kinsman, 'despising thus your king;
But reverence the glory kingly state doth bring.
Dinamalar: Never criticize the king because he is young or your own kin. Rather respect the resplendent dignity that kingship commands.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Men whose wisdom is unwavering do not use their high reputation to excuse lowly behavior.
Transliteration: Those whose judgement is firm will not do what is disagreeable (to the sovereign) saying (within themselves) "We are esteemed by the king".
T.Kannan:
Those with unwavering vision
Do not misuse their privileges and do wrong.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those with unwavering vision Do not misuse
their privileges and do wrong.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those with a clarity of purpose will refrain from acting repulsively thinking they command respect.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Men of high intelligence, respected by a king will not indulge in things revolting to him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kolappattem Endrennik Kollaadha
Seyyaar
Thulakkatra Kaatchi Yavar
Various Translators:
The clear visioned do nothing base 
Deeming they have the monarch's grace.
Dinamalar:
We've gained his grace, boots nought what graceless acts we do',
So deem not sages who the changeless vision view.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Men who do unworthy deeds, expecting the king’s indulgence because of a long standing friendship, warrant their own ruin.
Transliteration: The (foolish) claim with which a minister does unbecoming acts because of his (long) familiarity (with the king) will ensure his ruin.
T.Kannan:
Unworthy acts under the trust of old friendship
Lead to ruinous woes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: To take liberty under the cover of old acquaintance and do unwanted things is to court ill.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Unworthy acts under the trust of old
friendship Lead to ruinous woes.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Taking advantage of proximity to the top and acting out of character brings ruin.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Pazhaiyam Enakkarudhip Panpalla
Seyyum
Kezhudhakaimai Ketu Tharum
Various Translators:
Worthless acts based on friendship old 
Shall spell ruin and woe untold.
Dinamalar:
Who think' We're ancient friends, ' and do unseemly things;
To these familiarity sure ruin brings.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who knows the sign, and reads unuttered thought, the gem is he,
Of earth round traversed by the changeless sea.
Transliteration: The minister who by looking (at the king) understands his mind without being told (of it), will be a perpetual ornament to the world which is surrounded by a never-drying sea.
T.Kannan: He who can discern another’s unspoken thoughts by merely looking is an emerald on an Earth encircled by equable seas.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
He is a jewel on this sea-girt earth
Who can read a thought without being told.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who is able to divine one’s hidden intentions is a jewel among men on this sea-girt earth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
He is a jewel on this sea-girt earth Who
can read a thought without being told.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He who reads minds by observing, with no words spoken, is ever an adornment for the world with unchanging oceans.
Various Translators:
701 Kooraamai Nokkake Kuripparivaan
EgngnaandrumMaaraaneer Vaiyak Kani
Dinamalar:
Who reads the mind by look, untold 
Adorns the changeless sea girt world.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He is to be esteemed a god who is able to ascertain without a doubt what is within (one's mind).
Transliteration:
Undoubting, who the minds of men scan,
As deity regard that gifted man.
T.Kannan: Regard as god like those who can divine without hesitation what is in the minds of others.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Deem that man on par with God
Who can divine with conviction what is in the heart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who would speak out fearlessly what he feels will be regarded equal to God.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Deem that man on par with God Who can
divine with conviction what is in the heart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Rate him amongst gods, he who can read minds with indubitable certainty.
Various Translators:
Aiyap Pataaadhu Akaththadhu
Unarvaanaith
Theyvaththo Toppak Kolal
Dinamalar:
Take him as God who reads the thought
Of another man without a doubt.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
By sign who scans the sign admit 
At any cost in cabinet.
Transliteration:
Who by the sign the signs interprets plain,
Give any member up his aid to gain.
T.Kannan: Give whatever is required to gain an advisor who, knowing his own mind, can read another’s intentions.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The king at any cost should secure among his associates one who can discover by intuition another’s unexpressed thoughts.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
He is worth any price who by intuition
can read another's thought.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
He is worth any price who by intuition can
read another's thought.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who can read others’ minds by observing their own minds- if need be, give any of your organs to have them with you.
Various Translators: The king should ever give whatever (is asked) of his belongings and secure him who, by the indications (of his own mind) is able to read those of another.
Dinamalar:
Kurippir Kurippunar Vaarai Uruppinul
Yaadhu Kotuththum Kolal

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Kuriththadhu Kooraamaik Kolvaaro
Tenai
Uruppo Ranaiyaraal Veru
Transliteration:
Untold, he who divines the thought 
Though same in form is quite apart.
T.Kannan:
Who reads what's shown by signs, thought words unspoken be,
In form may seem as other men, in function nobler far is he.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who grasp others’ unspoken thoughts have the same physical features as most folks—yet how different they are.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who are able to discover unexpressed thoughts may be deemed superior to other’s service.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A thought reader may resemble other men
But is a class apart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who understand one's thoughts without being informed (thereof) and those who do not, may (indeed) resemble one another bodily; still are they different (mentally).
Various Translators:
A thought reader may resemble other men
But is a class apart.
Dinamalar: Who can sense thoughts without being told, they are distinct, resembling others only in their human forms.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If one can’t observe and interpret body language, what purpose do eyes serve amongst the organs?
Transliteration:
Kurippir Kurippunaraa Vaayin
Uruppinul
Enna Payaththavo Kan?
T.Kannan:
Among senses what for is eye 
If thought by thought one can't descry?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
By sign who knows not signs to comprehend, what again,
'Mid all his members, from his eyes does he obtain?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Of what avail is the eye, among the organs of sense, if it does not note another’s intentions?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Of what benefit are eyes in a body, if they cannot by their observing powers perceive another’s intentions?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What use are the eyes among senses,
If they cannot read a man's thoughts on his face?
Various Translators: Of what use are the eyes amongst one's members, if they cannot by their own indications dive those of another ?.
Dinamalar:
What use are the eyes among senses, If
they cannot read a man's thoughts on his face?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Like a mirror that shows what is in front,
The face reveals the affairs of the mind.
Transliteration: The face, like a crystal that shows the hues of objects around, betrays the mood of the mind.
T.Kannan:
Atuththadhu Kaattum Palingupol
Nenjam
Katuththadhu Kaattum Mukam
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What throbs in mind the face reflects 
Just as mirror nearby objects.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Like a mirror that reflects what is near it, the face will show what passes in the mind.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As forms around in crystal mirrored clear we find.
The face will show what's throbbing in the mind.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: As a crystal mirror reflects objects that are nearby, so the face reflects what is foremost in the heart.
Various Translators:
Like a mirror that shows what is in front,
The face reveals the affairs of the mind.
Dinamalar: As the mirror reflects what is near so does the face show what is uppermost in the mind.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What can be more expressive than the face
To reveal the mind's pleasure and pain?
Transliteration: What can be smarter than the face? It is quick to sense and show if the heart is pleased or peeved.
T.Kannan: Is there anything more expressive than the face which is an index as well as agony?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Mukaththin Mudhukkuraindhadhu Unto
Uvappinum
Kaayinum Thaanmun Thurum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Than face what is subtler to tell 
First if the mind feels well or ill.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Than speaking countenance hath aught more prescient skill?
Rejoice or burn with rage, 'tis the first herald still!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What is more forthrightly profound than the face? For whether the heart is angry or glad, the face expresses it first.
Various Translators: Is there anything so full of knowledge as the face ? (No.) it precedes the mind, whether (the latter is) pleased or vexed.
Dinamalar:
What can be more expressive than the face
To reveal the mind's pleasure and pain?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If you come across one, who can read your face, study one’s face as one does yours.
Transliteration:
Just standing in front would suffice For
those who can read the mind on face.
T.Kannan: When those who can look into your heart and know your intentions, be with you, tasks will be accomplished if you just face them.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Mukamnokki Nirka Amaiyum Akamnokki
Utra Thunarvaarp Perin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Just standing in front would suffice 
For those who read the mind on face.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To see the face is quite ehough, in presence brought,
When men can look within and know the lurking thought.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If you find a man who understands matters by looking into the mind, it suffices to stand silently looking into his face.
Various Translators: If the king gets those who by looking into his mind can understand (and remove) what has occurred (to him) it is enough that he stand looking at their face.
Dinamalar:
Just standing in front would suffice
For those who can read the mind on face.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The eye proclaims friendliness and hostility to one who can read the message of the eyes.
Transliteration:
Those familiar with the language of eyes
Can read from eyes both love and hatred.
T.Kannan: The eyes will convey the animosity or affinity to those who can decipher the subtleties of the eyes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pakaimaiyum Kenmaiyum Kannuraikkum
Kannin
Vakaimai Unarvaarp Perin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Friend or foe the eyes will show 
To those who changing outlooks know.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The eye speaks out the hate or friendly soul of man;
To those who know the eye's swift varying moods to scan.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If a king gets ministers who can read the movements of the eye, the eyes (of foreign kings) will (themselves) reveal (to him) their hatred or friendship.
Various Translators: If you find men who know the eye’s language the eyes will speak to them of hidden hate and love.
Dinamalar:
Those familiar with the language of eyes
Can read from eyes both love and hatred.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There is no other measuring rod, used by intelligent ministers than the monarch’s eye.
Transliteration:
You will find smart people use nothing but
eyes As a yardstick for measure.
T.Kannan: The scale used by the astute to gauge the emotions, if you think of it, is nothing but the eyes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nunniyam Enpaar Alakkungol
Kaanungaal
Kannalladhu Illai Pira
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The scale of keen discerning minds 
Is eye and eye that secrets finds.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The measuring-rod of those (ministers) who say "we are acute" will on inquiry be found to be their (own) eyes and nothing else.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The men of keen discerning soul no other test apply
(when you their secret ask) than man's revealing eye.
Various Translators: Observe those who are said to see subtly with their mind’s eye— their singular measuring rod is their eyes.
Dinamalar:
You will find smart people use nothing but eyes
As a yardstick for measure.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Meticulous masters of words
Must judge the council before they speak.
Transliteration:
Meticulous masters of words Must judge the
council before they speak.
T.Kannan: Those who are well versed with the various ways of speech, know and assess the audience before speaking.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Let the pure who know the arrangement of words speak with deliberation after ascertaining (the nature of) the court (then assembled).
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Avaiyarinadhu Aaraaindhu Solluka
Sollin
Thokaiyarindha Thooimai Yavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The pure in thought and eloquence 
Adapt their words to audience.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Men pure in heart, who know of words the varied force,
Should to their audience known adapt their well arranged discourse.
Various Translators: Pure men of studied eloquence should study an audience before speaking deliberate words.
Dinamalar: Men should weigh their words in speaking when addressing an audience.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Should skilled orators wish to speak,
Let them study the occasion with care.
Transliteration: Let the good who know the uses of words speak with a clear knowledge after ascertaining the time (suited to the court).
T.Kannan:
Should skilled orators wish to speak, Let
them study the occasion with care.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Before speaking, anticipate the reaction of the audience and master the subject, if you are conversant with the modes of expression.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Itaidherindhu Nankunarndhu Solluka
Sollin
Nataidherindha Nanmai Yavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who know the art of speech shall suit 
Their chosen words to time in fact.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Good men to whom the arts of eloquence are known,
Should seek occasion meet, and say what well they've made their own.
Various Translators: Let good men who know the orator’s art knowingly await the right moment to articulate their good knowledge.
Dinamalar: Good people who know the value of the language they employ, must speak noting how their words are received.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Only poor orators, good for nothing, speak at length
Without knowing the audience.
Transliteration: Those who undertake to speak without knowing the (nature of the) court are ignorant of the quality of words as well as devoid of the power (of learning).
T.Kannan:
Only poor orators, good for nothing, speak
at length Without knowing the audience.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who know not their audience and yet endeavor to speak, know not the styles of speech and their reach, nor can they be competent.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Avaiyariyaar Sollalmer Kolpavar
Sollin
Vakaiyariyaar Valladhooum Il
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They speak in vain at length who talk 
Words unversed which ears don't take.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Unversed in councils, who essays to speak,
Knows not the way of suasive words, and all is weak.
Various Translators: The learning of those who speak without taking into consideration the assembly addressed or ignorant of the art of speaking can be of no use to them.
Dinamalar: Failing to assess an audience before venturing to speak is to be unaware of the way of words and remain ineffective.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Before the bright, be brilliant light.
Before the dull, assume mortar white.
Transliteration: Ministers should be lights in the assembly of the enlightned, but assume the pure whiteness of mortar (ignorance) in that of fools.
T.Kannan:
Before the bright, be brilliant light.
Before the dull, assume mortar white.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Be brilliant before the bright, and amidst the ignorant turn blank as a wall plastered white.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Oliyaarmun Olliya Raadhal
Veliyaarmun
Vaansudhai Vannam Kolal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Before the bright be brilliant light 
Before the muff be mortar white.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Before brilliant people be brilliant; before plain people be as plain as white chalk.
Various Translators:
Before the bright ones shine as doth the light!
Before the dull ones be as purest stucco white!
Dinamalar: Be brilliant before brilliant men; but assume the dullness of pale mortar before dullards.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Of all good things, the best is the polite reserve that refrains from speaking first when with elders and superiors.
Transliteration: The modesty by which one does not rush forward and speak in (an assembly of) superiors is the best among all (one's) good qualities.
T.Kannan:
The best amongst all good qualities
Is the modesty to holdback before elders.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The best amongst all good qualities Is the
modesty to holdback before elders.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It is the best among all the good deeds to have the restraint to not speak out of turn, in a forum of learned elders.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The humility to maintain silence before superiors is the best of all good qualities.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Nandrendra Vatrullum Nandre
Mudhuvarul
Mundhu Kilavaach Cherivu
Various Translators:
Modest restraint all good excels
Which argues not before elders.
Dinamalar:
Midst all good things the best is modest grace,
That speaks not first before the elders' face.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To blunder before perceptive, erudite men is like slipping and falling from a very high place.
Transliteration: (For a minister) to blunder in the presence of those who have acquired a vast store of learning and know (the value thereof) is like a good man stumbling (and falling away) from the path (of virtue).
T.Kannan:
To slip before men of wide learning
Is like slipping from the path of righteousness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: To be censured by an assembly of the learned wise is like losing one’s balance while on the road to salvation.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To slip before men of wide learning Is
like slipping from the path of righteousness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: It will tantamount to swerving from the righteous path, being disgraced before an audience, widely-read but highly-receptive.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Aatrin Nilaidhalarn Thatre
Viyanpulam
Etrunarvaar Munnar Izhukku
Various Translators:
Tongue slip before the talented wise 
Is like slipping from righteous ways.
Dinamalar:
As in the way one tottering falls, is slip before
The men whose minds are filled with varied lore.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The learning of the learned sage shines bright,
To those whose faultless skill can value it aright.
Transliteration: The learning of those who have read and understood (much) will shine in the assembly of those who faultlessly examine (the nature of) words.
T.Kannan: A learned man’s learning shines the brightest among luminaries capable of critiquing his language.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The scholarship of a scholar shines
In an assembly of meticulous scholars.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The scholarship of the learned shines brilliantly before those who can appreciate faultless speech.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The scholarship of a scholar shines In an
