assembly of meticulous scholars.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The expertise of the erudite gets enhanced by addressing an audience capable of flawlessly grasping those words.
Various Translators:
Katrarindhaar Kalvi Vilangum
Kasatarach
Choldheridhal Vallaar Akaththu
Dinamalar:
The learning of the learned shines 
Valued by flawless scholar minds.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Lecturing to those who have the ability to understand (for themselves) is like watering a bed of plants that are growing (of themselves).
Transliteration:
To speak where understanding hearers you obtain,
Is sprinkling water on the fields of growing grain!
T.Kannan: Speaking to an audience of thinking men is like watering a bed of growing plants.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Speaking before a receptive audience
Is like watering a nursery of growing plants.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Speaking before the wise is like feeding crops with water.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Speaking before a receptive audience Is
like watering a nursery of growing plants.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To speak before an audience who possess clear understanding is like watering a sapling, growing by itself in a nursery.
Various Translators:
Unarva Thutaiyaarmun Sollal
Valarvadhan
Paaththiyul Neersorin Thatru
Dinamalar:
To address understanding ones 
Is to water beds of growing grains.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
O ye who speak before the keen 
Forgetful, address not the mean.
Transliteration:
In councils of the good, who speak good things with penetrating power,
In councils of the mean, let them say nought e'en in oblivious hour.
T.Kannan: Those who speak good things to good and learned gatherings should never repeat them to ignorant groups, even forgetfully.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who say good things before a good assembly should not even in forgetfulness say the same before the illiterate.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Don't tell an assembly of fools even forgetfully
Things meant for the wise.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Don't tell an assembly of fools even
forgetfully Things meant for the wise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who can speak lucidly in a learned forum should refrain from even forgetfully speaking the same in an unworthy forum.
Various Translators: Those who are able to speak good things impressively in an assembly of the good should not even forgetfully speak them in that of the low
Dinamalar:
Pullavaiyul Pochchaandhum Sollarka
Nallavaiyul
Nankusalach Chollu Vaar

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Anganaththul Ukka Amizhdhatraal
Thanganaththaar
Allaarmun Kotti Kolal
Transliteration:
To hostiles who wise words utters 
Pours ambrosia into gutters.
T.Kannan:
Ambrosia in the sewer spilt, is word,
Spoken in presence of the alien herd.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Expounding to a throng of unfit men is like pouring sweet nectar into an open gutter.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Entering an assembly of men of unequal respectability will be like pouring nectar in an unclean courtyard.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To deliberate with people of dissimilar interests
Is like spilling nectar in the drain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To utter (a good word) in the assembly of those who are of inferior rank is like dropping nectar on the ground.
Various Translators:
To deliberate with people of dissimilar
interests Is like spilling nectar in the drain.
Dinamalar: Speaking before an audience who are no match for you, is like throwing away the elixir of life into the drains.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who are well versed with the various ways of speech, will choose the right style for a forum, and won’t blunder out of fear.
Transliteration:
Vakaiyarindhu Vallavai Vaaisoraar
Sollin
Thokaiyarindha Thooimai Yavar
T.Kannan:
The pure fail not in power of words 
Knowing grand council's moods and modes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Men, pure in heart, who know of words the varied force,
The mighty council's moods discern, nor fail in their discourse.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The expert in the art of speaking will not flounder, addressing an assembly of the learned.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Unsullied men, skilled in discourse, may speak unfalteringly before the powerful, provided they understand their audience.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The pure skillful orators, knowing the council's strength,
Never fail in their speech.
Various Translators: The pure who know the classification of words having first ascertained the nature (of the court) will not (through fear) falter in their speech before the powerful body.
Dinamalar:
The pure skillful orators, knowing the
council's strength, Never fail in their speech.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Most learned among the learned is he Whose
learning the learned accept.
Transliteration: They are known the most learned amongst the learned, those who can express their learnings persuasively before a learned audience.
T.Kannan:
Katraarul Katraar Enappatuvar
Katraarmun
Katra Selachchollu Vaar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Among scholars he is scholar 
Who holds scholars with learned lore.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those will be deemed foremost among the learned, who can speak learned things acceptable to the learned.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who what they've learned, in penetrating words have learned to say,
Before the learn'd among the learn'd most learn'd are they.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Only the learned among learned can convincingly express what they have learned before a learned assembly.
Various Translators:
Most learned among the learned is he
Whose learning the learned accept.
Dinamalar: Those who can agreeably set forth their acquirements before the learned will be regarded as the most learned among the learned.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Many are ready to even die in battle, But
few can face an assembly without nerves.
Transliteration: Simple people, ready to die at the warfront, abound; those who fearlessly address an audience are a rare breed.
T.Kannan: Many die in the field of battle. But few are those who can fear fools addressing an assembly.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pakaiyakaththuch Chaavaar Eliyar
Ariyar
Avaiyakaththu Anjaa Thavar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Many brave foes and die in fields
The fearless few face wise councils.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Many encountering death in face of foe will hold their ground;
Who speak undaunted in the council hall are rarely found.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Men who can brave death on the battlefield are common; but rare are they who can face an audience without fear.
Various Translators: Many indeed may (fearlessly) die in the presence of (their) foes; (but) few are those who are fearless in the assembly (of the learned).
Dinamalar:
Many are ready to even die in battle,
But few can face an assembly without nerves.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Speak to the learned what you have learnt, and receive from them much that you have to learn.
Transliteration:
Let the learned learn from you, And you
from one more learned.
T.Kannan: Speak persuasively before the learned, what you have learnt, and absorb more from those who are more learned than you.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Katraarmun Katra Selachchollith
Thaamkatra
Mikkaarul Mikka Kolal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Impress the learned with your lore
From greater savants learn still more.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What you have learned, in penetrating words speak out before
The learn'd; but learn what men more learn'd can teach you more.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Speak confidently before the learned what you have mastered; and learn from those more learned what you do not know.
Various Translators: (Ministers) should agreeably set forth their acquirements before the learned and acquire more (knowledge) from their superiors (in learning).
Dinamalar:
Let the learned learn from you,
And you from one more learned.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Understand the full scope of learning and learn, so that you may, without fear, reply effectively in an assembly.
Transliteration:
Study the science of logic so that you may
Fearlessly reply in any assembly.
T.Kannan: Choose the right works and learn, knowing the limitations, so that you can debate fearlessly with any audience.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aatrin Alavarindhu Karka Avaiyanjaa
Maatrang Kotuththar Poruttu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Grammar and logic learn so that 
Foes you can boldly retort.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
By rule, to dialectic art your mind apply,
That in the council fearless you may make an apt reply.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: In order to reply fearlessly before a foreign court, (ministers) should learn logic according to the rules (of grammar).
Various Translators: Study the science of logic in order that you may fearlessly reply in any assembly.
Dinamalar:
Study the science of logic so that you may
Fearlessly reply in any assembly.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Of what use is the sword for the unvaliant? Likewise of what use is learning for the timid to face an assembly?
Transliteration:
What use is a sword to cowards And books
to those who fear assembly?
T.Kannan: What use is the sword to cowards? Of what use are books to those who fear a learned audience?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Vaaloten Vankannar Allaarkku
Nooloten
Nunnavai Anju Pavarkku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To cowards what can sword avail 
And books to those who councils fail?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: What have they to do with a sword who are not valiant, or they with learning who are afraid of an intelligent assembly ?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To those who lack the hero's eye what can the sword avail?
Or science what, to those before the council keen who quail?
Various Translators: What can a coward do with a sword? What can a man who fears an astute council do with books?
Dinamalar:
What use is a sword to cowards
And books to those who fear assembly?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
As a sword to a eunuch before his foes,
Is the learning to one who fears assembly.
Transliteration:
As a sword to a eunuch before his foes, Is
the learning to one who fears assembly.
T.Kannan: A sharp sword in the hands of a coward before foes, is the scholarship of him who fears a forum.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The learning of him who is diffident before an assembly is like the shining sword of an hermaphrodite in the presence of his foes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pakaiyakaththup Petikai Olvaal
Avaiyakaththu
Anju Mavankatra Nool
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Like eunuch's sword in field, is vain 
His lore who fears men of brain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As shining sword before the foe which 'sexless being' bears,
Is science learned by him the council's face who fears.
Various Translators: The learning of those who fearfully face an audience is like the shining saber of effeminate men facing foes.
Dinamalar: The learning of one afraid of an assembly is like the shining sword in the hands of an eunuch in a battle-field.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
They are useless however learned
Who cannot impress a learned assembly.
Transliteration: Those who cannot agreeably speak good things before a good assembly are indeed unprofitable persons inspite of all their various acquirements.
T.Kannan:
They are useless however learned Who
cannot impress a learned assembly.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: They may be of great learning but can serve no purpose if they shy away from speaking compellingly to a good audience.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pallavai Katrum Payamilare
Nallavaiyul
Nanku Selachchollaa Thaar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though learned much his lore is dead 
Who says no good before the good.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though many things they've learned, yet useless are they all,
To man who cannot well and strongly speak in council hall.
Various Translators: Having learned many things, men remain useless if they cannot speak well in good assemblies.
Dinamalar: Vain is the versed learning of one who can not address with profit a learned assembly.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Scholars dread of facing an assembly of good men
Are ranked lower than the ignorant.
Transliteration: They who, though they have learned and understood, are yet afraid of the assembly of the good, are said to be inferior (even) to the illiterate.
T.Kannan:
Scholars dread of facing an assembly of
good men Are ranked lower than the ignorant.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Though well learned, they’re considered worse than the ignorant, those who fear an assembly of good people.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kallaa Thavarin Kataiyenpa
Katrarindhum
Nallaa Ravaiyanju Vaar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who fear to face good assembly 
Are learned idiots, certainly.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who, though they've learned before the council of the good men quake,
Than men unlearn'd a lower place must take.
Various Translators: The learned who are afraid of a good assembly will be regarded as worse than the illiterate.
Dinamalar: Literary men intimidated by gatherings of good men are said to be inferior to the illiterate.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those stage-fearing who keep their learning to themselves,
Though living, are dead.
Transliteration: Those who through fear of the assembly are unable to set forth their learning in an interesting manner, though alive, are yet like the dead.
T.Kannan:
Those stage-fearing who keep their
learning to themselves, Though living, are dead.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Out of stage-fright, those who can’t articulate their learnings well, maybe alive but are as good as lifeless.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ulareninum Illaarotu Oppar
Kalananjik
Katra Selachchollaa Thaar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They are breathing dead who dare not 
Empress before the wise their art.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Dead though alive are those who are afraid to address an assembly on what they have learnt.
Various Translators:
Who what they've learned, in penetrating words know not to say,
The council fearing, though they live, as dead are they.
Dinamalar: Men whose fear of assemblies forbids them to share their knowledge, though living, may as well be dead.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Where unfailingly fertile fields, worthy men and wealthy merchants come together—that is a country!
Transliteration: A kingdom is that in which (those who carry on) a complete cultivation, virtuous persons, and merchants with inexhaustible wealth, dwell together.
T.Kannan:
Unfailing harvests, learned men and honest traders
Constitute a country.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Unfailing harvests, learned men and honest
traders Constitute a country.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Unfailing crops, exemplary people, and the wealthy with untarnished and undiminishing wealth, constitute a country.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: That is a kingdom which has undiminishing produce, righteous people and fadeless riches.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thallaa Vilaiyulum Thakkaarum
Thaazhvilaach
Chelvarum Servadhu Naatu
Various Translators:
It's country which has souls of worth 
Unfailing yields and ample wealth.
Dinamalar:
where spreads fertility unfailing, where resides a band,
Of virtuous men, and those of ample wealth, call that a 'land'.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A land coveted for its vast wealth, free from calamities and yielding in abundance is indeed a country.
Transliteration: A kingdom is that which is desire for its immense wealth, and which grows greatly in prosperity, being free from destructive causes.
T.Kannan:
A land is known for its great wealth
Of abundant produce that never declines.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: That is a kingdom which has boundless wealth coveted for by other nations and has imperishable fertile resources.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A land is known for its great wealth Of
abundant produce that never declines.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Desirable due to its huge wealth; devoid of detriments for high yields: such should a country be.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Perumporulaal Pettakka Thaaki
Arungettaal
Aatra Vilaivadhu Naatu
Various Translators:
The Land has large luring treasure 
Where pests are nil and yields are sure.
Dinamalar:
That is a 'land' which men desire for wealth's abundant share,
Yielding rich increase, where calamities are rare.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When burthens press, it bears; yet, with unfailing hand,
To king due tribute pays: that is the land.
Transliteration: A kingdom is that which can bear any burden that may be pressed on it (from adjoining kingdoms) and (yet) pay the full tribute to its sovereign.
T.Kannan: Call that a nation which bears every burden that befalls it, yet pays in full all tariffs owed to the king.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
An ideal land bears all burdens that befall
And yet pays all taxes to the king.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: That alone is a kingdom which accommodates immigrants and whose king receives taxes willingly paid.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
An ideal land bears all burdens that
befall And yet pays all taxes to the king.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: In an ideal country, its citizens bear any new burdens which, all at once, afflict them, and continue to willingly pay taxes.
Various Translators:
Poraiyorungu Melvarungaal Thaangi
Iraivarku
Iraiyorungu Nervadhu Naatu
Dinamalar:
It's land that bears pressing burdens 
And pays its tax which king demands.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A kingdom is that which continues to be free from excessive starvation, irremediable epidemics, and destructive foes.
Transliteration:
That is a land whose peaceful annals know,
Nor famine fierce, nor wasting plague, nor ravage of the foe.
T.Kannan: Free of famine, endless epidemics and ravaging foes— now that is a flourishing country.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
That is a land which is free of much hunger,
Incessant plagues and ravaging enemies.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: That is a kingdom where excessive hunger, incurable diseases and destructive enemies are absent.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
That is a land which is free of much
hunger, Incessant plagues and ravaging enemies.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Acute hunger, debilitating diseases and warring foes are absent in a good state.
Various Translators:
Urupasiyum Ovaap Piniyum
Serupakaiyum
Seraa Thiyalvadhu Naatu
Dinamalar:
It is country which is free from 
Fierce famine, plague and foemen's harm.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Sects and ruinous foes are nil 
No traitors in a land tranquil.
Transliteration:
From factions free, and desolating civil strife, and band
Of lurking murderers that king afflict, that is the land.
T.Kannan: Proliferating factions, ruinous subversives and murderous gangs harassing the king—a real country is free from all these.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: That is a kingdom where there are not many (disloyal) associations, destructive internal dissensions and disturbing murderous chieftains.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
That is a land free from factions,
Ruinous traitors and terrorists harassing kings.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
That is a land free from factions, Ruinous
traitors and terrorists harassing kings.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Multiple factions, destructive dissent, and murderous criminals who torment the rulers are not found in a good state.
Various Translators: A kingdom is that which is without various (irregular) associations, destructive internal enemies, and murderous savages who (sometimes) harass the sovereign.
Dinamalar:
Palkuzhuvum Paazhseyyum Utpakaiyum
Vendhalaikkum
Kolkurumpum Illadhu Naatu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ketariyaak Ketta Itaththum
Valangundraa
Naatenpa Naattin Thalai
Transliteration:
The land of lands no ruin knows 
Even in grief its wealth yet grows.
T.Kannan:
Chief of all lands is that, where nought disturbs its peace;
Or, if invaders come, still yields its rich increase.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: An incomparable state is one never devastated; yet if devastated, it would not diminish, but prosper.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: That is the top kingdom which is not harassed by an enemy, and which even if harassed does not experience want.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Call that a leading land that knows no evil days,
And whose yields don't cease even if they come.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The learned say that the best kingdom is that which knows no evil (from its foes), and, if injured (at all), suffers no diminution in its fruitfulness.
Various Translators:
Call that a leading land that knows no
evil days, And whose yields don't cease even if they
come.
Dinamalar: It faces no calamities; even if it does, its resources are undiminished: such a nation is the foremost amongst nations.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Lakes above and wells below, mountains well-located, rivers and streams flowing from them, and strong fortresses constitute a country.
Transliteration:
Irupunalum Vaaindha Malaiyum
Varupunalum
Vallaranum Naattirku Uruppu
T.Kannan:
Waters up and down, hills and streams 
With strong forts as limbs country beams.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Waters from rains and springs, a mountain near, and waters thence;
These make a land, with fortress sure defence.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Surface and subsoil water, well situated hills from which flow waters and an invincible fort are the limbs of a kingdom.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Rain waters, underground waters and rivers shed from well situated mountains, plus strong fortresses, are features of a fine country.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A land's limbs are waters from rains,
Springs and well placed hills, and strong fortress.
Various Translators: The constituents of a kingdom are the two waters (from above and below), well situated hills and an undestructible fort.
Dinamalar:
A land's limbs are waters from rains,
Springs and well placed hills, and strong fortress.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A country's jewels are these five:
Unfailing health, Fertility, joy, security and wealth.
Transliteration: Health, wealth, high yields, happiness and strong defence. these five adorn a state.
T.Kannan:
Piniyinmai Selvam Vilaivinpam Emam
Aniyenpa Naattiv Vaindhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Rich yield, delight, defence and wealth
Are jewels of lands with blooming health.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Five are the ornaments of a kingdom - absence of disease, wealth, fertility, happiness and security.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A country's jewels are these five: unfailing health,
Fertility and joy, a sure defence, and wealth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Five ornaments adorn a country: good health, abundant harvests, wealth, happiness and safety from invasions.
Various Translators:
A country's jewels are these five: Unfailing health,
Fertility, joy, security and wealth.
Dinamalar: Freedom from epidemics, wealth, produce, happiness and protection (to subjects); these five, the learned, say, are the ornaments of a kingdom.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Call that a land which yields without
toil. That is no land where toil precedes yield.
Transliteration: A good state is one which is self-sufficient; it is not one, if it is dependent on external resources.
T.Kannan: That is a kingdom which has rich natural resources. That is no kingdom which yields wealth by toil.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Naatenpa Naataa Valaththana Naatalla
Naata Valandharu Naatu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A land is land which yields unsought 
Needing hard work the land is nought.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
That is a land that yields increase unsought,
That is no land whose gifts with toil are bought.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A land where prosperity comes easily deserves the name country, not one where wealth entails laborious toil.
Various Translators: The learned say that those are kingdom whose wealth is not laboured for, and those not, whose wealth is only obtained through labour.
Dinamalar:
Call that a land which yields without toil.
That is no land where toil precedes yield.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Vain is the kingdom which may have all the excellence except harmony between the ruler and the ruled.
Transliteration:
Even if endowed with all blessings, a
country is no worth If not blessed with a ruler.
T.Kannan: A state might have everything; but they are of no use, if it doesn’t have the right ruler.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aangamai Veydhiyak Kannum Payamindre
Vendhamai Villaadha Naatu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Though a land has thus every thing 
It is worthless without a king.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though blest with all these varied gifts' increase,
A land gains nought that is not with its king at peace.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even if a country acquires all these blessings, it is worth nothing if it lacks harmony between the ruler and the ruled.
Various Translators: Although in possession of all the above mentioned excellences, these are indeed of no use to a country, in the absence of harmony between the sovereign and the sujects.
Dinamalar:
Even if endowed with all blessings, a country is no worth
If not blessed with a ruler.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A fortress is important alike to a conquering foe and a timid defender.
Transliteration:
A fortress is an asset to the offender As
well as to those who seek refuge in defence.
T.Kannan: A fortress is critical for those on the offensive; so is it, for those on the defensive to protect themselves.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aatru Pavarkkum Aranporul Anjiththar
Potru Pavarkkum Porul
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The fort is vital for offence 
Who fear the foes has its defence.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A <font color="#333399">fort is wealth to those who act against their foes;
Is wealth to them who, fearing, guard themselves from woes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A fort is an object of importance to those who march (against their foes) as well as to those who through fear (of pursuers) would seek it for shelter.
Various Translators: A fortress is a strategic asset both to aggressors and to those in fear who seek defense.
Dinamalar:
A fortress is an asset to the offender
As well as to those who seek refuge in defence.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is a fortress which has sparkling water, open spaces, hills and cool and shady forests round.
Transliteration:
Blue water, open space, hills and thick
forests Constitute a fortress.
T.Kannan: Pearl-like perennial water, sand, mountains and shaded woods. a strong fortress contains all these.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Manineerum Mannum Malaiyum Aninizhar
Kaatum Utaiya Tharan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A crystal fount, a space a mount 
Thick woods form a fort paramount.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A fort is that which has everlasting water, plains, mountains and cool shady forests.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A <font color="#333399">fort is that which owns a fount of waters crystal clear,
An open space, a hill, and shade of beauteous forest near.
Various Translators: An effective fort has crystal clear water, arable lands, a hill and lovely shaded woods.
Dinamalar:
Blue water, open space, hills and thick forests
Constitute a fortress.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Books declare that a fort should have these four:
Height, breadth, strength and difficult access.
Transliteration:
Books declare that a fort should have
these four: Height, breadth, strength and difficult
access.
T.Kannan: Tall, vast, impregnable and unapproachable. experts prescribe these four measures for forts.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The learned say that a fortress is an enclosure having these four (qualities) viz., height, breadth, strength and inaccessibility.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Uyarvakalam Thinmai Arumaiin Naankin
Amaivaran Endruraikkum Nool
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
An ideal fort's so says science: 
High, broad, strong and hard for access.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Height, breadth, strength, difficult access;
Science declares a fort must these possess.
Various Translators: The expert texts ordain four features for a fort’s barricades: that they be high, thick, solid and impregnable.
Dinamalar: Treatises on fortification state that the walls of a stronghold should be lofty, broad, strong and inaccessible.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A fortress, ample in space and easy to defend,
Spoils the might of the foe.
Transliteration: A fort is that which has an extensive space within, but only small places to be guarded, and such as can destroy the courage of besieging foes.
T.Kannan:
A fortress, ample in space and easy to
defend, Spoils the might of the foe.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Boundaries, vulnerable and needing protection, are minimal but area enclosed is vast. such a fortress destroys the confidence of advancing foes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Sirukaappir Peritaththa Thaaki
Urupakai
Ookkam Azhippa Tharan
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Ample in space, easy to hold 
The fort foils enemies bold.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A <font color="#333399">fort must need but slight defence, yet ample be,
Defying all the foeman's energy.
Various Translators: The ideal fortress is spacious, vulnerable in very few places and, of itself, defies a determined foe’s designs to storm it.
Dinamalar: A fortress which has a name as a natural defence cools the heat of the attacking foe.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A good fortress is hard to seize, well-supplied
And suited to those within.
Transliteration: A fort is that which cannot be captured, which abounds in suitable provisions, and affords a position of easy defence to its inmates.
T.Kannan:
A good fortress is hard to seize,
well-supplied And suited to those within.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A good fortress is unassailable, contains sufficient food and makes life easy for the residents.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kolarkaridhaaik Kontakoozhth Thaaki
Akaththaar
Nilaikkelidhaam Neeradhu Aran
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Impregnable with stores of food 
Cosy to live That fort is good.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Impregnable, containing ample stores of food,
A <font color="#333399">fort, for those within, must be a warlike station good.
Various Translators: A good fortress is that which is inaccessible, is sufficiently provided and is easily defensible from within.
Dinamalar: A good garrison is hard to assail, amply provisioned and accommodates inmates well.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
With all materials stocked inside,
A fort should have brave soldiers as well.
Transliteration: A fort is that which has all (needful) things, and excellent heroes that can help it against destruction (by foes).
T.Kannan:
With all materials stocked inside, A fort
should have brave soldiers as well.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A strong fortress contains all required resources and valiant warriors who will support during a siege.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ellaap Porulum Utaiththaai
Itaththudhavum
Nallaal Utaiyadhu Aran
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A fort is full of stores and arms
And brave heroes to meet alarms.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A fortress shall have all things needed by its residents including capable warriors.
Various Translators:
A <font color="#333399">fort, with all munitions amply stored,
In time of need should good reserves afford.
Dinamalar: The most formidable fortress, stocked with all needed goods, still needs men of good stock to fend off attack.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Whether by hurling artillery, tunneling beneath or encircling to lay siege, it is impossible to capture a strong fort.
Transliteration: A fort is that which cannot be captured by blockading, assaulting, or undermining it.
T.Kannan:
Hard to capture a fort that withstands
Besieging, artillery and treachery.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Hard to capture a fort that withstands
Besieging, artillery and treachery.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Neither siege, nor an all-out attack, nor sowing dissent will befell a strong fortress.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A good fortress cannot be besieged or taken by storm or be undermined.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Mutriyum Mutraa Therindhum
Araippatuththum
Patrar Kariyadhu Aran
Various Translators:
Besieging foes a fort withstands
Darts and mines of treacherous hands.
Dinamalar:
A <font color="#333399">fort should be impregnable to foes who gird it round,
Or aim there darts from far, or mine beneath the ground.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: However forcefully assailants may press, a secure fortress promises allies defense and foes defeat.
Transliteration: That is a fort whose inmates are able to overcome without losing their ground, even abler men who have besieged it.
T.Kannan:
Even if encircled by besieging foes,
A fortress enables the besieged to win.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The inmates of a good fortress can defend themselves even when besieged on all sides.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Even if encircled by besieging foes, A
fortress enables the besieged to win.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A strong fortress aids those devoted to stay and defend it, to defeat the formidable foes who have besieged it.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Mutraatri Mutri Yavaraiyum
Patraatrip
Patriyaar Velvadhu Aran
Various Translators:
A fort holds itself and defies 
The attacks of encircling foes.
Dinamalar:
Howe'er the circling foe may strive access to win,
A <font color="#333399">fort should give the victory to those who guard within.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
At outset of the strife a <font color="#333399">fort should foes dismay;
And greatness gain by deeds in every glorious day.
Transliteration: A fort is that which derives excellence from the stratagems made (by its inmates) to defeat their enemies in the battlefield.
T.Kannan: A fortress earns greatness by enabling courageous defenders to gloriously defeat the enemy at the battle’s very onset.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A good fort gains fame frustrating its siege
At the outset of the battle.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: That fortress is famous which makes it possible for its defenders to destroy the besiegers even at the outset.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A good fort gains fame frustrating its
siege At the outset of the battle.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A fortress attains glory through the glory attained by its residents, who, through their daring deeds, swiftly subdue the foes on the warfront.
Various Translators:
Munaimukaththu Maatralar Saaya
Vinaimukaththu
Veereydhi Maanta Tharan
Dinamalar:
A fort it is that fells the foes 
And gains by deeds a name glorious.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Although a fort may possess all (the above-said) excellence, it is, as it were without these, if its inmates possess not the excellence of action.
Transliteration:
Howe'er majestic castled walls may rise,
To craven souls no fortress strength supplies.
T.Kannan: Whatever excellent qualities a fortress may possess, it will be of no avail without men of excellent action.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A fortress, however grand, amounts to nothing
If its defenders are meek.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Of what use are these barriers of defence to a stronghold if it possesses no men of valour.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A fortress, however grand, amounts to
nothing If its defenders are meek.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: However formidable it maybe, a fortress is futile for those not formidable in their deeds.
Various Translators:
Enaimaatchith Thaakiyak Kannum
Vinaimaatchi
Illaarkan Illadhu Aran
Dinamalar:
But a fort however grand 
Is nil if heroes do not stand.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Naught exists that can, save wealth 
Make the worthless as men of worth.
Transliteration:
Nothing exists, save wealth, that can
Change man of nought to worthy man.
T.Kannan: There is nothing like wealth for lending consequence to an inconsequential man.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: There is nothing else than riches that make insignificant men prominent.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
There is nothing like wealth
To make the worthless worthy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
There is nothing like wealth To make the
worthless worthy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Wealth makes them, who were deemed worthless, worthy; if not, it is not wealth.
Various Translators: Besides wealth there is nothing that can change people of no importance into those of (some) importance.
Dinamalar:
Porulal Lavaraip Porulaakach Cheyyum
Porulalladhu Illai Porul

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Illaarai Ellaarum Elluvar Selvarai
Ellaarum Seyvar Sirappu
Transliteration:
The have nothing poor all despise 
The men of wealth all raise and praise.
T.Kannan:
Those who have nought all will despise;
All raise the wealthy to the skies.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who have nothing have everyone’s contempt, while the rich are exalted by one and all.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: All will despise the poor; all will accord honour to the wealthy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Everyone despises the poor
While the rich are exalted by all.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: All despise the poor; (but) all praise the rich.
Various Translators:
Everyone despises the poor While the rich
are exalted by all.
Dinamalar: The poor are ridiculed by all, and the rich esteemed by all.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The unfailing lamp called wealth will dislodge darkness by throwing light anywhere it wants to.
Transliteration:
Porulennum Poiyaa Vilakkam
Irularukkum
Enniya Theyaththuch Chendru
T.Kannan:
Waneless wealth is light that goes 
To every land and gloom removes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Wealth, the lamp unfailing, speeds to every land,
Dispersing darkness at its lord's command.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The faultless lamp of riches will dispel the darkness (of trouble) in any country to which it is taken.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Wealth is an unfailing lamp whose light reaches every imaginable land, dispelling darkness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The unfailing light called wealth can dispel darkness
Even in far reaching lands.
Various Translators: The imperishable light of wealth goes into regions desired (by its owner) and destroys the darkness (of enmity therein).
Dinamalar:
The unfailing light called wealth can
dispel darkness Even in far reaching lands.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Wealth acquired sinless and well, Yields
both virtue and happiness.
Transliteration: It yields righteousness and joy, the wealth acquired capably without causing any harm.
T.Kannan:
Araneenum Inpamum Eenum
Thiranarindhu
Theedhindri Vandha Porul
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The blameless wealth from fairest means 
Brings good virtue and also bliss.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The wealth accumulated justly and without sin will confer virtue and happiness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Their wealth, who blameless means can use aright,
Is source of virtue and of choice delight.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Riches acquired by mindful means, in a manner that harms no one, will bring both piety and pleasure.
Various Translators:
Wealth acquired sinless and well,
Yields both virtue and happiness.
Dinamalar: The wealth acquired with a knowledge of the proper means and without foul practices will yield virtue and happiness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Discard and let go the wealth Obtained
without love and grace.
Transliteration: Consider it unworthy of acquiring. wealth that is not generated with compassion and love.
T.Kannan: Let not the king accept the wealth not acquired through mercy and love.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Arulotum Anpotum Vaaraap Porulaakkam
Pullaar Purala Vital
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Riches devoid of love and grace
Off with it; it is disgrace!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Wealth gained by loss of love and grace,
Let man cast off from his embrace.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Wealth acquired without compassion and love is to be cast off, not embraced.
Various Translators: (Kings) should rather avoid than seek the accumulation of wealth which does not flow in with mercy and love.
Dinamalar:
Discard and let go the wealth
Obtained without love and grace.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Unclaimed wealth, tolls and tributes by the subdued chieftains are the king’s property.
Transliteration:
Unclaimed wealth, spoils of war and wealth
from taxes Are all rulers' wealth.
T.Kannan: Funds generated in the normal course, internal taxes and acquisitions from enemies are sources of wealth for the king.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Uruporulum Ulku Porulumdhan Onnaarth
Theruporulum Vendhan Porul
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Escheats, derelicts; spoils of war 
Taxes duties are king's treasure.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Wealth that falls to him as heir, wealth from the kingdom's dues,
The spoils of slaughtered foes: these are the royal revenues.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Wealth with no owner, wealth of defeated foes, wealth from tax and customs—these constitute the royal revenues.
Various Translators: Unclaimed wealth, wealth acquired by taxes, and wealth (got) by conquest of foes are (all) the wealth of the king.
Dinamalar:
Unclaimed wealth, spoils of war and wealth from taxes
Are all rulers' wealth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: What is mercy, but the child of love? What is wealth, but the nurse of mercy?
Transliteration:
The offspring of love 'graciousness' is
nursed By that generous foster-mother 'wealth'.
T.Kannan: The infant called compassion, birthed by love, is nurtured by the rich custodian called wealth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Arulennum Anpeen Kuzhavi Porulennum
Selvach Cheviliyaal Untu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Grace the child of love is nourished 
By the wet nurse of wealth cherished.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Tis love that kindliness as offspring bears;
And wealth as bounteous nurse the infant rears.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The child mercy which is borne by love grows under the care of the rich nurse of wealth.
Various Translators: Compassion, which is the child of Love, requires for its care the bountiful nurse called Wealth.
Dinamalar:
The offspring of love 'graciousness' is nursed
By that generous foster-mother 'wealth'.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The deeds of the wealthy are like elephant fights witnessed from a hill.
Transliteration:
A wealthy man's undertakings Are like
elephant-fights witnessed from a hill.
T.Kannan: Doing a deed with some wealth on hand is like climbing a hilltop and watching tuskers tussle.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kundreri Yaanaip Por Kantatraal
ThankaiththondruUntaakach Cheyvaan Vinai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Treasures in hand fulfil all things 
Like hill tuskers the wars of kings.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: An undertaking of one who has wealth in one's hands is like viewing an elephant-fight from a hill-top.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As one to view the strife of elephants who takes his stand,
On hill he's climbed, is he who works with money in his hand.
Various Translators: Undertaking an enterprise with sufficient resources in hand is like standing on a hilltop watching elephants fight below.
Dinamalar:
A wealthy man's undertakings
Are like elephant-fights witnessed from a hill.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Stock wealth: no steel sharper than that
To cut down your foe's pride.
Transliteration:
Stock wealth: no steel sharper than that
To cut down your foe's pride.
T.Kannan: Make money. there is no weapon sharper than it to sever the pride of your foes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Accumulate wealth; it will destroy the arrogance of (your) foes; there is no weapon sharper than it.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Seyka Porulaich Cherunar
Serukkarukkum
Eqkadhanir Kooriya Thil
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Make wealth; there is no sharper steel
The insolence of foes to quell.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Make money! Foeman's insolence o'er grown,
To lop away no keener steel is known.
Various Translators: Make money—that is the sharpest scalpel for paring down an enemy’s pride.
Dinamalar: Store up wealth; no other weapon is sharper than that to destroy the enemy’s pride.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
He who makes glorious wealth in plenty,
Gains the other two treasures together.
Transliteration: To those who have honestly acquired an abundance of riches, the other two, (virtue and pleasure) are things easy (of acquisition).
T.Kannan:
He who makes glorious wealth in plenty,
Gains the other two treasures together.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: For those who have made abundant wealth through fair means, the remaining two (righteousness and love) are easy to achieve.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Onporul Kaazhppa Iyatriyaarkku
Enporul
Enai Irantum Orungu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They have joy and virtue at hand 
Who acquire treasures abundant.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who plenteous store of glorious wealth have gained;
By them the other two are easily obtained.
Various Translators: Having acquired affluence, the acquisition of two other treasures—duty and delight—is effortless.
Dinamalar: Amass wealth by lawful means; the other two (virtue and happiness) will follow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A well organized army unafraid of obstacles
Is a ruler's greatest of all possessions.
Transliteration: The army which is complete in (its) parts and conquers without fear of wounds is the chief wealth of the king.
T.Kannan:
A well organized army unafraid of
obstacles Is a ruler's greatest of all possessions.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A well-structured, indomitable military, never daunted by dire prospects, is primary amongst all possessions of the king.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Uruppamaindhu Ooranjaa Velpatai
Vendhan
Verukkaiyul Ellaam Thalai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The daring well armed winning force 
Is king's treasure and main resource.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A conquering <font color="#333399">host, complete in all its limbs, that fears no wound,
Mid treasures of the king is chiefest found.
Various Translators: A well-equipped and fearlessly conquering army is the foremost wealth of a king.
Dinamalar: Foremost among a monarch’s possessions stands a conquering army, complete and fearless.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Only seasoned armies show courage in dire straits,
To stand fearless despite decimation.
Transliteration: Ancient army can alone have the valour which makes it stand by its king at the time of defeat, fearless of wounds and unmindful of its reduced strength.
T.Kannan:
Only seasoned armies show courage in dire
straits, To stand fearless despite decimation.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The undaunted valour in dire situations, with no fear of consequences, is rarely seen outside of a seasoned army.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ulaivitaththu Ooranjaa Vankan
Tholaivitaththuth
Tholpataik Kallaal Aridhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Through shots and wounds brave heroes hold 
Quailing not in fall, the field.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The heroic valour of rallying round the king even in adversity is peculiar to hereditary force, and not to others.
Various Translators:
In adverse hour, to face undaunted might of conquering foe,
Is bravery that only veteran <font color="#333399">host can show.
Dinamalar: Only seasoned soldiers remain bravely determined when onslaughts decimate them and threaten defeat.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: So what if a legion of rats roars like the raging sea? The mere hiss of a cobra will deaden their din.
Transliteration: What if (a host of) hostile rats roar like the sea ? They will perish at the mere breath of the cobra.
T.Kannan:
So what if an army of rats roar like the sea?
The hiss of a cobra will silence it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
So what if an army of rats roar like the
sea? The hiss of a cobra will silence it.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What if a rival army of rats comes roaring like an ocean, they will dissipate when the snake hisses.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The hiss of a cobra stills for ever an army of rats as vast as the ocean.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Oliththakkaal Ennaam Uvari Elippakai
Naakam Uyirppak Ketum
Various Translators:
Sea like ratfoes roar ... What if?
They perish at a cobra's whiff.
Dinamalar:
Though, like the sea, the angry mice send forth their battle cry;
What then? The dragon breathes upon them, and they die!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Commanding a long tradition of valor, acquainted with neither defeat nor desertion—that defines an army.
Transliteration: That indeed is an army which has stood firm of old without suffering destruction or deserting (to the enemy).
T.Kannan:
A true army has a long tradition of valour
And knows neither defeat nor desertion.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It is a heroic force that is hereditary, undiminished in powers and not undermined by the enemy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A true army has a long tradition of valour
And knows neither defeat nor desertion.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A real army is one that displays the innate valour of never getting vanquished by any disaster.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Azhivindri Araipokaa Thaaki
Vazhivandha
Vanka Nadhuve Patai
Various Translators:
The army guards its genial flame
Not crushed, routed nor marred in name.
Dinamalar:
That is a <font color="#333399">host, by no defeats, by no desertions shamed,
For old hereditary courage famed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
That is a <font color="#333399">'host' that joins its ranks, and mightily with stands,
Though death with sudden wrath should fall upon its bands.
Transliteration: That indeed is an army which is capable of offering a united resistance, even if Yama advances against it with fury.
T.Kannan: That indeed is an army which stands together, even when faced with death’s grim fury.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A capable army stands together and defies
Even if yama attacks in fury.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A valiant army faces courageously the advancing foe even when led by the God of Death.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A capable army stands together and defies
Even if yama attacks in fury.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: An army is one which has the courage to battle united, even if the Lord of Death descends on them.
Various Translators:
Kootrutandru Melvarinum Kooti
Edhirnirkum
Aatra Ladhuve Patai
Dinamalar:
The real army with rallied force 
Resists even Death God fierce.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Valour, honour, following in the excellent-footsteps (of its predecessors) and trust-worthiness; these four alone constitute the safeguard of an army.
Transliteration:
Valour with honour, sure advance in glory's path with confidence;
To warlike <font color="#333399">host these four are sure defence.
T.Kannan: Valor, honor, trustworthiness and a tradition nobly upheld— these four are an army’s protective armor.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Valour, honour, tradition of chivalry and credibility;
These four alone are an army's safeguards.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Heroism, honour, tried policy and fidelity to the king, these four are an army’s shelter.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Valour, honour, tradition of chivalry and
credibility; These four alone are an army's
safeguards.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Courage, pride, striding the honorable course, clarity. these four best fortify an army.
Various Translators:
Maramaanam Maanta Vazhichchelavu
Thetram
Enanaanke Emam Pataikku
Dinamalar:
Manly army has merits four: 
Stately march, faith, honour, valour.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Army sets on to face the foes 
Knowing how the trend of war goes.
Transliteration:
A valiant army bears the onslaught, onward goes,
Well taught with marshalled ranks to meet their coming foes.
T.Kannan: Well trained armed forces will withstand every attack, then outflank and storm the foe.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: That alone is an army which understands the enemy’s tactics, and fearlessly advances.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
An army should withstand and confound
The foe's tactics, and advance.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
An army should withstand and confound The
foe's tactics, and advance.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The army that can discern the tactics of its advancing foes, will stride over the dust the foes bite.
Various Translators: That is an army which knowing the art of warding off an impending struggle, can bear against the dust-van (of a hostile force).
Dinamalar:
Thaardhaangich Chelvadhu Thaanai
Thalaivandha
Pordhaangum Thanmai Arindhu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ataldhakaiyum Aatralum Illeninum
Thaanai
Pataiththakaiyaal Paatu Perum
Transliteration:
Army gains force by grand array 
Lacking in stay or dash in fray.
T.Kannan:
Though not in war offensive or defensive skilled;
An army gains applause when well equipped and drilled.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even without a winning offense and defense, an army of splendid appearance may still win acclaim.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: An army by mere show can achieve distinction though it may lack bold advance or even self-protection.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Even if lacking in virtue of offence and defence,
An army can gain fame by virtue of its size
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though destitute of courage to fight and strength (to endure), an army may yet gain renown by the splendour of its appearance.
Various Translators:
Even if lacking in virtue of offence and
defence, An army can gain fame by virtue of its size
Dinamalar: An army though bereft of the skills and resources to wage a war, will still gain renown for its discipline and preparation.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Pettiness, unabated fury and hatred, and poverty. an army not having these will win.
Transliteration:
Sirumaiyum Sellaath Thuniyum
Varumaiyum
Illaayin Vellum Patai
T.Kannan:
Army shall win if it is free 
From weakness, aversion, poverty.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Where weakness, clinging fear and poverty
Are not, the <font color="#333399">host will gain the victory.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It is a winning army which has neither littleness, nor irremovable bitterness and poverty.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: An army will prevail as long as there is no desertion, no privation and no contention.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
An army can triumph if it is free from diminution,
Irrevocable aversion and poverty.
Various Translators: An army can triumph (over its foes) if it is free from diminution; irremediable aversion and poverty.
Dinamalar:
An army can triumph if it is free from
diminution, Irrevocable aversion and poverty.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
However many and solid the soldiers, An
army without a chief will lose its way.
Transliteration: An army may have brave warriors in abundance, but will meet its end if there are no great leaders.
T.Kannan:
Nilaimakkal Saala Utaiththeninum
Thaanai
Thalaimakkal Ilvazhi Il
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
With troops in large numbers on rolls 
Army can't march missing gen'rals.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Of what avail is the army of heroic warriors if there be no general to guide them?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though men abound, all ready for the war,
No army is where no fit leaders are.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though courageous troops abound, there can be no army without commanders.
Various Translators:
However many and solid the soldiers,
An army without a chief will lose its way.
Dinamalar: Though an army may contain a large number of permanent soldiers, it cannot last if it has no generals.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Foes! Don't stand before my chief. Many
who stood now stand as stones!'
Transliteration: Oh foes, stand not facing my leader! Many have done so, and stand as stones.
T.Kannan: O, Enemies! Do not stand in front of our Lord; for many who stood before him are now standing as hero-stones.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ennaimun Nillanmin Thevvir
Palarennai
Munnindru Kalnin Ravar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Stand not before my chief, O foes! 
Many who stood, in stones repose.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Ye foes! Stand not before my lord! for many a one
Who did my lord withstand, now stands in stone!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Dare you not, my enemies, to stand against my monarch! Many who did now stand as stone monuments.
Various Translators: O my foes, stand not before my leader; (for) many are those who did so but afterwards stood (in the shape of) statues.
Dinamalar:
Foes! Don't stand before my chief.
Many who stood now stand as stones!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Better to bear the spear hurled against an elephant, though it misses its aim, than the arrow aimed against a hare in the forest.
Transliteration:
Better collect the spear that missed an
elephant Than the arrow that killed a hare.
T.Kannan: Better to bear the spear that missed the tusker than the arrow that got the rabbit.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaana Muyaleydha Ampinil Yaanai
Pizhaiththavel Endhal Inidhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To lift a lance that missed a tusker 
Is prouder than shaft that hit a hare.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who aims at elephant, though dart should fail, has greater praise,
Than he who woodland hare with winged arrow slays.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is more gratifying to carry a lance that missed an elephant than to hold an arrow that hit a thicket dwelling rabbit.
Various Translators: It is more pleasant to hold the dart that has missed an elephant than that which has hit hare in the forest.
Dinamalar:
Better collect the spear that missed an elephant
Than the arrow that killed a hare.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Fearlessness is a manly virtue; but in distress, mercy is its keen edge.
Transliteration:
Fierce courage is what they call valour,
But to help a foe in distress cuts deeper.
T.Kannan: Great manliness lies in bellicose valor; grace towards ailing foes, adds steel to it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Peraanmai Enpa Tharukanon Rutrakkaal
Ooraanmai Matradhan Eqku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Valour is fight with fierce courage 
Mercy to the fallen is its edge.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Fierceness in hour of strife heroic greatness shows;
Its edge is kindness to our suffering foes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The learned say that fierceness (incontest with a foe) is indeed great valour; but to become a benefactor in case of accident (to a foe) is the extreme (limit) of that valour.
Various Translators: Intrepid courage is what they call valor, and clemency toward the defeated is its sharp edge.
Dinamalar:
Fierce courage is what they call valour,
But to help a foe in distress cuts deeper.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The warrior who hurls his spear against an advancing elephant enjoys to pull it from his body.
Transliteration:
Losing his spear hurled at a tusker, A
hero grabs happily the one that pierced him.
T.Kannan: He spent his spear slaying an elephant, but breaks into a smile, plucking out the spear that pierces him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaivel Kalitrotu Pokki Varupavan
Meyvel Pariyaa Nakum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
At the tusker he flings his lance 
One in body smiles another chance.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The hero who after casting the lance in his hand on an elephant, comes (in search of another) will pluck the one (that sticks) in his body and laugh (exultingly).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
At elephant he hurls the dart in hand; for weapon pressed,
He laughs and plucks the javelin from his wounded breast.
Various Translators: Having hurled his spear at a battlefield elephant, the hero found another piercing his side and grasped it with glee.
Dinamalar:
Losing his spear hurled at a tusker,
A hero grabs happily the one that pierced him.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Is it not shameful for a hero to even let his
Watchful eyes wink when a spear is hurled?
Transliteration:
Is it not shameful for a hero to even let
his Watchful eyes wink when a spear is hurled?
T.Kannan: Doesn’t it equal defeat, blinking the eyes when a spear is thrown at him, the eyes that are staring the foe down.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Is it not a defeat to the valiant to wink and destroy their ferocious look when a lance in cast at them (by their foe) ?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vizhiththakan Velkona Teriya
Azhiththimaippin
Ottandro Vanka Navarkku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When lances dart if heroes wink
"It is a rout" the world will think.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To hero fearless must it not defeat appear,
If he but wink his eye when foemen hurls his spear.
Various Translators: Is it not a disgraceful defeat to the courageous warrior if his defiant eyes so much as blink when a lance is hurled at him?
Dinamalar: If the fierce look (of a warrior) winks at a dart aimed at him, it is tantamount to a retreat.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The brave shall deem all the days devoid of battle wounds
As days gone waste.
Transliteration: The hero will reckon among wasted days all those on which he had not received severe wounds.
T.Kannan:
The brave shall deem all the days devoid
of battle wounds As days gone waste.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Count those as wasted days, the days when you didn’t earn a wound in a battle.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vizhuppun Pataadhanaal Ellaam
Vazhukkinul
Vaikkumdhan Naalai Etuththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The brave shall deem the days as vain
Which did not battle wounds sustain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The heroes, counting up their days, set down as vain;
Each day when they no glorious wound sustain.
Various Translators: When recounting his days, the heroic soldier regards all those on which no battle scars were sustained as squandered.
Dinamalar: Reflecting on the days past, a hero regards those days vain in which he has not received a wound.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
That hero, who gives up his life for fame,
Is worthy of being adorned with the anklet.
Transliteration: The fastening of ankle-ring by those who disire a world-wide renown and not (the safety of) their lives is like adorning (themselves).
T.Kannan:
That hero, who gives up his life for fame,
Is worthy of being adorned with the anklet.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The anklets of courage become ornate when they adorn those who spurn their lives seeking lasting fame.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Suzhalum Isaiventi Ventaa Uyiraar
Kazhalyaappuk Kaarikai Neerththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Their anklets aloud jingle their name 
Who sacrifice their life for fame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who seek for world wide fame, regardless of their life,
The glorious clasp adorns, sign of heroic strife.
Various Translators: The anklet is a fitting adornment to warriors who fight fearless of life for a world-wide reputation.
Dinamalar: To fasten the warrior’s anklet on one who desires glory more than life is to decorate heroism with distinction.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even a king's wrath cannot hold back heroes
Who do not fear their lives in battle.
Transliteration: The heroes who are not afraid of losing their life in a contest will not cool their ardour, even if the king prohibits (their fighting).
T.Kannan:
Even a king's wrath cannot hold back
heroes Who do not fear their lives in battle.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When a battle begins, the warriors who war without fear for life, do not let their vigour reduce even when the king restrains them.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Urinuyir Anjaa Maravar Iraivan
Serinum Seerkundral Ilar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The king may chide, they pursue strife; 
They fear loss of glory; not life.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Warriors unmindful of their lives in battle will not be daunted even by the wrath of their obstructing monarch.
Various Translators:
Fearless they rush where'er 'the tide of battle rolls';
The king's reproof damps not the ardour of their eager souls.
Dinamalar: Men of courage who do not fear for their lives in battle do not forfeit soldierly ardor, even if the king prohibits their fighting.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Who would dare deride as defeated men who die fulfilling valor’s vow?
Transliteration: Who would reproach with failure those who seal their oath with their death ?
T.Kannan:
Who dares to despise a man for not fulfilling
A pledge he died to fulfill?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who dares to despise a man for not
fulfilling A pledge he died to fulfill?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: When he is ready to embrace death to fulfill his vow, who can taunt him for failure.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Who can find fault with those (soldiers) who will lay down their lives to fulfil their vow?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Izhaiththadhu Ikavaamaich Chaavaarai
Yaare
Pizhaiththadhu Orukkir Pavar
Various Translators:
Who will blame the heroes that lose
Their lives in war to keep their vows?
Dinamalar:
Who says they err, and visits them scorn,
Who die and faithful guard the vow they've sworn?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Heroic death that fills the sovereign’s eyes with tears worth begging for and then dying for.
Transliteration: If (heroes) can so die as to fill with tears the eyes of their rulers, such a death deserves to be obtained even by begging.
T.Kannan:
If death lies in glory that draws tears from the ruler,
It is worth seeking even in alms.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Ye! Soldiers, endeavour to earn a death of glory which will move your chief to tears.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If death lies in glory that draws tears
from the ruler, It is worth seeking even in alms.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: If one overwhelms his patron with tears while dying for him, death deserves to be beseeched.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Purandhaarkan Neermalkach Chaakirpin
Saakkaatu
Irandhukol Thakkadhu Utaiththu
Various Translators:
Such a death shall be prayed for 
Which draws the tears of the ruler.
Dinamalar:
If monarch's eyes o'erflow with tears for hero slain,
Why would not beg such boon of glorious death to gain?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What so hard for men to gain as freindship true?
What so sure defence 'gainst all that foe can do?
Transliteration: What things are there so difficult to acquire as friendship ? What guards are there so difficult to break through by the efforts (of one's foes) ?
T.Kannan: What is as difficult to secure as friendship? And what greater security is there against foes?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What greater security exists than a secure friendship
As a protection against foes?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What is there more important than an ally; and what is more helpful than securing his aid.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What greater security exists than a secure
friendship As a protection against foes?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What is better than making friends? What better protection can there be for accomplishing a task?
Various Translators:
Seyarkariya Yaavula Natpin Adhupol
Vinaikkariya Yaavula Kaappu
Dinamalar:
Like friendship what's so hard to gain? 
That guards one against acts villain?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The friendship of the wise waxes like the new moon; (but) that of fools wanes like the full moon.
Transliteration:
Friendship with men fulfilled of good 
Waxes like the crescent moon;Friendship with men of foolish mood, Like the full orb, waneth soon.
T.Kannan: With wise men, friendship waxes like the crescent moon; with fools, it wanes as surely as the full moon must.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Wise men's friendship waxes like the crescent
And fools', like the full moon, wanes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The friendship of the wise resembles the waxing crescent; the friendship of the unwise fades away like the waning moon.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Wise men's friendship waxes like the
crescent And fools', like the full moon, wanes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Amongst the wise, camaraderie waxes like the crescent, and amongst fools, wanes like the full moon.
Various Translators:
Niraineera Neeravar Kenmai
Piraimadhip
Pinneera Pedhaiyaar Natpu
Dinamalar:
Good friendship shines like waxing moon, 
The bad withers like waning moon.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Like taste in books good friendship grows 
The more one moves the more he knows.
Transliteration:
Learned scroll the more you ponder, 
Sweeter grows the mental food;So the heart by use grows fonder, Bound in friendship with the good.
T.Kannan: The bonds that good men share are like good bound books, revealing new enchantments at each new encounter.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even as good literature enraptures its reader the attachment of good men increases a king’s happiness.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Being with good friends is like reading good books.
More time you spend, more the delight.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Being with good friends is like reading
good books. More time you spend, more the delight.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The nuances of a book are enjoyed more, the deeper one reads it; the more you nurture a friendship, the more the joy.
Various Translators: Like learning, the friendship of the noble, the more it is cultivated, the more delightful does it become.
Dinamalar:
Navildhorum Noolnayam Polum
Payildhorum
Panputai Yaalar Thotarpu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nakudhar Poruttandru Nattal
Mikudhikkan
Mersenaru Itiththar Poruttu
Transliteration:
Not to laugh is friendship made 
But to hit when faults exceed.
T.Kannan:
Nor for laughter only friendship all the pleasant day.
But for strokes of sharp reproving, when from right you stray.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: What matters in making friends is not merrymaking, but a stern rebuking when friends go astray.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Friendship is made not for pleasure but it is a corrective to him who errs on the other side.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Friendship is not for merriment
But for stern reproach when friends go astray.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Friendship is to be practised not for the purpose of laughing but for that of being beforehand in giving one another sharp rebukes in case of transgression.
Various Translators:
Friendship is not for merriment But for
stern reproach when friends go astray.
Dinamalar: A friendship is not merely to have fun; it is also to admonish when a friend errs.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Friendship is forged on shared feelings; physical proximity or long association is inconsequential.
Transliteration:
Punarchchi Pazhakudhal Ventaa
Unarchchidhaan
Natpaang Kizhamai Tharum
T.Kannan:
No close living nor clasping grip
Friendship's feeling heart's fellowship.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Not association constant, not affection's token bind;
'Tis the unison of feeling friends unites of kindred mind.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Friendship is not cultivated by mere acquaintance. It is the harmony that cements the bond of friendship.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: It is not constant meeting and companionship, but shared sensibilities that confer the alliance of friendship.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Identity of feelings makes friendship.
No need for friends to meet and long together.
Various Translators: Living together and holding frequent intercourse are not necessary (for friendship); (mutual) understanding can alone create a claim for it.
Dinamalar:
Identity of feelings makes friendship. No
need for friends to meet and long together.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A smiling face alone makes no friendship,
But the heart should also smile with the face.
Transliteration: A smile on the face does not make a friendship; a smile in the depths of the heart does.
T.Kannan:
Mukanaka Natpadhu Natpandru
Nenjaththu
Akanaka Natpadhu Natpu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Friendship is not more smile on face 
It is the smiling heart's embrace.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Smile is no index for friendship. Real friendship makes the heart also smile.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Not the face's smile of welcome shows the friend sincere,
But the heart's rejoicing gladness when the friend is near.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A smiling face is no sure sign of friendship. Friendship is found deep within a smiling heart.
Various Translators:
A smiling face alone makes no friendship,
But the heart should also smile with the face.
Dinamalar: The love that dwells (merely in the smiles of the face is not friendship; (but) that which dwells deep in the smiles of the heart is true friendship.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Friendship saves from ruin, guides towards
right, And shares the pain of distress.
Transliteration: Rescuing from ruin, steering along the right path, and when in distress, sharing it, is friendship.
T.Kannan: Friendship prevents harmful deeds being committed and does beneficial things sharing the other’s misfortunes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Azhivi Navaineekki Aaruyththu
Azhivinkan
Allal Uzhappadhaam Natpu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
From ruin friendship saves and shares 
The load of pain and right path shows.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Friendship from ruin saves, in way of virtue keeps;
In troublous time, it weeps with him who weeps.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To divert a man from wrong, direct him toward right and share his sorrow in misfortune is comradeship.
Various Translators: (True) friendship turns aside from evil (ways) makes (him) walk in the (good) way, and, in case of loss if shares his sorrow (with him).
Dinamalar:
Friendship saves from ruin, guides towards right,
And shares the pain of distress.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Friendship removes suffering even as promptly as the hand which clutches the slipping garment.
Transliteration:
Swift as the hand seizing a slipping
garment, Friendship acts to assuage a friend in
distress.
T.Kannan: Like the hand that moves reflexively when the dress slips, a friend reacts swiftly to remove a woe.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Utukkai Izhandhavan Kaipola Aange
Itukkan Kalaivadhaam Natpu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Friendship hastens help in mishaps 
Like hands picking up dress that slips.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As hand of him whose vesture slips away,
Friendship at once the coming grief will stay.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: As swiftly as the hand moves to seize a slipping garment, friendship acts to assuage a friend’s distress.
Various Translators: (True) friendship hastens to the rescue of the afflicted (as readily) as the hand of one whose garment is loosened (before an assembly).
Dinamalar:
Swift as the hand seizing a slipping garment,
Friendship acts to assuage a friend in distress.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If one asks where friendship abides, it lies in timely aid.
Transliteration:
What is the throne of friendship? It is
that resolve Of unfailing support given at all time.
T.Kannan: Crowning glory for friendship is when a friend supports unflinchingly in all ways.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Natpirku Veetrirukkai Yaadhenin
Kotpindri
Ollumvaai Oondrum Nilai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Friendship is enthroned on the strength
That always helps with utmost warmth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
And where is friendship's royal seat? In stable mind,
Where friend in every time of need support may find.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Friendship may be said to be on its throne when it possesses the power of supporting one at all times and under all circumstances, (in the practice or virtue and wealth).
Various Translators: Where does Friendship hold her court? It is where friends find constant support in every possible circumstance.
Dinamalar:
What is the throne of friendship? It is that resolve
Of unfailing support given at all time.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even one may say, “These are my friends; I am deeply attached to them". Yet, it may be insignificant friendship.
Transliteration:
To boast, 'He means so much to me and I to
him,' Merely demeans a friendship.
T.Kannan: He is so dear to me; I mean so much to him. to even utter this, takes the lustre off friendship.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Inaiyar Ivaremakku Innamyaam Endru
Punaiyinum Pullennum Natpu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
"Such we are and such they are" 
Ev'n this boast will friendship mar.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Though friends may praise one another saying, "He is so intimate with us, and we so much (with him)"; (still) such friendship will appear mean.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Mean is the friendship that men blazon forth,
'He's thus to me,'and such to him my worth.
Various Translators: To boast, “He means so much to me, and I to him,” merely belittles a friendship.
Dinamalar:
To boast, He means so much to me and I to him,
Merely demeans a friendship.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nothing worse than befriending one untried,
For friends once made should last forever.
Transliteration:
Nothing worse than befriending one
untried, For friends once made should last forever.
T.Kannan: Nothing can be more pernicious than accepting a friend without assessing; after accepting, there is no letting go of them.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: As those who are of a friendly nature will not forsake (a friend) after once loving (him), there is no evil so great as contracting a friendship without due inquiry.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Naataadhu Nattalir Ketillai Nattapin
Veetillai Natpaal Pavarkku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Than testless friendship nought is worse 
For contacts formed will scarcely cease.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To make an untried man your friend is ruin sure;
For friendship formed unbroken must endure.
Various Translators: Nothing is more grievous than friendship formed without first testing, for once adopted, it cannot be abandoned by the faithful.
Dinamalar: Nothing causes greater harm than the indiscriminate choice of friends; for one cannot give up one’s chosen friends.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Friendship made without enquiries
Can cause lifetime trouble.
Transliteration: The friendship contracted by him who has not made repeated inquiry will in the end grieve (him) to death.
T.Kannan:
Friendship made without enquiries Can
cause lifetime trouble.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Assess and assess before taking a friend, else the ensuing anguish will be fatal.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Aaindhaaindhu Kollaadhaan Kenmai
Kataimurai
Thaansaam Thuyaram Tharum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Friendship made without frequent test 
Shall end in grief and death at last.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Alliance with the man you have not proved and proved again,
In length of days will give you mortal pain.
Various Translators: Unless it begins with testing and proving, friendship may end in mortal sorrow.
Dinamalar: The friendship entered into without repeated tests causes grief till the end of one’s life.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Make one a friend after knowing his nature,
Family, fellows and flaws.
Transliteration: Make friendship (with one) after ascertaining (his) character, birth, defects and the whole of one's relations.
T.Kannan:
Make one a friend after knowing his
nature, Family, fellows and flaws.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Know one’s traits, roots, faults and flawless kinship, and then forge a friendship.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kunamum Kutimaiyum Kutramum Kundraa
Inanum Arindhiyaakka Natpu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Temper, descent, defects and kins 
Trace well and take companions.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Temper, descent, defects, associations free
From blame: know these, then let the man be friend to thee.
Various Translators: Make friends with one after knowing one’s character, ancestry, defects and one’s great associates.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A man of birth and scrupulous honour
Is worth seeking even at a price.
Transliteration: The friendship of one who belongs to a (good) family and is afraid of (being charged with) guilt, is worth even purchasing.
T.Kannan:
A man of birth and scrupulous honour Is
worth seeking even at a price.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Of high birth, and fears disgrace. give whatever and gain the friendship.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kutippirandhu Thankan Pazhinaanu
Vaanaik
Kotuththum Kolalventum Natpu
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even by paying a price secure the friendship of one of noble family who fears a blot on his character.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Take as good friend at any price 
The nobly born who shun disgrace.
Various Translators:
Who,born of noble race, from guilt would shrink with shame,
