Pay any price, so you as friend that man may claim.
Dinamalar: Pay any price to possess the friendship of well born men who cannot bear rebuke and shame.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Seek out and befriend those who, speaking out, move you to repent, reprove your wrongdoing and teach you the right ways.
Transliteration: You should examine and secure the friendship of those who can speak so as to make you weep over a crime (before its commission) or rebuke you severely (after you have done it) and are able to teach you (the ways of) the world.
T.Kannan:
Seek a friend who will make you cry,
Rail and rate when you go astray.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seek a friend who will make you cry, Rail
and rate when you go astray.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: When you err, they may chide you till you cry, and show you the right way. assess and accept their friendship.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Make after proper test friendship with the wise who make you weep for a crime and chastise when you err.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Azhachcholli Alladhu Itiththu
Vazhakkariya
Vallaarnatapu Aaindhu Kolal
Various Translators:
Who make you weep and chide wrong trends 
And lead you right are worthy friends.
Dinamalar:
Make them your chosen friends whose words repentance move,
With power prescription's path to show, while evil they reprove.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ruin itself one blessing lends:
'Tis staff that measures out one's friends.
Transliteration: There is a benefit even in misfortune, for it is the rod with which a man may measure the loyalty of friends.
T.Kannan: Even in ruin there is some good; (for) it is a rod by which one may measure fully (the affection of one's) relations.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Is there any yardstick better than adversity,
To spread out and measure friends?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Adversity has its uses, for it is the touchstone that tries the genuine friend.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Is there any yardstick better than
adversity, To spread out and measure friends?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: There is a gain in grief: it is a tool to stretch and gauge a friend.
Various Translators:
Kettinum Untor Urudhi Kilaignarai
Neetti Alappadhor Kol
Dinamalar:
Is there a test like misfortune 
A rod to measure out kinsmen?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Tis gain to any man, the sages say,
Friendship of folls to put away.
Transliteration: It is indead a gain for one to renounce the friendship of fools.
T.Kannan: To give up friendship with fools and quit their company— such loss is said to be a man’s greatest gain.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
It is a gain by itself if one gets away
From the friendship of fools.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: One must regard it as a windfall if one is able to shake off unwise friends.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
It is a gain by itself if one gets away
From the friendship of fools.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is a gain to lose the friendship of a fool.
Various Translators:
Oodhiyam Enpadhu Oruvarkup
Pedhaiyaar
Kenmai Oreei Vital
Dinamalar:
Keep off contacts with fools; that is 
The greatest gain so say the wise.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Do not think of things that discourage your mind, nor contract friendship with those who would forsake you in adversity.
Transliteration:
Off with thoughts that depress the heart 
Off with friends that in woe depart.
T.Kannan:
Think not the thoughts that dwarf the soul; nor take
For friends the men who friends in time of grief forsake.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Don’t dwell on thoughts that dim your spirit. Don’t befriend those who flee you in affliction.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Dwell not in thoughts that dim your spirit
And befriend not those who desert in affliction.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Refrain from doing things which make your heart shrink. Likewise avoid friends who desert you in adversity.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Dwell not in thoughts that dim your spirit
And befriend not those who desert in affliction.
Various Translators: Think not of trifles that stifle your fervor; take not the friendship of those who desert in distress.
Dinamalar:
Ullarka Ullam Sirukuva Kollarka
Allarkan Aatraruppaar Natpu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Friends who betray at ruin's brink 
Burn our mind ev'n at death to think.
Transliteration:
Of friends deserting us on ruin's brink,
'Tis torture e'en in life's last hour to think.
T.Kannan: Even in the hour of death, the thoughts of friends who left you in your hour of need will hurt the heart.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Friendship of those who fall off in adversity continues to rankle in your heart of hearts till your death.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The thought of friend's betrayal in need
Rankles even on the deathbed.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The thought of friend's betrayal in need
Rankles even on the deathbed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A friend who abandons in times of adversity, will torment the heart even at death’s door.
Various Translators: The very thought of the friendship of those who have deserted one at the approach of adversity will burn one's mind at the time of death.
Dinamalar:
Ketungaalaik Kaivituvaar Kenmai
Atungaalai
Ullinum Ullanj Chutum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Maruvuka Maasatraar Kenmaion
Reeththum
Oruvuka Oppilaar Natpu
Transliteration:
The blameless ones as friends embarace;
Give something and give up the base.
T.Kannan:
Cling to the friendship of the spotless ones;whate'er you pay,
Renounce alliance with the men of evil way.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Hold tight to friendship with pure men; let go of unfit fellows, even by paying them off.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Count the friendship of the faultless and release yourself even at a price from friends not of approved conduct.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Seek the friendship of the pure, and shake off
The worthless even at a price.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Continue to enjoy the friendship of the pure; (but) renounce even with a gift, the friendship of those who do not agree (with the world).
Various Translators:
Seek the friendship of the pure, and shake
off The worthless even at a price.
Dinamalar: Seek friendship with the impeccable; give anything to sever ties with unbefitting allies.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When a friend takes the liberty to do anything, and you never hinder it, that is called rapport.
Transliteration:
Pazhaimai Enappatuvadhu Yaadhenin
Yaadhum
Kizhamaiyaik Keezhndhitaa Natpu
T.Kannan:
That friendship is good amity
Which restrains not one's liberty.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Familiarity is friendship's silent pact,
That puts restraint on no familiar act.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What is old friendship? It is that which willingly submits to friendly interferences.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: What is old familiarity? It is when neither friend objects to liberties taken by the other.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Call that an old friendship
Where liberties are not resented.
Various Translators: Imtimate friendship is that which cannot in the least be injured by (things done through the) right (of longstanding intimacy).
Dinamalar:
Call that an old friendship Where
liberties are not resented.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
True friendship permits liberties and to
concede to it Is the duty of the wise.
Transliteration: Taking the liberty is a part of friendship; to oblige and salt it is the duty of the noble.
T.Kannan:
Natpir Kuruppuk Kezhudhakaimai
Matradharku
Uppaadhal Saandror Katan
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The soul of friendship is perfect freedom. To be of cheer in friendly interference is the duty of the wise.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Friendship's heart is freedom close; 
Wise men's duty is such to please.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Familiar freedom friendship's very frame supplies;
To be its savour sweet is duty of the wise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Liberties taken by a friend are friendship’s rightful possession; to allow them is the willing duty of wise men.
Various Translators:
True friendship permits liberties and to concede to it
Is the duty of the wise.
Dinamalar: The constituents of friendship are (things done through) the right of intimacy; to be pleased with such a right is the duty of the wise.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What is that intimacy which does not
approve And reciprocate liberties?
Transliteration: What purpose does intimate friendship serve, when one can’t indulge a friend who uses his rights to do something unsolicited.
T.Kannan: What use is old friendship if one’s intimacy does not approve of one’s acts?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pazhakiya Natpevan Seyyung
Kezhudhakaimai
Seydhaangu Amaiyaak Katai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Of long friendship what is the use 
Righteous freedom if men refuse?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When to familiar acts men kind response refuse,
What fruit from ancient friendship's use?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What is the purpose of long standing fellowship if friends’ familiar actions are not accepted as one’s own?
Various Translators: Of what avail is long-standing friendship, if friends do not admit as their own actions done through the right of intimacy ?
Dinamalar:
What is that intimacy which does not approve
And reciprocate liberties?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If friends voluntarily do their duty through intimacy the wise accept it with approval.
Transliteration:
The wise take in good spirit if friends,
by right of familiarity, Do things without asking.
T.Kannan: Without asking, when a friend acts, presuming assent, one accepts it as if they desired it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Vizhaidhakaiyaan Venti Iruppar
Kezhudhakaiyaar
Kelaadhu Nattaar Seyin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Things done unasked by loving friends
Please the wise as familiar trends!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When friends unbidden do familiar acts with loving heart,
Friends take the kindly deed in friendly part.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Familiar with familiarity, the wise are never annoyed when friends do things without asking.
Various Translators: If friends, through the right of friendship, do (anything) without being asked, the wise will be pleased with them on account of its desirability.
Dinamalar:
The wise take in good spirit if friends, by right of familiarity,
Do things without asking.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If a friend acts contrary to one’s wishes, treat it as not due to ignorance but to intimacy.
Transliteration:
When friends hurt, attribute it to either
ignorance Or privileges of friendship.
T.Kannan: Discern it not merely as ignorance, but as a sign of intimacy, when a friend does an undesired act that hurts.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pedhaimai Ondro Perungizhamai
Endrunarka
Nodhakka Nattaar Seyin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Offence of friends feel it easy 
As folloy or close intimacy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Not folly merely, but familiar carelessness,
Esteem it, when your friends cause you distress.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If friends should perform what is painful, understand that it is owing not only to ignorance, but also to the strong claims of intimacy.
Various Translators: When friends do things that hurt you, attribute it to unawareness or to the privileges of friendship.
Dinamalar:
When friends hurt, attribute it to either ignorance
Or privileges of friendship.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Old friends may do harm but it is the quality of friendship not to abandon them.
Transliteration:
Those bound by intimacy never desert their
old pals Even if they bring loss.
T.Kannan: A friend who has stood by you at all times, even when he causes harm. those who know the expanse of friendship will never let go.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ellaikkan Nindraar Thuravaar
Tholaivitaththum
Thollaikkan Nindraar Thotarpu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who stand within the limits (of true friendship) will not even in adversity give up the intimacy of long-standing friends.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They forsake not but continue 
In friendship's bounds though loss ensue.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who stand within the bounds quit not, though loss impends,
Association with the old familiar friends.
Various Translators: Bound by brotherhood, true friends never break their bond with an old comrade, even if he brings them loss.
Dinamalar:
Those bound by intimacy never desert their old pals
Even if they bring loss.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
In a friendship built on love, friends do not cease to love
Even when there is betrayal.
Transliteration:
In a friendship built on love, friends do
not cease to love Even when there is betrayal.
T.Kannan: In friendships built on love, no love is lessened even when one does a destructive deed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who have (long) stood in the path of affection will not give it up even if their friends cause (them) their ruin.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Azhivandha Seyyinum Anparaar Anpin
Vazhivandha Kenmai Yavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Comrades established in firm love 
Though ruin comes waive not their vow.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
True friends, well versed in loving ways,
Cease not to love, when friend their love betrays.
Various Translators: Old friends do not forsake loving fellowships, even when those they cherish happen to do them harm.
Dinamalar: Old and loving friends, even when betrayed do not break off in their love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Close friends who won't listen to friend's faults,
Hail in silence the day they offend.
Transliteration: To those who understand that by which they should not listen to (tales about) the faults of their friends, that is a (profitable) day on which the latter may commit a fault.
T.Kannan:
Close friends who won't listen to friend's
faults, Hail in silence the day they offend.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: For one who brooks no charges against an intimate friend, the day is made when the friend errs.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kelizhukkam Kelaak Kezhudhakaimai
Vallaarkku
Naalizhukkam Nattaar Seyin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Fast friends who list not tales of ill 
Though wronged they say "that day is well".
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
In strength of friendship rare of friend's disgrace who will not hear,
The day his friend offends will day of grace to him appear.
Various Translators: An intimate of any strength will never listen to faults said of friends; and on the day a friend offends, he is content to keep silent.
Dinamalar: Intimacy is the refusal to hear about friend’s faults. Noble friends smile that day when their friends commit faults.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The world will cherish those friends
Who never forsake old, unbroken friendships.
Transliteration: They will be loved by the world, who have not forsaken the friendship of those with whom they have kept up an unbroken long-standing intimacy.
T.Kannan:
The world will cherish those friends Who
never forsake old, unbroken friendships.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Friends with resolute rapport, will never let it rupture even if the world wills it.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ketaaa Vazhivandha Kenmaiyaar Kenmai
Vitaaar Vizhaiyum Ulaku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To love such friends the world desires
Whose friendship has unbroken ties.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Friendship of old and faithful friends,
Who ne'er forsake, the world commends.
Various Translators: The world applauds long established friends who do not forsake one another.
Dinamalar: The world cherishes faithful men who never forsake old friendships, worn by time but unbroken.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even adversaries admire the character of old friends
Who don't part.
Transliteration: Even enemies will love those who have never changed in their affection to their long-standingfriends.
T.Kannan:
Even adversaries admire the character of
old friends Who don't part.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One who by nature never breaks with intimate friends Shall be loved even by those who loathe them.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vizhaiyaar Vizhaiyap Patupa
Pazhaiyaarkan
Panpin Thalaippiriyaa Thaar
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even foes long for those who do not forsake their old and erring friends.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Even foes love for better ends 
Those who leave not long standing friends.
Various Translators:
III wishers even wish them well, who guard,
For ancient friends, their wonted kind regard.
Dinamalar: Even ill wishers will wish those well who never abandon affection for old friends.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Though unscrupulous men may seem to consume you in friendship, their companionship grows more delightful as it declines.
Transliteration: The decrease of friendship with those who look as if they would eat you up (through excess of love) while they are really destitute of goodness is far better than its increase.
T.Kannan:
The hypocrite's flattering friendship pleases more
As it wanes than as it grows.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The hypocrite's flattering friendship
pleases more As it wanes than as it grows.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Their gaze may seem to guzzle you lovingly; but let the ties with characterless friends wane than flourish.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Let that kind of friendship diminish rather than increase if it is really pretentious and devoid of genuine feeling.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Parukuvaar Polinum Panpilaar Kenmai
Perukalir Kundral Inidhu
Various Translators:
Swallowing love of soulless men 
Had better wane than wax anon.
Dinamalar:
Though evil men should all absorbing friendship show,
Their love had better die away than grow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What though you gain or lose friendship of men of alien heart,
Who when you thrive are friends, and when you fail depart?
Transliteration: What does it matter if one gains or loses the friendship of manipulators who befriend to gain and otherwise forsake?
T.Kannan: Of what avail is it to get or lose the friendship of those who love when there is gain and leave when there is none ?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What matters if one gain or lose that unsettling friendship
Which sticks and ends at will?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What does it matter whether we gain or lose the equal friendship of those who befriend if advantageous to them and betray if disadvantageous?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What matters if one gain or lose that
unsettling friendship Which sticks and ends at will?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Ill-suited mates who are intimate if they benefit and distant if they don’t. does it matter if we gain them or lose them?
Various Translators:
Urinnattu Arinoruum Oppilaar Kenmai
Perinum Izhappinum En?
Dinamalar:
Who fawn in wealth and fail in dearth 
Gain or lose; such friends have no worth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
These are alike: the friends who ponder friendship's gain,
Those who accept what'er you give, and all the plundering train.
Transliteration: Friendship who calculate the profits (of their friendship), prostitutes who are bent on obtaining their gains, and thieves are (all) of the same character.
T.Kannan: Prostitutes, thieves and people who make friends to make money are all alike.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those who weigh friendship for gain
Are no different from whores and frauds.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who value friendship for the gain thereof are only avaricious prostitutes and thieves.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those who weigh friendship for gain Are no
different from whores and frauds.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Friends who only gauge what they gain, whores who embrace only what they are paid, and thieves are all the same.
Various Translators:
Uruvadhu Seerdhookkum Natpum
Peruvadhu
Kolvaarum Kalvarum Ner
Dinamalar:
Cunning friends who calculate 
Are like thieves and whores wicked.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Solitude is more to be desired than the society of those who resemble the untrained horses which throw down (their riders) in the fields of battle.
Transliteration:
Better be alone than trust in those 
That throw in field like faithless horse.
T.Kannan:
A steed untrained will leave you in the tug of war;
Than friends like that to dwell alone is better far.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Some men are like an untrained horse that throws its rider on the battlefield. Loneliness is better than their friendship.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Better to be alone than befriend those,
Who, like a broken horse, throw you down.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Better solitude than the alliance of the wicked who fail like the unbroken steed its rider in the battlefield.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Better to be alone than befriend those,
Who, like a broken horse, throw you down.
Various Translators: Better be lonely than have the company of those, who are like untrained horses that can’t bear you on the battlefield.
Dinamalar:
Amarakaththu Aatrarukkum Kallaamaa
Annaar
Thamarin Thanimai Thalai

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Friends low and mean that give no help 
Leave them is better than to keep.
Transliteration:
Tis better not to gain than gain the friendship profitless
Of men of little minds, who succour fails when dangers press.
T.Kannan: Better to give up than to gain the friendship of inferior men who stay away when they should stay and help.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Better to abandon than contract the friendship of the lowly who do not aid you in adversity.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Better to forfeit than seek the friendship of the base
Who betray at need.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Better to forfeit than seek the friendship
of the base Who betray at need.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Regardless of what you do, petty people who can’t protect you. it is better not to gain their vain friendship.
Various Translators: It is far better to avoid that to contract the evil friendship of the base who cannot protect (their friends) even when appointed to do so.
Dinamalar:
Seydhemanj Chaaraach Chiriyavar
Punkenmai
Eydhalin Eydhaamai Nandru

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Pedhai Perungezheei Natpin
Arivutaiyaar
Edhinmai Koti Urum
Transliteration:
Million times the wise man's hate 
Is better than a fool intimate.
T.Kannan:
Better ten million times incur the wise man's hate,
Than form with foolish men a friendship intimate.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The enmity of the wise is ten million times better than intimate friendship with fools.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Very much more valuable is the hatred of the wise than the doting friendship of fools.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A wise man's enmity is a million of times better
Than a fool's fast friendship.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The hatred of the wise is ten-million times more profitable than the excessive intimacy of the fool.
Various Translators:
A wise man's enmity is a million of times
better Than a fool's fast friendship.
Dinamalar: Million times worthwhile it is to be foes with the wise than be bosom friends with the foolish.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Billion times rewarding it is to have adversaries than friends who engage only in ridicule.
Transliteration:
Nakaivakaiya Raakiya Natpin
Pakaivaraal
Paththatuththa Koti Urum
T.Kannan:
Ten fold crore you gain from foes 
Than from friends who are vain laughers.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
From foes ten million fold a greater good you gain,
Than friendship yields that's formed with laughters vain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Ten thousand times better is the enmity of foes than the friendship which makes one a laughing stock.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: An enemy’s rancor is a hundred million times more worthwhile than companionship with fellows who always clown around.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ten million times better the enmity of foes
Than the friendship of jesters and fools.
Various Translators: What comes from enemies is a hundred million times more profitable than what comes from the friendship of those who cause only laughter.
Dinamalar:
Ten million times better the enmity of
foes Than the friendship of jesters and fools.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Drop silently the friends who pose And
won't help when they can.
Transliteration: If a friend keeps shirking from doing what they are capable of, make no fuss and let the ties wither away.
T.Kannan:
Ollum Karumam Utatru Pavarkenmai
Sollaataar Sora Vital
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Abandon without fuss friends who make a possible thing impossible.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Without a word those friends eschew 
Who spoil deeds which they can do.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those men who make a grievous toil of what they do
On your behalf, their friendship silently eschew.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If friends feign inability to discharge reasonable tasks, remain silent and gradually give up their friendship.
Various Translators:
Drop silently the friends who pose
And won't help when they can.
Dinamalar: Gradually abandon without revealing (beforehand) the friendship of those who pretend inability to carry out what they (really) could do.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Friends whose words differ from their
deeds Distress even in dreams.
Transliteration: Bonds with those whose words and deeds differ, alas, causes mayhem even in dreams.
T.Kannan: The alliances of men whose words are different from their deeds afford no pleasure even in a dream.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kanavinum Innaadhu Manno Vinaiveru
Solveru Pattaar Thotarpu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Even in dreams the tie is bad
With those whose deed is far from word.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
E'en in a dream the intercourse is bitterness
With men whose deeds are other than their words profess.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The fellowship of men whose acts belie their spoken words is bitter, even in dreams.
Various Translators: The friendship of those whose actions do not agree with their words will distress (one) even in (one's) dreams.
Dinamalar:
Friends whose words differ from their deeds
Distress even in dreams.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Avoid the friendship however little, of those who befriend you at home but betray you in the assembly (public).
Transliteration:
Keep them far off who are friends at home
And foes in public.
T.Kannan: Cosy in private and derisive in public. allow not a hint of a link with such a person.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Enaiththum Kurukudhal Ompal
Manaikkezheei
Mandril Pazhippaar Thotarpu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Keep aloof from those that smile 
At home and in public revile.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In anywise maintain not intercourse with those,
Who in the house are friends, in hall are slandering foes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: There are men who will cherish you in private but censure you in public—avoid their every befriending approach.
Various Translators: Avoid even the least approach to a contraction of friendship with those who would love you in private but ridicule you in public.
Dinamalar:
Keep them far off who are friends at home
And foes in public.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Friendship of the wicked is but a pretext to stab you cunningly in an unwary mood.
Transliteration:
Posing friends treat you like an anvil To
strike you at the opportune time.
T.Kannan: Fair-weather friendship based on opportunism than feelings is like an anvil to take the blow when the tool has to strike.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seeritam Kaanin Eridharkup Pattatai
Neraa Nirandhavar Natpu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The friendship by an enemy shown 
Is anvil in time, to strike you down.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Anvil where thou shalt smitten be, when men occasion find;
Is friendship's form without consenting mind.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The friendship of those who behave like friends without inward affection is a weapon that may be thrown when a favourable opportunity presents itself.
Various Translators: The friendship of those who feign affection is an anvil on which they hammer you when the opportunity arises.
Dinamalar:
Posing friends treat you like an anvil
To strike you at the opportune time.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Inconstant as the heart of a woman is the false friendship of seeming friends.
Transliteration:
Fickle as a woman's heart is the
friendship of those Who act like friends.
T.Kannan: Friendship with those who profess amity but lack it will oscillate like the heart of a woman.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Inampondru Inamallaar Kenmai Makalir
Manampola Veru Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The friendship of those who seem to be friends while they are not, will change like the love of women.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who pretend kinship but are not 
Their friendship's fickle like woman's heart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Friendship of those who seem our kin, but are not really kind,
Will change from hour to hour like woman's mind.
Various Translators: For those who act like friends, but are not, friendship fluctuates like a fickle woman.
Dinamalar:
Fickle as a woman's heart is the friendship of those
Who act like friends.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Hard for the ignoble to be good-hearted,
No matter how well educated they are.
Transliteration:
Hard for the ignoble to be good-hearted,
No matter how well educated they are.
T.Kannan: They may have learnt from many a good book but the ungracious shall never turn good-natured.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Though (one's) enemies may have mastered many good books, it will be impossible for them to become truly loving at heart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Palanalla Katrak Kataiththu
Mananallar
Aakudhal Maanaark Karidhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They may be vast in good studies
But heartfelt love is hard for foes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To heartfelt goodness men ignoble hardly may attain,
Although abundant stores of goodly lore they gain.
Various Translators: Though their learning may be abundantly good, ignoble men rarely learn goodness of heart.
Dinamalar: A wicked heart never mellows with learning.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Beware of those deceits who, with a smiling face,
Conceal bitterness in their hearts.
Transliteration: One should fear the deceitful who smile sweetly with their face but never love with their heart.
T.Kannan:
Beware of those deceits who, with a
smiling face, Conceal bitterness in their hearts.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The schemers with a sweet smile on the face but devious at heart ought to be feared.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Mukaththin Iniya Nakaaa Akaththinnaa
Vanjarai Anjap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Fear foes whose face has winning smiles 
Whose heart is full of cunning guiles.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Tis fitting you should dread dissemblers' guile,
Whose hearts are bitter while their faces smile.
Various Translators: Fear the cunning friend who, harboring wickedness in his heart, smiles sweetly to your face.
Dinamalar: Fear those who smile and smile but are villainy at heart.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Trust not the mere words of those
Whose minds don't agree with us.
Transliteration: In nothing whatever is it proper to rely on the words of those who do not love with their heart.
T.Kannan:
Trust not the mere words of those Whose
minds don't agree with us.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When the hearts don’t converge, never conclude based on their words to embark on any task.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Manaththin Amaiyaa Thavarai
Enaiththondrum
Sollinaal Therarpaatru Andru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Do not trust in what they tell 
Whose mind with your mind goes ill.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When minds are not in unison, 'its never just,
In any words men speak to put your trust.
Various Translators: It is impossible to convince those whose minds do not agree.
Dinamalar: Distrust whatever words may come from men whose hearts do not beat in harmony with your own.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A foe's words though seem friendly and good
Can be read at once.
Transliteration: Though (one's) foes may utter good things as though they were friends, once will at once understand (their evil, import).
T.Kannan:
A foe's words though seem friendly and
good Can be read at once.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Though, like friends, they speak of what is right, words of foes will be exposed right away.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nattaarpol Nallavai Sollinum
Ottaarsol
Ollai Unarap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Of what avail are the friendly words of your foe?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The words of foes is quickly seen 
Though they speak like friends in fine.
Various Translators:
Though many goodly words they speak in friendly tone,
The words of foes will speedily be known.
Dinamalar: Sounding very much like a good friend’s words, a rival’s words are nonetheless known very quickly.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Knowing how the bending of a bow forebodes nothing but harm, never trust an enemy, though he bends low in his speech.
Transliteration: Since the bending of the bow bespeaks evil, one should not accept (as good) the humiliating speeches of one's foes.
T.Kannan:
Trust not the bowing speech of your foe.
A bending bow is a sign of imminent danger.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Trust not the bowing speech of your foe. A
bending bow is a sign of imminent danger.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The bow bends not to greet but to hurt. Likewise, the greeting of your enemy signifies no bonhomie.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Do not trust the seeming humility of the enemy’s speech for the bow bends only to do harm.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Solvanakkam Onnaarkan Kollarka
Vilvanakkam
Theengu Kuriththamai Yaan
Various Translators:
Trust not the humble words of foes 
Danger darts from bending bows.
Dinamalar:
To pliant speech from hostile lips give thou no ear;
'Tis pliant bow that shows the deadly peril near!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
In hands that worship weapon often hidden lies;
Such are the tears that fall from foeman's eyes.
Transliteration: Folded in respect, a foe’s hands may hide a dagger. So, too, his tears dare not be trusted.
T.Kannan: A weapon may be hid in the very hands with which (one's) foes adore (him) (and) the tears they shed are of the same nature.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Like a dagger concealed in folded hands
Is the mourning tears of foes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The folded hands of the enemy in an attitude of devotion conceal a weapon. Likewise are his false tears.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Like a dagger concealed in folded hands Is
the mourning tears of foes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Hands folded in reverence may conceal a weapon; so do the tears of your foes.
Various Translators:
Thozhudhakai Yullum Pataiyotungum
Onnaar
Azhudhakan Neerum Anaiththu
Dinamalar:
Adoring hands of foes hide arms 
Their sobbing tears have lurking harms.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Tis just, when men make much of you, and then despise,
To make them smile, and slap in friendship's guise.
Transliteration: It is the duty of kings to affect great love but make it die (inwardly); as regard those foes who shew them great friendship but despise them (in their heart).
T.Kannan: Men may amply aid you, yet despise you in their heart; make them laugh, but let feigned friendship die.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Cajole and crush with friendly guise
Those who flatter you but despise within.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Policy requires that hostility to a foe should be hidden under a smile.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Cajole and crush with friendly guise Those
who flatter you but despise within.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Exuding affection externally but harboring derision inside. humour such people but let their friendship fade away.
Various Translators:
Mikachcheydhu Thammellu Vaarai
Nakachcheydhu
Natpinul Saappullar Paatru
Dinamalar:
In open who praise, at heart despise 
Cajole and crush them in friendly guise.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When one's foes begin to affect friendship, one should love them with one's looks, and, cherishing no love in the heart, give up (even the former).
Transliteration:
When foes, in time, play friendship's part 
Feign love on face but not in heart.
T.Kannan:
When time shall come that foes as friends appear,
Then thou, to hide a hostile heart, a smiling face may'st wear.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When the time comes that foes pose as friends, keep a friendly face but banish their brotherhood from your heart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
While playing a friend to foes, keep a friendly face
But banish them from thy heart.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: When the enemy pretends alliance, receive him with outward smile and inward distrust.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
While playing a friend to foes, keep a
friendly face But banish them from thy heart.
Various Translators: If there comes a time for camaraderie with your adversaries, sport it on the face but keep it out of your heart.
Dinamalar:
Pakainatpaam Kaalam Varungaal
Mukanattu
Akanatpu Oreei Vital

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
This is folly's prominent vein 
To favour loss and forego gain.
Transliteration:
What one thing merits folly's special name.
Letting gain go, loss for one's own to claim!
T.Kannan: What is folly? It is holding on to that which is harmful and throwing away that which is helpful.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Stupidity clings to the evil and lets slip the good.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If there is a thing called folly,
It is seizing what brings ill and letting the good slip.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If there is a thing called folly, It is
seizing what brings ill and letting the good slip.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Naivete can be defined as embracing all that is detrimental and relinquishing all that is rewarding.
Various Translators: Folly is one (of the chief defects); it is that which (makes one) incur loss and forego gain.
Dinamalar:
Pedhaimai Enpadhondru Yaadhenin
Edhangontu
Oodhiyam Poka Vital

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Pedhaimaiyul Ellaam Pedhaimai
Kaadhanmai
Kaiyalla Thankat Seyal
Transliteration:
Folly of follies is to lead 
A lewd and lawless life so bad.
T.Kannan:
Mid follies chiefest folly is to fix your love
On deeds which to you station unbefitting prove.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The folly of all follies is to find pleasure in doing what one is forbidden to do.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The crown of stupidity is the desire to do evil.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Folly among follies is the fondness for doing things
Beyond one's reach.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The greatest folly is that which leads one to take delight in doing what is forbidden.
Various Translators:
Folly among follies is the fondness for
doing things Beyond one's reach.
Dinamalar: The height of naivete is to fall in love with what can never be one’s own.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Lack of remorse, having no mission, being devoid of compassion, inability to cherish anything are traits of the witless.
Transliteration:
Naanaamai Naataamai Naarinmai
Yaadhondrum
Penaamai Pedhai Thozhil
T.Kannan:
Shameless, aimless, callous, listless 
Such are the marks of foolishness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ashamed of nothing, searching nothing out, of loveless heart,
Nought cherishing, 'tis thus the foll will play his part.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Shamelessness, negligence, arrogance and giddiness mark the stupid.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To be shameless, uninquisitive, loveless and uncaring are four failings common among all fools.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Shamelessness, aimlessness, callousness and listlessness
Are marks of foolishness.
Various Translators: Shamelessness indifference (to what must be sought after), harshness, and aversion for everything (that ought to be desired) are the qualities of the fool.
Dinamalar:
Shamelessness, aimlessness, callousness
and listlessness Are marks of foolishness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
There is no greater fool than he Who has
studied and taught, but lacks control.
Transliteration: There is no greater dolt than one who has learnt the essential texts, grasped their essence and expounds them to others but does not abide by them.
T.Kannan:
Odhi Unarndhum Pirarkkuraiththum
Thaanatangaap
Pedhaiyin Pedhaiyaar Il
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Most stupid is the learned fool who remains disloyal to his own noble teaching.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
No fool equals the fool who learns 
Knows, teaches, but self control spurns.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The sacred law he reads and learns, to other men expounds, 
Himself obeys not: where can greater fool be found?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: No fool is more foolish than one who eagerly expounds his learning to others while failing to follow it himself.
Various Translators:
There is no greater fool than he
Who has studied and taught, but lacks control.
Dinamalar: There are no greater fools than he who, though he has read and understood (a great deal) and even taught it to others, does not walk according to his own teaching.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A fool does deeds in a single birth That
will plunge him in hell in the succeeding seven.
Transliteration: The deeds of a dimwit in one life is enough to doom him in hell for seven lifetimes.
T.Kannan: Acts of folly done in one birth cause misery to him in seven more births to come.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Orumaich Cheyalaatrum Pedhai
Ezhumaiyum
Thaanpuk Kazhundhum Alaru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The fool suffers seven fold hells 
In single birth of hellish ills.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The fool will merit hell in one brief life on earth,
In which he entering sinks through sevenfold round of birth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It only takes a single birth for a fool to earn by his efforts a morass of misery in the succeeding seven births.
Various Translators: A fool can procure in a single birth a hell into which he may enter and suffer through all the seven births.
Dinamalar:
A fool does deeds in a single birth
That will plunge him in hell in the succeeding seven.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The task undertaken by a foolish man is spoiled and also ruined.
Transliteration:
When a half-baked fool takes on a task,
The task is undone, and so is he!
T.Kannan: If an injudicious idiot takes up a task, it is not only destined to fail but will also land him up in fetters.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Poipatum Ondro Punaipoonum
Kaiyariyaap
Pedhai Vinaimer Kolin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A know nothing fool daring a deed 
Not only fails but feels fettered.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When fool some task attempts with uninstructed pains,
It fails; nor that alone, himself he binds with chains.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Not knowing how to act, when a fool undertakes an enterprise, he doesn’t just fail, he shackles himself in chains.
Various Translators: If the fool, who knows not how to act undertakes a work, he will (certainly) fail. (But) is it all ? He will even adorn himself with fetters.
Dinamalar:
When a half-baked fool takes on a task,
The task is undone, and so is he!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Strangers and not relatives fatten on the unlimited wealth of a fool.
Transliteration:
Should a fool get hold of a great fortune,
Strangers will feast while his kindred starve.
T.Kannan: When great wealth falls on a fool, strangers shall feast, while the kith and kin starve.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Edhilaar Aarath Thamarpasippar
Pedhai
Perunjelvam Utrak Katai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Strangers feast and kinsmen fast 
When fools mishandle fortunes vast.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When fools are blessed with fortune's bounteous store,
Their foes feed full, their friends are prey to hunger sore.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If a fool happens to get an immense fortune, his neighbours will enjoy it while his relations starve.
Various Translators: Should a fool fall upon a great fortune, strangers will feast while his family starves.
Dinamalar:
Should a fool get hold of a great fortune,
Strangers will feast while his kindred starve.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A fool that lives by a fortune is like a mad man in his drunken glee.
Transliteration:
A fool getting hold of wealth Is like a
lunatic getting drunk.
T.Kannan: When an idiot ends up possessing something, it resembles someone already in a groggy state getting drunk.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Maiyal Oruvan Kaliththatraal
Pedhaidhan
Kaiyondru Utaimai Perin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A fool happening to possess something is like the intoxication of one who is (already) giddy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Fools possessing something on hand 
Like dazed and drunken stupids stand.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When folly's hand grasps wealth's increase, 'twill be
As when a mad man raves in drunken glee.
Various Translators: If a fool happens to acquire something of value, he will behave like a drunken lunatic.
Dinamalar:
A fool getting hold of wealth
Is like a lunatic getting drunk.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Sweet indeed is a fool's friendship,
For when it breaks there is no pain.
Transliteration:
Sweet indeed is a fool's friendship, For
when it breaks there is no pain.
T.Kannan: Friendship with dimwits is terribly sweet; there is no grief when they part.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The friendship between fools is exceedingly delightful (to each other): for at parting there will be nothing to cause them pain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Peridhinidhu Pedhaiyaar Kenmai
Pirivinkan
Peezhai Tharuvadhon Ril
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Friendship with fools is highly sweet 
For without a groan we part.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Friendship of fools is very pleasant thing;
Parting with them will leave behind no sting
Various Translators: Friendship among fools is particularly sweet, for there is not the slightest pain when they part.
Dinamalar: Verily sweet are the uses of fools’ love. For nothing is lost in a separation.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A fool's entry into a learned assembly
Is like entering a shrine with unclean legs.
Transliteration: The appearance of a fool in an assembly of the learned is like placing (one's) unwashed feet on a bed.
T.Kannan:
A fool's entry into a learned assembly Is
like entering a shrine with unclean legs.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A fool mingling with the learned and noble is like placing unwashed dirty feet on a clean bed.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kazhaaakkaal Palliyul Vaiththatraal
Saandror
Kuzhaaaththup Pedhai Pukal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Entrance of fools where Savants meet 
Looks like couch trod by unclean feet.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Like him who seeks his couch with unwashed feet,
Is fool whose foot intrudes where wise men meet.
Various Translators: A fool’s stepping into a saintly council is like entering a clean bed with filthy feet.
Dinamalar: A fool’s entry into the assembly of the wise is like one’s unclean foot on the bed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The lack of lacks is the lack of knowledge.
Other lacks are not deemed such by the world.
Transliteration: The want of wisdom is the greatest of all wants; but that of wealth the world will not regard as such.
T.Kannan:
The lack of lacks is the lack of
knowledge. Other lacks are not deemed such by the
world.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Lack of wisdom is the worst that one can lack; whatever else they lack, the world cares not.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Arivinmai Inmaiyul Inmai Piridhinmai
Inmaiyaa Vaiyaa Thulaku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Want of wisdom is want of wants 
Want of aught else the world nev'r counts.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Want of knowledge, 'mid all wants the sorest want we deem;
Want of other things the world will not as want esteem
Various Translators: Of all forms of poverty, poverty of intellect is the most serious; other forms of poverty are not regarded serious by the world.
Dinamalar: Dearth of wisdom is the direst destitution. Other poverties the world deems less impoverishing.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Should a fool gift a thing heartily, it is nothing but
Due to the penance of the recipient.
Transliteration: (The cause of) a fool cheerfully giving (something) is nothing else but the receiver's merit (in a former birth).
T.Kannan:
Should a fool gift a thing heartily, it is
nothing but Due to the penance of the recipient.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If ever the unwise give wholeheartedly, it is nothing but the result of the receiver’s penance.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Arivilaan Nenjuvandhu Eedhal
Piridhiyaadhum
Illai Peruvaan Thavam
Ramachandra Dikshitar: If a fool makes a gift with pleasure, it is due to the recipient’s luck.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When fool bestows with glee a gift 
It comes but by getter's merit.
Various Translators:
The gift of foolish man, with willing heart bestowed, is nought,
But blessing by receiver's penance bought.
Dinamalar: If any merit is gained when a fool gives a gift, however gladly, it is due to the recipient’s past penance and nothing else.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The suffering that ignorant men inflict upon themselves can hardly be contrived by their enemies.
Transliteration: The suffering that fools inflict upon themselves is hardly possible even to foes.
T.Kannan:
The harm fools do to themselves
Is beyond anything their foes do to them.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The harm fools do to themselves Is beyond
anything their foes do to them.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The injury that the unintelligent can inflict on themselves. not even their enemies can fare better.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The unwise inflict upon themselves more harm than the enemies can think of.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Arivilaar Thaandhammaip Peezhikkum
Peezhai
Seruvaarkkum Seydhal Aridhu
Various Translators:
The self torments of fools exceed 
Ev'n tortures of their foes indeed.
Dinamalar:
With keener anguish foolish men their won hearts wring,
Than aught that even malice of their foes can bring.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What is stupidity? The arrogance that cries,
'Behold, we claim the glory of the wise.'
Transliteration: What is stupidity, you ask? It is the conceit that dares to declare, “I am wise.”
T.Kannan: What is called want of wisdom is the vanity which says, "We are wise".
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What is stupidity? It is that vanity
Which dares to declare, I am wise.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Where does conceit dwell but in the immature mind?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What is stupidity? It is that vanity Which
dares to declare, 'I am wise.'
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What is simplemindedness but the vain presumption of one’s own intelligence.
Various Translators:
Venmai Enappatuva Thiyaadhenin Onmai
Utaiyamyaam Ennum Serukku
Dinamalar:
Stupidity is vanity 
That cries "We have sagacity"

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If men what they have never learned assume to know,
Upon their real learning's power a doubt 'twill throw.
Transliteration: Fools pretending to know what has not been read (by them) will rouse suspicion even as to what they have thoroughly mastered.
T.Kannan: He who pretends to knowledge he does not possess raises doubts about the things he really knows.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pretence to learning not learnt,
Calls in question the learning learnt.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Pretension to knowledge beyond one’s province makes men suspect the proficiency in one’s own province.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Pretence to learning not learnt, Calls in
question the learning learnt.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Brazenly acting out what one has not learnt arouses doubts over that they’ve flawlessly mastered.
Various Translators:
Kallaadha Merkon Tozhukal Kasatara
Valladhooum Aiyam Tharum
Dinamalar:
Feigning knowledge that one has not 
Leads to doubt ev'n that he has got.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even to cover one's nakedness would be folly, if (one's) faults were not covered (by forsaking them).
Transliteration:
Fools their nakedness conceal 
And yet their glaring faults reveal.
T.Kannan:
Fools are they who their nakedness conceal,
And yet their faults unveiled reveal.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Fools follow a perverse path, clothing their well formed naked body, yet never thinking to conceal their deformed mind.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Can a fool be said to be clothed
When his faults lie exposed?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: What availeth one’s garment if one’s defects lie naked to the world?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Can a fool be said to be clothed When his
faults lie exposed?
Various Translators: It is simpleminded to cover one’s private parts when there is no way to mask their flaws.
Dinamalar:
Atram Maraiththalo Pullarivu
Thamvayin
Kutram Maraiyaa Vazhi

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The fool that slights sacred counsels 
Upon himself great harm entails.
Transliteration:
From out his soul who lets the mystic teachings die,
Entails upon himself abiding misery.
T.Kannan: Neglecting valuable advice, an ignorant man becomes the cause of his own misery.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A learned fool doth harm to himself.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A fool who can't hold on to rare secrets
Does great harm to himself.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A fool who can't hold on to rare secrets
Does great harm to himself.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When a precious teaching is imparted to a simpleton, by not grasping it, they self-inflict immense harm.
Various Translators: The fool who neglects precious counsel does, of his own accord, a great injury to himself.
Dinamalar:
Arumarai Sorum Arivilaan Seyyum
Perumirai Thaane Thanakku

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Evavum Seykalaan Thaandheraan
Avvuyir
Poom Alavumor Noi
Transliteration:
He listens not nor himself knows 
Plague is his life until it goes.
T.Kannan:
Advised, he heeds not: of himself knows nothing wise;
This man's whole life is all one plague until he dies.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: That soul who neither follows another’s orders nor fathoms what to do himself creates nothing but torment until he leaves this life.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A fool neither listens to wise counsel nor exerts himself. He will be a plague to the world till his death.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Heeds no advice; knows nothing wise;
His life is an illness till he dies.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The fool will not perform (his duties) even when advised nor ascertain them himself; such a soul is a burden (to the earth) till it departs (from the body).
Various Translators:
Heeds no advice; knows nothing wise; His
life is an illness till he dies.
Dinamalar: He neither obeys others nor reasons out himself. he is an ailment till he is alive.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He who shows him who can’t see, himself can’t see; he who can’t see sees only what he sees.
Transliteration:
Kaanaadhaan Kaattuvaan Thaankaanaan
Kaanaadhaan
Kantaanaam Thaankanta Vaaru
T.Kannan:
Sans Self sight in vain one opens Sight
To the blind who bet their sight as right.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
That man is blind to eyes that will not see who knowledge shows; 
The blind man still in his blind fashion knows.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who seeks to enlighten a fool befools himself i For the conceited fool thinks that he knows everything.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: As an unseeing man sees only the ways of his own mind, whoever attempts to open the eyes of those who will not see is himself blind.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
He is a fool, who tries to open the eyes of a fool,
For a fool sees things only his own way.
Various Translators: One who would teach a fool will (simply) betray his folly; and the fool would (still) think himself "wise in his own conceit".
Dinamalar:
He is a fool, who tries to open the eyes
of a fool, For a fool sees things only his own way.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
He who denies what the world affirms Will
be thought a demon on earth.
Transliteration: What the (wise of the) world says exists, he denies; he shall be deemed a ghost in this world.
T.Kannan:
Ulakaththaar Untenpadhu Illenpaan
Vaiyaththu
Alakaiyaa Vaikkap Patum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: He who is out of tune with the world is regarded a demon.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To people's "Yes" who proffer "No" 
Deemed as ghouls on earth they go.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who what the world affirms as false proclaim,
O'er all the earth receive a demon's name.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He who denies as false what the world declares to be true is deemed to be an earthly demon.
Various Translators:
He who denies what the world affirms
Will be thought a demon on earth.
Dinamalar: He who denies the existence of what the world believes in will be regarded as a demon on earth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Hatred, they say, is the disease That
spreads the plague of discord among all life.
Transliteration: The concomitant ills of the uncultured trait of being at divergence with all beings is termed as discord.
T.Kannan: Hatred is a foul disease that brings discord among men.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ikalenpa Ellaa Uyirkkum Pakalennum
Panpinmai Paarikkum Noi
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Hatred is a plague that divides 
And rouses illwill on all sides.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Hostility disunion's plague will bring,
That evil quality, to every living thing.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is said that hatred is the disease that spreads the plagues of discord among all living creatures.
Various Translators: The disease which fosters the evil of disunion among all creatures is termed hatred by the wise.
Dinamalar:
Hatred, they say, is the disease
That spreads the plague of discord among all life.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: What if one does us harm out of hatred? It is the height of wisdom to resist not evil.
Transliteration:
Even if disagreeable things are done to
cause rift, Better do nothing painful to avoid
conflict.
T.Kannan: On account of differences, if one offends us, it is important to disregard the discord and do no harm.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pakalkarudhip Patraa Seyinum
Ikalkarudhi
Innaasey Yaamai Thalai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Rouse not hatred and confusion 
Though foes provoke disunion
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though men disunion plan, any do thee much despite,
'Tis best no enmity to plan, nor evil deeds requite.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though men devise disunity and deliberately harm you, the highest path plots no hateful retribution.
Various Translators: Though disagreeable things may be done from (a feeling of) disunion, it is far better that nothing painful be done from (that of) hatred.
Dinamalar:
Even if disagreeable things are done to cause rift,
Better do nothing painful to avoid conflict.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He who is rid of the full disease of hatred crowns himself with eternal glory.
Transliteration:
If that dire disease called hostility is
discarded, What yields is undying everlasting fame.
T.Kannan: If the distressing disease of discord is discarded, it yields flawless fame that never fades.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ikalennum Evvanoi Neekkin
Thavalillaath
Thaavil Vilakkam Tharum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Shun the plague of enmity 
And win everlasting glory.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If enmity, that grievous plague, you shun,
Endless undying praises shall be won.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To rid one-self of the distressing dtsease of hatred will bestow (on one) a never-decreasing imperishable fame.
Various Translators: Removing the incurable cancer called hatred reveals one’s immortal, undiminishing splendor.
Dinamalar:
If that dire disease called hostility is discarded,
What yields is undying everlasting fame.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It is the joy of joys to bury hatred, the evil of all evils.
Transliteration:
When the misery of miseries called malice
ceases, There comes the joy of joys.
T.Kannan: Discord is the misery of all miseries; when it goes the joy of all joys ensues.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Inpaththul Inpam Payakkum Ikalennum
Thunpaththul Thunpang Ketin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If hatred which is the greatest misery is destroyed, it will yield the greatest delight.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Hate the woe of woes destroy; 
Then joy of joys you can enjoy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Joy of joys abundant grows,
When malice dies, that woe of woes.
Various Translators: The quelling of hatred, that sorrow of sorrows, confers on man the joy of joys.
Dinamalar:
When the misery of miseries called malice ceases,
There comes the joy of joys.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who can ever overcome the one,
Who refuses to give in to feelings of hatred?
Transliteration:
Who can ever overcome the one, Who refuses
to give in to feelings of hatred?
T.Kannan: Those who can act against their discords. who has the capacity to consider overcoming them?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Who indeed would think of conquering those who naturally shrink back from hatred ?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ikaledhir Saaindhozhuka Vallaarai
Yaare
Mikalookkum Thanmai Yavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who can overcome them in glory 
That are free from enmity?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If men from enmity can keep their spirits free,
Who over them shall gain the victory?
Various Translators: Who is there who can conquer those who have relinquished all hostilities?
Dinamalar: Can anyone overcome him who has conquered hatred?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Want and ruin will soon befall the life of one
Who delights in excess hostility.
Transliteration: Failure and ruin are not far from him who says it is sweet to excel in hatred.
T.Kannan:
Want and ruin will soon befall the life of
one Who delights in excess hostility.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The life of one who relishes a spate of discords has in its proximity suffering and demise.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ikalin Mikalinidhu Enpavan Vaazhkkai
Thavalum Ketalum Naniththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
His fall and ruin are quite near 
Who holds enmity sweet and dear.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The life of those who cherished enmity hold dear,
To grievous fault and utter death is near.
Various Translators: For all who boast that they take delight in hatred, failure and death are drawing near.
Dinamalar: Swift ruin awaits one who delights in discord.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those learned rapt up in destructive hate
Will never see the triumphant nature of truth.
Transliteration: Those whose judgement brings misery through its connection with hatred cannot understand the triumphant nature of truth.
T.Kannan:
Those learned rapt up in destructive hate
Will never see the triumphant nature of truth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: They shall never see the transcendent truth, those devious minds teeming with discord.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Mikalmeval Meypporul Kaanaar
Ikalmeval
Innaa Arivi Navar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They cannot see the supreme Truth 
Who hate and injure without ruth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The very truth that greatness gives their eyes can never see,
Who only know to work men woe, fulfilled of enmity.
Various Translators: Those who nourish hatred will never see the triumphant light of truth.
Dinamalar: Men filled with hatred, knowingly causing harm to others, never see that their hoped for triumph lies in God’s true grace.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To resist hatred is a gain.
Yielding to it, one is overcome by ruin.
Transliteration: Shrinking back from hatred will yield wealth; indulging in its increase will hasten ruin.
T.Kannan:
To resist hatred is a gain. Yielding to
it, one is overcome by ruin.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Siding against one’s own discord is valuable; allowing it to accumulate invites injury.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ikalirku Edhirsaaidhal Aakkam
Adhanai
Mikalookkin Ookkumaam Ketu
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To fight against hatred is to save one’s soul; to harbour it is to court one’s own ruin.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To turn from enmity is gain 
Fomenting it brings fast ruin.
Various Translators:
Tis gain to turn the soul from enmity;
Ruin reigns where this hath mastery.
Dinamalar: Wealth increases when a man walks away from hatred and diminishes whenever he draws it near.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Seeing a prosperous season approach, men neglect hatred. In times of ruin, they nurture it lavishly.
Transliteration: At the approach of wealth one will not think of hatred (but) to secure one's ruin, one will look to its increase.
T.Kannan:
Destined to prosper one will not look at hatred.
Destined for ruin, one will see it all the time.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Destined to prosper one will not look at
hatred. Destined for ruin, one will see it all the
time.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: When there is benefit, the discord goes unnoticed. When it is detrimental, it seems stark.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Freedom from hatred is the sign of one’s prosperity. Presence of hatred foreshadows decline of one’s fortune.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ikalkaanaan Aakkam Varungaal Adhanai
Mikalkaanum Ketu Thararku
Various Translators:
Fortune favours when hate recedes
Hatred exceeding ruin breeds.
Dinamalar:
Men think not hostile thought in fortune's favouring hour,
They cherish enmity when in misfortune's power.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
From enmity do all affictive evils flow;
But friendliness doth wealth of kindly good bestow.
Transliteration: Out of hatred springs all bitter suffering, while cheerful friendship yields good fortune’s every joy.
T.Kannan: All calamities are caused by hatred; but by the delight (of friendship) is caused the great wealth of good virtues.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
From hatred comes all evil.
And from friendship the pride of goodness.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: From love springs the proud joy of a righteous life.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From hatred comes all evil. And from
friendship the pride of goodness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: All woes emanate from discord. The great wealth. good deeds and joy for all, stems from friendly smiles.
Various Translators:
Ikalaanaam Innaadha Ellaam
Nakalaanaam
Nannayam Ennum Serukku
Dinamalar:
All evils come from enmity
All goodness flow from amity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
With stronger than thyself, turn from the strife away;
With weaker shun not, rather court the fray.
Transliteration: Avoid offering resistance to the strong; (but) never fail to cherish enmity towards the weak.
T.Kannan: Rein in antagonism against the strong, but unleash animosity against feeble adversaries.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Avoid opposing the strong.
Cherish your desire of enmity with the weak.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Avoid hostility towards the powerful do not cease from hostility towards the weak.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Avoid opposing the strong. Cherish your
desire of enmity with the weak.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Avoid hostility with the strong; unleash your enmity on the weak failing to do so.
Various Translators:
Valiyaarkku Maaretral Ompuka Ompaa
Meliyaarmel Meka Pakai
Dinamalar:
Turn from strife with foes too strong 
With the feeble for battle long.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: How can he who is unloving, destitute of powerful aids, and himself without strength overcome the might of his foe ?
Transliteration:
Loveless, aidless, powerless king 
Can he withstand an enemy strong?
T.Kannan:
No kinsman's love, no strength of friends has he;
How can he bear his foeman's enmity?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: How can an unloving man, with neither powerful allies nor the strength to stand alone, overcome mighty enemies?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
No love, great support, or own strength has he!
How can he survive a strong enemy?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: One devoid of love has neither the strength nor support. How can he stem the tide of the advancing foe?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
No love, great support, or own strength
has he! How can he survive a strong enemy?
Various Translators: Loveless, lacks right companions, and on his own has no strengths. how shall the might of his foes fail?
Dinamalar:
Anpilan Aandra Thunaiyilan
Thaandhuvvaan
Enpariyum Edhilaan Thuppu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Unskilled, timid, miser, misfit
He is easy for foes to hit.
Transliteration:
A craven thing! knows nought, accords with none, gives nought away;
To wrath of any foe he falls an easy prey.
T.Kannan: He who is fearful, ignorant, unfriendly and uncharitable proves an easy prey to his enemies.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: He who is cowardly, ignorant, restless and niggardly, falls an easy prey to his enemy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A coward, ignorant, unsocial and mean
Is an easy prey to his enemy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A coward, ignorant, unsocial and mean Is
an easy prey to his enemy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Timid, ignorant, unsettled and ungenerous. he is easy prey to his foes.
Various Translators: In the estimation of foes miserably weak is he, who is timid, ignorant, unsociable and niggardly.
Dinamalar:
Anjum Ariyaan Amaivilan Eekalaan
Thanjam Eliyan Pakaikku

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Neengaan Vekuli Niraiyilan
Egngnaandrum
Yaanganum Yaarkkum Elidhu
Transliteration:
The wrathful restive man is prey
To any, anywhere any day.
T.Kannan:
His wrath still blazes, every secret told; each day
This man's in every place to every foe an easy prey.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Letting go of his secrets but not his antipathy, a man becomes easy prey to anyone, anywhere, anytime.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who does not abstain from anger and has insufficient resources can be attacked by any one at any time.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The unrestrained and angry are an easy prey
To anyone, anytime, anywhere.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He who neither refrains from anger nor keeps his secrets will at all times and in all places be easily conquered by all.
Various Translators:
The unrestrained and angry are an easy
prey To anyone, anytime, anywhere.
Dinamalar: Never ceases to be angry, ever insatiate. anytime, anywhere, he is easy prey for anyone.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Doesn’t look up the right means, seizes not his opportunities, fears no ignominy, and lacks character. his foes relish him.
Transliteration:
Vazhinokkaan Vaaippana Seyyaan
Pazhinokkaan
Panpilan Patraarkku Inidhu
T.Kannan:
Crooked, cruel, tactless and base 
Any foe can fell him with ease.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
No way of right he scans, no precepts blind, no crimes affright,
No grace of good he owns; such man's his foes' delight.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He who does not walk in the right path or follow the rule, who is callous to public odium falls an easy victim to his enemies.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Without character, conscience, piety and propriety, a man may yet be delightful—to his enemies!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Foes prefer the tactless and shameless one
Who cares not for codes and scorns.
Various Translators: (A) pleasing (object) to his foes is he who reads not moral works, does nothing that is enjoined by them cares not for reproach and is not possessed of good qualities.
Dinamalar:
Foes prefer the tactless and shameless one
Who cares not for codes and scorns.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those with blind fury and inordinate lust
Are vulnerable enemies to be nursed with.
Transliteration: Has unheard of and unseeing anger, and is prodigiously lustful. enmity with him will be seized with glee.
T.Kannan:
Kaanaach Chinaththaan Kazhiperung
Kaamaththaan
Penaamai Penap Patum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One can court the enmity of the blindly wrathful and the inordinately lustful.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Blind in rage and mad in lust 
To have his hatred is but just.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Blind in his rage, his lustful passions rage and swell;
If such a man mislikes you, like it well.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even hatred can be a welcome thing, when it comes from scoundrels seized by blind rage and indulgent lust.
Various Translators:
Those with blind fury and inordinate lust
Are vulnerable enemies to be nursed with.
Dinamalar: Highly to be desired is the hatred of him whose anger is blind, and whose lust increases beyond measure.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
He is a foe worth purchasing Who starts a
fight and does all wrong.
Transliteration: He is adept at harming his own endeavours. give anything to gain his enmity.
T.Kannan: It is good to get the enmity of one who is blind to one’s purpose.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kotuththum Kolalventum Mandra
Atuththirundhu
Maanaadha Seyvaan Pakai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pay and buy his enmity 
Who muddles chance with oddity.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Unseemly are his deeds, yet, proffering aid, the man draws nigh;
His hate 'tis cheap at any price be sure to buy!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Some men undertake a task, then undermine it unawares. Acquire their hatred—indeed, pay good money for it.
Various Translators: It is indeed necessary to obtain even by purchase the hatred of him who having begun (a work) does what is not conductive (to its accomplishment).
Dinamalar:
He is a foe worth purchasing
Who starts a fight and does all wrong.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One who is void of virtue but full of vice invites the foe.
Transliteration:
Enemies will rejoice the one With no
virtues, many vices, and no allies.
T.Kannan: Shorn of good qualities, filled with flaws, free of allies. he is the best safeguard for his foes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kunanilanaaik Kutram Palavaayin
Maatraarkku
Inanilanaam Emaap Putaiththu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
With no virtue but full of vice 
He loses friends and delights foes.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No gracious gifts he owns, faults many cloud his fame:
His foes rejoice, for none with kindred claim.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If a man has no virtues and many vices, he will surely have no allies, and this will be his enemies’ surest advantage.
Various Translators: He will become friendless who is without (any good) qualities. and whose faults are many; (such a character) is a help to (his) foes.
Dinamalar:
Enemies will rejoice the one
With no virtues, many vices, and no allies.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The cowardly and the foolish gladden the heart of the foe beyond measure.
Transliteration:
Enemies' joy has no bounds When they get a
fool and coward as a foe.
T.Kannan: Rapturous joy never ends for aggressors who gain as foes, the foolish and fearful .
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seruvaarkkuch Chenikavaa Inpam
Arivilaa
Anjum Pakaivarp Perin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The joy of heroes knows no bounds 
When timid fools are opponents.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The joy of victory is never far removed from those
Who've luck to meet with ignorant and timid foes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: There will be no end of lofty delights to the victorious, if their foes are (both) ignorant and timid.
Various Translators: Finding that his foe is ignorant and afraid to fight, the attacker’s cheerfulness cannot forsake him.
Dinamalar:
Enemies' joy has no bounds
When they get a fool and coward as a foe.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Glory awaits one who does not exploit the ignorant.
Transliteration:
No glory or gain can ever come to one Who
cannot overcome an ignorant foe.
T.Kannan: Ignorant, irritable and disinclined to earn a trifle. fame never favours him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kallaan Vekulum Siruporul
Egngnaandrum
Ollaanai Ollaa Tholi
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The light (of fame) will never be gained by him who gains not the trifling reputation of having fought an unlearned (foe).
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Glory's light he will not gain
Who fails to fight a fool and win.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The task of angry war with men unlearned in virtue's lore
Who will not meet, glory shall meet him never more.
Various Translators: Fame will flee the grasp of one who fails to grasp the wealth of an enemy who is angry and unlearned.
Dinamalar:
No glory or gain can ever come to one
Who cannot overcome an ignorant foe.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
One should never wish for the accursed thing
Called enmity, even in jest.
Transliteration:
One should never wish for the accursed
thing Called enmity, even in jest.
T.Kannan: Enmity is an oddity that is best left undesired even in jest.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The evil of hatred is not of a nature to be desired by one even in sport.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pakaiennum Panpi Ladhanai Oruvan
Nakaiyeyum Ventarpaatru Andru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let not one even as a sport
The ill natured enmity court.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
For Hate, that ill conditioned thing, not e'en in jest,
Let any evil longing rule your breast.
Various Translators: So accursed is the thing called hatred that one should never wish for it—even in jest.
Dinamalar: One should not desire, even in a sportive mood, the evil known as enmity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Make foes, if you must, with bowmen
And never of men whose weapon is their tongue.
Transliteration: Though you may incur the hatred of warriors whose ploughs are bows, incur not that of ministers whose ploughs are words.
T.Kannan:
Make foes, if you must, with bowmen And
never of men whose weapon is their tongue.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: You may gain the enmity of the ploughman wielding a bow as plough but not that of the one wielding the word.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Viller Uzhavar Pakaikolinum Kollarka
Soller Uzhavar Pakai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Incur the hate of bow ploughers 
But not the hate of word ploughers.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Although you hate incur of those whose ploughs are bows,
Make not the men whose ploughs are words your foes!
Various Translators: It is bad enough to incur the enmity of those who live by the bow, but never provoke the hatred of those who sow and reap with words.
Dinamalar: You may not fear the sword; but beware of the pen.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
It is worse than madness for one who has no allies,
To make numerous enemies.
Transliteration: He who being alone, incurs the hatred of many is more infatuated than even mad men.
T.Kannan:
It is worse than madness for one who has
no allies, To make numerous enemies.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One who, alone, antagonizes many, has a dimmer wit than a loony.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Emur Ravarinum Ezhai Thamiyanaaip
Pallaar Pakaikol Pavan
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Forlorn, who rouses many foes 
The worst insanity betrays.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Than men of mind diseased, a wretch more utterly forlorn,
Is he who stands alone, object of many foeman's scorn.
Various Translators: One who incurs the wrath of the enemy is blinder than the mad.
Dinamalar: One man who, all by himself, arouses hatred in many is crazier than any lunatic.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The world is secure under one
Whose nature can make friends of foes.
Transliteration: The world abides in the greatness of that good-natured man who behaves so as to turn hatred into friendship.
T.Kannan:
The world is secure under one Whose nature
can make friends of foes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The one with the virtue of turning a foe into a friend. the world shall rest under the sway of his virtuosity.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pakainatpaak Kontozhukum Panputai
Yaalan
Thakaimaikkan Thangitru Ulaku
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The world is under the sway of one who has the art of converting an enemy into a friend.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
This world goes safely in his grace 
Whose heart makes friends even of foes.
Various Translators:
The world secure on his dexterity depends,
Whose worthy rule can change his foes to friends.
Dinamalar: The world abides beneath the greatness of noble natured rulers who befriend even their enemies.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Finding that he faces two foes and has no allies, a lone man lures one to side with him.
Transliteration: He who is alone and helpless while his foes are two should secure one of them as an agreeable help (to himself).
T.Kannan:
While facing two foes, unaided and alone,
Make one your friend.
