Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
While facing two foes, unaided and alone,
Make one your friend.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If one has no allies but two foes, better befriend one of them.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: One who has no ally but two adversaries must befriend one of them.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thandhunai Indraal Pakaiyirantaal
Thaanoruvan
Indhunaiyaak Kolkavatrin Ondru
Various Translators:
Alone, if two foes you oppose 
Make one of them your ally close.
Dinamalar:
Without ally, who flights with twofold enemy o'ermatched,
Must render one of these a friend attached.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Whether you trust or not, in time of sore distress,
Questions of diff'rence or agreement cease to press.
Transliteration: When distress dawns, neither draw near nor depart from new friends and foes—rather, leave them alone.
T.Kannan: Though (one's foe is) aware or not of one's misfortune one should act so as neither to join nor separate (from him).
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
In times of crisis, be wary of joining or opposing any,
Whether tested or untested.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: In a dark hour assume a neutral attitude either to your known enemy or to an unknown foe.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In times of crisis, be wary of joining or
opposing any, Whether tested or untested.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Whether you’ve qualified someone as a foe or not, in troubled times, it is better not to get cozy nor split.
Various Translators:
Therinum Theraa Vitinum Azhivinkan
Theraan Pakaaan Vital
Dinamalar:
Trust or distrust; during distress 
Keep aloof; don't mix with foes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To those who know them not, complain not of your woes;
Nor to your foeman's eyes infirmities disclose.
Transliteration: Relate not your suffering even to friends who are ignorant of it, nor refer to your weakness in the presence of your foes.
T.Kannan: Never tell your troubles to those who cannot comprehend them, nor expose your weaknesses to your enemies.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Keep your sorrows from strangers
And your weakness from foes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Whisper not your troubles to friends who cannot divine them; betray not your weakness to your enemy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Keep your sorrows from strangers And your
weakness from foes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Express not your pain to those who can’t empathize; expose not your frailties to your foes.
Various Translators:
Novarka Nondhadhu Ariyaarkku Mevarka
Menmai Pakaivar Akaththu
Dinamalar:
To those who know not, tell not your pain 
Nor your weakness to foes explain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The joy of one's foes will be destroyed if one guards oneself by knowing the way (of acting) and securing assistance.
Transliteration:
Know how and act and defend well
The pride of enemies shall fall.
T.Kannan:
Know thou the way, then do thy part, thyself defend;
Thus shall the pride of those that hate thee have an end.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Engineer a plan, execute that plan well and ensure your security—thus is the joy of rivals forever ruined.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Engineer, execute and defend.
Thus keep the pride of your foes at bay.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Plan well your design and arm yourself with all the sinews of war.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Engineer, execute and defend. Thus keep
the pride of your foes at bay.
Various Translators: Knowing oneself and one’s foes, preparing oneself and strengthening the defences. these surely shall quell the vanity of the enemy.
Dinamalar:
Vakaiyarindhu Tharseydhu Tharkaappa
Maayum
Pakaivarkan Patta Serukku

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Cut off thorn trees when young they are; 
Grown hard, they cut your hands beware.
Transliteration:
Destroy the thorn, while tender point can work thee no offence;
Matured by time, 'twill pierce the hand that pluck it thence.
T.Kannan: Chop down a thorny tree while it is young. Left to grow mature, it will one day cut the cutter’s hand.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Nip the thorn in the bud lest it should hurt the hands of those who seek to cut it when hardened into a tree.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Cut a thorny shrub when young.
Allowed to grow, it injures the hand that cuts.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Cut a thorny shrub when young. Allowed to
grow, it injures the hand that cuts.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Weed out a thorn tree when it is still slender; once fully grown, it’ll slash the hands of the weeder.
Various Translators: A thorny tree should be felled while young, (for) when it is grown it will destroy the hand of the feller.
Dinamalar:
Ilaidhaaka Mulmaram Kolka Kalaiyunar
Kaikollum Kaazhththa Itaththu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Uyirppa Ularallar Mandra Seyirppavar
Semmal Sidhaikkalaa Thaar
Transliteration:
To breathe on earth they are not fit 
Defying foes who don't defeat.
T.Kannan:
But breathe upon them, an they surely die,
Who fail to tame the pride of angry enemy.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who fail to quell a hostile rival’s pride will be blown away by the mere fact that he still breathes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: He is one among the dead who fails to subdue his naughty foe.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those who can't crush the pride of defying foes
Will cease to breathe long.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who do not destroy the pride of those who hate (them) will certainly not exist even to breathe.
Various Translators:
Those who can't crush the pride of defying
foes Will cease to breathe long.
Dinamalar: One who can’t crush the conceit of the enemy, will be vanquished the moment they hiss.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even shade and water, when noxious, can be baneful; kith and kin, when malicious, can be harmful.
Transliteration:
Nizhalneerum Innaadha Innaa
Thamarneerum
Innaavaam Innaa Seyin
T.Kannan:
Traitorous kinsmen will make you sad 
As water and shade do harm when bad.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Water and shade, if they unwholesome prove, will bring you pain;
And qualities of friends, who treacherous act, will be your bane.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Even shade and water, wholesome as they are, become pernicious where not needed; our kith and kin likewise are.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even shade and water are unpleasant if they breed disease. So, too, may relatives be unpleasant if they cause harm.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Even shade and water unwholesome can harm
Likewise one’s kinsmen if they hurt. (PS)
Various Translators: Shade and water are not pleasant, (if) they cause disease; so are the qualities of (one's) relations not agreeable, (if) they cause pain.
Dinamalar:
Even shade and water unwholesome can harm
Likewise one’s kinsmen if they hurt. (PS)

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No need to fear an enemy wielding a sword.
Beware of enemies posing as friends.
Transliteration: Fear not foes, overt like swords; but those faking as friends. fear the ties with them.
T.Kannan:
Vaalpola Pakaivarai Anjarka Anjuka
Kelpol Pakaivar Thotarpu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Be not afraid of open enemies with drawn swords; but beware of false friends.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
You need not sword like kinsmen fear 
Fear foes who feign as kinsmen dear.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Dread not the foes that as drawn swords appear;
Friendship of foes, who seem like kinsmen, fear!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Fear not the foe who is like a drawn sword; rather fear the friendship of an enemy who poses as kin.
Various Translators:
No need to fear an enemy wielding a sword.
Beware of enemies posing as friends.
Dinamalar: Fear not foes (who say they would cut) like a sword; (but) fear the friendship of foes (who seemingly act) like relations.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Guard against the foe within, lest he
strike you In times of peril like the potter's knife.
Transliteration: Fear internal strife and protect yourself; during trouble, like a tool that cuts wet clay, it will hurt without fail.
T.Kannan: Guard yourselves against your enemies from within. In your trying hour they will undermine your strength, like the potter’s knife, cleaving the mind asunder.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Utpakai Anjiththar Kaakka
Ulaivitaththu
Matpakaiyin Maanath Therum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The secret foe in days evil 
Will cut you, beware, like potters' steel.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Of hidden hate beware, and guard thy life;
In troublous time 'twill deeper wound than potter's knife.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Dread hatred from within and defend yourself against it. In calamitous times it will cut deeper than a potter’s knife.
Various Translators: Fear internal enmity and guard yourself; (if not) it will destroy (you) in an evil hour, as surely as the tool which cuts the potter's clay.
Dinamalar:
Guard against the foe within, lest he strike you
In times of peril like the potter's knife.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The land is seething with dissensions when the foes from within, appear on the scene.
Transliteration:
When hidden hatreds lurk in the mind,
Myriad miseries manifest among kin.
T.Kannan: When internal strife that disconcerts minds appears, it gives rise to flaws that unsettle the kith.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Manamaanaa Utpakai Thondrin
Inamaanaa
Edham Palavum Tharum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The evil minded foe within 
Foments trouble, spoils kinsmen!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If secret enmities arise that minds pervert,
Then even kin unkind will work thee grievous hurt.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Hidden hatreds may lurk only in the mind, yet among kin they can manifest many miseries.
Various Translators: The secret enmity of a person whose mind in unreformed will lead to many evils causing disaffection among (one's) relations.
Dinamalar:
When hidden hatreds lurk in the mind,
Myriad miseries manifest among kin.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Many evils dark as death befall a king, when his own kith and kin sow dissensions in the land.
Transliteration:
Hidden hatred amongst kinsman Can cause
all sorts of deadly sorrows.
T.Kannan: If internal conflicts surface amongst the kin, many a destructive flaw is aroused.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Uralmuraiyaan Utpakai Thondrin
Iralmuraiyaan
Edham Palavum Tharum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A traitor among kinsmen will 
Bring life endangering evil.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Amid one's relatives if hidden hath arise,
'Twill hurt inflict in deadly wise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If there appears internal hatred in a (king's) family; it will lead to many a fatal crime.
Various Translators: Hate hidden in a kinsman’s heart will cause many miseries, and more—it will kill a man.
Dinamalar:
Hidden hatred amongst kinsman
Can cause all sorts of deadly sorrows.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If kinsmen were to play to the traitor it would be difficult to escape death.
Transliteration:
Unanimity will disappear for ever Once
disunity arises within a union.
T.Kannan: If disharmony crops up among those who are at one with each other, infallibility is impossible to achieve.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ondraamai Ondriyaar Katpatin
Egngnaandrum
Pondraamai Ondral Aridhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If hatred arises among (one's) own people, it will be hardly possible (for one) to escape death.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Discord in kings' circle entails 
Life destroying deadly evils.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If discord finds a place midst those who dwelt at one before,
'Tis ever hard to keep destruction from the door.
Various Translators: When hatred arises, dissension destroys unity, and men fall inescapably toward ever ready death.
Dinamalar:
Unanimity will disappear for ever
Once disunity arises within a union.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A house that harbours hatred, like a vial and its lid,
Seems one but comes apart.
Transliteration:
A house that harbours hatred, like a vial
and its lid, Seems one but comes apart.
T.Kannan: Though it appears well joint like a copper vessel, a house ridden with internal strifes shall never jell.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Never indeed will a family subject to internal hatred unite (really) though it may present an apparent union like that of a casket and its lid.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Seppin Punarchchipol Kootinum
Kootaadhe
Utpakai Utra Kuti
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A house hiding hostiles in core 
Just seems on like the lid in jar.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As casket with its cover, though in one they live alway,
No union to the house where hate concealed hath sway.
Various Translators: A house that harbors hatred will never be a united whole, though, like a vessel and its lid, it may appear to be one.
Dinamalar: There will be no real union in a house divided. The apparent unity is like the appearance of the casket and the lid seen as one.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A family with internal frictions wears out
And loses its strength like gold being filed.
Transliteration: A family subject to internal hatred will wear out and lose its strength like iron that has been filed away.
T.Kannan:
A family with internal frictions wears out
And loses its strength like gold being filed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Like a metal abraded by a file, the might of a clan is eroded by enemies within.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Aramporudha Ponpolath Theyum
Uramporudhu
Utpakai Utra Kuti
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
By secret spite the house wears out
Like gold crumbling by file's contact.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As gold with which the file contends is worn away,
So strength of house declines where hate concealed hath sway.
Various Translators: As iron is worn away by frequent filing, a family’s strength is eroded by incessant inner frictions.
Dinamalar: The family torn with internal dissensions dwindles in strength just like pure gold filed away by an iron file.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even a dissent as small as a seed,
Can trigger that destructive internal hatred.
Transliteration: Although internal hatred be as small as the fragment of the sesamum (seed), still does destruction dwell in it.
T.Kannan:
Even a dissent as small as a seed, Can
trigger that destructive internal hatred.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It maybe tiny as a split sesame, but disaster resides in internal strife.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Etpaka Vanna Sirumaiththe Aayinum
Utpakai Ulladhaang Ketu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Ruin lurks in enmity 
As slit in sesame though it be.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though slight as shred of 'sesame' seed it be,
Destruction lurks in hidden enmity.
Various Translators: Internal hostility little as it is, like a tiny seed, hides within a mighty evil.
Dinamalar: Internal dissension may seem as small as a split sesame seed, yet there is enough power in it to destroy.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To partner one with a hidden hate
Is to share a hut with a cobra.
Transliteration: Living with those who do not agree (with one) is like dwelling with a cobra (in the same) hut.
T.Kannan:
To partner one with a hidden hate Is to
share a hut with a cobra.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Life with those whose hearts are not in harmony is like staying in a hut with a snake for company.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Utampaatu Ilaadhavar Vaazhkkai
Kutangarul
Paampotu Utanurain Thatru
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Dwelling among men of hidden hate is like dwelling in a hamlet which harbours a snake.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Dwell with traitors that hate in heart 
Is dwelling with snake in selfsame hut.
Various Translators:
Domestic life with those who don’t agree,
Is dwelling in a shed with snake for company.
Dinamalar: Living with those who cannot dwell in harmony is like living in a hut with a deadly cobra.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Of all the ways to protect oneself, the foremost is this: do not belittle the prowess of powerful men.
Transliteration: Not to disregard the power of those who can carry out (their wishes) is more important than all the watchfulness of those who guard (themselves against evil).
T.Kannan:
The best way to guard oneself is to not spite
The powers of the prowess.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The best way to guard oneself is to not
spite The powers of the prowess.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: For those keen on self-preservation, the prominent concern is not to belittle the capabilities of the capable.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Not to offend the mighty is the crowning means of shielding one self.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Aatruvaar Aatral Ikazhaamai
Potruvaar
Potralul Ellaam Thalai
Various Translators:
Not to spite the mighty ones 
Safest safeguard to living brings.
Dinamalar:
The chiefest care of those who guard themselves from ill,
Is not to slight the powers of those who work their mighty will.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If men will lead their lives reckless of great men's will,
Such life, through great men's powers, will bring perpetual ill.
Transliteration: Disrespectful conduct toward great men will bring, through those great men, unremitting miseries.
T.Kannan: To behave without respect for the great (rulers) will make them do (us) irremediable evils.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Irreverence to the great will lead
To endless trouble through them.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Lack of reverence for the great results in endless troubles.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Irreverence to the great will lead To
endless trouble through them.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If we rankle those worthy of veneration, they can cause unceasing tribulation.
Various Translators:
Periyaaraip Penaadhu Ozhukir
Periyaaraal
Peraa Itumpai Tharum
Dinamalar:
To walk unmindful of the great 
Shall great troubles ceaseless create.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who ruin covet, let them shut their ears, and do despite
To those who, where they list, to ruin have the might.
Transliteration: If a person desires ruin, let him not listen to the righteous dictates of law, but commit crimes against those who are able to slay (other sovereigns).
T.Kannan: If you desire destruction, simply ignore the rules and provoke those who, if they desire, can destroy you.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
If destruction you desire, provoke those
Who in turn can destroy as they desire.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: To pick a quarrel with the mighty is to court one’s own ruin.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If destruction you desire, provoke those
Who in turn can destroy as they desire.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If you are keen on self destruction, act with disregard and denigrate those who can destroy at will.
Various Translators:
Ketalventin Kelaadhu Seyka
Atalventin
Aatru Pavarkan Izhukku
Dinamalar:
Heed not and do, if ruin you want
Offence against the mighty great.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The weak doing evil to the strong is like beckoning Yama to come (and destroy them).
Transliteration:
The weak who insult men of might 
Death with their own hands invite.
T.Kannan:
When powerless men 'gainst men of power will evil deeds essay,
'Tis beck'ning with the hand for Death to seize them for its prey.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: For the powerless to wreak harm upon the powerful is to summon Death with a gesturing hand.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
For the weak to challenge the mighty
Is to summon yama with the hand.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Behold the weak trying to do harm to the mighty. It is like beckoning unto death.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
For the weak to challenge the mighty Is to
summon yama with the hand.
Various Translators: The incapable venturing to harm the capable, is like waving a welcome to the deity of death.
Dinamalar:
Kootraththaik Kaiyaal Viliththatraal
Aatruvaarkku
Aatraadhaar Innaa Seyal

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Where can they go and thrive where 
Pursued by powerful monarch's ire?
Transliteration:
Who dare the fiery wrath of monarchs dread,
Where'er they flee, are numbered with the dead.
T.Kannan: Once he incurs a fierce king’s withering wrath, one is doomed, wherever he wanders, whatever he does.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Where is the refuge for one who incurs the wrath of the mighty monarch?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Where can he go and how can he thrive,
Who falls foul of a powerful king?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Where can he go and how can he thrive, Who
falls foul of a powerful king?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Wherever one flees, and forever, there can be no respite, after enraging a ruler with fiery might.
Various Translators: Those who have incurred the wrath of a cruel and mighty potentate will not prosper wherever they may go.
Dinamalar:
Yaantuch Chendru Yaantum Ularaakaar
VendhuppinVendhu Serappat Tavar

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Eriyaal Sutappatinum Uyvuntaam
Uyyaar
Periyaarp Pizhaiththozhuku Vaar
Transliteration:
One can escape in fire caught 
The great who offends escapes not.
T.Kannan:
Though in the conflagration caught, he may escape from thence:
He 'scapes not who in life to great ones gives offence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Though burned by a blazing fire, one may still survive; but there is no survival for those who offend great men.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: There is just a chance of saving oneself if one gets caught in a fire; but there is no hope for men who insult the great.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
One may survive even if burnt in fire
But no survival for those who offend the great.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though burnt by a fire (from a forest), one may perhaps live; (but) never will he live who has shown disrespect to the great (devotees).
Various Translators:
One may survive even if burnt in fire But
no survival for those who offend the great.
Dinamalar: One may survive being fried in a fire but not after offending the venerable.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Of what use are a life good in all aspects, and immense wealth, if one infuriates men of outstanding greatness and prowess.
Transliteration:
Vakaimaanta Vaazhkkaiyum Vaanporulum
Ennaam
Thakaimaanta Thakkaar Serin
T.Kannan:
If holy mighty sages frown 
Stately gifts and stores who can own?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though every royal gift, and stores of wealth your life should crown,
What are they, if the worthy men of mighty virtue frown?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What avails one’s proof of prosperity and mighty riches if one rouses the wrath of the great.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: What is the use of a man’s varied life and splendid wealth if he reaps the wrath of great and righteous men?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What avails glorious life and great wealth
If one incurs the wrath of the virtuous great?
Various Translators: If a king incurs the wrath of the righteous great, what will become of his government with its splendid auxiliaries and (all) its untold wealth ?
Dinamalar:
What avails glorious life and great wealth
If one incurs the wrath of the virtuous great?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If you underestimate the eminent, You will
be shaken off the earth of all your ties.
Transliteration: They, who seem tenacious, with their clans shall perish from this world, if august men, great as a mountain, are slighted.
T.Kannan:
Kundrannaar Kundra Madhippin
Kutiyotu
Nindrannaar Maaivar Nilaththu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The fury of the sages like the lofty hills destroys the great race of pure men of stable fortune.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
When hill like sages are held small 
The firm on earth lose home and all.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If they, whose virutues like a mountain rise, are light esteemed;
They die from earth who, with their households, ever during seemed
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If men of mountainous stature are meagerly esteemed, others who seemed as enduring as earth will die, as will their kin.
Various Translators:
If you underestimate the eminent,
You will be shaken off the earth of all your ties.
Dinamalar: If (the) hill-like (devotees) resolve on destruction, those who seemed to be everlasting will be destroyed root and branch from the earth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even the mightiest of kings can perish
midway If men of high repute burst in rage.
Transliteration: An emperor, one may be, but he shall be derailed and his reign wrecked, if persons with lofty ideals are incensed.
T.Kannan: Even the Lord of Heaven will be humbled from his throne if he rouses the wrath of men of mighty penance.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Endhiya Kolkaiyaar Seerin
Itaimurindhu
Vendhanum Vendhu Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Before the holy sage's rage 
Ev'n Indra's empire meets damage.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When blazes forth the wrath of men of lofty fame,
Kings even fall from high estate and perish in the flame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The most kingly king will tumble from his throne and die, should he unleash a towering sage’s bridled temper.
Various Translators: If those of exalted vows burst in a rage, even (Indra) the king will suffer a sudden loss and be entirely ruined.
Dinamalar:
Even the mightiest of kings can perish midway
If men of high repute burst in rage.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even kings of ancient renown perish before the wrath of the great.
Transliteration:
Even men with all their might and aid
Cannot be saved if great sages frown.
T.Kannan: One may have the best of allies but cannot survive the wrath of those with the best of qualities.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Irandhamaindha Saarputaiyar Aayinum
Uyyaar
Sirandhamaindha Seeraar Serin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Even mighty aided men shall quail 
If the enraged holy seers will.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though all surpassing wealth of aid the boast,
If men in glorious virtue great are wrath, they're lost.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though he commands unrivaled powers of protection, a king cannot survive the wrath of powerful ascetics.
Various Translators: Though in possession of numerous auxiliaries, they will perish who are-exposed to the wrath of the noble whose penance is boundless.
Dinamalar:
Even men with all their might and aid
Cannot be saved if great sages frown.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To follow one’s wife’s advice is to lose one’s honour and fortune.
Transliteration:
Wives unduly exalted impede greatness.
Ambitious men avoid that very thing.
T.Kannan: One who forever acts out of fervor for his wife never attains anything worthy; this is the trait that those who focus on execution shun.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Manaivizhaivaar Maanpayan Eydhaar
Vinaivizhaiyaar
Ventaap Porulum Adhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who dote on wives lose mighty gain
That lust, dynamic men disdain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who give their soul to love of wife acquire not nobler gain:
Who give their soul to strenuous deeds such meaner joys disdain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who lust after their wives will not attain the excellence of virtue; and it is just this that is not desired by those who are bent on acquiring wealth.
Various Translators: Men who dote upon their wives never achieve great gains, and men of great ambition avoid that very thing.
Dinamalar:
Wives unduly exalted impede greatness.
Ambitious men avoid that very thing.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The wealth of a henpecked husband is a mere mockery to him.
Transliteration:
The affluence of a careless uxorious man
Will buy him only shameful shame.
T.Kannan: Without preserving the good, driven by the desire for the woman- the wealth made thus is a greatly disconcerting disgrace.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Penaadhu Penvizhaivaan Aakkam
Periyadhor
Naanaaka Naanuth Tharum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The wealth of him who, regardless (of his manliness), devotes himself to his wife's feminine nature will cause great shame (to ali men) and to himself;
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who dotes, unmanly, on his dame
His wealth to him and all is shame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who gives himself to love of wife, careless of noble name,
His wealth will clothe him with o'erwhelming shame.
Various Translators: The riches of a man who fawningly follows a woman’s lead will buy him only shameful shame.
Dinamalar:
The affluence of a careless uxorious man
Will buy him only shameful shame.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Habitual submission to one’s wife
Will always bring disrepute among the good.
Transliteration:
Habitual submission to one’s wife Will
always bring disrepute among the good.
T.Kannan: Stooping to go against the grain by submitting to the wife’s will, always embarrasses good men.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The frailty that stoops to a wife will always make (her husband) feel ashamed among the good.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Illaalkan Thaazhndha Iyalpinmai
Egngnaandrum
Nallaarul Naanuth Tharum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who's servile to his wife always 
Shy he feels before the wise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who to his wife submits, his strange, unmanly mood
Will daily bring him shame among the good.
Various Translators: An abnormal submissiveness to his spouse will earn a man endless disgrace among decent men.
Dinamalar: The cowardice of one who submits to one’s wife makes one shrink from the company of the good.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The deeds of one who dreads his wife
Merits little in this life or the next.
Transliteration: The undertaking of one, who fears his wife and is therefore destitute of (bliss), will never be applauded.
T.Kannan:
The deeds of one who dreads his wife
Merits little in this life or the next.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: There is no salvation for one who fears his wife; never can he achieve fame nor mastery over execution.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Manaiyaalai Anjum Marumaiyi Laalan
Vinaiyaanmai Veereydha Lindru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Fearing his wife salvationless 
The weaklings' action has no grace.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
No glory crowns e'en manly actions wrought
By him who dreads his wife, nor gives the other world a thought.
Various Translators: Though he has mastered the doing of deeds, the henpecked husband merits little in this life or the next.
Dinamalar: He who dreads his wife denies himself the joys of Heaven. Even his noble actions are held in scorn.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A man who fears his wife will always fear
To do good things to good people.
Transliteration: He that fears his wife will always be afraid of doing good deeds (even) to the good.
T.Kannan:
A man who fears his wife will always fear
To do good things to good people.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One who fears his wife will forever fear doing good to the good folk.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Illaalai Anjuvaan Anjumar
Regngnaandrum
Nallaarkku Nalla Seyal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who fears his wife fears always 
Good to do to the good and wise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who quakes before his wife will ever tremble too,
Good deeds to men of good deserts to do.
Various Translators: He who fears his wife fails in his offices to the good and the virtuous.
Dinamalar: A man’s fears of his own wife will make him constantly fearful of doing good for good folks.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those who fear their wives' slender shoulders
May live like gods but are not men.
Transliteration: They that fear the bamboo-like shoulders of their wives will be destitute of manliness though they may flourish like the Gods.
T.Kannan:
Those who fear their wives' slender
shoulders May live like gods but are not men.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One may live amongst the celestial beings but has no standing, if he fears the drooping of the shapely shoulders of his wife.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Imaiyaarin Vaazhinum Paatilare
Illaal
Amaiyaardhol Anju Pavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Those who are under the spell of their bamboo-shouldered bewitching wives cease to be men even though they are like Gods on earth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who fear douce arms of their wives
Look petty even with god like lives.
Various Translators:
Though, like the demi gods, in bliss they dwell secure from harm,
Those have no dignity who fear the housewife's slender arm.
Dinamalar: Though providence has filled his life, a man who fears his graceful spouse is devoid of dignity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A woman’s shy ways show great dignity, unlike a man who lives to do a woman’s bidding.
Transliteration: Even shame faced womanhood is more to be esteemed than the shameless manhood that performs the behests of a wife.
T.Kannan:
Modest womanhood is greater than the manhood
Which thrives on obeisance to wife.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Modest womanhood is greater than the
manhood Which thrives on obeisance to wife.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The demure woman deserves more acclaim than the manliness that dances to the woman’s tune.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: More respectful is the bashfulness of a woman than the ignoble conduct of one who is a slave to one’s wife.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Penneval Seydhozhukum Aanmaiyin
Naanutaip
Penne Perumai Utaiththu
Various Translators:
Esteemed more is women bashful 
Than man servile unto her will.
Dinamalar:
The dignity of modest womanhood excels
His manliness, obedient to a woman's law who dwells.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who to the will of her with beauteous brow their lives conform,
Aid not their friends in need, nor acts of charity perform.
Transliteration: Those who live only to fulfill their wive’s wishes can neither satisfy the needs of friends nor benefit others.
T.Kannan: Those who yield to the wishes of their wives will neither relieve the wants of (their) friends nor perform virtuous deeds.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Men governed by their fair ladies cannot address
The needs of friends nor do any good.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: An infatuated husband can never be a friend in need; nor can he hope to do virtuous deeds.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Men governed by their fair ladies cannot
address The needs of friends nor do any good.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: One who caters to the whims of her, with elegant brows, shall never do any good nor resolve any of his friends’ woes.
Various Translators:
Nattaar Kuraimutiyaar Nandraatraar
Nannudhalaal
Pettaangu Ozhuku Pavar
Dinamalar:
By fair browed wives who are governed 
Help no friends nor goodness tend.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No virtuous deed, no seemly wealth, no pleasure, rests
With them who live obedient to their wives' behests.
Transliteration: From those who obey the commands of their wives are to be expected neither deeds of virtue, nor those of wealth nor (even) those of pleasure.
T.Kannan: Neither virtuous deeds nor vast wealth nor domestic joys will be found with men who carry out their wife’s commands.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Virtuous deeds, exalted wealth and other deeds
Are not for the henpecked.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Pleasures of life are not for the henpecked husband.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Virtuous deeds, exalted wealth and other
deeds Are not for the henpecked.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Virtuous deeds, valuable possession and various pursuits are beyond those who do what the wife bids.
Various Translators:
Aravinaiyum Aandra Porulum
Piravinaiyum
Peneval Seyvaarkan Il
Dinamalar:
No virtue riches nor joy is seen 
In those who submit to women

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The foolishness that results from devotion to a wife will never be found in those who possess a reflecting mind and a prosperity (flowing) therefrom.
Transliteration:
Thinkers strong and broad of heart 
By folly on fair sex do not dote.
T.Kannan:
Where pleasures of the mind, that dwell in realms of thought, abound,
Folly, that springs from overweening woman's love, is never found.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Moneyed men whose thoughts dwell in the mind never dwell foolishly on relationships with women.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The thoughtful and firm-willed never indulge
In the folly of doting on their wives.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Men of resolute will never commit the folly of slaving for women.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The thoughtful and firm-willed never
indulge In the folly of doting on their wives.
Various Translators: Cultured hearts with precious thoughts allow not the folly of appeasing their consorts.
Dinamalar:
Enserndha Nenjath Thitanutaiyaarkku
Egngnaandrum
Penserndhaam Pedhaimai Il

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
For gold, not love their tongue cajoles 
Men are ruined by bangled belles.
Transliteration:
Those that choice armlets wear, who seek not thee with love,
But seek thy wealth, their pleasant words will ruin prove.
T.Kannan: The sweet words of beautifully bangled women who desire a man’s wealth and not his love decree his fall into disgrace.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Honeyed words of public women who serve not for love but for money become gall and wormwood in the end.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Fraught with disgrace are the sweet words
Of jeweled women who desire wealth, not love.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Fraught with disgrace are the sweet words
Of jeweled women who desire wealth, not love.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Bedecked with bracelets, she seeks him not for love but money. her saccharine words are charged with disgrace.
Various Translators: The sweet words of elegant braceleted (prostitutes) who desire (a man) not from affection but from avarice, will cause sorrow.
Dinamalar:
Anpin Vizhaiyaar Porulvizhaiyum
Aaidhotiyaar
Insol Izhukkuth Tharum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Payandhookkip Panpuraikkum Panpin
Makalir
Nayandhookki Nallaa Vital
Transliteration:
Avoid ill natured whores who feign 
Love only for their selfish gain.
T.Kannan:
Who weigh the gain, and utter virtuous words with vicious heart,
Weighing such women's worth, from their society depart.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Weigh the worth and abandon the company of wanton women who, weighing their profit, prattle about their virtues.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Beware of public women sweet of tongue but greedy of gain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
See through and avoid the immoral women
Who talk of morals with a purpose.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: One must ascertain the character of the ill-natured women who after ascertaining the wealth (of a man) speak (as if they were) good natured-ones, and avoid intercourse (with them).
Various Translators:
See through and avoid the immoral women
Who talk of morals with a purpose.
Dinamalar: Discern and spurn pretentious women who schemingly gloat.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The fake cuddling of women coveting money is like hugging an unknown corpse in a dark room.
Transliteration:
Porutpentir Poimmai Muyakkam
Iruttaraiyil
Edhil Pinandhazheei Atru
T.Kannan:
The false embrace of whores is like 
That of a damned corpse in the dark.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
As one in darkened room, some stranger corpse inarms,
Is he who seeks delight in mercenary women's charms.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Embracing false women bent on gain is like embracing a strange corpse in a dark room.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A mercenary woman pretends intimate embrace, but in the darkened room, she caresses a stranger’s carcass.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A harlot’s false embrace for money is like one hired
To clasp an alien corpse in a dark room.
Various Translators: The false embraces of wealth-loving women are like (hired men) embracing a strange corpse in a dark room.
Dinamalar:
A harlot’s false embrace for money is like
one hired To clasp an alien corpse in a dark room.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The wise who treasure grace desire not the
false charms Of those who treasure wealth.
Transliteration: The wise who seek the way of compassion are not swayed by trivial pleasures of covetous women.
T.Kannan:
Porutporulaar Punnalan Thoyaar
Arutporul
Aayum Arivi Navar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Men seeking the light of grace turn away in scorn from the fleshy delights of prostitutes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The wise who seek the wealth of grace 
Look not for harlots' low embrace.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Their worthless charms, whose only weal is wealth of gain,
Form touch of these the wise, who seek the wealth of grace, abstain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Men seeking spiritual treasures are too worldly wise to touch tawdry women who treasure only material riches.
Various Translators:
The wise who treasure grace desire not the false charms
Of those who treasure wealth.
Dinamalar: The wise who seek the wealth of grace will not desire the base favours of those who regard wealth (and not pleasure) as (their) riches.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Sensible men of lofty wisdom will find no
joy In the cheap delight of public women.
Transliteration: Wise men renowned for their sagacity shun the trite frolics of women who profess love for all.
T.Kannan: Men of great wisdom care not for the barren pleasures of women who sell themselves for hire.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Podhunalaththaar Punnalam Thoyaar
Madhinalaththin
Maanta Arivi Navar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The lofty wise will never covet 
The open charms of a vile harlot.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From contact with their worthless charms, whose charms to all are free,
The men with sense of good and lofty wisdom blest will flee.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Men of innate good sense and acquired wisdom never touch tramps who shamelessly share their beauty with all.
Various Translators: Those whose knowledge is made excellent by their (natural) sense will not covet the trffling delights of those whose favours are common (to all).
Dinamalar:
Sensible men of lofty wisdom will find no joy
In the cheap delight of public women.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Men aspiring to fame do not long for the delights of women who sell themselves.
Transliteration:
Those who would spread their own good will
not touch Others who spread their charms for money.
T.Kannan: Those who care for themselves care not for the shoulders of those who offer exaggerated banal joys.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thannalam Paarippaar Thoyaar
Thakaiserukkip
Punnalam Paarippaar Thol
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Those who guard their worthy fame 
Shun the wanton's vaunting charm.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From touch of those who worthless charms, with wanton arts, display,
The men who would thier own true good maintain will turn away.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Desiring to maintain their jubilant goodness, men will not embrace enticing women who proffer lewd charms to all.
Various Translators: Those who would spread (the fame of) their own goodness will not desire the shoulders of those,who rejoice in their accomplishments and bestow their despicable favours (on all who pay).
Dinamalar:
Those who would spread their own good will not touch
Others who spread their charms for money.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Only men of unruly desires go in search of the shoulders of women who sell themselves.
Transliteration:
The empty-hearted alone will embrace The
hearts that go not with their bodies.
T.Kannan: Those with discontented hearts embrace the shoulders of those who make love with devious thoughts in their hearts.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nirainenjam Illavar Thoivaar
Piranenjir
Penip Punarpavar Thol
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Hollow hearts alone desire 
The arms of whores with hearts elsewere.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who cherish alien thoughts while foldding in their feigned embrace,
These none approach save those devoid of virtue's grace.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who are destitute of a perfectly (reformed) mind will covet the shoulders of those who embrace (them) while their hearts covet other things.
Various Translators: Only men of unchaste mind will lie in the arms of women whose hearts chase after other things as they embrace.
Dinamalar:
The empty-hearted alone will embrace
The hearts that go not with their bodies.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: False women’s embraces which only the ignorant desire are like the possession of evil spirits.
Transliteration:
Only those who can’t see through a false
woman’s embrace Consider her to be an angel.
T.Kannan: Those who cannot reason wisely see a divine enchantress in a dubious woman’s embrace.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aayum Arivinar Allaarkku Anangenpa
Maaya Makalir Muyakku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The wise say that to such as are destitute of discerning sense the embraces of faithless women are (as ruinous as those of) the celestail female.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Senseless fools are lured away 
By arms of sirens who lead astray.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As demoness who lures to ruin, woman's treacherous love
To men devoid of wisdom's searching power will prove.
Various Translators: It is said that men devoid of discerning wisdom succumb to a deceiving damsel’s embrace as to a siren’s song.
Dinamalar:
Only those who can’t see through a false woman’s embrace
Consider her to be an angel.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The soft arms of those who sell their charm
Are a hell that plunge the base.
Transliteration:
The soft arms of those who sell their
charm Are a hell that plunge the base.
T.Kannan: Soft shoulders of loose women, decked with jewels, is the hell where imprudent louts dwell.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The delicate shoulders of prostitutes with excellent jewels are a hell into which are plunged the ignorant base.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Varaivilaa Maanizhaiyaar Mendhol
Puraiyilaap
Pooriyarkal Aazhum Alaru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The soft jewelled arms of whores are hell
Into which the degraded fall.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The wanton's tender arm, with gleaming jewels decked,
Is hell,where sink degraded souls of men abject.
Various Translators: The soft arms of the elegantly bejeweled harlot are a murky mire that engulfs wicked, stupid men.
Dinamalar: The soft shoulders of women who deck themselves for attraction are the hell into which undiscerning fools sink.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Fortune leaves those whose associates are
Treacherous women, wine and dice.
Transliteration: Treacherous women, liquor, and gambling are the associates of such as have forsaken by Fortune.
T.Kannan:
Fortune leaves those whose associates are
Treacherous women, wine and dice.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Deceitful women, drink and dice are friends of those wantonly dumping their wealth.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
920 Irumanap Pentirum Kallum
KavarumThiruneekkap Pattaar Thotarpu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Double minded whores, wine and dice 
Are lures of those whom fortune flies.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Women of double minds, strong drink, and dice to these giv'n o'er,
Are those on whom the light of Fortune shines no more.
Various Translators: Two faced females, besotting brew and addictive dice befriend the men whom fortune has forsaken.
Dinamalar: Double-tongued women, wine and dice are the allies of those abandoned by the goddess of fortune.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those who always love wine
Will neither inspire fear in others nor retain their fame.
Transliteration: Those who always thirst after drink will neither inspire fear (in others) nor retain the light (of their fame).
T.Kannan:
Those who always love wine Will neither
inspire fear in others nor retain their fame.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: They shall not be respected nor feared, and they shall lose their glory. they who are in love with alcohol.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Utkap Pataaar Oliyizhappar
Egngnaandrum
Katkaadhal Kontozhuku Vaar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Foes fear not who for toddy craze 
The addicts daily their glory lose.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who love the palm's intoxicating juice, each day,
No rev'rence they command, their glory fades away.
Various Translators: He who is addicted to wine can never strike fear in the heart of his foe; nor can he retain his ancient splendour.
Dinamalar: Those who crave intoxicating drink each day will never be feared and never find fame.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Drink no wine, or let them drink
Who do not care what wise men think.
Transliteration: Let no liquor be drunk; if it is desired, let it be drunk by those who care not for esteem of the great.
T.Kannan:
Drink no wine, or let them drink Who do
not care what wise men think.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Consume not alcohol; consume if you will, those who care not to be held highly by the noble.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Unnarka Kallai Unilunka Saandroraan
Ennap Pataventaa Thaar
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Do not drink wine, for a drunkard can never command the homage of the great.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Drink not liquor; but let them drink 
Whom with esteem the wise won't think.
Various Translators:
Drink not inebriating draught. Let him count well the cost.
Who drinks by drinking, all good men's esteem is lost.
Dinamalar: Do not drink liquor. If some wish to, let it be those who have no wish for the esteem of exemplary men.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The sight of a drunken man’s revelry is unbearable even to his own mother. How, then, must it appear to the wise?
Transliteration: Intoxication is painful even in the presence of (one's) mother; what will it not then be in that of the wise ?
T.Kannan:
When a drunkard's glee hurts his own mother,
Why speak of the wise?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
When a drunkard's glee hurts his own
mother, Why speak of the wise?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Drunken revelry is horrid in front of your mother; how would it seem in front of the esteemed?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even an indulgent mother never puts up with a drunkard; will the virtuous ever tolerate him?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Eendraal Mukaththeyum Innaadhaal
Enmatruch
Chaandror Mukaththuk Kali
Various Translators:
The drunkard's joy pains ev'n mother's face 
How vile must it look for the wise?
Dinamalar:
The drunkard's joy is sorrow to his mother's eyes;
What must it be in presence of the truly wise?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Shame, goodly maid, will turn her back for aye on them
Who sin the drunkard's grievous sin, that all condemn.
Transliteration: The virtuous damsel called Decency will turn her back on men who indulge in the vile vice called drunkenness.
T.Kannan: The fair maid of modesty will turn her back on those who are guilty of the great and abominable crime of drunkenness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The good lady Shame turns her back to men
Addicted to the grave vice drunkenness.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The good lady of modesty averts her face from him guilty of hateful drink.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The good lady Shame turns her back to men
Addicted to the grave vice drunkenness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The good lady, Sense of Shame, will turn her back on those despicably guilty of being drunk.
Various Translators:
Naanennum Nallaal Purangotukkum
Kallennum
Penaap Perungutrath Thaarkku
Dinamalar:
Good shame turns back from him ashamed 
Who is guilty of wine condemned.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
With gift of goods who self oblivion buys,
Is ignorant of all that man should prize.
Transliteration: To give money and purchase unconsciousness is the result of one's ignorance of (one's own actions).
T.Kannan: Spending one’s wealth to purchase self oblivion results from being oblivious to proper conduct.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
It is sheer ignorance to spend one’s substance
And obtain in return only insensibility.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: To acquire forgetfulness at a price is indeed the fruit of past sin.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
It is sheer ignorance to spend one’s
substance And obtain in return only insensibility.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: They have no sense of consequences, those who pay to lose their senses.
Various Translators:
Kaiyari Yaamai Utaiththe
Porulkotuththu
Meyyari Yaamai Kolal
Dinamalar:
To pay and drink and lose the sense 
Is nothing but rank ignorance.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: They that sleep resemble the deed; (likewise) they that drink are no other than poison-eaters.
Transliteration:
They take poison who take toddy
And doze ev'n like a dead body.
T.Kannan:
Sleepers are as the dead, no otherwise they seem;
Who drink intoxicating draughts, they position quaff, we deem.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who always sleep are akin to the dead. Those who constantly drink are like men who take poison.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Slumbers are no different from the dead.
Nor alcoholics from consumers of poison.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To be asleep is to be dead. To drink wine is to drink poison.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Slumbers are no different from the dead.
Nor alcoholics from consumers of poison.
Various Translators: One who is asleep is no different from the dead; one who consumes alcohol forever consumes poison.
Dinamalar:
Thunjinaar Seththaarin Verallar
Egngnaandrum
Nanjunpaar Kallun Pavar

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The secret drunkards' senses off 
Make the prying public laugh.
Transliteration:
Who turn aside to drink, and droop their heavy eye,
Shall be their townsmen's jest, when they the fault espy.
T.Kannan: The drooping eyes of those who secretly drink betray that secret, evoking their neighbor’s relentless ridicule.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: A drunkard who has lost his senses becomes an object of ridicule to his sober neighbours.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Those who often get drunk in private
Will soon become a laughing stock in public.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those who often get drunk in private Will
soon become a laughing stock in public.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who are in a perpetual drunken stupor shall be sneered at by the knowing locals.
Various Translators: Those who always intoxicate themselves by a private (indulgence in) drink; will have their secrets detected and laughed at by their fellow-townsmen.
Dinamalar:
Ullotri Ulloor Nakappatuvar
Egngnaandrum
Kallotrik Kansaai Pavar

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Kaliththariyen Enpadhu Kaivituka
Nenjaththu
Oliththadhooum Aange Mikum
Transliteration:
Don't say "I'm not a drunkard hard"
The hidden fraud is known abroad.
T.Kannan:
No more in secret drink, and then deny thy hidden fraud;
What in thy mind lies hid shall soon be known abroad.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Stop denying, “I never drink,” for next time you drink, your mind’s hidden deception will be betrayed then and there.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let not a drunkard boast that he has not tasted wine; for that which is hidden shows itself with greater force when drunk.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Drop saying, I never drank:
Hidden secrets will be out when drunk.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Let (the drunkard) give up saying "I have never drunk"; (for) the moment (he drinks) he will simply betray his former attempt to conceal.
Various Translators:
Drop saying, 'I never drank': Hidden
secrets will be out when drunk.
Dinamalar: Drop the pretense of never feeling merry while drinking; all that’s hidden in your heart will tumble out.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Making an inebriated person see reason is like pursuing with a flame, someone under water .
Transliteration:
Kaliththaanaik Kaaranam Kaattudhal
Keezhneerk
Kuliththaanaith Theeththureei Atru
T.Kannan:
Can torch search one in water sunk?
Can reason reach the raving drunk?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Like him who, lamp in hand, would seek one sunk beneath the wave,
Is he who strives to sober drunken man with reasonings grave.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: To reason a drunkard into his senses is like searching with a candle for one lost in deep waters.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: One may as well carry a candle under water to search for a drowned man as use reason to sober a drunk drowned in drink.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To reason with one drowned in drink is like
Searching with a candle for a man drowned in water.
Various Translators: Reasoning with a drunkard is like going under water with a torch in search of a drowned man.
Dinamalar:
To reason with one drowned in drink is
like Searching with a candle for a man drowned in
water.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When a drunkard sober sees another drunk,
Why does he not note his own damage?
Transliteration: While sober, will he not think of his crapulence when he sees others sloshed under the influence?
T.Kannan:
Kallunnaap Pozhdhir Kaliththaanaik
Kaanungaal
Ullaankol Untadhan Sorvu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If a drunkard in sober moments sees, another under the influence of wine, will he fail to realise his own state when drunk?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The sober seeing the drunkard's plight 
On selves can't they feel same effect?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When one, in sober interval a drunken man espies,
Does he not think, 'Such is my folly in my revelries'?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Why can’t the drunkard who, when sober, sees another’s drunken stupor realize the degrading shame of his own drunkenness?
Various Translators:
When a drunkard sober sees another drunk,
Why does he not note his own damage?
Dinamalar: When (a drunkard) who is sober sees one who is not, it looks as if he remembered not the evil effects of his (own) drink.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Don’t gamble even if you win for it draws
you in Like fishes drawn to shining baits.
Transliteration: Love not gambling even when you win. To win is akin to a fish biting the metallic hook on a fishing line.
T.Kannan: Do not desire to gamble even if you win; for your gain is like the bait to a fish.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ventarka Vendritinum Soodhinai
Vendradhooum
Thoontirpon Meenvizhungi Atru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Avoid gambling, albeit you win 
Gulping bait hook what does fish gain?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Seek not the gramester's play; though you should win,
Your gain is as the baited hook the fish takes in.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Do not take to gambling, even if you can win, for your wins will be like the baited hooks that fish swallow.
Various Translators: Though able to win, let not one desire gambling; (for) even what is won is like a fish swallowing the iron in fish-hook.
Dinamalar:
Don’t gamble even if you win for it draws you in
Like fishes drawn to shining baits.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Can gamblers who lose a hundred times before winning once ever dream of an upright life?
Transliteration:
Can gamblers gain anything good in life
Who gain one and lose a hundred?
T.Kannan: Can there ever be a rewarding course of life for a gambler who wins one to lose a hundred.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ondreydhi Noorizhakkum Soodharkkum
Untaangol
Nandreydhi Vaazhvadhor Aaru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Can gamblers in life good obtain 
Who lose a hundred one to gain?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Is there for gamblers, too, that gaining one a hundred lose, some way
That they may good obtain, and see a prosperous day?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To win once, a gambler loses a hundred times. What a way to procure happiness and prosperity!
Various Translators: Is there indeed a means of livelihood that can bestow happiness on gamblers who gain one and lose a hundred ?
Dinamalar:
Can gamblers gain anything good in life
Who gain one and lose a hundred?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If one continually plays with the rolling dice one’s riches desert one to enrich one’s enemies.
Transliteration:
To be lost all the time in the rolling
dice Is to lose your hoarded wealth to others.
T.Kannan: If one keeps calling as the dice roll, their wealth shall roll away to others.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Urulaayam Ovaadhu Koorin Porulaayam
Pooip Purame Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If kings indulge in casting dice
All their fortune will flow to foes.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If prince unceasing speak of nought but play,
treasure and revenue will pass from him away.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If the king is incessantly addicted to the rolling dice in the hope of gain, his wealth and the resources thereof will take their departure and fall into other's hands.
Various Translators: Incessantly calling bets on rolling dice causes a man’s rich reserves and potential revenues to run elsewhere.
Dinamalar:
To be lost all the time in the rolling dice
Is to lose your hoarded wealth to others.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Nothing brings on poverty more than gambling. It ruins one’s fame and is the mother of all evils.
Transliteration:
There is nothing like gambling to bring
Poverty, sorrow and disgrace.
T.Kannan: Nothing else can cause as much poverty as the degrading and demeaning gambling.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sirumai Palaseydhu Seerazhikkum
Soodhin
Varumai Tharuvadhondru Il
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: There is nothing else that brings (us) poverty like gambling which causes many a misery and destroys (one's) reputation.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nothing will make you poor like game 
Which adds to woes and ruins fame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Gaming brings many woes, and ruins fair renown;
Nothing to want brings men so surely down.
Various Translators: Gambling brings on many miseries and erodes one’s good name. Nothing else ends in such wretched poverty.
Dinamalar:
There is nothing like gambling to bring
Poverty, sorrow and disgrace.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
They lose all who will not give up the dice,
The board and the throw.
Transliteration:
They lose all who will not give up the
dice, The board and the throw.
T.Kannan: The dice, the casino and the playing hand. those who lovingly embrace these lose everything.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Penniless are those who by reason of their attachment would never forsake gambling, the gambling-place and the handling (of dice).
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kavarum Kazhakamum Kaiyum Tharukki
Ivariyaar Illaaki Yaar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The game, game hall and gambler's art 
Who sought with glee have come to nought.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The dice, and gaming hall, and gamester's art, they eager sought,
Thirsting for gain the men in other days who came to nought.
Various Translators: Desiring to win everything, those who love the dice, the gambling hall and their lucky hand lose it all.
Dinamalar: None but those who dream of dice and the gaming table will come to grief.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those blindfolded by the dark ogress called dice
Will starve and suffer in distress.
Transliteration: Those who are swallowed by the goddess called "gambling" will never have their hunger satisfied, but suffer the pangs of hell in the next world.
T.Kannan:
Those blindfolded by the dark ogress
called dice Will starve and suffer in distress.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When one is enclasped by Gambling, the Imp of Misfortune, they shall starve and suffer.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Akataaraar Allal Uzhapparsoo Thennum
Mukatiyaan Mootappat Taar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Men swallowed by the ogress, dice 
Suffer grief and want by that vice.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Gambling's Misfortune's other name: o'er whom she casts her veil,
They suffer grievous want, and sorrows sore bewail.
Various Translators: Gambling is Misfortune’s other name. Fools ensnared by her will suffer an empty stomach and distressing sorrows.
Dinamalar: Torments of poverty and hell befall one who is seized by the demon of gambling.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Time wasted in a gambling house
Will end one’s ancestral wealth and worth.
Transliteration: To waste time at the place of gambling will destroy inherited wealth and goodness of character.
T.Kannan:
Time wasted in a gambling house Will end
one’s ancestral wealth and worth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When one enters the gambling den at dawn, their character and inheritance decline.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pazhakiya Selvamum Panpum Ketukkum
Kazhakaththuk Kaalai Pukin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If men their time in game den spend 
Ancestral wealth and virtues end.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ancestral wealth and noble frame to ruin haste,
If men in gambler's halls their precious moments waste.
Various Translators: Ceaseless gambling destroys one’s ancestral wealth and fame.
Dinamalar: Spending time in the gambling hall squanders ancestral wealth and wastes personal worth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Dicing loses wealth, imposes lies,
Kills grace and causes sorrow.
Transliteration: Gambling destroys property, teaches falsehood, puts an end to benevolence, and brings in misery (here and hereafter).
T.Kannan:
Dicing loses wealth, imposes lies, Kills
grace and causes sorrow.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It erodes wealth and imposes falsehood. gambling that causes torment and erases tenderness.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Porul Ketuththup Poimer Koleei
ArulketuththuAllal Uzhappikkum Soodhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Gambling destroys wealth, makes one play false, kills all virtues, and brings on distress.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Game ruins wealth and spoils grace
Leads to lies and wretched woes.
Various Translators:
Gambling wastes wealth, to falsehood bends the soul; it drives away
All grace, and leaves the man to utter misery a prey.
Dinamalar: Gambling will consume a man’s wealth and corrupt his honesty. It will curtail his benevolence and increase his torment.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who take to gambling’s fickle gain forfeit these five: raiments, riches, rations, renown and erudition.
Transliteration: The habit of gambling prevents the attainment of these five: clothing, wealth, food, fame and learning.
T.Kannan:
Gambling will make one lose these five:
Riches, food, fame, learning and clothes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Gambling will make one lose these five:
Riches, food, fame, learning and clothes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Food, dress, learning, wealth and fame. these five elude one who takes to the dice.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A king whose hobby is gambling has neither raiment nor food, nor wealth nor renown nor learning.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Utaiselvam Oonoli Kalviendru Aindhum
Ataiyaavaam Aayang Kolin
Various Translators:
Dress, wealth, food, fame, learning these five 
In gambler's hand will never thrive.
Dinamalar:
Clothes, wealth, food, praise and learning, all depart
From him on gambler's gain who sets his heart.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Howe'er he lose, the gambler's heart is ever in the play;
E'en so the soul, despite its griefs, would live on earth alway.
Transliteration: The gambler’s passion increases with the losses incurred. Even so does the soul’s craving for life grow with the griefs suffered.
T.Kannan: As the gambler loves (his vice) the more he loses by it, so does the soul love (the body) the more it suffers through it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Like the attachment to life despite sufferings
Is the love for gambling despite loss.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: In spite of all the ills of life we cling to it. In spite of all losses, a gambler clings to his dice.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Like the attachment to life despite
sufferings Is the love for gambling despite loss.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Like the spirit that yet loves the body in torment, the gambler loves to wager despite the losses.
Various Translators:
Izhaththoruvum Kaadhalikkum Soodhepol
Thunpam
Uzhaththoruvum Kaadhatru Uyir
Dinamalar:
Love for game grows with every loss 
As love for life with sorrows grows.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The learned books count three, with wind as first; of these,
As any one prevail, or fail, it will cause disease.
Transliteration: If (food and work are either) excessive or deficient, the three things enumerated by (medical) writers, flatulence, biliousness, and phlegm, will cause (one) disease.
T.Kannan: Disease is but deficiency or excess of three life forces, defined by writers of scientific texts as air, fire and water.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Three things beginning with wind, say the experts,
In excess or lacking cause disease.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Overfeeding and underfeeding upset the three humours and cause disease, says the physician.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Three things beginning with wind, say the
experts, In excess or lacking cause disease.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Food and deed, both in excess and deficit, cause disease, induced by the three (humors)* listed by the learned, starting with wind.
Various Translators:
Mikinum Kuraiyinum Noiseyyum Noolor
Valimudhalaa Enniya Moondru
Dinamalar:
Wind, bile and phlegm three cause disease 
So doctors deem it more or less.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: No medicine is necessary for him who eats after assuring (himself) that what he has (already) eaten has been digested.
Transliteration:
After digestion one who feeds 
His body no medicine needs.
T.Kannan:
No need of medicine to heal your body's pain,
If, what you ate before digested well, you eat again.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The body requires no medicine if you eat only after the food you have already eaten is digested.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The body needs no drugs if what is eaten
Is digested before the next meal.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: There is no need for medicine if one eats with appetite.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The body needs no drugs if what is eaten
Is digested before the next meal.
Various Translators: The body needs no medicine, if one eats after ensuring the earlier intake is digested.
Dinamalar:
Marundhena Ventaavaam Yaakkaikku
Arundhiyadhu
Atradhu Potri Unin

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Eat food to digestive measure 
Life in body lasts with pleasure.
Transliteration:
Who has a body gained may long the gift retain,
If, food disgested well, in measure due he eat again.
T.Kannan: Once digestion is complete, eat with moderation; that is the way to prolong the life of the body.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Let there be measure and moderation in eating. It leads to long life.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Once digested, eat with moderation.
That prolongs the life of one embodied.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Once digested, eat with moderation. That
prolongs the life of one embodied.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: After digestion, eat in right measure. This is the way for the possessor of the body to prolong its being.
Various Translators: If (one's food has been) digested let one eat with moderation; (for) that is the way to prolong the life of an embodied soul.
Dinamalar:
Atraal Aravarindhu Unka Aqdhutampu
Petraan Netidhuykkum Aaru

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Atradhu Arindhu Kataippitiththu
Maaralla
Thuykka Thuvarap Pasiththu
Transliteration:
Know digestion; with keen appetite 
Eat what is suitable and right.
T.Kannan:
Knowing the food digested well, when hunger prompteth thee,
With constant care, the viands choose that well agree.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Assured the last meal has digested and sensing a keen appetite, savor only foods that are fully agreeable.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Eat wholesome food when you feel hungry.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Assured of digestion and real hunger,
Eat with care what is agreeable.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: (First) assure yourself that your food has been digested and never fail to eat, when very hungry, whatever is not disagreeable (to you).
Various Translators:
Assured of digestion and real hunger, Eat
with care what is agreeable.
Dinamalar: After ascertaining digestion, when you feel quite hungry, eat, in right measure, food that suits your constitution.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If one eats after refusing incompatible food there is no harm for their existence.
Transliteration:
Maarupaatu Illaadha Unti
Maruththunnin
Oorupaatu Illai Uyirkku
T.Kannan:
With fasting adjusted food right 
Cures ills of life and makes you bright
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
With self denial take the well selected meal;
So shall thy frame no sudden sickness feel.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: No disease attacks the person who eats with moderation the food which agrees with him.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Life remains unharmed when one eats with restraint, refraining from foods that have proven disagreeable.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
No harm to life if what is eaten
Does not include disagreeable food.
Various Translators: There will be no disaster to one's life if on e eats with moderation, food that is not disagreeable.
Dinamalar:
No harm to life if what is eaten Does not
include disagreeable food.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
As pleasure dwells with a moderate eater,
So is disease with a voracious glutton.
Transliteration: Joy resides with one who knows what not and how much to eat. Likewise, disease rests with the glutton.
T.Kannan:
Izhivarindhu Unpaankan Inpampol
Nirkum
Kazhiper Iraiyaankan Noi
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Health dwells in a man of temperance, disease invades a glutton.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who eats with clean stomach gets health 
With greedy glutton abides ill health.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
On modest temperance as pleasures pure,
So pain attends the greedy epicure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The pleasures of health abide in the man who eats moderately. The pains of disease dwell with him who eats excessively.
Various Translators:
As pleasure dwells with a moderate eater,
So is disease with a voracious glutton.
Dinamalar: As pleasure dwells with him who eats moderately, so disease (dwells) with the glutton who eats voraciously.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Unlimited eating beyond one’s measure
Leads to unlimited number of ills.
Transliteration: One who cannot judge his extent of hunger and gobbles up greedily will be afflicted with boundless malady.
T.Kannan: Countless are the ills that befall a glutton.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Theeyala Vandrith Theriyaan
Peridhunnin
Noyala Vindrip Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
who glut beyond the hunger's fire 
Suffer from untold diseases here.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who largely feeds, nor measure of the fire within maintains,
That thoughtless man shall feel unmeasured pains.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The thoughtless glutton who gorges himself beyond the limits of his digestive fires will be consumed by limitless ills.
Various Translators: He will be afflicted with numberless diseases, who eats immoderately, ignorant (of the rules of health).
Dinamalar:
Unlimited eating beyond one’s measure
Leads to unlimited number of ills.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Diagnose the disease, find out its cure after tracing its root and apply the proper remedy.
Transliteration:
Diagnose the illness, trace its cause,
Seek the proper remedy and apply it with skill.
T.Kannan: Diagnose the disease, detect its root cause, discern its cure and then act aptly.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Noinaati Noimudhal Naati
Adhudhanikkum
Vaainaati Vaaippach Cheyal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Test disease, its cause and cure 
And apply remedy that is sure.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Disease, its cause, what may abate the ill;
Let leech examine these, then use his skill.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Diagnose the illness, trace its cause, seek the appropriate remedy and apply it skillfully.
Various Translators: Let the physician enquire into the (nature of the) disease, its cause and its method of cure and treat it faithfully according to (medical rule).
Dinamalar:
Diagnose the illness, trace its cause,
Seek the proper remedy and apply it with skill.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Let the learned physician know the nature of the patient and the duration of ailment and then treat.
Transliteration:
A doctor should have the measure of the
patient, Disease and its stage, and treat.
T.Kannan: The learned medic should consider the state of the ailing, the extent of ailment and the timing, and then treat.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Utraan Alavum Piniyalavum Kaalamum
Katraan Karudhich Cheyal
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Let the skilful doctor note
The sickmen, sickness, season and treat.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The habitudes of patient and disease, the crises of the ill
These must the learned leech think over well, then use his skill.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The learned (physician) should ascertain the condition of his patient; the nature of his disease, and the season (of the year) and (then) proceed (with his treatment).
Various Translators: An accomplished doctor prescribes a remedy after considering the patient’s nature, the disease’s nature and the time of year
Dinamalar:
A doctor should have the measure of the patient,
Disease and its stage, and treat.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The science of medicine deals with the patient, the physician, the medicine and the recipe.
Transliteration:
Any treatment involves these four orders:
The patient, doctor, medicine and the nurse.
T.Kannan: The ailing, the medic, the medicine and the caregiver. the treatment encompasses all these four.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Utravan Theerppaan Marundhuzhaich
Chelvaanendru
AppaalNaar Kootre Marundhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Medical science consists of four parts, viz., patient, physician, medicine and compounder; and each of these (again) contains four sub-divisions.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Patient, doctor, medicine and nurse 
Are four fold codes of treating course.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
For patient, leech, and remedies and him who waits by patient's side,
The art of medicine must fourfold code of laws provide.
Various Translators: Medicine consists of a patient, a physician, a prescription and a nurse—each of these having four parts.
Dinamalar:
Any treatment involves these four orders:
The patient, doctor, medicine and the nurse.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
None except the well-born
Have that natural sense of integrity and shame.
Transliteration:
None except the well-born Have that
natural sense of integrity and shame.
T.Kannan: Those of good birth stand apart through their sense of justice and sense of shame that come naturally for them.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Consistency (of thought, word and deed) and fear (of sin) are conjointly natural only to the high-born.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Irpirandhaar Kanalladhu Illai
Iyalpaakach
Cheppamum Naanum Orungu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Right sense and bashfulness adorn 
By nature only the noble born.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Save in the scions of a noble house, you never find
Instinctive sense of right and virtuous shame combined.
Various Translators: An innate sense of right and shying away from wrong are found together only in the nobly born.
Dinamalar: Probity and a sense of shame are virtues innate only in men of noble lineage.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Men of birth will never deviate from these three:
Good manners, truthfulness and modesty.
Transliteration: The high-born will never deviate from these three; good manners, truthfulness and modesty.
T.Kannan:
Men of birth will never deviate from these
three: Good manners, truthfulness and modesty.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Propriety, truth and modesty: those of good birth do not lapse on these three.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ozhukkamum Vaaimaiyum Naanum Im
MoondrumIzhukkaar Kutippiran Thaar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The noble born lack not these three: 
Good conduct, truth and modesty.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
In these three things the men of noble birth fail not;
In virtuous deed and truthful word, and chastened thought.
Various Translators: Men of noble birth will never fall away from these three: correct conduct, truthfulness and modesty.
Dinamalar: Men of noble descent never forsake good conduct, truthfulness and modesty.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A smiling face, a generous heart, sweet words and no scorn;
These four are said to mark the well-born.
Transliteration: A cheerful countenance, liberality, pleasant words, and an unreviling disposition, these four are said to be the proper qualities of the truly high-born.
T.Kannan:
A smiling face, a generous heart, sweet
words and no scorn; These four are said to mark the
well-born.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those born in a family that treasures truth internalize these four: smile, generosity, sweet words and not belittling anyone.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nakaieekai Insol Ikazhaamai Naankum
Vakaiyenpa Vaaimaik Kutikku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
