Smile, gift, sweet words and courtesy 
These four mark true nobility.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The smile, the gift, the pleasant word, unfailing courtesy:
These are the signs, they say, of true nobility.
Various Translators: A cheerful countenance, charity, soft words and sweet learning all these characterise men of noble birth.
Dinamalar: Four traits define the true gentleman: a smiling face, a generous hand, a courteous demeanor and kindly words.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Men of birth will not indulge in mean acts
Even if offered millions manifold.
Transliteration: Though blessed with immense wealth, the noble will never do anything unbecoming.
T.Kannan:
Men of birth will not indulge in mean acts
Even if offered millions manifold.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even if they are bound to gain millions, those of good lineage shall never stoop to do things beneath themselves.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Atukkiya Koti Perinum
Kutippirandhaar
Kundruva Seydhal Ilar
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Men of noble birth never stoop to mean acts, though they may thereby gain untold riches.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Even for crores, the noble mood 
Cannot bend to degrading deed.
Various Translators:
Millions on millions piled would never win
The men of noble race to soul degrading sin.
Dinamalar: Though millions upon millions could be gained by it, men nobly born would never commit a demeaning deed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Though their means of charitableness may be cut off, venerable families will never be severed from propriety.
Transliteration: Though their means fall off, those born in ancient families, will not lose their character (for liberality).
T.Kannan:
An ancient family may default in charity,
But never in their conduct.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
An ancient family may default in charity,
But never in their conduct.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Their ability to give may dwindle, but those of ancient lineage do not depart from their character.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A family of ancient dignity never fails of its charity even when fallen on evil days.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Vazhanguva Thulveezhndhak Kannum
Pazhanguti
Panpil Thalaippiridhal Indru
Various Translators:
The means of gift may dwindle; yet 
Ancient homes guard their noble trait.
Dinamalar:
Though stores for charity should fail within, the ancient race
Will never lose its old ancestral grace.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Whose minds are set to live as fits their sire's unspotted fame,
Stooping to low deceit, commit no deeds that gender shame.
Transliteration: Those committed to their family’s flawless fame dare not commit deceitful, dishonorable deeds.
T.Kannan: Those who seek to preserve the irreproachable honour of their families will not viciously do what is detrimental thereto.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those wedded to their spotless heritage
Will do nothing deceitful and ignoble.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those who walk in the untarnished traditions of their noble family never do wrong even in poverty.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those wedded to their spotless heritage
Will do nothing deceitful and ignoble.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who seek to live in harmony with their families, of flawless descent, do not do unworthy deeds spurred by vengeance and deceit.
Various Translators:
Salampatrich Chaalpila Seyyaarmaa
Satra
Kulampatri VaazhdhumEn Paar
Dinamalar:
Who guard their family prestige pure 
Stoop not to acts of cunning lure.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The faults of men of noble race are seen by every eye,
As spots on her bright orb that walks sublime the evening sky.
Transliteration: The defects of the noble will be observed as clearly as the dark spots in the moon.
T.Kannan: In high born men, blemishes are clearly seen, just as the moon’s elevation makes it more visible.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Defects in people of noble descent
Appear prominently as spots on the moon.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Dark as the spot of the Moon in the sky doth the stain of the noble family loom large.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Defects in people of noble descent Appear
prominently as spots on the moon.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Any fault in a person of good descent stands out like the wart on the moon of the sky.
Various Translators:
Kutippirandhaar Kanvilangum Kutram
Visumpin
Madhikkan Maruppol Uyarndhu
Dinamalar:
The faults of nobly born are seen 
Like on the sky the spots of moon.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If one of a good family betrays want of affection, his descent from it will be called in question.
Transliteration:
If manners of the good are rude 
People deem their pedigree crude.
T.Kannan:
If lack of love appear in those who bear some goodly name,
'Twill make men doubt the ancestry they claim.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When a man with good background lacks loving affection, doubts arise whether he arose from that family.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Want of affection from one of good family
Calls in question his descent from it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The world suspects the noble lineage of one who lacks in sympathy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Want of affection from one of good family
Calls in question his descent from it.
Various Translators: If lack of compassion is seen while considering the welfare of others, aspersions are cast on their ancestry.
Dinamalar:
Nalaththinkan Naarinmai Thondrin
Avanaik
Kulaththinkan Aiyap Patum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Soil's nature is seen in sprout 
The worth of birth from words flow out.
Transliteration:
Of soil the plants that spring thereout will show the worth;
The words they speak declare the men of noble birth.
T.Kannan: The nature of a soil is known by the seedlings it sprouts. The nature of a man’s family is known by the words he speaks.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The plants are quite racy of the soil. The words of men of high birth betoken their ancestral dignity.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nature of sprout indicates the quality of soil;
So does the quality of speech one’s descent.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nature of sprout indicates the quality of
soil; So does the quality of speech one’s descent.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The sprouting shoots betray the seed hidden in the soil; words spoken portray the nature of their families.
Various Translators: As the sprout indicates the nature of the soil, (so) the speech of the noble indicates (that of one's birth).
Dinamalar:
Nilaththil Kitandhamai Kaalkaattum
Kaattum
Kulaththil Pirandhaarvaaich Chol

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nalamventin Naanutaimai Ventum Kulam
VentinVentuka Yaarkkum Panivu
Transliteration:
All gain good name by modesty
Nobility by humility.
T.Kannan:
Who seek for good the grace of virtuous shame must know;
Who seek for noble name to all must reverence show.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those desiring greatness must desire modesty. Those seeking their family’s honor must seek to be respectful to all.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Out of modesty springs one’s greatness. Out of humility rises the honour of family.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
There is no good without a sense of shame,
Nor high birth without politeness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He who desires a good name must desire modesty; and he who desires (the continuance of) a family greatness must be submissive to all.
Various Translators:
There is no good without a sense of shame,
Nor high birth without politeness.
Dinamalar: If one cares for his wellbeing, he needs a sense of shame; if one cares for his family, he needs to be humble before anyone.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: It maybe essential and important, yet, let it go, if it is beneath your dignity.
Transliteration:
Indri Amaiyaach Chirappina Aayinum
Kundra Varupa Vital
T.Kannan:
Though needed for your life in main, 
From mean degrading acts refrain.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though linked to splendours man no otherwise may gain,
Reject each act that may thine honour's clearness stain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Reject mean actions, even if they bring glory in their turn.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Shun any actions that will diminish honor, even if they are vital for the preservation of life.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Reject base actions even if such rejection
Makes life impossible.
Various Translators: Actions that would degrade (one's) family should not be done; though they may be so important that not doing them would end in death.
Dinamalar:
Reject base actions even if such rejection
Makes life impossible.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Those who desire fame with honour Will not
sacrifice honour for fame.
Transliteration: Fame and riches may beckon but they’d not do ignoble deeds, those who seek high-mindedness besides honour.
T.Kannan:
Seerinum Seeralla Seyyaare Seerotu
Peraanmai Ventu Pavar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Those who desire honour and name will not do mean things in their thirst for glory.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who seek honour and manly fame
Don't do mean deeds even for name.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who seeks with glory to combine honour's untarnished fame,
Do no inglorious deeds, though men accord them glory's name.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who honorably pursue glory never act ingloriously, even if glorious fame is to be gained.
Various Translators:
Those who desire fame with honour
Will not sacrifice honour for fame.
Dinamalar: Those who desire (to maintain their) honour, will surely do nothing dishonourable, even for the sake of fame.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
In prosperity, bend low. In adversity,
stand straight.
Transliteration: In times of prosperity, humility is needed; but during poverty, don your pride.
T.Kannan: During prosperity practise humility. Even in adversity keep dignity.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Perukkaththu Ventum Panidhal Siriya
Surukkaththu Ventum Uyarvu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Be humble in prosperity
In decline uphold dignity.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Bow down thy soul, with increase blest, in happy hour,
Lift up thy heart, when stript of all by fortune's power.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Cultivate modesty in the midst of good fortune, but in times of adversity preserve your dignity.
Various Translators: In great prosperity humility is becoming; dignity, in great adversity.
Dinamalar:
In prosperity, bend low.
In adversity, stand straight.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Men fallen from a high estate are like the hair fallen from the head.
Transliteration:
Men fallen from high stature Are like hair
fallen from the head.
T.Kannan: When people slip beneath their dignified state, they are lowly as hair fallen from the head.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thalaiyin Izhindha Mayiranaiyar
Maandhar
Nilaiyin Izhindhak Katai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Like hair fallen from head are those 
Who fall down from their high status.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Like hairs from off the head that fall to earth,
When fall'n from high estate are men of noble birth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Honorable men fallen from high status are like useless hair fallen from the head.
Various Translators: They who have fallen from their (high) position are like the hair which has fallen from the head.
Dinamalar:
Men fallen from high stature
Are like hair fallen from the head.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even a trivial mean act will drag down a man from the hill top of his eminence.
Transliteration:
Even a hill-like eminence can be brought
low By deeds as small as a speck.
T.Kannan: A base act, as minor as a rosary pea, will make those, as towering as a mountain, to shrivel.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kundrin Anaiyaarum Kundruvar
Kundruva
Kundri Anaiya Seyin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Even hill like men will sink to nought 
With abrus grain like small default.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If meanness. slight as 'abrus' grain, by men be wrought,
Though like a hill their high estate, they sink to nought.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even those who are exalted like a hill will be thought low, if they commit deeds that are debasing.
Various Translators: Unworthy acts, though mustard seed small, will bring down a man, though he towers like a mountain.
Dinamalar:
Even a hill-like eminence can be brought low
By deeds as small as a speck.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Of what use is servility to one who despises you? It brings neither fame nor does it show the path to heaven.
Transliteration:
Why go behind those who scorn when it
yields Neither fame nor place in heaven?
T.Kannan: It leads not to earthly fame, nor to a divine land; why then must one scamper behind those who revile them.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pukazhindraal Puththelnaattu Uyyaadhaal
Enmatru
Ikazhvaarpin Sendru Nilai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Of what good is it (for the high-born) to go and stand in vain before those who revile him ? it only brings him loss of honour and exclusion from heaven.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Why fawn on men that scorn you here 
It yields no fame, heaven's bliss neither.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
It yields no praise, nor to the land of Gods throws wide the gate;
Why follow men who scron, and at their bidding wait?
Various Translators: It offers neither Earth’s renown nor Heaven’s refuge, so why do men run after and stand by those who revile them?
Dinamalar:
Why go behind those who scorn when it yields
Neither fame nor place in heaven?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Better said doomed that state of life
Spent clinging on to those who scorn.
Transliteration:
Better said doomed that state of life
Spent clinging on to those who scorn.
T.Kannan: Better to be known that he died without stooping low, than live by depending on those who humiliate him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It is better for a man to be said of him that he died in his usual state than that he eked out his life by following those who disgraced him.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ottaarpin Sendroruvan Vaazhdhalin
Annilaiye
Kettaan Enappatudhal Nandru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Better it is to die forlorn 
Than live as slaves of those who scorn.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Better 'twere said, 'He perished!' than to gain
The means to live, following in foeman's train.
Various Translators: Better to die right where you stand, the saying goes, than to live running after those who despise you.
Dinamalar: Better to die in poverty than to be servile to one that scorns you.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Is body as precious as ambrosia that men desire to save it
Even at the cost of honour?
Transliteration: For the high-born to keep their body in life when their honour is gone will certainly not prove a remedy against death.
T.Kannan:
Is body as precious as ambrosia that men
desire to save it Even at the cost of honour?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Living on to preserve your body, when the greatness of your character is gone. is that an elixir of life?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Marundhomatru Oonompum Vaazhkkai
Perundhakaimai
Peetazhiya Vandha Itaththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Is nursing body nectar sweet 
Even when one's honour is lost?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When high estate has lost its pride of honour meet,
Is life, that nurses this poor flesh, as nectar sweet?
Various Translators: Will any medicine preserve the body of the high born man whose honor has already perished?
Dinamalar: When one’s honour is ruined, will the life that sustains the body confer immortality?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The yak, sheared of its hair, does not survive.
The noble, stripped of their honour, prefer death.
Transliteration: Those who give up (their) life when (their) honour is at stake are like the yark which kills itself at the loss of (even one of) its hairs.
T.Kannan:
The yak, sheared of its hair, does not
survive. The noble, stripped of their honour, prefer
death.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The kavarimaa will cease living if a shred of hair is lost; likewise, there are those who’ll shed their lives, if disgraced.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Mayirneeppin Vaazhaak Kavarimaa
Annaar
Uyirneeppar Maanam Varin
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Honour lost, the noble expire 
Like a yak that loses its hair.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He whose honour is at stake lays down his life like the Yak that is shorn of its single hair.
Various Translators:
Like the wild ox that, of its tuft bereft, will pine away,
Are those who, of their honour shorn, will quit the light of day.
Dinamalar: Shorn of its hair, the yak will refuse to live. Such men do exist who prefer death to the loss of honor.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The world will admire and worship the glory of men
Who prefer death to dishonour.
Transliteration: The world will (always) praise and adore the fame of the honourable who would rather die than suffer indignity.
T.Kannan:
The world will admire and worship the
glory of men Who prefer death to dishonour.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The world shall revere their fame, those who are proud enough to face death than ignominy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ilivarin Vaazhaadha Maanam Utaiyaar
Olidhozhudhu Eththum Ulaku
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The world sings in praise of those noble persons who prefer death to dishonour.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Their light the world adores and hails 
Who will not live when honour fails.
Various Translators:
Who , when dishonour comes, refuse to live, their honoured memory
Will live in worship and applause of all the world for aye!
Dinamalar: The world will extol and exalt honorable men who exult in death rather than endure dishonor.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The aspiration for glorious achievement is the light of life. Disgrace is the dark thought that says, “I can live without it.”
Transliteration: One's light is the abundance of one's courage; one's darkness is the desire to live destitute of such (a state of mind.)
T.Kannan:
Honour is to crave for excellence.
Dishonor is to say: “I shall live without it”.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Honour is to crave for excellence.
Dishonor is to say: “I shall live without it”.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Reputation rests on possession of passion; It’s a disgrace to strive to live if ‘tis foregone.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The glory of life is to achieve greatness. The poverty of life is to be lost to all glory.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Olioruvarku Ulla Verukkai
Ilioruvarku
Aqdhirandhu Vaazhdhum Enal
Various Translators:
A heart of courage lives in light 
Devoid of that one's life is night.
Dinamalar:
The light of life is mental energy; disgrace is his
Who say's 'I ill lead a happy life deviod of this.'

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
All men that live are one in circumstances of birth,
Diversities of works give each his special worth.
Transliteration: All men who live are alike at birth. Diverse actions define their distinction and distinctiveness.
T.Kannan: All human beings agree as regards their birth but differ as regards their characteristics, because of the different qualities of their actions.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
By birth all men are equal. Differences in their action
Render their worth unequal.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It is not birth but deeds that mark men.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
By birth all men are equal. Differences in
their action Render their worth unequal.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: All beings are born equal. Distinction Comes with differences in profession.
Various Translators:
Pirappokkum Ellaa Uyirkkum
Sirappovvaa
Seydhozhil Vetrumai Yaan
Dinamalar:
All beings are the same in birth 
But work decides their varied worth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The men of lofty line, whose souls are mean, are never great;
The men of lowly birth, when high of soul, are not of low estate.
Transliteration: Though (raised) above, the base cannot become great; though (brought) low, the great cannot become base.
T.Kannan: Lowly men are never high, even when elevated. High souls are never low, even when downtrodden.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Neither the high-born who act low are high,
Nor the low-born who act high, low.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: One is not great because of one’s birth in a noble family; one is not low because of one’s low birth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Neither the high-born who act low are
high, Nor the low-born who act high, low.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Eminent in stature, but not eminent in deed, is no eminence Lowly in stature, but not lowly in deed, is no lowliness.
Various Translators:
Melirundhum Melallaar Melallar
Keezhirundhum
Keezhallaar Keezhal Lavar
Dinamalar:
Ignoble high not high they are 
The noble low not low they fare.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even greatness, like a woman's chastity, belongs only to him who guards himself.
Transliteration:
Greatness like woman's chastity 
Is guarded by self varacity.
T.Kannan:
Like single hearted women, greatness too,
Exists while to itself is true.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Like chastity in a woman, greatness is guarded by being true to one’s own self.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Even greatness, like a woman’s chastity,
Belongs only to him who guards himself.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Greatness springs from one’s own good conduct preserved like the sacred honour of a woman.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Even greatness, like a woman’s chastity,
Belongs only to him who guards himself.
Various Translators: Like women of virtue, greatness exists Due to steadfast adherence to its virtues.
Dinamalar:
Orumai Makalire Polap Perumaiyum
Thannaiththaan Kontozhukin Untu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Great souls when their will is active
Do mighty deeds rare to achieve.
Transliteration:
The man endowed with greatness true,
Rare deeds in perfect wise will do.
T.Kannan: A man possessing greatness possesses the power to effectively perform uncommonly difficult deeds.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Greatness achieves things difficult for others.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If the great achieve anything,
It will be deeds rare in achievement.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If the great achieve anything, It will be
deeds rare in achievement.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who are bestowed with greatness Do deeds that aren’t commonplace.
Various Translators: (Though reduced) the great will be able to perform, in the proper way, deeds difficult (for others to do).
Dinamalar:
Perumai Yutaiyavar Aatruvaar Aatrin
Arumai Utaiya Seyal

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Siriyaar Unarchchiyul Illai
Periyaaraip
Penikkol Vemennum Nokku
Transliteration:
The petty natured ones have not 
The mind to seek and befriend the great.
T.Kannan:
As votaries of the truly great we will ourselves enroll,'
Is thought that enters not the mind of men of little soul.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: “We will befriend great men and become like them.” Such thoughts seldom intrude upon small minds.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Littleness feels no reverence for the great.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
It is not in the nature of the small to have
That outlook of emulating the great.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is never in the nature of the base to seek the society of the great and partake of their nature.
Various Translators:
It is not in the nature of the small to
have That outlook of emulating the great.
Dinamalar: The petty do not have it in them, the foresight To embrace and emulate the great.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The undeserving, if eminence graces, Pompous, lowly conduct ensues.
Transliteration:
Irappe Purindha Thozhitraam
Sirappundhaan
Seeral Lavarkan Patin
T.Kannan:
The base with power and opulence
Wax with deeds of insolence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Littleness is proud of its virtues.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Whene'er distinction lights on some unworthy head,
Then deeds of haughty insolence are bred.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: When small minded men do achieve some distinction, it only serves to augment their arrogance.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If any distinction falls on the little minded,
Their insolence will know no bounds.
Various Translators: Even nobility of birth, wealth and learning, if in (the possession of) the base, will (only) produce everincreasing pride.
Dinamalar:
If any distinction falls on the little
minded, Their insolence will know no bounds.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The great are always humble, And the small
lost in self-admiration.
Transliteration: Greatness has forever humility Pettiness wallows in vanity.
T.Kannan:
Paniyumaam Endrum Perumai Sirumai
Aniyumaam Thannai Viyandhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Greatness is all humility; littleness is all arrogance.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Greatness bends with modesty 
Meanness vaunts with vanity
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Greatness humbly bends, but littleness always
Spreads out its plumes, and loads itself with praise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Greatness is always humbly self effacing, while pettiness adorns itself with words of praise.
Various Translators:
The great are always humble,
And the small lost in self-admiration.
Dinamalar: The great will always humble himself; but the mean will exalt himself in self-admiration.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The great are never puffed up, While the
small are inordinately proud.
Transliteration: Greatness is devoid of pride Pettiness is perfused with bombast.
T.Kannan: Greatness is not conscious of its worth. Littleness is rooted in pride.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Perumai Perumidham Inmai Sirumai
Perumidham Oorndhu Vital
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Greatness is free from insolence 
Littleness swells with that offence.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Greatness is absence of conceit; meanness, we deem,
Riding on car of vanity supreme.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Greatness abides in the absence of arrogance. Smallness proudly parades its fulsome haughtiness.
Various Translators: Freedom from conceit is (the nature of true) greatness; (while) obstinacy therein is (that of) meanness.
Dinamalar:
The great are never puffed up,
While the small are inordinately proud.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Greatness hides the faults of others; littleness trumpets their faults alone.
Transliteration:
The great hide others' faults. Only the
small talk of nothing else.
T.Kannan: Greatness masks others’ failings Pettiness keeps wailing.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Atram Maraikkum Perumai Sirumaidhaan
Kutrame Koori Vitum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Weakness of others greatness screens 
Smallness defects alone proclaims.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Greatness will hide a neighbour's shame;
Meanness his faults to all the world proclaim.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Greatness conceals by silence the weaknesses of others. Pettiness promptly proclaims such things to all.
Various Translators: The great hide the faults of others; the base only divulge them.
Dinamalar:
The great hide others' faults.
Only the small talk of nothing else.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: All virtues dwell in one who is alive to one’s nobility of conduct.
Transliteration:
All virtues are said to be natural to
those Who acquire character as a duty.
T.Kannan: For those who dutifully strive to be noble, To do all that’s good is seen as natural.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Katanenpa Nallavai Ellaam
Katanarindhu
Saandraanmai Merkol Pavarkku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
All goodness is duty to them
Who are dutiful and sublime.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
All goodly things are duties to the men, they say,
Who set themselves to walk in virtue's perfect way.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is said that those who are conscious of their duty and behave with a perfect goodness will regard as natural all that is good.
Various Translators: It is said that all good things are natural to those who know their duty and walk the path of perfect goodness.
Dinamalar:
All virtues are said to be natural to those
Who acquire character as a duty.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Good conduct is the virtue of the great; all other things are but dross.
Transliteration:
No other goodness than good character Is
deemed good by the noble.
T.Kannan: Being good within, is nobility; All else is no quality.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kunanalam Saandror Nalane Piranalam
Ennalaththu Ulladhooum Andru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The only delight of the perfect is that of their goodness; all other (sensual) delights are not to be included among any (true) delights.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Good in the great is character 
Than that there is nothing better.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The good of inward excellence they claim,
The perfect men; all other good is only good in name.
Various Translators: Perfect men hold as good their own good character. They count no other goodness so genuinely good.
Dinamalar:
No other goodness than good character
Is deemed good by the noble.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The pillars of excellence are five:
Love, modesty, altruism, compassion, truthfulness.
Transliteration:
The pillars of excellence are five: Love,
modesty, altruism, compassion, truthfulness.
T.Kannan: Love, compunction, beneficence, compassion and truthfulness: On these five columns rests nobleness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Affection, fear (of sin), benevolence, favour and truthfulness; these are the five pillars on which perfect goodness rests.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Anpunaan Oppuravu Kannottam
Vaaimaiyotu
Aindhusaal Oondriya Thoon
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Love, truth, regard, modesty, grace 
These five are virtue's resting place.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Love, modesty, beneficence, benignant grace,
With truth, are pillars five of perfect virtue's resting place.
Various Translators: Love, modesty, propriety, a kindly eye and truthfulness— these are the five pillars on which perfect goodness rests.
Dinamalar: Love, modesty, impartiality, sympathy and truthfulness are the five pillars of nobility.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The characteristic of penance is non-killing,
And that of goodness not speaking others’ faults.
Transliteration: Penance consists in the goodness that kills not , and perfection in the goodness that tells not others' faults.
T.Kannan:
The characteristic of penance is
non-killing, And that of goodness not speaking others’
faults.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The virtue of the ascetic is to not kill any being; The virtue of the noble is to never resort to blaming.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kollaa Nalaththadhu Nonmai
Pirardheemai
Sollaa Nalaththadhu Saalpu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Not to kill is penance pure 
Not to slander virtue sure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The type of 'penitence' is virtuous good that nothing slays.
To speak no ill of other men is perfect virtue's praise.
Various Translators: Penance is the goodness that refrains utterly from killing. Perfection is the goodness that refuses to utter others’ faults.
Dinamalar: Penance kills not, nobility slanders not.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Humility is the strength of the strong and the weapon
The wise use to conquer their foes.
Transliteration: Stooping (to inferiors) is the strength of those who can accomplish (an undertaking); and that is the weapon with which the great avert their foes.
T.Kannan:
Humility is the strength of the strong and
the weapon The wise use to conquer their foes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Humility is the vital capability of the capable: To convert foes, the weapon of the noble.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Aatruvaar Aatral Panidhal
Adhusaandror
Maatraarai Maatrum Patai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Humility is valour's strength 
A force that averts foes at length.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Humility is the strength of the great. It is the weapon that disarms the foe.
Various Translators:
Submission is the might of men of mighty acts; the sage
With that same weapon stills his foeman's rage.
Dinamalar: Humility is the strength of the strong and the instrument the wise use to reform their foes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The touchstone of goodness is to own
One's defeat even to inferiors.
Transliteration: The touch-stone of perfection is to receive a defeat even at the hands of one's inferiors.
T.Kannan:
The touchstone of goodness is to own One's
defeat even to inferiors.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The mark of nobility, if you ask, Is to concede with grace, defeat by the underdog.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Saalpirkuk Kattalai Yaadhenin Tholvi
Thulaiyallaar Kannum Kolal
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The touchstone of nobility is to accept defeat even at the hands of inferiors.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To bear repulse e'en from the mean 
Is the touch stone of worthy men.
Various Translators:
What is perfection's test? the equal mind,
To bear repulse from ever meaner men resigned.
Dinamalar: The touchstone of perfect character is accepting with dignity defeat from one’s inferiors.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Of what gain is perfect goodness if it does not do good to all, even to those who have done painful things to others?
Transliteration: Of what avail is perfect goodness if it cannot do pleasing things even to those who have pained (it) ?
T.Kannan:
What good is that goodness if it does not return good
Even to those who cause evil?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What good is that goodness if it does not
return good Even to those who cause evil?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Of what use is being noble If one can’t do good unto those who did evil.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: What profits one’s nobility if good is not done even to those who do harm?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Innaasey Thaarkkum Iniyave
Seyyaakkaal
Enna Payaththadho Saalpu
Various Translators:
Of perfection what is the gain 
If it returns not joy for pain?
Dinamalar:
What fruit doth your perfection yield you say!
Unless to men who work you ill good repay?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To soul with Perfect virtue's strength endued,
Brings no disgrace the lack of every earthly good.
Transliteration: Deprived of all else, one remains undisgraced if still endowed with strength of character.
T.Kannan: Poverty is no disgrace to one who abounds in good qualities.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Poverty is no disgrace to one
Who has the strength called character.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Poverty is no disgrace to one of enduring nobility.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Poverty is no disgrace to one Who has the
strength called character.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Poverty is no disgrace if you possess The strength of nobleness.
Various Translators:
Inmai Oruvarku Ilivandru Saalpennum
ThinmaiUn Taakap Perin
Dinamalar:
No shame there is in poverty 
To one strong in good quality.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Call them of perfect virtue's sea the shore,
Who, though the fates should fail, fail not for evermore.
Transliteration: Those who are said to be the shore of the sea of perfection will never change, though ages may change.
T.Kannan: Destiny’s last days may surge with oceanic change, yet perfectly good men remain, like the shore, unchanged.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The depth of goodness is said to be the never changing attitude
In spite of ever changing fortunes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The sea may recede but noble men will remain steadfast.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The depth of goodness is said to be the
never changing attitude In spite of ever changing
fortunes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those known to be the ocean of nobility aren’t perturbed Even when there is the proverbial Flood.
Various Translators:
Oozhi Peyarinum Thaampeyaraar
Saandraanmaikku
Aazhi Enappatu Vaar
Dinamalar:
Aeons may change but not the seer 
Who is a sea of virtue pure.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If there is a defect in the character of the perfect, (even) the great world cannot bear (its) burden.
Transliteration:
The world will not more bear its weight 
If from high virtue fall the great.
T.Kannan:
The mighty earth its burthen to sustain must cease,
If perfect virtue of the perfect men decrease.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Should the perfect virtue of perfect men ever diminish, this mighty Earth would bear our burdensome weight no more.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The earth will cease to bear its burden
If perfect men fall short of perfection.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Were the nobility of the noble to shrink, the vast firm earth would totter.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The earth will cease to bear its burden If
perfect men fall short of perfection.
Various Translators: If the nobility of the noble does erode, The vast earth cannot bear its load.
Dinamalar:
Saandravar Saandraanmai Kundrin
Irunilandhaan
Thaangaadhu Manno Porai

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To the polite free of access 
Easily comes courteousness.
Transliteration:
Who easy access give to every man, they say,
Of kindly courtesy will learn with ease the way.
T.Kannan: They say if a man is easily accessible to everyone, the virtue of courtesy will be easily accessible to him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Be cautious and easy of access. You will command the homage of the world.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The demeanor called courtesy, they say,
Comes easily to those easily accessible to all.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The demeanor called courtesy, they say,
Comes easily to those easily accessible to all.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Affability with all will help achieve with ease The quality of being courteous.
Various Translators: If one is easy of access to all, it will be easy for one to obtain the virtue called goodness.
Dinamalar:
Enpadhaththaal Eydhal Elidhenpa
Yaarmaattum
Panputaimai Ennum Vazhakku

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Anputaimai Aandra Kutippiraththal
Ivvirantum
Panputaimai Ennum Vazhakku
Transliteration:
Humanity and noble birth 
Develop courtesy and moral worth.
T.Kannan:
Benevolence and high born dignity,
These two are beaten paths of courtesy.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Loving kindness and birth in a good family— these two are said to confer on one a gracious manner.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Courtesy springs from love and noble lineage.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Kindness and exalted birth: these two
Constitute the demeanor called courtesy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Affectionateness and birth in a good family, these two constitute what is called a proper behaviour to all.
Various Translators:
Kindness and exalted birth: these two
Constitute the demeanor called courtesy.
Dinamalar: A kind heart and good heredity are considered To make the quality of being well-mannered.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Physical resemblance makes not people similar Similar qualities make them similar.
Transliteration:
Uruppoththal Makkaloppu Andraal
Veruththakka
Panpoththal Oppadhaam Oppu
T.Kannan:
Likeness in limbs is not likeness 
It's likeness in kind courteousness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Mere physical features do not rank with men but only courtesy makes them ascend the scale.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Men are not one because their members seem alike to outward view;
Similitude of kindred quality makes likeness true.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Resemblance among humans is not that their bodies look alike. Real similarities come from similar traits of courtesy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What binds humanity together is not physical proximity,
But that binding of courteousness.
Various Translators: Resemblance of bodies is no resemblance of souls; true resemblance is the resemblance of qualities that attract.
Dinamalar:
What binds humanity together is not
physical proximity, But that binding of courteousness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The world applauds the conduct of those
Who help with impartiality and generosity.
Transliteration: Being likeable and righteous, they serve all- Their good character the world shall extol.
T.Kannan:
Nayanotu Nandri Purindha
Payanutaiyaar
Panpupaa Raattum Ulaku
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The world respects the courtesy of those who are just and willing to do good.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The world applauds those helpful men 
Whose actions are just and benign.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Of men of fruitful life, who kindly benefits dispense,
The world unites to praise the 'noble excellence'
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The world commends the civility of those who combine fruitful effort and kindly benevolence.
Various Translators:
The world applauds the conduct of those
Who help with impartiality and generosity.
Dinamalar: The world applauds the character of those whose usefulness results from their equity and charity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Mockery hurts even in jest, and hence the
considerate Are courteous even to their foes.
Transliteration: One who discerns others’ nature and sees merit in foes, Won’t deride others for a laugh that causes many woes.
T.Kannan: Do not mock at others even in a sportive mood. There is virtue in being courteous even to a foe.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nakaiyullum Innaa Thikazhchchi
Pakaiyullum
Panpula Paatarivaar Maattu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The courteous don't even foes detest 
For contempt offends even in jest.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Contempt is evil though in sport. They sho man's nature know,
E'en in their warth, a courteous mind will show.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Disparaging words are painful even when uttered in jest. Hence, knowers of human nature are courteous even to enemies.
Various Translators: Reproach is painful to one even in sport; those (therefore) who know the nature of others exhibit (pleasing) qualities even when they are hated.
Dinamalar:
Mockery hurts even in jest, and hence the considerate
Are courteous even to their foes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The world is built on the wisdom of the noble and the good; but for them the entire world would be a heap of ruins.
Transliteration:
The world goes on because of civilized
men. Without them it would collapse into dust.
T.Kannan: The world exists because of courteous people Else it’ll perish by sinking in its own soil.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Panputaiyaarp Pattuntu Ulakam
Adhuindrel
Manpukku Maaivadhu Man
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The world rests with the mannered best
Or it crumbles and falls to dust.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The world abides; for 'worthy' men its weight sustain.
Were it not so , 't would fall to dust again.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The world exists because civilized men exist. Without them, it would collapse into mere dust.
Various Translators: The (way of the) world subsists by contact with the good; if not, it would bury itself in the earth and perish.
Dinamalar:
The world goes on because of civilized men.
Without them it would collapse into dust.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Of what avail is one’s intelligence keen as the edge of the chist^? One is with the socks and gloves if one is not affable.
Transliteration:
Men without character, despite their sharp
minds, Are no better than blocks of wood.
T.Kannan: But for humanity, they are but a tree, Though sharp as a rasp they may be.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Arampolum Koormaiya Renum
Marampolvar
Makkatpanpu Illaa Thavar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The mannerless though sharp like file 
Are like wooden blocks indocile.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though sharp their wit as file, as blocks they must remain,
Whose souls are void of 'courtesy humane'.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He who is destitute of (true) human qualities (only) resembles a tree, though he may possess the sharpness of a file.
Various Translators: Though their minds are as sharp as a wood rasp, men without human decency are as wooden as a tree.
Dinamalar:
Men without character, despite their sharp minds,
Are no better than blocks of wood.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To be failing in one’s courtesy even to one’s foe is sin.
Transliteration:
It is disgraceful to be discourteous, Even
towards the unfriendly who treat you unjustly.
T.Kannan: Even with those, hostile, and callously act, Behaving ungraciously is a blot.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nanpaatraar Aaki Nayamila
Seyvaarkkum
Panpaatraar Aadhal Katai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It is wrong (for the wise) not to exhibit (good) qualities even towards those who bearing no friendship (for them) do only what is hateful.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Discourtesy is mean indeed 
E'en to a base unfriendly breed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though men with all unfriendly acts and worngs assail,
'Tis uttermost disgrace in 'courtesy' to fail.
Various Translators: It is disgraceful to be discourteous towards others, even to unfriendly fellows who treat you unjustly.
Dinamalar:
It is disgraceful to be discourteous,
Even towards the unfriendly who treat you unjustly.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To those who cannot laugh,
This big world is all darkness even during the day.
Transliteration:
To those who cannot laugh, This big world
is all darkness even during the day.
T.Kannan: For those with no faculty to have fun Darkness swamps the large earth despite the sun.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: To those who cannot rejoice, the wide world is buried darkness even in (broad) day light.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nakalvallar Allaarkku Maayiru
Gnaalam
Pakalumpaar Pattandru Irul
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To those bereft of smiling light 
Even in day the earth is night.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To him who knows how to smile in kindly mirth,
Darkness in daytime broods o'er all the vast and mighty earth.
Various Translators: To those who cannot smile in joy, this wide world lies engulfed in darkness, even in broad daylight.
Dinamalar: Even the wide world darkens at noon to the sullen who fails to gladden the hearts of men.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The great wealth kept by the uncultured
Is clean milk gone sour in a can unclean.
Transliteration: The great wealth obtained by one who has no goodness will perish like pure milk spoilt by the impurity of the vessel.
T.Kannan:
The great wealth kept by the uncultured Is
clean milk gone sour in a can unclean.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Good milk spoiled by the vessel that is stained Is wealth in the hands of the uncultured.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Panpilaan Petra Perunjelvam Nanpaal
Kalandheemai Yaaldhirin Thatru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wealth heaped by the churlish base
Is pure milk soured by impure vase.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Like sweet milk soured because in filthy vessel poured,
Is ample wealth in churlish man's unopened coffers stored.
Various Translators: Great wealth amassed by men who lack sweet courtesy is like good milk turned sour in an unclean vessel.
Dinamalar: Of what' use is the wealth of the discourteous? It is like good milk spoilt by an unclean vessel.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A miser makes of his pile of vast wealth,
No more use than a corpse.
Transliteration: He who does not enjoy the immense riches he has heaped up in his house, is (to be reckoned as) dead, (for) there is nothing achieved (by him).
T.Kannan:
A miser makes of his pile of vast wealth,
No more use than a corpse.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Wealth allover the house stashed but is not used Makes one impotent as if he is deceased.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vaiththaanvaai Saandra Perumporul
Aqdhunnaan
Seththaan Seyakkitandhadhu Il
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Dead is he with wealth in pile 
Unenjoyed, it is futile.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He who does not make use of his hoarded wealth is really dead, though aliye; for he cannot do anything great.
Various Translators:
Who fills his house with ample store, enjoying none.
Is dead, Nought with the useless heap is done.
Dinamalar: He who has amassed great wealth but does not enjoy it is reckoned as dead, like his unused heap.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Believing wealth is everything, yet giving nothing,
The miser is ensnared in the misery of birth.
Transliteration: He who knows that wealth yields every pleasure and yet is so blind as to lead miserly life will be born a demon.
T.Kannan:
Believing wealth is everything, yet giving
nothing, The miser is ensnared in the misery of birth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Wealth is all, thinking thus, clinging and being ungenerous, Is a delusion leading to a birth most inglorious.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Porulaanaam Ellaamendru Eeyaadhu
Ivarum
Marulaanaam Maanaap Pirappu
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The birth of a ghost awaits a miser who thinks he gains everything by hoarding wealth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The niggard miser thinks wealth is all 
He hoards, gives not is born devil.
Various Translators:
Who giving nought, opines from wealth all blessings springs,
Degraded birth that doting miser's folly brings.
Dinamalar: Believing wealth is everything, yet giving away nothing, the miser himself will be possessed by a miserable birth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The mere sight of men who lust after wealth, caring nothing for renown, is a burden to the Earth.
Transliteration: A burden to the earth are men bent on the acquisition of riches and not (true) fame.
T.Kannan:
Their very sight is a burden to earth
Who hoard wealth and not renown.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Their very sight is a burden to earth Who
hoard wealth and not renown.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: They seek to gain wealth but not fame, being mean: The presence of such men is earth’s burden.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He who prefers mere accumulation of wealth to glory is a burden unto the earth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Eettam Ivari Isaiventaa Aatavar
Thotram Nilakkup Porai
Various Translators:
A burden he is to earth indeed
Who hoards without a worthy deed.
Dinamalar:
Who lust to heap up wealth, but glory hold not dear,
It burthens earth when on the stage of being they appear.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Whom no one loves, when he shall pass away,
What doth he look to leave behind, I pray?
Transliteration: What could a man, unloved by even a single soul, imagine he might leave to posterity?
T.Kannan: What will the miser who is not liked (by any one) regard as his own (in the world to come) ?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What legacy can one, who is loved by none,
Think of leaving behind?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: What awaits one if one cannot win the affections of others?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What legacy can one, who is loved by none,
Think of leaving behind?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What’d he think is the legacy he’ll leave, He who has nobody’s love?
Various Translators:
Echchamendru Enennung Kollo
Oruvaraal
Nachchap Pataaa Thavan
Dinamalar:
What legacy can he leave behind 
Who is for approach too unkind.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Amid accumulated millions they are poor,
Who nothing give and nought enjoy of all they store.
Transliteration: Those who neither give (to others) nor enjoy (their property) are (truly) destitute, though possessing immense riches.
T.Kannan: Amid millions heaped high, a man remains poor if he neither gives away his wealth nor enjoys it himself.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Wealth, though millions manifold, amounts to nothing
If one neither gives nor enjoys it.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Of what avail is the untold wealth of one who neither gives nor enjoys it?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Wealth, though millions manifold, amounts
to nothing If one neither gives nor enjoys it.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Many crores one may make, but it means nothing If one is neither spending nor giving.
Various Translators:
Kotuppadhooum Thuyppadhooum Illaarkku
Atukkiya
Kotiyun Taayinum Il
Dinamalar:
What is the good of crores they hoard 
To give and enjoy whose heart is hard.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He who enjoys not (his riches) nor relieves the wants of the worthy is a disease to his wealth.
Transliteration:
Great wealth unused for oneself nor 
To worthy men is but a slur.
T.Kannan:
Their ample wealth is misery to men of churlish heart,
Who nought themseleves enjoy, and nought to worthy men inpart.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Vast wealth can be a wretched curse to one who neither gladdens himself in its worth nor gives to the worthy.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Riches are a curse when neither enjoyed,
Nor given to the worthy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Abundance of wealth is not a blessing but a curse to one who can neither enjoy it nor spend it on the deserving.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Riches are a curse when neither enjoyed,
Nor given to the worthy.
Various Translators: Wealth is a malady, when oneself it doesn’t serve And to the deserving, one isn’t disposed to give.
Dinamalar:
Edham Perunjelvam Thaandhuvvaan
Thakkaarkkondru
Eedhal Iyalpilaa Thaan

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who loaths to help have nots, his gold 
Is like a spinster belle grown old.
Transliteration:
Like woman fair in lonelihood who aged grows,
Is wealth of him on needy men who nought bestows.
T.Kannan: The wealth of a greedy man who gives nothing to the needy is like the beauty of a maiden growing old unwed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The wealth that is not spent on the needy is as barren as the withering charm of a spinster.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Wealth not given to the needy goes waste
Like a lovely spinster growing old.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Wealth not given to the needy goes waste
Like a lovely spinster growing old.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: A maiden of bounteous merit, being single, if greyed: Such is wealth that is not used to aid the deprived.
Various Translators: The wealth of him who never bestows anything on the destitute is like a woman of beauty growing old without a husband.
Dinamalar:
Atraarkkondru Aatraadhaan Selvam
Mikanalam
Petraal Thamiyalmooth Thatru

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nachchap Pataadhavan Selvam
Natuvoorul
Nachchu Marampazhuth Thatru
Transliteration:
The idle wealth of unsought men
Is poison fruit tree amidst a town.
T.Kannan:
When he whom no man loves exults in great prosperity,
'Tis as when fruits in midmost of the town some poisonous tree.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The wealth of a man whom no heart loves is like fruits on a poisonous tree in the heart of a village.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The wealth of a miser is like the fruit of a poison-tree in the heart of a village.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wealth of the unloved is like a poisonous tree
That ripens in the heart of a village.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The wealth of him who is disliked (by all) is like the fruit-bearing of the etty tree in the midst of a town.
Various Translators:
The wealth of the unloved is like a
poisonous tree That ripens in the heart of a village.
Dinamalar: Wealth of a person, who is loved by none, Is a toxic fruit tree in the middle of a town.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Devoid of love and denying oneself, Wealth gained with no scruples, others shall seize.
Transliteration:
Anporeeith Tharsetru Aranokkaadhu
Eettiya
Onporul Kolvaar Pirar
T.Kannan:
Others usurp the shining gold 
In loveless, stingy, vicious hold.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Strangers inherit the great wealth of a miser who neither enjoys it nor gives.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who love abandon, self afflict, and virtu's way forsake
To heap up glittering wealth, their hoards shall others take.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He who casts out love and dharma and chooses self denial so wealth can pile high will see it seized by strangers.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Strangers shall possess that wealth
Amassed without love, comfort or scruples.
Various Translators: Strangers will inherit the riches that have been acquired without regard for friendship, comfort and charity.
Dinamalar:
Strangers shall possess that wealth
Amassed without love, comfort or scruples.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The brief want of the benign rich Is like
the monsoon clouds just shed its moisture.
Transliteration: When the famed wealthy go through poverty They resemble clouds that lost their bounty.
T.Kannan:
Seerutaich Chelvar Sirudhuni Maari
Varangoorn Thanaiyadhu Utaiththu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The short-lived poverty of the generous rich is the drought of rain-laden clouds.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The brief want of the rich benign 
Is like rainclouds growing thin.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Tis as when rain cloud in the heaven grows dry,
When generous wealthy man endures brief poverty.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The short lived poverty of a benevolent rich man is like the temporary dryness of a bountiful rain cloud.
Various Translators:
The brief want of the benign rich
Is like the monsoon clouds just shed its moisture.
Dinamalar: The short-lived poverty of those who are noble and rich is like the clouds becoming poor (for a while).

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Real shyness is to shy away from shameful
acts. The rest are like shyness of pretty women.
Transliteration: Compunction is having scruples about one’s action Distinct from demureness of pretty-browed fine women.
T.Kannan: True modesty shrinks from littleness. All other forms of modesty are womanish.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Karumaththaal Naanudhal Naanun
Thirunudhal
Nallavar Naanup Pira
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To shrink from evil deed is shame 
The rest is blush of fair faced dame.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To shrink abashed from evil deed is 'generous shame';
Other is that of bright browed ones of virtuous fame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: For fair faced maidens, modesty means bashfulness, but the deeper modesty shies away from shameful karmas.
Various Translators: True modesty is the fear of (evil) deeds; all other modesty is (simply) the bashfulness of virtuous maids.
Dinamalar:
Real shyness is to shy away from shameful acts.
The rest are like shyness of pretty women.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Common to all human beings are food and clothing and other necessaries of life. But what distinguishes them is modesty.
Transliteration:
Food, clothing and the rest are common to
all. Distinction comes from sensitivity to shame.
T.Kannan: Needs of food, dress et al are not dissimilar for all Compunction is the distinctive feature of good people.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Oonutai Echcham Uyirkkellaam Veralla
Naanutaimai Maandhar Sirappu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Food, dress and such are one for all 
Modesty marks the higher soul.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Food, clothing and other things alike all beings own;
By sense of shame the excellence of men is known.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Food, clothing and such do not differ much among people; what distinguishes good men from others is modesty.
Various Translators: Food, clothing and the like are common to all men but modesty is peculiar to the good.
Dinamalar:
Food, clothing and the rest are common to all.
Distinction comes from sensitivity to shame.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Man clings to his body. The noble clings to modesty.
Transliteration:
All souls abide in the body And the
goodness called modesty in perfection.
T.Kannan: Food is the basis for all lives, the goodness Of compunction is the basis for nobleness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Oonaik Kuriththa Uyirellaam
Naanennum
Nanmai Kuriththadhu Saalpu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
All lives have their lodge in flesh 
Perfection has its home in blush.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
All spirits homes of flesh as habitation claim,
And perfect virtue ever dwells with shame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: As the body is the abode of the spirit, so the excellence of modesty is the abode of perfection.
Various Translators: All life clings to a body; perfect goodness clings to all that is modest.
Dinamalar:
All souls abide in the body
And the goodness called modesty in perfection.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Disgraceful is the painted pomp of the life of the immodest.
Transliteration:
Is not modesty the jewel of the great, And
without it a curse for their pride and demeanor?
T.Kannan: For the noble, having compunction is an adornment; Without it, ain’t their proud stride an ailment?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aniandro Naanutaimai Saandrorkku
Aqdhindrel
Piniandro Peetu Natai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Is not the modesty ornament of the noble ? Without it, their haughtiness would be a pain (to others).
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Shame is the jewel of dignity 
Shameless swagger is vanity.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
And is not shame an ornament to men of dignity?
Without it step of stately pride is piteous thing to see.
Various Translators: Is not modesty a jewel adorning perfect men? Without it, is not their strut an awful blemish to behold?
Dinamalar:
Is not modesty the jewel of the great,
And without it a curse for their pride and demeanor?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To the world, the sense of shame resides in them
Who blush for their and others’ blame.
Transliteration:
To the world, the sense of shame resides
in them Who blush for their and others’ blame.
T.Kannan: If blame for others and self, moves one to the same sense of shame The world shall call them the home for compunction.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The world regards as the abode of modesty him who fear his own and other's guilt.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pirarpazhiyum Thampazhiyum Naanuvaar
Naanukku
Uraipadhi Ennum Ulaku
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In them resides the sense of shame 
Who blush for their and other's blame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As home of virtuous shame by all the world the men are known,
Who feel ashamed for others, guilt as for their own.
Various Translators: The world decrees that men who are as ashamed by others’ disgrace as by their own are modesty’s fondest home.
Dinamalar: The world finds the very abode of modesty in one who dreads one’s infamy and that of others.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The great would rather defend with modesty's barricade
Than breach it to acquire the vast world.
Transliteration: The great make modesty their barrier (of defence) and not the wide world.
T.Kannan:
The great would rather defend with
modesty's barricade Than breach it to acquire the vast
world.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Great men desire not the vast world under their reign Without the protective fence of compunction.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Naanveli Kollaadhu Manno
Viyangnaalam
Penalar Melaa Yavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The great refuse the wonder world 
Without modesty's hedge and shield.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Unless the hedge of shame inviolate remain,
For men of lofty soul the earth's vast realms no charms retain.
Various Translators: The great would rather hold themselves behind modesty’s barricade than breach it to acquire the vast world.
Dinamalar: The great prefer modesty to the riches of the world.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Men of honour give up life for honour’s sake,
But never abandon honour to save life.
Transliteration: The modest would rather lose their life for the sake of modesty than lose modesty for the sake of life.
T.Kannan:
Men of honour give up life for honour’s
sake, But never abandon honour to save life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Their lives they may shed but never their scruples to save their lives They who by their scruples ever abide.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Naanaal Uyiraith Thurappar
Uyirpporuttaal
Naandhuravaar Naanaal Pavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
For shame their life the shame sensed give 
Loss of shame they won't outlive.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Better retain modesty than cling to life. The noble would rather die than lose modesty.
Various Translators:
The men of modest soul for shame would life an offering make,
But ne'er abandon virtuous shame for life's dear sake.
Dinamalar: Those who prize unpretentiousness will forsake life to preserve it. But they never forsake modesty for the sake of life.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Virtue will shy away from one who does not shy away
From what others shy from.
Transliteration: Virtue is likely to forsake him who shamelessly does what others are ashamed of.
T.Kannan:
Virtue will shy away from one who does not
shy away From what others shy from.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If what shames others doesn’t raise in him a qualm Virtue’ll flee him feeling that shame.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pirarnaanath Thakkadhu Thaannaanaa
Naayin
Aramnaanath Thakkadhu Utaiththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar: One who does not shrink from what others blush at knows no righteousness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Virtue is much ashamed of him 
Who shameless does what others shame.
Various Translators:
Though know'st no shame, while all around ashamed must be;
Virtue will shrink away ashamed of thee!
Dinamalar: If a man does not feel ashamed of what makes others feel ashamed, virtue itself will be ashamed of him.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Failing to observe good conduct, one sets his family on fire. Living in shamelessness, he incinerates everything good.
Transliteration: Want of manners injures one's family; but want of modesty injures one's character.
T.Kannan:
Lapse in manners injures the family,
But every good is lost by lack of shame.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Lapse in manners injures the family, But
every good is lost by lack of shame.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The family is hurt if one breaches convention All good is spoilt if there is lack of compunction.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Lack of decorum disgraces a home; lack of modesty destroys everything good.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kulanjutum Kolkai Pizhaippin
Nalanjutum
Naaninmai Nindrak Katai
Various Translators:
Lapse in manners injures the race 
Want of shame harms every good grace.
Dinamalar:
Twill race consume if right observance fail;
'Twill every good consume if shamelessness prevail.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Tis as with strings a wooden puppet apes life's functions, when
Those void of shame within hold intercourse with men.
Transliteration: The movements of men devoid of modesty mock life, like wooden puppets suspended on a string.
T.Kannan: The actions of those who are without modesty at heart are like those of puppet moved by a string.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The moves of those devoid of conscience
Are like those of puppets moved by a string.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The activity of those lacking in modesty is like that of a marionette.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The moves of those devoid of conscience
Are like those of puppets moved by a string.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The actions of those who, deep within, have no compunction Is akin to a stringed puppet seeming alive, an illusion.
Various Translators:
Naanakath Thillaar Iyakkam
Marappaavai
Naanaal Uyirmarutti Atru
Dinamalar:
Movements of the shameless in heart 
Are string led puppet show in fact.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who says 'I'll do my work, nor slack my hand',
His greatness, clothed with dignity supreme, shall stand.
Transliteration: There is no higher greatness than that of one saying. I will not cease in my effort (to raise my family).
T.Kannan: No greater dignity exists than when a man resolutely declares, “I will never cease in laboring to fulfill my karmas.”
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
There is nothing more glorious than to persist
In the advance of the community.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Nothing is more exalted and manly than one’s ceaseless toil to uplift one’s own family.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
There is nothing more glorious than to
persist In the advance of the community.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: To proclaim, I shall never take my hands off to do one’s duty No acclaim can match that dignity.
Various Translators:
Karumam Seyaoruvan Kaidhooven Ennum
Perumaiyin Peetutaiyadhu Il
Dinamalar:
No greatness is grander like 
Saying "I shall work without slack".

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: One's family is raised by untiring perseverance in both effort and wise contrivances.
Transliteration:
These two exalt a noble home 
Ardent effort and ripe wisdom.
T.Kannan:
The manly act and knowledge full, when these combine
In deed prolonged, then lengthens out the race's line
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One prolongs his clan by prolonged exertion in both perseverance and sound understanding.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Manly exertion and sound knowledge:
A community progresses with these two.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Manly effort and ripe wisdom exalt one’s family.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Manly exertion and sound knowledge: A
community progresses with these two.
Various Translators: Tasks one takes on with persistence and profound wisdom. The people shall prosper through them.
Dinamalar:
Aalvinaiyum Aandra Arivum Enairantin
Neelvinaiyaal Neelum Kuti

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When one resolves to raise his race 
Loin girt up God leads his ways.
Transliteration:
I'II make my race renowned', if man shall say,
With vest succinct the goddess leads the way.
T.Kannan: When a man vows to advance his community, God Himself will wrap His robes and lead the way.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even God girds up His loins in the service of one who strives for the glory of one’s family.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The Lord himself will wrap his robes
And lead the one bent on social service.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The Lord himself will wrap his robes And
lead the one bent on social service.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: I’ll serve my people, for the one who so said God shall gird up his robes and rush to his aid.
Various Translators: The Deity will clothe itself and appear before him who resolves on raising his family.
Dinamalar:
Kutiseyval Ennum Oruvarkuth Theyvam
Matidhatruth Thaanmun Thurum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Soozhaamal Thaane Mutiveydhum
Thamkutiyaith
Thaazhaadhu Ugnatru Pavarkku
Transliteration:
Who raise their races with ceaseless pain 
No need for plan; their ends will gain.
T.Kannan:
Who labours for his race with unremitting pain,
Without a thought, spontaneously, his end will gain.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When a man’s effort to raise his community high is unremitting, his work will prosper on its own, even if he makes no plans.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Success comes unbidden to one who exalts one’s family with unremitting toil.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Success will come by itself to the one
Who tirelessly strives for his society.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those who are prompt in their efforts (to better their family) need no deliberation, such efforts will of themselves succee d.
Various Translators:
Success will come by itself to the one Who
tirelessly strives for his society.
Dinamalar: When for his kindred, one perseveres without respite: With no contriving, on its own, it’ll turn out right.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Doing no wrong, the one who serves his kin. The world shall embrace as its own.
Transliteration:
Kutram Ilanaaik Kutiseydhu
Vaazhvaanaich
Chutramaach Chutrum Ulaku
T.Kannan:
Who keeps his house without a blame
People around, his kinship claim.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The world becomes kin to one who leads an unblemished householder’s life.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
With blameless life who seeks to build his race's fame,
The world shall circle him, and kindred claim.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The world will surround and befriend him who, without fault, lives to advance his community.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The world will flock round the one
Leading a blameless life doing social service.
Various Translators: People will eagerly seek the friendship of the prosperous soul who has raised his family without foul means.
Dinamalar:
The world will flock round the one Leading
a blameless life doing social service.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
True valour lies in raising the community
One is born into.
Transliteration: One will be known for his imposing command when He takes command of the house where he was born.
T.Kannan:
Nallaanmai Enpadhu Oruvarkuth
Thaanpirandha
Illaanmai Aakkik Kolal
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: What is true manliness except perfect ordering of the house for its own glory?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who raise their race which gave them birth
Are deemed as men of manly worth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Of virtuous manliness the world accords the praise
To him who gives his powers, the house from which he sprang to raise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is said that true manliness consists in becoming head and provider of the clan one was born into.
Various Translators:
True valour lies in raising the community
One is born into.
Dinamalar: A man's true manliness consists in making himself the head and benefactor of his family.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
As in the battlefield, the burden of
social work Also falls on the capable.
Transliteration: Like the bravehearts do on a battlefield The ablest takes charge of the household.
T.Kannan: The brunt of the battle falls on the victorious; the burden of the family on the competent few.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Amarakaththu Vankannar Polath
Thamarakaththum
Aatruvaar Metre Porai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Like dauntless heroes in battle field 
The home burden rests on the bold.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The fearless hero bears the brunt amid the warrior throng;
Amid his kindred so the burthen rests upon the strong.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: As on a battlefield the burden falls upon the brave, in the community weight is carried by the most competent.
Various Translators: Like heroes in the battle-field, the burden (of protection etc.) is borne by those who are the most efficient in a family.
Dinamalar:
As in the battlefield, the burden of social work
Also falls on the capable.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To pure householders there is no cessation of work. One’s false prestige leads to the ruin of one’s family.
Transliteration:
There is no set time for social service.
To put off is to ruin repute.
T.Kannan: To serve one’s people look not for the ripe hour Being lethargic and ego-centric makes all suffer.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kutiseyvaark Killai Paruvam
Matiseydhu
Maanang Karudhak Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
No season have they who raise their race 
Sloth and pride will honour efface.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Wait for no season, when you would your house uprear;
 'Twill perish, if you wait supine, or hold your honour dear.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Those seeking to improve their clan await no season, for delays and undue regard for dignity will destroy it.
Various Translators: As a family suffers by (one's) indolence and false dignity there is to be so season (good or bad) to those who strive to raise their family.
Dinamalar:
There is no set time for social service.
To put off is to ruin repute.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Is he who protects his family from the ills of life a mere vessel of suffering?
Transliteration:
Is the body that protects one’s family
against hurdles A receptacle for hardships alone?
T.Kannan: Is his body the bin for all stress Who shields his kin from distress?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Itumpaikke Kolkalam Kollo
Kutumpaththaik
Kutra Maraippaan Utampu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Is not his frame a vase for woes 
Who from mishaps shields his house?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Is not his body vase that various sorrows fill,
Who would his household screen from every ill?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Is it only to suffering that his body is exposed who undertakes to preserve his family from evil ?
Various Translators: When a man shields his family from every suffering, doesn’t his body become a vessel filled with their afflictions?
Dinamalar:
Is the body that protects one’s family against hurdles
A receptacle for hardships alone?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The axe of adversity falls on the family which has no noble son to shield it.
Transliteration:
Society will crash axed by misfortune
Without good men to support it.
T.Kannan: The people who have not a good man to lean on Shall fall with their base shorn by some affliction.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Itukkankaal Kondrita Veezhum
Atuththoondrum
Nallaal Ilaadha Kuti
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If there are none to prop up and maintain a family (in distress), it will fall at the stroke of the axe of misfortune.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A house will fall by a mishap 
With no good man to prop it up.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When trouble the foundation saps the house must fall,
If no strong hand be nigh to prop the tottering wall.
Various Translators: Without good men to hold it up, the family home will fall the moment misfortune’s axe comes down.
Dinamalar:
Society will crash axed by misfortune
Without good men to support it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Wherever it whirls, the world must follow the farmer.
Thus despite hardships, farming is the best.
Transliteration:
Wherever it whirls, the world must follow
the farmer. Thus despite hardships, farming is the
best.
T.Kannan: The world tails the plough despite other pursuit Even if one toils, farming remains foremost.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Agriculture, though laborious, is the most excellent (form of labour); for people, though they go about (in search of various employments), have at last to resort to the farmer.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Suzhandrumerp Pinnadhu Ulakam
Adhanaal
Uzhandhum Uzhave Thalai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Farming though hard is foremost trade 
Men ply at will but ploughmen lead.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Howe'er they roam, the world must follow still the plougher's team;
Though toilsome, culture of the ground as noblest toil esteem.
Various Translators: Wherever it may wander, the world follows the farmer’s plow. Thus despite all its hardships, farming is the foremost occupation.
Dinamalar: After vain wanderings in search of callings the world returned to the plough.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Farmers are the linchpin of the world
For they support all others who cannot till.
Transliteration: Agriculturists are (as it were) the linch-pin of the world for they support all other workers who cannot till the soil.
T.Kannan:
Farmers are the linchpin of the world For
they support all others who cannot till.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Farmers are the linchpin of the world All others not farming, it does hold.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Uzhuvaar Ulakaththaarkku Aaniaq
Thaatraadhu
Ezhuvaarai Ellaam Poruththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Tillers are linch pin of mankind 
Bearing the rest who cannot tend.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The ploughers are the linch pin of the world; they bear
Them up who other works perform, too weak its toils to share.
Various Translators: Farmers are the linchpin of the world, for they support all who take up other work, not having the strength to plow.
Dinamalar: Husbandmen are the sheet-anchor of the world for on them depend lives of others.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
They only live who live by the plough.
The rest must stoop and trail behind.
Transliteration: They alone live who live by agriculture; all others lead a cringing, dependent life.
T.Kannan:
They only live who live by the plough. The
rest must stoop and trail behind.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Only they live, who eat from what they plough Others follow, and to eat, they kowtow.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Uzhudhuntu Vaazhvaare Vaazhvaarmar
Rellaam
Thozhudhuntu Pinsel Pavar
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They live who live to plough and eat 
The rest behind them bow and eat.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Only the husbandmen live; all others subsist on their toil.
Various Translators:
Who ploughing eat their food, they truly live;
The rest to others bend subservient, eating what they give.
Dinamalar: Those who live by the plow live in self sufficiency. All others lean on them to simply subsist.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The reign of many kingdoms comes under
The reign of those with abundant grain.
Transliteration: Patriotic farmers desire to bring all other states under the control of their own king.
T.Kannan:
The reign of many kingdoms comes under The
reign of those with abundant grain.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Who bring their land under their crops’ shade Many states under their king’s reign shall bade.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Palakutai Neezhalum Thangutaikkeezhk
Kaanpar
Alakutai Neezha Lavar
