Ramachandra Dikshitar: It is the husbandmen that bring the might of the kings under the sway of their own sovereign.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who have the shade of cornful crest 
Under their umbra umbrellas rest.
Various Translators:
O'er many a land they'll see their monarch reign,
Whose fields are shaded by the waving grain.
Dinamalar: Those whose fields lie shaded by abundant sheaves of grain will see many nations overshadowed by their own.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who eat food harvested with their own hands will never beg and never refuse a beggar’s outstretched palm.
Transliteration: Those whose nature is to live by manual labour will never beg but give something to those who beg.
T.Kannan:
Those who eat what their hands produce
Neither beg nor refuse a beggar.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Those who eat what their hands produce
Neither beg nor refuse a beggar.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: They never beg, nor deny others, givin’ what they seek Whose nature is to eat what they till and make.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A toiling peasant never begs but gives.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Iravaar Irappaarkkondru Eevar
Karavaadhu
Kaiseydhoon Maalai Yavar
Various Translators:
Who till and eat, beg not; nought hide
But give to those who are in need.
Dinamalar:
They nothing ask from others, but to askers give,
Who raise with thier own hands the food on which they live.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
For those who've left what all men love no place is found,
When they with folded hands remain who till the ground.
Transliteration: When plowers of the fields stand idly with folded arms, even desireless ascetics will not last long.
T.Kannan: If the farmer's hands are slackened, even the ascetic state will fail.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Even the desire-free hermits will lose their state
If ploughmen fold their hands.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Even the anchorite ceases from penance if husbandmen sit with their hands folded.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Even the desire-free hermits will lose
their state If ploughmen fold their hands.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If tillers fold their hands still, sages who say I’ve given up desire, as such cannot stay.
Various Translators:
Uzhavinaar Kaimmatangin Illai
Vizhaivadhooum
Vittemen Paarkkum Nilai
Dinamalar:
Should ploughmen sit folding their hands 
Desire free monks too suffer wants.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Reduce your soil to that dry state 
When ounce is quarter ounce's weight;Without one handful of manure, Abundant crops you thus secure.
Transliteration: If the land is dried so as to reduce one ounce of earth to a quarter, it will grow plentifully even without a handful of manure.
T.Kannan: If soil is dried so that one ounce shrinks to one quarter ounce, fruitful yields will not require a single handful of fertilizer.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
If ploughed and dried to quarter its size,
The soil yields plenty sans even handful manure.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let the land be allowed to dry with dust. Even a handful of manure is not needed for a good harvest.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If ploughed and dried to quarter its size,
The soil yields plenty sans even handful manure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If one measure of soil, is turned fine and dried to a quarter, Good yield needs not a handful of manure.
Various Translators:
Thotippuzhudhi Kaqsaa Unakkin
Pitiththeruvum
Ventaadhu Saalap Patum
Dinamalar:
Moulds dried to quarter dust ensure
Rich crops without handful manure.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Manuring is better than ploughing; after weeding, watching is better than watering (it).
Transliteration:
Better manure than plough; then weed; 
Than irrigating, better guard.
T.Kannan:
To cast manure is better than to plough;
Weed well; to guard is more than watering now.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It is better to fertilize than to furrow a field. After weeding, it is more important to watch over a field than even to water it.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Manuring is crucial than ploughing. After weeding,
Protection is crucial than watering.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: After weeding, let the land be guarded, for more important than water is the protection of crops.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Manuring is crucial than ploughing. After
weeding, Protection is crucial than watering.
Various Translators: Worthier than ploughing is to manure the field; Weeding done, worthier than watering is to secure the yield.
Dinamalar:
Erinum Nandraal Eruvitudhal Kattapin
Neerinum Nandradhan Kaappu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If landsmen sit sans moving about 
The field like wife will sulk and pout.
Transliteration:
When master from the field aloof hath stood;
Then land will sulk , like wife in angry mood.
T.Kannan: If the lord of the land fails to visit his fields, they will sulk as surely as a neglected wife.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The land neglected by its owner puts on the appearance of a sulky woman abandoned by her lord.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If the landlord neglects his field visits,
The angry land will sulk like a neglected wife.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If the landlord neglects his field visits,
The angry land will sulk like a neglected wife.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If from the land, her master stays off Like a wife, she’ll sulk and start a tiff.
Various Translators: If the owner does not (personally) attend to his cultivation, his land will behave like an angry wife and yield him no pleasure.
Dinamalar:
Sellaan Kizhavan Iruppin
Nilampulandhu
Illaalin Ooti Vitum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ilamendru Asaii Iruppaaraik Kaanin
Nilamennum Nallaal Nakum
Transliteration:
Fair good earth will laugh to see 
Idlers pleading poverty.
T.Kannan:
The earth, that kindly dame, will laugh to see,
Men seated idle pleading poverty.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Mother Earth laughs when she sees lazy men crying, “We are so poor.”
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Mother earth laughs in scorn at those who plead poverty
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Mother Earth laughs at the sight of those
Who remain idle pleading poverty.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The maiden, Earth, will laug h at the sight of those who plead poverty and lead an idle life.
Various Translators:
Mother Earth laughs at the sight of those
Who remain idle pleading poverty.
Dinamalar: Seeing them say, We have not and loiter The Fair Lady Earth scorns them with laughter.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If you ask, what torments more than poverty: Only poverty can torment more than poverty.
Transliteration:
Inmaiyin Innaadhadhu Yaadhenin
Inmaiyin
Inmaiye Innaa Thadhu
T.Kannan:
What gives more pain than scarcity?
No pain pinches like poverty.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: There is no greater evil than poverty!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
You ask what sharper pain than poverty is known;
Nothing pains more than poverty, save poverty alone.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Ask what is more miserable than being poor, and the answer comes—only poverty pains like poverty.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What is more painful than poverty?
The pain of poverty itself!
Various Translators: There is nothing that afflicts (one) like poverty.
Dinamalar:
What is more painful than poverty? The
pain of poverty itself!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The demon of poverty takes away The joys
of this life and the next.
Transliteration: Poverty is a wretch; This life and the next does it snatch.
T.Kannan:
Inmai Enavoru Paavi Marumaiyum
Immaiyum Indri Varum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Poverty is an evil which blasts at once the joys of earth and of heaven.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The sinner Want is enemy dire 
Of joys of earth and heaven there.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Malefactor matchless! poverty destroys
This world's and the next world's joys.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Poverty, the cruelest of demons, deprives a man of every joy in this life, then takes them from the next life.
Various Translators:
The demon of poverty takes away
The joys of this life and the next.
Dinamalar: When cruel poverty comes on, it deprives one of both the present and future (bliss).

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
That cancer called poverty destroys at
once The honor of ancient descent and clout.
Transliteration: Ancestral legacy and parlance crumble in totality Due to hankering caused by poverty.
T.Kannan: Poverty which springs of avarice ruins one’s ancestry and its fair name.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Tholvaravum Tholum Ketukkum
Thokaiyaaka
Nalkuravu Ennum Nasai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The craving itch of poverty 
Kills graceful words and ancestry.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Importunate desire, which poverty men name,
Destroys both old descent and goodly fame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Craving, another name for poverty, will obliterate at once ancestral honor and dignity of speech.
Various Translators: Hankering poverty destroys at once the greatness of (one's) ancient descent and (the dignity of one's) speech.
Dinamalar:
That cancer called poverty destroys at once
The honor of ancient descent and clout.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Dejection due to poverty makes the noble utter the language of the base.
Transliteration:
Even in those of high birth, poverty will
produce The fault of uttering mean words.
T.Kannan: From the high-born too, vile words may be born When deprivation makes them so cast down.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Irpirandhaar Kanneyum Inmai
Ilivandha
Sorpirakkum Sorvu Tharum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Want makes even good familymen 
Utter words that are low and mean.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From penury will spring, 'mid even those of noble race,
Oblivion that gives birth to words that bring disgrace.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Privation produces unmindfulness, which gives birth to improper words, even in men of proper birth.
Various Translators: Even in those of high birth, poverty will produce the fault of uttering mean words.
Dinamalar:
Even in those of high birth, poverty will produce
The fault of uttering mean words.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Poverty in itself an evil is the mother of all ills.
Transliteration:
That misery called poverty brings with it
A diversity of sufferings.
T.Kannan: From the one misery named penury Emanates many a worry.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nalkuravu Ennum Itumpaiyul
Palkuraith
Thunpangal Sendru Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The pest of wanton poverty 
Brings a train of misery.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From poverty, that grievous woe,
Attendant sarrows plenteous grow.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The misery of poverty brings in its train many (more) miseries.
Various Translators: Poverty is that single sorrow which gives rise to a multitude of miseries.
Dinamalar:
That misery called poverty brings with it
A diversity of sufferings.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The words of the poor, though born of experience and wisdom are not listened to.
Transliteration:
A poor man's words carry no weight,
However meaningful and profound.
T.Kannan: After deep reflection they may say words of deep essence Yet what the poor say may be seen to have no sense.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Narporul Nankunarndhu Sollinum
Nalkoorndhaar
Sorporul Sorvu Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The words of the poor are profitless, though they may be sound in thought and clear in expression.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The poor men's words are thrown away 
Though from heart good things they say.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though deepest sense, well understood, the poor man's words convey,
Their sense from memory of mankind will fade away.
Various Translators: Even when the poor perceive profoundly and speak skillfully, their most meaningful words are always forgotten.
Dinamalar:
A poor man's words carry no weight,
However meaningful and profound.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Poverty, destitute of all virtues, alienates a man
Even from the mother who bore him.
Transliteration:
Poverty, destitute of all virtues,
alienates a man Even from the mother who bore him.
T.Kannan: Poverty aligned to no virtue makes even one’s mother Who bore bore him, to see him as a misfit.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: He that is reduced to absolute poverty will be regarded as a stranger even by his own mother.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Aranjaaraa Nalkuravu Eendradhaa
Yaanum
Piranpola Nokkap Patum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Even the mother looks as stranger 
The poor devoid of character.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
From indigence devoid of virtue's grace,
The mother e'en that bare, estranged, will turn her face.
Various Translators: He who is impoverished and estranged from virtue will be regarded as a stranger even by his own mother.
Dinamalar: Even a mother turns her back on one whose poverty is devoid of probity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Will that hunger which almost killed me yesterday,
Pester me even today?
Transliteration: Is the poverty that almost killed me yesterday, to meet me today too ?
T.Kannan:
Will that hunger which almost killed me
yesterday, Pester me even today?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Did not my privation kill me yesterday? Does it have to be back again today?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Indrum Varuvadhu Kollo Nerunalum
Kondradhu Polum Nirappu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The killing Want of yesterday 
Will it pester me even to day?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
And will it come today as yesterday,
The grief of want that eats my soul away?
Various Translators: Will the wretched poverty that nearly killed me yesterday come again today?
Dinamalar: Oh, how I dread it I Will that beggary that almost killed me yesterday assail me today also?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
One may sleep even in the midst of fire,
But by no means in the midst of poverty.
Transliteration: One may sleep in the midst of fire; but by no means in the midst of poverty.
T.Kannan:
One may sleep even in the midst of fire,
But by no means in the midst of poverty.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: One may snatch a nap amidst raging fire But can not sleep a wink in poverty dire.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Neruppinul Thunjalum Aakum
Nirappinul
Yaadhondrum Kanpaatu Aridhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
One may sleep in the midst of fire 
In want a wink of sleep is rare.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: One may sleep in the midst of scorching fire. But the poverty-stricken know no sleep.
Various Translators:
Amid the flames sleep may men's eyelids close,
In poverty the eye knows no repose.
Dinamalar: Men may slumber even in the midst of fire, but none can find repose in the midst of poverty.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The poverty stricken has a chance to renounce,
Lest he hang around for salt and gruel.
Transliteration: The destitute poor, who do not renounce their bodies, only consume their neighbour's salt and water.
T.Kannan:
The poverty stricken has a chance to
renounce, Lest he hang around for salt and gruel.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When want does not make one give up desire It spells doom for salt and sour gruel next door.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Thuppura Villaar Thuvarath
Thuravaamai
Uppirkum Kaatikkum Kootru
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The indigent that do not renounce the world batten on other man’s salt and porridge.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Renounce their lives the poor must 
Or salt and gruel go to waste.
Various Translators:
Unless the destitute will utterly themselves deny,
They cause their neighbour's salt and vinegar to die.
Dinamalar: Lacking a morsel of food, a man may either slay every desire or kill off his neighbor’s salt and rice broth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If you meet a man of means, by all means beg his help. If he refuses, the fault is his, not yours.
Transliteration: If you meet with those that may be begged of, you may beg; (but) if they withhold (their gift) it is their blame and not yours.
T.Kannan:
Beg if you meet men of means.
If they refuse, the fault is theirs, not yours.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Beg if you meet men of means. If they
refuse, the fault is theirs, not yours.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Seeks alms if you find those worthy of benefaction; If they refuse, blame is theirs and not yours.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Beg if you meet people who can give. If they refuse, it is their fault, not yours.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Irakka Iraththakkaark Kaanin
Karappin
Avarpazhi Thampazhi Andru
Various Translators:
Demand from those who can supply
Default is theirs when they deny.
Dinamalar:
When those you find from whom 'tis meet to ask, for aid apply;
Theirs is the sin, not yours, if they the gift deny.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even to ask an alms may pleasure give,
If what you ask without annoyance you receive.
Transliteration: Even begging can prove pleasurable when what is begged for comes with no sense of burden.
T.Kannan: Even begging may be pleasant, if what is begged for is obtained without grief (to him that begs).
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Begging is a pleasure if what is asked
Comes without pain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Begging would be pleasant to one if one were to achieve one’s object without causing pain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Begging is a pleasure if what is asked
Comes without pain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Seeking alms causes us great delight If what is sought is got without any plight.
Various Translators:
Inpam Oruvarku Iraththal Irandhavai
Thunpam Uraaa Varin
Dinamalar:
Even demand becomes a joy
When the things comes without annoy.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The men who nought deny, but know what's due , before their face
To stand as suppliants affords especial grace.
Transliteration: There is even a beauty in standing before and begging of those who are liberal in their gifts and understand their duty (to beggars).
T.Kannan: Begging has its own beauty when one supplicates before dutiful men whose hearts never say no.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
There is beauty even in begging
If it is before dutiful men with generous heart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: There is a grace even in begging of one noble and generous of heart.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
There is beauty even in begging If it is
before dutiful men with generous heart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: With ungrudging hearts, they view charity as a duty To stand before them and beg. there’s a beauty!
Various Translators:
Karappilaa Nenjin Katanarivaar
Munnindru
Irappumo Reer Utaiththu
Dinamalar:
Request has charm form open hearts 
Who know the duty on their part.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To beg of such as never think of withholding (their charity) even in their dreams, is in fact the same as giving (it oneself);
Transliteration:
Like giving even asking seems 
From those who hide not even in dreams.
T.Kannan:
Like giving alms, may even asking pleasant seem,
From men who of denial never even dream.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: There are men who never deny a request, even in their dreams. Begging from them is the same as giving.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Begging from men who do not refuse even in their dreams
Is as honorable as bestowing.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Begging is endowed with all the grace of giving when the noble guest does not fail of his gifts even in dreams.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Begging from men who do not refuse even in
their dreams Is as honorable as bestowing.
Various Translators: They know not withholding even in their dreams Same as giving it seems, asking them for alms.
Dinamalar:
Iraththalum Eedhale Polum Karaththal
Kanavilum Thetraadhaar Maattu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The needy demand for help because 
The world has men who don't refuse.
Transliteration:
Because on earth the men exist, who never say them nay,
Men bear to stand before their eyes for help to pray.
T.Kannan: Because men do exist on Earth who never begrudge giving, others dare to plead their needs before men’s gaze.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: There is beggary because of persons touched by its very presence.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Men stand expectant only because
The world has a few who won't refuse.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Men stand expectant only because The world
has a few who won't refuse.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: That the world has them who give and nothing conceal Is why others appear before them and for alms appeal.
Various Translators: As there are in the world those that give without refusing, there are (also) those that prefer to beg by simply standing before them.
Dinamalar:
Karappilaar Vaiyakaththu Unmaiyaal
Kannindru
Irappavar Merkol Vadhu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Karappitumpai Yillaaraik Kaanin
Nirappitumpai
Ellaam Orungu Ketum
Transliteration:
The pain of poverty shall die 
Before the free who don't deny.
T.Kannan:
If those you find from evil of 'denial' free,
At once all plague of poverty will flee.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The miseries of begging will flee at the mere sight of those who are free from refusal’s miserable manners.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: All the indignities of begging vanish in the presence of the truly generous who know not the sin of withholding gifts.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
All ills of begging will flee at the sight of those
Who are free from the ills of refusal.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: All the evil of begging will be removed at the sight of those who are far from the evil of refusing.
Various Translators:
All ills of begging will flee at the sight
of those Who are free from the ills of refusal.
Dinamalar: When we see those without the folly of concealing Gone are all the ills of having nothing.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Seeing givers who do not mock and deride The heart delights and rejoices deep inside.
Transliteration:
Ikazhndhellaadhu Eevaaraik Kaanin
Makizhndhullam
Ullul Uvappadhu Utaiththu
T.Kannan:
When givers without scorn impart 
A thrill of delight fills the heart.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Mendicancy inwardly rejoices in the bounty of the generous free of scorn.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If men are found who give and no harsh words of scorn employ,
The minds of askers, through and through, will thrill with joy.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A jubilant heart rejoices upon seeing those who give without scoffing or scorning.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The glad heart rejoices within
When it sees one who gives without scorn.
Various Translators: Beggars rejoice exceedingly when they behold those who bestow (their alms) with kindness and courtesy.
Dinamalar:
The glad heart rejoices within When it
sees one who gives without scorn.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Without beggars this vast scenic world
Would be a stage of puppets that come and go.
Transliteration: If there be no mendicants, this vast moist world Will resemble wooden puppets that come and go.
T.Kannan:
Irappaarai Illaayin Eernganmaa
Gnaalam
Marappaavai Sendruvan Thatru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Were there to be no mendicancy the vast world would be peopled with men moving like dolls.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
This grand cool world shall move to and fro 
Sans Askers like a puppet show.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If askers cease, the mighty earth, where cooling fountains flow,
Will be a stage where wooden puppets come and go.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Deprived of beggars, this vast and verdant Earth would become uncharitable, a ball for the play of wooden puppets.
Various Translators:
Without beggars this vast scenic world
Would be a stage of puppets that come and go.
Dinamalar: If there were no beggars, (the actions done in) the cool wide world would only resemble the movement of a puppet.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What fame can givers achieve If there is
none to beg and receive?
Transliteration: Ah, what is there to brag about those who give If there be none to seek and gladly receive.
T.Kannan: If there be no beggars in the world, will there be any glory for the bountiful?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Eevaarkan Ennuntaam Thotram
Irandhukol
Mevaar Ilaaak Katai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Where stands the glory of givers 
Without obligation seekers?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What glory will there be to men of generous soul.
When none are found to love the askers' role?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: What glory would generous men enjoy if there were none to beg for and receive their gifts?
Various Translators: What (praise) would there be to givers (of alms) if there were no beggars to ask for and reveive (them).
Dinamalar:
What fame can givers achieve
If there is none to beg and receive?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Do not chafe against the hunks for inevitable is the pain of poverty.
Transliteration:
The denied suppliant should not chafe. His
own want is proof enough.
T.Kannan: The denied mendicant should never feel indignant The pain of poverty is proof enough of its worth.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Irappaan Vekulaamai Ventum
Nirappitumpai
Thaaneyum Saalum Kari
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The needy should not scowl at "No" 
His need anothers' need must show.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Askers refused from wrath must stand aloof;
The plague of poverty itself is ample proof.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: One who begs and is refused should not be angry, for his own poverty is sufficient proof of giving’s limits.
Various Translators: He who begs ought not to be angry (at a refusal); for even the misery of (his own) poverty should be a sufficient reason (for so doing).
Dinamalar:
The denied suppliant should not chafe.
His own want is proof enough.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: A million times blessed is he who refrains from begging even from the generous delighting in charity.
Transliteration:
It is worth millions not to beg Even from
the precious ones who delight in giving.
T.Kannan: Not concealing, they give with joy, and are as dear as eyes; Yet, to resist asking even from them is worth crores.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Karavaadhu Uvandheeyum Kannannaar
Kannum
Iravaamai Koti Urum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Not to beg is billions worth 
E'en from eye like friends who give with mirth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Ten million fold 'tis greater gain, asking no alms to live,
Even from those, like eyes in worth, who nought concealing gladly give.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Not to beg (at all) even from those excellent persons who cheerfully give without refusing, will do immense good.
Various Translators: It is ten million times better not to beg, even from those precious men whose joy is giving and who thus never refuse.
Dinamalar:
It is worth millions not to beg
Even from the precious ones who delight in giving.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: May the creator of the world perish if he has ordained life only through mendicancy?
Transliteration:
If some must beg and live, let the Creator
of the world Himself roam and perish!
T.Kannan: Having to beg for survival, if anyone is destined, The Maker of this world be damned.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Irandhum Uyirvaazhdhal Ventin
Parandhu
Ketuka Ulakiyatri Yaan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If the Creator of the world has decreed even begging as a means of livelihood, may he too go abegging and perish.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let World Maker loiter and rot 
If "beg and live" be human fate.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If he that shaped the world desires that men should begging go,
Through life's long course. let him a wanderer be and perish so.
Various Translators: Were it the World Creator’s wish for men to live by begging, men might wish that He, too, die a wandering beggar.
Dinamalar:
If some must beg and live, let the Creator of the world
Himself roam and perish!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No greater folly than the hope that
Begging will rid the misery of poverty.
Transliteration:
No greater folly than the hope that
Begging will rid the misery of poverty.
T.Kannan: Nothing can be more brazen than Banking on charity to end deprivation.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: There is no greater folly than the boldness with which one seeks to remedy the evils of poverty by begging (rather than by working).
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Inmai Itumpai Irandhudheer Vaamennum
Vanmaiyin Vanpaatta Thil
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nothing is hard like hard saying 
"We end poverty by begging".
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Nothing is harder than the hardness that will say,
The plague of penury by asking alms we'll drive away.
Various Translators: There is no greater foolhardiness than to say, “I shall end the pains of poverty by begging.”
Dinamalar: There is no greater folly than the thought of wiping out poverty by beggary.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No place can hold the greatness of those
Who don’t beg even during troubled times.
Transliteration: Even the whole world cannot sufficiently praise the dignity that would not beg even in the midst of destitution.
T.Kannan:
No place can hold the greatness of those
Who don’t beg even during troubled times.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: No place is adequate to hold their nobility When, in direst straits, they seek no charity.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Itamellaam Kollaath Thakaiththe
Itamillaak
Kaalum Iravollaach Chaalpu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
All space is small before the great 
Who beg not e'en in want acute.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who ne'er consent to beg in utmost need, their worth
Has excellence of greatness that transcends the earth.
Various Translators: This entire world is too small to contain the dignity of men who will not stoop to beg, even in the direst destitution.
Dinamalar: The greatness of refusing to beg even in adversity transcends the glory of the world.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
There is nothing sweeter than even the watery gruel
Earned by one's own labour.
Transliteration: Even thin gruel is ambrosia to him who has obtained it by labour.
T.Kannan:
There is nothing sweeter than even the
watery gruel Earned by one's own labour.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Mere gruel made of clear water tastes sweetest When it is earned through earnest effort.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Thenneer Atupurkai Aayinum
Thaaldhandhadhu
Unnalin Oonginiya Thil
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though gruel thin, nothing is sweet
Like the food earned by labour's sweat.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Nothing is sweeter than the thin porridge earned by the sweat of one’s brow.
Various Translators:
Nothing is sweeter than to taste the toil won cheer,
Though mess of pottage as tastless as the water clear.
Dinamalar: Though it is only gruel, thin as water, nothing is more savory than food that is earned by the labor of one’s own hands.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
No greater disgrace for the tongue than to beg
Even if only water for a cow.
Transliteration: There is nothing more disgraceful to one's tongue than to use it in begging water even for a cow.
T.Kannan:
No greater disgrace for the tongue than to
beg Even if only water for a cow.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Nothing but begging shames the tongue more Even if what is sought is water for the cow.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Aavirku Neerendru Irappinum Naavirku
Iravin Ilivandha Thil
Ramachandra Dikshitar: It is a heinous sin to beg for water even for a cow crying of thirst.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
It may be water for the cow 
Begging tongue is mean anyhow.
Various Translators:
E'en if a draught of water for a cow you ask,
Nought's so distaseful to the tongue as beggar's task.
Dinamalar: The tongue finds nothing more distasteful than begging, even just to beg drinking water for a cow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: This I beg of all beggars: “If you must beg, beg not from misers.”
Transliteration: I beseech all beggars and say, "If you need to beg, never beg of those who give unwillingly."
T.Kannan:
This I beg of all beggars,
If beg you must, beg not from misers.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
This I beg of all beggars, 'If beg you
must, beg not from misers.'
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: I beg of all beggars: beg if you must, But beg not from those who conceal.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: I implore beggars not to beg of people who hide their wealth.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Irappan Irappaarai Ellaam Irappin
Karappaar Iravanmin Endru
Various Translators:
If beg they must I beg beggers 
Not to beg from shrinking misers.
Dinamalar:
One thing I beg of beggars all ,'If beg ye may,
Of those who hide their wealth , beg not , I pray.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The fragile bark of beggary
Wrecked on denial's rock will lie.
Transliteration: The unsturdy ship called begging will break apart the moment it crashes against the rock of refusal.
T.Kannan: The unsafe raft of begging will split when it strikes on the rock of refusal.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The hapless ship of begging will split
The moment it strikes the rock of refusal.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The unavailing canoe of begging gets wrecked on the rock of refusal.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The hapless ship of begging will split The
moment it strikes the rock of refusal.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The fragile boat of begging will be wrecked When it knocks against the rock of refusal.
Various Translators:
Iravennum Emaappil Thoni Karavennum
Paardhaakkap Pakku Vitum
Dinamalar:
The hapless bark of beggary splits 
On the rock of refusing hits.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The heart will melt away at thought of beggary;
With thought of stern repulse 'twill perish utterly.
Transliteration: To think of (the evil of) begging is enough to melt one's heart; but to think of refusal is enough to break it.
T.Kannan: Thoughts of a beggar’s plight melt the heart. Thoughts of refusals he receives crush it completely.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The heart melts at the thought of begging
And dies at the thought of denial.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The mere thought of begging melts one’s heart. It breaks at one’s denial.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The heart melts at the thought of begging
And dies at the thought of denial.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When I think of those who beg, my heart melts; When I think of those who refuse, it wilts.
Various Translators:
Iravulla Ullam Urukum Karavulla
Ulladhooum Indrik Ketum
Dinamalar:
The heart at thought of beggars melts; 
It dies at repulsing insults.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Saying "No" to a beggar takes away his life. (but as that very word will kill the refuser) where then would the latter's life hide itself ?
Transliteration:
The word "No" kills the begger's life 
Where can the niggard's life be safe?
T.Kannan:
E'en as he asks, the shamefaced asker dies;
Where shall his spirit hide who help denies?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Having said “no” to a beggar, knowing it might kill the poor man, where is a miser going to hide from his word?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Where will the niggard’s life seek refuge
When the beggar’s life is taken by refusal?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A rebuff takes the life out of the beggar. But can the deceitful escape death?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Where will the niggard’s life seek refuge
When the beggar’s life is taken by refusal?
Various Translators: When one asks but is denied, his life departs; Where will he hide, the one who denies.
Dinamalar:
Karappavarkku Yaangolikkum Kollo
Irappavar
Sollaatap Poom Uyir

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The mean seem men only in form 
We have never seen such a sham.
Transliteration:
The base resemble men in outward form, I ween;
But counterpart exact to them i've never seen.
T.Kannan: Outwardly, vile men resemble human beings. We have never witnessed such a remarkable likeness.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Ignoble men are only touched with human shapes. Rare indeed are such specimens.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The wicked look utterly like men!
Such close mimics we have never seen!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The wicked look utterly like men! Such
close mimics we have never seen!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: By all appearances, the vile look so human; Such resemblance, I’ve nowhere seen.
Various Translators: The base resemble men perfectly (as regards form); and we have not seen such (exact) resemblance (among any other species).
Dinamalar:
Makkale Polvar Kayavar Avaranna
Oppaari Yaanganta Thil

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nandrari Vaarir Kayavar
Thiruvutaiyar
Nenjaththu Avalam Ilar
Transliteration:
The base seem richer than the good 
For no care enters their heart or head.
T.Kannan:
Than those of greatful heart the base must luckier be,
Their minds from every anxious thought are free!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The low minded are happier than men who know goodness, for they are never troubled by the pangs of conscience.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Blessed are the base who are ignorant of the good. Verily they are never ill at ease.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
More blessed than the good are the base,
For they have no scruples.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The low enjoy more felicity than those who know what is good; for the former are not troubled with anxiety (as to the good).
Various Translators:
More blessed than the good are the base,
For they have no scruples.
Dinamalar: More gifted than those who know the right course Are the vile: their hearts have no remorse.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those who are base are like Devas They are free to do as they please.
Transliteration:
Thevar Anaiyar Kayavar Avarundhaam
Mevana Seydhozhuka Laan
T.Kannan:
The base are like gods; for they too 
As prompted by their desire do.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Mean men resemble unruly gods, for they know no law.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The base are as the gods; they too
Do ever what they list to do!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Wicked rogues resemble the Gods, for they, too, live doing whatever they want.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The base are like the gods.
They also do whatever they like.
Various Translators: The base resemble the Gods; for the base ac t as they like.
Dinamalar:
The base are like the gods. They also do
whatever they like.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The base are proud when they find men
Meaner than themselves.
Transliteration: When they meet brutish people unfettered by scruples The lowest of the low take pride in surpassing them.
T.Kannan:
Akappatti Aavaaraik Kaanin Avarin
Mikappattuch Chemmaakkum Keezh
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The mean fought their superiority among men baser than them.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
When the base meets a rake so vile 
Him he will exceed, exult and smile.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When base men those behold of conduct vile,
They straight surpass them and exulting smile,
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When a vile man meets a wicked one, he will outdo him in his vices and pride himself on the achievement.
Various Translators:
The base are proud when they find men
Meaner than themselves.
Dinamalar: The base feels proud when he sees persons whose acts meaner than his own.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Fear is the base man's only code;
Sometimes, greed a little.
Transliteration: The conformity of the vile is forced by fear And perhaps, a wee bit by desire.
T.Kannan:
Achchame Keezhkaladhu Aasaaram
Echcham
Avaavuntel Untaam Siridhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Fear and desire rule the conduct of the base.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Fear forms the conduct of the low 
Craving avails a bit below.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Fear is the base man's virtue; if that fail,
Intense desire some little may avail.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Fear is the primary force motivating base men. Besides that, the desire for gain may motivate them—a little.
Various Translators: (The principle of) behaviour in the mean is chiefly fear; if not, hope of gain, to some extent.
Dinamalar:
Fear is the base man's only code;
Sometimes, greed a little.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The base are like the drum for they noise abroad the secrets of men.
Transliteration:
The base are like drum, for they sound off
to others Every secret they hear.
T.Kannan: Like the broadcasting drum are the vile, Revealing everything confidential.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Araiparai Annar Kayavardhaam Ketta
Maraipirarkku Uyththuraikka Laan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The base are like the beaten drum 
Since other's secrets they proclaim.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The base are like the beaten drum; for when they hear,
The sound the secret out in every neighbour's ear.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Base men are like a bass drum, sounding off to others every secret they happen to hear.
Various Translators: The base are like a drum that is beaten, for they unburden to others the secrets they have heard.
Dinamalar:
The base are like drum, for they sound off to others
Every secret they hear.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The base part with their crumbs only to a clenched hand.
Transliteration:
The base won’t even shake their wet hands
Unless their jaws are shaken with clenched fists.
T.Kannan: The vile will not even wiggle their smeared dining fingers Unless their cheeks are cracked by a clenched fist.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Eerngai Vidhiraar Kayavar
Kotirutaikkum
Koonkaiyar Allaa Thavarkku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The base their damp hand will not shake 
But for fists clenched their jaws to break.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From off their moistened hands no clinging grain they shake,
Unless to those with clenched fist their jaws who break.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The mean will not (even) shake off (what sticks to) their hands (soon after a meal) to any but those who would break their jaws with their clenched fists.
Various Translators: Some men are too crude to even shake the water off their just washed hands, except for those who could break their jaw with a fist.
Dinamalar:
The base won’t even shake their wet hands
Unless their jaws are shaken with clenched fists.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Even the least cry of distress touches the heart of the good; but squeezing goodness out of the vile is like crushing the sugar-cane.
Transliteration:
A word will move the noble; While the
base, like sugarcane, must be crushed.
T.Kannan: A word is enough to move the noble to help; Crushed like a sugarcane, the vile maybe of some use.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sollap Payanpatuvar Saandror
Karumpupol
Kollap Payanpatum Keezh
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The great bestow (their alms) as soon as they are informed; (but) the mean, like the sugar-cane, only when they are tortured to death.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The good by soft words profits yield 
The cane like base when crushed and killed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The good to those will profit yield fair words who use;
The base, like sugar cane, will profit those who bruise.
Various Translators: Worthy men yield their gifts when told of a need, but like sugarcane, base men give only when crushed and squeezed.
Dinamalar:
A word will move the noble;
While the base, like sugarcane, must be crushed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The base excel in finding faults of others
When they see them well clothed and fed.
Transliteration:
The base excel in finding faults of others
When they see them well clothed and fed.
T.Kannan: When they see others well fed and well dressed The vile are adept at getting their flaws exposed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Utuppadhooum Unpadhooum Kaanin
Pirarmel
Vatukkaana Vatraakum Keezh
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The base will bring an evil (accusation) against others, as soon as he sees them (enjoying) good food and clothing.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Faults in others the mean will guess 
On seeing how they eat and dress.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If neighbours clothed and fed he see, the base
Is mighty man some hidden fault to trace?
Various Translators: Let a base man behold others dressing and dining well, and instantly their faults are all that he can see.
Dinamalar: The base envy others in their food and clothing and slander them.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What use are the base in a crisis,
Save to rush and sell themselves?
Transliteration: The base will hasten to sell themselves as soon as a calamity has befallen them. For what else are they fitted ?
T.Kannan:
What use are the base in a crisis, Save to
rush and sell themselves?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When in trouble, themselves, the vile swiftly sell. What else do they have as a skill?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Etrir Kuriyar Kayavarondru Utrakkaal
Vitrarku Uriyar Viraindhu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The base hasten to sell themselves 
From doom to flit and nothing else.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
For what is base man fit, if griefs assail?
Himself to offer, there and then, for sale!
Various Translators: Is there anything for which lowly men are suited? Well, when crises come, they are the first to offer themselves for sale!
Dinamalar: What are the base men fit for? They hasten only to sell themselves in adversity.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A goddess, a rare peahen or a woman
Decked with jewels? My heart is amazed!
Transliteration: Is this jewelled female a celestial, a choice peahen, or a human being ? My mind is perplexed.
T.Kannan:
A goddess, a rare peahen or a woman Decked
with jewels?' My heart is amazed!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Anangukol Aaimayil Kollo Kananguzhai
Maadharkol MaalumEn Nenju
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Is it an angel? A fair peacock 
Or jewelled belle? To my mind a shock!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Is this a goddess fair? Or is it a rare peacock? Or, is it a mortal with heavy ear-rings? My mind is perplexed in the extreme.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Goddess? or peafowl rare?
 She whose ears rich jewels wear,Is she a maid of human kind? All wildered is my mind!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
She returns my look with looks that strike
Like darts of an armed angel.
Transliteration: This female beauty returning my looks is like a celestial maiden coming with an army to contend against me.
T.Kannan:
She returns my look with looks that strike
Like darts of an armed angel.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nokkinaal Nokkedhir Nokkudhal
Thaakkanangu
Thaanaikkon Tanna Thutaiththu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The glance she returns for mine resembles that of a terrible goddess leading an army.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The counter glances of this belle 
Are armied dart of the Love Angel.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
She of the beaming eyes, 
To my rash look her glance replies,As if the matchless goddess' hand Led forth and armed band.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: I never knew before what is called Yama; I see it now; it is the eyes that carry on a great fight with (the help of) female qualities.
Transliteration:
I never knew yama before, but now I realize
That it is feminine and has warring eyes.
T.Kannan:
I never knew yama before, but now I
realize That it is feminine and has warring eyes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pantariyen Kootren Padhanai
Iniyarindhen
Pentakaiyaal Peramark Kattu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The god of death I never knew. Now I behold him in the shape of this woman with battling eyes.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Not known before I spy Demise 
In woman's guise with battling eyes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Death's form I formerly 
Knew not; but now 'tis plain to me;He comes in lovely maiden's guise, With soul subduing eyes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
In sweet simplicity, 
A woman's gracious form hath she; But yet those eyes, that drink my life, Are with the form at strife!
Transliteration: These eyes that seem to kill those who look at them are as it were in hostilities with this feminine simplicity.
T.Kannan:
She may have that feminine grace
But her look sucks life out of men who gaze.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The cruel eyes of this woman seem to devour the lives of those on whom they fall.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
She may have that feminine grace But her
look sucks life out of men who gaze.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Kantaar Uyirunnum Thotraththaal
Pentakaip
Pedhaikku Amarththana Kan
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
This artless dame has darting eyes 
That drink the life of men who gaze.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The light that on me gleams,
Is it death's dart? or eyes' bright beams?Or fawn's shy glance? All three appear In form of maiden here.
Transliteration: Is it Yama, (a pair of) eyes or a hind ?- Are not all these three in the looks of this maid ?
T.Kannan:
Is it death's dart, or eye's beams, or fawn's glance?
Her look has all these three.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Oh, how the death-dealing antelope-eyes of the lady charm and puzzle me!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Is it death's dart, or eye's beams, or
fawn's glance? Her look has all these three.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Kootramo Kanno Pinaiyo Matavaral
Nokkamim Moondrum Utaiththu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Is it death, eye or doe? All three 
In winsome woman's look I see.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Her eyes will cause (me) no trembling sorrow, if they are properly hidden by her cruel arched eye-brows.
Transliteration:
If cruel brows unbent, would screen 
Her eyes won't cause me trembling pain.
T.Kannan:
If cruel eye brow's bow.
 Unbent, would veil those glances now; The shafts that wound this trembling heart Her eyes no more would dart.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
It’s only when her callous eyebrows bend and veil her eyes
That my heart’s flutters cease.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Her cruel eyes, had they not been shaded by her brows, would have made me quail and shudder.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
It’s only when her callous eyebrows bend
and veil her eyes That my heart’s flutters cease.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kotumpuruvam Kotaa Maraippin
Natungagnar
Seyyala Manival Kan

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Vest on the buxom breast of her 
Looks like rutting tusker's eye cover.
Transliteration:
As veil O'er angry eyes
Of raging elephant that lies, The silken cincture's folds invest This maiden's panting breast.
T.Kannan: The garment over the ample swell of her bosom is like the cloth on the face of a wild elephant.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Like the veil over the face of a rutting elephant
Is the vest that veils her buxom breasts.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Like the veil over the face of a rutting
elephant Is the vest that veils her buxom breasts.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Kataaak Kalitrinmer Katpataam
Maadhar
Pataaa Mulaimel Thukil
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The cloth that covers the firm bosom of this maiden is (like) that which covers the eyes of a rutting elephant.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Onnudhar Koo Utaindhadhe Gnaatpinul
Nannaarum Utkumen Peetu
Transliteration:
Ah these fair brows shatter my might 
Feared by foemen yet to meet.
T.Kannan:
Ah! woe is me! my might, 
That awed my foemen in the fight,By lustre of that beaming brow Borne down,lies broken now!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: My might which has struck terror in the heart of the foe who has only heard of my prowess lies overthrown before her splendid face.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ah, there goes all my might which foes dread in fight,
When I face her brows beaming bright!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: On her bright brow alone is destroyed even th at power of mine that used to terrify the most fearless foes in the battlefield.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ah, there goes all my might which foes
dread in fight, When I face her brows beaming bright!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Pinaiyer Matanokkum Naanum
Utaiyaatku
Aniyevano Edhila Thandhu
Transliteration:
Which jewel can add to her beauty 
With fawn like looks and modesty?
T.Kannan: What need of ornament has this lady of modesty, adorned with the glances of an antelope?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Like tender fawn's her eye;
 Clothed is she with modesty;What added beauty can be lent; By alien ornament?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What use are jewels to a damsel
Adorned with modesty and meek looks of a hind?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Of what use are other jewels to her who is adorned with modesty, and the meek looks of a hind ?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What use are jewels to a damsel Adorned
with modesty and meek looks of a hind?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Wine delights only when imbibed, But never
at mere look like love!
Transliteration:
Untaarkan Alladhu Atunaraak
Kaamampol
Kantaar Makizhseydhal Indru
T.Kannan: Wine intoxicates the person when only drunk but love inebriates the soul even by a mere look.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To the drunk alone is wine delight 
Nothing delights like love at sight.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The palm tree's fragrant wine, 
To those who is taste yields joys divine;But love hath rare felicity For those that only see!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Wine delights only when imbibed,
But never at mere look like love!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Unlike boiled honey which yields delight only when it is drunk, love gives pleasure even when looked at.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Her painted eyes have a double effect: One
glance brings pain and the other cures.
Transliteration:
Irunokku Ivalunkan Ulladhu Orunokku
Noinokkon Rannoi Marundhu
T.Kannan: The glances of her collirium-painted eyes have a double sway. One wounds and the other heals.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Her painted eyes, two glances dart 
One hurts; the other heals my heart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A double witchery have glances of her liquid eye;
One glance is glance that brings me pain; the other heals again.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: There are two looks in the dyed eyes of this (fair one); one causes pain, and the other is the cure thereof.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Her painted eyes have a double effect:
One glance brings pain and the other cures.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: More telling than her actual embrace are her stealthy love looks.
Transliteration:
A single sneaky glance of her eyes Is more
than half the pleasure of love.
T.Kannan:
Kankalavu Kollum Sirunokkam
Kaamaththil
Sempaakam Andru Peridhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Her furtive lightning glance is more 
Than enjoyment of sexual lore.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The furtive glance, that gleams one instant bright,
Is more than half of love's supreme delight.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A single stolen glance of her eyes is more than half the pleasure (of sexual embrace).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A single sneaky glance of her eyes
Is more than half the pleasure of love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: She gazed and gazed but she became shy and her bashful look has nurtured the plant of love between us.
Transliteration:
She looked, and dropped her head, And so
watered the plant of love.
T.Kannan:
Nokkinaal Nokki Irainjinaal Aqdhaval
Yaappinul Attiya Neer
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
She looked; looking bowed her head 
And love plant was with water fed.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
She looked, and looking drooped her head;
On springing shoot of love 'its water shed!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: She has looked (at men) and stooped (her head); and that (sign) waters as it were (the corn of) our love.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
She looked, and dropped her head,
And so watered the plant of love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: She casts her shy look on earth when I gaze at her; but if I turn aside, she glances at me with a gentle smile.
Transliteration:
When I look, she looks to the ground. When
I don't, she looks and gently smiles!
T.Kannan:
Yaannokkum Kaalai Nilannokkum
Nokkaakkaal
Thaannokki Mella Nakum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When I look, she looks down; when I do not, she looks and smiles gently.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
I look; she droops to earth awhile 
I turn; she looks with gentle smile.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
I look on her; her eyes are on the ground the while;
I look away; she looks on me with timid smile.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When I look, she looks to the ground.
When I don't, she looks and gently smiles!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Without looking straight,
She passes a slanting glance and smiles.
Transliteration:
Without looking straight, She passes a
slanting glance and smiles.
T.Kannan:
Kurikkontu Nokkaamai Allaal Orukan
Sirakkaniththaal Pola Nakum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: She not only avoids a direct look at me, but looks as it were with a half-closed eye and smiles.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
No direct gaze; a side long glance 
She darts at me and smiles askance.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
She seemed to see me not; but yet the maid
Her love, by smiling side long glance, betrayed.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Without looking straight at me, with furtive glances she smiles inwardly.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
They may speak like strangers, but the words
Will soon reveal their intimacy.
Transliteration: Though they may speak harshly as if they were strangers, the words of the friendly are soon understood.
T.Kannan:
They may speak like strangers, but the
words Will soon reveal their intimacy.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Uraaa Thavarpol Solinum Seraaarsol
Ollai Unarap Patum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Their words at first seem an offence
But quick we feel them friendly ones.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though with their lips affection they disown,
Yet, when they hate us not, 'tis quickly known.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though her words are as harsh as those of a stranger, they betoken only love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Words that look unfriendly and looks that look offending
Are signs of love in disguise.
Transliteration: Little words that are harsh and looks that are hateful are (but) the expressions of lovers who wish to act like strangers.
T.Kannan:
Words that look unfriendly and looks that
look offending Are signs of love in disguise.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seraaach Chirusollum Setraarpol
Nokkum
Uraaarpondru Utraar Kurippu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Harsh little words; offended looks, 
Are feigned consenting love lorn tricks.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The pretended angry look and the bitter-sweet word of the beloved are like those of a stranger. Surely these are but the masks of her love.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The slighting words that anger feign, while eyes their
 love reveal,Are signs of those that love, but would their love conceal.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Her gentle smile to my pleading look
Adds beauty to her gentle nature.
Transliteration: When I look, the pitying maid looks in return and smiles gently; and that is a comforting sign for me.
T.Kannan:
Her gentle smile to my pleading look Adds
beauty to her gentle nature.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Asaiyiyarku Untaantor Eeryaan Nokkap
Pasaiyinal Paiya Nakum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: When I look beseechingly at her she returns a gentle smile. Oh, what bewitching charm fills the tender maid’s look!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What a grace the slim maid has! 
As I look she slightly smiles.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
I gaze, the tender maid relents the while;
And, oh the matchless grace of the soft smile!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Both the lovers are capable of looking at each other in an ordinary way, as if they were perfect strangers.
Transliteration:
To look at each other as if they were strangers
Belongs to lovers alone.
T.Kannan:
To look at each other as if they were
strangers Belongs to lovers alone.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Edhilaar Polap Podhunokku Nokkudhal
Kaadhalaar Kanne Ula
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Oh, what an indifferent air do the lovers assume! They look at each other as if they were strangers.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Between lovers we do discern 
A stranger's look of unconcern.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The look indifferent, that would its love disguise,
Is only read aright by lovers' eyes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When eye to answering eye reveals the tale of love,
All words that lips can say must useless prove.
Transliteration: The words of the mouths are of no use whatever, when there is perfect agreement between the eyes (of lovers).
T.Kannan:
When eyes with eyes commingle,
What do words avail?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Of what avail are words when eyes speak to eyes and heart whispers unto heart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
When eyes with eyes commingle, What do
words avail?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Kannotu Kaninai Nokkokkin
Vaaichchorkal
Enna Payanum Ila
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The words of mouth are of no use 
When eye to eye agrees the gaze.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The (simultaneous) enjoyment of the five senses of sight, hearing, taste, smell and touch can only be found with bright braceleted (women).
Transliteration:
All joys that senses five sight, hearing, taste,smell ,touch can give,
In this resplendent armlets bearing damsel live!
T.Kannan:
In her alone, my jewel, can I find the five senses of
Sight, smell, hearing, taste and touch.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: All the pleasures that the five senses give us are garnered in this lady with glittering bracelets. What a thrill she gives me!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
In her alone, my jewel, can I find the
five senses of Sight, smell, hearing, taste and touch.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Kantukettu Untuyirththu Utrariyum
Aimpulanum
Ondhoti Kanne Ula
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
In this bangled beauty dwell 
The joys of sight sound touch taste smell.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The remedy for a disease is always something different (from it); but for the disease caused by this jewelled maid, she is herself the cure.
Transliteration:
The cure for ailment is somewhere 
For fair maid's ill she is the cure.
T.Kannan:
Disease and medicine antagonists we surley see;
This maid, to pain she gives, herself is remedy.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The cure for a disease is always different.
But this jewel is both disease and cure.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The remedy for a disease lies not in the disease but in some healing balm; but not so the loved one who is at once the disease and the cure for the pangs of love.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The cure for a disease is always
different. But this jewel is both disease and cure.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Pinikku Marundhu Piraman Aniyizhai
Thannoikkuth Thaane Marundhu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Is lotus eyed lord's heaven so sweet 
As sleep in lover's arms so soft?
Transliteration:
Than rest in her soft arms to whom the soul is giv'n,
Is any sweeter joy in his, the Lotus eyed one's heaven?
T.Kannan: Are the pleasures of the world of the lotus-eyed lord sweeter than reclining on the soft shoulder of the beloved?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Is heaven sweeter than slumbering
On the soft shoulders of the women you love?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Is heaven sweeter than slumbering On the
soft shoulders of the women you love?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Thaamveezhvaar Mendrol Thuyilin
Inidhukol
Thaamaraik Kannaan Ulaku
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Can the lotus-eyed Vishnu's heaven be indeed as sweet to those who delight to sleep in the delicate arms of their beloved ?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Neengin Theruvum Kurukungaal
Thannennum
Theeyaantup Petraal Ival?
Transliteration:
Away it burns and cools anear 
Wherefrom did she get this fire?
T.Kannan:
Withdraw, it burns; approach, it soothes the pain;
Whence did the maid this wonderous fire obtain?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: This lady has a fire which burns me with passion when I am away; but it cools down when I see her. Can anyone say where she has acquired this power?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Whence did she get the fire
Which burns when far, and cools when near?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: From whence has she got this fire that burns when I withdraw and cools when I approach ?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Whence did she get the fire Which burns
when far, and cools when near?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Vetta Pozhudhin Avaiyavai Polume
Thottaar Kadhuppinaal Thol
Transliteration:
The arms of my flower tressed maid 
Whatever I wish that that accord.
T.Kannan: Like the dreams of pleasures sought, the embrace of this sweet-shouldered, flower-decked maiden gives me untold pleasure.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
In her embrace, whose locks with flowery wreaths are bound,
Each varied form of joy the soul can wish is found.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Her flower-decked shoulders
Give me whatever I need, then and there.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The shoulders of her whose locks are adorned with flowers delight me as if they were the very sweets I have desired (to get).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Her flower-decked shoulders Give me
whatever I need, then and there.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Her shoulders must verily be nectar For
they refresh my life whenever I touch.
Transliteration:
Urudhoru Uyirdhalirppath Theentalaal
Pedhaikku
Amizhdhin Iyandrana Thol
T.Kannan: Her embrace ever kindles new warm life in me. Verily her shoulders are packed with ambrosia.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
My simple maid has nectar arms 
Each embrace brings life thrilling charms.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ambrosia are the simple maiden's arms; when I attain
Their touch, my withered life puts forth its buds again!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Her shoulders must verily be nectar
For they refresh my life whenever I touch.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The shoulders of this fair one are made of ambrosia, for they revive me with pleasure every time I embrace them.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Like sharing one’s food at one’s own home
Is the embrace of this fair maid.
Transliteration:
Thammil Irundhu Thamadhupaaththu
Untatraal
Ammaa Arivai Muyakku
T.Kannan: The embrace of my golden-coloured love reminds me of the joy of a householder who delights in fulfilling the laws of hospitality.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ah the embrace of this fair dame 
Is like sharing one's food at home.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
As when one eats from household store, with kindly grace
Sharing his meal; such is this golden maid's embrace.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The embraces of a gold-complexioned beautiful female are as pleasant as to dwell in one's own house and live by one's own (earnings) after distributing (a portion of it in charity).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Like sharing one’s food at one’s own home
Is the embrace of this fair maid.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Sweet indeed to both the lover and his beloved is that close embrace which allows not even a wisp of air to steal in between their arms.
Transliteration:
Sweet indeed is that embrace Wherein not a
breath comes between.
T.Kannan:
Veezhum Iruvarkku Inidhe Valiyitai
Pozhap Pataaa Muyakku
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Joy is the fast embrace that doth 
Not admit e'en air between both.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Sweet is the strict embrace of those whom fond affection binds,
Where no dissevering breath of discord entrance finds.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To ardent lovers sweet is the embrace that cannot be penetrated even by a breath of breeze.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Sweet indeed is that embrace
Wherein not a breath comes between.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Separation, reconciliation and reunion are the pleasures vouchsafed to those stricken with love.
Transliteration:
To fall out, make up, and unite again are
the gains Reaped by those obsessed with love.
T.Kannan:
Ootal Unardhal Punardhal Ivaikaamam
Kootiyaar Petra Payan
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sulking, feeling and clasping fast 
These three are sweets of lover's tryst.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Love quarrel, reconciliation and intercourse - these are the advantages reaped by those who marry for lust.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The jealous variance, the healing of the strife, reunion gained;
These are the fruits from wedded love obtained.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To fall out, make up, and unite again are the gains
Reaped by those obsessed with love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The more I taste the charms of my beloved the more do d hunger for them. Verily what is already experienced pales into insignificance before the promise of the future.
Transliteration:
The more you indulge, the more you realize
your ignorance. Be it love or learning.
T.Kannan:
Aridhoru Ariyaamai Kantatraal Kaamam
Seridhorum Seyizhai Maattu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: As (one's) ignorance is discovered the more one learns, so does repeated intercourse with a well-adorned female (only create a desire for more).
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
As knowledge reveals past ignorance
So is the belle as love gets close.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The more men learn the more their lack of learning they detect;
'Tis so when I approach the maid with gleaming jewels decked.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The more you indulge, the more you realize your ignorance.
Be it love or learning.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Hail thee, aniccham, the soft flower!
The damsel I dote is softer than thee!
Transliteration:
Hail thee, aniccham, the soft flower! The
damsel I dote is softer than thee!
T.Kannan:
Nanneerai Vaazhi Anichchame Ninninum
Menneeral Yaamveezh Paval
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: May you flourish, O Anicham! you have a delicate nature. But my beloved is more delicate than you.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Soft blessed anicha flower, hail 
On whom I dote is softer still.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
O flower of the sensitive plant ! than thee
More tender's the maiden beloved by me.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: O aniccam flower, the best and softest of all flowers, may you be blest; but do not forget that my lady is yet more tender.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
O heart, why get distracted seeing common flowers
And match them with her eyes!
Transliteration: O my soul, fancying that flowers which are seen by many can resemble her eyes, you become confused at the sight of them.
T.Kannan:
O heart, why get distracted seeing common
flowers And match them with her eyes!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Malarkaanin Maiyaaththi Nenje
Ivalkan
Palarkaanum Poovokkum Endru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
You can't liken flowers by many eyed, 
To her bright eyes, O mind dismayed.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
You deemed, as you saw the flowers, her eyes were as flowers my soul,
That many may see; it was surely some folly that over you stole!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: O Mind, when you behold flowers you think that your beloved’s eyes are like these and pine away.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
She has a slender frame, pearly smile, fragrant breath,
Lancet eyes and bamboo shoulders.
Transliteration: The complexion of this bamboo-shouldered one is that of a shoot; her teeth, are pearls; her breath, fragrance; and her dyed eyes, lances.
T.Kannan:
She has a slender frame, pearly smile,
fragrant breath, Lancet eyes and bamboo shoulders.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Murimeni Muththam Muruval
Verinaatram
Velunkan Veyththo Lavatku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The bamboo shouldered has pearl like smiles 
Fragrant breath and lance like eyes.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Her body is of rich gold, her teeth pearls. She is fragrant, her eyes dart forth glances like a lance, her shoulders gently curve as the bamboo. O! what a varied charm my beloved has!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As tender shoot her fame; teeth, pearls; around her odours blend;
Darts are the eyes of her whose shoulders like the bambu bend.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Unable to match the eyes of this jewel,
Lilies droop down earthwards in shame.
Transliteration: If the blue lotus could see, it would stoop and look at the ground saying, "I can never resemble the eyes of this excellent jewelled one."
T.Kannan:
Unable to match the eyes of this jewel,
Lilies droop down earthwards in shame.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaanin Kuvalai Kavizhndhu
Nilannokkum
Maanizhai Kannovvem Endru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The kundalai flower hangs down in shame before the eyes of my tastefully adorned lady-love.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Lily droops down to ground and says 
I can't equal the jewelled one's eyes.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The lotus, seeing her, with head demiss, the ground would eye,
And say, 'With eyes of her, rich gems who wears, we cannot vie.'

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: No merry drums will be beaten for the (tender) waist of her who has adorned herself with the anicham without having removed its stem.
Transliteration:
The solemn drums will blare if her waist is crushed
By the aniccham she wore with its stalk.
T.Kannan:
The solemn drums will blare if her waist
is crushed By the aniccham she wore with its stalk.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Anichchappook Kaalkalaiyaal Peydhaal
Nukappirku
Nalla Pataaa Parai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: She decks herself with aniccam flowers without removing the stalks. It is the death-knell of her slender waist.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Anicha flower with stem she wears
To her breaking waist sad drum blares!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The flowers of the sensitive plant as a girdle around her she placed;
The stems she forgot to nip off; they 'll weigh down the delicate waist.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The stars perplexed are rushing widly from their spheres;
For like another moon this maiden's face appears.
Transliteration: The stars have become confused in their places not being able to distinguish between the moon and the maid's countenance.
T.Kannan:
The perplexed stars are all over the place,
Unable to tell the moon from her face.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even the stars of heaven veer their usual courses mistaking my lady’s face for their queen moon.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The perplexed stars are all over the
place, Unable to tell the moon from her face.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Madhiyum Matandhai Mukanum Ariyaa
Padhiyin Kalangiya Meen
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Stars are confused to know which is 
The moon and which is woman's face.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Could there be spots in the face of this maid like those in the bright full moon ?
Transliteration:
In moon, that waxing waning shines, as spots appear,
Are any spots discerned in face of maiden here?
T.Kannan:
Are there spots on my love’s face
Like the spots on the shining moon?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Is there a dark spot on the face of my lady-love as on the shining moon which waxes and wanes?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Are there spots on my love’s face Like the
spots on the shining moon?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Aruvaai Niraindha Avirmadhikkup Pola
Maruvunto Maadhar Mukaththu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Are there spots on the lady's face 
Just as in moon that changes phase?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If you can indeed shine like the face of women, flourish, O moon, for then would you be worth loving ?
Transliteration:
Like my lady's face if you shine 
All my love to you; hail O moon!
T.Kannan:
Farewell, O moon! If that thine orb could shine
Bright as her face, thou shouldst be love of mine.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Hail O moon! If you could also shine as my love’s face,
You too I shall love.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Blest indeed are you. Moon! If you will be resplendent without a spot even as the face of my lady, I shall love you with all my heart.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Hail O moon! If you could also shine as my
love’s face, You too I shall love.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Maadhar Mukampol Olivita Vallaiyel
Kaadhalai Vaazhi Madhi

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Like the face of my flower eyed one 
If you look, then shine alone O moon!
Transliteration:
If as her face, whose eyes are flowers, thou wouldst have charms for me,
Shine for my eyes alone, O moon, shine not for all to see!
T.Kannan: Moon, if you wish to equal the face of my lady then hide yourself from this world.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
O moon, if you imitate my flower-eyed jewel’s face,
Stop revealing thyself to all.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
O moon, if you imitate my flower-eyed
jewel’s face, Stop revealing thyself to all.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Malaranna Kannaal Mukamoththi Yaayin
Palarkaanath Thondral Madhi
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: O moon, if you wish to resemble the face of her whose eyes are like (these) flowers, do not appear so as to be seen by all.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Anichchamum Annaththin Thooviyum
Maadhar
Atikku Nerunjip Pazham
Transliteration:
The soft flower and the swan's down are
Like nettles to the feet of the fair.
T.Kannan:
The flower of the sensitive plant, and the down of the swan's white breast,
As the thorn are harsh, by the delicate feet of this maiden pressed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The soft aniccam flower and the down of the swan are but thistles before the soft feet of my lady.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Even aniccham flower and swan's down
Are as nerunji fruit to my maidens’ feet.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The anicham and the feathers of the swan are to the feet of females, like the fruit of the (thorny) Nerunji.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Even aniccham flower and swan's down Are
as nerunji fruit to my maidens’ feet.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Paalotu Thenkalan Thatre Panimozhi
Vaaleyiru Ooriya Neer
Transliteration:
Like milk and honey the dew is sweet 
From her white teeth whose word is soft.
T.Kannan: The kiss of the tender lips of my modest maid is like the taste of honey with milk.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The dew on her white teeth, whose voice is soft and low,
Is as when milk and honey mingled flow.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Like a mixture of milk and honey,
Is the drool that drips through her pearly teeth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The water which oozes from the white teeth of this soft speeched damsel is like a mixture of milk and honey.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Like a mixture of milk and honey, Is the
drool that drips through her pearly teeth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The bond between me and this damsel Is
like the union of body and soul.
Transliteration:
Utampotu Uyiritai Ennamar Ranna
Matandhaiyotu Emmitai Natpu
T.Kannan: The love that has sprung up between me and my beloved is constant, even as body and soul are inseparable.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Love between me and this lady 
Is like bond between soul and body.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Between this maid and me the friendship kind
Is as the bonds that soul and body bind.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The bond between me and this damsel
Is like the union of body and soul.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The love between me and this damsel is like the union of body and soul.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
O pupil of my eye! Be gone, For there is
no place for the maiden I love.
Transliteration:
Karumaniyir Paavaainee Podhaayaam
Veezhum
Thirunudharku Illai Itam
T.Kannan: O Image in the pupil of my eye, begone! How can my fair-browed lady sit enthroned, unless you give place to her?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Depart image in my pupil 
Giving room to my fair browed belle!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
For her with beauteous brow, the maid I love, there place is none;
To give her image room, O pupil of mine eye, begone!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: O you image in the pupil (of my eye)! depart; there is no room for (my) fair-browed beloved.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
O pupil of my eye! Be gone,
For there is no place for the maiden I love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Embracing the arms of my choicely adorned lady I feel all the thrill and joy of life, but the moment I separate, I feel the wretchedness of death.
Transliteration:
Life is lively when she is around, But
dreadful when she leaves.
T.Kannan:
Vaazhdhal Uyirkkannal Aayizhai
Saadhal
Adharkannal Neengum Itaththu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Life with my jewel is existence 
Death it is her severance.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Life is she to my very soul when she draws nigh;
Dissevered from the maid with jewels rare, I die!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: My fair-jewelled one resembles the living soul (when she is in union with me), the dying soul when she leaves me.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Life is lively when she is around,
But dreadful when she leaves.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: I cannot forget the noble quality of my love of the sparkling eyes.
Transliteration:
Recollection is needed if only I forget.
How can I forget her dazzling warring eyes!
T.Kannan:
Ulluvan Manyaan Marappin
Marappariyen
Ollamark Kannaal Kunam
