Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Can I forget? I recall always 
The charms of her bright battling eyes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If I had forgotten her who has bright battling eyes, I would have remembered (thee); but I never forget her. (Thus says he to her maid).
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
I might recall, if I could once forget; but from my heart
Her charms fade not, whose eyes gleam like the warrior's dart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Recollection is needed if only I forget.
How can I forget her dazzling warring eyes!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: My lover will never vanish from my eyes; nor will he be disturbed if I close them. He is so ethereal as to be invisible.
Transliteration:
So subtle is my lover’s form that he
neither leaves my eyes Nor is he hurt when I wink.
T.Kannan:
Kannullin Pokaar Imaippin
Parukuvaraa
Nunniyarem Kaadha Lavar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: My lover would not depart from mine eyes; even if I wink, he would not suffer (from pain); he is so ethereal.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
So subtle is my lover's form 
Ever in my eyes winking, no harm.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
My loved one's subtle form departs not from my eyes;
I wink them not, lest I should pain him where he lies.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
So subtle is my lover’s form that he neither leaves my eyes
Nor is he hurt when I wink.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
I will not paint my eyes and so lose
Even for a trice the sight of my love.
Transliteration:
I will not paint my eyes and so lose Even
for a trice the sight of my love.
T.Kannan:
Kannullaar Kaadha Lavaraakak Kannum
Ezhudhem Karappaakku Arindhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: As my lover abides in my eyes, I will not even paint them, for he would (then) have to conceal himself.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
My lover in my eyes abides 
I paint them not lest he hides.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
My love doth ever in my eyes reside;
I stain them not ,fearing his form to hide.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: I fear to paint ray eyes, lest it should hide the vision of my lord dwelling within.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
I dare not swallow anything hot
Lest it hurt my lover within me!
Transliteration: As my lover is in my heart, I am afraid of eating (anything) hot, for I know it would pain him.
T.Kannan:
I dare not swallow anything hot Lest it
hurt my lover within me!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Nenjaththaar Kaadha Lavaraaka
Veydhuntal
Anjudhum Vepaak Karindhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
My lover abides in my heart 
I fear hot food lest he feels hot.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Within my heart my lover dwells; from food I turn
That smacks of heat, lest he should feel it burn
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: With my lover in my heart I do not eat anything hot lest it should harm the delicate one.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My eyes don’t close for fear of losing him.
Seeing this, folks blame him for desertion.
Transliteration: I will not wink, knowing that if I did, my lover would hide himself; and for this reason, this town says, he is unloving.
T.Kannan:
My eyes don’t close for fear of losing
him. Seeing this, folks blame him for desertion.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Imaippin Karappaakku Arival
Anaiththirke
Edhilar EnnumIv Voor
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
My eyes wink not lest he should hide 
And him as cruel the townsmen chide.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: My eyes wink not lest they should lose the vision of my lord within; not knowing this people blame him for my sleeplessness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
I fear his form to hide, nor close my eyes;
Her love estranged is gone!' the village cries.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
He dwells gladly forever in my heart.
And the folks say he is loveless and has left me.
Transliteration: My lover dwells in my heart with perpetual delight; but the town says he is unloving and (therefore) dwells afar.
T.Kannan:
He dwells gladly forever in my heart. And
the folks say he is loveless and has left me.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Uvandhuraivar Ullaththul Endrum
Ikandhuraivar
Edhilar EnnumIv Voor
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Delightfully my lover makes my heart for ever his abode; but villainous people say he is cruel and dwells apart.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
He abides happy in my heart
But people mistake he is apart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Rejoicing in my very soul he ever lies;
'Her love estranged is gone far off'! the village cries.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To those who after enjoyment of sexual pleasure suffer (for want of more), there is no help so efficient as the palmyra horse.
Transliteration:
Those that enjoyed love and now mourn in affliction
Have nothing but the madal for strength.
T.Kannan:
Those that enjoyed love and now mourn in
affliction Have nothing but the madal for strength.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaamam Uzhandhu Varundhinaarkku Emam
Matalalladhu Illai Vali
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Men anguished by unrequited love find no stronger solace than mounting the madal.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Pangs of passion find no recourse 
Except riding <sup>*</sup>'palmyra horse'.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To those whe'e proved love's joy and now afflicted mourn,
Except the helpful 'horse of palm', no other strength remains.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My body and my soul, that can no more endure,
Will lay reserve aside,and mount the 'horse of palm'
Transliteration: Having got rid of shame, the suffering body and soul save themselves on the palmyra horse.
T.Kannan:
Away with shame! Soul and body can bear no more,
And will mount the madal.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: My body and soul, unequal to the pangs of love, seek to mount the madal; bashfulness and reserve are swept away.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Away with shame! Soul and body can bear no
more, And will mount the madal.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nonaa Utampum Uyirum Matalerum
Naaninai Neekki Niruththu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Pining body and mind lose shame 
And take to riding of the palm.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Modesty and manliness were once my own; now, my own is the palmyra horse that is ridden by the lustful.
Transliteration:
I once retained reserve and seemly manliness;
To day I nought possess but lovers' 'horse of palm'
T.Kannan:
Modesty and manliness once I owned,
But now only the madal ridden by the lustful.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Reserve and dignified manliness once I had; but today I possess the madal which the helpless love-sick resort to.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Modesty and manliness once I owned, But
now only the madal ridden by the lustful.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Naanotu Nallaanmai Pantutaiyen
Indrutaiyen
Kaamutraar Erum Matal
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Once I was modest and manly 
My love has now Madal only.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The raft of modesty and manliness, is, alas, carried-off by the strong current of lust.
Transliteration:
Rushing flood of love sweeps away
The raft of shame and firmness, aye!
T.Kannan:
Lover's rushing tide will sweep away the raft
Of seemly manliness and shame combined.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Alas, the raft of modesty and manliness is swept away
By the rushing tide of lust!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The giant force of the floods of love has carried away the raft of my manliness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Alas, the raft of modesty and manliness is
swept away By the rushing tide of lust!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kaamak Katumpunal Uykkum Naanotu
Nallaanmai Ennum Punai

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Palm ride and pangs of eventide 
Are gifts of wreath like bracelet maid.
Transliteration:
The maid that slender armlets wears, like flowers entwined,
Has brought me 'horse of palm' and pangs of eventide!
T.Kannan: The lady of little bracelets strung like garlands has taught me the love-sick pangs of evening and the madal horse. Never before have I known
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The maiden with her armlets of garland
Gave me the madal and the pangs of eventide.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The maiden with her armlets of garland
Gave me the madal and the pangs of eventide.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Thotalaik Kurundhoti Thandhaal
Matalotu
Maalai Uzhakkum Thuyar
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: She with the small garland-like bracelets has given me the palmyra horse and the sorrow that is endured at night.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Mataloordhal Yaamaththum Ulluven
Mandra
Patalollaa Pedhaikken Kan
Transliteration:
Madal I ride at midnight for 
My eyes sleep not seeing this fair.
T.Kannan:
Of climbing 'horse of palm' in midnight hour, I think;
My eyes know no repose for that same simple maid.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Thinking of this maid, my eyelids never close in slumber; even in dead of night my thoughts run, on the suicidal madal.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Even at midnight I think of riding the madal,
Unable to close my eyes because of her.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Mine eyes will not close in sleep on your mistress's account; even at midnight will I think of mounting the palmyra horse.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Even at midnight I think of riding the
madal, Unable to close my eyes because of her.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Katalanna Kaamam Uzhandhum
Mataleraap
Pennin Perundhakka Thil
Transliteration:
Her sea like lust seeks not Madal! 
Serene is woman's self control.
T.Kannan: Woman tossed about in a sea of the anguish of love think not of mounting the madal — there is nothing greater than this.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
There's nought of greater worth than woman's long enduring soul,
Who, vexed by love like ocean waves, climbs not the'horse of palm'
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nothing grandeur than women! Their love may rage like sea,
Yet don’t mount the madal!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: There is nothing so noble as the womanly nature that would not ride the palmyra horse, though plunged a sea of lust.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Nothing grandeur than women! Their love
may rage like sea, Yet don’t mount the madal!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Pitiless love with no regard for modesty,
Betrays itself to reveal the secrets public.
Transliteration:
Niraiyariyar Manaliyar Ennaadhu
Kaamam
Maraiyirandhu Mandru Patum
T.Kannan: Oh my beloved I Wanton is my love which has no sympathy for my modesty or my helplessness; How it compels me to unpack my hidden secret and drag it out to the open!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Lust betrays itself in haste 
Though women are highly soft and chaste.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
In virtue heart to move,yet very tender, too, are we;
Love deems not so, would rend the veil and court publicity!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Pitiless love with no regard for modesty,
Betrays itself to reveal the secrets public.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even the Lust (of women) transgresses its secrecy and appears in public, forgetting that they are too chaste and liberal (to be overcome by it).

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Perplexed is my passion that it roves in
public With complaints of being unnoticed.
Transliteration:
Arikilaar Ellaarum Endreen Kaamam
Marukin Marukum Maruntu
T.Kannan: ‘Nobody knows my secret’ I said to myself; but my angry love rages in the market-place to my utter disgrace.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
My perplexed love roves public street 
Believing that none knows its secret.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
There's no one knows my heart, ' so says my love,
And thus, in public ways, perturbed will rove.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: My lust, feeling that it is not known by all, reels confused in the streets (of this town).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Perplexed is my passion that it roves in public
With complaints of being unnoticed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Foolish people laugh at me before my very eyes; verily they have not experienced agony of love.
Transliteration:
Fools laugh so as to be seen by us, Not
having endured what we have.
T.Kannan:
Yaamkannin Kaana Nakupa Arivillaar
Yaampatta Thaampataa Aaru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Fools laugh at me before my eyes
For they feel not my pangs and sighs.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Before my eyes the foolish make a mock of me,
Because they ne'er endured the pangs I now must drie.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even strangers laugh (at us) so as to be seen by us, for they have not suffered.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Fools laugh so as to be seen by us,
Not having endured what we have.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The many scandals about our love do indeed give me fresh hope and sustain my wretched life. Luckily for me the village folk do not know what their scandals have done.
Transliteration:
Rumours revive hope; Those that spread
them Luckily don't know this.
T.Kannan:
Alarezha Aaruyir Nirkum Adhanaip
Palarariyaar Paakkiyath Thaal
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Rumour sustains my existence
Good luck! many know not its sense.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: My precious life is saved by the raise of rumour, and this, to my good luck no others are aware of.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
By this same rumour's rise, my precious life stands fast;
Good fortune grant the many know this not!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Rumours revive hope; Those that spread them
Luckily don't know this.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Blind to the esteem of my lady of flower-like eyes, the village folk have linked her name with mine.
Transliteration:
Rumours have gifted me this flowery-eyed
belle; The public know not her preciousness.
T.Kannan:
Malaranna Kannaal Arumai Ariyaadhu
Alaremakku Eendhadhiv Voor
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Not knowing the value of her whose eyes are like flowers this town has got up a rumour about me.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Rumour gives me the flower like belle
People know not what rare angel.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The village hath to us this rumour giv'n that makes her mine;
Unweeting all the rareness of the maid with flower like eyne.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Rumours have gifted me this flowery-eyed belle;
The public know not her preciousness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Should I not welcome their rumours
Which give that feel of owning whom I own not?
Transliteration:
Should I not welcome their rumours Which
give that feel of owning whom I own not?
T.Kannan:
Uraaadho Oorarindha Kelavai Adhanaip
Peraaadhu Petranna Neerththu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Will I not get a rumour that is known to the (whole) town ? For what I have not got is as if I had got it (already).
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
I profit by this public rumour 
Having not, I feel, I have her.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The rumour spread within the town, is it not gain to me?
It is as though that were obtained that may not be.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Is not the rumour of this village sweet to me? For it makes me feel that I have attained the bliss of love even without my lover at my side.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Rumours enhance my love which might have
Otherwise waned losing its power.
Transliteration: Rumour increases the violence of my passion; without it it would grow weak and waste away.
T.Kannan:
Rumours enhance my love which might have
Otherwise waned losing its power.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kavvaiyaal Kavvidhu Kaamam
Adhuvindrel
Thavvennum Thanmai Izhandhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Rumour inflames the love I seek 
Or else it becomes bleak and weak.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The rumour rising makes my love to rise;
My love would lose its power and languish otherwise.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The rumours set afloat have heightened my love; but for these, it might lose its sweetness and wither away.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Wine delights with every sip.
So does love with every disclosure.
Transliteration: As drinking liquor is delightful (to one) whenever one is in mirth, so is lust delightful to me whenever it is the subject of rumour.
T.Kannan:
Wine delights with every sip. So does love
with every disclosure.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaliththorum Kalluntal Vettatraal
Kaamam
Velippatun Thorum Inidhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Drink delights as liquor flows 
Love delights as rumour grows.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Each cup adds to the gaiety of a revelling drunkard. Even so each rumour of our love adds to my delight.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The more man drinks, the more he ever drunk would be;
The more my love's revealed, the sweeter 'tis to me!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Our meeting was but for a day, but the outcry is
As if a serpent has swallowed the moon.
Transliteration: It was but a single day that I looked on (my lover); but the rumour thereof has spread like the seizure of the moon by the serpent.
T.Kannan:
Our meeting was but for a day, but the
outcry is As if a serpent has swallowed the moon.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kantadhu Mannum Orunaal Alarmannum
Thingalaip Paampukon Tatru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Only once have I seen him; but oh! rumours of our secret love have spread all over the vast world, even as the news of the serpent devouring
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
One lasting day we met alone 
Lasting rumours eclipse our moon.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
I saw him but one single day; rumour spreads soon
As darkness, when the dragon seizes on the moon.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: This malady (of lust) is manured by the talk of women and watered by the (harsh) words of my mother.
Transliteration:
The village gossip manures my love,
And my mother's reproaches water it.
T.Kannan:
The village gossip manures my love, And my
mother's reproaches water it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ooravar Kelavai Eruvaaka Annaisol
Neeraaka Neelumin Noi
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: How this plant of sickness grows on! The gossip of the village manures it and the frown of my mother waters it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Scandal manures; mother's refrain 
Waters the growth of this love pain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
My anguish grows apace; the town's report
Manures it; my mother's word doth water it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
With butter oil extinguish fire! 'Twill prove
Harder by scandal to extinguish love.
Transliteration: To say that one could extinguish passion by rumour is like extinguishing fire with ghee.
T.Kannan:
To suppress love with scandal
Is to put fire out with ghee!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: With the scandals of the village one can never stifle love; it is like smothering fire with ghee.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To suppress love with scandal Is to put
fire out with ghee!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Neyyaal Erinudhuppem Endratraal
Kelavaiyaal
Kaamam Nudhuppem Enal
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To quench the lust by rumour free 
Is to quench fire by pouring ghee.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When the departure of him who said "fear not" has put me to shame before others, why need I be ashamed of scandal.
Transliteration:
When he who said 'Fear not!' hath left me blamed,
While many shrink, can I from rumour hide ashamed?
T.Kannan:
He who said “fear not” has flared up rumour.
Why then should I blush for this outcry?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When my lover who swore not to leave me alone has abandoned me to the mockery of the many, why need I fear these tittle-tattle?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
He who said “fear not” has flared up
rumour. Why then should I blush for this outcry?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Alarnaana Olvadho Anjalompu Endraar
Palarnaana Neeththak Katai
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who said "fear not" flared up rumour 
Why then should I blush this clamour?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The rumour I desire is raised by the town (itself); and my lover would if desired consent (to my following him).
Transliteration:
Town raising this cry, I desire 
Consent is easy from my sire.
T.Kannan:
If we desire, who loves will grant what we require;
This town sends forth the rumour we desire!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
This village gossip is what we desire,
For it serves the desire of my lover.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: This village rumour is useful; it has coupled you and your lover; the moment he desires, the lover can thus help us.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
This village gossip is what we desire, For
it serves the desire of my lover.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thaamventin Nalkuvar Kaadhalar
Yaamventum
Kelavai Etukkumiv Voor

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Tell me if you but do not leave, 
Your quick return to those who live.
Transliteration:
If you will say, 'I leave thee not, ' then tell me so;
Of quick return tell those that can survive this woe.
T.Kannan: If you are not to go away, tell me so that I may sustain my lingering life. If you are to go, return soon.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Tell me if you are not leaving. Bid farewell to those
Who can survive to see your return.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Tell me if you are not leaving. Bid
farewell to those Who can survive to see your return.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Sellaamai Untel Enakkurai Matrunin
Valvaravu Vaazhvaark Kurai
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If it is not departure, tell me; but if it is your speedy return, tell it to those who would be alive then.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Inkan Utaiththavar Paarval
Pirivanjum
Punkan Utaiththaal Punarvu
Transliteration:
His sight itself was pleasing, near 
Embrace pains now by partings fear.
T.Kannan:
It once was perfect joy to look upon his face;
But now the fear of parting saddens each embrace.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: In the days of courtship what pleasure lay in each glance of his! Now after our union, the prospect of his separation brings gloom even in moments of happiness.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
His mere look was once a delight; but now
Even his embrace saddens, fearing separation.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: His very look was once pleasing; but (now) even intercourse is painful through fear of separation.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
His mere look was once a delight; but now
Even his embrace saddens, fearing separation.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Aridharo Thetram Arivutaiyaar Kannum
Pirivo Ritaththunmai Yaan
Transliteration:
On whom shall I lay my trust hence 
While parting lurks in knowing ones?
T.Kannan: Hard it is for me to rest assured; the lover who knows full well my miseries in separation still may part from me, making promises of quick return.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To trust henceforth is hard, if ever he depart,
E'en he, who knows, his promise and my breaking heart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
How hard it is to trust when even he who knows
Breaks his word and goes!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: As even the lover who understands (everything) may at times depart, confidence is hardly possible.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
How hard it is to trust when even he who
knows Breaks his word and goes!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
How can I be blamed for trusting one Who
left me after assuring “fear not”?
Transliteration:
Aliththanjal Endravar Neeppin
Theliththasol
Theriyaarkku Unto Thavaru
T.Kannan: How can there be blame on one who has put implicit trust in the comforting words of him who promised to shelter me forever?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
He parts whose love told me fear not 
Is my trust in him at default?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If he depart, who fondly said, 'Fear not.' what blame's incurred
By those who trusted to his reassuring word?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
How can I be blamed for trusting one
Who left me after assuring “fear not”?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If he who bestowed his love and said "fear not" should depart, will it be the fault of those who believed in (his) assuring words ?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If you would serve me, stop him going.
Gone we shall not meet again.
Transliteration: Stop my lord from leaving me; only then can you save my life. Else it will flee at his parting and never again shall we meet.
T.Kannan:
Ompin Amaindhaar Pirivompal Matravar
Neengin Aridhaal Punarvu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Stop his parting my life to save 
Meeting is rare if he would leave.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If you would guard my life, from going him restrain
Who fills my life! If he depart, hardly we meet again.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: If you would save (my life), delay the departure of my destined (husband); for if he departs, intercourse will become impossible.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If you would serve me, stop him going.
Gone we shall not meet again.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If he is cruel enough to speak of leaving me, I am lost; false it is to entertain any hope of his mercy.
Transliteration:
When he is stubborn to announce
separation, It is futile to hope for reunion.
T.Kannan:
Pirivuraikkum Vankannar Aayin
Aridhavar
Nalkuvar Ennum Nasai
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
His hardness says, "I leave you now" 
Is there hope of his renewed love?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To cherish longing hope that he should ever gracious be,
Is hard, when he could stand, and of departure speak to me.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: If he is so cruel as to mention his departure (to me), the hope that he would bestow (his love) must be given up.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When he is stubborn to announce separation,
It is futile to hope for reunion.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Will not the bracelets slipping loose from my wrist, tell the tale of the separation of my husband?
Transliteration:
Do not the bangles sliding down my arms
Forebode the departure of my lord?
T.Kannan:
Thuraivan Thurandhamai Thootraakol
Munkai
Iraiiravaa Nindra Valai
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Will not my gliding bangles' cry 
The parting of my lord betray?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Do not the rings that begin to slide down my fingers forebode the separation of my lord ?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The bracelet slipping from my wrist announced before
Departure of the Prince that rules the ocean shore.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Do not the bangles sliding down my arms
Forebode the departure of my lord?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Painful it is to live removed from familiar friends in a far-off village; but far more painful is the parting of the dearest one.
Transliteration:
It is bitter to live among strangers.
Bitter still is to part with one's love.
T.Kannan:
Innaadhu Inaniloor Vaazhdhal
Adhaninum
Innaadhu Iniyaarp Pirivu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Painful is it to live in a friendless town; but far more painful is it to part from one's lover.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Bitter is life in friendless place; 
Worse is parting love's embrace!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Tis sad to sojourn in the town where no kind kinsmen dwell;
'Tis sadder still to bid a friend beloved farewell.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
It is bitter to live among strangers.
Bitter still is to part with one's love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Can fire, which hurts when touched,
Hurt like the passion of love even untouched?
Transliteration:
Can fire, which hurts when touched, Hurt
like the passion of love even untouched?
T.Kannan:
Thotirsutin Alladhu Kaamanoi Pola
Vitirsutal Aatrumo Thee
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Fire burns when touched; but, like the sickness of love, can it also burn when removed ?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Can fire that burns by touch burn like 
Parting of the hearts love sick?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Fire burns the hands that touch; but smart of love
Will burn in hearts that far away remove.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Fire can scorch only when touched, but can it, like love, scorch persons away from it?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Strange how many can bear separation,
Survive sorrow, and live!
Transliteration: As if there were many indeed that can consent to the impossible, kill their pain, endure separation and yet continue to live afterwards.
T.Kannan:
Strange how many can bear separation,
Survive sorrow, and live!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Aridhaatri Allalnoi Neekkip
Pirivaatrip
Pinirundhu Vaazhvaar Palar
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Many survive pangs of parting 
Not I this sore so distressing.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Sorrow's sadness meek sustaining,
 Driving sore distress away,Separation uncomplaining Many bear the livelong day!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Many ladies have gracefully borne news of separation, steered clear of sorrow, endured the parting of the loved one and still survived I

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
I would hide this sickness, but it wells up
Like water drawn from a spring.
Transliteration: I would hide this pain from others; but it (only) swells like a spring to those who drain it.
T.Kannan:
I would hide this sickness, but it wells
up Like water drawn from a spring.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Maraippenman Yaaniqdho Noyai
Iraippavarkku
Ootruneer Pola Mikum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
It swells out like baled out spring 
How to bear this pain so writhing?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: This my disease I seek to hide; but how endlessly it wells up like the waters of the spring.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
I would my pain conceal, but see! It surging swells,
As streams to those that draw from ever springing wells.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Hide this sickness, I cannot.
To tell him who caused it, I am ashamed.
Transliteration: I cannot conceal this pain, nor can I relate it without shame to him who has caused it.
T.Kannan:
Hide this sickness, I cannot. To tell him
who caused it, I am ashamed.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Karaththalum Aatrenin Noyainoi
Seydhaarkku
Uraiththalum Naanuth Tharum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: It lies not in my power to conceal the disease of my love. Nor am I able to speak of it unabashed to him who caused it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
I can't conceal this nor complain 
For shame to him who caused this pain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
I cannot hide this pain of mine, yet shame restrains
When I would tell it out to him who caused my pains.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: (Both) lust and shame, with my soul for their shoulder pole balance themselves on a body that cannot bear them.
Transliteration:
Love and shame hang poised on my life.
My body unable to bear them.
T.Kannan:
Love and shame hang poised on my life. My
body unable to bear them.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: My frail body is harassed by love and my bashfulness bids me be quiet. My soul is torn between them.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kaamamum Naanum Uyirkaavaath
Thoongumen
Nonaa Utampin Akaththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In life poles of this wearied frame 
Are poised the weights of lust and shame.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
My soul, like porter's pole, within my wearied frame,
Sustains a two fold burthen poised, of love and shame.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A sea of love, 'tis true, I see stretched out before,
But not the trusty bark that wafts to yonder shore.
Transliteration: There is indeed a flood of lust; but there is no raft of safety to cross it with.
T.Kannan:
There is indeed a flood of lust;
But no safe raft to swim across it.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Verily the endless sea of love stretches before me; but I find not even a raft to cross the limitless expanse.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
There is indeed a flood of lust; But no
safe raft to swim across it.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Kaamak Katalmannum Unte Adhuneendhum
Emap Punaimannum Il
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
My lust is a sea, I do not see 
A raft to go across safely.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He who can produce sorrow from friendship, what can he not bring forth out of enmity ?
Transliteration:
Who work us woe in friendships, trustful hour,
What will they prove when angry tempests lower?
T.Kannan:
If his friendship can bring so much misery,
How will it be in enmity?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Even to the loving one, he brings so much suffering; how much more pain will he cause to his enemy!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If his friendship can bring so much
misery, How will it be in enmity?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Thuppin Evanaavar Mankol
Thuyarvaravu
Natpinul Aatru Pavar
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What wilt they prove when they are foes
Who in friendship bring me woes!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The pleasure of lust is (as great as) the sea; but the pain of lu st is far greater.
Transliteration:
The pleasure in love is oceanful 
But its pangs are more painful.
T.Kannan:
A happy love's sea of joy; but mightier sorrows roll
From unpropitious love athwart the troubled soul.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The pleasure of love is as vast as the sea.
Vaster still is the sorrow of its hurt.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Vast as the sea is the delight of wedded love; but vaster still are the sorrows of parting.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The pleasure of love is as vast as the
sea. Vaster still is the sorrow of its hurt.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Inpam Katalmatruk Kaamam
Aqdhatungaal
Thunpam Adhanir Peridhu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Wild waves of love I swim shoreless 
Pining alone in midnight hush.
Transliteration:
I swim the cruel tide of love, and can no shore descry,
In watches of the night, too, 'mid the waters, only I!
T.Kannan: Tossed in the troubled waters of love, I reach no shore;  am all alone in the still watches of the night.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Whirling in the stormy sea of love, I find no shore;
Even at midnight I am alone.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Whirling in the stormy sea of love, I find
no shore; Even at midnight I am alone.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Kaamak Katumpunal Neendhik
Karaikaanen
Yaamaththum Yaane Ulen
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: I have swam across the terrible flood of lust, but have not seen its shore; even at midnight I am alone; still I live.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Mannuyir Ellaam Thuyitri Aliththiraa
Ennalladhu Illai Thunai
Transliteration:
Night's mercy lulls all souls to sleep 
Keeping but me for companionship.
T.Kannan:
All living souls in slumber soft she steeps;
But me alone kind night for her companing keeps!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Beneficent night which has rocked all living creatures to sleep finds in me her lone sleepless companion.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Poor night, putting all things to sleep,
Has only me for company.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The night which graciously lulls to sleep all living creatures, has me alone for her companion.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Poor night, putting all things to sleep,
Has only me for company.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Kotiyaar Kotumaiyin Thaamkotiya
Innaal
Netiya Kazhiyum Iraa
Transliteration:
Crueller than that cruel he
Are midnight hours gliding slowly.
T.Kannan: These nights, all too short in those sweet days, now lengthen their heavy hours, surpassing in cruelty even my lord.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
More cruel than the cruelty of him, the cruel one.
In these sad times are lengthening hours of night I watch alone.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Even crueler than my cruel lord
Are the long nights of these days.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The long nights of these days are far more cruel than the heartless one who is torturing me.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Even crueler than my cruel lord Are the
long nights of these days.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If eyes could also reach him like the
heart, They won’t be swimming in a flood of tears.
Transliteration:
Ullampondru Ulvazhich Chelkirpin
Vellaneer
Neendhala Mannoen Kan
T.Kannan: If only my eyes like my mind had the speedy power of fleeing to my lover, they need not now swim in a flood of tears.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Like heart, if my sight reaches him 
It won't in floods of tears swim!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
When eye of mine would as my soul go forth to him,
It knows not how through floods of its own tears to swim.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If eyes could also reach him like the heart,
They won’t be swimming in a flood of tears.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Could mine eyes travel like my thoughts to the abode (of my absent lord), they would not swim in this flood of tears.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Why the same eyes that showed him to me
And caused this fever, now cry in anguish?
Transliteration: Did you not show him to me and push me into the incurable sickness of love? Then why do you weep now to sft him, the cause of all your woe?
T.Kannan:
Kandhaam Kaluzhva Thevankolo
Thantaanoi
Thaamkaatta Yaamkan Tadhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The eye pointed him to me; why then 
They weep with malady and pine?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
They showed me him, and then my endless pain
I saw: why then should weeping eyes complain?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: As this incurable malady has been caused by my eyes which showed (him) to me, why should they now weep for (him).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Why the same eyes that showed him to me
And caused this fever, now cry in anguish?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Oh Eyes! Having thoughtlessly feasted upon the lover, how can you now grieve for your own folly?
Transliteration:
Why do these eyes, once thoughtlessly
looked at him, Now not repent but grieve?
T.Kannan:
Therindhunaraa Nokkiya Unkan
Parindhunaraap
Paidhal Uzhappadhu Evan?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Why should these dyed eyes grieve now sans 
Regrets for their thoughtless glance?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
How glancing eyes, that rash unweeting looked that day,
With sorrow measureless are wasting now away!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The dyed eyes that (then) looked without foresight, why should they now endure sorrow, without feeling sharply (their own fault).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Why do these eyes, once thoughtlessly looked at him,
Now not repent but grieve?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Those eyes once leapt to see the lover; now they weep by themselves. Is it not laughable?
Transliteration:
Funny the very same eyes that once Eagerly
looked at him are now in tears!
T.Kannan:
Kadhumenath Thaanokkith Thaame
Kaluzhum
Ithunakath Thakka Thutaiththu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Eyes darted eager glance that day 
It's funny that they weep today.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: They themselves looked eagerly (on him) and now they weep. Is not this to be laughed at ?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The eyes that throw such eager glances round erewhile
Are weeping now. Such folly surely claims a smile!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Funny the very same eyes that once
Eagerly looked at him are now in tears!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Plunging me into an inevitable and incurable disease, these eyes of mine pour out their tears and run dry.
Transliteration:
Having driven me to this incurable fever,
My eyes have dried up, drained of all tears.
T.Kannan:
Peyalaatraa Neerulandha Unkan
Uyalaatraa
Uyvilnoi Enkan Niruththu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: These painted eyes have caused me a lasting mortal disease; and now they can weep no more, the tears having dried up.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
These eyes left me to endless grief 
Crying adry without relief.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Those eyes have wept till all the fount of tears is dry,
That brought upon pain that knows no remedy.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Having driven me to this incurable fever,
My eyes have dried up, drained of all tears.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My eyes plunged me in a raging sea of love
And for this must suffer sleepless pain.
Transliteration:
My eyes plunged me in a raging sea of love
And for this must suffer sleepless pain.
T.Kannan:
Patalaatraa Paidhal Uzhakkum
Katalaatraak
Kaamanoi Seydhaen Kan
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Mine eyes have caused me a lust that is greater than the sea and (they themselves) endure the torture of sleeplessness.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
My eyes causing lust more than sea 
Suffer that torture sleeplessly.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The eye that wrought me more than sea could hold of woes,
Is suffering pangs that banish all repose.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: My eyes that caused a disease of love vaster than the sea itself, do not now close themselves in sleep; they languish in grief.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
How nice! The eyes that caused this torment
Are themselves tormented.
Transliteration: The eyes that have given me this disease have themselves been seized with this (suffering). Oh! I am much delighted.
T.Kannan:
How nice! The eyes that caused this
torment Are themselves tormented.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Oo Inidhe Emakkinnoi Seydhakan
Thaaam Itharpat Tadhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Lo! eyes that wrought this love sickness 
Are victims of the same themselves.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Oho! How sweet a thing to see ! the eye
That wrought this pain, in the same gulf doth lie.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The very eyes that have caused me all those woes languish in sorrow by themselves. This is indeed just!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Let tears dry up pining and pining in the eyes
That eyed him longing and longing.
Transliteration: The eyes that became tender and gazed intently on him, may they suffer so much as to dry up the fountain of their tears.
T.Kannan:
Let tears dry up pining and pining in the
eyes That eyed him longing and longing.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Uzhandhuzhan Thulneer Aruka
Vizhaindhizhaindhu
Venti Avarkkanta Kan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Let tears dry up pining pining 
In eyes that eyed him longing longing.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: These eyes hungered, wept, and repeatedly sent their glances to him. May they grieve and dry up all their stock of tears!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Aching, aching, let those exhaust their stream,
That melting,melting ,that day gazed on him.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
He made love with words, not with heart.
Yet my eyes pine, seeing him not.
Transliteration: He is indeed here who loved me with his lips but not with his heart but mine eyes suffer from not seeing him.
T.Kannan:
He made love with words, not with heart.
Yet my eyes pine, seeing him not.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Penaadhu Pettaar Ularmanno Matravark
Kaanaadhu Amaivila Kan
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: She says to her companion: ‘Did you not say that he who loves with words gets the wearing. Unless I see him straight before me, my eyelids do not close in sleep.’
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Ther's he whose lips loved, not his heart 
Yet my eyes pine seeing him not.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who loved me once, unloving now doth here remain;
Not seeing him, my eye no rest can gain.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When he is away they do not sleep; when he is present they do not sleep; in either case, mine eyes endure unbearable agony.
Transliteration:
Sleepless when he is not here, sleepless when he is,
Either way my eyes never rest.
T.Kannan:
Sleepless when he is not here, sleepless
when he is, Either way my eyes never rest.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When he is away, my eyes are restless. When he comes, they are sleepless. Lost between these extremities my eyes endure untold suffering.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Vaaraakkaal Thunjaa Varindhunjaa
Aayitai
Aaragnar Utrana Kan
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
He comes; no sleep; he goes; no sleep 
This is the fate of eyes that weep.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When he comes not, all slumber flies; no sleep when he is there;
Thus every way my eyes have troubles hard to bear.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
It is not hard for all the town the knowledge to obtain,
When eyes, as mine, like beaten tambours, make the mystery plain.
Transliteration: It is not difficult for the people of this place to understand the secret of those whose eyes, like mine, are as it were beaten drums.
T.Kannan:
With eyes that drum up and declare my grief,
It is hard to conceal secrets from these folks!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It is certainly not hard for the villagers to read my secret love. My tell-tale eyes proclaim it to the world.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
With eyes that drum up and declare my
grief, It is hard to conceal secrets from these folks!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Maraiperal Ooraarkku Aridhandraal
Empol
Araiparai Kannaar Akaththu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Like drum beats eyes declare my heart; 
From people who could hide his secret?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: I who (then) consented to the absence of my loving lord, to whom can I (now) relate the fact of my having turned sallow.
Transliteration:
I willed my loved absent should remain;
Of pining's sickly hue to whom shall I complain?
T.Kannan:
Having agreed to part my love,
How can I complain of my pallor to others?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: I did not assent to my lover’s parting. To whom can I now complain of the pallor of my body, stricken with separation?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Having agreed to part my love, How can I
complain of my pallor to others?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nayandhavarkku Nalkaamai Nerndhen
Pasandhaven
Panpiyaarkku Uraikko Pira
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
My lover's parting, I allowed 
Whom to complain my hue pallid?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Sallowness, as if proud of having been caused by him, would now ride on my person.
Transliteration:
Claiming it is begot through him 
Pallor creeps and rides over my frame.
T.Kannan:
He gave' this sickly hue thus proudly speaks
Then climbs, and all my frame its chariot makes.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Claiming that it begot through him,
Pallor creeps over my body with pride.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The pallor spread over my body, exalting in the fact that he gave its birth.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Claiming that it begot through him, Pallor
creeps over my body with pride.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Avardhandhaar Ennum Thakaiyaal
Ivardhandhen
Menimel Oorum Pasappu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
He seized my beauty and modesty 
Leaving pangs and Pallor to me.
Transliteration:
Of comeliness and shame he me bereft,
While pain and sickly hue, in recompense, he left.
T.Kannan: For my beauty and my bashfulness which he took away with him, my lover rewarded me with anguish and pallor.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
He robbed me first of my beauty and shame,
And gave in exchange sickness and pallor.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
He robbed me first of my beauty and shame,
And gave in exchange sickness and pallor.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Saayalum Naanum Avarkontaar
Kaimmaaraa
Noyum Pasalaiyum Thandhu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: He has taken (away) my beauty and modesty, and given me instead disease and sallowness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ulluvan Manyaan Uraippadhu
Avardhiramaal
Kallam Piravo Pasappu
Transliteration:
He is my thought, his praise my theme 
Yet this pallor steals over my frame.
T.Kannan:
I meditate his words, his worth is theme of all I say,
This sickly hue is false that would my trust betray.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: I think only of him and I open my lips only to sing his praises. Yet this pallor has come over me — O what cunning is this!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
His words I recollect and prowess I chant.
Yet, how does pallor sneak in?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: I think (of him); and what I speak about is but his excellence; still is there sallowness; and this is deceitful.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
His words I recollect and prowess I chant.
Yet, how does pallor sneak in?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Uvakkaanem Kaadhalar Selvaar
Ivakkaanen
Meni Pasappoor Vadhu
Transliteration:
My lover departed me there 
And pallor usurped my body here.
T.Kannan: Lo! Yonder is my lover gone. And here is the pallid hue spreading over my frame.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
My lover there went forth to roam;
This pallor of my frame usurps his palce at home.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
There goes my lover and here comes the pallor
To creep over my body.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Just as my lover departed then, did not sallowness spread here on my person ?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
There goes my lover and here comes the
pallor To creep over my body.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Darkness lies in wait for the lamp to go
out, And pallor for the embrace to break.
Transliteration:
Vilakkatram Paarkkum Irulepol Konkan
Muyakkatram Paarkkum Pasappu
T.Kannan: Pallor awaits me the moment I am away from my lord’s embrace, even as darkness lies in wait for the light to fade.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Just as darkness waits for light off 
Pallor looks for lover's arms off.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
As darkness waits till lamp expires, to fill the place,
This pallor waits till I enjoy no more my lord's embrace.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Darkness lies in wait for the lamp to go out,
And pallor for the embrace to break.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Just as darkness waits for the failing light; so does sallowness wait for the laxity of my husband's intercourse.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Locked in embrace, I turned a little.
Seizing that moment, pallor seized me in full.
Transliteration: I lay locked up in my lover’s embrace; I moved away so little from him; when lo! pallor sprang up as it were to devour me.
T.Kannan:
Pullik Kitandhen Putaipeyarndhen
Avvalavil
Allikkol Vatre Pasappu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
From his embrace I turned a nonce 
This pallor swallowed me at once.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
I lay in his embrace, I turned unwittingly;
Forthwith this hue, as you might grasp it , came on me
Ramachandra Dikshitar: I who was in close embrace just turned aside and the moment I did so, sallowness came on me like something to be seized on.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Locked in embrace, I turned a little.
Seizing that moment, pallor seized me in full.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: People say that I have gone sickly pale; never do they blame him that has abandoned me.
Transliteration:
Pallid has she become” blame everyone, But
none say “He parted her”.
T.Kannan:
Pasandhaal Ivalenpadhu Allaal
Ivalaith
Thurandhaar Avarenpaar Il
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
On my pallor they cast a slur 
But none says "lo he parted her".
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
On me, because I pine, they cast a slur;
But no one says,'He first deserted her'
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Besides those who say "she has turned sallow" there are none who say "he has forsaken her".
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Pallid has she become” blame everyone,
But none say “He parted her”.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If only he would keep his promise to return, my frame would gladly endure all the pallor of love.
Transliteration:
If my lord who left me remains free of
guilt, My pallor is worth all the grief.
T.Kannan:
Pasakkaman Pattaangen Meni
Nayappiththaar
Nannilaiyar Aavar Enin
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Let all my body become pale 
If he who took my leave fares well.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If he is clear of guilt who has conciliated me (to his departure) let my body suffer its due and turn sallow.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Well! Let my frame ,as now, be sicklied o'er with pain,
If he who won my heart's consent, in good estate remain.!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If my lord who left me remains free of guilt,
My pallor is worth all the grief.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Good it is for me to be known as pallor incarnate if only people do not call my lover merciless.
Transliteration:
I don’t mind being called pallid, so long
as They don’t blame him for causing it.
T.Kannan:
Pasappenap Perperudhal Nandre
Nayappiththaar
Nalkaamai Thootraar Enin
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It would be good to be said of me that I have turned sallow, if friends do not reproach with unkindness him who pleased me (then).
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Let people call me all pallid 
But my lover let them not deride.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Tis well, though men deride me for my sickly hue of pain;
If they from calling him unkind, who won my love, refrain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
I don’t mind being called pallid, so long as
They don’t blame him for causing it.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Only those blessed with the love of being loved
Are blessed with the seedless fruit of love.
Transliteration:
Only those blessed with the love of being
loved Are blessed with the seedless fruit of love.
T.Kannan:
Thaamveezhvaar Thamveezhap Petravar
Petraare
Kaamaththuk Kaazhil Kani
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The women who are beloved by those whom they love, have they have not got the stone-less fruit of sexual delight ?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Stoneless fruit of love they have 
Who are beloved by those they love.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The bliss to be beloved by those they love who gains,
Of love the stoneless, luscious fruit obtains.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Only those women taste all the juice of the seedless fruit of love, whose love is returned by their lovers.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Like the heavenly showers to living men
Is the blessing of grace by lovers to their beloved.
Transliteration: The bestowal of love by the beloved on those who love them is like the rain raining (at the proper season) on those who live by it.
T.Kannan:
Like the heavenly showers to living men Is
the blessing of grace by lovers to their beloved.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Vaazhvaarkku Vaanam Payandhatraal
Veezhvaarkku
Veezhvaar Alikkum Ali
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The lover and beloved's self givings 
Are like rains to living beings.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As heaven on living men showers blessing from above,
Is tender grace by lovers shown to those they love.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Welcome as the rain to the tillers of the earth is the grace of the lover to his loved one.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
They alone can have the pride of living together
Who are loved by their beloved.
Transliteration: The pride that says "we shall live" suits only those who are loved by their beloved (husbands).
T.Kannan:
They alone can have the pride of living
together Who are loved by their beloved.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Veezhunar Veezhap Patuvaarkku
Amaiyume
Vaazhunam Ennum Serukku
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The pride of living is for those 
Whose love is returned by love so close.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Justly may those women feel proud of their life who are endowed with lovers who requite their love in all its fullness.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Who love and are beloved, to them alone
Belongs the boast, 'We've made life's very joys our own'

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even if loved by others, they are luckless
Unless loved by those they love.
Transliteration: Even those who are esteemed (by other women) are devoid of excellence, if they are not loved by their beloved.
T.Kannan:
Even if loved by others, they are luckless
Unless loved by those they love.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Veezhap Patuvaar Kezheeiyilar
Thaamveezhvaar
Veezhap Pataaar Enin
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Those whose love is not returned by their sweet ones are unlucky beyond measure. Of what avail to them is the esteem of others?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Whose love is void of love in turn 
Are luckless with all esteems they earn.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Those well beloved will luckless prove.
Unless beloved by those they love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He who is beloved by me, what will he do to me, if I am not beloved by him ?
Transliteration:
What more can I expect of my lord
If he does not love me as much as I love him?
T.Kannan:
What more can I expect of my lord If he
does not love me as much as I love him?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When he does not return my love, what favour can I expect of him?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Naamkaadhal Kontaar Namakkevan
Seypavo
Thaamkaadhal Kollaak Katai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What can our lover do us now
If he does not requite our love?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
From him I love to me what gain can be,
Unless, as I love him, he loveth me?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Love on one side is bad; like balanced load.
By porter borne, love on both sides is good.
Transliteration: Lust, like the weight of the KAVADI, pains if it lies in one end only but pleases if it is in both.
T.Kannan:
One-sided love pains like lopsided kavadi.
It is sweet only when shared by both sides.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Bitter is unrequited love; sweet it is if returned in equal measure like the well-poised even scales.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
One-sided love pains like lopsided kavadi.
It is sweet only when shared by both sides.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Orudhalaiyaan Innaadhu Kaamamkaap
Pola
Irudhalai Yaanum Inidhu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
One sided pains; love in both souls 
Poises well like shoulder poles.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Would not cupid who abides and contends in one party (only) witness the pain and sorrow (in that party)?
Transliteration:
While Kaman rushes straight at me alone,
Is all my pain and wasting grief unknown?
T.Kannan:
Can't the god of Love, lodged in me alone
Causing distress, see my pallor and pain?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Cannot the god of love, who pays his attention to me alone, behold all my anguish and sorrow?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Can't the god of Love, lodged in me alone
Causing distress, see my pallor and pain?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Paruvaralum Paidhalum Kaanaankol
Kaaman
Oruvarkan Nindrozhuku Vaan
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
This cupid aims at me alone; 
Knows he not my pallor and pain?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There is no one in the world so hard-hearted as those who can live without receiving (even) a kind word from their beloved.
Transliteration:
Hard is the heart that can survive this world
Without a word of love from the beloved.
T.Kannan: Breathes there a more cruel soul on this earth than the one who lives on without the encouraging words of the loved one?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
None is so firm as she who loves 
Without kind words from whom she dotes.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who hear from lover's lips no pleasant word from day to day,
Yet in the world live out their life, no braver souls than they!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Hard is the heart that can survive this
world Without a word of love from the beloved.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Veezhvaarin Insol Peraaadhu
Ulakaththu
Vaazhvaarin Vankanaar Il

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Though the loved one favours me not, delightful indeed is stray news of him that reaches my ears.
Transliteration:
Though my beloved bestows nothing,
Still any news about him is sweet to my ears.
T.Kannan:
The lover accords not my desires 
And yet his words sweeten my ears.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though he may heart desires no grace accords to me,
Yet every accent of his voice is melody.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Though my beloved bestows nothing, Still
any news about him is sweet to my ears.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nasaiiyaar Nalkaar Eninum Avarmaattu
Isaiyum Iniya Sevikku
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though my beloved bestows no love on one, still are his words sweet to my ears.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Uraaarkku Urunoi Uraippaai Katalaich
Cheraaaai Vaazhiya Nenju
Transliteration: Oh my heart! try to tell gnawing cares to your unresponsive lover; you may as well strive to dry up the surging sea.
T.Kannan:
O heart, why pour your concerns to the unconcerned?
As well dump into the sea!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
You tell your grief to listless he
Bless my heart! rather fill up sea!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Tell him thy pain that loves not thee?
Farewell, my soul' fill up the sea!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Live, O my soul, would you who relate your great sorrow to strangers, try rather to fill up your own sea (of sorrow).
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
O heart, why pour your concerns to the
unconcerned? As well dump into the sea!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ullinum Theeraap Perumakizh
Seydhalaal
Kallinum Kaamam Inidhu
Transliteration: Love is far sweeter than wine; for unlike wine the very thought of love intoxicates me.
T.Kannan:
Love is sweeter than wine;
Its mere thought intoxicates.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Sexuality is sweeter than liquor, because when remembered, it creates a most rapturous delight.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Love is sweeter than wine; for vast 
Is its delight at very thought.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
From thought of her unfailing gladness springs,
Sweeter than palm tree wine the joy love brings.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Love is sweeter than wine; Its mere
thought intoxicates.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
How great is love! Behold its sweetness past belief!
Think on the lover, and the spirit knows no grief.
Transliteration:
Nothing better than sweet memories of love
To overcome the pain of loneliness!
T.Kannan:
Enaiththonaru Inidhekaan Kaamamdhaam
Veezhvaar
Ninaippa Varuvadhondru El
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Love is sweet in all respects; the thought of the dear one even in separation tastes sweet.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nothing better than sweet memories of love
To overcome the pain of loneliness!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even to think of one's beloved gives one no pain. Sexuality, in any degree, is always delightful.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Pains are off at the lover's thought
In all aspects this love is sweet.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
A fit of sneezing threatened, but it passed away;
He seemed to think of me, but do his fancies stray?
Transliteration:
Is it because of my lover’s incomplete
thoughts That my sneeze passes off incomplete?
T.Kannan: She says to her companion: “A sneeze comes upon me but goes away all of a sudden; perhaps a thought of me occurs to him and then he forgets it.”
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ninaippavar Pondru Ninaiyaarkol
Thummal
Sinaippadhu Pondru Ketum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: I feel as if I am going to sneeze but do not, and (therefore) my beloved is about to think (of me) but does not.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Is it because of my lover’s incomplete thoughts
That my sneeze passes off incomplete?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To sneeze I tried hence but could not 
Me he tried to think but did not.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Have I a place within his heart? 
Ah from mine he will never depart.
Transliteration: He is ever present in my thoughts. Am I or am I not ever present in his thoughts?
T.Kannan:
Have I a place within his heart!
From mine, alas! he never doth depart!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
No doubt my lord abides in my heart. Do I
also likewise abide in his?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Yaamum Ulengol Avarnenjaththu
Ennenjaththu
Oo Ulare Avar
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He continues to abide in my soul, do I likewise abide in his ?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
No doubt my lord abides in my heart.
Do I also likewise abide in his?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He keeps me away from his heart; does he not feel ashamed of constantly stealing into my heart?
Transliteration:
Shame! My heart often he enters
Banning me entry into his.
T.Kannan:
Me from his heart he jealously excludes;
Hath he no shame who ceaseless on my heart intrudes?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Having kept me out of his heart, Is he not
ashamed to enter mine?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Thamnenjaththu Emmaik Katikontaar
Naanaarkol
Emnenjaththu Ovaa Varal
Ramachandra Dikshitar: He who has imprisoned me in his soul, is he ashamed to enter incessantly into mine.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Having kept me out of his heart,
Is he not ashamed to enter mine?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Only the recollection of those ecstatic days with him makes me live. What else can sustain me?
Transliteration:
Beyond the thought of life with him
What else of life can I presume?
T.Kannan:
How live I yet? I live to ponder o'er
The days of bliss with him that are no more.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
You know why I live? To live in
remembrance of the days I lived in union with him.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Matriyaan Ennulen Manno Avaroti
YaanUtranaal Ulla Ulen
Ramachandra Dikshitar: I live by remembering my (former) intercourse with him; if it were not so, how could I live ?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
You know why I live? To live in remembrance of the days
I lived in union with him.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What will happen if I forget him,
When his memory itself burns my heart?
Transliteration:
What will happen if I forget 
When his memory burns my heart?
T.Kannan:
If I remembered not, what were I then? And yet,
The fiery smart of what my spirit knows not to forget?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
What will happen if I forget him, When his
memory itself burns my heart?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Marappin Evanaavan Markol
Marappariyen
Ullinum Ullam Sutum
Ramachandra Dikshitar: I have never forgotten (the pleasure); even to think of it burns my soul; could I live, if I should ever forget it ?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Never have I forgotten the golden days with my beloved; his separation now burns into my heart; certain is death if ever the memory of him forsakes my luckless heart.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
He never resents, however much I think of him.
Isn’t it an honor from my lover?
Transliteration:
I bring him to ceaseless memory 
He chides not; and thus honours me.
T.Kannan:
My frequent thought no warth excites, Is it not so?
This honour doth my love on me bestow.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: He will not be angry however much I may think of him; is it not so much the delight my beloved affords me ?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
He never resents, however much I think of
him. Isn’t it an honor from my lover?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Enaiththu Ninaippinum Kaayaar
Anaiththandro
Kaadhalar Seyyum Sirappu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: However much I may think of him, he is never angry with me. Inimitable is my lover's grace.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My dear life wastes thinking of his cruelty;
For once he said we are not different.
Transliteration: My precious life is wasting away by thinking too much on the cruelty of him who said we were not different.
T.Kannan:
Dear life ebbs away by thought 
Of him who said we are one heart.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Dear life departs, when his ungracious deeds I ponder o'er,
Who said erewhile, 'We 're one for evermore'.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
My dear life wastes thinking of his
cruelty; For once he said we are not different.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Viliyumen Innuyir Verallam Enpaar
Aliyinmai Aatra Ninaindhu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: As I think and think of the cruelty of my love who swore that our lives were inseparable, my soul ebbs away.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Hail Moon! Set not till I set my eyes on him
Who left me but not from my heart.
Transliteration: May you live, O Moon! Do not set, that I mine see him who has departed without quitting my soul.
T.Kannan:
Hail moon! Set not so that I find
Him who left me but not my mind.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Set not, so may'st thou prosper, moon! that eyes may see
My love who went away, but ever bides with me.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Hail Moon! Set not till I set my eyes on
him Who left me but not from my heart.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Vitaaadhu Sendraaraik Kanninaal
Kaanap
Pataaadhi Vaazhi Madhi
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: She says to the moon : “O blessed moon I ceaselessly pour your rays till I am able to see with my eyes the loved one who has forsaken me but yet dwells forever in my heart.”

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Where with shall I feast the dream which has brought me my dear one's messenger ?
Transliteration:
How shall I feast this dream which brought
A message from my lord?
T.Kannan:
How shall I feast this dream vision
That brings the beloved's love mission?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
It came and brought to me, that nightly vision rare,
A message from my love, what feast shall I prepare?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
How shall I feast this dream which brought
A message from my lord?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: With what feast may I entertain the dream that has brought glad tidings of my lover?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kaadhalar Thoodhotu Vandha
Kanavinukku
Yaadhusey Venkol Virundhu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If my fish-like painted eyes should, at my begging, close in sleep, I could fully relate my sufferings to my lord.
Transliteration:
If only my painted eyes could sleep,
I will tell him in my dream of my true predicament.
T.Kannan:
I beg these fish like dark eyes sleep 
To tell my lover how life I keep.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If only my eyes would close in sleep at my request, how I would meet him in dreams!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
If my dark, carp like eye will close in sleep, as I implore,
The tale of my long suffering life I'll tell my loved one o'er.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If only my painted eyes could sleep, I
will tell him in my dream of my true predicament.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kayalunkan Yaanirappath Thunjir
Kalandhaarkku
Uyalunmai Saatruven Man

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: My life lasts because in my dream I behold him who does not favour me in my waking hours.
Transliteration:
Though I miss him when I am awake,
My life lingers on as I see him in my dreams.
T.Kannan: The merciless one favours me not in waking hours but in dreams I feast on him and thus manage to live.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
In wakeful hours who sees me not 
I meet in dreams and linger yet.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Him, who in walking hour no kindness shows,
In dreams I see: and so my lifetime goes!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though I miss him when I am awake, My life
lingers on as I see him in my dreams.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Nanavinaal Nalkaa Thavaraik
Kanavinaal
Kaantalin Unten Uyir

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: There is pleasure in my dream, because in it I seek and obtain him who does not visit me in my wakefulness.
Transliteration:
Dreams sustain my love for in it I seek him
Who visits not while I am awake.
T.Kannan: Why do I love dreams? It is because they bring before me the one who in waking hours favours me not.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
In dreams I enjoy his love bliss 
Who in wakeful hours I miss.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Some pleasure I enjoy when him who loves not me
In waking hours, the vision searches out and makes me see.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Dreams sustain my love for in it I seek
him Who visits not while I am awake.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kanavinaan Untaakum Kaamam
Nanavinaan
Nalkaarai Naatith Thararku

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Dream sight of him delights at once 
Awake What of seeing him hence.
Transliteration:
As what I then beheld in waking hour was sweet,
So pleasant dreams in hour of sleep my sprit greet.
T.Kannan: Sweet is his presence in the waking hours; sweet too is his appearance in a dream. What then do I miss in seeing him in my dreams?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The very sight of him is joyous.
Be it in dreams or while I am awake.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The very sight of him is joyous. Be it in
dreams or while I am awake.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nanavinaal Kantadhooum Aange
Kanavundhaan
Kanta Pozhudhe Inidhu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: I saw him in my waking hours, and then it was pleasant; I see him just now in my dream, and it is (equally) pleasant.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nanavena Ondrillai Aayin Kanavinaal
Kaadhalar Neengalar Man
Transliteration:
If wakeful hours cometo nought 
My lov'r in dreams would nev'r depart
T.Kannan:
And if there were no waking hour , my love
In dreams would never form my side remove.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If only there was no such thing as waking hours, my lover would never desert me in my dreams.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Save for that thing called waking,
My dream-lover won't leave me indeed.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Were there no such thing as wakefulness, my beloved (who visited me) in my dream would not depart from me.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Save for that thing called waking, My
dream-lover won't leave me indeed.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nanavinaal Nalkaak Kotiyaar
Kanavanaal
Enemmaip Peezhip Padhu
Transliteration:
Awake he throws my overtures 
Adream, ah cruel! he tortures!
T.Kannan:
The cruel one, in waking hour, who all ungracious seems,
Why should he thus torment my soul in nightly dreams?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Why does the cruel one plague me in my dreams when he shows no compassion on me in my waking state?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Why does he haunt me in my dreams
When he cruelly deserts me when awake?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The cruel one who would not favour me in my wakefulness, what right has he to torture me in my dreams?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Why does he haunt me in my dreams When he
cruelly deserts me when awake?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Asleep he is round my shoulders. Awake he
hurries back to my heart.
Transliteration:
Thunjungaal Tholmelar Aaki
Vizhikkungaal
Nenjaththar Aavar Viraindhu
T.Kannan:
Asleep he embraces me fast; 
Awake he enters quick my heart.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: She says to her companion: “He embraces me in my dreams but the moment I awake he quickly vanishes into my heart.”
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
And when I sleep he holds my form embraced;
And when I wake to fill my heart makes haste!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Asleep he is round my shoulders.
Awake he hurries back to my heart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When I am asleep he rests on my shoulders, (but) when I awake he hastens into my soul.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Only those starved of love dreams, Rue
missing their beloved in wakefulness.
Transliteration: Only those women who do not see their lovers in dreams, blame them for their cruelty in walking hours.
T.Kannan:
Nanavinaal Nalkaarai Novar
Kanavinaal
Kaadhalark Kaanaa Thavar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
In dreams who don't discern lovers 
Rue their missing in wakeful hours.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
In dreams who ne'er their lover's form perceive,
For those in waking hours who show no love will grieve.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: They who have no dear ones to behold in their dreams blame him who visits me not in my waking hours.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Only those starved of love dreams,
Rue missing their beloved in wakefulness.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Folk say: “He has abandoned her in sooth.” Verily they do not know how he visits me in my dreams.
Transliteration:
He is a deserter, people say. But how can
they see his visits in my dreams?
T.Kannan:
Nanavinaal Namneeththaar Enpar
Kanavinaal
Kaanaarkol Ivvoo Ravar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The townsmen say he left me thus
In dreams failing to see him close.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
They say, that he in waking hours has left me lone;
In dreams they surely see him not, these people of the town!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The women of this place say he has forsaken me in my wakefulness. I think they have not seen him visit me in my dreams.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
He is a deserter, people say.
But how can they see his visits in my dreams?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: O blessed twilight! You are not the twilight of the joyous old times; you are the end of the world devouring the lives of the parted lovers.
Transliteration:
Farewell, evening! You are no more just,
For you devour the souls of brides!
T.Kannan:
Maalaiyo Allai Manandhaar Uyirunnum
Velainee Vaazhi Pozhudhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Bless you! you are not eventide 
But killing dart to wedded bride!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Thou art not evening, but a spear that doth devour
The souls of brides; farewell, thou evening hour!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Live, O you evening are you (the former) evening? No, you are the season that slays (married) women.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Farewell, evening! You are no more just,
For you devour the souls of brides!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: “Blest be thou, O twilight! You are pale and your eyes are lustreless. Is your sweet one as cruel as mine?"
Transliteration:
Bless you, muddled, lack-lustre twilight!
Is your love too heartless like mine?
T.Kannan:
Punkannai Vaazhi Marulmaalai
Emkelpol
Vankanna Thonin Thunai
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Hail sad eventide dim and grim
Has your mate like mine, cruel whim!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: A long life to you, O dark evening! You are sightless. Is your help-mate (also) as hard-hearted as mine.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Thine eye is sad; Hail, Doubtful hour of eventide!
Of cruel eye, as is my spouse , is too thy bride?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Bless you, muddled, lack-lustre twilight!
Is your love too heartless like mine?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The evening that once sighed with unease,
Now comes with growing hatred causing pain.
Transliteration:
The evening that once sighed with unease,
Now comes with growing hatred causing pain.
T.Kannan:
Paniarumpip Paidhalkol Maalai
Thuniarumpith
Thunpam Valara Varum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The evening that (once) came in with trembling and dimness (now) brings me an aversion for life and increasing sorrow.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Wet eve came pale and trembling then
Now it makes bold with growing pain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
With buds of chilly dew wan evening's shade enclose;
My anguish buds space, and all my sorrow grows.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: O Evening! In those joyous days with my beloved you approached me timidly with drops of dew on you and sadness written in your face. Your advance now brings with it only distaste and sorrow.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
There goes my love and in strides the evening,
Like slayers at the slaughter
Transliteration: In the absence of my lover, evening comes in like slayers on the field of slaughter.
T.Kannan:
There goes my love and in strides the
evening, Like slayers at the slaughter
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaadhalar Ilvazhi Maalai
Kolaikkalaththu
Edhilar Pola Varum
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Lover away, comes eventide 
Like slayer to field of homicide.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When absent is my love, the evening hour descends,
As when an alien host to field of battle wends.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: My lover away, evening comes murderously like a hangman rushing to the place of slaughter.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What good did I do to dawn?
And what harm to evening?
Transliteration: What good have I done to morning (and) what evil to evening?
T.Kannan:
What good did I do to dawn? And what harm
to evening?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaalaikkuch Cheydhanandru Enkol
Evankolyaan
Maalaikkuch Cheydha Pakai?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What good have I done to morning 
And what evil to this evening?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
O morn, how have I won thy grace? thou bring'st relief!
O'eve, why art thou foe? thou dost renew my grief.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Morning, Evening, why should these alternately assuage and afflict me in this separation? What good have I done to morn and what harm to even?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When my love was with me, I did not know
How cruel evening could be.
Transliteration: Previous to my husband's departure, I know not the painful nature of evening.
T.Kannan:
When my love was with me, I did not know
How cruel evening could be.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Maalainoi Seydhal Manandhaar
Akalaadha
Kaalai Arindha Thilen
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Evening pangs I have not known 
When my lord nev'r left me alone.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: With my lover by my side, never for once, did I taste the bitterness that eventide can cause.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The pangs that evening brings I never knew,
Till he , my wedded spouse, from me withdrew.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: This malady buds forth in the morning, expands all day long and blossoms in the evening.
Transliteration:
Budding at dawn and growing all day,
This disease blooms by evening.
T.Kannan:
Budding at dawn and growing all day, This
disease blooms by evening.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaalai Arumpip Pakalellaam Podhaaki
Maalai Malarumin Noi
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: This disease of love buds in the morning, grows and grows all day long and flowers into full bloom at eventide.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Budding at dawn burgeoning all day
This disease blooms in evening gay.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
My grief at morn a bud, all day an opening flower,
Full blown expands in evening hour.
