G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: The shepherd's flute now sounds as a fiery forerunner of night, and is become a weapon that slays (me).
Transliteration:
The cowboy’s flutes now sound as envoys of death
Forecasting the fiery evening.
T.Kannan:
The cowboy’s flutes now sound as envoys of
death Forecasting the fiery evening.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The note of the shepherd’s pipe, which sounded so pleasant in the happy days, has now become a message of the hot evening — verily a weapon forging my death.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Azhalpolum Maalaikkuth Thoodhaaki
Aayan
Kuzhalpolum Kollum Patai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
A deadly arm, this shepherd's flute 
Hails flaming eve and slays my heart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Then shepherd's pipe is like a murderous weapon, to my ear,
For it proclaims the hour of ev'ning's fiery anguish near.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If evening's shades, that darken all my soul, extend;
From this afflicted town will would of grief ascend.
Transliteration: When night comes on confusing (everyone's) mind, the (whole) town will lose its sense and be plunged in sorrow.
T.Kannan:
This place will all be dizzy and grieved
When the evening spreads and smothers me.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: When senseless evening creeps painfully along, the whole village feels dizzy and is plunged in the anguish of separation.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
This place will all be dizzy and grieved
When the evening spreads and smothers me.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Padhimaruntu Paidhal Uzhakkum
Madhimaruntu
Maalai Patardharum Pozhdhu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Deluding eve if it prolongs 
The whole town will suffer love pangs.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
This darkening eve, my darkling soul must perish utterly;
Remembering him who seeks for wealth, but seeks not me.
Transliteration: My (hitherto) unextinguished life is now lost in this bewildering night at the thought of him who has the nature of wealth.
T.Kannan:
Longing for him who left longing for wealth,
The evenings take toll of my undying soul.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: This life of mine which has survived this bitter separation is very near to death in this treacherous evening, as I think of my lord who values riches far above love.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Longing for him who left longing for
wealth, The evenings take toll of my undying soul.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Porulmaalai Yaalarai Ulli
Marulmaalai
Maayumen Maayaa Uyir
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thinking of him whose quest is wealth 
My life outlives the twilight stealth.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To lift from want he left me afar 
His thought makes my eyes blush the flower.
Transliteration:
Thine eyes grown dim are now ashamed the fragrant flow'rs to see.
Thinking on him, who wand'ring far, leaves us in misery.
T.Kannan: While we endure the unbearable sorrow, your eyes weep for him who is gone afar, and shun (the sight of) fragrant flowers.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Companion to lady-love: “Stop tins weeping and wailing. The thought of the one gone far away has made your eyes pale and lustreless.”
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
To lift us from want, he left us afar. Brooding over him,
Your eyes now quail before flowers.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To lift us from want, he left us afar.
Brooding over him, Your eyes now quail before flowers.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Sirumai Namakkozhiyach Chetchendraar
Ulli
Narumalar Naanina Kan

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Nayandhavar Nalkaamai Solluva Polum
Pasandhu Panivaarum Kan
Transliteration:
My pale tearful eyes betray 
The hardness of my husband, away.
T.Kannan: The discoloured eyes that shed tears p rofusely seem to betray the unkindness of our beloved.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The eye, with sorrow wan, all wet with dew of tears,
As witness of the lover's lack of love appears.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: “Your pallid eyes streaming with tears proclaim the callousness of your lord.”
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The pale and tear-filled eyes seem to convey
That your lover has been unkind.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The pale and tear-filled eyes seem to
convey That your lover has been unkind.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Thanandhamai Saala Arivippa Polum
Manandhanaal Veengiya Thol
Transliteration: The shoulders that swelled on the day of our union (now) seem to announce our separation clearly (to the public).
T.Kannan:
These arms that swelled on nuptial day 
Now shrunk proclaim "He is away".
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
These withered arms, desertion's pangs abundantly display,
That swelled with joy on that glad nuptial day.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: “Your shoulders that swelled with joy on the day of your marriage are thin today; they proclaim how your lord has cruelly forsaken you.”
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Sagging shoulders that once stood firm on the bridal day
Seem to clearly point to parting.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Sagging shoulders that once stood firm on
the bridal day Seem to clearly point to parting.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: In the absence of your consort, your shoulders having lost their former beauty and fulness, your bracelets of pure gold have become loose.
Transliteration:
Your lord away, your think shoulders
droop, Beauty and bracelets lost.
T.Kannan:
Panaineengip Paindhoti Sorum
Thunaineengith
Tholkavin Vaatiya Thol
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Bracelets slip off the arms that have 
Lost old beauty for He took leave.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: “Since your separation from your lord your shoulders have lost their innate grace; worse still they have become lanky; and the bangles too slip on your slender arms.”
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When lover went, then faded all their wonted charms,
And armlet's golden round slips off from these poor wasted arms.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Your lord away, your think shoulders droop,
Beauty and bracelets lost.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Drooping shoulders, its fading beauty And
slipping bracelets declare his cruelty.
Transliteration:
Kotiyaar Kotumai Uraikkum Thotiyotu
Tholkavin Vaatiya Thol
T.Kannan: My bracelets slip; the charm of my shoulders withers away. It proclaims the cruelty of the heartless one.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Bereft of bracelets and old beauty 
Arms tell the cruel's cruelty.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
These Wasted arms, the bracelet with their wonted beauty gone,
The cruelty declare of that most cruel one.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Drooping shoulders, its fading beauty
And slipping bracelets declare his cruelty.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The (loosened) bracelets, and the shoulders from which the old beauty has faded, relate the cruelty of the pitiless one.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Drooping shoulders and slipping bracelets,
These I bear; to call him cruel, unbearable.
Transliteration: With loose bangles and leaner shoulders, I still feel pained to hear him called cruel; I cannot bear any affront to my lord’s fair name.
T.Kannan:
Thotiyotu Tholnekizha Noval Avaraik
Kotiyar Enakkooral Nondhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Arms thin, armlets loose make you call 
My sire cruel; that pains my soul.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
I grieve. 'tis pain to me to hear him cruel chid,
Because the armlet from my wasted arm has slid.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Drooping shoulders and slipping bracelets,
These I bear; to call him cruel, unbearable.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: I am greatly pained to hear you call him a cruel man, just because your shoulders are reduced and your bracelets loosened.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: “O my heart, do you desire to cover yourself with glory? Then go to the cruel one and tell him the wasting away of my shoulders and these rumours of cruelty abroad.”
Transliteration:
Can you, O heart, gain glory by relating
that cruel man The woes of my fading shoulders?
T.Kannan:
Paatu Perudhiyo Nenje Kotiyaarkken
Vaatudhot Poosal Uraiththu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Go and tell the cruel, O mind 
Bruit ov'r my arms and glory find.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
My heart! Say ought of glory wilt thou gain,
If to that cruel one thou of thy wasted arms complain?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Can you O my soul! gain glory by relating to the (so-called) cruel one the clamour of my fading shoulders?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Can you, O heart, gain glory by relating that cruel man
The woes of my fading shoulders?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: He soliloquising: “once when I gently loosened my hands from an ecstatic embrace, the forehead of my love suddenly turned pale. I wonder
Transliteration:
For once I relaxed my hugging arms, This
poor girl’s forehead turned pale.
T.Kannan:
Muyangiya Kaikalai Ookkap
Pasandhadhu
Paindhotip Pedhai Nudhal
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The front of this fair one O paled 
As my clasping arms loosed their hold.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
One day the fervent pressure of embracing arms I checked,
Grew wan the forehead of the maid with golden armlet decked.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: When I once loosened the arms that were in embrace, the forehead of the gold-braceleted women turned sallow.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
For once I relaxed my hugging arms,
This poor girl’s forehead turned pale.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Cool breeze crept between our embrace;
Her large rain-cloud eyes paled at once.
Transliteration:
Cool breeze crept between our embrace; Her
large rain-cloud eyes paled at once.
T.Kannan:
Muyakkitaith Thanvali Pozhap
Pasapputra
Pedhai Perumazhaik Kan
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Cool breeze crept between our embrace 
Her large rain cloud eyes paled at once.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
As we embraced a breath of wind found entrance there;
The maid's large liquid eyes were dimmed with care.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: When but a breath of breeze penetrated our embrace, her large cool eyes became sallow.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: “The still eyes of my love dark as the rain bearing cloud turned sickly pale the moment a gust of wind crept in between our locked arms; how does she bear the estranging seas and mountains hurled in between us now?”

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Seeing the once bright forehead grow pale,
Her eyes too suffered and grew pale!
Transliteration:
Seeing the once bright forehead grow pale,
Her eyes too suffered and grew pale!
T.Kannan:
Kannin Pasappo Paruvaral Eydhindre
Onnudhal Seydhadhu Kantu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pale eyes pained seeing the pallor 
Of the bright forehead of this fair.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Was it at the sight of what the bright forehead had done that the sallowness of her eyes became sad?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The dimness of her eye felt sorrow now,
Beholding what was done by that bright brow.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: “Her eyes turned lustreless at the release of my arms from their close embrace; was it in sympathy with the fading brightness of her forehead?”

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My heart, can't you suggest any remedy at all
For this incurable sickness?
Transliteration:
My heart, can't you suggest any remedy at
all For this incurable sickness?
T.Kannan:
Ninaiththondru Sollaayo Nenje
Enaiththondrum
Evvanoi Theerkkum Marundhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: O my soul, will you not think and tell me some medicine be it what it may, that can cure this incurable malady?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Think of, O heart, some remedy 
To cure this chronic malady.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
My heart, canst thou not thinking of some med'cine tell,
Not any one, to drive away this grief incurable?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: O heart! can you not cast about and find a remedy for my lovesickness which causes me such sorrow?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
O my heart! How foolish you are to grieve for him
Who has no love for me!
Transliteration: May you live, O my soul! While he is without love, for you to suffer is (simple) folly.
T.Kannan:
O my heart! How foolish you are to grieve
for him Who has no love for me!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kaadhal Avarilar Aakanee Novadhu
Pedhaimai Vaazhiyen Nenju
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Bless O mind! you pine in vain
For me he has no love serene.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: ‘Blessed may you be O heart! how foolish of you to bemoan separation when he has no love for you!’
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Since he loves not, thy smart
Is folly, fare thee well, my heart!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
O heart, what use to stay here and pine
When he who caused this sickness is heartless?
Transliteration: O my soul! why remain (here) and suffer thinking (of him)? There are no lewd thoughts (of you) in him who has caused you this disease of sorrow.
T.Kannan:
O heart, what use to stay here and pine
When he who caused this sickness is heartless?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Irundhulli Enparidhal Nenje
Parindhullal
Paidhalnoi Seydhaarkan Il
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: ‘O heart! Why stay in vain here and feel wretched? There is no sympathy in the heart of him who has caused you this wasting disease.’
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
O mind, why pine and sit moody? 
Who made you so pale lacks pity.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What comes of sitting here in pining thought, O heart? He knows
No pitying thought, the cause of all these wasting woes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Rid me of these eyes, O my heart! For they,
Longing to see him, wear my life away.
Transliteration: O my soul! take my eyes also with you, (if not), these would eat me up (in their desire) to see him.
T.Kannan:
Rid me of these eyes, O my heart! For
they, Longing to see him, wear my life away.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: ‘O my heart! if you go to him, take my eyes also with you. They eat into my being in their craving to see him.’
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Kannum Kolachcheri Nenje
Ivaiyennaith
Thinnum Avarkkaanal Utru
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Take these eyes and meet him, O heart 
Or their hunger will eat me out.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
O rid me of these eyes, my heart; for they,
Longing to see him, wear my life away.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
O heart, as a foe, can I abandon utterly
Him who, though I long for him, longs not for me?
Transliteration: O my soul! can he who loves not though he is beloved, be forsaken saying he hates me (now)?
T.Kannan:
O heart, can I call him a foe and dump him
Who longs not for me though I long for him?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: ‘O heart! can I really forsake him as cruel though he has used me cruelly when I clung to him.’
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
O heart, can I call him a foe and dump him
Who longs not for me though I long for him?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Setraar Enakkai Vitalunto Nenjeyaam
Utraal Uraaa Thavar
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
He spurns our love and yet, O mind, 
Can we desert him as unkind?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My heart, false is the fire that burns; thou canst not wrath maintain,
If thou thy love behold, embracing, soothing all thy pain.
Transliteration: O my soul! when you see the dear one who remove dislike by intercourse, you are displeased and continue to be so. Nay, your displeasure is (simply) false.
T.Kannan:
My heart that pretends to be angry will at once
Yield and jell seeing my lover.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: ‘O my heart I could you ever bear even a mock quarrel with your lover to sweeten his company Then why call him cruel now for your own fault?’
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
My heart that pretends to be angry will at
once Yield and jell seeing my lover.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Kalandhunarththum Kaadhalark Kantaar
Pulandhunaraai
Poikkaaivu Kaaidhien Nenju
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Wrath is false, O heart, face to face. 
Sans huff, you rush to his sweet embrace.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Off with love O mind, or shame 
I cannot endure both of them.
Transliteration:
Or bid thy love, or bid thy shame depart;
For me , I cannot bear them both, my worthy heart!
T.Kannan: O my good soul, give up either lust or honour, as for me I can endure neither.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: My good heart I cast off one of the two - love or bashfulness. I cannot bear the insupportable weight of them both.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
O my good heart! Either shed shame or shed love
For I cannot bear both.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
O my good heart! Either shed shame or shed
love For I cannot bear both.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Kaamam Vituondro Naanvitu Nannenje
Yaano Poreniv Virantu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Parindhavar Nalkaarendru Engip
Pirindhavar
Pinselvaai Pedhaien Nenju
Transliteration:
Without pity he would depart! 
You sigh and seek his favour, poor heart!
T.Kannan: You are a fool, O my soul! to go after my departed one, while you mourn that he is not kind enough to favour you.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thou art befooled, my heart, thou followest him who flees from thee;
And still thou yearning criest; 'He will nor pity show nor love to me;
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: ‘You go seeking with a hopeless aching heart after the far-off lover, because he has not understood and favoured you with his mercy. O foolish heart!’
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
O my poor soul! You persist in pursuit of the departed,
Longing for his favours!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
O my poor soul! You persist in pursuit of
the departed, Longing for his favours!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ullaththaar Kaadha Lavaraal Ullinee
Yaaruzhaich Cheriyen Nenju
Transliteration: O my soul! to whom would you repair, while the dear one is within yourself?
T.Kannan:
The lover lives in Self you know; 
Whom you think, mind to whom you go?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
My heart! My lover lives within my mind;
Roaming, whom dost thou think to find?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: ‘O my heart, is it you keep your lover within you? Then whom do you search in your thoughts? Why search for him outside? Whom do you hope to reach?’
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Where are you searching my heart
While you know my dear one is within?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Where are you searching my heart While you
know my dear one is within?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If I retain in my heart him who has left me without befriending me, I shall lose even the (inward) beauty that remains.
Transliteration:
To retain the deserter still in my heart
Is to suffer losing more charm.
T.Kannan:
Thunnaath Thurandhaarai Nenjaththu
Utaiyemaa
Innum Izhaththum Kavin
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Without a thought he deserted us 
To think of him will make us worse.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The more I have him in my heart who has left me never to come back, the more my beauty wastes away.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If I Should keep in mind the man who utterly renounces me,
My soul must suffer further loss of dignity.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To retain the deserter still in my heart
Is to suffer losing more charm.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The axe of love can break open the door of
chastity Secured by the bolt of modesty.
Transliteration:
Kaamak Kanichchi Utaikkum
Niraiyennum
Naanuththaazh Veezhththa Kadhavu
T.Kannan: The door of my maidenly grace and the bolt and bars of modesty are hewn by the weapon of restless love.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Passion's axe shall break the door 
Of reserve bolted with my honour.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Of womanly reserve love's axe breaks through the door,
Barred by the bolt of shame before.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The axe of love can break open the door of chastity
Secured by the bolt of modesty.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The axe of lust can break the door of chastity which is bolted with the bolt of modesty.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
That pitiless thing called Love Exploits
my heart even at night.
Transliteration: Verily the thing called love has no grace; even at dead of night it rules my heart and keeps it awake when all the world is in slumber.
T.Kannan:
Kaamam Enavondro Kannindren
Nenjaththai
Yaamaththum Aalum Thozhil
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The thing called lust is a heartless power 
It sways my mind at midnight hour.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What men call love is the one thing of merciless power;
It gives my soul no rest, e'en in th midnight hour.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
That pitiless thing called Love
Exploits my heart even at night.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Even at midnight is my mind worried by lust, and this one thing, alas! is without mercy.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: I strive to hide this - my passion. Yet it breaks out against my wish like a sudden sneeze.
Transliteration:
Fain would I hide my love, but it breaks
out Unawares like a sneeze.
T.Kannan:
Maraippenman Kaamaththai Yaano
Kurippindrith
Thummalpol Thondri Vitum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
How to hide this lust which shows 
Itself while I sneeze unawares!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
I would my love conceal, but like a sneeze
It shows itself, and gives no warning sign.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: I would conceal my lust, but alas, it yields not to my will but breaks out like a sneeze.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Fain would I hide my love, but it breaks out
Unawares like a sneeze.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: I pride myself on my modesty. But my passion breaks all barriers and brings me out into the open.
Transliteration:
In modesty I deemed myself beyond assail;
But love has now cast away the veil.
T.Kannan:
Niraiyutaiyen Enpenman Yaanoen
Kaamam
Maraiyirandhu Mandru Patum
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
I was proud of my sex reserve 
Lo lust betrays what I preserve.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
In womanly reserve I deemed myself beyond assail;
But love will come abroad, and casts away the veil.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: I say I would be firm, but alas, my malady breaks out from its concealment and appears in public.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
In modesty I deemed myself beyond assail;
But love has now cast away the veil.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The dignity of not pursuing the indifferent
Is one thing unknown to the love-sick.
Transliteration:
The dignity of not pursuing the
indifferent Is one thing unknown to the love-sick.
T.Kannan:
Setraarpin Sellaap Perundhakaimai
Kaamanoi
Utraar Arivadhondru Andru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Dignity seeks not a deserter 
But Love sick is its innovator.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The dignity that seeks not him who acts as foe,
Is the one thing that loving heart can never know.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The dignity that would not go after an absent lover is not known to those who are sticken by love.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Victims of passion can never understand the nobility of giving up the pursuit of unrequited love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
What sort of passion is this that induces me
To follow the very one who deserted me?
Transliteration:
What sort of passion is this that induces
me To follow the very one who deserted me?
T.Kannan:
Setravar Pinseral Venti Aliththaro
Etrennai Utra Thuyar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
O Grief, my deserter you seek 
Of your caprice what shall I speak!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The sorrow I have endured by desiring to go after my absent lover, in what way is it excellent?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
My grief how full of grace, I pray you see!
It seeks to follow him that hateth me.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: How cruel is the malady which sends me after the heartless one! Mine is indeed a pitiable lot.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When the lover does all we desire,
We forget all shame unawares.
Transliteration:
When the lover does all we desire, We
forget all shame unawares.
T.Kannan:
Naanena Ondro Ariyalam Kaamaththaal
Peniyaar Petpa Seyin
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: I know nothing like shame when my beloved does from love (just) what is desired (by me).
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
When lover's love does what it desires 
We forget all shame unawares.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
No sense of shame my gladdened mind shall prove,
When he returns my longing heart to bless with love.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When the loved one, after all his vagaries, took me into his loving embraces all my bashfulness fled away.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Are not the enticing words of this wily fraud
Weapons that break my feminine reserve?
Transliteration: Are not the enticing words of my trick-abounding roguish lover the weapon that breaks away my feminine firmness?
T.Kannan:
Are not the enticing words of this wily
fraud Weapons that break my feminine reserve?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Panmaayak Kalvan Panimozhi Andronam
Penmai Utaikkum Patai
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The cheater of many wily arts 
His tempting words break through women's hearts.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: The weapon that shatters our maidenly reserve is none other than the talk of the artful lover.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The words of that deceiver, versed in every wily art,
Are instruments that break through every guard of woman's heart!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Determined to sulk I went, but when my heart merged,
I too went and clasped him.
Transliteration: I said I would feign dislike and so went (away); (but) I embraced him the moment I say my mind began to unite with him!
T.Kannan:
Determined to sulk I went, but when my
heart merged, I too went and clasped him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Pulappal Enachchendren Pullinen
Nenjam
Kalaththal Uruvadhu Kantu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: With the fixed resolve of forsaking him I went, but my heart yielded to his embrace.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In huff I went and felt at ease 
Heat to heart in sweet embrace.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
I' ll shun his greeting'; saying thus with pride away I went;
I held him in my arms, for straight I felt my heart relent.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Can they ever think of refusing to be reconciled,
Whose hearts melt like fat in fire?
Transliteration: Is it possible for those whose hearts melt like fat in the fire to say they can feign a strong dislike and remain so?
T.Kannan:
Can they ever think of refusing to be
reconciled, Whose hearts melt like fat in fire?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: People with hearts melting like fat at the touch of fire — how can they reject the offered love and stand aloof?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ninandheeyil Ittanna Nenjinaarkku
Unto
Punarndhooti Nirpem Enal
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To feign dislike is it not rare
For mates who melt like fat in fire?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
We' ll stand aloof and then embrace'; Is this for them to say,
Whose hearts are as the fat that in the blaze dissolves away?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My eyes have lost their brightness, sight is dimmed, my fingers worn,
With noting on the well the days since I was left forlorn.
Transliteration: My finger has worn away by marking (on the wall) the days he has been absent while my eyes have lost their lustre and begin to fail.
T.Kannan:
My eyes have lost their glow and my fingers worn out
Marking the days of his absence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Counting the days of his separation, my fingers have become wasted and worn out; my eyes have grown dim and faint.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
My eyes have lost their glow and my
fingers worn out Marking the days of his absence.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Vaalatrup Purkendra Kannum
Avarsendra
Naalotrith Theyndha Viral
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
My eyes are dim lustre bereft 
Worn fingers count days since he left.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
O thou with gleaming jewels decked, could I forget for this one day,
Henceforth these bracelets from my arms will slip, my beauty worn away.
Transliteration: O you bright-jewelled maid, if I forget (him) today, my shoulders will lose their beauty even in the other life and make my bracelets loose.
T.Kannan:
What if I forget him now, my bright jewel?
For it costs my beauty and armlets!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: O! bright girl, if I forget my lord today, then my shoulders will become thin and my bangles loose.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What if I forget him now, my bright jewel?
For it costs my beauty and armlets!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Ilangizhaai Indru Marappinen Tholmel
Kalangazhiyum Kaarikai Neeththu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Beauty pales and my bracelets slide; 
Why not forget him now, bright maid?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Will as guide he went to win
Yet I live to see him again.
Transliteration:
On victory intent,
His mind sole company he went; And I yet life Sustain!And long to see his face again!
T.Kannan: I still live by longing for the arrival of him who has gone out of love for victory and with valour as his guide.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: I continue to live in eager expectation of the return of my lover. He took with him as his friend his own brave heart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
He parted from me longing for conquests;
And if I live yet, it is longing for his return.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
He parted from me longing for conquests;
And if I live yet, it is longing for his return.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Urannasaii Ullam Thunaiyaakach
Chendraar
Varalnasaii Innum Ulen

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Kootiya Kaamam Pirindhaar Varavullik
Kotuko Terumen Nenju
Transliteration:
My heart in rapture heaves to see 
His retun with love to embrace me.
T.Kannan: My heart is rid of its sorrow and swells with rapture to think of my absent lover returning with his love.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
He comes again, who left my side, and I shall taste love's joy,; 
My heart with rapture swells, when thoughts like these my mind employ.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: With the thought of my lover’s return anxious for reunion, my heart goes on climbing higher and higher.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The thought of reunion when my love returns
Makes my heart burgeon higher and higher.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The thought of reunion when my love
returns Makes my heart burgeon higher and higher.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Kaankaman Konkanaik Kannaarak
Kantapin
Neengumen Mendhol Pasappu
Transliteration: May I look on my lover till I am satisfied and thereafter will vanish the sallowness of my slender shoulders.
T.Kannan:
Let me but gaze and gaze my spouse
sallow on my soft shoulders flies.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
O let me see my spouse again and sate these longing eyes!
That instant from my wasted frame all pallor flies.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: After feasting my eyes with the sight of my husband, my soft shoulders will lose their pallor.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Pallor will soon disappear from my slim shoulders,
Once my eyes feast seeing him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Pallor will soon disappear from my slim
shoulders, Once my eyes feast seeing him.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: May my husband return some day; and then will I enjoy (him) so as to destroy all this agonizing sorrow.
Transliteration:
Enough if he returns for a day, I will
gorge him till all my ills vanish.
T.Kannan:
Varukaman Konkan Orunaal Parukuvan
Paidhalnoi Ellaam Keta
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Let my spouse return just a day 
Joy drink shall drive my pain away.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Let my husband come here one day. Then my wasting disease will be completely cured.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
O let my spouse but come again to me one day!
I'll drink that nectar; wasting grief shall flee away.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Enough if he returns for a day,
I will gorge him till all my ills vanish.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When he, dear as my eyes, returns, Should
I frown or embrace him or do both?
Transliteration:
Pulappenkol Pulluven Kollo
Kalappenkol
Kananna Kelir Viran
T.Kannan: When my husband, dear to me as my eyes, returns, shall I be indifferent or complaining? Shall I not be one with him?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
If my eye like lord returneth 
Shall I sulk or clasp or do both?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Shall I draw back, or yield myself, or shall both mingled be,
When he returns, my spouse dear as these eyes to me.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When he, dear as my eyes, returns,
Should I frown or embrace him or do both?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: On the return of him who is as dear as my eyes, am I displeased or am I to embrace (him); or am I to do both?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
May the king succeed in his efforts! I can
then join my wife and party in the evenings.
Transliteration: May my lord be victorious in action and may I also go home to enjoy my evening repast with a guest.
T.Kannan:
Vinaikalandhu Vendreeka Vendhan
Manaikalandhu
Maalai Ayarkam Virundhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
May the king fight and win and give 
And with my wife I will feast this eve!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
O would my king would fight, o'ercome, divide the spoil;
At home, to night the banquet spread should crown the toil.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
May the king succeed in his efforts!
I can then join my wife and party in the evenings.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Let the king fight and gain (victories); (but) let me be united to my wife and feast the evening.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: To one who awaits the day of arrival of her husband, one day appears as long as seven.
Transliteration:
Even a day will seem seven to those Who
long for the day of their mate’s return.
T.Kannan:
Orunaal Ezhunaalpol Sellumsen
Sendraar
Varunaalvaiththu Engu Pavarkku
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
One day seems as seven to those
Who yearn return of distant spouse.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
One day will seem like seven, to those who watch and yearn
For that glad day when wanderers from afar return.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: To those who suffer waiting for the day of return of their distant lovers one day is as long as seven days.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Even a day will seem seven to those
Who long for the day of their mate’s return.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If her heart has been broken, of what avail is it if I become available to her, reach her or even join her?
Transliteration:
To one dead of a broken heart, what avails
my return, Meeting or even embrace?
T.Kannan:
Perinennaam Petrakkaal Ennaam
Urinennaam
Ullam Utaindhukkak Kaal
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
When her heart is broken, what is 
The good of meeting and love embrace?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
What's my return, the meeting hour, the wished for greeting worth,
If the heart broken lie, with all her life poured forth?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: After (my wife) has died of a broken heart, what good will there be if she is to receive me, has received me, or has even embraced me?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To one dead of a broken heart, what avails my return,
Meeting or even embrace?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Even if you hide, your divulging eyes reveal
That something lurks your mind.
Transliteration:
Even if you hide, your divulging eyes
reveal That something lurks your mind.
T.Kannan:
Karappinung Kaiyikan Thollaanin
Unkan
Uraikkal Uruvadhon Runtu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
You hide; but your painted eyes 
Restraint off, report your surmise.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
She cannot hide her dread of his departure.
He reads the sign, and says:Thou hid'st it, yet thine eye, disdaining all restraint,Something, I know not what, would utter of complaint.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Though you would conceal (your feelings), your painted eyes would not, for, transgressing (their bounds), they tell (me) something.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though you hide it, your uncontrolled eyes reveal a secret to me.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Her eye catching beauty and bamboo shoulders
Simply enhance her feminine reserve!
Transliteration:
Her eye catching beauty and bamboo
shoulders Simply enhance her feminine reserve!
T.Kannan:
Kanniraindha Kaarikaik Kaamperdhot
Pedhaikkup
Penniraindha Neermai Peridhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
With seemly grace and stem like arms 
The simple she has ample charms.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Unusually great is the female simplicity of your maid whose beauty fills my eyes and whose shoulders resemble the bamboo.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The simple one whose beauty fills mine eye, whose shoulders curve
Like bambu stem, hath all a woman's modest sweet reserve.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: This girl of long eyes and bamboo shoulders has too much womanly modesty.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Something shines in her jeweled charm,
Like the thread shining in a crystal bead.
Transliteration:
Something shines in her jeweled charm,
Like the thread shining in a crystal bead.
T.Kannan:
Maniyil Thikazhdharu Noolpol
Matandhai
Aniyil Thikazhvadhondru Untu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: There is something that is implied in the beauty of this woman, like the thread that is visible in a garland of gems.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Something shines through her jewelled charm 
Like thread shining through wreathed gem.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
As through the crystal beads is seen the thread on which they're strung
So in her beauty gleams some thought cannot find a tongue.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Just like the thread concealed by the beads there is something lying beneath this damsel’s beauty.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Something lurks behind her half smile
Like the fragrance in a flower bud.
Transliteration: There is something in the unmatured smile of this maid like the fragrance that is contained in an unblossomed bud.
T.Kannan:
Something lurks behind her half smile Like
the fragrance in a flower bud.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Mukaimokkul Ulladhu Naatrampol
Pedhai
Nakaimokkul Ulladhon Runtu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Like scent in bud secrets conceal 
In the bosom of her half smile.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even as the fragrance that is locked up in the bud, there is something hidden in this damsel’s smile.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
As fragrance in the opening bud, some secret lies
Concealed in budding smile of this dear damsel's eyes.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The trickery caused by the braceleted one
Carries the medicine to cure my ills as well.
Transliteration: The well-meant departure of her whose bangles are tight-fitting contains a remedy that can cure my great sorrow.
T.Kannan:
The trickery caused by the braceleted one
Carries the medicine to cure my ills as well.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Seridhoti Seydhirandha Kallam
Urudhuyar
Theerkkum Marundhondru Utaiththu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The tactful departure of my bangled lady serves as soothing balm for my excruciating pain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The close bangled belle's hidden thought 
Has a cure for my troubled heart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
The secret wiles of her with thronging armlets decked,
Are medicines by which by raising grief is checked.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The lack of love in his embrace implies that
More sufferings are in store for me.
Transliteration: The embrace that fills me with comfort and gladness is capable of enduring (my former) sorrow and meditating on his want of love.
T.Kannan:
The lack of love in his embrace implies
that More sufferings are in store for me.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: The pleasant union after the distress of separation still reminds one of the past indifference of the lover.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Peridhaatrip Petpak Kalaththal
Aridhaatri
Anpinmai Soozhva Thutaiththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
His over kind close embrace sooths; 
But makes me feel, loveless, he parts.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
While lovingly embracing me, his heart is only grieved;
It makes me think that I again shall live of love bereaved.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My severance from the lord of this cool shore,
My very armlets told me long before.
Transliteration: My bracelets have understood before me the (mental) separation of him who rules the cool seashore.
T.Kannan:
Even before I could, my bangles figured out
The immanent separation from my lord.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: My bangles betrayed even before I did my lover’s separation from me.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Even before I could, my bangles figured
out The immanent separation from my lord.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Thannan Thuraivan Thanandhamai
Namminum
Munnam Unarndha Valai
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Quick, my bracelets read before 
The mind of my lord of cool shore.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My loved one left me, was it yesterday?
Days seven my pallid body wastes away!
Transliteration: It was but yesterday my lover departed (from me); and it is seven days since my complexion turned sallow.
T.Kannan:
My lord left only yesterday,
And I already have a week's pallor.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: It was only yesterday that my lover went, but I have acquired seven days’ pallor.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
My lord left only yesterday, And I already
have a week's pallor.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Nerunatruch Chendraarem Kaadhalar
Yaamum
Ezhunaalem Meni Pasandhu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
My lover parted but yesterday; 
With sallowness it is seventh day.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
She views her armlets, her tender arms 
And then her feet; these are her norms.
Transliteration:
She would join him,but shrinks from proposing it.
Her companion reads the sign, andsays:She viewed her tender arms, she viewed the armlets from them slid;She viewed her feet; all this the lady did.
T.Kannan: She looked at her bracelets, her tender shoulders, and her feet; this was what she did there (significantly).
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: She looks at her bangles; she looks at her beautiful shoulders and she looks down at her feet. This is her present occupation.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
She did no more than show me her loose bracelets,
Slender shoulders and swollen feet.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
She did no more than show me her loose
bracelets, Slender shoulders and swollen feet.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Thotinokki Mendholum Nokki Atinokki
Aqdhaan Tavalsey Thadhu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Penninaal Penmai Utaiththenpa
Kanninaal
Kaamanoi Solli Iravu
Transliteration:
To express love pangs by eyes and pray 
Is womanhood's womanly way.
T.Kannan: To express their love-sickness by their eyes and resort to begging bespeaks more than ordinary female excellence.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
He is overcome.
To show by eye the pain of love, and for relief to pray,Is womanhood's most womaly device, men say.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: The eyes seek the cure of passion. It is the modesty of a modest woman.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
They say a woman is most womanly
When she makes her eyes declare and plead.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
They say a woman is most womanly When she
makes her eyes declare and plead.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ullak Kaliththalum Kaana
Makizhdhalum
Kallukkil Kaamaththir Kuntu
Transliteration: To please by thought and cheer by sight is peculiar, not to liquor but lust.
T.Kannan:
Rapture at thought and joy when seen 
Belong to love and not to wine.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
She answers the question Why are you not angry
with him who, unmindful of you, is preparing for departure:Gladness at the thought , rejoicing at the sight,Not palm tree wine, but love, yields such delight.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: To become pleased with the thought and happy at the sight of the lover, these are the fruits not of wine but of love.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To please with the thought and delight with the sight,
Belongs not to liquor but love.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
To please with the thought and delight
with the sight, Belongs not to liquor but love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: If women have a lust that exceeds even the measure of the palmyra fruit, they will not desire (to feign) dislike even as much as the millet.
Transliteration:
Where love is as large as a palm tree,
Even millet of sulk is misplaced.
T.Kannan:
Thinaiththunaiyum Ootaamai Ventum
Panaith
ThunaiyumKaamam Niraiya Varin
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
When passion grows palmyra tall 
Sulking is wrong though millet small.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: If a woman’s passion becomes excessive, she should avoid even slight misunderstanding.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When as palmyra tall, fulness of perfect love we gain,
Distrust can find no place small as the millet grain.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Where love is as large as a palm tree,
Even millet of sulk is misplaced.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Let him neglect me and do what he will. My
eyes will not rest till they see him.
Transliteration:
Penaadhu Petpave Seyyinum Konkanaik
Kaanaa Thamaiyala Kan
T.Kannan: Though my husband acts regardless of me, yet my eyes cannot be satisfied without seeing him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Though slighting me he acts his will 
My restless eyes would see him still.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Although, his will his only law, he lightly value me,
My heart knows no repose unless my lord I see.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Let him neglect me and do what he will.
My eyes will not rest till they see him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Though my eyes disregard me and do what is pleasing to my husband, still will they not be satisfied unless they see him.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My friend, I went all set to quarrel, But
my heart forgot and clasped him.
Transliteration: O Friend! I went to quarrel with him; but forgetting it my heart sought for reconciliation.
T.Kannan:
Ootarkan Sendrenman Thozhi
Adhumarandhu
Kootarkan SendradhuEn Nenju
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Huff I would, maid, but I forget;
And leap to embrace him direct.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
My friend, I went prepared to show a cool disdain;
My heart, forgetting all, could not its love restrain.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
My friend, I went all set to quarrel,
But my heart forgot and clasped him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: O my friend! I was prepared to feign displeasure but my mind forgetting it was ready to embrace him.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Just as our eyes do not see the pen when writing I could not see my lover’s faults when I saw him.
Transliteration:
Like eyes that can’t see the painting
brush, I don’t see his faults when I see him.
T.Kannan:
Ezhudhungaal Kolkaanaak Kannepol
Konkan
Pazhikaanen Kanta Itaththu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
When close I see not lord's blemish 
Like eyes that see not painter's brush.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The eye sees not the rod that paints it; nor can I
See any fault, when I behold my husband high.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Like the eyes which see not the pencil that paints it, I cannot see my husband's fault (just) when I meet him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Like eyes that can’t see the painting brush,
I don’t see his faults when I see him.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When I see my husband I cannot see his faults. In his absence I cannot see anything else.
Transliteration:
When I see him I see no faults, and when I
don't, I see nothing but faults!
T.Kannan:
Kaanungaal Kaanen Thavaraaya
Kaanaakkaal
Kaanen Thavaral Lavai
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
When he's with me I see not fault 
And nought but fault when he is not.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
When him I see, to all his faults, I'm blind;
But when I see him not , nothing but faults I find.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: When I see my husband, I do not see any faults; but when I do not see him, I do not see anything but faults.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When I see him I see no faults, and when I don't,
I see nothing but faults!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
It is folly to plunge into a known raging stream.
Likewise, why sulk and plumb known lies?
Transliteration:
It is folly to plunge into a known raging
stream. Likewise, why sulk and plumb known lies?
T.Kannan:
Uyththal Arindhu Punalpaai Pavarepol
Poiththal Arindhen Pulandhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To leap in stream which carries off
When lord is close to feign a huff.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
As those of rescue sure, who plunge into the stream,
So did I anger feign, though it must falsehood seem?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Like those who leap into a stream which they know will carry them off, why should a wife feign dislike which she knows cannot hold out long?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Of what avail is it to sift all the lies of one’s husband! It is as ineffectual as a diver battling with an irresistible current.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The drunkard seeks wine knowing well its shame;
So does your bosom to me, O thief!
Transliteration:
The drunkard seeks wine knowing well its
shame; So does your bosom to me, O thief!
T.Kannan:
Iliththakka Innaa Seyinum
Kaliththaarkkuk
Kallatre Kalvanin Maarpu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Like wine to addicts that does disgrace 
Your breast, O thief, is for my embrace!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: O you rogue! your breast is to me what liquor is to those who rejoice in it, though it only gives them an unpleasant disgrace.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Though shameful ill it works, dear is the palm tree wine
To drunkards; traitor, so to me that breast of thine!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: O cheat! your breast is coveted more and more even as liquor with all its harm is by the drunkard.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Love is more delicate than flower;
Not many handle it properly.
Transliteration:
Love is more delicate than flower; Not
many handle it properly.
T.Kannan:
Malarinum Mellidhu Kaamam Silaradhan
Sevvi Thalaippatu Vaar
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Sexual delight is more delicate than a flower, and few are those who understand its real nature.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Flower soft is love; a few alone 
Know its delicacy so fine.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
He muses:
Love is tender as an opening flower. In season dueTo gain its perfect bliss is rapture known to few.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: More tender than a flower is love and few are they who enjoy it fully.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Though hostile in the eyes, she was faster than me
To break down and unite.
Transliteration: She once feigned dislike in her eyes, but the warmth of her embrace exceeded my own.
T.Kannan:
Though hostile in the eyes, she was faster
than me To break down and unite.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Kannin Thuniththe Kalanginaal
Pulludhal
Enninum Thaanvidhup Putru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
She feigned dislike awhile but flew 
Faster for embrace than I do.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: With resentful eyes, my lady complained: but eager for reconciliation she forgets her anger.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Her eye, as I drew nigh one day, with anger shone;
By love o'erpowered, her tenderness surpassed my own.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My heart! You see his heart and stand by him,
But why don’t you stand by me?
Transliteration: O my soul! although you have seen how his soul stands by him, how is it you do not stand by me?
T.Kannan:
My heart! You see his heart and stand by
him, But why don’t you stand by me?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Avarnenju Avarkkaadhal Kantum
Evannenje
Neeemakku Aakaa Thadhu
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: O! My heart, though you know that my husband’s heart thinks only o^ himself, how is it you think of him and not of me?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
You see, his heart is his alone; 
Why not my heart be all my own?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
You see his heart is his alone;
O heart, why not be all my own?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
My heart! Having seen his indifference,
Why do you go after him in hope?
Transliteration: O my soul! although you have known him who does not love me, still do you go to him, saying "he will not be displeased."
T.Kannan:
My heart! Having seen his indifference,
Why do you go after him in hope?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: O! My heart, knowing that he has no thought for you, still you run after him expecting no refusal.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Uraaa Thavarkkanta Kannum Avaraich
Cheraaarenach Cheriyen Nenju
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
O heart, you see how he slights me 
Yet you clasp him as if friendly.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Tis plain , my heart, that he's estranged from thee;
Why go to him as though he were not enemy?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The ruined have no friends, 'they say; and so my heart,
To follow him, at thy desire, from me thou dost depart.
Transliteration: O my soul! do you follow him at pleasure under the belief that the ruined have no friends?
T.Kannan:
O my heart! Is it because the fallen have no friends
That you madly run after him?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: ! My heart, you go after him without my permission. Is it because none will befriend those in adversity?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
O my heart! Is it because the fallen have
no friends That you madly run after him?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Kettaarkku Nattaaril Enpadho
Nenjenee
Pettaangu Avarpin Selal
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
You follow him at will. Is it 
"The fallen have no friends" my heart?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
See, thou first show offended pride, and then submit,' I bade;
Henceforth such council who will share with thee, my heart?
Transliteration: O my soul! you would not first seem sulky and then enjoy (him); who then would in future consult you about such things?
T.Kannan:
Who will consult you hereafter, my heart,
Having failed to sulk before yielding?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: O! My heart, if you see him, you do not resent his faults. Who can consult you for advice?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Who will consult you hereafter, my heart,
Having failed to sulk before yielding?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Inianna Ninnotu Soozhvaaryaar Nenje
Thuniseydhu Thuvvaaikaan Matru
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
You won't sulk first and then submit
Who will then consult you, my heart?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Frets to gain and fears loss in gain 
O my heart suffers ceaseless pain.
Transliteration:
I fear I shall not gain, I fear to lose him when I gain;
And thus my heart endures unceasing pain.
T.Kannan: My soul fears when it is without him; it also fears when it is with him; it is sub ject to incessant sorrow.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: My mind can have only endless anxiety; for I fear both when he is with me and also without me.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Anxious of not getting, and of losing when got,
Either way my heart is always anxious.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Anxious of not getting, and of losing when
got, Either way my heart is always anxious.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Peraaamai Anjum Perinpirivu Anjum
Araaa Itumpaiththen Nenju

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Thaniye Irundhu Ninaiththakkaal
Ennaith
Thiniya Irundhadhen Nenju
Transliteration:
My itching mind eats me anon 
As I muse on him all alone.
T.Kannan: My mind has been (here) in order to eat me up (as it were) whenever I think of him in my solitude.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
My heart consumes me when I ponder lone,
And all my lover's cruelty bemoan.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: My heart eats me up when I think of him in my loneliness.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If my heart stays with me here,
It is to devour me when I am musing alone.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If my heart stays with me here, It is to
devour me when I am musing alone.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Naanum Marandhen Avarmarak Kallaaen
Maanaa Matanenjir Pattu
Transliteration: I have even forgotten my modesty, having been caught in my foolish mind which is not dignified enough to forget him.
T.Kannan:
forget shame but not his thought 
In mean foolish mind I'm caught.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Fall'n neath the sway of this ignoble foolish heart,
Which will not him forget, I have forgotten shame.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: With my foolish heart remembering him who has forgotten me, I have forgotten even my sense of shame.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Even modesty I have forgotten,
Due to my meek and foolish heart unable to forget him.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Even modesty I have forgotten, Due to my
meek and foolish heart unable to forget him.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: My soul which clings to life thinks only of his (own) gain in the belief that it would be disgraceful for it to despise him.
Transliteration:
My dear loving heart decrees, my lord is
not to be shamed And thus hails only his glory.
T.Kannan:
Ellin Ilivaamendru Enni Avardhiram
Ullum Uyirkkaadhal Nenju
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
My heart living in love of him 
Hails his glory ignoring blame.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: My heart that loves life and views it ignoble to blame and to deny access to him, ever thinks of his success.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If I contemn him, then disgrace awaits me evermore;
My soul that seeks to live his virtue numbers o'er.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
My dear loving heart decrees, my lord is not to be shamed
And thus hails only his glory.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Who will help one in distress, When one’s
own heart refuses to help?
Transliteration:
Thunpaththirku Yaare Thunaiyaavaar
Thaamutaiya
Nenjan Thunaiyal Vazhi
T.Kannan: Who will be a friend in misery but one’s own heart?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Who support a man in grief 
If lover's heart denies relief?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
And who will aid me in my hour of grief,
If my own heart comes not to my relief?
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Who will help one in distress,
When one’s own heart refuses to help?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Who would help me out of one's distress, when one's own soul refuses help to one?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
When one's own heart behaves like a
stranger, Why talk of strangers?
Transliteration: If one’s own heart turns against one, how can one expect anything but hostility from others?
T.Kannan:
Thanjam Thamarallar Edhilaar
Thaamutaiya
Nenjam Thamaral Vazhi
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Why wonder if strangers disown 
When one's own heart is not his own?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A trifle is unfriendliness by aliens shown,
When our own heart itself is not our own!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When one's own heart behaves like a stranger,
Why talk of strangers?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: It is hardly possible for strangers to behave like relations, when one's own soul acts like a stranger.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Let us see a little his distress in passion, by showing reserve. ^
Transliteration:
Let me feign to be angry And see his pain
of suffering for a while.
T.Kannan:
Pullaa Thiraaap Pulaththai Avar
UrumAllalnoi Kaankam Siridhu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Feign sulk; embrace him not so that 
We can see his distress a bit.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Be still reserved, declined his profferred love;
A little while his sore distress we'll prove.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Let us witness awhile his keen suffering; just feign dislike and embrace him not.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Let me feign to be angry
And see his pain of suffering for a while.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: Reserve like a pinch of salt adds to enjoyment, If excessive, it spoils the taste.
Transliteration:
Sulking is the salt of love. To prolong it
Is like salt a little too much.
T.Kannan:
Uppamain Thatraal Pulavi Adhusiridhu
Mikkatraal Neela Vital
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Sulking is the salt of love; but 
Too much of it spoils the taste.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
A cool reserve is like the salt that seasons well the mess,
Too long maintained, 'tis like the salt's excess.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: A little dislike is like salt in proportion; to prolong it a little is like salt a little too much.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Sulking is the salt of love. To prolong it
Is like salt a little too much.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To leave a sulky woman alone
Is to cause more pain to the suffering.
Transliteration:
To leave a sulky woman alone Is to cause
more pain to the suffering.
T.Kannan:
Alandhaarai Allalnoi Seydhatraal
Thammaip
Pulandhaaraip Pullaa Vital
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To leave the sulker unembraced 
Is to grieve the one sorely grieved.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Tis heaping griefs on those whose hearts are grieved
To leave the grieving one without a fond embrace.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: For men not to embrace those who have feigned dislike is like torturing those already in agony.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If men do not pacify women who feign coolness, it is like causing more pain to those who already suffer.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
To ignore a lady in pout is to cut
An already withering climber at its root.
Transliteration:
To ignore a lady in pout is to cut An
already withering climber at its root.
T.Kannan:
Ooti Yavarai Unaraamai Vaatiya
Valli Mudhalarin Thatru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
To comfort not lady in pout 
Is to cut the fading plant at root.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Not to reconcile those who have feigned dislike is like cutting a faded creeper at its root.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
To use no kind conciliating art when lover grieves,
Is cutting out the root of tender winding plant that droops.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: Not to pacify the lady who feigns coolness is to cut the withering creeper away at the root.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The beauty of her feigned anger has an attraction
Even for the spotlessly pure men.
Transliteration:
The beauty of her feigned anger has an
attraction Even for the spotlessly pure men.
T.Kannan:
Nalaththakai Nallavarkku Eer
Pulaththakai
Pooanna Kannaar Akaththu
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: An increased shyness in those whose eyes are like flowers is beautiful even to good and virtuous husbands.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pouting of flower eyed has 
To pure good mates a lovely grace.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Even to men of good and worthy mind, the petulance
Of wives with flowery eyes lack not a lovely grace.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The beauty of a loyal lover is only enhanced by the reserve of his flower-eyed lady.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Without frowns and sulking,
Love is like a fruit unripe or overripe.
Transliteration: Sexual pleasure, without prolonged and short-lived dislike, is like too ripe, and unripe fruit.
T.Kannan:
Without frowns and sulking, Love is like a
fruit unripe or overripe.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Thuniyum Pulaviyum Illaayin Kaamam
Kaniyum Karukkaayum Atru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Love devoid of frowns and pets 
Misses its ripe and unripe fruits.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: If indignation and gentle resentment are absent, love will be like fruit over-ripe or unripe.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Love without hatred is as ripened fruit;
Without some lesser strife, fruit immature.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Coyness has this one drawback.
That is the worry of delayed union.
Transliteration: The doubt as to whether intercourse would take place soon or not, creates a sorrow (even) in feigned dislike.
T.Kannan:
Coyness has this one drawback. That is the
worry of delayed union.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Ootalin Untaangor Thunpam Punarvadhu
Neetuva ThandruKol Endru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: There is anxiety and pain in lovers’ uncertain quarrels.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
"Will union take place soon or late?" 
In lover's pout this leaves a doubt.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
A lover's quarrel brings its pain, when mind afraid
Asks doubtful, ' Will reunion sweet long delayed?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Why grieve when the lover is not there
To know whether you are grieving?
Transliteration: What avails sorrow when I am without a wife who can understand the cause of my sorrow?
T.Kannan:
Why grieve when the lover is not there To
know whether you are grieving?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: If a lover were to be blind to the suffering of the lady-love, then the suffering would be in vain.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Nodhal Evanmatru Nondhaarendru
Aqdhariyum
Kaadhalar Illaa Vazhi
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
What's the good of grieving lament 
When concious lover is not present?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
What good can greiving do, when none who love
As there to know the grief they soul endures?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Water is pleasant in the cooling shade;
So coolness for a time with those we love.
Transliteration: Like water in the shade, dislike is delicious only in those who love.
T.Kannan:
Just as the refreshing water in the shade,
Pouting has its charms only between lovers.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Just as water in the shade is sweet, so lovers’ quarrels become sweet only to people deep-rooted in love.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Just as the refreshing water in the shade,
Pouting has its charms only between lovers.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Neerum Nizhaladhu Inidhe Pulaviyum
Veezhunar Kanne Inidhu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Water delights in a shady grove
And sulking in souls of psychic love.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Of her who leaves me thus in variacne languishing,
To think with my heart with love is fond desire.
Transliteration: It is nothing but strong desire that makes her mind unite with me who can leave her to her own dislike.
T.Kannan:
Only my desire makes my heart pine for union
With one who keeps on sulking.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: My heart longs for reunion with him who cares not for my sufferings in the quarrel.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Only my desire makes my heart pine for
union With one who keeps on sulking.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Ootal Unanga Vituvaarotu Ennenjam
Kootuvem Enpadhu Avaa
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
My heart athirst would still unite 
With her who me in sulking left!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
I shrink to clasp you bosom lewd 
To the gaze of all ladies exposed.
Transliteration:
From thy regard all womankind
 Enjoys an equal grace;O thou of wandering fickle mind, I shrink from thine embrace!
T.Kannan: You are given to prostitution; all those who are born as womankind enjoy you with their eyes in an ordinary way. I will not embrace you.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: You yielded yourself to all sorts of women to look at you with their eyes. Therefore I shall not approach your breast.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
I won't clasp your broad chest,
A common dish for all women's eyes to gorge!
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
I won't clasp your broad chest, A common
dish for all women's eyes to gorge!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Penniyalaar Ellaarum Kannin
Podhuunpar
Nannen Paraththanin Maarpu

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ooti Irundhemaath Thumminaar
Yaamdhammai
Neetuvaazh Kenpaak Karindhu
Transliteration:
He sneezed while we went on sulking 
Expecting me to say "live long".
T.Kannan: When I continued to be sulky he sneezed and thought I would (then) wish him a long life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
One day we silent sulked; he sneezed:
 The reason well I knew;He thought that I, to speak well pleased, Would say, 'Long life to you!'
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: When I sat away from him, he sneezed knowing that I would bless him, saying "May you live long.”
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
When I sulked, he sneezed: hoping
I would forget and say Bless you.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When I sulked, he sneezed: hoping I would
forget and say 'Bless you'.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Kottup Pooch Chootinum Kaayum
OruththiyaikKaattiya Sootineer Endru
Transliteration: Even if I were adorned with a garland of branch-flowers, she would say I did so to show it to another woman.
T.Kannan:
"For which lady?" she widely cries 
While I adorn myself with flowers.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
I wreathed with flowers one day my brow,
 The angry tempest lowers;She cries, 'Pray, for what woman now Do you put on your flowers?'
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Even if I put on a garland of hill-flowers, my sweetheart will say “You wore this to please some mistress of yours.”
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
If I wear a wreath, she cries enraged:
For which woman's sake is this?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If I wear a wreath, she cries enraged:
'For which woman's sake is this?'

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When I said I loved her more than any other woman, she said "more than others, yes, more than others," and remained sulky.
Transliteration:
If I say 'I love you more than any one',
She frowned asking, 'Than whom, than whom?'
T.Kannan:
Yaarinum Kaadhalam Endrenaa Ootinaal
Yaarinum Yaarinum Endru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
"I love you more than all" I said 
"Than whom, than whom?" she sulked and chid.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: When I said my beloved was greater than anybody else, she grew angry and repeatedly asked me “Greater than whom?”
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
I love you more than all beside,'
 'T was thus I gently spoke;'What all, What all?' she instant cried; And all her anger woke.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
If I say I love you more than any one,
She frowned asking, Than whom, than whom?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The moment I said we won’t part in this
life, Her eyes were filled with tears.
Transliteration:
Immaip Pirappil Piriyalam Endrenaak
Kannirai Neerkon Tanal
T.Kannan: When I said “We shall not separate in this life”, her eyes were full of tears meaning that I would separate from her in the next life.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
"In this life we won't part" I told 
Her eyes at once with tears were filled.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
While here I live, I leave you not,'
 I said to calm her fears.She cried, 'There, then, I read your thought': And straight dissolved in tears.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
The moment I said we won’t part in this life,
Her eyes were filled with tears.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When I said I would never part from her in this life her eyes were filled with tears.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
I remembered you', I said; 'After
forgetting?' said she withdrawing herself!
Transliteration: When I said ‘I thought of you’, she replied “So you forgot me before” and felt displeased.
T.Kannan:
Ullinen Endrenmar Renmarandheer
Endrennaip
Pullaal Pulaththak Kanal
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
I said "I thought of you". She left 
Her embrace crying "Oft you forget".
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Each day I called to mind your charms,'
 'O, then, you had forgot,'She cried, and then her opened arms, Forthwith embraced me not.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
I remembered you, I said;
After forgetting? said she withdrawing herself!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: When I said I had remembered her, she said I had forgotten her and relaxing her embrace, began to feign dislike.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When I sneezed she blessed me; but she wept and asked me which maiden thought of me when I sneezed.
Transliteration:
She blessed as I sneezed, but soon
recalled it crying: 'Thinking whom did you sneeze?'
T.Kannan:
Vazhuththinaal Thumminen Aaka
Azhiththazhudhaal
Yaarullith Thummineer Endru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
I sneezed; she blessed; then changed and wept 
"You sneezed now at which lady's thought?"
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
She hailed me when I sneezed one day;
 But straight with anger seized,She cried; 'Who was the woman, pray, Thinking of whom you sneezed?'
Ramachandra Dikshitar: When I sneezed she blessed me, but at once changed (her mind) and wept, asking, "At the thought of whom did you sneeze?"
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
She blessed as I sneezed, but soon recalled it crying:
Thinking whom did you sneeze?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary: When I controlled sneezing, she shed fretful tears and asked whether I tried to conceal the fact that others think of me.
Transliteration:
When I suppressed my sneeze, she wept
saying, 'Whom are you hiding from me?'
T.Kannan:
Thummuch Cheruppa Azhudhaal
Numarullal
Emmai Maraiththiro Endru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
I repressed sneeze; she wept crying 
"Your thoughts from me you are hiding".
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
And so next time I checked my sneeze;
 She forthwith wept and cried,(That woman difficult to please), 'Your thoughts from me you hide.'
Ramachandra Dikshitar: When I suppressed my sneezing, she wept saying, "I suppose you (did so) to hide from me your own people's remembrance of you".
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
When I suppressed my sneeze, she wept saying,
Whom are you hiding from me?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If I try making up with her, she would ask enraged,
Is this how you coax others as well?
Transliteration:
If I try making up with her, she would ask
enraged, 'Is this how you coax others as well?'
T.Kannan:
Thannai Unarththinum Kaayum
Pirarkkumneer
Inneerar Aakudhir Endru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
I try to coax her and she remarks
"Your coaxing others thus this marks".
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
I then began to soothe and coax,
 To clam her jealous mind;'I see', quoth she, 'to other folks How you are wondrous kind'
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Even when I try to remove her dislike, she is displeased and says, "This is the way you behave towards (other women)."
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: She will quarrel with me even if I fully satisfy her, saying “You will behave thus to every woman.”

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
If I gaze at her in silence, she would fume and ask,
Thinking of whom this comparison?
Transliteration:
If I gaze at her in silence, she would
fume and ask, 'Thinking of whom this comparison?'
T.Kannan:
Ninaiththirundhu Nokkinum Kaayum
Anaiththuneer
Yaarulli Nokkineer Endru
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
I think and gaze at her; she chides: 
"On whom your thought just now abides?"
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Even when I look on her contemplating (her beauty), she is displeased and says, "With whose thought have you (thus) looked on my person?"
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
I silent sat, but thought the more,
 And gazed on her. Then sheCried out, 'While thus you eye me o'er, Tell me whose form you see'.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: If I look at her silently and appreciate her beauty, she will ask me querulously, “whom you are thinking of?”

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Though he is not to blame, I feign sulking
To bring out the best in him.
Transliteration: Though he is guiltless, false accusations make him more attached.
T.Kannan:
Though he is not to blame, I feign sulking
To bring out the best in him.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Illai Thavaravarkku Aayinum Ootudhal
Valladhu Avaralikku Maaru
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: Although my husband is free from defects, the way in which he embraces me is such as to make me feign dislike.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
He is flawless; but I do pout. 
So that his loving ways show out.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Although there be no fault in him, the sweetness of his love
Hath power in me a fretful jealously to move.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The pinpricks of sulking do not discourage
But strengthen love.
Transliteration: The little resentment resulting from lover’s quarrels yields delight in the end, though it may for the moment seem to cause pain.
T.Kannan: His love will increase though it may (at first seem to) fade through the short-lived distress caused by (my) dislike.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
The pinpricks of sulking do not discourage
But strengthen love.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Ootalin Thondrum Sirudhuni Nallali
Vaatinum Paatu Perum
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Fading first, love blooms and outlives 
The petty pricks that pouting gives.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
My 'anger feigned' Gives but a little pain;
And when affection droops; it makes it bloom again.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Is there a heaven higher than love’s sulk
With hearts that join like earth and water?
Transliteration: Is there a celestial land that can please like the feigned dislike of those whose union resembles that of earth and water?
T.Kannan: Is there any other heaven than the quarrel between lovers whose minds are united even as earth and water?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
Is there a heaven higher than love’s sulk
With hearts that join like earth and water?
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pulaththalin Puththelnaatu Unto
Nilaththotu
Neeriyain Thannaar Akaththu
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Is there a heaven like sulk beneath 
Of hearts that join like water and earth?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Is there a bliss in any world more utterly divine.
Than 'coyness' gives when hearts as earth ahd water join?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
From this prolonged pout arises the weapon
To break the defence of my heart.
Transliteration: In prolonged dislike after an embrace there is a weapon that can break my heart.
T.Kannan: The weapon that breaks my obstinate heart lies in the quarrel itself.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
From this prolonged pout arises the weapon
To break the defence of my heart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Pulli Vitaaap Pulaviyul Thondrumen
Ullam Utaikkum Patai
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In long pout after embrace sweet 
A weapon is up to break my heart.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Within the 'anger feigned' 'that close love's tie doth bind,
A weapon lurks, which quite breaks down my mind.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
II He consoles himself, since reconciliation makes
 amends.Though free from fault, from loved one's tender armsTo be estranged a while hath its own special charms.
Transliteration: Though free from defects, men feel pleased when they cannot embrace the delicate shoulders of those whom they love.
T.Kannan:
Even for the guiltless it is a joy to forgo briefly
The shoulders from one’s clasp.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Though guiltless being denied, there is a pleasure in the embrace of the soft beautiful shoulders of the sweetheart.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Even for the guiltless it is a joy to
forgo briefly The shoulders from one’s clasp.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Thavarilar Aayinum Thaamveezhvaar
Mendrol
Akaralin Aangon Rutaiththu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Though free form faults, one feels the charms 
Of feigned release from lover's arms.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Tis sweeter to digest your food than 'tis to eat;
In love, than union's self is anger feigned more sweet.
Transliteration: To digest what has been eaten is more delightful than to eat more; likewise love is more delightful in dislike than intercourse.
T.Kannan:
More joyous than the meal is its digestion.
So is sulking more joyous than union.
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar: Sweeter than eating is the pause in the process. Likewise misunderstanding by lovers affords more joy than union itself.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
More joyous than the meal is its
digestion. So is sulking more joyous than union.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
Unalinum Untadhu Aralinidhu Kaamam
Punardhalin Ootal Inidhu
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Sweeter than meal is digestion 
And sulk in love than union.

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The yielder wins in lover's pout 
Reunited joy brings it out.
Transliteration:
In lover's quarrels, 'Tis the one that first gives way,
That in re union's joy is seen to win the day.
T.Kannan: Those are conquerors whose dislike has been defeated and that is proved by the love (which follows).
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
In lovers' quarrels the loser wins,
As shown when they make up.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: In a lovers’ quarrel, the vanquished becomes the victor; this is revealed when they reunite.
Ramachandra Dikshitar:
In lovers' quarrels the loser wins, As
shown when they make up.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Ootalil Thotravar Vendraar
Adhumannum
Kootalir Kaanap Patum

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ootip Perukuvam Kollo
Nudhalveyarppak
Kootalil Thondriya Uppu
Transliteration:
Shall not our pouting again give 
The dew browed joy of joint love?
T.Kannan: Will I enjoy once more through her dislike, the pleasure of that love that makes her forehead perspire?
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
And shall we ever more the sweetness know of that embrace
With dewy brow; to which 'feigned anger' lent its piquant grace.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
Will she sulk again to bring back the pleasure
Of that union drenched in sweat?
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Am I likely to gain, after a friendly quarrel, the delight now experienced in the union with her moistened forehead?
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
Will she sulk again to bring back the
pleasure Of that union drenched in sweat?

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
Ootuka Manno Oliyizhai Yaamirappa
Neetuka Manno Iraa
Transliteration:
Sulk on O belle of shining jewels! 
Prolong O night! our delight swells!
T.Kannan:
Let her, whose jewels brightly shine, aversion feign?
That I may still plead on, O night, prolong thy reign!
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
May the bright-jewel sulk,
And may the night be prolonged for me to implore her!
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems: May the bright-jewelled one feign dislike, and may the night be prolonged for me to implore her!
Ramachandra Dikshitar: May the jewelled lady-love go on quarrelling; may also the night be long enough to conciliate her!
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami:
May the bright-jewel sulk, And may the
night be prolonged for me to implore her!

G.U.Pope & Co - Commentary:
The joy of love lies in sulking, for that
joy is realized While embracing in union.
Transliteration:
Ootudhal Kaamaththirku Inpam
Adharkinpam
Kooti Muyangap Perin
T.Kannan:
Bouderie is lovers' delight 
Its delight grows when they unite
Yogi Shuddhananda Bharatiyar:
A 'feigned aversion' coy to pleasure gives a zest;
The pleasure's crowned when breast is clasped to breast.
G.U.Pope & Co - Poems:
The joy of love lies in sulking, for that joy is realized
While embracing in union.
Ramachandra Dikshitar: Dislike adds delight to love; and a hearty embrace (thereafter) will add delight to dislike.
Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami: The delight of love is the lovers’ quarrel; greater delight is the loving reunion.
